2: ābādhā (EI 15), same as bādhā or vādhā; obstacle.
3: abātamāla, abātamālā, Prakrit; meaning doubtful (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 272; ZDMG, Vol. XL, pp. 345-46); explained as a kind of sculptured slab (LL).
4: abdapa (IA 16), the entrance of the sun into the Aries (Meṣa).
8: ābdika-śrāddha (CII 4), an annual rite in honour of a dead person.
9: ābhāvya (EI 11, 16), income or proceeds; cf. rāja-rāja-puruṣ ādibhiḥ svaṃ svam = ābhāvyaṃ parihartavyam; see also rāja-bhāvya, etc. Cf. ‘the income (ābhāvya) derived from the loads on bullocks going on their way or coming to Nāḍlāi’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 36).
10: abhaya (EI 24), pose of hand (mudrā); see abhaya-mudrā. (SITI), place of security to persons in distress; called añjinānpugal-idam in Tamil. Cf. abhaya-śāsana.
11: abhaya-hasta (SII 2), pose of hand known as abhaya-mudrā (q. v.).
12: abhaya-mudrā (HA), pose of hand offering protection, in which the palm of the right hand, facing the devotee, is held with fingers upwards. Cf. abhaya-hasta.
13: abhaya-śāsana (EI 12, 27; SITI), ‘grant of shelter’, ‘charter of security’; a deed offering protection; a grant recording the provision of shelter.
17: abhijñāna (LP), a token by which the identity of a person is recognised.
18: abhikāra, cf. kṛt-ābhikāra (CII 1), probably, one who has committed an offence under the instigation of another.
20: abhinava (EI 5; IA 18), name of a tax; cf. abhinava-mārga-ṇaka-prabhṛti-sarv-ādāyair = upetaḥ, epithet of the gift village. It may also mean ‘new’ and the reference may be to the new mārgaṇaka tax. See abhinava-mārgaṇaka.
21: abhinava-mārgaṇaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 264, note 1), name of a tax. See mārgaṇaka, mārg-ādāya, etc.
23: Ābhīra (IE 8-3), member of the cowherd community.
25: abhiṣeka (EI 4), coronation; cf. abhiṣeka-kkāṇi, abhiṣeka-kkāṇikkai (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; presents offered to the king at the time of his coronation.
26: abhiṣeka-maṇdapa (SITI), a hall where ceremonial baths are taken; the coronation hall; also called tiru-mañjana-śālai and kuḻikkum-iḍam in Tamil.
27: abhiṣeka-nāman (SITI), the name or title assumed by a king at the time of his coronation.
28: abhiṣikta (CII 1), cf. dvādaśa-varṣ-ābhiṣikta, ‘when one has been anointed twelve years’, ‘when twelve years have elapsed from one's coronation’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, pp. 333 ff.
29: abhīṣṭa-devatā (IA 18), same as iṣṭa-devatā; the favourite deity; the tutelary deity.
30: abhisthāna, correctly abhiṣṭhāna; used in the sense of adhiṣṭhāna, ‘the residence’, ‘a city’, or ‘the headquarters’. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 219.
31: Abhitvaramāṇa, Abhitvaramāṇaka (IE 8-3; EI 31; HD), the letter-carrier or a special kind of messenger. Cf Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321 (dūta-praiṣaṇika-gamāgamik-ābhi-tvaramāṇaka); Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., pp. 125-26.
32: ābhoga (IE 8-4), a territorial unit; similar to bhoga; cf. Gorajj-ābhoga.
34: abhyaṅga (IA 22), smearing the body with oil.
35: Ābhyantara (HD), an officer specially intimate or in close contact with the king. Cf. Antaraṅga. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 426. But cf. also Ābhyantarika, Abhyantar-opasthāyaka.
37: ābhyantar-ādāya, cf. bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya (IE 8-5); internal revenue income of a village; probably, taxes payable to the village authorities as against those payable to the king. Cf. antar-āya, abhyantara-siddhi, antaḥ-kara, etc. See bāhya.
38: abhyantara-siddhi, abhyantara-siddhika (IE 8-5; EI 20, 22), same as ābhyantara-siddhi; internal income or revenue, or taxes payable to the village authorities as against those payable to the king; cf. tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya; also sarv-ābhyantara-siddhi (EI 20), and antaḥ-siddhika (CII 4), a privilege of the donee of rent-free land. According to some (CII 4), it refers to the privilege of the donee offering full power of adjudication in law-suits. But expressions like tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi (q. v.) render it doubtful. See bāhya, siddhi, siddh-āya.
39: ābhyantara-siddhi (CII 4), same as abhyantara-siddhi; explained by some as ‘the powers of adjudication’; probably, taxes payable to the village authorities as against those payable to the king. See abhyantara-siddhi, etc.
40: Ābhyantarika (IE 8-3), a guard of the inner apartments of the palace; cf. Ābhyantarikā. See Ābhyantara, Abhyantar-opasthāyaka.
41: Ābhyantarikā, a female guard of the inner apartment of the palace; probably also a concubine (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 3).
48: abhyutthita, cf. abbhuṭṭhio khāmavo (HA), obeisance to one's teacher (i. e. a Jain monk) with formal query about the his health and confession of one's own weakness.
51: Āboṭī (EI 11), an inferior class of Brāhmaṇas in Rajasthan.
52: ā-candr-ārkkam (SITI), ‘so long as the moon and the sun last’; ‘in perpetuity’.
53: acala-pravṛtti (SII 11-1), cf. ‘was administering Pandi-goḻa as acala-pravṛtti’; a kind of tenure; probably, a permanent holding. See vṛtti, the same as pravṛtti.
54: ācāra (IE 8-5; EI 30), a custom or customary law. (EI 20), religious practice, being regarded as five in number. Cf. navanavaty-ācāreṇa (LP), ‘99 per cent’, i. e. ‘cer-tainly’.
55: ācāra-pātra (EI 30), same as sthiti-pātra, ācāra-sthiti-pātra, etc.; a document relating to customary laws.
56: ācāra-sthiti-pātra (IE 8-5), same as ācāra-pātra, etc.; regulation regarding customary laws; cf. sthiti-pātra, a charter relating to customary laws (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169).
57: Ācārya (EI 33; BL), title of a religious teacher; used commonly by the Buddhists and Jains (LL; SII 1). (CII 3; EI 32; ML), a spiritual guide or teacher; a preceptor.
58: Same as Sthān-ācārya (EI 17), a temple priest. (EI 8; IA 14), an architect; used in the sense of ‘a master’, i. e. ‘a master-mason’; cf. Ācāri (EI 17), an artisan. Pāli Ācariya is explained as ‘a master goldsmith’ in the P. T. S. Pāli-Eng. Dict. (LL), title of a sculptor. (HA; IA 19), Jain; a Sādhu who has the right of both reading the sacred texts publicly and explaining them authoritatively.
59: ācāryakula (LL), a Buddhist temple; cf. devakula.
60: ācārya-pīṭha (EI 16), a holy site; a site sanctified by a religious teacher.
62: ācchanna (EI 30), a word of doubtful import.
63: accu (IE 8-8; SITI), Tamil; name of a coin; cf. ānai-accu, nall-ānai-accu, paḻamudal-ānai-accu, paḻañjalāgai-accu, paducca-lāgai-accu, amudan-accu, uṇḍi-accu, etc. Cf. also pañcālav-accu (SITI), name of a coin probably struck by the body called pañcālattār or pañcakarmāra; uṇḍiy-accu (SITI); vaḻudiy-accu-varggam (SITI), a group of taxes payable in Pāṇḍya coins; yakki-accu (SITI), from Sanskrit Yakṣī; name of a coin current in the Koṅgu country. (EI 24), name of a tax.
64: accu-pannāya (EI 16), department of taxation or coining.
65: Accupannāyadadhiṣṭhāyaka (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa; superinten-dent of the revenue from mints; sometimes also called Mahā-sāmantādhipati, Mahāpradhāna, Bhānasavĕrgaḍĕ, etc., additionally.
66: accuvari (SITI), Tamil; probably the same as pŏnvari; the duty payable for minting gold into coins.
67: āchu (CII 4), same as āsu, the name of a coin; cf. Tamil accu.
69: āḍa, aḍḍa (CITD), Telugu; a measure of capacity equal to 2 mānikas or one-eighth of a tūm; half, especially half of a fanam or a certain measure called kuñcamu; a weight represent-ing the eighteenth portion of a varāha (q. v.).
70: ādāna (IE 8-5; EI 12; CII 4), a levy or impost; same as ādāya.
71: āḍāṇaka (LP), same as aḍḍāṇaka; cf. āḍāṇake muktā, mortgaged; valitāya āḍāṇake muktam, Gujarātī vaḻat dāṇ mukyuṃ, ‘something morgaged, the produce of which will pay off the debt in course of time’.
72: ādatta (IE 8-5), adattā (EI 33), ādattā (EI 28), a tax of uncertain import; probably, interest or fine on arrears of tax.
73: ādāya (EI 33), income or impost; cf. bhūta-bhaviṣyad-vartamāna-niḥśeṣ-ādāya-sahita (IE 8-5); cf. also viseṇim-ādāya (EI 21), name of a tax.
75: adbhuta-dharma, cf. abbhuta-dhamma (EI 33), Buddhist. Cf. Childers, Pāli-Eng. Dict., s. v.
76: adbhuta-śānti (EI 33), a ceremony to avert evil.
78: aḍḍaga, aḍduga (CITD), Telugu; half a fanam.
79: aḍḍāṇaka (LP), a morgaged thing; cf. gṛh-āḍḍāṇaka-patra (LP), deed for mortgaging a house.
80: Ādeśakārin (EI 10), an officer or agent, or a representative.
81: Ādeśa-naibandhika (EI 7; CII 4), official designation indicating the recorder of orders.
82: ādeya (EI 7, 12, 15; CII 3), ‘what is to be taken or levied’; a fiscal term meaning the same thing as ādāya, i. e. income or impost; dues (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 237).
83: āḏha (IE 8-6), same as āḍhika or āḍhaka; a measure of capacity; a land measure also called āḍhavāpa.
84: āḏhā (IE 8-6), Bengali form of āḍhaka and āḍhavāpa.
85: adhaḥ, cf. s-ādha-ūrdhva (IE 8-5); what is below the surface of the ground; root-crops.
86: āḍhaka (IE 8-6; EI 27), a measure of capacity; often regarded as equal to 264 handfuls and to one-fourth of a droṇa; 16 to 20 seers according to Bengali authors; also used as a shortened form of āḍhavāpa or ādhakavāpa.
87: ādhāna, cf. dān-ādhāna-vikraya (IE 8-5); mortgaging. Cf. n = ādheyaṃ na ca vikreyam (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 218).
88: ādhavāpa, also called āḍhakavāpa (IE 8-6), ‘an area of land requiring one āḍhaka measure of seed grains for being sown’; a land measure which was not the same in all ages and localities.
89: Adhi (LP), contraction of Adhikārin, regarded by some as ‘a revenue officer like the Māmlatdār’.
90: Adhi, Ādhi (IE 8-1; 8-8), shortened forms of Adhikaraṇika or Ādhikaraṇika.
91: ādhi (SII 2; LP), a mortgage or deposit; ādhau kṛtam, ‘mortgaged’; cf. ādhau muktam, ādhau dattam. Cf. vinaṣṭ-ādhi-sakta (LP), used in connection with a lost thing which had been given in mortgage.
94: adhika-paḍi (CITD), Sanskrit-Telugu; an extra allowance in food (grain, salt, vegetables and all that is required to pre-pare a meal, including firewood), sometimes also in money, granted to servants, friends or poor people.
95: Adhikāra, cf. Tamil Adigāram (EI 25); same as Adhikārin (SII 1), explained as ‘a magistrate’.
97: adhikaraṇa (IE 8-1, 8-8; EI 28), an office; cf. rājakule ='dhi-karaṇasya, apparently referring to an office. See adhikaraṇ-āva-dhāraṇā, ‘official investigation’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 267). (EI 24), a court or department. (EI 30), a law-court. (SITI), a class of law courts; probably, the chief court. (EI 30, 31), an administrative office or a board of administration. (EI 31), a district. (SII 2), same as Adhikārin, a magistrate.
98: adhikaraṇa-daṇḍa (SITI), fine imposed by the adhikaraṇa or law-court.
99: Adhikaraṇa-lekhaka (EI 30), a scribe pertaining to a law-court or office. (HD), the official recorder or scribe [who drew up deeds of sale and the like after having measured the land to be sold]. Cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, VI. 38; Viṣṇu Dh. S., VII, 3.
100: Adhikaraṇika, Ādhikaraṇika (IE 8-1; EI 28), an officer belonging to or in charge of an adhikaraṇa or office.
101: adhikāra-varttanā (SITI), customary payments made to an officer at stipulated periods; probably the same as Sanskrit-Tamil adhikāra-ppeṟu, adhikāra-ppŏn, etc.
102: Adhikārika, Ādhikārika (IE 8-3; EI 2, 23, 28; CII 4; BL; HD), ‘an officer’; same as Adhikārin, Niyogika, Adhyakṣa, etc., regarded as meaning a minister, magistrate, superintendent, governor or director. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 184.
104: Adhikārin (IE 8-3; EI 28; BL), ‘an officer’; same as Ādhikārika; cf. Kannaḍa Vĕrgaḍĕ, etc., and Sanskrit Adhyākṣa, meaning a superintendent, governor or director. (ASLV), explained as ‘a special officer or royal agent’. (EI 7), explained as ‘a minister’. (SII 2), explained as ‘a magistrate’. Cf. Viḍaiy-adhikāri, Viḍaiyil-adhikāri (SITI), an officer issu-ing royal orders.
109: Adhirāja (IE 8-2), sometimes used as an imperial title, but sometimes as the title of a feudatory. Cf. Adhimahārāja. (BL), title of a subordinate ruler. (LL), designation of a supreme king.
110: Adhirājarāja (EI 9), royal title. Cf. Rājarāja, Rājādhirāja, etc.
112: ādhirājya (CII 3), a derivative from the title Adhirāja; supreme sovereignty.
113: adhisthāna, adhiṣṭhāna (CII 1), cf. dharm-ādhisthāna, dharm-ādhiṣṭhāna, ‘the establishment of morality’.
114: adhiṣṭhāna (IE 8-3; EI 24, 28, 31; LL), the capital or headquarters of an administrative unit; a city or town; the chief city. See abhisthāna. (EI 9), probably, residence. (EI 8), same as sthāna. (EI 24), cf. adhiṣṭhānam, ‘under the supervision of’. (SITI), the base of the vimāna in a temple; a seat.
115: adhiṣṭhān-ādhikaraṇa (IE 8-3; EI 23; BL), administrative office or board at the headquarters of a territorial unit; office of the administrators of a city; the city office.
116: Adhiṣṭhāyaka (EI 16), official designation; same as Adhyakṣa (q. v.).
117: adhivāsa, cf. adhivāsa-sakta-cāturvarṇya-samakṣam (LP), ‘in the presence of the people of the four castes living in the vicinity’; cf. adhivāsa-saktīya (LP); neighbours.
118: Adhvapa (EI 20), official designation; same as Mārgapati, etc.
119: Adhyakṣa (EI 24; CII 4), the head of a department; the superintendent of a department; a superintendent or director; sometimes mentioned in the list of officials (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 80). Cf. Mahādhyakṣa. (IA 20), explained as the Dūtaka or Ājñapti, i. e. executor of grants.
120: Adhyakṣa-pracāra (EI 12, 15), a list of superintendents of departments; probably also a notice setting forth the dis-tribution of the Adhyakṣas in various departments and stations.
122: a-dhyātam, ‘without any consideration or hesitation’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 239).
124: Adhyayana-bhaṭṭa (IA 12), assistant officiating priest (also called Sādhācārya) at the temple at Rāmeśvaram.
126: adhyayana-vṛtti (SITI), tax-free land endowed for reciting the Vedas in temples.
129: ādikāra (CII 1), an initiator; one who starts a practice or to do a particular deed.
130: Ādikartṛ (CII 3), ‘an originator’; epithet of the Jain Tīrthaṅkaras.
131: Ādirāja (EI 12), an ancient king, e. g., Bharata, Nala, Nahuṣa, etc.; founder of a royal family (Select Inscriptions, pp. 412, 415).
132: āditya (IE 8-2; EI 33), ending of royal titles like Vikramā-ditya, Kramāditya, Mahendrāditya, etc., probably popularised by the Imperial Guptas in the fourth century A. D. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twelve’.
133: āditya-kāca (EI 32), probably, the jewel called sūryakānta.
134: ādivarāha-dramma (EI 30; CII 4), name of a coin (dramma) styled after Ādivarāha, i. e. Pratīhāra Bhoja I (c. 836-85 A. D.).
136: ādvaliśa (IA 17), or dvaliśa; regarded as a word of doubtful meaning; but really, a geographical name.
137: ādya-māṣa, the original māṣa 5 ratis in weight, later its weight being regarded as 6, 7 or 10 ratis (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 139). See māṣa.
139: āgama (SII 1), a doctrine; cf. Lākul-āgama (EI 32), the doctrine of Lakula (Lakulīśa). Cf. āgama-samaya. Cf. s-āgama-nirgama-praveśa (IE 8-5), ‘together with approaches, ingress and egress’.
140: āgama-nigama-dāna (LP), tax for importing and exporting.
141: agamārga (SITI), a variety of dance performed in the presence of the gods in temples.
142: āgama-samaya, cf. Lākul-āgama-samaya (EI 32), the tenets of Lakula's doctrine.
143: āgāmin (IE 8-5; EI 19; SITI), future income, future bene-fits; one of the 8 kinds of rights in the property; cf. aṣṭa-bhoga.
144: agara (EI 19), a corrupt form of agrahāra, often noticed in Tamil inscriptions.
145: agara-brahmadeya (SITI), village granted to Brāhmaṇas; also called agara (agrahāra) and brahmadeya. See agara.
146: agara-ppaṟṟu (SITI), Tamil; same as agara or agrahāra; land granted to Brāhmaṇas.
147: Agasāli (EI 28), a goldsmith; same as Akṣaśālin.
149: āghāṭana (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 264, text line 42), same as āghāṭa, boundary; see also āghāṭī.
150: āghāṭī (EI 23), same as āghāṭa; boundary; see also āghāṭana.
151: aghoṣa (IE 7-1-2), ‘thirteen’ [being the number of surds in the Sanskrit alphabet].
154: Agnicit (SII 2), title of a Brāhmaṇa. cf. agni-cayana.
155: agnihotra (EI 22; CII 3, 4), offerings to fire; a particular sacrifice, often mentioned as one of the five sacrificial rites (mahāyajña) which are the daily duties of a Brāhmaṇa.
156: Agnihotrin (CII 4), epithet of a Brāhmaṇa performing the agnihotra sacrifice.
158: Agni-kula, ‘a family, the progenitor of which was born from the fire pit of a sage’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 162, for a 12th century ‘Fire family’ in the Nanded District, Maharashtra.
159: agni-kuṇḍa (CII 4), fire-pit; an emblem of the worship of the Fire or Sun.
162: agni-sthitikā, fire-place (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 107).
164: Agnyāhita (EI 15), same as Āhitāgni, ‘a Brāhmaṇa per-petually maintaining and consecrating the sacred fire in his house’.
165: agra (EI 24), same as agra-bhāga; the king's share. (CII 1), cf. anyatra agreṇa parākrameṇa, ‘without a great effort’.
166: agra-bhāga (CII 2-1; ML), the principal share; same as agra, agra-pratyāya, the king's share.
169: agra-dharmarājikā (ML), the chief Dharmarājikā (a stūpa enshrining the relies of the Dharmarāja or Buddha).
170: agahara, agāhara, āgahara (Chamba), corruptions of agrahāra.
171: Agrahara (EI 24), a collector of the king's share. See agra.
172: agrahāra (IE 8-4; EI 30; CII 4; SII 1; HRS; Chamba), rent-free land given to Brāhmaṇas; a rent-free village; a Brāhmaṇa village; sometimes suffixed to names of localities especially in South India. It was primarily, ‘a rent-free village in the possession of Brāhmaṇas’; but there are occasional references to dev-āgrahāra (rent-free holding in the possession of a deity), vaiśy-āgrahāra (rent-free holding in the possession of the Vaiśyas), etc.; sometimes spelt agrāhāra (CII 3). See mah-āgrahāra, brahmapurī, caturvedi-maṅgala, etc.; also aṅga-bhoga.
173: agrahāra-pradey-āṃśa (EI 33), a small rent payable for land granted to Brāhmaṇas and declared rent-free.
174: Agrahārika, Āgrahārika (IE 3-8; EI 23; HD; CII 3; etc.), the owner of an agrahāra; sometimes probably, the superin-tendent of agrahāras; same as Agrahārin. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 127.
175: Agrahārin, Agrahārīṇa (EI 23, 24), the holder of an agrahāra; headman or owner of an agrahāra village. Cf. Agrahārika.
176: Agrahārīṇa-mahattara (EI 24), headman among the Agrahārīṇas, i. e. owners of an agrahāra (rent-free village in the possession of Brāhmaṇas).
178: agraja (EI 23), the elder brother (or cousin); rarely used wrongly in the sense of ‘the eldest son’ (EI 9).
179: agrajanman (EI 9), same as agraja (q. v.); wrongly used to mean ‘the eldest son’ instead of ‘the elder brother’ (cf. agraja). (EI 24), a Brāhmaṇa.
180: Agra-mahādevī (SITI), chief queen of a king.
181: Agra-mahāmahiṣī (IE 8-2), title of a chief queen; cf. Mahiṣī, Agra-mahiṣī, Mahāmahiṣī, Agra-mahādevī.
182: Agra-mahiṣī (IE 8-2; EI 22; LL; ML), designation of the chief queen; cf. Mahiṣī, Agra-mahādevī, etc.
183: agra-maṇḍapa (SITI), front hall of a temple.
184: agra-pra, āda, same as tala-vṛtti (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 166, note 2).
185: agra-pratyaṃśa (EI 23; CII 2-1; ML), principal share; same as agra-bhāga.
186: agra-pratyāya (EI 23), principal share or income; same as agra-bhāga.
188: āgrayaṇa (EI 7), the first Soma libation at the agniṣṭoma sacrifice; oblation consisting of first-fruits at the end of the rainy season.
190: agrika-pāyā (LP), original foundation; cf. Gujarātī pāyā, foundation.
191: Agronomoi (IE 8-3), Greek; probably the same as Rajjuka.
193: Ahaṃvīra, see Amīra. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 178.
194: ahan (CII 3), ‘a day’; used to denote the solar, or more properly civil, day.
195: āhāra (IE 8-4; EI 27; CII 1, 3, 4), a district; cf. āharaṇī. Cf. grām-āhāra (IE 8-4), a group of villages. (IA 17), cf. s-āhāra in Buddhist literature explained as sa-janapada. Āhāra = [land for] food; cf. bhoga.
196: āharaṇī (IE 8-4; EI 16), a district or its subdivision; cf. Hastakavapr-āharaṇī (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 109); also cf. āhāra.
197: āhāra-viṣaya (IE 8-4), originally an āhāra, but later a viṣaya; cf. Kheṭak-āhāra-viṣaya.
200: ahi-daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 12, 28, 33), professional tax levied from snake-charmers or levy for their maintenance.
202: airāvata (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’; sometimes hastin, etc., are used in this sense though they really mean ‘seven’.
205: ājivaka-kāsu (SITI), same as Tamil āśuva-kkāśu, āśuvikaḻ-kāśu, āśuva-kkaḍamai; tax payable by Ājīvakas or for the maintenance of Ājīvaka monks.
206: Ājñā (IE 8-3; EI 27; BL; CII 3), an order or command; same as ājñapti or ājñāpti supposed to be connected with giving the order for the drawing up of a charter; person receiving a king's order regarding the preparation of a charter; usually translated as ‘executor of a grant’; standing alone, the word is supposed to indicate the office of the Dūtaka, though the latter seems to have been additionally responsible for giving the donee the possession of the gift land. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 362 (of the Gaṅga year 149) where the words are ājñā mahāmahattara-Śivarmā; also svayam = ājñā (CII, Vol. III, p. 115; Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 19) taken to mean that the king employed no Dūtaka to convey the details of his grant to the local officers, but that he gave the details in person. The expression sva-mukh-ājñā (literally, the oral order of the king) is also explained in the same way. The suggestion that Ājñādāpaka sometimes occurs as a synonym of Dūtaka is wrong. See Ājñapti, Ājñā-sañcārin, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., pp. 143-44. Cf. Tamil āṇai (EI 23), sign; the insignia.
207: Ājñā-bhogika (EI 21; BL), Ājñā and Bhogika wrongly made into a single official designation. See Ājñā and Bhogika.
208: Ājñā-dāpaka (BL; HD), wrongly taken as a compound expression meaning an officer (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIV, p. 161). See Ājñā and Dāpaka.
209: Ājñādhāraka (ASLV), an executor of the royal order; cf. Ājñā-paripālaka.
210: Ājñā-paripālaka (ASLV), an executor of the royal order; cf. Ājñā-dhāraka.
211: Ājñapti, Ājñāpti (IE 8-3; EI 24, 27, 30; SII 1; HD), ‘the agency that obtains the command’; the executor of a grant; one who communicates, at the order of the king, the details about a land grant to local officers; probably the same as Dūtaka. Cf. Ājñā; also Tamil Vāy-kkeḻvi, Vāy-kkeḻviyār. See Ind. Ep., pp. 143-44; Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 184; Vol. VIII, p. 146. Cf. Ājñā-sañcārin.
214: ājñāta (IA 18), ‘an order’; sañcaritaṃ c = ājñātam, ‘and the command has been communicated or carried into effect.’
216: ākāra (CII 1), same as prakāra, a way or kind.
217: ākarṣaka (EI 5), probably, the extent [of a piece of land].
219: Ākāśamukhin (ASLV), epithet of certain Śaiva ascetics, also called Ākāśavāsin.
220: ākāśa-pātāl-otpatti (EI 30), fruits and roots produced in a piece of land. Cf. ākāś-otpatti.
223: ākāś-otpatti (HRS), ‘produce of the sky’; fruits; wrongly regarded by some as the same as bhūta-vāta-pratyāya (q. v.). See ākāśa-pātāl-otpalli.
224: akhaṇḍa-dīpa (EI 30), a lamp to be perpetually burnt before a deity in a temple, the installation of which was regard-ed as a meritorious act; same as nandā-dīpa, etc.
226: akiñcid-grāhya (HRS), same as akiñcit-kara, ‘free from tax’.
227: akiñcit-kara (HRS), same as akiñcit-grāhya, ‘free from tax’.
228: akkam (SII 3; SITI), Tamil; name of a coin; one-twelfth of a kāśu; a mint (cf. akka-śālā).
229: akka-śālā (SITI), Tamil-Sanskrit; a mint; cf. akkaśālai-vari (SITI), charges payable to the mint for minting coins.
230: akkasālavaru (CITD), cf. Telugu agasāli, akkasāla, akasālĕ; also Kannaḍa agasālavāḍu; a goldsmith or his workshop.
231: Akkasāliga (EI 7), a goldsmith; same as Akṣaśālika.
234: akṣapaṭala (BL), the department of records and accounts. See Akṣapaṭalika, etc. Cf. Mahāsāndhivigrah-ākṣapaṭal-ādhipati.
235: akṣapaṭal-ādāya (IA 18), levy for the maintenance of the akṣapaṭala department or the Paṭvārī. Cf. akṣapaṭala-prastha.
236: Akṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta (CII 3; HD; BL), an officer of the akṣapaṭala department or the officer in charge of it; same as Akṣapaṭalika, etc. See CII, Vol. III, p. 257; Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 301, 397-98.
237: Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati (BL), the head of the akṣapaṭala department; same as Akṣapaṭalin, etc.; also called Akṣapāla (cf. karaṇa).
238: Akṣapaṭal-ādhyakṣa (HD), the superintendent of records and accounts. Cf. Arthaśāstra, II. 7; Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 143.
239: akṣapaṭala-prastha (IA 18; HRS), contributions paid by the villagers at the rate of a prastha of grain (probably, per standard measure) for the expenses of the akṣapaṭala department (probably for the maintenance of the Paṭvārī). Cf. akṣapaṭal-ādāya.
240: Akṣapaṭalika (EI 30; CII 4; HD; BL), same as Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati, officer in charge of accounts and records. Akṣapaṭala means ‘accounts office’ (Stein) or ‘records office’ (Bühler). There is Grām-ākṣapaṭalika in the Harṣacarita (VII, para. 2) probably meaning the Paṭvārī, and a section on the superin-tendent of the akṣapaṭala in the Arthaśāstra (II. 7). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XX, p. 128; Vol. IX, p. 305. Cf. Mahākṣapaṭalika.
241: Ākṣapaṭalika (HD), same as Akṣapaṭalika; officer in charge of the accounts and records office. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. I, pp. 316, 318.
242: Akṣapaṭalin (EI 19; BL), same as Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati, Akṣapaṭalika, etc.
243: akṣara, cf. hast-ākṣarāṇi (LP), a deed for borrowing money; also kṛṣṇ-ākṣarāṇi (LP), the record containing a censure; also ujjval-ākṣarāṇi (LP), a certificate of good conduct; also viśuddh-ākṣarāṇi (LP), an acknowledgement. Cf. uttar-ākṣarāṇi (LP), same as Marāṭhī utarāi; probably, a deed by which land is given at a favourable rent to merchants, etc., who helped the govern-ment with money. Cf. guṇ-ākṣara, also called guṇa-patra; see also gupt-ākṣara.
244: akṣarapalli (IA 11), the system of writing numbers by syllables; name applied to the system of writing numbers as found in inscriptions before the popularisation of the decimal system, though the symbols employed in the Brāhmī inscriptions do not appear to be akṣaras in all cases.
245: Akṣaśālika (EI 29), same as Akṣaśālin, etc.; a goldsmith. (HD), explained as ‘an officer in charge of the gambling-hall’.
246: Akṣaśālin (EI 29; BL), same as Akṣaśālika, etc.; a gold-smith; from Telugu-Kannaḍa Akkasālĕ (EI 3), Agasāli, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 173. (HD), explained as ‘an officer in charge of the gambling hall’.
247: akṣatā (IA 11), probably, rice grains mixed with red powder.
250: Akṣāvāpa (HD), superintendent of gambling. Cf. Hist. Dharm., Vol. II, p. 1216; Vol. III, p. 112.
251: akṣayanī, akṣayaṇī (EI 32), modified forms of akṣaya-nīvī.
253: akṣayanīkā (EI 30), corrupt form of akṣaya-nīvikā, a perpetual endowment.
254: akṣaya-nīvi, akṣaya-nīvī (CII 3, 4; HRS), a permanent endowment.
255: akṣayanīvī-dharma (EI 29), the nature of a permanent endowment; also called akṣayanidhi-dharma (EI 12).
256: akṣaya-nīvikā (EI 24, 30), same as akṣaya-nīvī; a perpetual endowment.
257: akṣaya-pūrṇamāsī (EI 23), probably, the same as Māgha su-di 15.
258: akṣaya-tṛtīyā (EI 4, 23; CII 4; IA 18; BL), same as Vai-śākha su-di 3; see akṣata-tṛtīyā.
260: akṣīṇin (IE 8-5; EI 19; SITI), actual or fixed income; regarded as one of the eight rights of ownership. Cf. aṣṭa-bhoga.
261: akṣoṭa-bhaṅga (HRS), same as khoṭa-bhaṅga and ukkoṭa-bhaṅga (Abhidhānarājendra, s. v. parihāra). Cf. utkoṭa and bhaṅga.
262: aḻag-accu (SITI), Tamil; name of a coin.
265: alavaṇa (IA 19), probably a Sanskritised form of aṟuvaṇa (q. v.).
266: ālaya, cf. ālai (SII 3), a temple; a contraction of dev-ālaya. Cf. āyatana, bhavana, pura, etc.
267: ālepana (SITI), anointing; coating the image with unguent.
268: āli (Chamba), wet land, irrigable land; also called kohlī.
269: alinī (EI 26), ‘a swarm of bees’; female Jain devotees.
270: alīpaka, also read as alīyaka (EI 32), a fiscal expression of uncertain import; see nidhān-ālīpaka. The word alipaka means ‘a bee’. Thus ālipaka may refer to the right over wax, bee-hives, and honey. Alīyaka, from ali, ‘a bee’, would mean the same thing.
271: Aḻiya (EI 15), an official title. Cf. alīpaka.
274: alpa-bhāṇḍatā (CII 1), moderation in the hoarding of wealth.
275: alpam-irai (SITI) Sanskrit-Tamil; a minor tax payable in grains.
277: Amaca (HD), Prakrit Amacca = Sanskrit Amātya (q. v.). Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol VIII, pp. 71, 73.
278: amalasāraka (CII 4), the circular fluted disc on the spire of a temple.
280: amānta (CII 3), the technical name for the scheme of the lunar months in Southern India, according to which a month ends with the new-moon day, and the bright fortnight precedes the dark. According to Fleet, it is always this arrangement that is taken for calculation in astronomical works, though, even in Southern India, the arrangement was not applied to the Śaka years, for the civil reckoning, till between 804 and 866 A. D.; on the other hand, according to him, even in Northern India, this arrangement was used in Nepal with the years of the Newār era, though it was abandoned there when the Newār era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern variety. For its prevalence in Indonesia, see Sel. Ins., p. 470.
281: amara (IE 7-1-2), ‘thirtythree’ [being the original number of the gods]. (SITI; ASLV), land or revenue granted by a ruler to his retainers for military service; land assigned to military officers who were entitled to collect only certain revenues with the obligation to raise a contingent of army ready for service when-ever called upon and also to pay tribute to the king; same as amara-māgaṇi. Cf. Amara-nāyaka.
282: amara-māgaṇi (SITI; ASLV), same as amara; estate given to an Amara-nāyaka.
283: Amara-nāyaka (EI 16; SITI; ASLV), a retainer chief enjoying amara, i. e. land or its revenue, for military service to be rendered to his master.
284: amāri-rūḍhi (EI 11), Jain; an edict for the non-slaughter [of animals].
285: Amātya (IE 8-3; EI 28, 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD; LL), a minister; sometimes, officer in charge of a district; explained as deś-ādi-kārya-nirvāhaka; in some cases, called Sarvādhikārin, etc., additionally. Cf. Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 114, note 150. See Mahāmātya.
287: amāvāsyā, cf. ṣaṣṭhī amāvāsyā, caturthī-amāvāsyā, nava rātri-amāvāsyā, mahānavamī-amāvāsyā, etc.
292: ambikā-janika (CII 1), ‘mothers and wives’; women in general.
295: aṃhati, also spelt aṃhiti (EI 4), a gift.
296: āmi (EI 28), same as Arabic amīn; an officer of the revenue or judicial department.
297: Amīra (IA 11), Indianised form of Arabic Amīr; often found in the form Hammīra in Indian records and rarely as Hambīra, Haṃvīra and Ahaṃvīra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 178).
298: amma (EI 24), literally ‘the mother’; a village goddess.
299: Ammanagandhavāraṇa (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; ‘the musk-elephant of the father’; subordinate title; also found in the form Appanagandhavāraṇa.
300: āmnāta (EI 12), cf. śrī-Mālava-gaṇ-āmnāte praśaste Kṛta-saṃjñite; explained as ‘authoritatively laid down’ or ‘constantly used’; cf. sthiti.
301: āmnāya (CII 4), a Jain sub-sect. (IA 20), same as kula or kula-krama; generations, succes-sions.
302: āmra-pipīlikā, cf. aṃbā-kapīlikā (EI 2; CII 1), usually interpreted as ‘the mother-ant’; but really, big red ants generally living in large numbers on mango trees. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, pp. 99-100.
304: amṛta-gaṇa (SII 12), same as Tamil amirta-gaṇattār (SITI), members of the committee for the management of village affairs; members in charge of the cash-receipts of a temple.
305: amṛta-paḍi, cf. Tamil amuda-ppaḍi (SII 1; SITI), raw rice; food offering to a deity; (CITD), paḍi is an allowance in food (i. e. all the necessary commodities to prepare a meal) and some-times also in money and amuda-paḍi is an endowment often made in favour of a deity for daily offering of food as bhoga, etc.
306: amṛta-yoga (EI 9), a particular time regarded as auspicious.
307: aṃśa, a small territorial unit (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 297, text line 26).
308: Aṃśa-bṛhadbhogika (IE 8-3; EI 28), probably, the share-holder of a big jāgīr. See Bhāgika.
309: aṃśa-gaṇa (EI 33); a class of metres; cf. mātrā-gaṇa.
310: Aṃśapati (EI 30), co-sharer of a gift land.
311: aṃśuka-bhāṇḍāra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of clothes.
312: amukāka-sakta (LP), ‘belonging to a certain man’, sakta being often used for satka.
313: anācchedya (IE 8-5), ‘uncurtailable’; ‘not to be resumed’; epithet of gift land. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 267, note 4.
314: anādeśya (EI 12), ‘not to be pointed out (or, ordered)’; epithet of gift land; same as anirdeśya.
317: anaka, anikā (EI 20), Prakrit suffixes to male and female names respectively, known from early South Indian inscrip-tions; same as annaka, annikā.
324: anāsedhya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 267, note 4), free from legal restraints (e. g. kāl-āsedha, ‘limitation of time’; sthān-āsedha ‘confinement to a place’; pravās-āsedha, ‘prohibition of removal or departure’; and karm-āsedha ‘restriction from employment’); epithet of gift land.
325: anātha-saṃrakṣaṇa (EI 23), ‘protection of the helpless’, mentioned as the purpose of a donation.
326: āṇatti (SITI), Tamil; Sanskrit ājñapti; an executor of order; royal order.
327: anāvāsa (CII 1), ‘habitation which is quite unsuitable for one’.
328: andhāruvā, āndhāruvā (IE 8-5; EI 12), variant readings of arthāruvā or ārthāruvā (q. v.); Oḏiyā name of a tax.
329: Āndhra-daṇḍa (IE 8-5), a tax; cf. Turuṣka-daṇḍa and Tiguḻa-daṇḍa. There is also reference to ‘an assembly of Āndhra-daṇḍa’, the meaning of which is doubtful unless daṇḍa is taken here in the sense of ‘an army’.
330: aṇḍikā, weight equal to (1/4) of a māṣa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48); same as the copper paṇa (ibid., Vol. II, p. 7); also called dhānaka and regarded as equal to 4 kārṣāpaṇas or to (1/12)th suvarṇa (ibid., p. 8).
332: Anĕsāhiṇi-vĕrgaḍa (A. R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 12), Kannaḍa; official designation; same as Sanskrit Gaja-sādhanik-ādhyakṣa.
333: aṅga (IE 7-1-2), ‘six’. (EI 15), an abbreviation of aṅga-bhoga; cf. gātra (IA 11).
334: aṅga-bhoga (EI 17; CITD), often associated with raṅga-bhoga as aṅga-raṅga-bhoga, usually explained as ‘decora-tions and illuminations of a deity’. That aṅga-bhoga means decoration of the image of a deity is clear from the fact that a queen is known to have received a village as an agrahāra for her aṅga-bhoga, i. e. as her pin-money (Bomb. Gaz., Vol. I, Part ii, p. 448). Sometimes the land granted for the aṅga-bhoga of a deity came to be known as the deity's aṅga-bhoga (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 182); cf. aṅga, same as gātra (IA 11).
335: aṅgaḍa-siddhāya (CITD), Telugu-Sanskrit; fixed revenue from shops.
336: aṅga-devatā (SITI), attendant deity of a superior god; same as parivāra-devatā.
337: Aṅgaja (EI 16), same as the god Kāma.
338: aṅga-maṇi (SITI), property owned by a woman; cf. aṅga-maṇi-dravya (SITI), dowry.
339: Aṅga-nigūhaka (BL), an official designation of uncertain import; probably, a kind of spies.
340: aṅgāra, aṅgāraka, cf. a-carm-āṅgāraka (IE 8-5; EI 15); charcoal for cooking, which the villagers were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers.
341: aṅga-racanā (HA), adorning of the various limbs of an image of the Jina with marks of sandal paste or leaves of gold, silver, etc., and with additional ornaments.
344: Aṅgarakṣa, Aṅgarakṣaka (IE 8-3; EI 15, 29; SITI), body-guard; the king's body-guard, or the head of the body guards.
345: aṅga-raṅga-bhoga (EI 23; SII 1), decorations and illumi-nations of a deity; various kinds of enjoyment provided for a deity; sometimes explained as ‘worship to include all kinds of enjoyments’ (SITI). Cf. aṅga-bhoga-raṅga-bhoga, raṅg-āṅga-bhoga, etc.
346: aṅga-raṅga-bhoga-vaibhava (EI 3; SII 1; SITI), enjoyments of all kinds provided for a deity; same as aṅga-raṅga-bhoga.
347: aṅga-raṅga-vaibhoga (EI 3; SII 1; SITI), same as aṅga-raṅga-bhoga, i. e. aṅga-bhoga and raṅga-bhoga.
349: Aṅga-vaidya (SITI), same as Tamil Aṅga-vavicciyar; a physician.
350: Āṅgīkaraṇika (IE 8-3), officer in charge of administering oaths in a court of law.
351: aṅgula, aṅguli (IE 8-6), a linear measure equal to the breadth of the middle finger.
353: Aniketŏs (IE 8-2), Greek; royal title; ‘unopposed’; translated into Prakrit as Apadihata (Sanskrit Apratihata).
354: animeṣ-ānokaha (EI 4), same as sura-druma, i. e. kalpa-vṛkṣa.
355: Anivartaka-nivartayitṛ (CII 4), ‘repeller of the unrepellable’; title of a ruler.
358: aniyukta (IA 9), cf. niyukt-āniyukta-rājapuruṣa; probably refers to officials of the king, who were not actually appointed by the government, but occupied posts by virtue of heredity or election.
359: añjaṣṭa-sabhā, añjaṣṭa-śattu-sabhai (SITI), Tamil-Sanskrit; village committee of five or eight members. Cf. pañca-kula and aṣṭa-kula.
360: añjuvaṇṇam (SITI; EI 35), Tamil; Sanskrit pañca-varṇa; the five artisan classes; called hañjamāna in Kannaḍa inscriptions; sometimes regarded as a form of Persian anjuman.
361: aṅka (IA 19), a name, appellation or biruda. (IE 7-1-12; CII 4), ‘nine’. Cf. aṅke, aṅkena, aṅkataḥ (IA 15), ‘in figures’. Cf. aṅka, abbreviation of Telugu-Kannaḍa aṅkakāṟa; same as Sanskrit gaṇḍa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 270), ‘a hero, champion or warrior’. See aṅkakāra.
362: aṅka-daṇḍa-khaṇḍana, translated as ‘faults, fines and divisions’; cf. pañch-āṅga-prasāda.
363: aṅkakāra (EI 3, 4), a champion; same as Telugu-Kannaḍa aṅkakāṟa, sometimes explained as ‘a soldier or warrior who took a vow to defend his master and fight in the latter's cause to death’ (Hyderabad Archaeological Series, No. 18, p. 34). See aṅka.
364: aṅka-śālā (SITI), probably, the place where duels were fought; cf. aṅga-śālā.
365: anna, Anglicised form of āṇaka; (1/16)th of a rupee (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 142).
367: Aṇṇanasiṃha (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa; ‘the lion of the brother’; a subordinate title. Cf. Ayyanasiṃha.
368: anta (IE 8-4; CII 1), a state beyond the borders of one's territories, or a bordering district; also its people; cf. pratyanta. (CII 1), cf. Anta-mahāmātra, officer employed in districts bordering on the frontiers of one's kingdom. (EI 3), a neighbour.
369: antaḥ-kara (CII 4), explained as ‘excise duty’; probably, ‘internal revenue’ or revenue income; same as antar-āya, antar-ādāya, abhyantar-ādāya, etc.; cf. antaḥ-kara-viṣṭika (EI 6), antara (EI 15), etc.
370: Antaḥ-pratīhāra (IE 8-3), officer in charge of defending the back gate of the palace or of the palace-gates as distinguished from the gates of the capital city.
371: antaḥpura, cf. karaṇa (LP); the royal harem. (ML), the household; same as avarodhana in Aśoka's edicts.
372: Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa (IE 8-3; EI 13; SII 11-2), superinten-dent of the royal harem; same as Āntaḥpurika, Stryadhyakṣa, etc., and Sanskrit-Kannaḍa Antaḥpura-vĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3); sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Mahāpasāyita, Hĕri-Lāḻa-Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin, Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ, etc., additionally.
373: Āntaḥpurika (EI 13, 14, 18, 19, 23; HD), officer in charge of the royal harem; cf. Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305.
374: Antaḥpura-mahāmātra (HD), officer in charge of the royal harem, mentioned in the Masulipatam plates of Amma II (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 276). Cf. Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra of Rock Edict XII of Aśoka (CII 1).
376: Anta mahāmātra (IE 8-3; CII 1), executive officers in charge of the bordering districts of an empire and probably not ambassadors at the courts of neighbouring kings. Cf. Antapāla.
377: Antapāla (EI 9), frontier guard; explained by some as ‘an officer in charge of the boundaries’ (HD). Cf. Arthaśāstra, I. 12 (one of the 18 tīrthas); II. 21; V, 1; Kāmandaka, XII. 5; Mālavikāgnimitra, Act. I. See Anta-mahāmātra.
378: antara (CII 1), a period of time. (EI 15), name of a tax; cf. antar-ādāya, antaḥ-kara, etc.
380: antar-ādāya (CII 4), explained as ‘excise duty’; but same as antaḥ-kara, abhyantar-ādāya, etc.
381: antarāla (EI 1), part of a temple; cf. antarāla-maṇḍapa.
382: antarāla-maṇḍapa (SITI), portion of a temple connecting the garbha-gṛha and the mukha-maṇḍapa; also called ardha-maṇḍapa.
383: Antaraṅga (IE 8-3; BL), explained as ‘a privy councillor or a physician’, though the same person is known to be called Rāja-vaidya (i. e. the royal physician) and Antaraṅga; probably a private secretary; but mentioned along with Vaiśvāsika (EI 3); regarded by some as a class of royal servants very intimate with the king, probably the same as Ābhyantara (HD). Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 286; Vol. XII, p. 99.
384: āntarāvaḍḍi (IE 8-5; EI 12; 33), a variant reading of āturāvaḍḍi (q. v.); name of a tax; cf. rintakābaḍḍi.
385: antara-viniyoga (SITI), individual share to make up the shortage in the total revenue occasioned by the grant of exemp-tion of antar-āya or uḻvari.
386: antar-āya (EI 22, 23; SII 1, 2), explained as ‘a tax’, ‘revenue’ or ‘a kind of revenue’; same as antar-ādāya; also explained as internal revenue or taxes levied by local bodies, called uḻvari in Tamil (SITI).
387: antarāya-kkāśu, antarāya-ppāṭṭam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; explained as ‘internal taxes or minor taxes like the profession tax, etc., payable to the village assembly’.
388: antarikā (CII 1), a period of time passed.
391: Antarvaṃśika (HD), officer in charge of the inner apart-ments or harem. See Arthaśāstra, I. 12 (mentioned among the 18 tīrthas); Kādambarī (para. 88); Daśakumāracarita, III; cf. Antarveśika in the Amarakośa, Kṣatriya-varga, 8.
394: anubandha (CII 1), same as krama, order. (SITI), help.
395: anubhavana (IA 18), ‘the time or period of office [of a person]’.
396: anubhoga-ppaṟṟ-ŏl13ugu (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; renewal of title deeds.
398: anudhyai (IE 8-2), ‘to meditate’, etc.; ‘to favour’, etc.; cf. anudhyāya (IE 8-2), ‘having favoured’; also Svāmi-Mahāsena-Mātṛgaṇ-ānudhyāt-ābhiṣikta (IE 8-2), ‘favoured and anointed [as king] by the lord Mahāsena and the Mothers’; also anudadhyuḥ (IE 8-2), same as anujagṛhuḥ, ‘[they] favoured’. See anudhyāna; also pād-ānudhyāta.
400: anudhyāna-rata (IE 8-2), see pād-ānudhyāna-rata, ‘engaged in meditating on the feet of’.
402: anudhyeya (IE 8-2), same as anugrāhya; ‘to be favoured’.
405: anuga-jīvita, spelt in Kannaḍa as aṇuga-jīvita or aṇuṃga-jīvita (SII 11-1), a fief held by a king's subordinate for his main-tenance; similar to bīḻa-vṛtti, bīḻ-ānuvṛtti.
407: anugraha-sthiti-pātra (IE 8-5), same as sthiti-pātra or ācāra-sthiti-pātra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169).
408: anugrāhya (IE 8-2), same as anudhyeya, ‘to be favoured’.
409: anuja (Ep. Ind., Vol XXXIII, p. 271), a younger cousin.
410: anuloma (CII 4), name of a kind of marriage, in which the bride belongs to a lower social order than the bridegroom.
411: anunidhyāpti, cf. anunijhapayati (CII 1); explanation or exhortation; cf. nidhyāpti.
412: anupratipatti, cf. dharm-ānupratipatti (CII 1), practice of morality.
413: anupūrvī, cf. saṃvatsaraḥ dvitīyaḥ hemanta-pakṣaḥ caturthaḥ lithir = daśamī anay = ānupūrvyā. Cf. pūrvā.
416: anusandhāna, recitation (A. R. Ep., 1959-60, No. B. 335).
418: anuśāsana, anuśāsanā (CII 1), same as anuśasti, inculcation.
419: anuśasti (CII 1), inculcation, instruction; same as anuśāsana.
420: Anusenāpati (EI 18), probably, a subordinate of the Senāpati (q. v.).
423: Anutpanna-dāna-samudgrāhaka, an official title (Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 221-22); officer engaged in the forcible collection of unrealised dāna (q. v.).
425: anuvah, cf. anuvahamānaka (EI 15), literally, ‘flowing on’; but actually, ‘ever-prospering’.
426: anuvarttanā (SITI), a class of contingent dues which come under the head varttanā (q. v.).
428: anuvṛtti, same as vṛtti; cf. bīḻa-vṛtti, bīḻ-ānuvṛtti (SII 11-1).
429: anvaya (EI 33; SII 1), a [spiritual] race; a Jain sect.
430: anya-jāta (HRS), accidental revenue; one of the three kinds of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra.
435: apacāra (IE 8-5), same as aparādha; cf. daś-āpacāra (EI 15), same as daś-āparādha.
436: apadāna, cf. dharm-āpadāna (CII 1); a noble deed.
440: āpāna (EI 2; CII 1), a watering station or shed.
442: apara-pakṣa (IA 16), used to indicate ‘the dark fortnight’.
444: aparipanthya (IE 8-5), ‘not to be troubled’; an epithet of gift land.
445: apasaraka (EI 1), probably, a porch or portico.
447: apavāha (CII 1), the act of carrying away [as a prisoner].
448: apavaraka, cf. Prakrit avaraka (EI 20; LL), a cell.
450: apohana (SITI), waste or uncultivated; cf. Tamil agovana, waste land.
452: apradā (EI 15) ‘[gift land] not to be alienated’; same as nīvī; sometimes used as an epithet of akṣaya-nīvī
453: apradā-dharma (EI 15), custom regarding inalienable gift land; same as nīvī-dharma.
457: apratikara (HRS), explained as ‘without the right of alienation’; ‘without yield of revenue’; but cf. pratikara.
459: Apratyagrāja, ‘having no rival among kings’; feudatory title.
462: apūrva, cf. apūrva-Brāhmaṇa (IA 18), a new Brāhmaṇa who was not fed on a previous occasion and is not to be fed again.
463: apūrvin, apūri (SITI), a Brāhmaṇa well-versed in the Vedas on a visit to holy shrines.
464: aputra-dhana (IE 8-5; EI 25; CII 4), confiscation of the property of one dying without leaving a son or an heir.
465: aputrikā-dhana (EI 3; CII 4; HRS), same as aputra-dhana; the property of persons who died sonless, which the king could confiscate; escheat of the property of females.
467: ārādh (CII 1), ‘to attain’; cf. svargam = ārādhayantu; also ārāddha (CII 1), ‘obtained’.
468: Ārādhya (EI 15), ‘the worshipful one’; title of certain Śaivite Brāhmaṇas of Karṇāṭaka.
469: araghaṭṭa (EI 10, 14, 22), a water-drawing machine; a well with a water-wheel.
470: Ārakṣ-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3); cf. Prakrit Ārakh-ādhikata (EI 2), a police officer; a magistrate looking after the maintenance of law and order, or the chief of the king's body-guards; same as Ārakṣika.
471: Ārakṣika (EI 10), cf. Prakrit Ārakhiya (EI 2), a police officer; same as Arakṣ-ādhikṛta, and also Talāra (q. v.) and Daṇḍapāśika (q. v.); cf. IHQ, December 1960, p. 266.
472: ārāma (LL), a park. (ML), a grove or monastery.
476: ārati, ārti (EI 1), a lamp; same as ārātrika.
477: ārātrika (SII 1), same as nīrājana; cf. maṅgal-ārātrika (EI 4), ‘a lamp used in waving before an idol’; also the rite.
478: ārcā (EI 24), the image of a god; cf. arcā, adoration.
480: arcanā-bhoga (EI 23), offerings to be made to a deity at the time of worship. (SII 3, 12; SITI), land set apart for meeting the expenses of worship (arcanā) in the temple; an endowment created for conducting worship; same as arcanā-vṛtti.
481: arcanā-vibhava-kāṇi (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; rent-free land granted to temple priests.
483: ardha-candra (SITI), literally, ‘half-moon’; a part of the tiruvāśi; a variety of ornament. (SII 2), the arch of an aureola.
484: ardha-jā(yā)ma (SII 13), midnight; midnight service in a temple; cf. ardhajāma-ppuṟam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; land set apart for conducting the midnight worship in temples.
485: ardha-kākiṇī (CII 4), the half of a kākiṇī; name of a coin.
486: ardha-namasya-vṛtti (IE 8-5); see namasya-vṛtti; a gift land, taxed at half of the normal rate; cf. pannāsa.
487: Ardhanārīśvara (CII 4), a form of Śiva, in which the bodies of Śiva and Pārvatī are combined into one.
488: Ardha-nauvāṭaka (EI 28), official designation; mention-ed together with Nauvāḷaka probably in the sense of an officer in command of half of a fleet.
492: ardha-srotikā (EI 4), probably, a small stream or half of a river bed.
494: ārdhika (EI 9), a cultivator who tills other's lands and gets half the crop as his share. Cf. Prakrit addhika (EI 1), a slave.
495: ardhodaya (EI 5), the new-moon tithi falling on a Sunday when, during day time, the nakṣatra is Śravaṇā and the yoga Vyatīpāta.
496: ārdrā (SITI), Tamil ātrai; probably, the expenses for the ārdrā festival in the month of Mārgaḻi.
497: argala (IA 19), a check; used in certain dates and translated as ‘checked by’; cf. dvy-argala-catvāriṃśat-samadhika-vatsara-sahasra, ‘one thousand years, increased by forty [which have run into and are] checked by two’, i. e. the year 1042.
498: argha-vañcana (EI 30), probably, fraud committed in respect of the price of articles.
499: Arhad-ācārya (EI 29), a Buddhist or Jain teacher.
501: Arhad-dāsa, a Jain monk; cf. Arhad-dāsī.
503: Arhat (EI 7-1-2), ‘twentyfour’. (CII 3; LL), Buddhist and Jain; a class of saints.
505: ari-ṣaḍ-varga, also called ari-ṣaṭka (CII 3), the group of six enemies, viz. kāma, krodha, lobha, etc.
507: Arka (IE 7-1-2; EI 25), ‘twelve’. (EI 7), explained as ‘metal’ in relation to Arkaśālika.
508: Arkaśālika (EI 7), same as Akkasāliga, Akṣośālika; a goldsmith.
509: Arkaśālin (BL), same as Akṣaśālin; a goldsmith.
510: Arkasālin (EI 29), same as Akṣaśālin; a goldsmith.
512: arṇikā, weight equal to 2 māṣas (JNSI, Vol. VI, p. 46).
514: ārogya-śālā (EI 24; ASLV), hospital; cf. Raṅgādhip-ārogyaśālā (EI 24), ‘the hospital of [the god] Raṅganātha [at Śrīraṅgam]’.
515: Ārohaka (EI 27), official designation; possibly, same as Aśvāroha.
516: artha (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’, (CII 1), a cause or matter. (CII 1), business.
520: arthāruvā (IE 8-5; EI 28), a tax of uncertain import; probably, Sanskrit artha-rūpyaka in the sense of a levy from the money-lenders on the amounts loaned out; also read as andhā-ruvā; see pratyarthāruvā.
521: artiga, a lover (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 58).
522: aruhaṇa (EI 27), probably, the tax also called āruvaṇa.
523: āruvaṇa (EI 27), same as Tamil aṟuvaṇa (IA 19), the tax of six paṇas levied on mānya lands.
525: ārya, cf. Tamil ayyar (EI 25), the father. Cf. bhadatasa aya-Isipālitasa, ‘of the Reverend Lord Ṛṣipālita’ (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 29). (SII 1), a [Jain] saint.
527: ārya-guru, cf. ajja-guru (EI 5), ‘a grandfather preceptor’; preceptor's preceptor.
528: āryaka, Prakrit ajjaka, ayyaka (EI 20, 28; CII 3; IA 15), the grandfather; father's father. Cf. prārya, āryikā. Cf. Prakrit ajjaka (EI 24), an ascetic.
529: āryakā, cf. Prakrit ajjakā (EI 24), Sanskrit āryikā; a female ascetic of the Jain order.
530: Ārya-putra, Prakrit Aya-puta (IE 8-2; EI 3; HD), probably, title of a son of the ruling king. Cf. CII, Vol. I, p. 175.
531: ārya-saṃgha (CII 3), ‘the community of the faithful (i. e. the Buddhist monks)’.
532: ārya-satya, cf. Pali ariya-sacca (EI 5), Buddhist; four in number.
533: āryikā, cf. Prakrit āyikā (EI 20, 28), the grandmother; ‘father's mother’; mentioned side by side with mahāmātṛkā, ‘mother's mother’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 225).
537: āsana (IE 8-8), a seat. Cf. a-cār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra (IE 8-5; EI 15), probably, camping [of the royal officers in a village]; āsana-carma is sometimes taken as one expression meaning ‘a hide seat’.
538: āsana-paṭṭa (EI 23, 24), a seat; a slab used as a seat.
540: ā-ṣāṇmāsika (CII 1), ‘less than six months in age’.
541: Āśāpāla (HD), ‘the guardian of the quarters’; a chief ruling over 10,000 villages, according to the Śukranītisāra, I. 192.
543: Āsedhabhaṅg-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; EI 31), a police officer to check people's escape from prison or legal restraint.
545: aśeṣa-vidya (SII 1), belonging to all the branches of sacred studies.
548: āsīhāra, cf. udak-āsīhāra-kullaka; probably, a kind of channel.
549: āsīna (JAHRS, Vol. IX, Part i, p. 31, text line 12), literally ‘seated’; downcast, dejected. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, pp. 264-65.
552: āśrama (EI 13) a stage of life; a religious establishment (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 67); cf. Caṇḍik-āśrama-guru (IA 11), ‘the Superior of the hermitage of Caṇḍikā’. (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’.
553: āśraya (IA 20), subdivision of a viṣaya. Cf. āśiriyam, āśiriya-kkal, āśiriya-ppramāṇam (SITI), a document by which a person submits to another's protection.
554: Assamese, same as Asamīyā; language and alphabet of Assam, the alphabet being sometimes called Bengali-Assamese.
555: aṣṭa, cf. aṣṭa-bhoga, probably ‘all kinds of enjoyment’ (and not merely ‘eight’ kinds) ensuring tejaḥ-svāmya or owner-ship endowed with complete authority. Cf. aṣṭādaśa, etc.
556: āṣṭa-bhāgika (CII 1), ‘[a village] paying one-eighth of the produce [instead of the usual rate of one-sixth or so]’.
557: aṣṭa-bhoga (IE 8-5; EI 14, 17), privileges of the donee of a rent-free holding, believed to be grouped into eight classes which are sometimes enumerated as nidhi, nikṣepa, jala, pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha and sādhya. Cf. aiśvary-āṣṭaka and aṣṭa-bhūti (EI 33); also aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya. (CITD), the eight privileges associated with the enjoy-ment of rent-free land, also enumerated as (1) nidhi (a treasure or a hoard, i. e. a natural hoard such as a mine), (2) nikṣepa (a treasure hidden or stored up by some one), (3) akṣīṇa (permanent or lasting benefits), (4) āgāmin (future benefits); (5) sañcita (benefits already stored up), (6) jala (waters); (7) taru (trees) and (8) pāṣāṇa (stones). See JAHRS, Vol. X, p. 124. Pāṣāṇa seems to mean ‘hilly area’. (SITI), eight kinds of rights in enjoying landed property; mentioned sometimes as vikraya, dāna, vinimaya, jala, taru, pāṣāṇa, nidhi and nikṣepa, and also as nidhi, nikṣepa, jalāmṛta, pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha and sādhya.
558: aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya (IA 8), unbridled ownership endowed with all the rights associated with the enjoyment of property; translated as ‘with the eight rights of full possession’ though aṣṭa probably means ‘all’ and not merely ‘eight’ (cf. aṣṭādaśa, etc.); cf. aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmyaṃ ca krayeṇ = ādāya (EI 23), ‘having secured the aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya rights by pur-chase’; (IA 19), translated as ‘the proprietorship of all the glory of the aṣṭa-bhoga’, and aṣṭa-bhoga explained as ‘the deposits of buried treasure (nidhi-nikṣepa), water, stones, the akṣīṇī, that which may accrue, that which has been made property, that which may be made property, and augmen-tation’. But there is probably no justification for taking nidhi-nikṣepa as a single unit. Cf. aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmya-daṇḍaśulka-yukta (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 102), mentioned along with nidhi-nikṣepa-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣ-prakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita. The separate mention of these two groups shows that aṣṭa-bhoga vaguely indicated all kinds of proprietary rights.
560: aṣṭādaśa, cf. aṣṭādaśa-jāti-parihāra (IE 8-5); literally, ‘eighteen’; actually, ‘all’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 115). Cf. Oḏiyā aṭhara-gaḍajāta (EI 26). See aṣṭa, ṣaṭtriṃśat, ṣaṭpañcāśat, bāhattara, etc.
561: aṣṭādaśa-doṣa (SII 1), the eighteen or all sins.
562: aṣṭādaśa-jāti (CITD), same as aṣṭādaśa-prajā; the 18 castes. Kittel enumerates the 18 castes of the Kannaḍa-speaking area as the Brāhmaṇa, Kṣatriya, Vaiśya, Liṅgavanta, Baṇajige, Gaṅgaḍikāra-vokkaliga, Maḍivāli, Kelasiga, Kuṟuba, Kumbāṟa, Kaṭuka, Baḍagi, Akkasālĕ, Toreya, Uppāra, Besta, Holeya and Mādiga. But really the number 18 means ‘all’ in such cases. The number 36 has the same meaning in the Bengali expression chatriś-jāti, ‘36 castes’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 115.
564: aṣṭādaśa-prakṛti, cf. s-āṣtādaśa-prakṛty = opeta (EI 2); all classes of tenants; tenants belonging to all communities. (IA 17), ‘the eighteen (i. e. all) officials (i. e. classes of officials)’.
565: aṣṭa-diggaja (EI 33), eight poets at king Kṛsṇadevarāya's court at Vijayanagara.
567: āṣṭ-āhikā (EI 8), Jain festival; same as aṣṭ-āhnika (q. v.).
568: aṣṭ-āhnika, aṣṭ-āhnikā (EI 8, 33), Jain festival held in the months of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika; also called aṣṭ-āhnika-parvan; same as aṭṭhāi-mahotsava. See the Halsi plates of Kadamba Ravivarman (c. 490-538 A. D.) in Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, pp. 25-26. Cf The Successors of the Sātavāhanas, p. 271; Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 47 and note; cf. p. xvi.
569: aṣṭaka (EI 7), same as ba-di 8; worship of the manes with oblations to them. Cf. aṭṭagam (SII 13), division of land, and aṭṭagattār (SII 13), share-holders in a land. See dvādaśaka.
570: aṣṭa-kula, cf. Tamil ūr-ĕṭṭu (SITI); the committee of eight members of the village assembly (ūr); taxes payable for the expenses of the committee (cf. eṇ-per-āyam which may also refer to the eight major items of revenue). See añjaṣṭa-sabhā. Cf. aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa (IE 8-3; EI 31), an administrative board (like the Pañcāyat) consisting of eight (or more) members representing various classes or communities of people; cf. grām-āṣṭa-kul-ādhikaraṇa; mahattar-ādy-aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.
571: aṣṭamī-pakṣa (CII 1), used to indicate pakṣ-āṣṭamī, i. e. the eighth tithi of each fortnight.
572: astamba, cf. samudaya-bāhy-ādy-astamba (EI 23), ‘land originally devoid of vegetation which does not yield any revenue to the State’.
574: aṣṭāṅga (CITD), the eight constituents of yoga consisting of (1) niyama (restraint of the mind), (2) āsana (a parti-cular posture or mode of sitting), (3) prāṇāyāma (restraining or suspending the breath during the mental recitation of the names or attributes of a deity), (4) yama (self-control), (5) pratyā-hāra (restraining the organs), (6) dhāraṇa (the faculty of retaining in the mind, steady abstraction of mind), (7) dhyāna (abstract contemplation, religious meditation), and (8) samādhi (perfect absorption of thought in the one object of meditation, i. e. the Supreme Spirit); mentioned in connec-tion with obeisance, it means the 8 parts of the body, viz., the two hands, chest, forehead, two knees and two feet (cf. aṣṭāṅga-namaskāra).
575: aṣṭāṅga-bhakti-krama (EI 19), eight forms of worship; same as aṣṭa-vidh-ārcana, etc.
576: aṣṭāṅga-namaskāra (HA), obeisance with the eight limbs (viz. forehead, chest, two hands, two knees and two feet) done by lying straight on the ground, face downwards. See pañc-āṅga-namaskāra.
577: aṣṭa-paripālana (SITI), deities of the eight cardinal points; same as aṣṭa-dikpāla.
578: Aṣṭaprahārika (IA 17), probably an official designation; may be derived from aṣṭa-prahara; probably ‘a watchman’. The correct form would, in that case, be āṣṭaprāharika, etc.
581: Aṣṭāvadhāna (IA 11), one who has the power of listening and grasping eight things at a time; epithet of a poet.
582: Āṣṭavargika (IE 8-3; EI 7), probably, the superintendent of eight departments; mentioned as a Pātra.
583: aṣṭa-vidha-bhakti-kriyā (SITI), eight aspects of worship including arcanā, vandana, smaraṇa, pāda-sevana, stava, pradakṣiṇa, sakhya and ātma-nivedana or ātm-ārpaṇa.
584: aṣṭa-vidh-ārcana, aṣṭa-vidh-ārcanā (EI 19), same as aṣṭāṅga-bhakti-krama, the eight forms of worship. (IA 14; SITI), explained as ‘worship with eight materials, e. g., jala (water), gandha (scent), puṣpa (flower), akṣatā (grains), dhūpa (incense), dīpa (lamps), naivedya (food) and tāmbula (betel)’.
586: Āsthāyika-puruṣa (IA 8), official designation; probably the same as Sthāyin; may be ‘hereditary village officials’.
587: asti (Ep. Ind., Vol XXVIII, p. 302, note 2), a mere particle used to introduce the narration of a grant.
590: āsu (CII 4), name of a coin; cf. āchu and accu.
591: a-śuddha-pakṣa (IA 16), used to indicate the dark fort-night.
592: Āśu-kavi (EI 5), epithet of a poet; cf. Sukara-kavi, Śīghra-kavi.
593: a-śukla (IA 15), also called a-śukla-pakṣa (IA 16), the dark fortnight.
596: Asura-vijayin (CII 4), ‘a devilish conqueror’; epithet of a conqueror.
598: aśv-āḍḍāṇaka-patra (LP), deed for mortgaging a horse.
599: Aśv-ādhyakṣa (EI 18), superintendent of stables or cavalry officer; cf. Aśva-sādhanika, Aśvapati.
600: Aśva-ghāsa-kāyastha (HD), a petty officer in charge of the fodder for horses. Cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, III. 489.
601: aśvamedha (CII 3, 4), a sacrificial ceremony centering in a horse, generally performed by independent monarchs. Kings celebrating the sacrifice sometimes assumed suitable titles (cf. Aśvamedha-parākrama and Aśvamedha-Mahendra claimed respectively by Samudragupta and Kumāragupta I on their coins). Some kings performed two, four or more horse-sacri-fices. For a list of the performers of aśvamedha known form epigraphic and numismatic records, see Sundaram Pillai Com. Vol., pp. 93 ff.
604: Aśvapati (IE 8-2; CII 4)), cf. Aśvapati-Gajapati-Nara-pati-rāja-tray-ādhipati; royal title; the king as ‘the leader of the cavalry’; title of the Vijayanagara kings on account of their strength in horses (ASLV); title assumed by the rulers of some royal families. (EI 9, 21; CII 3; HD), an official title meaning either the master of the stables or the commander of the cavalry; cavalry officer; cf. Aśv-ādhyakṣa (EI 18). See CII, Vol. III, p. 259.
605: Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-mūvaru-rāyara-gaṇḍa (IE 8-2), title of the Vijayanagara kings; Kannaḍa translation of the title Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-rāja-tray-ādhipati.
606: Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-rāja-tray-ādhipati (IE 8-2; CII 4), holder (or, lord of the holders) of the three royal titles, viz., leader of the cavalry, leader of the elephant corps and leader of infantry; title assumed by the rulers of certain dynasties. Cf. Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-muvaru-rāyara-gaṇḍa.
610: aśvaśālā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of horses.
613: Aśvavāraka, Aśvavārika (LL), a trooper; same as Aśvavāra.
614: Aśvin (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; sometimes Āśvina is also used in this sense.
615: Āśvina (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; cf. Aśvin. See IHQ, Vol. XXXIII, p. 101.
619: āṭavika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 303, text line 50), a kind of grains. (EI 20; HD), an officer in charge of forest tracts. See Arthaśāstra, I 12 (mentioned among the 18 tīrthas).
620: aṭha-gānī, a coin equal to a ṭaṅka; there are do-gānī ((1/4) ṭaṅka), cau-gānī ((1/2) ṭaṅka), cha-gānī ((3/4) ṭaṅka), bārah-gānī (1(1/2) ṭaṅkas), caubīs-gānī (3 ṭaṅkas), aḍatālīs-gānī (6 taṅkas). See JNSI, Vol. XXII, pp. 198-99.
621: Atharva-veda (CII 3; etc.), one of the four Vedas. See Veda.
622: Ati-brahmaṇya (CII 3), probably meaning ‘extremely friendly to the Brāhmaṇas’ and not ‘a devout worshipper of the god Brahman’. See Parama-brahmaṇya.
626: atiprasaṅga (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 347, note 5), a case in which a grammatical rule exceeds its sphere.
627: atirātra (CII 3), name of a particular sacrifice.
630: atīta (IA 17), ‘expired’; cf. Śaka-nṛpa-kāl-ātīta-saṃvatsareṣu. The word gateṣu, sometimes additionally used, refers to the expiry of the expired years.
631: atīla-rājya (IA 19), indicates that so many years ‘since [the commencement of] the reign have [now] passed’; used in connection with the regnal reckoning of Govindapāla and Lakṣmaṇasena and rarely with the years of an era (e. g. the Vikrama-saṃvat associated with the reign of a legendary king named Vikramāditya). See also gata-rājya and vinaṣṭa-rājya. Cf. JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, 1954, pp. 43 ff.
632: atithi (EI 10; CII 3, 4), reception of guests; one of the five daily rites (mahāyajñas) of a Brāhmaṇa. See sattra.
633: ātithya (HRS), land assigned to government officers for public charities, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra.
634: ātivāhika (HRS), escorting fee paid by the merchants, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 77.
635: atiyātra (EI 30), same as atiyātrika; exit tax.
636: atiyātrika (IE 8-8), tax for crossing the boundary; see śulk-ātiyātrika, ‘the boundary-crossing fee’; also atiyātra.
643: Aṭṭapati (HD), the market-master. Cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 167.
644: aṭṭapati-bhāga (HRS), office entrusted with the collection of the share of the lord of the market, as indicated by the Rāja-taraṅgiṇī; literally, ‘share of the market-master’.
645: aṭṭhāi-mahotsava (HA), an eight-day festival celebrated by the Jains especially in the months of Āśvina and Caitra according to some but Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika according to others; same as aṣṭāhnika-parvan (q. v.).
646: aṭu (Chamba), a land measure. Cf. jilo, etc.
647: ātura-śālā, cf. ātula-śālai (EI 24; SITI), a hospital.
648: āturāvaḍḍi (IE 8-5; EI 28), tax of uncertain import; probably, a levy related to the treatment of the king when sick; also read as āntarāvaḍḍi.
649: atyagniṣṭoma (EI 26), name of a sacrifice. cf. agniṣṭoma.
650: Atyanta-bhagavad-bhakta (IE 8-2; CII 3), ‘extremely devoted to the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu)’; epithet of a pious Vaiṣṇava.
651: Atyanta-māheśvara (EI 23; CII 3), epithet of a pious Śaiva.
652: Atyanta-svāmi-mahābhairava-bhakta (EI 23; CII 3), epithet of a pious Śaiva.
654: atyaya (HRS), prescribed fine, as indicated in the Artha-śāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 26, 108. Cf. ātyayika.
655: ātyayika (CII 1; EI 22), a matter for urgent disposal; derived from atyaya, emergency, distress.
656: Audayantrika (LL), cf. Prakrit Odayantrika (EI 8); the maker of hydraulic machines or the person owning or working on such a machine.
657: Audraṅgika (IE 8-3; EI 23), collector of the udraṅga tax meaning ‘tax on permanent tenants or the principal tax’; sometimes mentioned side by side with the Hiraṇyasāmudāyika or the collector of tax in cash. See Ṣaṣṭh-ādhikṛta, Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇika, etc.
658: aukapiṇḍa, cf. okapiṇḍa (CII 1), probably, household vermin.
659: aulikara, cf. aulikara-lāñchana (EI 26; CII 3), the lāñchana or crest of the kings of the Aulikara dynasty of Mandasor. The real meaning of auli is uncertain; sometimes aulikara is interpreted as himakara or the moon.
661: Aupaśatika, cf. Prakrit Opasati (EI 16), name of a gotra.
662: aupāyanika (HRS), earnings from presents, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 28, 38.
664: aureus (IE 8-8), name of the Roman gold coin, also called denarius (q. v.).
665: Aurṇasthānika (IE 8-3; EI 23), officer in charge of an ūrṇā-sthāna (wool factory) or of all the ūrṇā-sthānas. Cf. ūrṇā-sthāna.
667: Autkheṭika (HRS), officer in charge of the collection of the impost called utkheṭana (q. v.).
669: Autthitāsanika (IE 8-3), same as Utthitāsanin; probably, courtier of a special rank provided with a special seat; perhaps, the chief nobleman at the royal court.
670: avabhṛtha (EI 9; CII 4), name of the ceremonial bath at the end of a sacrifice.
671: avacaṭita (EI 13), a crack; cf. khaṇḍa-sphuṭit-āvacaṭita-patita-saṃskār-ārtham, ‘for the repairs of dilapidated, broken, cracked and fallen [parts]’.
673: avadāna, also spelt āvadāna (EI 28, 29, 33), Oḏiyā; a present; a tax; tax in general; also called āvedana. (SITI), same as Sanskrit avasāna; termination, end.
674: avadāra (EI 13), cf. paśukul-āvadāra-karmānta-koṇakalikā-gaṅgāgrāme; meaning uncertain; possibly ‘a pound’ or ‘a pen’.
675: Avadhānin (EI 16), title of Brāhmaṇas; cf. Śatāvadhāna.
676: avadhāraṇā, cf. adhikaraṇ-āvadhāraṇā, ‘official investiga-tion’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 267).
677: avadhi, cf. avadher = anantaram (LP), ‘after the time limit is over’.
679: āvāha (CII 1), marriage of a son; cf. vivāha, ‘marriage of a daughter’.
680: avakara (EI 32), sweepings, a mound. Cf. avaṣkara; also niravakara, remainder after deduction (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 188).
681: avakāśa (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 347, note 5), ‘opportunity for a grammatical rule taking effect’.
682: avalagā (LP), same as Gujarātī oḻaga; cf. avalagā sad = aiv = āvalokyā (LP), ‘care should be constantly taken’.
683: avalagaka (EI 2; HRS), same as avalagā (q. v.); some-times regarded as presents or supplies.
684: avalagana (EI 2; HRS), same as avalagaka and avalagā.
685: avalambaka (EI 30), probably, a rod from which loops are suspended for carrying bundles.
687: āvaṇa (SITI), Tamil; a document; generally, a sale-deed; also called vilaiy-āvaṇam; cf. āvaṇa-kkaḻari (SITI), a place where documents like sale-deeds, etc., are registered; regis-tration office.
689: avani-maṇḍala, cf. Kon-āvani-maṇḍala (EI 32), also called Kona-maṇḍala, Kona-sīma, etc.
690: avani-randhra-nyāya (CII 4), same as bhūmi-cchidra-nyāya (q. v.), ‘the maxim of the fallow land.’
691: avani-vetana (SITI), police duties of a village; contri-bution for such duties; the same as Tamil pā ṭikāval.
693: āvāra (IE 8-5), cf. āpaṇeṣu āvāraḥ, ‘collections to be made from the shops in a market’. Cf. āvara.
695: avaraja (ML), a younger brother or cousin.
696: āvaraṇa (EI 17), a shield. (SITI), shelter, covering; same as prākāra or wall around the temple.
699: avarodha-jana (EI 23), inmates of the royal harem or the king's wives and concubines; wrongly interpreted as ‘a watchman’.
700: āvarta, cf. sarv-āvarta-yutā, ‘assigned as the date of pay-ment as it falls annually’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 310, note 1).
701: āvāsa, cf. a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa (IE 8-5), shelter or accommodation [which the villagers were obliged to provide for the touring officers of the king]; cf. saṃvāsa, etc.
702: āvāsaka (IE 8-5; EI 25), same as āvāsa or saṃvāsa, i. e. accommodation [which the villagers were obliged to provide to the royal officers on tour].
704: Avasara (SITI), an officer of the royal household having the duty of bringing to the notice of the king anything that demanded his immediate attention. Cf. Kārtākṛtika.
705: avasara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 347), one of the periods when the worship is performed and offerings are made to the deity in a temple.
706: Avasara-varttanā (SITI), presents payable to an Avasara (q. v.).
707: avasatha (IE 8-3), explained as ‘a college or a dharma-śālā’. But see Āvasathika.
708: Āvasathika (IE 8-3), variously explained as ‘the superin-tendent of avasathas, i. e. colleges or dharma-śālās’, ‘the super-visor of the royal palace and other government buildings’ (Hist. Beng., I, ed. Majumdar, p. 284); ‘one who keeps the domestic fire (āvasathya) burning with daily offerings’ (D. Bhattacharya, Halāyudha's Brāhmaṇasarvasva, p. xx); etc. (EI 9, 11, 24), title or family name of Brāhmaṇas. Cf. Āvasathin.
709: Āvasathin (EI 23), explained as ‘one who keeps the sacred fire called āvasathya’; cf. Āvasathika.
710: avaṣkara, sweepings, a mound; cf. s-oṣar-āvaṣkara-sthāha-nivīta-lavaṇākara (EI 22); also sa-gart-āvaṣkara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135, text line 21). See avakara.
713: Āvasthika (EI 23), corruption of Āvasathika; same as Āvasathin.
714: āvāta (IE 8-5), same as vāta, storm; cf. udvāta. (EI 32; CII 3; etc.), a fiscal term referring to the income from lands as a result of changes caused by natural agencies; an income probably resulting from storms. See vāta, probably meaning ‘a storm or tempest’; also āvāt-āya.
716: avataraṇa, cf. gṛh-āvataraṇa (IE 8-5), probably the same as umbara-bheda (q. v.).
717: avatāri-amāvāsyā (IA 18), Kannaḍa name for the new-moon of Pauṣa.
718: āvāt-āya (HRS), ‘the income derived from storms’; cf. āvāta and bhūta-vāta-pratyāya.
720: āvedana (EI 28), same as avadāna or āvadāna of Oḏiyā records; tax in general. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 115.
721: āvedanaka (IE 8-8), a written complaint or application.
722: avaṇḍ-āya (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 96), Telugu; name of a tax.
723: Āveśanin, cf. Prakrit Āvesani (EI 2; LL), the chief artisan; the foreman of artisans.
725: aviprahīna (CII 1), used in the sense of ahīna, ‘not lost’; undiminished.
727: āvṛti (CII 1), order; cf. sakala-deś-āvṛtika (CII 1), ‘one whose order has reached all parts of the country’. Cf. anāvṛti (CII 1), ‘want of practice’.
728: āvṛtti (IE 8-4; EI 26), an administrative unit like a Pargana (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 205).
730: āya (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’. (EI 33; CII 3; SII 1, 2), a fiscal term meaning ‘revenue’, ‘tax’. (SITI), literally, income; a general term denoting ‘taxes’; cf. val13iy-āyam (SITI), tolls on the roadway. (HRS), revenue in general according to the Arthaśāstra and other authorities; a special branch of revenue according to the inscriptions of the Uccakalpa kings and later epigraphs. (CITD), profit, income, receipt; tribute; corn given by the well-to-do villagers to the hereditary servants of the village as their established fees of office.
731: āyāga (EI 1), an object of homage; cf. āyāga-paṭṭa.
732: āyāga-paṭa, āyāga-paṭṭa (EI 24; LL), Jain; tablet for worship.
733: āyāga-sabhā (LL), Jain; a hall of homage. (SITI), administration of a village by a group of officers called āyāgār (village officers and servants).
734: āyaka (EI 21; LL), the entrance pavilion of a Buddhist monastery; a pavilion in front of the door of a Buddhist monastery.
735: āya-mukha, ‘sources of income’; cf. āya-śarīra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 26.
737: ayan-āṃśa (CII 3), the degree of procession of the equinoxes.
738: āya-pada (LP), income; property (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 145).
739: āya-śarīra, ‘body of income’ separated from āya-mukha, ‘source of income’. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 25-26.
742: āyatana (EI 30), a temple or shrine. Cf. bhavana, ālaya, pura, etc. Cf. ṣaḍ-āyatana; an organ. Cf. tuṣṭy-āyatana (CII 1), same as tuṣṭi-pātra.
744: āyudhīya (HRS), land granted for supplying troops in lieu of tax, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra. See amara.
745: Āyukta (CII 4; HD), literally ‘an officer’. Same as Āyuktaka. Pāṇini (II, 3. 40) knows the word in the sense of a servant or office. Cf. Āyukta-puruṣa (CII, Vol. III, p. 8).
746: Āyuktaka (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; EI 30; BL; HD), same as Āyukta; often the governor of a district or subdivision. See Kāmasūtra, V. 5. 5; Kāmandaka, V. 82.
748: āyuṣa, used in the sense of āyus in the Junagadh inscrip-tion of Rudradāman, text line 10 (Sel. Ins., p. 171).
749: āyuṣya (EI 10), Jain; a variety of karman.
750: Ayyanagandhavāraṇa (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; ‘the musk-elephant of the grandfather’; a subordinate title.
751: Ayyanasiṃha (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; ‘the lion of the grandfather’; a subordinate title. Cf. Aṇṇanasiṃha.
752: ba (IE 8-1; CII 3, etc.); an abbreviation of bahula or of bahula-pakṣa, i. e. the dark fortnight; used in connection with di or ti (see ba-di, la-ti) and also by itself. Cf. va.
753: Bā° (PJS), contraction of the honorific Bāi (q. v.) applied to ladies (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions of Western India).
754: bābū (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 316), meaning uncertain.
756: bācha, bāchī (Chamba), a tax in cash. See vākṣa.
757: bāḍa (EI 5), Kannaḍa; a town or village. (IE 8-4), Kannaḍa; a small territorial unit like a Pargana.
759: badalā (Chamba), return, exchange; same as parata.
760: badara, same as tolaka (q. v.) or tolā.
764: ba-di (IE 8-1; CII 3; etc.), contraction of bahula-pakṣa-dina or °divasa; also spelt va-di, cf. śu-di; abbreviations of separate words (see ba, di, śu and va) and not words in themselves, ba-di or va-di referring to the dark fortnight and śu-di the bright fortnight; they denote the fortnight and the solar or civil day, with reference to the lunar tithi, in the fortnight.
765: baḍi-māḍuvulu (CITD) Telugu; a coin of unknown value. Baḍi means ‘petty’ or ‘a tax’ and māḍuvu may be the same as māḍa meaning half a dīnār or the tenth of a paṇa.
767: bāhattara (IE 8-3), literally, ‘seventytwo’, but actually ‘all’ (cf. aṣṭādaśa, etc.); see Bāhattaraniyogādhipati, Bāhattara-niyogin, Senādibāhattaraniyogādhiṣṭhāyaka.
768: Bāhattaraniyogādhipati (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30), the highest executive officer under South Indian kings like the Yādavas of Devagiri; same as Bāhattaraniyogin, etc.
769: Bāhattaraniyogin (EI 19), official designation; same as Bāhattaraniyogādhipati.
772: bahis, ‘excluding’; same as Bengali baï (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 215).
775: bahuśruta (CII 1), well informed in various doctrines.
776: bahusuvarṇa, bahusuvarṇaka (EI 4; IA 19; CII 4), name of a sacrifice.
779: bāhya, cf. bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya (IE 8-5; Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 276, text line 14); ‘income from the sale of things imported in a village’, same as Tamil puṟav-āyam (SITI), ‘revenue from external sources (collected mainly in cash)’ or Tamil puṟa-kaḍamai (SITI), ‘external taxes’, explained as taxes and fees payable to the State. But puṟa-kaḍamai is the same as puṟav-āyam. Bāhya and ābhyantatra may thus mean respectively taxes payable to the king and those payable to the village authorities. See ābhyantara. Cf. samudaya-bāhy-ādya-stamba (EI 23), ‘land covered with original shrubs, i. e. waste which does not yield any revenue to the State’. (HD), a class of royal servants distinguished from Antaraṅga. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 426, 680, 1542.
780: bāhyāli (CII 4), the outskirt of a town.
781: Bāi, Bāī (EI 8), honorific epithet or name-ending of ladies in Western India; cf. Bāyi, Bā.°
784: Balādhikṛta (CII 3, 4; BL; HD), ‘the commander of an army’. See JBBRAS, Vol. XVI, p. 108 (Balādhikṛta following Senāpati); Kādambarī, para. 74. According to some (cf. Balādhi in LP), the Balādhikṛta was probably the head of a territorial unit like the present Māmlatdār. See Balādhipa.
785: Balādhipa (BL), a leader of the army; cf. Balādhikṛta.
786: Balādhīra (CII 4), official designation; probably, mistake for Balādhīśa, same as Balādhipa.
787: Balādhyakṣa (IE 8-3), officer in charge of the army; mentioned along with the Senāpati who was probably a sub-ordinate officer.
789: balaharaṇa, cf. balaharaṇena (LP), same as Gujarātī lāine.
792: bāl-ālaya (SITI) temporary shrine to lodge the images of gods when repairing a temple; small shrine probably consist-ing of a single room wherein the images of all the gods are lodged; same as Tamil iḻaṅ-koyil.
793: balānaka (HA), a maṇḍapa above the entrance of a Jain shrine or the courtyard of a shrine, later known as ṭhākorkhānā. (BL), a stone seat. (EI 8), same as Marāṭhī balāṇī, ‘a raised seat along the walls of the gābhāra or sabhā-maṇḍapa of a temple.’
794: bala-yaṣṭi (EI 33; CII 4), a stout memorial pillar.
795: Balharā (IE 8-2), Arabic corruption of Vallabha-rāja through Prakrit Ballaha-rāa.
796: bali (IE 8-5; HRS), voluntary gift (afterwards, com-pulsory contribution) and tribute from the subjects as indicated by Vedic literature; later, tax in general as suggested by the standard lexicons; king's grain share, identical with bhāga but different from kara according to the Arthaśāstra, but not the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman (cf. bali-śulka-bhāga in line 14). The Rummindei inscription of Aśoka also distinguishes between bali and bhāga and seems to identify bali with kara (or with pilgrims' tax). See Select Inscriptions, pp. 71, 173. (EI 10, 23, 32; CII 3, 4), an offering to creatures; one of the five mahāyajñas or sacrificial rites. Cf. bali-caru-vaiśvadev-āgnihotra-kratu (EI 26), the five rites of a Brāhmaṇa. (SITI), offering of flowers, fruits, uncooked rice, etc., to the gods; same as śrībali. Cf. Nārāyaṇa-baly-upahāra in the sense of Nārayaṇa-pūjā (Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, p. 363). Cf. varāha-bali, ‘pig sacrifice’ (Ep Ind., Vol. XXXVI, p. 39). Cf. śrī-bali, havir-bali.
797: balīvarda, cf. a-paramparā-balīvarda, etc. (IE 8-5); a pair of bullocks (which the villagers were obliged to provide for the cart of the royal officers when they camped or toured in their villages). See also vara-balīvarda.
799: Bānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ (599-11-2), variant spelling of Kannaḍa Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ (q. v.).
801: bandha-daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 12, 33), probably, ransom or fine in lieu of imprisonment.
804: bandhanīya (LP), ‘to be fixed’, i. e. to be served to one; cf. Gujarātī bāndhī āpavāṃ.
807: bappa (EI 29, 30; CII 3; etc.), a Prakrit word meaning ‘the father’, often used in Sanskrit inscriptions. Cf. bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta (EI 31), epithet of certain rulers.
808: bappa-bhaṭṭāraka (EI 4), ‘the father, the lord’. Cf. bappa.
809: bāra (EI 13), Telugu; the distance between the ends of out-stretched arms.
810: bārāḍ, derived from Sanskrit varāṭa or varāṭaka, ‘a cowrie-shell (used as money)’ (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 18). Cf. varāṭikā.
811: baraṭa (CII 4), a plant grown for fencing.
813: Barkandāz, Persian; same as Pāik (q. v.).
814: bartanā (IE 3-5), Rājasthānī; a blunt stick for writing on a wooden slate; same as barthā.
816: Basilĕos Basilĕon Mĕgalŏu (IE 8-2), Greek; ‘of the great king of kings;’ used in the legend on the coins of the Scytho-Parthian kings; adapted from old Persian Khshyāthiya Khshāya-thiyānām, ‘the king of kings’; translated into Prakrit as Maha-rajasa Rajarajasa (or Rajadirajasa) mahalasa (Sanskrit Mahā-rājasya Rājarājasya mahataḥ or Rājātirājasya mahataḥ).
817: Basilĕos Mĕgalŏu (IE 8-2), Greek; ‘of the great king’, found in the legend on the coins of Indo-Greek kings at first translated in Prakrit as Rajasa mahatakasa (Sanskrit Rājñaḥ mahataḥ) and later as Maharajasa (Sanskrit Mahārājasya); adapted from old Persian Kshāyathiya vazrka.
818: ba-ti (IE 8-1), abbreviation of bahula-pakṣa-tithi. See ba-di.
819: bāva (CII 3, etc.), a Prakrit word denoting ‘a relative of the same generation with the father’; generally, ‘an uncle’; used in Sanskrit inscriptions.
820: Bāyi (Hyderabad Archaeological Series, No. 18, p. 35), suffix to the name of respectable women; same as Bāi; wrongly regarded as derived from the Kannaḍa words abbĕ (Sanskrit ambā) and āyi (Sanskrit āryā).
821: Beharā-mahāpātra (EI 28), Oḏiyā; official designation; probably, Sanskrit Vyavahārika-mahāpātra. See Vyavahārika, etc.
822: Bengali, Anglicised spelling of Vaṅgālī; the name of the people, language and alphabet of Bengal.
