823: Beṇṭakāra (CITD), same as Beṭakāra, beṭa (Telugu-Kannaḍa) meaning ‘the separation of lovers’. As an epithet of a ruler, Beṇṭakāra means ‘one who causes the separation of his enemies’ wives from their husbands’; cf. ripu-nārī-vaidhavya-vidhā-yak-ācārya, ‘one who renders the wives of his enemies widows’.
825: Bha° (PJS), abbreviation of Bhagavān (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions).
826: bhā° (PJS), abbreviation of bhāryā (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions).
828: Bhadanta (IA 11; LL), a title of monks (Buddhist, Jain and Ājīvika); cf. Bhadatasa aya-Isipālitasa, ‘of the Reverend Lord Ṛṣipālita’; also cf. Bhadantī.
829: Bhadantī (LL), used as the title of a Buddhist nun; cf. Bhadanta.
833: bhadra-bhoga, cf. ‘according to bhadra-bhoga’ (Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 215); principle of proper enjoyment.
834: bhadra-ghaṭa, cf. Tamil pattira-kaḍam (SITI), a pot filled with water and sanctified by rites.
835: bhadra-mukha (EI 16), an honorific used with personal names.
838: bhāga (IE 8-5; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HRS), the king's share of the produce, distinguished from bali in the Rummindei inscription and the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman and from kara in many other records; later, tax in general, identical with bali and kara (according to lexicons); cf. references in the Arthaśāstra to (1) lavaṇa-bhāga (king's share of salt sold by private merchants), (2) udaka-bhāga (king's grain share levied as water-tax upon irrigated fields), (3) king's share of the produce of mines leased out to private persons; (4) share paid to the king by merchants for selling the royal merchandise. (IE 8-5), dues (see kara); generally, the king's share of grains, which was originally one-sixth. (IE 8-4), a subdivision of a district or a territory. (EI 23, 33), an allotment; a share.
839: bhāga-bhoga (CII 3; etc.), a fiscal expression in which bhāga means the king's share of the produce and bhoga the periodical supplies made by tenants to the king; cf. bhāga-bhog-ādika, bhāga-bhoga-kara-hirany-ādika (EI 23), meaning ‘royal dues’; see bhāga, etc.
840: bhāga-bhoga-kara (HRS), taken by some as a single levy and explained as the king's grain-share, identical with bhāga of the Arthaśāstra and bali of the Smṛtis, though distinguished from dhānya in a Maitraka record, where it has been supposed to mean a fixed contribution in kind as distinguished from the contribution consisting of a share of the produce. If bhāgabhogakara was a single levy (and did not indicate bhāga, bhoga and kara), it may have really been a tax collected in lieu of bhāga (grain share) and bhoga (periodical offerings).
841: Bhāgadugha (HD), an official title; probably the same as Bhāgahāra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 9.
842: Bhāgahara (EI 24), same as Bhāgin; a collector of the king's grain share. Cf. Bhāgahāra.
843: Bhāgahāra (HD), ‘he who recovers the [king's] share [of the produce of land]’; one of the six officers of each village, according to Śukra, II. 120. Cf. Bhāgahara.
844: bhāgalāga, cf. bhāgalāg-ādika (LP), payments in kind or taxes.
845: bhāga-karṣaṇa (LP), taking away the portion allotted to someone else.
847: Bhagavad-bhakta (CII 3, etc.), a Vaiṣṇava sectarian title indicating ‘a follower of the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu)’.
848: Bhagavat (ML; CII 3, 4), ‘the lord’ or ‘the divine’; an epithet of divinities such as Viṣṇu, Buddha, Jinendra, Nārāyaṇa, Śiva, the Sun-god, Kārttikeya, etc; also applied to sages, etc. in the sense of ‘venerable’, e. g. to Vyāsa, the arranger of the Vedas; rarely applied to kings apparently on account of their saintliness (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 19).
849: Bhāgavata (LL), a votary of the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu). (CII 3; etc.), a Vaiṣṇava sect.
850: Bhagavatī (CII 3, 4; etc.), feminine form of Bhagavat (q. v.); often applied to goddesses, etc.
851: Bhagavatpād-ācārya (EI 6), epithet of a Vaiṣṇava religious teacher.
852: Bhagavatpāda-karmakara (CII 4), ‘a servant of the feet of the Bhagavat’; epithet of a temple official.
853: Bhāgika (IE 8-3; HD), probably, the collector of the king's grain share; same as Bhāgahāra. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 166. Cf. Bhāgin. (EI 13), mentioned along with Bhogika; probably, one getting a share [in a free-holding]. See Aṃśa-bṛhadbhogika.
854: Bhāgin (EI 24), same as Bhāgika, a collector of the king's grain share.
855: bhagna (CII 1), ‘departed’, ‘lost’, i. e. ‘inferior’; cf. the Hindī verb bhāgnā, Bengali bhāgā. Cf. bhagna-viśīrṇa-samāracana, repairs to the rents in and the wornout parts of a building (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
857: bhāgya-rekhā (EI 3), line of fortune on the palm.
859: bhaikṣaka (EI 21), land set apart for charity.
862: bhakt-ādāya (SITI), same as Tamil pakt-ātāyam (SITI), revenue in rice or paddy. Cf. bhakt-āya.
863: bhakt-āya, cf. Kannaḍa bhatt-āya (SII 11-1); same as bhakt-ādāya.
864: bhakta-grāma, cf. bhatta-grāma, provision-village; village granted for maintenance (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, pp. 8, 92; cf. Vol. XVIII, pp. 191, 193).
866: bhaktī (EI 8), name of a land measure.
868: Bhaṃ° (PJS), abbreviation of Bhaṇḍārin (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions). See Bhīṇḍārin, etc.
869: bhā-maṇḍala (HA), halo, aureole; same as prabhā-maṇḍala.
871: bhaṃḍi (CITD), same as Telugu baṃḍi, ‘a cart’; really ‘a cart load’.
872: Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa; same as Mahānas-ādhyakṣa; superintendent of the royal kitchen. Cf. Sūpakāra-pati, Khādyaṭapākika, Mahānasika.
874: bhāṇḍa, cf. bhaṇḍa (EI 5), a bale of goods.
875: bhāṇḍa-bhṛta-vahitra (IE 8-8), ‘a wagon full of pots or jars’.
876: Bhāṇḍ-ādhyakṣa (EI 28), officer in charge of the store-house. Cf. Bhāṇḍāgār-ādhikṛta, etc.
878: Bhāṇḍāgār-ādhikṛta (EI 12; BL; HRS), an officer employed in the treasury or store-house or the officer in charge of it. Cf. Bhāṇḍāgārika.
879: Bhāṇḍāgāra-prathama (HD), the chief of the royal store-house or treasury. See JBBRAS, Vol. IX, p. 219.
880: Bhāṇḍāgārika (IE 8-3; CII 4; HD; BL), officer in charge of the treasury or the royal store-house. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305.
881: bhaṇḍāra, same as Sanskrit bhāṇḍāra; cf. Bhaṇdārin, etc.
882: bhāṇḍāra, cf. Tamil paṇḍāra-kkal (SITI), stone of standard weight used in the treasury; also cf. paṇḍāra-kkaṇkāṇi, treasury officer, supervisor of the treasury. (IA 23), the five images used in the worship of Bhūtas, e. g., Jārandāya, etc. Cf. paṇḍāram (SII 1), a treasury; a Śaiva mendicant.
883: Bhāṇḍāra-pustaka, cf. Tamil baṇḍāra-ppottagam (EI 25), literally, ‘account book of the treasury’; a treasury accountant.
884: Bhaṇḍārin, Bhāṇḍārin (EI 9; SITI), officer in charge of the treasury; same as Bhāṇḍāgārika. Cf. Sejjeya-bhaṇḍārī (EI 13), ‘officer in charge of the stores in the king's bed-chamber’.
885: bhaṅga (Chamba), a land measure; a share or portion. (IA 23), hemp.
887: bhāra (EI 10), a weight equal to 2000 palas. (LP), probably, a load or bundle.
888: bharaka (CII 4), name of a measure or weight; one load (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309). Cf. mahiṣ-oṣṭra-bharaka (IE 8-8), ‘a load on a buffalo or a camel’; cf. bhāṇḍa-bhṛta-vahitra.
889: bharaṇa (CII 4), name of a measure. (EI 1), probably, a load [of stones].
892: Bhāratī-vṛtti (SITI), land set apart for expounding the Mahābhārata.
894: bhārikā (IE 8-5; EI 25), cf. bhārikāyāṃ vaṇik-putrasy = āṣṭottara-śataṃ rūpakāṇām; a crime, the nature of which is uncertain.
895: bhāṣā (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, a written declaration.
897: Bhāṣya-vṛtti (SITI), land set apart for meeting the ex-penses of expounding the Śrī-Bhāṣya of Rāmānuja.
898: Bhaṭa (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HD), same as Bhaṭa-manuṣya; probably derived from bhṛta which is sometimes used in its place. Generally used along with cāṭa or chātra; literally, ‘a soldier’; but really a Pāik, Barkandāz or Piāda, i. e. a constable. It is spelt as bhaṭṭa in the medieval inscriptions of Eastern India, though rarely the two are distinguished. See Bhaṭṭa. (SITI), a personal servant or soldier.
899: bhāṭaka (EI 30), same as prabhāṭaka; rent or hiring charges; cf. naukā-bhāṭaka (EI 14).
900: Bhaṭa-manuṣya (IE 8-3; EI 31; LL), explained as ‘a soldier, policeman or warden’; a Barkandāz, Pāik or Piāda.
901: Bhaṭāra (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa corruption of Bhaṭṭāraka; also spelt Bhaḍāra and Bhaḻāra.
902: Bhaṭṭa (IE 8-3), cf a-caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-praveśa (IE 8-5); same as Bhaṭa of earlier records; but rarely distinguished from Bhaṭa, Bhaṭṭa in that ease meaning ‘a minstrel’. (CII 3, 4; etc.), a title of respect attached to the names of learned Brāhmaṇas. (IE 8-3), a minstrel.
903: Bhaṭṭā° (PJS), abbreviation of Bhaṭṭāraka (in medieval Jain inscriptions); an epithet of Jain teachers.
905: Bhaṭṭa-grāma (EI 15, 25), a village owned by learned Brāhmaṇas as a rent-free holding; same as an agrahāra village.
906: Bhaṭṭāmākutika (EI 7), an official designation of uncer-tain import.
907: Bhaṭṭa-mahattara (EI 30), a Bhaṭṭa who was a Mahattara, or a leading Bhaṭṭa. Bhaṭṭa may not be a corruption of paṭṭa (cf. Bhaṭṭa-nāyaka).
908: Bhaṭṭa-nāyaka (EI 9), see Bhaṭṭa and Nāyaka (chief of a district) as well as Bhaṭṭa-mahattara. Cf. also Paṭṭa-nāyaka of medieval Orissan epigraphs.
909: Bhaṭṭaputra (EI 4; LP; BL), title of Brāhmaṇas; epithet of a Brāhmaṇa whose father was famous for learning. (LP), explained as ‘sepoys or soldiers’. (EI 11), explained as ‘a panegyrist’.
910: Bhaṭṭāraka (IE 8-2; CII 3; EI 30), title used in Sanskrit but really Prakrit derived from Sanskrit bhartṛ through the plural form bhartāraḥ = Prakrit bhaṭṭāra (see Svāmin); often suffixed to the personal names of paramount sovereigns as well as of feudatory Mahārājas, or Yuvarājas (crown-princes); applied to gods and priests in the sense of ‘worthy of worship or sacred’. Cf. bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta, bhaṭṭāraka-Mahāsena-parigṛhīta, etc. (EI 33), the king. (SII 1), title of Jain religious teachers. (CII 4), title of Śaiva ascetics, etc. (LP), a respected man. (EI 11), probably, epithet of the chief priest of a temple. (SITI), a deity; a spiritual preceptor.
911: Bhaṭṭāraka-pād-ānudhyāta (CII 4), ‘meditating on (or, favoured by) the feet of the lord paramount’; epithet of the feudatories and officers of the Gupta emperors and later imperial rulers. See Paramabhaṭṭāraka-pād-ānudhyāta.
914: Bhaṭṭa-vṛtti (EI 25; SII 1), a grant for the maintenance of the Bhaṭṭas or learned Brāhmaṇas.
915: Bhaṭṭavṛtti-mānya (SITI), tax-free land (inām) given for the support of Brāhmaṇas; same as bhaṭṭa-vṛtti.
916: Bhaṭṭārikā (EI 23; CII 3; etc.), feminine form of Bhaṭṭāraka (q. v.); a title of the wives of independent and feudatory rulers; often suffixed to personal names. Cf. Tamil paṭṭārikai (SITI), name of the goddess Durgā.
917: Bhaṭṭ-opādhyāya (EI 23), title of a Brāhmaṇa teacher.
918: bhauli, bhaulī (Chamba), a share, portion or allotment.
922: bhavana (LL), a temple. Cf. pura, āyatana, ālaya, etc.
923: bhāvanā (CII 4), sentiment, e. g., maitrī, etc. (EI 3), Jain; a method of kāy-otsarga.
924: Bhavasṛj (CII 3), ‘the creator of existence’; an epithet of the god Śiva.
926: bhavat, cf. sa bhavān (EI 3), same as tatrabhavān.
927: Bhāvinī (IA 10), same as Devadāsī; a dancing girl attached to a temple.
928: bhaviṣya-kkiḍai-ppuṟam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; tax-free land set apart to enable a teacher to reside permanently in a village for teaching.
930: bhāvya, cf. rāja-bhāvya-sarva-pratyāya-sameta (EI 23), income, levies; same as ābhāvya. According to some, bhāvya and ābhāvya mean pāghḏī. Cf. talār-ābhāvya. (LP), probably the same as bhāvyapada-paṭṭa.
932: bheruṇḍa (EI 31), a shortened form of gaṇḍabheruṇḍa (q. v.).
933: bhet (IA 11), Pañjābī; low lands inundated by rivers.
934: bheṭa (IE 8-5; EI 29), presents to be offered by a sub-ject or subordinate to a ruler on occasions; occasional offering of money or presents; same as vandāpanā. See bheṭana.
935: bheṭana (LP), a present or gift; cf. bheṭa.
937: bhikṣā (IE 8-4), a grant or endowment; cf. ekādaśa-Rudra-bhikṣā (EI 32), an endowment in the gods’ name.
938: Bhikṣu (EI 7, 21; CII 3; ML), Buddhist monk, also called Śākya-bhikṣu.
939: Bhikṣu-hala (LL), ‘the monks’ land’; rent-free land in the possession of Buddhist monks.
940: Bhikṣuhala-parihāra, cf. Prakrit Bhikhuhala-parihāra (HRS), known from Śātavāhana records as a number of privileges relating to rent-free land belonging to the community of Buddhist monks.
941: Bhikṣuṇī (EI 25; CII 3; LL), feminine form of Bhikṣu; ‘a Buddhist nun’; also called Śākya-bhikṣuṇī.
943: Bhikṣuṇī-saṅgha, cf. bhikkhuṇī-saṃgha (EI 23), a community of nuns.
944: Bhikṣurāja (LL), title of a pious [Jain] king.
945: Bhikṣu-saṅgha (EI 26; CII 4), community of Buddhist monks.
948: Bhiṣak (HD), the king's medical advisor. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305. (EI 24), a physician.
949: Bhīṣmāṣṭamī (IA 17), Māgha su-di 8 or amānta Māgha (i. e. pūrṇimānta Phālguna) va-di 8.
951: Bhitara-bhaṇḍāra-adhikārin (IE 8-3; EI 28), Oḏiyā; Sanskrit Abhyantara-bhāṇḍār-ādhikārin, ‘officer in charge of the inner store-house or treasury (i. e. one within the palace or the harem)’.
952: bhītara-navara (EI 28), Oḏiyā = Sanskrit abhyantara-nagara; the palace.
955: bhitti-citra, wall-painting (Journ. Mad. Univ., Vol. XXXII, p. 141).
956: Bhitvaramānya (IA 17), probably, a mistake for Abhitva-ramāṇa (q. v.).
957: bhoga (IE 8-4; CII 3; EI 23, 33), literally, ‘enjoyment’ (cf. bhukti); a jāgīr (cf. Mahārāja-Sarvanātha-bhoga, Mahā-sāmantādhipati-Śrīdhara-bhoga, etc.); possession (cf. bhog-ādhīnā gṛhītā). Originally ‘enjoyment’; then ‘property’, ‘a jāgīr’; then also a territorial unit which was generally the subdivision of a district (IE 8-4; EI 25; 28; CII 4). See bhukti, āhāra. Cf. Kaivarta-bhoga (IE 8-4; EI 2; CII 1), the fishermen's preserve. (IE 8-5; EI 29, 30; HRS), periodical supplies of fruits, firewood, flowers and the like which the villagers had to supply to the king; sometimes explained as ‘tax in kind’ (CII 4). (EI 1), [an object of] enjoyment. (SITI), tax-free land set apart for the enjoyment of a person for the performance of specified services; same as mānya. See bhogottara, Bhogin, etc. Cf. bhoge (LP), ‘for the right of enjoyment’. Cf. sa-bhoga (IA 9), privilege of the donee of rent-free land; probably refers to aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya (q. v.).
958: bhoga-bhāga (CII 3, etc.,), the same as bhāga-bhoga. Cf. bhoga-bhāga-kara-hiraṇy-ādi (EI 23), royal dues; see bhoga, etc.
959: bhoga-janapada (EI 12), probably, a free-holding in the country-side, or a rent-free area.
960: bhoga-lābha (EI 33), usufruct in lieu of interest.
961: Bhogapati (IE 8-3; EI 25, 27; HD), an Ināmdār or Jāgīr-dār, or an officer in charge of inām lands or jāgīrs, or the officer in charge of a territorial unit called bhoga. The last alternative is more probable; cf. Bhogika, etc. See also Mitākṣarā on the Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 320; Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 298. See Bhuktipati, Bhogikapāla, etc.
963: bhoga-patra (ASLV, SITI), a deed recording conveyance of land; a lease deed; the deed of re-conveyance of land.
964: bhoga-strī, a concubine (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 272).
967: bhog-āyaka (ASLV, SITI), land held as the result of a mortgage.
968: Bhogi-jana (EI 33), explained as ‘a village headman’. Cf. Bhogika,
969: Bhogika (IE 8-3; CII 3; HD; BL), the owner of a bhoga or jāgīr; a Jāgīrdār or Ināmdār; same as Bhogin. See Bhoktṛ. Explained by some as the head of a district, or the collector of the State's share of the produce of lands taken in kind (Bomb. Gaz., Vol. I, Part i, p. 82). See CII, Vol. III, pp. 96, 104. (IE 8-3); EI 18; 23), a groom or horse-keeper, accord-ing to lexicons; cf. its Telugu modification Bhoi, ‘a palanquin-bearer’. But these meanings may have been derived from the first as the people appear to have enjoyed rent-free land for their services. (EI 33), same as Bhojaka meaning a Jāgīrdār or Ināmdār. (CII 4), explained as ‘the head of a bhoga’. (EI 5), explained as ‘a village proprietor’.
970: Bhogikapāla, Bhogikapālaka (EI 5; CII 4; BL), superin-tendent of the jāgīrs and cess collector; cf. Bhogapati.
971: Bhogin (IE 8-3; EI 12, 28, 29, 30; BL), one in possession of a bhoga or jāgīr; a Jāgīrdār; same as Bhogika (q. v.).
972: bhogīna (EI 13), cf. dattidāyaka-sādhupratipādita-prāg-bhujyamān-āvicchinna-bhogīna-bhuvām translated rather loosely as ‘of the pieces of land in all the places that have been obtained in good manner from liberal donors’; probably, ‘[land] under possession’.
974: bhogi-rūpa (EI 12, 28), one who enjoys a free-holding as a representative of the real free-holder, or a title-holder who is not in actual possession of the land.
975: bhogiyār (SITI), Tamil; mistress, concubine; cf. bhogyār.
976: Bhog-oddharaṇika (HD), explained as ‘the collector of the king's share of the grains’; cf. bhoga, caur-oddharaṇika.
977: bhogottara (IE 8-5; EI 33), corrupt form of bhogatrā; land granted to the family priest for his services; grant for the enjoyment of a Brāhmaṇa or deity.
978: bhogyā, cf. pokiyār (SITI), a concubine; see bhogiyār.
979: bhogya-tithi (CII 3), the portion of a tithi that is still to run.
980: Bhoi, Telugu modification of Sanskrit Bhogin (q. v.); palanquin-bearer (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 308, note 8).
981: Bhoja, Bhojaka (IE 8-2; EI 1; 27; HD; LL), a Jāgīrdār; title of a feudatory; cf. the feminine form Bhojikī; also Mahā-bhoja. See Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 5. (EI 3; CII 3), a priest; title of a class of priests. Cf. Tamil pośar (SITI), one who enjoys a thing; the possessor.
983: bhojana-ākṣayaṇī, bhojan-ākṣayaṇī (EI 32), a permanent endowment created for the maintenance of the donee; cf. akṣayanīvī, grāmagrāsa, etc.
985: bhojana-śālā (EI 23), an almshouse; a free-feeding house. Cf. sattra.
986: Bhojikī (LL), wife of a Bhojaka (q. v.). cf. Mahābhojī.
987: Bhojpurī, language and people of the Bhojpur Pargana of the Shahabad District of Bihar and the adjoining regions.
988: Bhoktṛ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 193), same as Bhogin, Bhogika; an Ināmdār or Jāgīrdar; cf. Sammāṇaka-bhoktā; also Bhoktāri (EI 11), a free-holder. (BL), a proprietor.
989: Bhoṭṭa-viṣṭi (HRS), known from Nepal records; forced labour for carrying loads for officers sent to Tibet. See H. Rev. Syst., p. 233.
990: bhrama-jala-gati (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 98), probably, a sluice.
991: bhṛṣṭī (IA 15), ‘raised ground [near a tank] for plant-ing piper betel’; cf. bhīṭī.
992: bhṛta (LP), loaded. (IE 8-8), cf. bhāṇḍa-bhṛta-vahitra, ‘a wagonful of pots or jars’. See bharaka. Cf. a-bhṛta-prāvesya for a-bhaṭa-prāveśya, bhṛta being used for bhaṭa in the sense of a Pāik, Barkandāz or Piāda.
993: bhū (IA 17), a land measure; equal to four bhū-māṣakas. See bhūmi. (EI 9), a land measure or a plot of land. (IE 7-1-2; EI 15, 25), ‘one’.
997: Bhujabalan-māḍai (SITI), name of a coin of the māḍai (māḍha) type. See māḍa, etc.
1000: bhujaṅga (IA 20), an ogre. The word bhujaṅga was adopted in Javanese in the sense of a ‘pupil, disciple, scholar; a philologist, poet, literary councillor; an officially appointed professional usually residing at or near the court’. It has been suggested on this basis that Bhavadeva-bhaṭṭa's title Bālavalabhī-bhujaṅga may really mean ‘the pupil of the Bālavalabhī school’. See IHQ, Vol. XXVII, pp. 80-82.
1003: bhukta-tithi (CII 3), the elapsed portion of a tithi.
1004: bhukti (IE 8-4; EI 28, 33), a province including a group of districts called viṣaya or maṇḍala; small territorial unit like a Pargana in South India; cf. bhoga. (IE 8-3; 8-4; CII 3), literally, ‘enjoyment’; same as bhoga; a jāgīr; originally meaning ‘enjoyment’; then ‘property’ or ‘a jāgīr’; then ‘a province’. See bhoga. (BL), personal property. Cf. putti, pukti (SITI), the enjoyment of a property.
1005: bhukti-maṇḍala (IE 8-4), originally a bhukti but later on a maṇḍala; cf. Daṇḍabhukti-maṇḍala, āhāra-viṣaya.
1006: Bhuktipati (IE 8-3), a Jāgīrdār; or, the officer in charge of a territorial unit called bhukti. See Bhogapati.
1007: bhūmāṣaka (IA 17), a land measure, four bhūmāṣakas making one bhū (q. v.)
1008: bhumbhuka (EI 13), Kannaḍa; cf. bhuvana-bhumbhuka, probably, ‘an ornament of the world’.
1009: bhūmi, bhūmī (EI 3; CII 3), a particular land measure; sometimes also called bhū and regarded as equal to four bhū-māṣakas (cf. bhū). (CII 4), a territorial division. (EI 7-1-2), ‘one’.
1010: bhūmicchidra (IE 8-5), sometimes explained as ‘unculti-vable land’. See bhūmicchidra-nyāya.
1011: bhūmicchidra-nyāya (IE 8-5; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HRS), literally, ‘the maxim of the fallow land’; the principle of the rent-free enjoyment of land by one who brings it under cultiva-tion for the first time. See Ep. Ind., Vol XXIX, p. 86. The maxim is based on the old custom of allowing a person, who first brings a plot of fallow or jungle land under cultivation for the first time, to enjoy it without paying rent. Bhūmi-cchidra gradually came to mean ‘uncultivable land’. See bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya, avanirandhra-nyāya.
1012: bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya (IE 8-5; EI 11), the same as bhūmicchidra-nyāya; but it means ‘the maxim of covering up the hole in the land’ referring probably to the reclamation of fallow land for the first time; cf. bhūmicchidra understood in the sense of kṛṣy-ayogyā bhū, ‘land unfit for cultivation’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIX, p. 86.
1013: bhūmicchidravidhāna-nyāya (EI 24); same as bhūmicchidra-nyāya, bhumicchidrapidhāna-nyāya. Chidra-vidhāna = furrowing.
1015: bhūmi-putra. cf. pūmi-puttirar (SITI), husbandmen regarded as the sons of Mother Earth.
1017: bhurja (IE 3-2), really ‘the birch’; but same as lekhana; a written document.
1019: bhūta (CII 1), a living being. (IE 8-5), the element or nature. (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’. (CII 3, etc.), a fiscal term; cf. sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya, in which we have sometimes pātta (mistake for upātta), upātta, āvāta or vāta. See bhūta-pāta, etc.
1020: bhūta-bali (EI 11; SII 13), explained as ‘offering of boiled rice to the ghosts’.
1021: bhūta-koṭya (IA 23), the place of residence of the family ghost.
1022: bhūta-pāta, cf. sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya (IE 8-5); often written as bhūta-vāta and bhūt-opātta; probably, an event relating to the elements, such as an earthquake. See bhūta-pāta-pratyāya.
1023: bhūta-pāta-pratyāya (CII 4), explained by some as ‘excise and octroi duties’; but really, ‘the income resulting from storms, earthquakes, changes in the course of a river, etc’. See bhūta-vāta-pratyāya, etc. Pāta may be a mistake for upātta or vāta.
1024: bhūta-pratyāya (CII 3), an income derived from natural changes in the land. See bhūta-vāta-pratyāya, etc.
1026: bhūta-vāta-pratyāya (EI 23; CII 4; HRS), ‘the income derived from the elements and the winds’; explained by some as ‘excise and octroi duties’; but really, ‘the income resulting from storms, earthquakes, changes in the course of a river, etc.’ See bhūt-opātta-pratyāya, etc.
1027: bhūt-opātta-pratyāya (EI 32), income brought about by elemental or natural changes (e. g. storms, earthquakes, etc.).
1028: Bhūvara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 98), ‘a king’.
1030: bījaka, cf. bījak (EI 9), an inscribed stone or an inscription.
1032: bīḻ-ānuvṛtti, also called bīḻa-vṛtti (599 11-1), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; fief held by a king's subordinate for his mainte-nance; cf. anuga-jīvita.
1034: biṃ° (PJS), abbreviation of bimba, ‘an image’ (especia-cially in medieval Jain inscriptions).
1035: bimba (IA 3; HA), same as pratimā; an image.
1038: bīravaṇa-pārikhāya (IA 19), levy stated to have been of four kinds; cf. nidhi-nikṣepa-jala-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-chatuṣ-prakāra-bīra-vaṇa-pārikhāya-sahitaṃ which is mentioned along with aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmya-daṇḍa-śulka-yuktam; Sanskrit vīra-paṇa (tax for the maintenance of constables) and pārīkṣ-āya (pārīkṣika).
1040: Biśī (EI 24), derived from Viṣayin (Viṣayapati), the governor of a district.
1041: bīsva (EI 28), a land measure equal to (1/20) of a bīghā; derived from Sanskrit viṃśopaka.
1042: bīṭaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 279), modern bīḏā (i. e. a betel bīḏā).
1043: bittuvaṭṭa (A.R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 10), Kannaḍa; probably also called bittukaṭṭe; explained as ‘a portion of the produce derived from the lands irrigated by tanks, or wet land irriga-ted by a tank, granted to the person who built the tank or repaired it.’
1044: bodhi (LL), Buddhist; supreme knowledge attained by the Buddha; the tree of enlightenment; cf. mahābodhi, saṃbodhi.
1045: bodhi-cakra (LL), Buddhist; the wheel of enlightenment.
1046: Bodhisattva (CII 2-1; LL), Buddhist; a would-be Buddha in a previous birth. Cf. Chadmastha.
1047: bodhyaṅga, cf. bojjhaṅga (EI 5), Buddhist; seven in number.
1048: Boḏiyā, local name of the Gujarātī alphabet (Ind. Ep., p. 55).
1050: boppa (CII 3), a Prakrit word meaning ‘the father’; see bappa.
1051: boṭa, also spelt voṭa (CII 3), a termination of geographical names; meaning uncertain.
1052: botkaṭa (IA 19), a goat; cf. Deśī bokkaḍa; also varkara (IA 19).
1053: Brā, abbreviation of Brāhmaṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 55).
1054: brahmacārin (SII 2; LL), a Brāhmaṇa student; an unmarried student of the Vedas. (BL), epithet of one who takes a vow of celibacy. (SII 2), a temple servant.
1055: brahma-dāna, cf. pirama-dānam (SITI), gift to Brāhmaṇas; same as brahmadāya, etc.
1056: brahmadāya (EI 23; CII 4), gift to a Brāhmaṇa; the rent-free holding of Brāhmaṇas; same as brahmadeya. See brahmatrā, etc.
1057: brahmadeya (EI 30; ASLV; HRS; SITI), land or village given as gift (generally tax-free) to Brāhmaṇas; land to be granted to or in the possession of Brāhmaṇas.
1058: brahmadeya-kkil13avar (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; sole owner of a Brahmadeya village; sometimes supposed to be the headman or chief of a Brahmadeya village.
1059: Brahm-ādhirāja (SITI), title of distinguished Brāhmaṇa military commanders; also spelt Brahmādarāya in Tamil. See Brahma-mahārāja, Brahma-rāja.
1060: brahma-hatyā (CITD), killing a Brāhmaṇa, considered to be a great sin.
1061: brahma-kalpa (CITD), the kalpa or age of the god Brahman, extending to many thousands of years.
1062: Brahma-kṣatra, Brahma-kṣatriya (EI 5, 12, 24), a Kṣatriya family claiming descent from a Brāhmaṇa parent; a family in which the blood of the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas has been mixed. See Vishveshvaranand Ind. Journ., Vol. I, pp. 87 ff., etc. In one record (Journ. Karnatak Univ., Vol. II, No 2, January 1959, p. 47), the Nāgavaṃśa, to which a Kadamba king's minister Māyideva belonged, is called Brahma-kṣatra because it originated from the intercourse of its progenitor Nāgarāja with a Brāhmaṇa girl. Brahma-vaiśya should be likewise explained.
1063: Brahma-mahārāja, cf. pirama-mārāyaṉ (SITI), title of Brāh-maṇa ministers. See Brahm-ādhirāja, Brahmarāja.
1065: brahma-medha, cf. pirama-metam (SITI), special funeral rite for a saintly person.
1067: brāhmaṇa-rāśa(rāja)-kkāṇam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; tax payable by the Brāhmaṇa (Purohita) to the king.
1068: brāhmaṇa-viṃśati (HRS), title upon villagers for the main-tenance of the Brāhmaṇas.
1070: brahmaṇya (EI 22) ‘hospitable to the Brāhmaṇas’; see Paramabrahmaṇya, Atibrahmaṇya.
1072: brahmapura (EI 2), same as brahmapurī; a rent-free village in the possession of Brāhmaṇas; same as agrahāra, etc.
1073: brahmapurī (EI 4, 28; SITI), also called agara-brahmadeya (Sanskrit agrahāra-brahmadeya); a Brāhmaṇa settlement. See brahmapura.
1074: Brahmarāja (SITI), title of a Brāhmaṇa minister.
1075: Brahmarākṣasa (EI 3, 16), a Brāhmaṇa defeated in dis-putations.
1076: Brahmarāya (SITI), same as Brahmarāja. Cf. Brahm-ādhirāja.
1079: brahma-sthāna (SII 13; SITI), explained as ‘an assembly hall’; the Brāhmaṇa quarters of a village; cf. Tamil pirumma-stānam (SITI), the quarters of the Brāhmaṇas where the village assembly (sabhā) used to meet.
1083: brahma-yajña (EI 22; CII 4), study of the Vedas; name of a mahāyajña.
1084: Brāhmī, name of an early Indian alphabet, from which a large number of alphabets of India and some other countries have derived.
1085: brahmottara (IE 8-5), Bengali; corrupt form of brahmatrā. (IA 15), explained as ‘the sanctuary of a temple’.
1086: Bṛha, abbreviation of Bṛhatpuruṣa (q. v.). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 143.
1087: bṛhac-chulka, cf. Kannaḍa perjuṅka, perujuṅka, pejjuṅka, hejjuṅka.
1088: Bṛhad-bhogika (IE 8-3), same as Bṛhad-bhogin; see Bhogika and Aṃśa-bṛhadbhogika.
1089: Bṛhad-bhogin (IE 8-3; EI 28, 29; BL), same as Bṛhad-bhogika; a chief jāgīrdār; see Bhogin.
1090: Bṛhaddeva, cf. Tamil Periya-devar (SITI), literally, ‘the great king’; the predecessor or predecessors of the ruling mon-arch; also called Periya-perumāḻ sometimes indicating the para-mount sovereign or emperor. Cf. Bṛhan-nṛpati.
1091: bṛhaddhala (EI 7), ‘the big plough’; name of a land measure (Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 125); cf. hala.
1093: Bṛhad-uparika (EI 15, 26; HD), ‘the great governor of a province’; a viceroy. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 9. Cf. Uparika.
1096: bṛhan-māna (EI 23; CII 4), a measure larger than the standard one; cf. viṣaya-māna.
1097: Bṛhan-nṛpati (IE 8-2), predecessor of the ruling monarch; called Periya-devar in Tamil; cf. Oḏiyā Baḏa-Narasiṃha and Telugu Pedda-Narasiṃha. See Bṛhaddeva. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 231 and note 2; JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 212.
1098: bṛhaspatisava (EI 22; CII 3), name of a sacrifice.
1100: Bṛhat-kumāramahāpātra (EI 28), cf. Kumāra-mahāpātra which is similar to Kumārāmātya.
1102: Bṛhatpuruṣa, probably the same as Mahājana (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 143-44).
1104: Bṛhat-tantrapati (IE 8-3; EI 33), explained by a Kashmirian commentator as the Dharmādhikārin who was a judge also in charge of charities; cf. the Muslim official designation şadruŞ-şudūr, etc., explained as ‘the chief judge and grand almoner, or the custodian of the king's bequests and charities’ (Journ. As. Soc. Pak., Vol. IV, pp. 53-54).
1105: bṛha-vāra, (EI 31; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 125 and note), Saturday or Thurdsday (A. Venkatasubbiah, Some Śaka Dates in Inscriptions, pp. 57ff.); same as Vadḍa-vāra (q. v.).
1107: Buddha (LL), Buddhist; a class of saints. See Bodhisattva.
1109: buddh-ādhiṣṭhāna (EI 22), a city or locality in the possession of a Buddhist monastery.
1110: Buḏhāleṅkā (IE 8-3), Oḏiyā; same as Mahāpādamūlika, ‘chief attendant.’
1111: budh-āṣṭamī (IA 26), the eighth tithi on a Wednesday.
1112: bullaga-kara (HRS), tax relating to the supervision of meals according to the Abhidhānarājendra, s.v. kara.
1115: busi-bhaṃḍālu (CITD), Telugu; probably, stores of un-husked grain. Cf. kola-bhaṃdālu.
1119: Cāḍa (IE 8-3), same as Cāṭa (q. v.) and the modern Cāḏ of Chamba, the latter being the designation of the head of a Parganā.
1120: cāḏā (LP), a camp; an attacking party.
1121: caitra-pavitra, caitra-pavitraka (EI 7, 18), name of a rite (Ind. Ant., Vol. XXXVIII, p. 52); caitra is the daman-āropaṇa ceremony which takes place in the month of Caitra and pavitra is the pavitr-āropaṇa ceremony which occurs in Śrāvaṇa (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 274, notes 12-13); cf. Kannaḍa caitra-pavitr-ābhyāgat-ādi pūje gaḻgaṃ, translated as ‘for the caitra and pavitra and the entertainment of guests and other rites’ (IA 30).
1122: caitya (EI 22, 33; BL), a prayer hall; usually, a place of worship in a Buddhist monastery; same as caitya-gṛha. (EI 6, CII 4), same as stūpa.
1123: caity-āgāra (SII 1), a Jain temple; same as caity-ālaya.
1124: caitya-gṛha (EI 8, 33, LL), Buddhist; cf. Prakrit cetiya-ghara. (EI 24), the hall for worship or prayer; hall in a monastery.
1125: caityaka-śaila, a stone pillar raised in memory of a dead person on his cremation ground (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 133). See yaṣṭi.
1126: caity-ālaya (EI 7), same as caitya. (EI 3; SII 1), a Jain temple; same as caity-āgāra.
1127: caitya-paṭṭa (LL), Buddhist; a slab bearing the represen-tation of a caitya. See cakra-paṭṭa.
1129: caitya-vandana (HA), obeissance to and worship of the Jina with recitation of hymns, etc., and meditating on the qualities of a Jina.
1131: cakalī, a small coin, smaller than the ṭaṃka regarded as (1/02) of a rupee.
1132: cākāntara (EI 3), a village institution of uncertain meaning.
1133: cakra, cf. Cakrin (EI 4); a district; same as maṇḍala. Cf. sakkaram (SITI), wheel of authority; the king's order; an officer entrusted with the execution of the king's order. (CII 3), ‘the discus’; an emblem on seals. Cf. śakkara-kāṇikkai (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; tax paid by potters; also called tirigai-āyam.
1134: cakra-paṭṭa (LL), Buddhist; a slab bearing the represen-tation of a wheel. See caitya-paṭṭa.
1135: Cakravāla-giri (SITI), same as Tamil Śakkaravāḻam; a mythical mountain encircling the earth; the horizon.
1136: cakravarti-kṣetra (IE 8-2; EI 33), the sphere of influence of an Indian imperial ruler lying between the Himalayas and the three seas, viz. Bay of Bengal, Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea; sometimes regarded as conterminous with Āryāvarta or Dākṣiṇātya. See Sircar, Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind., pp. 1 ff.
1137: Cakravartin (IE 8-2; EI 21, 28; CII 3, 4), a title of para-mount sovereignty; the title of an emperor. See Saptama-cakravartin; also Cakreśvara, Cakrin. (IE 8-2), often suffixed to expressions like Pratāpa, Prau-ḍhapratāpa, Bhujabalapratāpa, Niḥśaṅkapratāpa, etc., and some-times also to dynastic names like Yādava. (EI 31), epithet of the Buddha. (IE 8-2), cf. cakravarti-kṣetra.
1139: Cakrin (EI 9), same as Cakravartin. (EI 4, 19), ‘the ruler of a cakra (circle) or district’; title of a provincial ruler.
1140: cakṣus (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; cf. netra. Cf. Pali cakkhu (EI 5), Buddhist; vision, five in number. Cf. cakṣur-vadha, ‘killing at sight’, ‘killing instantaneously’; or probably ‘blinding of the eyes’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 307 and note 1.
1141: Calamartigaṇḍa (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a title of the Kākatīya kings; from Kannaḍa gaṇḍa meaning ‘the husband, lord, master,’ i. e. ‘one who can control or punish’, and Telugu calam meaning ‘obstinacy, rudeness, overbearing’; translated as ‘one who is the controller or punisher of spiteful men or men of overbearing conduct’.
1142: cālī (IA 15), a system of land revenue.
1143: calivaṃdīli, caliveṃdala, caliveṃdra, calipaṃdili (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; halting place for travellers, where they are supplied gratis with milk and whey or with water.
1144: cāmara (IE 8-8), name of a coin; cf. cāmara-māda. (SII 3), a fly-whisk. See cauri, cavarālu.
1145: Cāmara-kumāra, cf. Cavari-kumāra (EI 10), probably, a prince in charge of the fly-whisk which was one of the royal insignia.
1146: cāmara-māḍa (EI 7), name of a coin; cf. cāmara.
1148: Camūnāyaka (EI 27), a general; cf. Senāpati, etc.
1149: Camūpa (IA 10), a general; same as Camūpati, etc.
1150: Camūpati (EI 8-3); a general, same as Senāpati, etc.
1151: Caṇḍa-pracaṇḍa (SITI), divinities guarding the inner shrine of a Viṣṇu temple.
1152: Caṇḍeśvara (SITI), traditional executive of Śiva temples; also called Ādi-dāsa.
1153: Caṇdeśvara-pperuvilai (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; literally, the sale-price of Caṇḍeśvara, the traditional executive of Śiva temples; actually, sale-price of land purchased from a Śiva temple.
1155: candrādityavat (SITI), same as Tamil candrādittaval, candrādittavar; ‘as long as the moon and the sun last’; ‘in perpetuity’.
1162: candra-viśada (LP), ‘as white as the moon’, i. e. guiltless.
1163: candy (IA 26), Anglicised form of khaṇdī, a weight of different value in different parts. See khaṇdikā.
1165: caṅkrama (LL), Prakrit caṃkama (EI 24); a promenade, a walk.
1168: Cāra (IE 8-3; EI 26), a spy; same as Cara; sometimes used in place of Cāṭa. (EI 15), cf. a-cār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra (IE 8-5), probably, passage [of royal officers through a village]; cf. also a-pār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra with pāra (probably, ferrying) instead of cāra.
1170: caraṇa (CII 4; IA 18, 20), a Vedic school; a sect or school studying a particular śākhā of the Vedas; e. g. Taittirīya-caraṇa. (CII 1), same as ācaraṇa; cf. dharma-caraṇa for dharm-ācaraṇa.
1171: Cāraṇa (EI 3), same as Vidyā-cāraṇa, a Jain monk endowed with magical powers. Cf. harita-pakva-sasy-ekṣu-cāraṇa-lavaṇ-opamardana (IE 8-5); grazing of cattle.
1172: caraṇḍi (EI 31), Gujarātī; a narrow passage of water.
1173: carī (EI 33), pasture land; same as carī-kṣetra. (EI 21), grazing tax; grazing land. Cf. cārī.
1174: cārī (LP), Gujarātī cāro, grass; probably, pasture land; cf. carī. (CII 4), grazing tax.
1176: carman (EI 15), cf. a-carm-āṅgāraka (IE 8-5); hide-seat which the villagers were obliged to supply to the touring officers of the king.
1177: caru (EI 10, 22, 23; CII 3, 4), an offering to the manes; one of the five mahāyajñas.
1178: caruka (EI 1), same as caru, one of the five mahāyajñas.
1180: cash (IE 8-8), Anglicised form of Tamil kāśu; name of a small copper coin.
1181: caṭ, cf. alīkaṃ caṭāpitam (LP), ‘circulated a false rumour’. Cf. caṭanti (LP); ‘to accumulate’; also cf. Gujarātī caḏhśe.
1182: Cāṭa (HD), irregular soldiers according to Fleet and Bühler. Vogel (Ant. Ch. St., pp. 130-32) points out that Chamba is the only place where the ancient word Cāṭa is still extant in the modern form Cāḏ meaning ‘the head of a Parganā’. An important privilege of a gift village was ‘not to be entered by Cāṭas and Bhaṭas’. Inscriptions (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 221) often specify that the granted land was not to be entered by Cāṭas and Bhaṭas except for seizing robbers and those guilty of harm or treason to the king (cf. a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśyaṃ cora-drohaka-varjam in op. cit., Vol. VIII, p. 287). Sometimes we have bhaṭa-cāṭa-sevak-ādīn (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 211) and caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-jātīyān janapadān (ibid., Vol. XIV, p. 160). (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4), generally mentioned along with bhaṭa; sometimes replaced by cāra (spy) and chātra (literally, ‘umbrella-bearer’, but really, a constable, i. e. a Pāik or Piāda); probably indicates the leader of a group of Bhaṭas, i. e. Pāiks and Piādas; a policeman leading a group of Pāiks. See caṭṭa. Yājñavalkya, I. 336, speaks of the duty of the king to protect people from the harassment caused by cāṭas, robbers and Kāyasthas and the Mitākṣarā explains cāṭa as persons who deprive people of their wealth after creating false confi-dence in them. According to Bṛhaspati quoted by Aparārka, ‘dangers common to all are those arising from the cāṭas and thieves’. The word cāṭa in the passage tārkika-cāṭa-bhaṭa-rāj-āpraveśya in Śaṅkara's Bhāsya on the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad is explained by Ānandagiri by saying that the cāṭas are those that transgress the rules of conduct for decent people and that bhaṭas are servants telling falsehood (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 296). But cāṭa is used in inscriptions in the sense of a royal official.
1183: caṭāpaka (LP), ‘increasing [the rent already fixed]’; cf. Gujarātī caḏhāvo.
1184: caṭāpya (LP), ‘to be entered [on the back of the bond]’; cf. Gujarātī caḏhāvavā.
1185: ca-ṭī abbreviation of an expression probably meaning ‘a mound suitable for planting fruit trees’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 56. Cf. ṭī.
1186: caṭita (LP), one who makes an attack. (LP), accumulated. Cf. khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-caṭita-pratiṣaṃskāra; a crack.
1187: Caṭṭa (EI 25), Tamil corruption of Sanskrit Chātra; a student. (IE 8-3), cf. a-caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-praveśa (IE 8-5); same as Cāṭa of earlier records.
1188: caṭṭanā (LP), food; sauce; cf. Gujarātī cāṭvuṃ, licking.
1189: cāṭu (IA 15), probably, a spoon. (EI 32), a eulogistic stanza.
1190: catuḥ-śāla, catuḥ-śālā (EI 20; SITI), a cloister. (SITI), a meeting hall; see catuś-śālā. (EI 24), same as catur-ālaya.
1191: cātu-paḍi (CITD), Telugu; an offering of food to the deity.
1193: caturaka (LP), same as Sanskrit catvara; Gujarātī coro; a public place in a village, or a police station; probably, a tax for the maintenance of a police station. (IE 8-4), a small territorial unit.
1194: catur-ālaya (EI 24), known, especially from Tamil inscrip-tions, in the sense of ‘a hall or pavilion attached to a temple’; also called caṭuḥ-śālā.
1197: caturaśīti (IE 8-4), a territorial unit like a Parganā; see caurāsī.
1198: caturdanta-samara, cāturdanta-samara, a war of elephants; cf. ghoṭaka-vigraha. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXVI, p. 8.
1199: caturdaśa-vidyā-sthāna (CII 3), the fourteen sections of science.
1200: Caturdhara-pratīhāra, cf. Kannaḍa Sodare-vadiyara (Hydera-bad Archaeological Series, No. 18, p. 34); explained as ‘the chief of the royal guards’. Caturdhara is modern Caudhari, written in Kannaḍa as Saudore, Saudare, Caudore, Cavudore and Cavudari and explained as ‘an officer of the royal guard’.
1201: cāturdiśa (EI 23; ML), ‘belonging to all the quarters’; cf. cāturdiś-ārya-bhikṣu-saṅgha, ‘Buddhist monks of all places’; ‘all monks coming from different places’.
1203: caturjātaka (IE 8-3), same as cauthiā, an administrative board of four members known from the Pañcāyat system of Western India; cf. pañcakula or pañcāyat. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 193. See caukaḍikā. (EI 20), four fragrant articles, viz. tvak, elā, patraka and nāgakesara.
1204: Cāturjātaka (EI 1), a member of the caturjātaka or cauthiā (q. v.). Cf. Pañcakulika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 193.
1205: Caturjātakīya, same as Cāturjātaka (EI 1); a member of the caturjātaka (q. v.); cf. Pañcakulika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 193.
1206: cāturmāsī (EI 2; CII 1), the full-moon tithis of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika.
1207: cāturmāsī-pakṣa (IA 18), the fortnight ending in a cātur-māsī (i. e. the full-moon of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika).
1208: cāturmāsya (SII 11-1, CITD), the season consisting of 4 months, viz. grīṣma consisting of the pūrṇimānta months of Caitra, Vaiśākha, Jyeṣṭha and Āṣāḍha, varṣā consisting of Śrāvana, Bhādrapada, Āśvina and Kārttika; and hemanta consisting of Mārgaśīrṣa, Pauṣa, Māgha and Phālguna. This was the official division of the year which was popularly divided into six seasons, viz. grīṣma (Jyeṣṭha-Āṣāḍha), varṣā (Śrāvaṇa-Bhādra-pada), śarad (Āśvina-Kārttika), hemanta (Mārgaśīrṣa-Pauṣa), śīta (Māgha-Phālguna) and vasanta (Caitra-Vaiśākha). Some times, the word cāturmāsya specially means the four months of the year, containing the two seasons of varṣā and śarad, i. e. from Śrāvaṇa to Kārttika. During this period, Viṣṇu is supposed to sleep, so that religious celebrations are avoided. During the period, religious mendicants desisted from roving. (EI 7; BL), related to the cāturmāsī or the full-moon day of Phālguna, Āshāḍha and Kārttika; a rite; same as cātur-māsya-vrata.
1210: caturmukha-bimba (EI 2), Jain; a four-sided slab with images on all the sides.
1211: caturtha (IE 8-8), one-fourth of the standard measure [of liquids like liquor].
1213: caturthī-amāvāsyā, cf. cauti-amāvāse (EI 5), the new-moon following the Gaṇeśa-caturthī.
1214: cāturvaidya-maryādā (EI 27), custom relating to rent-free land granted to learned Brāhmaṇas.
1215: caturvarṇin (LL), Jain; ‘consisting of four classes’; an epithet of the Jain community.
1216: caturvedi-bhaṭṭa-ttāna-pperumakkaḻ (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; general assembly of the Vedic scholars in a Brāhmaṇa village.
1217: caturvedi-maṅgala (IE 8-4; SITI), same as agrahāra; a village owned by Brāhmaṇas, generally tax-free; also called maṅgala; written as śaruppeṭi-maṅgalam in Tamil; sometimes suffix-ed to names of localities especially in the Tamil-speaking area.
1218: Caturvedin (EI 23, 24; CII 3, 4; SII 1), a Brāhmaṇa versed in the four Vedas; one who has studied the four Vedas; later stereotyped as a family name among Brāhmaṇas.
1219: cāturvīdya (EI 23, 32), cf. Caturvedin; ‘relating to the Caturvedin’, a community of Brāhmaṇas; cf. cāturvidya-grāma, cāturvidy-āgrahāra, cāturvidya-sāmānya (EI 22).
1220: catur-upāya (SII 1), the four expedients. Cf. upāya.
1221: caturviṃśati-tīrthaṅkara-paṭṭa (EI 2), a slab with the images o all the 24 Jain Tīrthaṅkaras. See covīsī.
1222: catuṣkikā (EI 19; CII 4), a hall; a hall resting on four pillars (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 75).
1223: catuṣpatha (LP), a place where four roads meet.
1224: catuś-śālā (SITI), a meeting hall; see catuḥ-śālā.
1225: catvāraka (IA 17), used in the sense of catuṣṭaya.
1226: Chau° (PJS), contraction of Caudharī (Caturdhara) especially in medieval Jain inscriptions.
1227: caukaḍikā (EI 11), a variety of the Pañcāyat system; cf. caturjātaka or cauthiā. (BL), explained as ‘a method of recovering stolen property’.
1228: caumukha (HA), Sanskrit caturmukha (cf. caturmukha-bimba); a quadruple image called pratimā sarvatobhadrikā (LL) in the Mathurā inscriptions of the Kuṣāṇa period, showing one Jina or several Jinas on each of the four faces; also seen on the top or in the centre of representations of the samavasaraṇa (q. v.).
1230: caurāsī (IE 8-4; EI 3, 4), literally, ‘eightyfour’; same as caturaśīti (q. v.); a group of eightyfour villages; a Parganā consisting of eightyfour villages; sometimes the name of a Parganā and often suffixed to its name.
1231: caura-varjam (CII 3; HRS), cf. cora-varjam, coradaṇda-varjam, cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam; ‘with immunity from the police tax’ according to some; may really mean ‘without any right to inflict punishment on thieves and persons committing the crime of treason or to levy fines from them’; may also be connected with a-bhaṭa-praveśa so as to indicate that the bhaṭas should not enter except for catching thieves and persons committing the crime of treason; cf. Cāṭa.
1232: cauri (ASLV), spelt chowrie in English; a flywhisk; some-times the right of its use was granted to persons as a mark of honour. See cāmara, cavarālu.
1233: Caurika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71), official designation. Cf. Cāmara-kumāra, Caur-oddharaṇika.
1235: caur-oddharaṇa (EI 33; HRS), according to some, the right to punish or levy fines from thieves; probably, the right to recover stolen property; recovery of stolen property; cf. sa-chauroddharaṇa (IE 8-5; EI 23).
1236: Caur-oddharaṇika (IE 8-3; EI 23; CII 3), an official desig-nation indicating an officer in charge of the recovery of stolen property; a police officer; same as Cor-oddharaṇika, Caur-oddhartṛ. (HD; CII, Vol. III, p. 216), explained as ‘the thief-catcher or one who exterminates thieves’. But cf. Daṇḍ-odddharaṇika.
1237: Caur-oddhartṛ (HD), same as Caur-oddharaṇika (cf. Yājña-valkyasmṛti, II. 271; also Kātyāyana quoted by Aparārka).
1238: cauthiā (IE 8-3; EI 33), an administrative board consis-ting of four members headed by the Nagarseṭh (Nagaraśreṣṭhin) as known from the Pañcāyat system of Western India; cf. caturjātaka, caukaḍikā.
1239: cāvaḍi (IE 8-4; SITI; ASLV), same as śāvaḍi or uśāvaḍi; an administrative unit or a territorial division. (EI 16), same as rājya; a district or subdivision.
1240: cavala (EI 6), name of a coin, (1/8) of a pagoda; cf. cāmara, cavela.
1241: cavarālu (CITD), Telugu; also called savarālu, savara-mulu; the hair of the camarī-mṛga, used by women as queue; also cavara, camara or cāmara, the chowrie (cauri) or long brush or fan usually made of the tail of the yak, which was one of the insignia of royalty.
1243: cavathe, a levy of one-fourth; see chavathā.
1244: cavela (EI 6), same as cavala; name of a coin, (1/8) of a pagoda. Cf. cāmara.
1245: ceṭaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 78), an attendant; some-times mentioned in the list of officials.
1246: cha (PJS) written as a mark indicating the end of a section of a record or of the whole of it. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 218.
1247: cha-cokī (HA), Sanskrit ṣaṭ-catuṣkikā; a hall adjacent to and in front of the gūḍha-maṇḍapa, with its ceiling divided into six sections by the pillars supporting it.
1248: Chadmastha (HA), a would-be Jina [living a monk's life] before attainment of kevala-jñāna. Cf. Bodhisattva.
1249: chādya, cf. tṛṇa-cchādya, thatch-covering (Ep. Ind., XXXIV, p. 145); same as Gujarātī chāj, thatch.
1250: chala (IE 8-8), meaning uncertain; probably, a pretext. (EI 30), probably, a plea, or persecution, prosecution.
1253: chaṅga (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 310), a measure of grain.
1254: chandovicita, the metrical science (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 146).
1256: chatra, an umbrella; cf. pañcāṅga-prasāda. (EI 27), an attendant or Piāda; cf. Chātra. Cf. Varāha-kṣetra = Barāh-chatra (Sircar, Studies in the Geography of Ancient and Medieval India, p. 221); corruption of Sanskrit kṣetra.
1257: Chātra (IE 8-3, 8-8; EI 23, 30), cf. a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya (IE 8-5); literally, ‘one bearing an umbrella’ or ‘the king's umbrella-bearer’; but probably the same as the Cāṭa or the leader of a group of Bhaṭas (Pāiks or Piādas) as in a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-prāveśya; a peon of the law-court. See Chatracchāyika. (CII 3), used in composition with bhaṭa and also singly; literally, ‘an umbrella-bearer’; but actually, a constable like a Pāik or Piāda. (SITI), celibate (Brahmacārin) in charge of a temple and the śālai attached to it; also called Śaṭṭar, Śāttirar.
1258: chatra-bhaṅga (IA 8), ‘the breaking of the umbrella [of sovereignty]’; sometimes interpreted as ‘an interregnum’.
1259: chatr-ābhoga (IA 17), corrected from ṣatr-ābhoga and explained as ‘the expanse of the royal umbrella’; but really, ‘the ābhoga (a territorial unit) called Ṣa(Kha)tra’.
1260: Chatracchāyika (IE 8-3; HD), an umbrella-bearer; the king's umbrella-bearer. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 128. Cf. Chātra.
1261: chatra-yaṣṭi (LL), an umbrella on a post.
1262: chavathā (IA 18), cf. viṃśati-chavathā, a levy of doubtful implication; may be a levy of 6 out of a unit of 20; cf. cavathe.
1264: chāyā-dīpa (EI 33), a lamp held by an image, often arranged to burn continuously in front of a deity in a temple; cf. akhaṇḍa-dīpa.
1265: chāyā-stambha (EI 33, 35), memorial pillar bearing image of the deceased.
1266: cheda (EI 13), a quarter, area or subdivision; cf. Brahma-cāri-ccheda.
1269: Chimpaka (IE 8-8; EI 30), a dyer of clothes; same as Prakrit Chimpaya.
1270: choha, same as Gujarātī cho, mortar (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
1271: choṭyamāna, cf. choṭyamāna-gṛhe (LP), ‘when the house is being vacated’.
1272: choultry, Anglicised form of a Dravidian word; a dharma-śālā.
1273: churi-prabandha (BL), name of a grant made in favour of a Churikāra, ‘a maker of churis’. The word churi may be the same as kṣurikā, ‘a knife’, and a Churikāra may have been an officer in charge of the production of knives and swords.
1274: chuṭ (LP), cf. choṭanīya; Gujarātī choḏāvavuṃ; also cf. granthi-baddhair = api drammaiḥ kṣetraṃ choṭayituṃ dhāraṇiko na labhate, ‘[when the date is already over], the debtor will not get his farm liberated by the ready money tied in a piece of cloth’. Cf. patra-grahāt chuṭanti (LP), ‘will be free from the bond’; also Gujarātī chaṭśe.
1276: ci-khi, abbreviation of cira-khila, ‘[land] never brought under cultivation’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 56).
1279: Cīna-pagoda (SII 12), ‘Chinese shrine’; name of a Buddhist temple at Nāgapaṭṭanam.
1280: cinna (EI 3; SITI), name of a coin; sometimes regarded as a fanam (CITD); also spelt sinna in Telugu; a weight equal to (1/30) of a tola and called a Canteroy fanam; one-eighth part of a coin called pagoda; the weight of 4 guri-giñjas.
1282: cira-khila (EI 30), land which was never cultivated.
1283: cira-khila-śūnya (EI 23), epithet of gift land; fallow land.
1284: cirañjīva (EI 30), ‘long-lived’; epithet of living (not dead) persons.
1286: ciravida (CITD), Telugu; name of a coin; probably a special kind of gadyāṇa.
1287: cīrikā (EI 26), a document; cf. kraya-cīrikā, ‘a deed of purchase’, i. e. a sale-deed.
1288: cīrṇa-vrat-opāyanaka (LP), the gift (upāyana) for the vows practised. Cf. Sel. Ins., p. 210, text line 14.
1289: ciṭalā (IE 8-5), a tax; cf. coṭāla, ciṭola.
1290: cīṭhikā (LP), a chit; cf. Gujarātī ciṭṭhī.
1291: ciṭola (IE 8-5), a tax or obligation of uncertain import.
1294: Citraka (IA 8), ‘a painter’; epithet of the engraver of an inscription.
1297: citra-bhāsa (ASLV), paintings on the walls and ceilings of temples.
1298: citramel13i (SITI), also spelt śittiramel13i, an organisation of the agriculturists; agricultural corporation of the Vĕḻḻāḻas; the plough which was the emblem of this organisation; the boundary stone with the representation of the plough emblem planted to mark the limits of their land.
1299: cīvara, cf. cīvarika (EI 8); garments of Buddhist monks.
1300: cīvarika (EI 8), expenses of cīvara; Sanskrit caivarika.
1304: collika (EI 3), collikā (EI 10), a load [of leaves]; a quantity of betel leaves.
1305: cora (IE 8-5), same as caura and cora-daṇḍa; probably, the power of punishing thieves and realising fines from them; cf. cora-varja; also Cāṭa.
1307: cora-daṇḍa-varjya (CII 3), a fiscal term which means either that no fines for theft should be collected from the gift village or, more probably, that the donee was not entitled to fines realisable on thieves in the gift villages. But see also caura-varjam.
1308: cora-drohaka-varja (CII 3, etc.), a fiscal term which is similar to coradaṇḍa-varja. The word drohaka means one committing a crime against the king. See caura-varjam, Cāḷa.
1309: Cora-grāha (HD), a thief-catcher (cf. Nārada, Pariśiṣṭa, verse 18; also Kātyāyana quoted by Aparārka).
1310: cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam (HRS), ‘with immunity from the police tax’, according to some; seems to mean ‘without any right to inflict punishment on or levy fines from thieves and rebels’. But see caura-varjam; also Cāṭa.
1311: cora-rajjū (HRS), ‘the rope for binding thieves’; supposed to be the dues collected by the superintendent of the bound-aries of villages.
1312: Corarajjuka (HD), probably the same as Dāṇdapāśika, an officer whose duty it was to secure robbers with ropes (cf. Arthaśāstra, IV. 13; II. 6 referring to cora-rajjū as a constituent of the rāṣṭra).
1314: cora-varja, also spelt cora-varjya (CII 3; HRS); a fiscal term which is the same as coradaṇḍa-varjya (q. v.). See also caura-varja.
1317: Cor-oddharaṇika (EI 28, 30), same as Caur-oddharaṇika; a police officer in charge of the recovery of stolen goods; explained by some as ‘the eradicator of thieves’ (CII 4). But cf. Daṇdoddharaṇika.
1319: coṭāla (IE 8-5), a tax of uncertain import; cf. ciṭola, ciṭalā.
1320: covīsī (HA); Sanskrit caturviṃśati or caturviṃśati-paṭṭa; a group of the 24 Jinas carved on one stone slab or cast in bronze together.
1321: cūḍā (IA 11), the top knot of hair; cf. cūḻā.
1322: cūḍāmaṇi (IA 26), an eclipse on certain days.
1323: cukka, error, fault (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 7, note 4).
1325: cullaka, cf. a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa (IE 8-5), ex-plained as ‘a pot’, i. e. cooking pot. The villagers were obliged to supply it to the touring officers of the king.
1328: cūnā, same as Sanskrit cūrṇa, lime (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
1329: Cūṇakara, same as Sanskrit Cūrṇakāra, a lime-burner or white-washer (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 145).
1330: Cūrakāra, cf. Cūṟakāra (CITD), from Telugu-Kannaḍa cūṟa and Sanskrit kāra; ‘one who has plundered’.
1331: cūrṇi (EI 3), an appended note. Cf. cūrṇī.
1332: cūrṇi, cūrṇī (EI 29, 33), one hundred cowrie-shells; cowrie-shells of the value of a purāṇa or kārṣāpaṇa (kāhaṇ).
1333: dabhra-sabhā (SII 3), the golden hall in the Chhidam-baram temple.
1334: dāḍhā (CII 4), a canine tooth; derived from Sanskrit daṃṣṭrā.
1335: dadhi (IE 7-12), confused with udadhi and used to indi-cate ‘four’. Cf. a-dugdha-dadhi-grahaṇa (IE 8-5); curds which the villagers (probably, the milkmen) were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions and to the touring officers.
1339: Daivāgārika (EI 7), the priest in charge of a temple or an officer in charge of temples. (IE 8-3), probably, a priest of the shrine of the king's tute-lary deity; sometimes mentioned as a Pātra.
1340: Daivajña (IE 8-3; EI 7), an astrologer; sometimes men-tioned as a Pātra.
1341: Daivaputra (IE 8-2; EI 30), same as Devaputra; title of certain kings of the Kuṣāṇa dynasty; derived from a Chinese title meaning ‘the Son of Heaven’.
1342: daivya (SITI), an act of the gods.
1343: dakṣa, used in the late Tantra literature in the sense of dakṣiṇa, ‘the south’ (cf. Sircar, Studies in the Georgraphy of Ancient and Medieval India, p. 76, note 19).
1345: dakṣiṇā (EI 32), perquisite. (BL), a present or gift to a Brāhmaṇa for a service. (CII 1), cf. prāṇa-dakṣinā, same as prāṇa-dāna.
1346: Dakṣiṇa-bhuja (SITI), ‘the right hand’; a trusted lieutenant.
1348: Dakṣiṇāpatha (CII 3), ‘the region of the south’; a name for Southern India.
1349: Dakṣiṇāpatha-sādhāra (CII 3), ‘the Pillar of Dakṣiṇāpatha’; title of a ruler. Sādhāra may be a mistake for sv-ādhāra.
1350: dakṣiṇāvarta-śaṅkha (SII 1), a conch-shell with convolutions from left to right.
1351: dakṣiṇ-āyana (IA 19), the period during which the sun moves from south to north; cf. uttar-āyaṇa (IA 17).
1352: dakṣiṇī, dākṣiṇya, cf. Prakrit dachini (ML); same as dakṣiṇā.
1353: dākṣiṇya, cf. dakṣiṇya (EI 23); same as dakṣiṇā.
1354: Dala-adhikāri (IE 8-3; SITI; ASLV), Dravidian-Sans-krit; same as Sainyādhikārin or Senāpati, Dalada-adhikāri or Dalavāy, a commander of forces.
1355: Dalada-adhikāri (ASLV), same as Dala-adhikāri or Dalavāy, the commander of forces.
1356: Dalavāy (IE 8-3; ASLV; SITI), same as Dala-adhikāri, Dalada-adhikāri or Senāpati; the commander of forces; some-times also enjoying the title Daṇdanāyaka.
1357: Dalavāy-agrahāra (ASLV), village granted for military service.
1358: Dalavāyi (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a general, a chief-tain, or the minister of state; same as Dalavāy.
1359: Dala-vṛtti (CITD), from Telugu-Kannaḍa dala, ‘army’, and Sanskrit vṛtti; probably, a grant for the maintenance of the army.
1360: dama, cf. dāma (EI 23); same as dramma (q. v.).
1361: dāma (EI 27; CII 4), name of a coin; derived from dramma. (EI 19), abbreviation of the name Dāmodara.
1363: damanaka-caturdaśī (EI 23), same as Caitra su-di 14; also called damanaka-parvan.
1365: ḍāmara (EI 12), tumultuous, terrible; a landlord or wealthy cultivator possessing much land [in ancient Kashmir], according to the Rājataraṅgiṇī.
1366: damma (SITI), same as dramma; name of a coin; derived from Greek drachma.
1367: dāna, dānā (ML), a gift. (HRS), known from Maitraka records to mean the so-called voluntary gifts of subjects. Cf. dānā-sambandhe (LP), ‘as regards the sale-tax’.
1368: dāṇa (IE 8-5; LP), same as dāna, road-cess; customs duties; cf. the official designation Dāṇī (Sanskrit Dānin).
1370: dānādāya-dānībhoga (LP), explained as ‘local cess or road-cess’; dāya is explained as ‘a gift to Brāhmaṇas or temples’, dānī as ‘land tax’ and bhoga as ‘right of enjoyment’; but probably, dāṇ-ādāya means excise or customs duties and dāni-bhoga a tax for the maintenance of the tax-collector.
1371: Dān-ādhikārin (EI 12), officer in charge of gifts, mentioned along with the Śāsan-ādhikārika, ‘officer in charge of grants (or their writing)’. See Dharm-ādhikārin. It may also mean ‘a tolls-collector’ (cf. dāna, Dānin).
1373: dāna-mukha (EI 7; ML), a gift; the principal gift; same as deya-dharma.
1374: dāna-palaṃ (IA 11), actually dāna(ṃ*)palaṃ, i. e. ‘the dāna (levy) is one pala’.
1375: Dānapati (EI 28, 30; HD), one who gives a gift; one who dedicates the images of a deity (especially as the result of a previous vow); probably, also an official designation; see Horamurta (CII 2-1), Dānādhikārin.
1376: dāna-ppuṟam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; land set apart for the purpose of charity.
1378: dāna-śālā (IA 11), a hall for the distribution of gifts.
1379: dāna-volāpana (LP), dāna (road-cess) and volāpana (tax; cf. Gujarātī valāvaṇuṃ). See Volāpika.
1381: daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 12), fine or tax, mentioned along with suṅka (śulka); a levy or free service (cf. prayāṇa-daṇda). (EI 24), fines; authority. (HRS), fines; distinguished from atyaya in the Artha-śāstra. (CII 1), punishment. (ASLV), judicial punishment; sometimes possibly also ‘administration’. (EI 25), ‘five’. (EI 30; LP), contraction of Daṇdanāyaka. (EI 28), Oḏiyā; a path (cf. daṇḍā). Cf. taṇḍu (SITI), a palanquin; a pole for carrying the vehicle on which the image of a deity is set up. Cf. daṇḍu, taṇḍu (SITI), an army; going on a military expedition. Cf. taṇdam (SII 1; CITD); fine, penalty or punishment; a punitive tax; a fine or tax payable as penalty.
1382: daṇḍā (EI 31), Oḏiyā; a boundary line or road. See daṇḍa.
1383: Dāṇḍabhogika (HD), same as Dāṇdapāśika (q. v.), or the police magistrate. See Ep. Ind., Vol XIII, p. 339.
1384: daṇḍa-daś-āparādha (CII 4), fines including those imposed for the ten offences; same as daś-āparādha. See daṇḍadoṣa-daś-āparādha, daṇḍa-śulka, etc.
1385: daṇḍ-ādāya (EI 20), fines; see Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 253-54.
1386: Daṇḍādhinātha (EI 16; SII 1; HD), same as Daṇḍapāla, Daṇḍanāyaka, etc. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XIV, p. 55.
1387: Daṇḍādhināyaka (SII 1), a general; same as Daṇḍādhinātha.
1388: Daṇḍādhipa (BL; HD), the commander of forces; same as Daṇḍapāla, Daṇḍādhipati, etc. See the commentary on the Yaśastilaka, I, p. 91; Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 151.
1389: Daṇḍādhipati (EI 26), cf. Daṇdanāyaka, etc. (LP), explained as ‘a governor’.
1391: daṇḍa-doṣa, cf. sa-daṇḍadoṣa (EI 23); fines. See daṇḍa.
1392: daṇḍadoṣa-daśāparādha (HRS), same as daṇḍa-daśāpa-rādha; cf. sahya-daś-āparādha; sa-daśāparādha means ‘with the privilege of remission for the ten offences’, according to some; seems to mean ‘with the right to enjoy fines for the ten offences’; cf. daś-āparādha.
1393: daṇḍaka (EI 30), probably, a regulation. (IE 8-8), meaning uncertain; probably, fines. Cf. daṇḍaku (IA 16), a boundary mark or land-mark.
1394: daṇḍa-kkāṇam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; amount imposed as fine; cf. daṇḍam kuṟṟam (EI 30; SITI), a levy of fines; fine and penalty imposed.
1396: Daṇḍanātha (EI 16; CII 4; SII 1), commander of an army. See Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 31. Cf. Daṇḍanāyaka, etc.
1397: Daṇḍanāyaka (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 4; BL), probably a translation of Greek Strategos; a general; a leader of forces, an army officer; a military commander; also called Daṇḍa-nātha, Daṇdanetṛ, etc.; sometimes also called Mahāsāmanta, Senādibāhattaraniyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, Mahāpasāyita, etc., additionally; see Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Sarva-daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka. (LP), generally, the viceroy or governor of a province; representative of the king. (ASLV), the commander of forces and officer in charge of administration; title of the provincial governors; similar to the Mansabdār of the Mughal period. (HD), a prefect of the police, according to Stein (Rāja-taraṅgiṇī, VII. 951); ‘a General or Magistrate’, according to some (cf. Kielhorn's Southern List, Nos. 291, 292, 296). In the Bṛhatsaṃhitā (7. 2-4), the queen, Yuvarāja, Senāpati and Daṇḍanāyaka are placed on the same level in the matter of the staff (daṇḍa) to be prepared for them. Cf. Taḍeya-daṇḍanāyaka, explained as ‘the general in charge of reserves’, from Kannaḍa, taḍĕ, ‘far, restraint’.
1398: Dāṇḍanāyaka (EI 23; HD), same as Daṇdanāyaka. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 269.
1399: Daṇḍanetṛ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 233), designation of a leader of forces; cf. Daṇḍanāyaka, etc.
1400: Daṇḍapāla (HD), an officer in charge of all branches of the army (Arthaśāstra, I. 12); cf. Daṇḍanāyaka. (IE 8-3), cf. Dāṇḍika.
1402: Daṇḍaparīkṣā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIX, p. 101); Oḏiyā; a governor; same as Sanskrit Daṇḍaparīkṣaka as well as Daṇda-nāyaka of other inscriptions; governor of a daṇḍapāṭa or province.
1403: Daṇḍapāśika (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), a policeman; an official who was probably the leader of a group of Dāṇḍikas; officer in charge of punishment (i. e. criminal justice), accord-ing to some; a policeman (same as Oḏiyā Daṇḍuāsi meaning ‘a village watchman’); called Talāra and Ārakṣika (IHQ), December 1960, p. 266). See Yaśastilaka, I, p. 50; Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 83; Vol. XII, p. 9. Cf. Dāṇḍabhogika.
1404: Dāṇḍapāśika (IE 8-3; EI 23; CII 3, 4; HD), same as Daṇḍapāśika or Daṇḍapāṇika, ‘an officer entrusted with the punishment of criminals’; see Pañcatantra II, Kathā 4 (spelt Daṇḍapāśaka meaning ‘a watchman’); Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 94.
1405: daṇḍapāṭa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIX, p. 107); Oḏiyā; the province of a kingdom; an administrative unit under a Daṇḍa-parīkṣā; cf. Daṇḍa or Daṇdanāyaka called Daṇḍaparīkṣā in the Orissan records; also paṭṭa in the sense of ‘a district’.
1406: Daṇḍapati (BL; HD), a commander of forces, or a governor; same as Daṇdanātha, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, pp. 148, 156.
1407: Daṇḍaśakti (IE 8-3; HD), a police officer; possibly the same as Dāṇḍika or Daṇḍapāśika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 250.
1408: daṇḍa-śulka, cf. daṇḍa-śulk-ādi-vividh-āya-samanvita (EI 23); income from fines and tolls.
1410: Daṇḍavāsika (HD), Prakrit form of Daṇḍapāśika. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 129.
1412: daṇḍ-āya (IA 29; SII 11-1), income from fines; explain-ed as ‘a tax’; cf. ‘the whole of the levy called daṇḍ-āya as much as accrued in the village’.
1413: Daṇḍeśa (EI 5; SII 1; HD), official designation; same as Daṇḍanātha. See JBBRAS, Vol. XV, p. 386.
1414: Daṇḍika (HD), same as Daṇḍapāśika. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 166. (CII 4), explained by some as a magistrate. Cf. Dāṇḍika.
1415: Dāṇḍika (CII 3; HD), a police officer. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306; CII, Vol. III, p. 216; Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321. Generally Dāṇḍika and Dāṇḍapāśika are mentioned side by side (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 231); probably the Dāṇḍika was the head of a group or outpost of the Dāṇḍapāśikas. Cf. Daṇḍika, Daṇḍ-oddharaṇika (collector of fines).
1416: daṇḍikā (SITI), also called daṇḍu; a palanquin.
1417: daṇḍikā-jīvita (SITI), tax-free land given to palanquin-bearers for enjoyment during their life-time.
1419: Daṇḍ-oddharaṇika (EI 9), literally, ‘collector of fines’; mentioned along with Daṇḍapāśika; may be the same as Dāṇḍika. Cf. Caur-oddharaṇika.
1421: Daṇḍoparika (EI 13), probably Daṇda (i. e. Daṇdanāyaka) and Uparika; otherwise Daṇḍoparika may mean a judge.
1422: daṇḍa (ASLV), a palanquin; its use was a privilege some-times specially granted to favourites or distinguished persons by the king.
1423: Daṇḍuāsi (IE 8-3), Oḏiyā; village watchman; derived from Sanskrit Dāṇḍapāśika.
1424: daṇḍudova (ASLV), a military route. See daṇḍinadāri.
1425: ḍāṅg (IA 26), also spelt dāṅk, corrupt form of ṭaṅka.
1426: dāṇi (HRS), known from Caulukya records and explained by some as ‘the king's dues’; perquisite of the collector of the duties called dāṇa or dāna.
1427: Dānī (IE 8-5; EI 26), i. e. Dānin, officer collecting tax or corn; officer storing the corn collected as tax from the farmers.
1428: dāni-bhāga, same as dāṇi-bhoga (q. v.). See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 256.
1429: dāṇi-bhoga (HRS), periodical supplies of fruits, firewood and the like by the villagers, according to some; tax for main-taining the collectors of the tax called dāna; same as dāṇi-bhoga-bhāga.
1431: Dānī-volāpika (LP), explained as ‘the collector of dānī (land cess) and volāpanā (tax, relating to Gujarātī vaḻāvaṇuṃ).’ See Volāpika.
1433: Daṇṇāik (ASLV), corrupt form of Daṇḍanāyaka; some-times the designation of a judge at the capital of the Vijaya-nagara kings.
1434: Daṇṇāyaka (IE 8-3; ASLV), corrupt form of Daṇḍanāyaka; a designation sometimes enjoyed by the Dala-adhikāri or commander of forces.
1436: Dantakāra (LL), a worker in ivory; here danta means hasti-danta.
1438: Dāpaka (EI 3; BL; HD), usually regarded as the same as Dūtaka; but really ‘one who causes another to give’, i. e. the creator of a rent-free holding which was ratified by the king. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, pp. 177, 243. (CII 1), a matter relating to giving gifts.
1439: dāpana, cf. dāpanāya (LP), ‘for making one pay’. See dāvāpana.
1441: dāradraṇaka (CII 3), a fiscal term of uncertain implication; an agricultural cess or marriage tax, according to some. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 242.
1442: Dāraka (IA 18; CII 1), explained as ‘the son of a king, whose mother's rank does not assure him an official title’.
1444: darśana (IE 8-5; EI 32, 33), a levy; same as Persian nazrāna. Cf. Tamil tariśana-kāṇikkai (SITI), presents offered to a king or a chief when one meets him. (CII 1), used in the sense of pradarśana, ‘showing’. (IE 7-1-2), ‘six’; cf. dṛṣti, ‘two’. (IA 14), used in the sense of ‘a religious procession for the purpose of visiting a deity’.
1445: darśapūrṇamāsa (CII 4), name of a Vedic sacrifice.
1446: darśa-tithi (EI 13), name of a tithi. Cf. darśa.
1449: daśabandha (SITI), variously explained as (1) one-tenth of the revenue set apart for repairs to the tanks and wells for irrigation purposes; (2) land, the income from which would be equal to the amount thus set apart; (3) the right of collect-ing one-tenth of the produce of lands irrigated from the waters of a tank or well by the person who repairs the water source; also explained as tax equal to one-tenth of the income of the subject (Ray, DHNI, Vol. II, p. 1113). See daśavandha. (SITI) tax or cess levied to keep the source of water supply like the tanks, etc., in good repair. (EI 4), rent-free land or probably land paying only one-tenth of the actual rent. (EI 20), one-tenth share. Cf. daśa-bandhe (LP), ‘at 10 per cent’. Cf. daśavandha (SII 3), a tax.
1452: Dāśagrāmika (IE 8-3; EI 24), the headman of a group of ten villages or the chairman of the council of a group of ten villages.
1454: daśa-kriyā (SITI), work of the architects who were to look after the repairs of temples.
1455: Daśamūlika (CII 4), official designation; same as Daśamūlin (q. v.).
1456: Daśamūlin (EI 21; CII 4; BL), an official designation; probably, a physician; same as Daśamūlika.
1458: daś-āparādha (CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the ten offences’; but really, the fines for the ten offences; cf. sa-daś-āparādha (IE 8-5); power to punish and realise fines for the ten offences; also called daś-āpacāra. According to the Buddhists, the ten sins were murder, theft, adultery, lying, calumny, insult, idle talk, hatred, covetousness and dogmatic error (A. Getty, The Gods of Northern Buddhism, p. xxv, note). For a Brahmanical list, see Dāśāparādhika; cf. pañca-mahāpātaka, pañc-āparādha.
1459: Dāśāparādhika (IE 8-3; EI 29; HD), a judge dealing with the ten offences (viz. theft, murder of women, adultery, use of abusive language, violation of order, mixing of castes, illegal pregnancy, obscenity, assault and abortion, according to some). It has been said that the ten offences or aparādhas are those of which the king could take cognisance suo moto. For the ten aparādhas, see Kane, Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 264; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321.
1462: Dāśari (ASLV; SITI), a class of subordinates of the headman of particular communities in the Vijayanagara empire; same as Samayācāra or Samayācārya.
1463: daśavandha, cf. daśavanna (IA 30), explained as ‘land granted to a person for repairing or building a tank on condi-tion of paying in money or kind one-tenth or some small share of the produce’ and as ‘land granted at one-tenth of the usual rates to a person in consideration of his constructing or repairing a tank’. See daśabandha.
1464: dāsī (CITD), a handmaid, slave, concubine, dancing girl.
1466: dāsūri-paṭṭu (CITD), Telugu; probably, silk of the Tusser variety; cf. Hobson-Jabson, s. v. tussah, tusser.
1468: datti (EI 23; CII 4; CITD), a gift; cf. Sarvasiddhi-datti (EI 19).
1469: Dauḥsādhasādhanika (EI 30; HD), explained as ‘those who catch dangerous robbers whom it is difficult to secure’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 211. Cf. Duḥsādhasādhanika (ibid., Vol. XI, p. 310), Dussādhyasādhaka, Duṣṭasāhanī, Mahādauḥsādhanika, etc.
1470: Dauḥsādhika (IE 8-3; HD), same as Dauḥsādhasādhanika, Duḥsādhyasādhanika, Dussādhyasādhaka, Duṣṭasāhani, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 9. Lexicons explain it as ‘gate-keeper’.
1472: Dauvārika (EI 28; SII 1; ASLV; BL; HD), a door-keeper; a gate-keeper. See Arthaśāstra, I. 12; Lalitavistara, p. 136; Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 30.
1473: dāvāpana, cf. dāvāpanāya (LP), ‘for making one pay’; cf. dāpana.
1476: dāyāda (CII 4), an agnate. (LL), Buddhist; an heir of the faith.
1477: denarius (IE 8-3), name of the Roman silver coin and also of the Roman gold coin usually called aureus; cf. dīnāra.
1478: deśa (IE 8-4; CII 3, 4), a territorial term meaning a small area or a group of villages in some cases but a kingdom, district, tract or country in others. (IE 8-4), a country of which there were seventy two in Bhārata or Bhāratavarṣa. (CII 1), a part of anything. (EI 24), a synonym of āspada. (ASLV), a school of music. Cf. Kona-deśa (EI 32), also called a maṇdala, rāṣṭra, sīma, sthala, etc. Cf. deśa-bhāṣā (EI 17), ‘vernacular of a province’. Cf. teśa-kālam (SITI), locality and time; also teśa-vāḻi, officer in charge of a village or district.
1479: Deś-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; HD), same as Deśādhipati; governor of a deśa or a province, district or sub-division. See Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 5 (Prakrit Desādhikata). See Sarva-deś-ādhikṛta. (LL), explained as ‘a local prefect’.
1480: Deś-ādhipati (EI 26, 30), same as Deśādhikṛta; ruler of the territorial or administrative unit called deśa.
1481: Deś-ākṣapaṭalādhikṛta (EI 28), officer of the records and accounts office pertaining to a territorial unit.
1482: Deśakūṭa (AI 7), official designation; cf. Rāṣṭrakūṭa, Grāmakūṭa, Deś-ādhipati.
1483: deśa-maryādā, custom prevalent in a locality; cf. deśa-maryād-āṟuvaṇa-ānvita (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 103), aṟuvaṇa being a tax of six paṇas levied on rent-free lands.
1484: deśanā, Prakrit desanā (EI 21), exposition of the Buddhist doctrine.
1485: deśa-rīta (Chamba), customary taxes of a locality.
1486: Deśa-talāra (LP), probably, a police superintendent. Cf. Talāra.
1489: Deśāyi (ASLV), same as Sanskrit Deśādhipati or Deśādhikṛta.
1490: deśī (EI 11), a guild of local merchants. This is also the name of Prakrit words which are neither Sanskrit (tat-sama) nor derived from Sanskrit (tad-bhava).
1492: Deśilaka, official designation (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71); same as Deśillaka.
1493: Deśillaka (EI 28), official designation as in rāṣtra-grāma-kūṭa-deśillaka-mahattar-ādhikārik-ādīn; same as Desilaka, Deśakūṭa; cf. Purillaka.
1495: deś-ottāra (LP), permission for allowing the cargo to go from one place to another.
1496: deva, a god; cf. te-aḍimai (SITI), a dancing woman as the servant of a god; maid servant attached to a temple; cf. teva-kuḍimai, tenancy under the control of a temple; tevakulam (deva-kula), a temple. (EI 7), the king. (EI 3), a saint. (EI 7-1-2), ‘thirtythree’.
1497: deva-bhoga (EI 23, 31; SITI), rent-free property of a temple; land given for the enjoyment of temples; same as deva-dāya, etc., Cf. devabhoga-hala.
1498: devabhoga-hala (EI 7, 8, 15, 24), rent-free land in the possession of temples.
1500: deva-dāna (EI 5, 23, 25, 30; SITI; ASLV), gift made to a god; rent-free land in the possession of a temple; same as deva-bhoga, deva-deya, deva-dāya, dev-āgrahāra. Cf. devadāna-iṟaiyili (SITI), village or land granted to a temple.
1501: deva-dāsī (EI 22, 33; LL), a dancing girl attached to a temple; a female temple-servant. See vilāsinī, gaṇikā, mahārī.
1502: deva-dāya (IE 8-5; EI 23; CII 4; SITI), a rent-free holding in the possession of a temple; a gift made in honour of a god; same as deva-deya, etc.
1503: deva-deya (IE 8-5; HRS), grant made in favour of temples; same as deva-dāya, etc.
1504: deva-dharma (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 144), same as deya-dharma when the gift was the image of a god.
1505: Dev-ādhyakṣa, superintendent of religious foundations. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 99.
1507: deva-droṇī (IE 8-3; EI 10), usually taken to mean ‘a pro-cession of the images of gods’, or ‘procession or ablution of images’; but probably, ‘rent-free property of a temple’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV pp. 143-44); cf. deva-droṇī-sambaddha (EI 23). A Prakrit inscription (A.R. Ep., 1959-60, No. B 173) has deva-doṇi data = Sanskrit deva-droṇī dattā.
1508: Devadroṇī-sambaddha (IE 8-3), same as Devadroṇy-adhikṛta; officer in charge of temple property (devadroṇī, usually taken in the sense of ‘a procession of the images of gods)’.
1509: Devadroṇy-adhikṛta (IE 8-3; BL), explained as ‘the superin-tendent of the procession of idols’; but probably, the superin-tendent of the property of a temple or of temple property in general; same as Devadroṇī-sambaddha; cf. deva-droṇī (EI 13).
1510: dev-āgāra, cf. tevāram, devāram (SITI), a temple.
1511: dev-āgrahāra (IE 8-5; EI 23, 25, 30; SITI), rent-free village granted to a temple; same as deva-bhoga, etc.; see agra-hāra.
1513: devagṛha-jagatī (IA 14), explained as ‘a temple and its ground’ or ‘a temple with the buildings attached to it.’ But cf. jagatī.
1514: devaka (IA 23), the guardian spirit or a god.
1515: deva-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as the deva-sthāna department.
1517: Devakarmin (EI 30; SII 1, 3, 12); cf. tevar-kaṉmi, devar-kaṉmi (EI 3; SITI); a Pūjāri or temple priest, a temple servant; servant of a god; an officer in charge of the affairs of a temple.
1519: devakula (EI 9, 23), a temple; cf. ācāryakula (LL). (EI 21), a gallery of portrait statues of deified or semi-deified ancestors.
1520: devakula-puṣkariṇī (IE 8-5), temples and tanks [the cons-truction of the former and the excavation of the latter requiring the permission of the king or landlord].
1523: devakulikā (EI 8; HA), a shrine; a cell; a supplementary or smaller shrine.
1525: dev-ālaya (EI 23), a temple; same as devakula.
1526: Devānāṃpriya (EI 21; CII 1; LL), a royal title; title assu-med by the Maurya kings.
1528: deva-nikāya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 115), probably, temple authorities.
1529: Devaputra (IE 8-2; EI 8, 21, 30), royal title of foreign origin; ‘the Son of Heaven’; title of certain Kuṣāṇa kings; same as Daivaputra. (LL), Buddhist; an angel.
1530: devaraḍiyāḻ (ASLV), Tamil; a dancing girl attached to a temple.
1531: devāram (SITI), Tamil corruption of Sanskrit devāgāra; a temple.
1532: Devātideva (EI 1), epithet of the Buddha and gods.
1533: devaṭisalam (EI 12), a ceremony indicative of royalty.
1535: Deva-vārika (EI 33), superintendent of a temple; cf. Vārika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVII, p. 142, text line 35.
1536: devaveśma-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of temples.
1537: deva-vihāra, land in the possession of temples. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 217.
1538: deva-vṛtti (SITI), land set apart for the maintenance of temples.
1539: deva-yajña (CII 4), offerings to gods; one of the five mahāyajñas.
1540: dev-āyatana (EI 23), a temple; same as devakula.
1541: Devī (IE 8-2; CII 1, 3; LL), a title originally of wives of independent monarchs and later also of feudatory rulers; often used as a termination of the names of wives of rulers of all classes; cf. Mahādevī; also means the Mother-goddess.
1543: Devī-kumāra (IA 18; CII 1), explained as ‘the son of a king, who has the rank of a prince’; the king's son born of a queen and not of a concubine.
1544: devottara (IE 8-5), Bengali corruption of devatrā; same as deva-dāya, etc.
1545: deya (IE 8-5), periodical offerings to be presented to the king or landlord; cf. ādeya, deya-meya.
1546: deya-dharma (EI 1; CII 3; ML), a pious gift; an appro-priate religious gift; an expression used in numerous donative inscriptions. A deity installed for worship was also called deya-dharma (sometimes deva-dharma) in medieval records. Same as dharma-deya, dharma-dāya, dharma-dāna.
1547: deyadharma-parityāga (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 10, text line 2), donation of a religious gift.
1548: deya-meya (HRS), known from a Śātavāhana record; king's share in kind and in cash; same as dhānya-hiranya of later records. See deya, meya.
1550: dhaḍā, dhaḍī, a small measure of capacity (Ind. Ant., Vol. XLI, p. 20).
1551: ḍhakkā (CII 3), a war drum; used in the Rājataraṅgiṇī in the sense of a watch-station (cf. Sircar, Geog. Anc. Med. Ind., p. 238).
1552: dhaḻa-vādi, dhala-vali (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a tax probably connected with dala-vṛtti, or at least with dala or the army.
1553: dhānaka, see hema-dhānyaka; also called aṇḍikā; equal to 4 kārṣāpaṇas or to 4 suvarṇas or dīnāras (JNSI, Vol. II, p. 7).
1554: dhanika, dhanin (LP), the owner; cf. Gujarātī dhaṇī; used in the sense of ‘one who is spending or lending money’ in the Maithilī documents (Proc. IHRC, Vol. XVIII, p. 90).
1555: dhānika, a coin equal to 4 kārṣāpaṇas or 64 paṇas according to the Kṛtyakalpataru (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K.V. Ranga-swami Aiyanger, p. 125); cf. dhānaka.
1556: dhanikatva, cf. dhanikatvaṃ vidhāya (LP), ‘having claimed ownership’.
1557: dhānya, cf. sa-hiraṇya-dhānya-praṇaya-pradeya (IE 8-5); pro-duce of the fields, a share of which was payable to the king or landlord; cf. dhāny-ādāya.
1558: dhāny-ādāya (SITI), tax payable in grains; cf. dhāny-āya.
1560: dhānya-hiraṇya (HRS), revenue in kind and in cash; same as dhānya-hiraṇy-ādeya.
