1561: dhānya-hiraṇy-ādeya (EI 32), tax in crops and cash. See dhānya-hiraṇya.
1562: dhānya-māṣa, weight equal to 1 yava or 2 taṇdulas (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
1563: dhānya-varga (SITI), literally, ‘the grain group’; actually, a class of taxes payable in grains.
1564: dhāny-āya (EI 7), tax in-grains; cf. dhāny-ādāya; called nĕll-āyam (SII 12) in Tamil.
1566: dhara, cf. Vinaya-dhara (EI 33), ‘one who has committed the [Buddhist] Vinaya texts by heart’.
1568: dhārā-datta, cf. tārā-tattam (SITI), a gift made with the ceremony of libation of water.
1570: dharaṇa (CII 4), name of a coin. (IE 8-8), a silver coin weighing 24 ratis (cf. JNSI, Vol. II, pp. 28-29) or the half of a gadyāṇaka according to the Līlāvatī; silver coin of 32 ratis according Manu, etc. (IE 8-8), same as kārṣāpaṇa or purāṇa. (EI 3), a gold coin or weight (320 ratis). (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 44), sometimes called śāna and ṭaṅka.
1572: dhāraṇī (IA 9; BL), a magic litany usually of the Bud-dhists; an occult Indian charm, especially Buddhistic; a short formula intended to represent a particular Tantra text, the recitation of the dhāraṇī being regarded as equally meritorious as that of the Tantra itself (Univ. Cey. Rev., January-April, 1960, p. 62, note 42).
1574: dhārā-pūrvakam, cf. udaka-pūrvam, etc. See dhātrā-datta.
1575: dharma (SII 1), the sacred law; religious merit; a meri-torious gift, a pious work, a charity; moral precept. (EI 24), law or law and order. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 116) virtue or religious merit. (IE 8-2), sometimes prefixed to the titles of kings and crown-princes; cf. Dharma-mahārāja, etc.
1576: dharma-baddha, cf. tarma-pattar (SITI), persons bound by the law; judicial officers.
1577: dharma-bāndhava, ‘one whose only friend is his religious faith’ or ‘a person who has become the friend of another on an oath in the name of his religious faith’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
1578: dharma-cakra (CII 3; LL), Buddhist; the wheel of Dharma which was the symbol representing the Buddha on early Buddhist sculptures, on stone inscriptions and on seals attached to copperplate grants. (HA) Jain; the wheel of law supposed to move in the sky in front of a Jina when he goes on his wanderings from place to place; one of the members of the parikara of a Jina image.
1579: dharmacakra-mudrā (EI 29), seal bearing the emblem of the Buddhist wheel of law.
1580: dharma-dāna (ML; SITI), a religious gift; a gift for religious merit; grant of tax-free land; same as deya-dharma.
1581: dharma-deya (IA 9; HRS), same as deya-dharma, dharma-dāya, etc.; a religious grant in general.
1582: dharma-deśanā (SII 1), a discourse on the sacred law.
1583: dharm-ādhikāra (EI 15; IA 9), court of law; an office relating to the civil and criminal courts as well as to religious and charitable institutions. See Dharmādhikārin.
1584: dharm-ādhikaraṇa (EI 18, 23, 25; CII 4; LP), a law-court; a court of justice. See Dharm-ādhikaraṇin. Cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of justice. (HD), a judge. See Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 24-25.
1585: Dharm-ādhikaraṇika (IE 8-3), a judge; mentioned as a Pātra.
1586: Dharm-ādhikaraṇin (HD), a judge. See Matsya Purāṇa, 215. 24. The reading is Dharm-ādhikaraṇa in some manuscripts.
1587: Dharm-ādhikārin (IE 8-3; EI 33), cf. dharm-ādhikāra (IA 9); an officer in charge of civil and criminal justice as well as charitable and religious institutions; same as Bṛhat-tantra-pati, according to a Kashmirian commentator; usually explained as ‘a judge’; same as Dharmakarm-ādhikārin and Dharm-ādhyakṣa. Cf. the Muslim official designations şadruŞ-Şudūr, Dādbak, etc., explained as ‘the chief judge and grand almoner, or custo-dian of the king's bequests and charities’ (Journ. As. Soc. Pak., Vol. IV, pp. 53-54).
1588: Dharm-ādhyakṣa (EI 15; HD), generally explained as ‘a judge’; but he was probably also the superintendent of charities, etc.; cf. Dharm-ādhikārin.
1589: dharma-hala (EI 7), a rent-free holding. See hala.
1590: dharma-jaya-stambha (IA 19), ‘a pillar of the victory of religion’.
1591: Dharmakarm-ādhikārin (EI 21; CII 4), officer in charge of charities and other religious works; probably the same as Dharm-ādhyakṣa; cf. Dharm-ādhikārin, Dharma-Pradhāna.
1593: Dharma-kathika (LL), cf. Prakrit dhamma-kadhika (EI 15), a [Buddhist] preacher; a preacher of the [Buddhist] religious system; same as Dharma-kathin; also spelt Dharma-kathaka.
1594: Dharma-kathin (CII 2-1; ML), Buddhist; the preacher of the [Buddhist] religious system; same as Dharma-kathika.
1595: dharma-lābha (LP), expression uttered by the Jain monks [of the Śvetāmbara sect] when they bless a householder saluting them.
1596: Dharma-lekhin (EI 4; CII 4; BL), a writer of charters or religious documents.
1597: dharma-lipi (EI 2, 33; CII 1), an edict on the subject of dharma (religion or moral precepts).
1598: Dharma-mahādhirāja (EI 12, 28), royal title; cf. Mahādhi-rāja and Dharma-mahārāja, etc.
1599: Dharma-mahāmātra (IE 8-3; EI 26; CII 1; HD), superin-tendent of morality; a Mahāmātra (high executive officer) of the department of religion; an executive officer superin-tending matters relating to religious affairs.
1600: Dharma-mahārāja (IE 8-2; EI 15, 28), royal title; supposed to mean ‘a Mahārāja who, at the particular time of issuing a record, was engaged in an act of religious merit.’
1601: Dharma-māhārājādhirāja (IE 8-2; EI 5, 15, 28), imperial title; title assumed by certain rulers. Cf. Dharma-mahārāja.
1602: dharma-nigama (LL), probably, a pious hamlet or its administrative council.
1603: Dharma-pradhāna (EI 21; CII 4), head of the religious department; cf. Dharm-ādhyakṣa and Dharmakarm-ādhikārin.
1604: dharma-putra (EI 32), ‘one theoretically accepted as a son’.
1605: Dharmarāja (EI 28), royal title; title of a pious king; cf. Dharma-mahārāja, etc.; also dharmarājikā.
1606: Dharma-rājaguru (EI 11), designation of the king's pre-ceptor.
1607: dharmarājikā (IA 14; ML), Buddhist; a stūpa built on the relics of the Buddha called Dharmarāja; a Buddhist stūpa.
1608: dharma-śālā (IE 8-3; IA 9), a house for accommodating pilgrims free of cost; cf. śrī-Vāgmatī-jal-āvatāra-sopān-ārāma-ghaṇṭā-dharmaśālā-pratiṣṭhā-karma. See choultry.
1609: dharm-āsana (EI 26; SII 3, 13; SITI), a court of justice; cf. Tamil daṉm-āsanam (EI 22), the seat of justice; a law-court.
1610: Dharmāsana-bhaṭṭa (SITI) a Brāhmaṇa versed in law assisting in a dharm-āsana or law-court.
1611: dharma-śāsana (EI 18, 22, 33; SII 1), an edict relating to dharma; a religious edict. (EI 22; SITI), same as tāmra-śāsana; a document recording a gift made for charitable purposes.
1612: dharmaśāsana-paṭṭa (EI 3), a slab containing a religious edict.
1614: dharma-sthāna (EI 24, 26, 32), a temple; a holy place; a place of religious worship. Cf. a mijigiti or mosque referred to as a dharma-sthāna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144); see also dharmasthāna-goṣṭhika. (Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 279, note 52), land or money assigned for a religious purpose. (EI 23), the office of justice.
1615: dharmasthāna-goṣṭhika (EI 33), member of a committee managing the affairs of a temple.
1616: Dharma-sthita (IE 8-2), ‘steadfast in religion’; epithet of a Kuṣāṇa king who may have been a convert to Buddhism. See Satyadharma-sthita.
1617: dharma-vāriyam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; committee look-ing after charitable endowments and institutions.
1618: dharmavijaya-śāsana (EI 33), same as dharma-śāsana; a royal record relating to one of the king's meritorious acts; cf. vijaya-śāsana.
1619: Dharma-vijayin (CII 4), a righteous conqueror; epithet of certain rulers.
1620: dharma-vṛtti-iṟaiyili (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; tax-free land for the maintenance of some charity.
1621: dharma-yātrā, cf. dhaṃma-yātā (EI 5; CII 1), pilgrimage; a tour of pilgrimage.
1622: Dharma-yuvamahārāja (IE 8-2; EI 24, 32), designation of a crown-prince engaged in a pious activity; cf. Dharma-mahārāja and Yuvamahārāja.
1623: dhārmika (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, a cess collected in the name of a religious institution or festival. (IE 8-2), royal title; same as Prakrit Dhramika, translated from Greek Dikaios.
1624: Dharmin, cf. dharmikaḻ (SITI), a body or commission managing endowments.
1626: dhāṭī (LP), campaign; cf. para-rāṣtṛ-opari datta-dhāṭyām, ‘in the course of an expedition led against a foreign country’.
1627: dhāṭivāha (Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 277, note 24), meaning doubtful.
1629: dhātu (ML), Buddhist; corporeal relics [of the Buddha]. (IE 7-1-2; EI 25), ‘seven’. Cf. Dhātu-parigṛhīta, an epithet of the Buddha; probably, salvation (Select Inscriptions, p. 228).
1630: dhātu-garbha, ‘containing the corporeal relies of the Buddha’ (Journ. Mad. Univ., Vol. XXXII, p. 136).
1631: dhātu-vara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVII, p. 16, text line 13), a Buddhist stūpa containing the Buddha's relics.
1632: Dhātuvara-parigṛhīta (EI 20), ‘one who has attained nirvāṇa’; epithet of the Buddha. Cf. dhātu.
1633: dhaukaṇa-patra (LP), permission of divorce; cf. Gujarātī chuṭāchedā meḻvavā.
1636: dhavala-cchatra (SII 2), a white parasol which was one of the royal insignia.
1638: ḍheṅku (EI 30), a machine for extracting juice.
1639: ḍheṅku-kaḍḍhaka (IE 8-8), probably, one whose profession was to draw water from a well by means of a machinery.
1642: dhīrmara (CII 4), probably, ‘a fish-basket’, according to some.
1645: Dhruva (EI 16, 32; HD), [a collector of] the fixed royal share of grains; contraction of Dhruv-ādhikaraṇika; cf. the Gujarātī family name Dhruva; same as dhruva-sthāna. See Bomb. Gaz., Vol. I, Part i, p. 477. (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’. (CII 1), regular.
1647: Dhruv-ādhikaraṇa (EI 30), office of [the collector of] the king's share of the produce of the fields from the farmers. Cf. Dhruva, Dhruvapati, Dhruv-ādhikaraṇika.
1648: Dhruv-ādhikaraṇika (IE 8-3; CII 3; HD; HRS), known from Maitraka records; according to some, the officer in charge of persons entrusted with the superintendence of the collection of the king's grain-share from the farmers; an official title of the Kathiawar region indicating an officer collecting the king's share of grains; sometimes called Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇika; the same as Dhruva or an employee of the dhruva-sthāna or Dhruva's office. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 339.
1650: dhruva-sthāna (IE 8-3), a station for the collection of the king's fixed grain share; cf. Dhruva.
1651: Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇa (IE 8-3; EI 30), the station for collecting the king's share or the office in its charge; cf. Dhruv-ādhikaraṇa and Dhruv-ādhikaraṇika.
1652: dhvaja (CII 3), banner or standard as distinguished from lāñchana or crest. Cf. cihna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 135 ff.).
1655: dhvaj-āvarohaṇa (SITI), function at the conclusion of a festival.
1656: dhvaṃśī, same as vaṃśya; a theoretical unit of measure-ment (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
1657: di (IE 8-1; CII 3), abbreviation of dina, dine, divasa or divase; used in connection with śu or su and ba in the case of lunar months and by itself in the case of solar months.
1660: diggaja (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’. Eight poets patronised by Kṛṣṇadevarāya were called the aṣṭa-diggaja.
1661: dig-vijaya, used in Kannaḍa inscriptions in the sense of ‘going in state; going in a triumpal procession; making a state progress through one's dominions’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 223, note 5; Vol. VI, p. 51, note 5). See vijaya.
1662: Dikaios (IE 8-2) Greek; royal title; ‘pious’; translated in Prakrit as Dhramika (Sanskrit Dhārmika).
1664: Dikpāla (HD), probably, officers in charge of the borders of a kingdom. See Nārada, Jolly's ed., Pariśiṣṭa, verse 17; Mitākṣarā on Yājñavalkyasmṛti, II. 271; Kātyāyana (v. 813) quoted by Aparārka. (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’.
1665: dīkṣā (HA), initiation as a monk or recluse; initiation into any doctrine.
1667: Dīkṣita (EI 22; CII 3, 4), same as Yajña-dīkṣita; epithet of Brāhmaṇas; later stereotyped as a Brahmanical family name.
1668: dina (CII 3), a day; used to denote the solar, or more properly civil, day. See also di and divasa. (IE 7-1-2), ‘fifteen’.
1669: dināra (SITI), name of a coin; same as dīnāra; derived from the Roman coin name denarius; a cowrie-shell according to the Rājataraṅgiṇī (Stein's trans., Vol. II, pp. 308 ff.).
1670: dīnāra (IE 8-8; EI 9, 23, 30; CII 3; SITI), a gold coin, the name being derived from the Roman denarius; gold coin equal to 16 silver rūpakas in the Gupta age (JNSI, Vol. II, p. 5); sometimes called kāśu in Tamil records; sometimes regarded as half of a satera or sateraka (Greek stater); men-tioned as a silver coin (K. V. Rangaswami Aiyanger, Kṛtya-kalpataru, Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, p. 125); also spelt dīnnāra, etc.
1671: dināri (IE 8-8), name of a coin probably modified from the Roman denarius; cf. dīnāra and dināri-māṣaka.
1672: dināri-māṣaka (IE 8-8), name of a coin; cf. dināri.
1673: dīpa-mālā, cf. tīpa-mālai (SITI), the string of lights hung in temples; same as śara-viḻakku.
1675: dīpa-pūjā (EI 9), dīpa and pūjā wrongly taken as a compound word of special significance.
1677: dīpāvalī (EI 5; CII 4), name of a festival; the festival of lights; cf. dīp-otsava.
1678: dīp-otsava (EI 11, 32), same as dīpāvalī, the festival of lights.
1680: dīrgha-mānya (SITI), land set apart for the supply of water for the holy bath of idols.
1681: dīrghā (CII 1), distance or the distant future.
1682: dīrghanāsiky-ārcā (EI 24), the image of a deity with long nose.
1683: dīrghikā (SITI), bath; a long or oval pond.
1684: diś, diśā (IE 7-1-2), ‘ten’; rarely used to indicate ‘four’ also.
1686: diśaḥ (EI 2), the nymphs of the quarters.
1687: Diśāmpati (EI 29), a provincial governor. A Cakravartin was sometimes conceived as a Dig-vijayin or a Diśāmpati.
1688: Diśāpaṭa (EI 16), Kannaḍa; ‘causing one's enemies to be scattered in all directions’; same as Diśāpaṭṭa.
1689: Diśāpaṭṭa (EI 5, 16), Kannaḍa; ‘causing one's enemies to be scattered in all directions’; same as Diśāpaṭa.
1691: ditya (EI 9, 12, 28; CII 4; HRS), known from Maitraka records; name of a tax, according to some; probably, the same as datti, i. e. a gift or occasional present to be offered to the landlord; cf. sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna or °parihṛta (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 298, text line 20); also cf. sa-ditya-dāna-karaṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 301, text line 14), an epithet of the gift land. Ditya is probably derived from Prakrit dijja = Sanskrit deya, ‘to be given’, ‘an object that has been given away’ in the sense of ‘customary presents’. For ditta, cf. Bhār. Vid., Vol. XVII, Nos. 3-4 pp. 125-26. See Dity-odgrāhaka.
1692: Dity-odgrāhaka (CII 4), probably, ‘an officer in charge of collecting customary presents’; cf. ditya.
1693: diva (CII 3, etc.), abbreviation of divasa or divase; used to denote the solar or, more properly, civil day.
1694: divā (CII 3), ‘by day’; an indeclinable used in some of the Nepal inscriptions in composition with words denoting tithis or lunar days.
1696: Dīvān (BL), the chief administrator or finance minister; see Dīwān, Dīwānjī.
1697: divasa (CII 3, etc.), a day; sometimes used for the week-day, instead of the usual term vāra; generally used to denote the solar or, more properly, civil day; sometimes used in connec-tion with words denoting tithis or lunar days. See also di, dina, diva.
1698: Divira (HD), same as Persian Dabīr, ‘a clerk’. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 131, mentioning Divira as distinct from Kāyastha; also CII, Vol. III, p. 122. Cf. Divirapati.
1699: Divirapati, Divīrapati (IE 8-3; EI 5, 28; BL; HD), chief secretary or the chief of the clerks; cf. Divira. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 180 (Sandhivigrahādhikṛta-Divirapati); Vol. XXII, p. 117 (Divirapati also called Sandhivigrahika, Mahā-pratīhāra and Sāmanta).
1700: divya (IA 10; LP), an ordeal; same as parīkṣā.
1702: Dīwān, Dīwānjī (BL), the chief administrator or finance minister. See Dīvān.
1704: ḍohalikā (EI 13), explained as ‘a piece of land granted to Brāhmaṇas, Svāmins, Sādhus and others’ (Prog. Rep. A. S. I., W. C., 1908-09, p. 53); cf. dohalikā dattā. See dohalikā-bhūmi.
1705: ḍohalikā-bhūmi (LP), explained as ‘land, of which the ownership is doubted and hence taken by government’; cf. Gujarātī ḍūlā, dulavuṃ, ḍohalavum; also lupta-ḍohalikā (LP), explained as ‘the ḍohalikā which is lost to the owner’. But see ḍohalikā.
1707: dola-yātrā (IA 9), the festival of the swinging of the image of Kṛṣṇa on Phālguna su-di 15.
1709: doṅgaka (EI 24), a variety of resin or aloe.
1710: doṣa (LP), doing anything wrongly. (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’. (EI 9), black or red spots on the tongue supposed to be a foreboding of death. Cf. daṇḍa-doṣa; fines; see also pradhān-āpradhāna-doṣa-samanvita used as an epithet of the gift village (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 274). Here doṣa apparently means daṇda-doṣa.
1712: doyaraka (EI 33), probably, ‘the singer who repeats part of a song after it has been once sung’; cf. Hindī dohrānā.
1714: drachma (IE 8-8; CII 4), name of an old Greek coin; Indian dramma.
1719: draṃkṣaṇa, same as tolaka (q. v.); a weight of 8 māṣas, also spelt drakṣaṇa, drakṣuṇa, etc.; cf. maṃkṣūṇa, equal to 7 māṣas.
1720: dramma (EI 25, 30; CII 4; SITI; BL), name of a coin; originally derived from Greek drachma. (IE 8-8), a silver coin, equal to one-sixteenth of a gold niṣka according to the Līlāvalī. Cf. pañciyaka-dramma (EI 30), Śrīmadādivarāha-dramma, Vigraha-dramma, Vigrahapāla-dramma, Vigrahapāla-satka-dramma, Vigrahapālīya-dramma, Vigrahatuṅgīya-dramma (IE 8-8; EI 1); Bhīmapriya-dramma (IE 8-8); poruttha-dramma (EI 23).--(IE 8-8), cf. gara-dramma, dāya-dramma, belliya-dramma (i. e. silver dramma), etc., of Kannaḍa inscriptions; the name dramma was also applied to the silver coin called purāṇa, dharaṇa or kārṣāpaṇa, though it was often used as the name of copper coins; money. For gold and ordinary (copper) dramma, cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 111. Cf. vāśal-tiramam (SITI), door tax.
1721: dramm-ārdha (CII 4), ‘half of a dramma’; name of a coin.
1722: dramma-tribhāga (CII 4), ‘three-fourths of a dramma’; name of a coin.
1723: draṅga (EI 32), used to indicate dramma; name of a coin. (EI 10), cf. Navagrāma-draṅga, ‘the draṅga of Nava-grāma’; possibly ‘a station for the collection of revenue’. (EI 8-3), a town or watch-station; possibly also a station for the collection of revenue; also called udraṅga which may thus indicate both revenue and the station for its collection.
1724: Draṅgapāla (EI 28), same as Drāṅgika official design-ation. See draṅga.
1725: Drāṅgeśa (EI 20; HD), supposed to be the designation of a guardian of the frontiers (cf. Stein, Rājataraṅgiṇī, Vol. II, pp. 291-92 for draṅga or draṅgā); cf. Draṅgapāla and Drāṅgika.
1726: Drāṅgika (IE 8-3; EI 10, 30; CII 3, 4; HD), probably, an officer in charge of a city-station or watch-tower for collection of customs duties. Draṅga means either ‘a town’ (Bhandarkar's List, No. 810) or ‘a watch-station’ (Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 2010). Drāṅgika was an officer in charge of a draṅga probably mean-ing a watch station or a station for revenue collection; similar to Audraṇgika in the latter sense; mentioned along with the Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇa or ‘the collector of the king's grain-share’. Cf. draṅga, Draṅgapāla, etc. See CII, Vol. III, p. 169.
1728: Drāviḍī, name applied to the South Indian variety of the Brāhmī alphabet.
1729: dravyabhāṇḍāra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of stores.
1730: droṇa (IE 8-6; Chamba), a grain measure; often regarded as equal to four āḍhakas; between one maund fourteen seers and two maunds, according to Bengali authors. (IE 8-1; EI 24, 29, 30), name of a land measure derived from that of a measure of capacity; shortened form of droṇavāpa.
1731: Droṇāgīka (EI 33), official disignation; possibly a mistake for Droṇāgraka.
1732: Droṇāgraka (EI 27), official disignation; probably an officer in charge of a droṇamukha or an important city, or one who collected the king's grain-share fixed per droṇa measure.
1733: Droṇamāpaka, measurer of the king's grain-share (Ghoshal, Ag. Syst. Anc. Ind., pp. 26-27).
1734: droṇavāpa (IE 8-6; EI 30), ‘an area of land requiring one droṇa measure of seed grains to be sown’; a land measure which was not the same in different ages and localities.
1735: droṇi, droṇī (CH 4; IA 11), treasury; property (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144--‘the droṇī of Śrī-Somanāthadeva’ to which a piece of land was attached); see devadroṇī probably meaning ‘rent-free property of a temple’.
1736: droṇī-kara, cf. Tamil toni-kkaḍamai (SITI), tax on boats.
1737: dṛś, cf. peṭaṃ (Sanskrit udaraṃ) darśayitum (EI 11), lite-rally, ‘to show one's belley’; but actually ‘to ask for the means of livelihood’.
1739: dṛṣṭa (EI 3, 23; CII 3; etc.), Prakrit diṭṭham, ‘has been seen’, i. e. ‘found correct and approved’, found on some copper-plate grants indicating the approval of the proper authorities endorsed on the original document later engraved on the plates. Cf. ni (an abbreviation of nibaddha or nirīkṣiṭa) in certain medieval copper-plate grants of Eastern India. In dṛṣṭa-pañcāśat-padāti (LP), dṛṣṭa-ghoṭaka (LP), etc., the word dṛṣṭa indicates that money should be paid after actually seeing the foot-soldiers and horses in question.
1741: dṛṣṭi (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; cf. netra; also darśana, ‘six’. (IA 19), Buddhist; theory or doctrine; a peculiar or heretical doctrine.
1743: dugdha, cf. a-dugdha-dadhi-grahaṇa (IE 8-5); milk which the villagers (probably, the milkmen) were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions and to the touring officers.
1745: Duḥsādha-sādhanika (IE 8-3; HD), the leader of police-men engaged in apprehending robbers, etc., or of expeditionary forces requisitioned on occasions of emergency; cf. Sādhanika, Duṣṭa-sādhaka, Dauḥsādhanika, Dussādhya-sādhaka, etc.
1746: Duḥsādhya (EI 2), abbreviation of Duḥsādhya-sādhanika, etc., or a criminal; cf. dussādhya.
1747: duḥsādhy-ādāya (EI 21), a tax probably levied from habitu-ally criminal people or for the maintenance of certain police or military officers called Duḥsādhya, etc. See duṣṭasādhy-ādāya.
1748: Duḥsādhya-sādhanika (IE 8-3), same as Dauhsādha-sādhanika, etc. Cf. Dussādhya-sādhaka, Duṣṭa-sāhaṇi, etc.
1750: ḍulita (LP), ‘[land, etc.,] that has become ḍohalikā (q. v.)’.
1751: dumphaka (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably the same as Sanskrit dṛmphaka, ‘one who presses’; see nīla-ḍumphaka.
1754: Durga-daṇḍanāyaka (ASLV), the ruler of a fort; cf. Daṇḍanāyaka.
1757: Durgā-putra (EI 33), epithet of one devoted to the goddess Durgā; used along with such similar epithets as Rudra-putra and Puruṣottama-putra.
1759: Durlabha (EI 23), an official designation of uncertain import.
1762: dussādhya (CII 4), ‘a criminal’; abbreviation of Duḥsādhya-sādhaka, etc.
1764: Duṣṭa-sādhaka (EI 7; CII 4; HD), official designation; ‘the mentor of criminals’; same as Duḥsādhya-sādhanika, Dauḥsā-dhanika, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91.
1765: Duṣṭa-sādhya (EI 21; CII 4), same as dus-sādhya or a criminal; abbreviation of the official designation Duṣṭa-sādhya-sādhanika; same as Duṣṭa-sādhaka, etc.
1766: duṣṭasādhy-ādāya, probably, a tax levied for maintaining the police engaged in suppressing dacoits. Cf. Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 254, note. See duḥsādhy-ādāya.
1767: Duṣṭasādhya-sādhanika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 132), same as Duṣṭa-sādhaka, etc.
1768: Duṣṭa-sāhaṇi (EI 33), same as Duṣṭa-sādhaka, Duṣṭasā-dhya-sādhanika, etc.
1770: Dūta (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 1; HD), a messenger or envoy. See Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 13-14, 28; CII, Vol. I, p. 67. (EI 23; CII 3, 4), an occasional substitute for Dūtaka, the executor of a grant.
1771: Dūtaka (IE 8-3; HD), messenger; conveyor of a request or message; cf. the Khalimpur plate of Dharmapāla (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 250), according to which the king was reques-ted to make a grant by a Mahāsāmantādhipati through prince Tribhuvanapāla as the Dūtaka. His function is called dūtya in the Nalanda plate of Devapāla (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, 318 ff., text line 51). (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 3, 4), according to some, the technical title of an officer connected with royal charters, whose duty it was to carry the king's orders to the local officials by whom the charter was then drawn up and delivered. But the Dūtaka seems to have been responsible for putting the document and also perhaps the gift land in the donee's possession. There are instances of more Dūtakas than one (IA 19). See also Ājñā, Dūta, and sva-mukh-ājñā. Cf. Ind. Ep., pp. 143-44.
1772: Dūta-praiṣaṇika (HD), officer in charge of sending envoys; same as Dūta-preṣaṇika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321; Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306. Cf. Preṣaṇika.
1773: Dūta-preṣaṇika (CII 4), also called Duta-saṃpreṣaṇika and Dūta-praiṣaṇika; the officer who despatched Dūtas.
1774: dūtya, same as dautya; function of the Dūtaka (q. v.).
1776: dvādaśa-bhāga (Rājataraṅgiṇī, VII. 203); name of an additional levy which was (1/12) of the fixed tax.
1777: dvādaśaka (SII 13), partnership in a land; cf. aṣṭaka.
1778: Dvādaśasthān-ādhipati, the head of twelve departments (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 276).
1780: dvāra (CII 1), a way or means. (IE 7-1-2), ‘nine’. (EI 4), the mouth of a river. (IE 8-3), cf. ‘the lord of the dvāra’ which was the desig-nation of a commander of forces in Kashmir; possibly, a pass [leading into the Kashmir valley]. Cf. Tamil vāśal-paṇam, ‘door-tax’; periodical payment due to the palace. Cf. dvār-ādeya. Cf. dvāra-koṣṭḥaka.
1781: dvār-ādeya (HRS), ‘gate-dues’; explained as a surcharge over and above the tolls on goods imported into a city. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 60, note. But cf. Tamil vāśal-paṇam explained as ‘door-tax’, i. e. the periodical payment due to the palace.’
1782: Dvār-ādhipa (IE 8-3; HD), same as Dvāranātha, Dvāra-pati, etc.; ‘the lord of the pass’; cf. dvāra.
1783: dvāra-koṣṭhaka (Lüders, Mathurā Inscriptions, p. 135, text line 4), translated as ‘gateway’; gate-chamber.
1784: dvāra-maṇḍapa (HA), a hall or pavilion on the entrance or door of a shrine.
1785: Dvāranātha (IE 8-3; HD), superintendent of the passes leading into the kingdom, according to Stein (Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 214); same as Dvār-ādhipa, Dvārapati, etc.
1787: Dvāra-parīkṣā (IE 8-3; EI 28), Oḏiyā; Sanskrit Dvāra-parīkṣaka; same as Pratīhāra. Cf. Parīkṣā.
1788: Dvārapati (IE 8-3; HD), ‘lord of the gate’; a commander of forces under the Kampanāpati [in Kashmir]; the guardian of a pass [leading into the Kashmir valley]; same as Dvāranātha, Dvār-ādhipa, etc.
1789: dvāroṣṭha (EI 1), meaning doubtful; probably a mistake for dvāra-koṣṭha, a gate-chamber.
1792: dvesa (CII 3), an epithet applied to land; a term of un-certain significance.
1793: Dvi (EI 11), abbreviation of Dviveda. (IE 8-1), abbreviation of dvitīya.
1797: dvikā, double measure (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXVI, p. 52, note 5).
1800: dvi-vallakya (LP), [coins] in which there is a mixture of two vāls (6 ratis) of a base metal. Cf. JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 197.
1801: Dviveda (CII 4), also called Dvivedin; epithet of Brāhma-ṇas; later stereotyped as a Brahmanical family name.
1805: dyūta (HRS), gambling; the king's dues collected by the superintendent of gambling.
1806: Dyūtasabhāpati (BL), superintendent of the gambling hall.
1807: eḍūka, cf. eḍuo (CII 2-1), supposed to be ‘a wall into which bones (meaning planks and other hard substances) have been inserted in order to strengthen the structure’, because it is explained in a commentary as asthy-aṅkita kuḍya; but asthy-aṅkita-kuḍya seems to mean a Buddhist stūpa raised on cor-poreal relics which were an object of worship. Although the word kuḍya is reckoned in the lexicons in the sense of a wall, it seems to mean ‘a mound’ in this case. The word aidūka derived from eḍūka is used in Buddhist Sanskrit in the sense of a Buddhist stūpa. See IHQ, Vol. XXIX, pp. 302-03.
1808: eka-bhoga (EI 16; SITI; ASLV), a tenure indicating exclusive ownership of a property invested in a single indivi-dual; sole possession and enjoyment of a village by a single person (without any joint owner); cf. ekabhoga-iṟaiyili, tax-free land or village in the sole enjoyment of a single owner. Same as eka-bhogya. Cf. gaṇa-bhoga. (SITI), single crop; same as Tamil oru-pū.
1809: eka-bhogya (EI 13, 14), a tenure; same as eka-bhoga.
1812: ekādaśa-Rudra-bhikṣā (EI 32), arrangement of free supply of food to Śaiva ascetics in the name of the eleven Rudras; land granted for such an arrangement.
1813: ekādaśa-śata (ML), same as ekādaś-ottara-śata, one hundred and eleven.
1814: ekādaśī-vrata (EI 31; CII 4), name of a vrata rite.
1816: ekala-mūrti (HA), a single Jina image without any orna-mental parikara.
1818: Ekāṅga (HD), probably, an officer belonging to a body organized in military fashion for collecting revenue or per-forming police duties. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 249; VII. 1604.
1819: Ekāṅgin (SITI), a single person; one who has no family, especially the Vaiṣṇava devotee in charge of temples.
1820: Ekapātra (EI 27), probably, Yāvadeka-pātra (q. v.); official designation; cf. Pātra and Mahāpātra.
1821: Eka-śāṭa (EI 29), same as Eka-cīvara; epithet of a monk who has taken a vow to wear only one piece of cloth.
1822: eka-tīrthī (HA), a sculpture showing only one Jina (Tīrthaṅkara) together with his parikara.
1824: ekāvalī, ekāvallī (SITI), necklace of a single string.
1825: eradu-bilkode (IE 8-5), Kannaḍa; name of a tax.
1826: Erjhuna (ML), a title of foreign origin; ‘a prince’.
1827: etatka cf. etaka (CII 1); same as etat.
1828: evaṃpariṇā (LP), ‘in this way’; cf. Gujarātī evī-pere.
1829: fanam, English spelling of Tamil paṇam; see paṇa. It was sometimes regarded as a gold coin equal to (1/10) of a partāb and (1/20) of a varāha (SII, Vol. I, p. 161).
1830: farmān, also spelt firmān; Persian; cf. phuramāṇa.
1833: ga (IE 8-1), used for gā (in Kharoṣṭhī) as an abbrevia-tion of gāthā; also abbreviation of gadyāṇa (q. v.).
1834: gabhāro (HA), Sanskrit garbha-gṛha; the sanctum of a temple.
1835: gaccha (IA 11; BL), name of particular communities of Jain monks; cf. the eightyfour gacchas of the Jains.
1837: gadhaiyā, also called gadhaiyā paisā; same as gadhiyā; a copper coin modified from old Sasanian types.
1839: gadiāṇaka, cf. Kumāra-gadiāṇaka (EI 8); same as gadyāṇaka. (EI 27), also called gadyāṇa; name of a coin.
1840: gadiyāṇa (EI 27; CII 4), same as gadyāṇa, gadyāṇaka; name of a coin called suvarṇa-gadiyāṇa, ‘gold gadiyāṇa’.
1842: gadyāna (EI 3), a gold coin or weight; also spelt gadyāṇa. generally regarded as 48 ratis in weight (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 42).
1843: gadyāṇa (IE 8-8; EI 27, 30), also called gadyāṇaka, often contracted as ga or gadyā; sometimes called pon-gadyāṇa or gadyāṇa-ponnu indicating that it was a gold coin; sometimes called suvarṇa; cf. bhairava-gadyāṇa, lokki-gadyāṇa (SII 11-2), aṅka-gadyāṇa, gāva-gadyāṇa, komarina-gadyāṇa, priyaśrāha-gaja-malla-gadyāṇa, ambili-gadyāṇa, jagadalaṃ-gadyāṇa, etc. Cf. also aṟu-gadyāṇa (IA 12) and kula-gadyāṇa (EI 17), names of coins. Cf. parameṣṭhi-gadyāṇa-ponna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXVI, p. 61). (SITI), name of a coin, probably equal to a varāha or pagoda; cf. bṛhad-bhairava-gadyāṇa (EI 30); also kaṭhāri-aṅkuśa-gadyāṇa (EI 8), name of a coin with the representation of a dagger and a goad; varāha-gadyāṇa (EI 8), name of the gold coin called both varāha and gadyāṇa.
1844: gadyāṇa (CITD), same as gadyāṇa; a coin like a farthing equal to (1/4) or (1/5) of the paikamu; also a dināra or varāha; a weight used in weighing silver; equal in some places to 20 vals, 8 māṣas, or half a tola.
1845: gadyānaka (EI 28), gadyāṇaka (IE 8-8; EI 27), same as gadyāna or gadyāṇa; name of a coin; a coin weighing 48 ratis according to the Lilāvatī.
1847: gāhṇa (Chamba), threshing floor; from Sanskrit gāhana.
1848: gairāṭa, cf. gelāṭa (CII 1); probably, a hill bird.
1850: Gajadhara (EI 4), same as Sūtradhara or Sūtradhāra, ‘mason’.
1851: Gajādhīśa (CII 4), ‘the lord of elephants’; official designa-tion; title of certain rulers. Cf. Gajapati, etc.
1852: Gajalakṣmī (EI 32), representation of Lakṣmī receiving water on the head from a jar held in the trunk of an elephant on either side; found on the seals of certain rulers.
1853: gajamāla (HA), row of elephants in the plinth of shrines; also called gajathara.
1854: Gaja-mṛgayā-vihāra (ASLV), ‘sportful hunting of ele-phants’; a title of the Vijayanagara kings.
1855: Gajapati (IE 8-2; EI 9, 30; CII 4; HD), ‘the lord of elephants’; officer in charge of the elephant arm in an army; title of certain rulers; dynastic name of the Sūryavaṃśīs of Orissa. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 7. See Mahāgajapati, etc.
1856: Gaja-sāhaṇī (EI 32), a leader of the elephant force; same as Gaja-sāhiṇi, Gaja-sādhanika.
1857: Gaja-sāhiṇi (IE 8-3; EI 27), same as Gaja-sāhaṇi, Gaja-sādhanika; leader of the elephant corps; cf. Sāhiṇi or Sāhaṇī, derived from Sādhanika.
1859: Gajavāha-rāuta (EI 31), title of a subordinate chief.
1860: gal-puṭṭi (CITD), Telugu; an unknown measure of land; a variation of puṭṭi.
1861: gāṇṭhi (LP), a package; cf. Gujarātī gāṇṭhḏī.
1862: Gamāgamika (IE 8-3; EI 4, 23; CII 4; HD), same as Gamāgamin; official designation; probably, an officer in charge of regulating the people's entrance and departure into cities; explained by some as ‘a kind of messenger’ (Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306). Utpala on the Bṛhatsaṃhitā, 85. 34, explains Dūta as Gamāgamika, though some Pāla inscriptions have dūta-khola-gamāgamik-ābhitvaramāṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, pp. 250, text line 45).
1864: gampaṇa (EI 27), same as kampaṇa; an administrative and territorial unit.
1865: Gāmuṇḍa (EI 15), Kannaḍa; same as Gāvuṇḍa; a village headman; probably derived from Grāmakūṭa, ‘headman of a village’, through Gāmaūḍa>Gāmuḍa under the influence of muṇḍa, ‘head’. Cf. Nāḍa-gāmuṇḍa Nāṟ-gāmuṇḍa, ‘headman of a district (nāḍu)’.
1866: gaṇa (LL), a section of the Jains. (SITI), a group of persons; a community or religious guild. (EI 26; CII 4), a guild or corporation. (EI 3), wrongly explained as a share. (SII 12), managing committee. (SII 2), the attendants of Śiva; also the fourteen divi-sions of learning.
1867: gaṇa-bhoga (SITI, ASLV), a tenure in which land is held in common by a group of persons; joint ownership of a village or villages by a number of persons; same as gaṇa-bhogya, gaṇa-bhojya. Cf. eka-bhoga, etc.
1868: gaṇa-bhogya (EI 13, 15), see gaṇa-bhoga or gaṇa-bhojya. Cf. eka-bhoga or eka-bhojya.
1869: gaṇa-bhojya (EI 16), same as gaṇa-bhoga or gaṇa-bhogya.
1870: Gaṇabhṛt (EI 3; SII I), the head of a [Jain] school; same as Gaṇin, Gaṇa-dhara.
1871: Gaṇ-ācārya (LL), the teacher of a Buddhist community.
1872: Gaṇadaṇḍa (EI 30), epithet of a hero; probably, an abbre-viation of Gaṇa-daṇḍanāyaka.
1873: Gaṇa-daṇḍanāyaka, also called Gaṇa-daṇdapāla (EI 18); official designation; probably, a Daṇdanāyaka serving under a gaṇa or corporation or commanding several gaṇas or contingents.
1875: Gaṇadhara (HA), chief disciple of a Jina.
1876: Gaṇaka (EI 18), official designation; cf. Tamil kaṇakaṉ (SITI), a village accountant; also vāśal-kaṇakkaṉ (SITI), accountant at the vāśal (palace or palace-gate); ūrkkaṇakkar-jīvitam (SITI), land assigned in lieu of salary to the village accountant or perquisites of the office of the village accountant (i. e. the Paṭvārī as he is called in many parts of India).
1878: Gaṇapaka (CII 4), official designation; probably the same as Sanskrit Gaṇaka.
1880: Gaṇa-pperumakkaḻ (SII 12; SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; the elders of a gaṇa managing its affairs.
1881: Gaṇa-śreṣṭha (CII 3), probably, the head of a corporation.
1882: Gaṇastha (EI 15), probably, the member of a corporation; same as Tamil Gaṇattār; see Mahāgaṇastha.
1883: gaṇa-sthiti (IA 19), cf. Mālavānāṃ gaṇa-sthityā, Mālava-gaṇa-sthiti-vaśāt, explained as ‘by, or according to, the rec-koning of the Mālavas’, gaṇa being taken to mean gaṇanā. But see sthiti.
1884: Gaṇattār (SITI), Tamil; Sanskrit Gaṇastha; people be-longing to a gaṇa.
1885: gaṇa-vāriyam (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; committee mana-ging the affairs of a gaṇa.
1886: Gaṇa-vāriya-pperumakkaḻ (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; elders of the committee called gaṇa-vāriyam (q. v.).
1887: Gaṇḍa (EI 12), cf. Tamil Gaṇḍaṉ; a hero, probably from the meaning ‘rhinoceros’; cf. similar use of vyāghra, siṃha, etc.; also cf. Paragaṇḍabhairava (EI 29). See Gaṇdaṉ and Gaṇda-peṇḍāra; also Calamartigaṇḍa.
1888: gaṇḍā (IE 8-6; EI 19; IA 27), in the monetary system of some areas of medieval and modern India, regarded as equal to four cowrie-shells and (1/20) of a paṇa; also a small area of land, twenty of which make one kānī.
1891: gaṇḍaka (EI 21), name of a coin; cf. gaṇdā. (EI 27), an official designation.
1893: gaṇḍa-māḍa (EI 5), name of a coin; sometimes specified as ‘small’; also called kārṣāpaṇa, niṣka or gaṇḍa-niṣka; cf. māḍa. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 43.
1895: goṇḍa-peṇḍāra (ASLV), Tamil; ‘the anklet of a hero’ which was worn by men of distinction.
1897: gandhakuṭī (EIA9, 18; IA 14), originally, ‘a chamber for the Buddha's use’; later ‘the chamber enshrining the Buddha image in a monastery’; a shrine where the image of the Buddha is worshipped; a Buddhist temple.
1899: gandha-śāli (EI 5), a kind of rice or paddy.
1901: Gaṇeśa-caturthī (EI 5; IA 17; CII 4), name of a tithi and festival; same as Bhādrapada su-di 4.
1902: Ganeśa-homa (EI 26), a rite; same as Vināyaka-homa.
1903: Gaṅgaikoṇḍa (IE 8-2), title of a Col13a king meaning ‘the conqueror of the Gaṅgā’.
1905: gaṅgāpupuṭaka (IA 18; CII 1), probably gaṅgā-puppuṭaka; a particular fish of the Ganges.
1906: Gaṅgā-yamunā (EI 24, 29), royal insignia probably con-sisting of the representation of the Gaṅgā and Yamunā on the flags or at the gate.
1907: gāṅgeya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 38), gold.
1909: gaṅginikā (EI 18), a stream. (EI 12), a dried up river bed.
1910: gānī, cf. aṭha-gānī, a coin equal to a ṭaṅka (JNSI, Vol. XII, p. 198); cf. jītal.
1911: gaṇikā (EI 33), same as devadāsī. (EI 7), a female elephant.
1912: gaṇikā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the amuse-ment department.’
1913: Gaṇin (SII 2), an astrologer. (EI 3), head of a school. (IA 19; LL), Jain; a Jain ecclesiastic; an ācārya who has disciples but has not risen to be the head of his gaccha or śākhā.
1914: gañja (EI 30), Persian ganj; a treasury or store-house. Utpala on the Bṛhatsaṃhitā, 52. 13, explains gañja as kośa-bhavana, i. e. treasury. See Gañjavara. (IE 8-8), a store-house of liquor.
1915: Gañj-ādhikārin (HRS), a treasury-officer according to the Rājataraṅgiṇī. See Gañjapati, etc.
1916: Gañjapati (EI 13; HRS; HD), same as Persian Ganjwar, treasurer (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 115). See gañja.
1917: Gañjavara (IE 8-3; EI 9; HD), Persian Ganjwar; a treasurer or store-keeper (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 247; Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 177). See Gañjapati, etc.
1919: garbha (LL), a cell; cf. pañca-garbha (LL), ‘a five-celled building’; nava-garbha (LL), ‘a nine-celled building’; sapta-garbha (LL), ‘seven-celled building’.
1921: garbh-āgāra (CII 1), the inner apartment of a temple or palace; same as garbha-gṛha.
1922: garbha-gṛha (SITI), the innermost sanctuary of a temple; inner part of palace; same as garbh-āgāra.
1924: Garga-yavana (EI 33), name applied to the Turkish Muslim invaders of North India, Garga probably being Ghaznī.
1926: garta, gartā (EI 3, 27; CII 3), a trench or pit; a boundary trench; a pit or valley; cf. sa-gart-oṣara (IE 8-5); also found as the termination of names of villages.
1927: garuḍa (IA 20), the royal eagle; the white kite (in areas like Bihar and Madras).
1929: gata-rājya, same as vinaṣṭa-rājya or atīta-rājya (q. v.).
1930: gati (IE 7-1-2; EI 25), ‘four’; also explained as five in number (EI 19).
1931: gātra (IA 14), same as aṅga-bhoga. (EI 33), same as gotra or gotra-śailikā, i.e. a memorial pillar for the dead members of one's family. See yaṣṭi.
1932: gātrī (LP), cf. Gujarātī gāḏa, a cart.
1933: Gauda (EI 5; ASLV), Kannaḍa; same as Gāvuṇḍa; a village headman; the chief farmer of a village. See Gavuḍa. (EI 1), a temple priest. (IE 8-5; EI 28), Oḏiyā; same as gokuṭa; a cowherd or milkman.
1934: Gauḍa-mahāsāndhivigrahika (IE 8-3), ‘the Mahāsāndhivi-grahika of the Gauḍa country’; cf. Mahāsāndhivigrahika.
1935: Gauḍī, name applied to the East Indian alphabet, langu-age and style of composition.
1936: Gauḍika (EI 28), maker and seller cf sugar; see Guḍika.
1938: Gaulmika (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), same as Gulma-pati (q. v.); ‘chief of a troop’; officer in charge of a gulma or outpost or group of guards, soldiers or policemen; ‘superin-tendent of woods and forests’ according to Fleet (CII, Vol. III, p. 50). See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 246.
1940: gaurī-paṭṭa, same as the yoni-paṭṭa of a Śiva-liṅga.
1941: gaurī-varāṭikā, ‘virgin-money’. Gaurī means ‘a virgin’ and varāṭikā is used primarily in the sense of varāṭa or varāṭaka, ‘a cowrie-shell’, and secondarily in that of ‘money’. In the records of Mithilā, gaurī-varāṭikā means ‘money to be paid to the master of a slave girl of marriageable age by the master of her bridegroom’. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 264 ff.
1942: Gautamī-putra (IE 2-8), metronymic meaning ‘the son of a lady born in a family belonging to the Gautama gotra’. Such metronymics refer to the absence of gotr-āntara (i. e. the change of the bride's paternal gotra to that of her husband at the time of marriage) in a popular form of ancient Indian marriage.
1943: Gavuḍa (EI 5; ASLV), Kannaḍa; same as Grāmakūṭa, Gauḍa, Gāvuṇḍa; village headman.
1944: Gāvuṇḍa, Gavuṇḍu (HD), same as Grāmakūṭa, Gavuḍa, Gauḍa. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 74; JBBRAS, Vol. X, p. 208.
1946: gavyūta (EI 22), a distance of about 4 miles; same as gavyūti.
1947: gavyūti (EI 27), a linear measure; same as gavyūta (q. v.).
1948: gayāḍa, cf. guyāḍa (EI 22), courtyard. Cf. the royal names Gayāḍa and Gayāḍatuṅga.
1949: Gayā-mukta (EI 33), one whose śrāddha ceremony has been performed at Gayā.
1951: gelāṭa (IA 18; CII 1), probably Sanskrit gairāṭa, ‘a hill bird’.
1952: geṇu (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; ‘one span’; a unit of measurment.
1954: ghāḏā (Chamba), a system by which the tiller receives one half of the produce. See ghāḏotā.
1955: ghāḏaka, also called ghāḏī (Chamba); land cultivated on the ghāḏā system.
1956: ghada-maṟuturu (CITD), Telugu; an unknown measure of land; a variation of maṟuturu (q. v.). Cf. kāl-maṟuturu.
1957: ghaḍa-puṭṭi (CITD), Telugu; a variation of puṭṭi. Cf. gāl-puṭṭi.
1959: ghaḍiyāramu (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a gong, a watch, a clock, an hour glass; a cup with a hole at the bottom placed on water for measuring time, an hour being counted when it sinks. Cf. ghaṭikā-gṛha.
1960: ghāḏotā (Chamba), spoken of a land tilled on the condition that one half of the produce should go to the owner. See ghāḏā, etc.
1961: ghale (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; measuring rod; cf. Gaṅgana ghale, ‘the rod [measured by the length of the forearm] of a person named Gaṅga’; cf. hasta in Śivacandra-hasta, etc.
1965: gharaṭhā (Chamba), also called gharahana, gharaṭhāi, gharṭhāi; a house site; homestead; from Sanskrit gṛha-sthāna.
1966: Chāñcika, maker of or dealer in oil (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 145-46); same as Gujarātī Ghāṃci.
1968: ghāṭa (EI 21), name of a tax. Cf. ghatṭa.
1969: ghaṭaka, a jar (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309).
1971: ghaṭi, ghaṭī (CII 3), same as ghaṭikā, the sixtieth division of a day (i. e. day and night); equal to twentyfour English minutes. Cf. ghaḍīyāramu.
1972: ghaṭī (CII 4), name of a measure of capacity.
1973: ghaṭika (CII 2-1), used in the sense of ghaṭikā, an hour equal to twentyfour English minutes.
1974: ghaṭikā (CII 3; ML), an hour; time equal to twentyfour English minutes; same as ghaṭi, ghaṭī. (Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 34, note 6), an establishment of holy and learned men. Cf. Tamil ghaṭikai (SII 12). Cf. ghaṭige (SII 3), an assembly. (SITI), an educational institution for advanced studies; a university; probably the same as śālā and mahāśālā. Cf. Prakrit ghaḍia-ghaḍā (EI 8), same as goṣṭhī.
1975: ghaṭikāgṛha-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of time-keeping. Cf. ghaḍiyāramu.
1976: Ghaṭikaiyār (SII 12; SITI), Tamil; members of a ghaṭikā managing its affairs; officials who declare to the public, by beat of tomtom, the orders of kings and other officers.
1978: Ghaṭikā-madhyastha (SITI), an intermediary officer having the authority of the ghaṭikā or recognised by the ghaṭikā.
1979: Ghaṭikāsāhasa (EI 8), same as the Brahmanical family name Ghaisāsa, also called Ghaṭaśāsin, etc. See Ghaṭaśāsulu.
1980: ghaṭikā-śālā (EI 25), same as ghāṭikā-sthāna; an establish-ment of holy and learned men.
1981: ghaṭikā-sthāna (EI 14, 16) ‘a religious centre’; the official meeting place of learned and godly men; cf. ghaṭikā-śālā.
1982: ghaṭita (CII 1), ‘put together’. (Ind. Ant., Vol. XII, p. 121, text line 55), engraved.
1985: ghaṭṭa (BL), bathing or landing place on the bank of a river. (IE 8-5), a harbour or a mountain pass. (ASLV), a contingent of elephants, the number being ten according to some authorities.
1986: Ghaṭṭapāla (IE 8-3); EI 31), the superintendent of landing places on the river banks or of passes.
1987: Ghaṭṭapati (EI 7; CII 4; HD), same as Ghaṭṭapāla; gene-rally explained as ‘an officer in charge of quays or landing places (ghāṭs)’; may also be an officer in charge of a pass (cf. the Orissan royal title Aṣṭādaśa-ghaṭṭa-gondram-ādhipati); see Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91; JBORS, Vol. V, pp. 582, 588.
1988: ghoṣa (CII 4), a settlement of the milkmen.
1989: ghoṭaka-vigraha (CII 4; BL), ‘a battle of horses’; probably, an encounter of horsemen; cf. caturdanta-samara.
1990: ghoṭikā (EI 31), a boundary post bearing the represen-tation of a mare.
1992: ghṛṣṭa-mūrdhaka (LP), ‘with hairs of one's head fallen off.’
1993: ghṛta-pradīpa (LL), a lamp to be burnt with ghee instead of oil.
1994: ghumara (EI 23), used in Bastar in the sense of ‘water-falls’.
1995: gi (IE 8-1), abbreviation of Prakrit gimha = Sanskrit grīṣma (q. v.).
1996: gidda (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a gill, or a liquid ounce; a quarter especially of a sola weighing 16 dubbus.
1997: gimha (CII 4), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit grīṣma; name of a season consisting of eight fortnights or four months.
2001: go (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’; rarely used in the sense of ‘nine’ (cf. graha). Cf. a-paramparā-go-balivarda (IE 8-5); a cow. See balī-varda.
2002: gocara (EI 15; Chamba), pasture land. (LP), a tax for allowing cattle to graze in the pasture land.
2003: gocaraka (Chamba), pasture land; same as gocara.
2004: gocarman (IE 8-6; EI 28; CITD), an area of land often regarded as equal to ten nivartanas although the exact area varied in different ages and localities.
2005: Gocchakapati (EI 28), official designation of uncertain import. Cf. the Bengali family name Guchāita 〈 Gochāyati 〈 Gocchakapati.
2006: go-dvādaśī (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, pp. 161, 163-64), name of a tithi; Āśvina su-di 12; regarded doubtfully also as Mārga-śīrṣa su-di 12.
2007: go-gauḍa (EI 12, 28), name of a tax probably levied on the cowherds; gauḍa is the same as gokuṭa meaning a cowherd or milkman.
2008: go-grāsa, troughful of fodder for the cattle (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 108).
2010: gohari (EI 31), Oḏiyā; cattle track or pasture land; or probably, a road (cf. gohara, gohārā).
2011: goja, the moon (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 58).
2012: gojha (Chamba), pocket; pocket money; personal pro-perty.
2014: gokarṇa (EI 9), gokarṇa-kuśa-kusuma-karatal-odaka-pūrṇa (EI 23), gokarṇa-kuśalatā-pūta-hast-odakena (Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 10, note 57), referring to an elaborate form of the ritual relating to donation generally indicated by the expression udak-ātisargeṇa; same as gaṇḍūṣa (in Bengali); palm hollowed to hold water and resembling a cow's ear.
2015: gokula (EI 9), cf. ‘officer in charge of the gokulas’; cf. Gokul-ādhikārin, Gokulika, Gomaṇḍalika. (SITI), a temple of Kṛṣṇa; also called āyappāḍi in Tamil.
2016: Gokul-ādhikārin (EI 24), superintendent of cattle; officer in charge of the royal cattle and cowpens (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 194). See Gokulika, Gomaṇḍalika. Cf. Vivīt-ādhyakṣa, Vrajabhūmika, Gomahiṣāj-ādhyakṣa.
2017: Gokulika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71), same as Gokul-ādhi-kārin, Gomaṇḍalika.
2018: Gokuṭa (IE 8-5; EI 28), same as Oḏiyā Gauḍa; a milk-man or cowherd.
2020: golakā (SITI), also called gulikā, goḻakkai, koḻakkai, kuḻigai; name of a coin, probably circular in shape.
2021: Golla (EI 3), a cowherd. (IE 8-4), a small territorial unit.
2022: Golla-vāru (CITD), Telugu; a caste of watchmen [emplo-yed as treasure-guards], generally herdsmen.
2025: Gomaṇḍalika (EI 18), officer in charge of the royal cattle. See Gokulika, Gokul-ādhikarin, etc.
2026: gomaṭha (EI 12), name of a sattra-like institution built by a Musalman chief together with a step-well and a garden.
2027: Gomin (IA 13), epithet of a Buddhist priest hailing from Gauḍa-viṣaya; supposed to denote a learned lay brother who held some high office on the establishment of a monastery.
2028: gomūtrikā-bandha (CITD), the style of composition of a stanza, the second half of which repeats nearly all the syllables of the first.
2029: gondrama (EI 30), Oḏiyā; probably, a hill fort or a state having its headquarters on a hill.
2030: goṇī (CII 4), name of a measure of capacity; cf. goṇī-prasṛti.
2031: goṇī-prasṛti (EI 1), a measure of uncertain weight; pro-bably, a handful.
2032: Gopa (EI 24), a watchman. (HD), officer in charge of the royal cattle; officer over five or ten villages according to the Arthaśāstra, II. 35. (HRS), according to the Arthaśāstra, (1) officer in charge of five or ten villages with revenue and police functions; (2) officer in charge of ten, twenty or forty families in the city; similar to the Paṭel, or Paṭvārī (H. Rev. Syst., pp. 146-47).
2036: gopīcandana (IA 16), a kind of coloured earth.
2037: gopracāra (EI 24, 31, 32; CII 4), pasture land. (EI 30), right of grazing cattle.
2038: go-pracāra-bhūmi (SITI), grazing-ground; same as Tamil kaṇṟu-meypāḻ.
2039: gopura (EI 3, 19, 24) a gateway; the gateway of a temple; a tower.
2040: gopura-vāśal (SII 1), Sanskrit-Tamil; the gate of a gopura.
2043: Gorava (EI 7), a Śaiva priest; same as Gurava, etc.
2046: goṣṭhī (EI 24; SII 3; BL), an assembly; a corporate body; cf. Tamil goṣṭhiśeydāṉ, convener of a pariṣad. (LL), Buddhist; a committee; cf. Bauddha-goṣṭhī, Goṣthī-śramaṇa.
2047: Goṣṭhika (EI 4, 24, 33; CII 4), member of a committee or assembly; member of a managing committee; mem-ber of a committee like that of the trustees.
2048: gotra (CII 3; IA 19; CITD), a family or clan, a tribe or lineage; a caste. No Hindu can marry a girl of his own gotra or stock, though some forms of ancient Indian marriages did not involve the gotr-āntara, i. e. the change of the wife's gotra to that of the husband at the time of marriage (Proc. IHC, Annamalainagar, 1945, pp. 48 ff.). Cf. Gautamī-putra, etc. (EI 33), abbreviation of gotra-śailikā, a memorial pillar raised for the dead members of one's family.
2049: gotr-āntara (IE 8-2), the change of the wife's paternal gotra to that of her husband, which was absent in some popular forms of marriage in ancient India (Proc. IHC, Annamalainagar, 1945, pp. 48 ff.).
2050: gotra-śailikā (EI 33), a pillar raised in memory of the dead members of one's family.
2051: Gouḍ (ASLV), Anglicised spelling of Gauḍa or Gavuḍa (q. v.).
2052: Go-vallabha, cf. Prakrit Go-vallava (EI 24; II), a cow-herd; keeper of the royal cattle; see Mahāgovallabha (EI 24).
2054: go-yūthī, cf. sva-sīmā-tṛṇagoyūthī-gocara-paryanta (EI 8-5); yuthī is the same as yūti (or pūti) used in the same context in many other records in the compound tṛṇa-yūti (or tṛṇa-pūti). Goyūthī-gocara may be ‘the enclosure for cattle and pasture ground’.
2055: go-yūti, same as ga-yuthī; cf. yūti.
2056: graha (IE 7-1-2), ‘nine’. (IA 21), seizure; cf. go-graha, cattle-lifting. Cf. sūrya-graha (EI 24), an eclipse of the sun.
2058: grahaṇaka (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, the custody or mortgage of an object. (LP), an ornament; cf. Gujarātī ghareṇuṃ.
2059: grāhya (IE 8-8), ‘to be apprehended or recruited’. Cf. a-kiñcid-grāhya; ‘to be levied’.
2060: grāma (IE 8-4), ‘a village’; often suffixed to the names of localities. (EI 24), a village assembly. (IE 8-4), sometimes used to indicate the number of villages in a territory or geographical unit; but the number was often either exaggerated or traditional without relation to reality; sometimes wrongly interpreted as ‘a unit of revenue assess-ment’. Cf. navanavati-sahasra-grāma-bhāj (IE 8-4), epithet of a territory. See Sircar, Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind., pp. 200 ff. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, pp. 146-47), a villager; same as Grāmeyaka.
2062: Grāma-bhogika (EI 24, 29; CII 4), probably the Jāgīrdār of a village or one who enjoys a village as a free-holding. Cf. rāja-sāmanta-viṣayapati-grāmabhogika-purillaka-cāṭa-bhaṭa-sevak-ādīn (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIX, pp. 114-15).
2063: grāma-deva (IA 14), a village god; cf. grāma-devatā.
2064: grāma-devatā (EI 3; SII 2), a village divinity; cf. grāma-deva.
2065: grām-ādhipati (IE 8-4), ‘headquarters of a Parganā’ (cf. triṃśad-grām-ādhipati-śrī-Kukkunūru); also called modala-vāḍa or rājadhāni in Kannaḍa inscriptions. (HD), same as Grāmapati (Kāmasūtra, V. 5. 5).
2066: Grāma-drohin (SITI), traitor to the village; cf. Grāmakaṇtaka.
2067: Grāmāgrāma-bhojaka (IE 8-3; LL), free-holders or Jāgīr-dārs of various villages.
2068: grāma-grāsa (EI 5, 6, 31), a village granted for the main-tenance of the donee; cf. grām-opahāra (EI 5).
2069: grām-āhāra (IE 8-4; LL), ‘a village-district’; a group of villages; a small territorial unit; cf. mahāgrāma and āhāra.
2071: Grāma-kaṇṭaka (EI 24; SII 13; SITI), a traitor to the village; enemy of the security of a village; annoyance to a village. Cf. Grāma-drohin.
2072: grāma-kārya (IA 8), explained as ‘village rites’; probably, ‘the various functions of the village’; village business (SITI); administration; committee of administration (SII 13).
2073: Grāma-kāyastha (HD), a village scribe or Paṭvārī. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 175.
2074: Grāmakūṭa (EI 8-3); EI 30; CII 4; HD), cf. Grāmamahattara; the headman of a village (or probably, a member of the village council). Paiṭhīnasi and Kauṭilya (IV 5) use the word, and the commentary on the Kāmasūtra (V. 55) explains Grāmakūṭa as halottha-vṛtti. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 285; Ind. Ant., Vol. XVI, p. 24. See Rāṣṭrakūṭa, Deśakūṭa.
2076: Grāma-mahattara (IE 8-3; EI 12, 28), same as Grāmakūṭa and Mahattara; the village headman and a member of the village council.
2077: Grāmamahattar-ādhikārin (EI 25), official designation; probably, Grāma-mahattara and Adhikārin.
2079: Grāma-netṛ (HD), a village headman. See Śukra, II. 120.
2080: Grāmaṇī (EI 27; LL; HD), a village headman; same as Grāmakūṭa. See Hist. Dharm., pp. 153-54; Pāṇini, V. 2. 78.
2081: grāma-parihāra (SITI), obligatory dues of a village.
2082: Grāmapati (EI 24, 26, 29; IA 9; HD), cf. Grāmakūṭa; the headman, owner or Jāgīrdār of a village (Mitākṣarā on Yājña-valkyasmṛti, II. 281). See Grāma-svāmika, etc. Cf. Kuḍipati (EI 18), the headman of a village.
2083: grāma-patra (EI 9), a document indicating the revenue fixed for a village.
2086: grām-āṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa (EI 31), the administrative board (e. g. Pañcāyat) of a village; see aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.
2087: Grāma-svāmika, cf. Gāma-sāmika (EI 24); same as Grāma-pati.
2088: Grāmaṭaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71), official designation; probably a mistake for Grāmakūṭaka.
2089: Grāma-talāra (LP), probably, something like a Faujdār. See Talāra.
2090: grāmaṭikā (EI 9, 19; SII 1), a hamlet; a small village.
2091: Grāmeyaka (EI 31; LL), a villager; inhabitant of a village; probably also the village headman, the same as Grāmika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 327); cf. Vaṭṭa-grāmeyaka (EI 27); also Grāmeyika.
2092: Grāmeyika (LL), a villager; same as Grāmeyaka.
2093: Grāmika (IE 8-5; EI 15; CII 3; LL; HD), a village head-man (Manusmṛti, VII. 116; Arthaśāstra, III. 10; CII, Vol. III, p. 112); same as Grāmaṇī, etc. Cf. grāmika-jana-samūha (EI 24), ‘an assembly of the villagers’.
2094: grāmīya-kula (EI 24), an assembly of the village.
2097: grāsa (EI 11; LP), food; land granted for maintenance; cf. grāsa-lopana (LP), confiscation of the lands given for main-teanance; also cf. grāma-grāsa.
2100: gṛ (IE 8-1), also spelt gri; wrong abbreviation of grīṣma in Prakrit records. Cf. gṛ-ṭī; abbreviation of gṛha.
2101: gṛ-ca-ṭī, abbreviation of an expression probably meaning ‘a mound on which houses can be (or, have been) built and fruit trees can be (or, have been) planted’. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 56.
2102: gṛha, cf. ghara (EI 7), a caitya; a cave. Cf. gṛha-mukha.
2103: gṛha-kara, cf. ilvari, manai-iṟai, manai-ppaṇam (SITI), house-tax.
2104: gṛha-kṛtya (HRS), an office concerned with domestic affairs of the kingdom as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 250.
2105: gṛha-mukha, cf. ghara-mugha (LL), the door of a cave.
2106: Gṛhapati (EI 25; CII 3; LL), a householder; same as Gṛhastha.
2107: Gṛhastha (LL), a householder; same as Gṛhapati.
2110: Gṛha-veṭaka (EI 9), possibly a mistake for Gṛha-ceṭaka, ‘a servant’.
2111: Gṛhīta-sāhasra (EI 33), probably, ‘one from whom one thousand coins have been realised’.
2112: grīṣma (EI 24; CII 4), one of the three seasons constituting the ancient Indian official year; the four months from Caitra ba-di 1 to Āṣāḍha su-di 15.
2113: gṛ-ṭī, abbreviation of gṛha-ṭikkara (ṭīkara) or gṛha-vāstu-ṭīkara, ‘a mound suitable for building houses’. Cf. Ep. Ind, Vol. XXX, p. 56.
2114: guḍa, cf. a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha (IE 8-5); sugar, the pro-duction of which was the monopoly of the king or landlord.
2115: guḍānta-patra (Journal of the Bihar Research Society, Vol. XL, Part 2, pp. 96-97), name of a type of document, the exact nature of which is doubtful; probably, a kind of lease deed. Cf. guṇa-patra.
2116: guḍḍa, guḍḍa-dhvaja (IA 10), Kannaḍa; the meaning of guḍḍa is doubtful; probably, a disciple.
2117: gūḍha-jāla-bandha (CITD), probably, the style of a verse with an artificial arrangement of the letters.
2118: gūḍha-maṇḍapa (HA), an adjacent hall; hall in front of the sanctum, where devotees carry on worship, etc.
2119: Gūḍha-puruṣa (HD), an officer of the secret service. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 156.
2120: Guḍika (EI 28, 31), maker or seller of sugar; see Gauḍika.
2124: Gujarātī, the people, language and alphabet of Gujarat. See Boḏiyā.
2125: gulikā, cf. pudu-kkuḻigai (SITI), name of a coin; also śeṇapaka-kkuḻigai (SITI), name of a coin probably struck by the Śambuvārāyas; puḻḻi-guḻikai-varāhaṉ (SITI), name of a gold coin; vīracampaṉ-kuḻigai (SITI), a coin struck and issued by the Śambuvarāya king Vīracampa; vāḻāl-vaḻitiṟantāṉ guḻikai (SITI), a Pāṇḍya coin supposed to have been issued by Jaṭā-varman Sundara-pāṇḍya I who had the title Vāḻāl-vaḻi-tiṟantāṉ.
2126: gulma (EI 8, 12), a battalion, squadron or outpost. Cf. Gaulmika. (IE 8-5), a bush; cf. sa-gulma-latāka as an epithet of a gift village.
2127: gulma-deya (HRS), dues paid at the military or police station as indicated in the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 78, 227.
2128: Gulmapati (HD), officer in charge of a gulma which means a group or outpost of guards, soldiers or policemen; same as Gaulmika. Cf. JBORS, Vol. V, p. 588.
2130: guṇa (IE 7-1-2; EI 15, 17, 25), ‘three’; rarely in late records, ‘six’. (EI 8), six in number.
2131: Guṇacarita (BL), supposed to be an epithet of a Pratīhāra king.
2132: guṇ-ākṣara (LP), a document for a lease of land by the pro-prietors to cultivators; see guṇa-patra. Cf. guṇ-ākṣarāṇi (LP), a concession letter.
2133: guṇa-patra (LP), a lease of land granted by proprietors to tenants or cultivators for the purpose of cultivating or im-proving it; cf. Pañcāladeśīya-kulānāṃ guṇa-patra-vidhiḥ, ‘an order of royal favour concerning the farmers of the Pañcāla country’; also cf. Gujarātī gaṇotnāmuṃ. See guṇākṣara, guḍāntapatra.
2135: guñjā (IE 8-8; IA 26), same as raktikā or rati. (EI 12), a kettle-drum.
2136: guṇṭha (IE 8-6; EI 28, 31), a land measure of Orissa; equal to one-twentififth of a Māṇa. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 62), Telugu; a pond; cf. silā-guṇṭha.
2137: gupta, cf. gupt-ākṣarāṇi (LP), same as gupta-patḷaka, a deed of permanent lease. See Tamil guttagai = Sanskrit guptakā.
2139: gupta-paṭṭaka (LP), a deed of permanent lease; called gupta probably because it reserved the right of use to a parti-cular man; cf. gupt-ākṣara (also gupta).
2142: Gurava, same as Gorava; epithet of a Śaiva priest (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIV, p. 140, note 4); also supposed to be a Jain priest. (EI 4), a teacher; cf. Gorava.
2143: Gurāva (IA 11), same as Gorava; a Śaiva priest.
2144: guru (SII 1), a preceptor; also ‘the head’ as in Caṇḍik-āśrama-guru.
2145: guru-dakṣiṇā (EI 32), money paid to the preceptor for initiation.
2146: Gurumukhī, also spelt Gurmukhī; alphabet in which the Punjabi language is written by the Sikhs.
2147: guru-āyatana (EI 21, 28) a temple where one's deceased guru (preceptor) is worshipped.
2148: guttagai (ASLV), Sanskrit guptakā; a contract or lease.
2150: guvāka, cf. sa-guvāka-nārikela (IE 8-5); arecanut palms, the enjoyment of which was not allowed to the ordinary ten-ants.
2151: hāda (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit pāda; a land measure equal to one-fourth of the standard measure which was the mattaru or nivartana.
2152: Haḍapada (EI 11), the bearer of the king's betel-bag (cf. Oḏiyā Vāguli, etc.); also explained as ‘a courtier’.
2153: hāga (IE 8-8, EI 5), Kannaḍa; same as pāga, or Sanskrit bhāga; name of a coin.
2154: Hairaṇyaka (LL), Hairaṇyika; a treasurer; also a goldsmith or mint-master. Cf. Hiraṇyakāra, Sauvarṇika.
2155: hala (IE 8-6), literally ‘a plough’; a free-holding (cf. bhikṣu-hala); an area of land, which was not exactly the same in different ages and localities (EI 7, 24, 29, 30, 31; CII 4). (IA 18), a land measure equal to one-fourth of a sīrā (cf. halavāhā); half of a kula; one plough-measure. (EI 3), probably, ‘arable land’; cf. sītā.
2156: hāla (EI 19), a land measure; same as hala.
2157: haladagāṅga (IA 19), explained as ‘the portion having (ga) water (da) and arable land (hala)’; meaning doubtful; probably the name of a locality.
2159: hala-kalita, ‘cultivated [land]’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 297, text line 25).
2161: halavāhā (IA 18), a land measure; cf. hala.
2162: hali (EI 24), a land measure; same as hala.
2163: Hālika (LL), a ploughman (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 274 and note).
2164: Hālikā (EI 15), feminine form of Hālika, ‘an agriculturist or ploughman’.
2166: halirākara (CII 3), a fiscal term of uncertain implica-tion; probably a mistake for halikā-kara, ‘plough-tax’.
2167: Hammīra (EI 24, 33, 34), derived from Arabic Amīr, often adopted by Hindu princes as a personal name; sometimes written as Hambīra and Ahaṃvīra (EI 34). Cf. Suratrāṇa.
2169: haṃsapada, same as suvarṇa (q. v.); same as kākapada (q. v.).
2170: haṃyamana (EI 32, 35), same as hañjamana; regarded by some as derived from Persian anjumān; cf. haṃyamana-paura, explained as ‘the assembly of the Parsees’. But see añjuvaṇṇam.
2171: haṇa (IE 8-8; EI 8), Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit paṇa; name of a coin.
2172: Haṇḍikāpati (EI 5), epithet of a Brāhmaṇa donee; mean-ing uncertain. Haṇḍikā means ‘an earthern pot [for cooking]’, and the expression may mean ‘the head of a joint family (i. e one responsible for feeding the family)’.
2173: hañjamaṇa, hañjamana (EI 25, 32), regarded by some as ‘a Parsee colony’, same as Persian anjumān (cf. haṃyamana), though really it is the same as Tamil añjuvaṇṇam = Sanskrit pañca-varṇa.
2175: hāraka, cf. ‘one hāraka of barley corn’ (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 30, text line 2); possibly bhāraka, a load or measure.
2177: haraṇī, cf. Hastavapra-haraṇī (EI 17), a district; probably a mistake for āharaṇī.
2179: haricandana (CITD), a sort of yellow sandal-wood; one of the five trees of svarga; a title of nobility in medieval Orissa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 4); cf. Śrīcandana.
2180: hari-dina (SITI), ‘the day of Hari’; Saturday; the ekādaśī day.
2182: harītaka, cf. a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa (IE 8-5); myro-balan [which the villagers were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers].
2183: Hārītī-putra (IE 8-2), originally a metronymic (cf. Gautamī-putra), but later sometimes adopted by members of a royal family like a dynastic usage.
2186: hasantikā (IA 15), a brazier or portable heater; also called kaṅgār in Kashmiri.
2187: hasta (IE 8-6), a cubit (24 aṅgulas); sometimes regarded as 36 aṅgulas (27 inches), 20(3/4) inches, 34 inches, etc., in length; cf. Śivacandra-hasta, ‘the cubit measured according to the length of the forearm of Śivacandra’ (cf. ghaḻe). (EI 23; SII 2), a square cubit; a land measure. (Ep. Ind., Vol XIV, p. 366 and note), probably the same as pakṣa, ‘a fortnight’.
2188: hasta-bhāṃ (LP), abbreviation of hastaka-bhāṇḍārin; ‘by the hand of (i. e. through) the Bhāṇḍārin’.
2191: hasti-bandha (EI 32), name of a tax; cf. hasti-daṇḍa.
2192: hasti-daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 33), name of the tax for keep-ing elephants. Cf. hasti-bandha.
2193: hasti-danta (IE 8-5, EI 1), ‘ivory’, referring to the right to keep elephants’ tusks without surrendering them to the king.
2194: Hastikośa, official designation (cf. The Successors of the Sātavāhanas, p. 110, note 2), mentioned along with Vīrakośa as an officer related to a district; probably, an officer in charge of elephants or the elephant corps.
2196: Hastipaka, cf. Hāthivaka (EI 18), keeper of elephants.
2197: Hasti-sādhanika (EI 30), leader of the elephant corps; cf. Gajasāhanī, etc.
2198: hastiśālā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of ele-phants.
2201: Hasty-adhyakṣa (BL; EI 18), keeper of elephants; officer in charge of the elephant corps. Cf. Hasti-sādhanika, etc.
2202: Hasty-āroha (Sel. Ins., p. 54), elephant-rider or elephant-driver; cf. Hāthāroha (EI 18).
2203: Hasty-aśva-go-mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādhyakṣa (IE 8-3), officer or officers in charge of elephants, etc.; Nauk-ādhyakṣa, Bal-ādhyakṣa, etc., are often mentioned separately in the same context.
2204: Hasty-aśva-jana-vyāpṛta, Hasty-aśva-jana-vyāpṛtaka (EI 33), leader or leaders of the elephant corps, cavalry and infantry. Cf. Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-bala-vyāpṛta, Kari-turagapaṭṭasāhaṇi, etc.
2205: Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-bala-vyāpṛta (EI 33), Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-bala-vyāpṛtaka (EI 23, HD), military officer or officers in charge of the elephant, horse and camel corps.
2207: Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-nau-bala-vyāpṛtaka (IE 8-3; EI 24, 29; HD), military officer or officers in charge of the elephant force, cavalry, camel corps and navy. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 166; Ep. Ind. Vol. XVII, p. 321. Cf. Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-go-mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādhyakṣa. It has to be noted that these two are never mentioned together while, on the other hand, one is used in place of the other. See Naubala-hasty-aśva-go-mahiṣ-ājāvik-ādi-vyāpṛtaka, etc.
2208: hatha-paṃṇi, hatha-pāṇi, hatha-pāṇī (Chamba), libation of water; from Sanskrit hasta-pānīya. See hast-odaka.
2209: haṭṭa (EI 1, 30, LP), a market or market-place.
2210: haṭṭa-dāna (EI 3), name of a tax; tolls collected at the market place. Cf. aṭṭapati-bhāga.
2212: haṭṭa-rathyā (EI 30), passage between rows of stalls in the market.
2214: haṭṭikā (LP), a market. (EI 4) probably ‘market-dues’, mentioned along with talapāṭaka or talavāṭaka.
2216: havir-bali (SITI), same as śrī-bali; bali offered with cooked food; same as Tamil ti-yeṟiśoṟu; tax payable for meeting the expenses of the same in a temple.
2217: Hayapati (EI 1, 24, 29; BL; CII 4), same as Aśvapati; ‘the lord of horses’; keeper of horses or a leader of horsemen.
2219: heḍa, cf. heḍāu, heḍavālā (LP), a man who wanders along with a herd of cattle (heḍa) for selling them.
2220: heḍāvika (EI 12), also called heḍāvuka; a horse-dealer. See heḍa.
2221: Hĕggaḍĕ (IE 8-3; EI 28; ASLV) Kannaḍa; official desig-nation indicating a chief, superintendent or director; same as Vĕrgaḍĕ, Pĕrgaḍĕ, Adhyakṣa, etc.
2222: hĕjjuṅka (EI 21), Kannaḍa; name of a tax; also called pĕrjuṅka; Sanskrit mahāśulka or bṛhac-chulka.
2223: hema (IE 8-1), abbreviation of hemanta. See also hema-dhānyaka.
2224: hemadhānyaka, same as māṣa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 45); sometimes hema or dhānaka is used in the same sense (ibid., p. 44).
2225: hema-garbha (EI 12, 16; SII 3), name of a mahādāna; same as hiraṇya-garbha.
2228: hema-ṭaṅka, ‘a gold ṭaṅka (q. v.)’. See JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 197.
2229: hemidrachma (IE 8-8), name of a Greek coin.
2230: Hĕri-Lāḻa-Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin (IE 8-3), same as Sanskrit Mahā-Lāṭa-Karṇāṭa-sandhivigrahin; the same officer is some-times also called Mahāpradhāna, Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa, Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ, etc., additionally. Cf. Sandhivigrahin.
2231: Hĕri-Lāḻa-sandhivigrahin (IE 8-3), ‘the great Sandhivigrahin of Lāṭa’; cf. Sandhivigrahin.
2232: Hĕri-Lāṭa-Karṇāṭa-sandhivigrahin (IE 8-3), ‘the great Sandhivigrahin of Lāṭa and Karṇāṭa’; cf. Sandhivigrahin.
2234: hevaka (IA 18), love or desire; same as Arabic hawwa.
2235: hi (IE 8-1), abbreviation of hiraṇya, ‘cash’ or ‘revenue income in cash’. Cf. sāṃ-hi.
2238: Hiṇḍipaka (LP), explained as ‘a touring revenue officer’.
2240: Hindurāja-suratrāṇa (IE 8-2), title assumed by some of the Vijayanagara kings, adopted from the Muslim royal title Sulṯān. See Suratrāṇa, Hindurāya-suratrāṇa.
2241: Hindurāya-suratrāṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 363), title of the Vijayanagara kings, Suratrāṇa being the same as Arabic Sulṯān. See Hindurāja-suratrāṇa.
2242: hīni (CII 1), same as Sanskrit hāni; loss or diminution.
2243: hiraṇya (IE 8-5; EI 12, 28, 29), same as hiraṇy-āya, hiraṇya-deya; tax payable to the king in cash; dues payable in coins; cash; sometimes abbreviated as hi as in sāṃ-hi = sāṃvatsarika-hiraṇya, annual revenue income in cash; cf. a-hiraṇya-dhānya-praṇaya-pradeya (IE 8-5); it may be in addition to the tax in grain or in lieu of the latter. Cf. Tamil kāś-āya, etc. (HRS), king's share of certain crops paid in cash. (CII 1), probably, ‘money’.
2244: hiraṇyagarbha (EI 16; IA 10; SII 3), name of a mahādāna.
2245: Hiraṇyakāra (LL), a treasurer; also a goldsmith or mint-master. Cf. Hairaṇyika.
2246: Hiraṇyasāmudāyika (IE 8-3), a collector of revenue in cash; sometimes mentioned along with the Audraṅgika or the collector of the udraṅga tax probably levied in grains.
2248: hiraṇyāśvaratha (EI 12), name of a mahādāna; same as hemāśvaratha.
2249: hiraṇy-āya (EI 7), tax in cash; cf. hiraṇya-deya, kāś-āya.
2251: hiraṇya-deya (EI 17), tax in cash; cf. hiraṇy-āya, kāś-āya.
2252: hobaḻi, also spelt hobḻi (IE 8-4; ASLV), Kannaḍa; a small territorial unit like a Parganā.
2255: homa (BL; SII 3), an oblation; name of a ceremony.
2257: hora, horaka (EI 9), probably, a foreign word meaning ‘a lady’
2258: Horamurta (CII 2-1), a foreign word explained as ‘donation-master [of someone else]’; cf. Dānapati.
2261: hrasita (IE 8-3), cf. svayaṃ hrasite karṇe; partly cut off.
2262: Hṛtapragrāh-āmātya (EI 31), officer in charge of the re-covery of stolen property. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 29.
2264: hūn (IE 8-8), same as varāha; name of a gold coin of about 50 grains, called pagoda or ‘star pagoda’ in English.
2265: huṇḍikā (LP), a bill of exchange (Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 266).
2268: Ibhya (CII 1), same as Rājanya or Kṣatriya.
2269: iḍaṅgal13i (EI 28), Tamil; a measure of capacity.
2270: īḍara-vāru, īḍige-vāḍu (CITD), Telugu; a toddy-man or arrack-drawer; from īḍa, ‘a date tree’.
2273: Il13aiya-nāyanār (SITI), the same as the god Subrahmaṇya.
2274: īl13a-kkāśu, also called īl13a-kkaruṅ-kāśu and karuṅ-kāśu (SITI); the Ceylonese coin.
2275: Immaḍi (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa; literally, ‘double’ or ‘twice’; prefixed to the names of certain kings in order to distinguish them from their predecessors bearing the same name; cf. Nūrmaḍi, Mummuḍi.
2278: indra-daṇḍa (CII 4), a pole raised in honour of Indra; also called indra-dhvaja, śakra-dhvaja, etc.
2283: Īśa (EI 23), the god Śiva; the king. (IE 7-1-2), ‘eleven’.
2285: iṣṭāpūrtta (EI 4; SII 3), a charitable deed; performance of charitable deeds.
2286: iṣṭi, used in the sense of viṣṭi; cf. sarv-eṣṭi-parihāra-parihṛta.
2289: īśvar-ālaya (SII 11-1), a temple; a Śiva temple.
2291: jadiākṣetra (IA 16), explained as ‘a kind of land’, but may be ‘land of a person named Jadiā’.
2293: jagati, jagatī (EI 11), explained variously as ‘ground’; (EI 3), ‘lower ground or compound’; (EI 1), ‘a kind of build-ing’; also as ‘railed parapet’ (R. Narsimhachar, The Keśava Temple at Somanāthapura, p. 2). Cf. devagṛha-jagatī (IA 14); also jagati-ppaḍai (SII 2), the upper tier of the basement. See jagatī below.
2294: jagatī (HA), same as bhamatī; the corridor of a shrine on the four sides of its open court, used for circumambulation of the main shrine. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twelve’; sometimes also ‘fortyeight’; rarely used in the sense of ‘the earth’ to indicate ‘one’.
2295: jagatīpura (EI 3), supposed to be the same as brahma-purī or Kannaḍa jagati-kaṭṭĕ which is ‘the raised square seat around a tree before a village’.
2296: jāgīr (EI 33; BL), Persian; a fief; a tenure under Muhammadan rule, in which the public revenues of a given tract of land were made over, either conditionally or uncondi-tionally, to persons like a servant of the State together with the powers required to enable them to collect and appropriate such revenues and administer the general government of the tract. Cf. Wilson's Glossary. See Jāgīrdār.
2297: Jāgīrdār (EI 33), Persian; a fief-holder. Cf. jāgīr.
2298: jāgṛ (CII 1), cf. [yūyaṃ] jāgṛta sampratipādayitum, ‘you would succeed in accomplishing [your duty]’.
2300: jala, cf. sa-jala-sthala (IE 8-5); the waters [in a village]. (IE 7-1-2), used in the sense of jaladhi to indicate ‘four’.
2301: jāla (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309), cf. Sanskrit jālaka, ‘a bunch of buds’; a load.
2303: jala-durga (ASLV), a fort surrounded by water.
2304: jalajakaraṇḍa (CITD), probably, some sort of drum which was either made of conch or shell or was shaped like a lotus.
2305: jala-kara (IE 8-5; EI 4), ‘water-tax’ paid for fishing rights, etc., in tanks, lakes and rivers; sometimes wrongly read as jāta-kara (Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 157, note 1).
2312: jala-yātrā (IA 13), Jain; the festival of bathing a Tīrthaṅ-kara on the occasion of the consecration of an image or of the erection of a dhvaja-stambha or of the prevalence of a plague.
2315: jamātha (IA 11), Indianised form of Arabic jamā'at; the congregation of a community. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144.
2316: jambu-dvīpa, jambū-dvīpa (CII 1), used in the sense of ‘the earth’ or the dominions of the Maurya emperor Aśoka; cf. pṛthivī.
2318: janapada, jānapada (IE 8-3; EI 23, 33), people of the countryside; regarded by some as an official designation (EI 26), and by others as a corporate body (EI 21).
2319: Jana-pradhānin (SITI), probably, a minister governing a district.
2320: Janendra (CII 3; IA 15), wrongly interpreted as ‘the lord of a people or tribe, a tribal ruler’; really, the same as Narendra, ‘a king’.
2321: jāṅgala (IA 18), cf. s-ānūpa-jāṅgala, an epithet of the gift land; either ‘arid’ or ‘covered with jungle’.
2322: jaṅgama, cf. sa-sthāvara jaṅgama (IE 8-5); the moveable belongings of a village. (SITI), a priest of the Liṅgāyat or Vīraśaiva sect.
2323: jaṅghā (HRS), forced service as messenger, as indicated by the Jātakas; also same as Jaṅghākarika.
2324: Jaṅghākarika (HRS), ‘one who pays the royal dues by means of his legs’; ‘one who is liable to compulsory service as a messenger’, according to the Amarakośa. Same as Jaṅghā (q. v.).
2325: jaṅghāla, an embankment (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 204).
2326: Jāṅghika (HRS), same as Jaṅghā or Jaṅghākarika.
2329: janitha (EI 13), cf. sudhā-janitha-niḥsyandad-vapuḥ, ‘its body welling forth from nectarous sources’.
2330: janma-bhūmi, called janma-kkāṇi in Tamil (SITI), gift of land, probably made for the lifetime of a person.
2331: janma-patra (EI 1), a document recording the birth of a child prepared by an astrologer on payment.
2334: jātaka (LL), Buddhist; birth-story [of one who is to be a Buddha in a future life]; story of a previous birth of Gautama Buddha.
2335: jātaka-kkuḍi (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; persons who have undertaken to serve for their lifetime in a temple, etc.
2336: jāta-kara (IA 15), explained as ‘a tax on things grown’; a mistake for or misreading of jala-kara (q. v.).
2337: jāta-karman (EI 4), a ceremony performed at the birth of a child.
2339: jāti-siddh-āya (SITI), communal tax payable in coin; cf. inavari or inavari-kkāśu of Tamil inscriptions.
2344: jauhar (IA 29), javhar (IA 6), Rājasthānī; funeral pile; commitment of suicide en masse; same as sākā or śākā.
2345: jayā (IA 23), hemp. (EI 12), name of a tithi.
2346: Jayadhara (IE8-2), royal title; translated from Greek Nikephoros.
2349: Jayanapati (EI 13), probably, an officer in charge of armour or the armoury. Cf. jayanaśālā-karaṇa.
2350: jayanaśālā-karaṇa cf. karaṇa (LP), explained as ‘the armour department’. Cf. Jayanapati.
2351: jayantapura (EI 4), probably, the same as brahmapurī.
2352: jayantī (EI 9, IA 26), the twelfth tithi; the 12th tithi of a lunar month joined with the Punarvasu nakṣatra.
2353: jayantī-vrata (IA 6), a festival in which maṇḍapanirmāṇa-jāgaraṇa-pratimādān-ādi (erection of a shed, watching through the night, distribution of images, etc.) take place.
2356: jaya-patra, jayarekha-patra (SITI), a certificate of victory in a dispute; a copy of the judgement. See jayarekha-patrikā. (EI 5), a certificate of success.
2357: jayarekha-patrikā (ASLV), a certificate of victory. See jayapatra, jayarekha-patra.
2358: jaya-skandhāvāra (EI 30, 33; CII 3; BL) ‘camp of victory’; the royal camp or capital; epithet of royal camps or residences; same as skandhāvāra.
2359: jaya-stambha (EI 23, 30, 33; CII 4; SII 1, 11-1), a pillar of victory; cf. dharma-jaya-stambha (IA 19).
2360: jayika (IE 8-8), the party that comes off victorious in a dispute.
2361: jemaka (IE 8-5; EI 25, 28), melas or food which the villagers were obliged to provide to the royal officers on tour; the obligation of the villagers to provide food to such officers; wrongly explained by some as ‘a tax for the boarding of touring royal officers’ (CII 4). Cf. Marāṭhī jevā, ‘a feed, a meal; sub-sistence which the villagers were bound to provide for the subordinate servants or Peons when sent to receive the collec-tions’ (Wilson's Glossary, s. v.).
2363: Jenā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 304), Oḏiyā; ‘a prince’; a title of nobility; later stereotyped as a family name in Orissa.
2365: jhāṭa (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 183), a shrub, wood or thicket; Bengali jhāḏ; a bush; used in sa-jhāṭa-viṭapa (EI 27).
2367: jilo, jiḻo, jīlo (Chamba), a land measure. Cf. aḷu.
2368: Jina, same as Tīrthaṅkara. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twentyfour’. (LL), an epithet of the Buddha.
2370: Jina-kalpin (HA), a Jain monk practising rigorous austerities like those practised by the Jinas before their attain-ment of kevala-jñāna.
2371: Jina-mātṛ (HA), the mother of a Jina.
2372: jina-nagara, cf. Tamil śinakaram (SITI), a Jaina temple.
2373: jina-nigama (EI 24), a township in the possession of a Jain temple or, more probably, a Jain temple (cf. jina-nagara).
2374: Jina-yugma (HA), an image showing two Tīrthaṅkaras; a pair of Jina images.
2375: jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-śrīmalla-priya (LP), name of a coin struck by the old Śreṣṭhin named Śrīmalla. Cf. śreṣṭhijīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya.
2376: jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya (LP), literally, ‘the favourite (coin) of old Viśvamalla’; name of a coin. Cf. jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-śrīmalla-priya and śreṣṭhi-jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya; also cf. vīsalapriya-dramma.
2377: jīrṇ-oddhāra (EI 23, 26; HA), repairs or renovation and conservation.
2378: jita, jīta (EI 28, 29), income or wages; revenue income; derived from Sanskrit jīvita in the same sense.
2379: jītal (SII 1), a copper coin; Indianised as jithala; (1/48)th of a silver ṭaṅka of the Delhi Sulṯāns (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 44); sometimes regarded as a copper coin equal to (1/3) of a silver tār which was itself equal to (1/8) of a gold fanam (SII, Vol. I, p. 161); also called dehlīwāl (Num. Supl., No. 38, p. 33).
2380: jitaṃ bhagavatā, also quoted as jitaṃ Viṣṇunā (CII 3, etc.); ‘victory has been achieved by the Divine One, i. e. Viṣṇu’; an invocation used at the commencement of certain ins-criptions.
2381: jīthala, same as jītal. See JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 197.
2382: jīva-loka (EI 3), a village institution of uncertain mean-ing.
2383: jīvana (SITI), maintenance; cf. jīvaṇa-śiṣa. See also bhṛtyebhyo jīvanam kartuṃ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, pp. 109-10).
