2385: Jīva-putrā, Prakrit Jīva-putā (EI 24), a lady whose son is (or, sons are) still living.
2386: jīvita (EI 28; SII 13; ASLV; SITI), maintenance; in-come or wages; also called jīvita-ppaṟṟu, jita and jīta.
2387: Jivita-kkārar (SITI), persons in enjoyment of lands in the jīvita (maintenance) tenure; a class of officials enjoying jīvita.
2388: Jīyar (EI 25; SITI), an ascetic (sannyāsin) looking after the affairs of a temple; same as Maṭh-ādhipati.
2390: jñāpaka (SITI; ASLV), remembrancer; memorandum of events and happenings.
2391: jñātiya (Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, pp. 208, 229), used in the sense of jātīya; e. g. Prāgvāṭa-jñātīya=Prāgvāṭa-jātīya (i. e. ‘belonging to the Prāgvāṭa community).
2392: Jo (EI 30), an abbreviation of Joṣī, same as Jyotiṣin, an astrologer or astronomer.
2393: joḍa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 19), used in some East Indian records in the sense of ‘a canal’. Cf. joṭī, jolaka.
2394: jolaka (EI 4), a canal; same as Bengali jolā; cf. joḍa.
2396: joṭī, same as joṭikā (EI 28), a stream.
2397: joṭikā (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 253, text line 37), a canal; same as joḍa and joṭī or joḍī.
2398: jūhaka (EI 3), a village institution of uncertain meaning.
2400: Jyeṣṭh-ādhikaraṇika (EI 18, 31), explained as ‘the chief judge’; senior officer, chief officer of a class, or officer in charge.
2401: Jyeṣṭha-devara (LP), elder brother of the husband.
2402: Jyeṣṭha-kāyastha (IE 8-3; EI 4, 24), the chief scribe, or the foreman of the Kāyastha class, or the scribe-member of the board of administration; explained as ‘the senior registrar’ (EI 31). Cf. Prathama-kāyastha, Paṭvārī.
2403: Jyeṣṭha-pitā, elder brother of one's father.
2405: jyoti-skandha (CII 1), masses of light; cf. agni-skandha.
2407: ka (IE 8-1), for kā (in Kharoṣṭhī), abbreviation of kāla.
2408: kā (PJS), abbreviation of kārita and kāritā (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions); also of Kāyastha; also of kāṇḍa, ‘a cluster’ (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 204).
2410: kaccha (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 177), a field bordering on a stream; land near a well (Ep. Ind., Vol XXXIV, p. 175, line 15). (EI 22), a resolution.
2411: kacchaka (EI 19), a low hill. (IA 18), wrongly read also as kasthaka; cf. khalaka-kacchaka-bhūmī-sahitā as an epithet of the gift land; probably, ‘land around a well’. See kūpaṃ khalakaṃ kacchakaṃ (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVIII, p. 114, text line 55, cf. line 43); also kūpa-kaccha (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 175, text line 15).
2412: kacchapa, cf. sa-matsya-kacchapa (IE 8-5); tortoise; see jala-kara.
2413: kaḏā (IE 8-6; EI 19), Bengali; the cowrie-shell regarded as a coin; a small area of land; one-fourth of a gaṇḍā and one-eightieth of a paṇa.
2414: kadaru (CII 4), same as kṛdara; a granary.
2415: kaḍḍhaka (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably the same as Sanskrit karṣaka; see ḍheṅku-kaḍḍhaka.
2417: Kaḍit-āmātya (EI 23), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; official desig-nation; same as Kaḍita-vĕrgaḍĕ (q. v.).
2418: Kaḍita-vĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa; superintendent of accounts and records; same as Akṣapaṭalika; sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Hĕrisandhivigrahin, Senādhipati, etc., addi-tionally. See Kaḍit-āmātya.
2419: Kaḍīya (LP), a bricklayer or mason; cf. Gujarātī Kaḍīyā.
2420: kāhala, kāhalā (EI 24; IA 15), a musical instrument; a trumpet. See kākala.
2421: kāhaṇa, kāhāṇa (IE 8-8; EI 29), Bengali-Oḏiyā; modified forms of kārṣāpaṇa.
2422: kai (IE 8-6), Dravidian; same as hasta, ‘cubit’; a unit of measurement.
2423: Kaïsara (EI 26), title of a Kuṣāna king; derived from Roman Caesar.
2426: kāka (IE 8-6), same as kākinī. (EI 14), name of a land measure.
2427: kāka-bindu (SII 2), name of a flaw in diamonds. (SITI), a black dot.
2428: kākala (IA 12), a trumpet. See kāhala, kāhalā.
2431: kākapada, kākapāda (SII 2), name of a flaw in diamonds; a mark indicating omission of letters written outside the line.
2434: kākinī (IE 8-6), also called kāka. (IE 8-6), a small land measure; cf. kānī. (IE 8-8; EI 1; CII 4), name of a small coin; equal to 20 cowrie-shells according to the Līlāvatī; (1/4) of a paṇa according to the Kṛtyakalpataru (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K. V. Ranga-swami Aiyangar, p. 125).
2437: kāla (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’. (CII 3, etc.), time, a period of time; used in the sense of ‘an era’; cf. kāl-ānuvartamāna-saṃvatsara (Select Inscriptions, p. 270, text lines 3-4), etc. See prakāla.
2438: kalabhaśālā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the camel department’.
2439: kāla-cakra, a mechanical weapon placed at the gate of forts according to the Vasudevahiṇḍī (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, No. 1, p. 15). See śataghnī.
2440: kāl-ākṣarita (LP), probably, ‘a word of censure passed’.
2443: kalana, a betelnut plantation (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 205).
2444: kal13añju (IE 8-8; EI 28, 30; SITI), Tamil; name of a gold coin; also of the equivalent weight; about 32 ratis (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 141). Cf. ūr-kal13añju (EI 28), name of a coin. (SII 13), same as suvarṇa.
2446: kalasa (CITD), a vase, flagon or water-pot; an orna-mental piece of painted wood, stone, brass, etc., fixed on the spires of temples, carts, etc.; a rounded pinnacle or ball on the top of a temple; a dome. (EI 5), the pinnacle of a temple; same as kumbha. (EI 11, 33), a measure; cf. droṇa. (SII 3), a pot. (EI 33), also called kalasikā; probably, the same as droṇa; a measure of capacity.
2448: kalasī (LP), a measure of capacity equal to sixteen maunds; cf. kalasikā, kalasikāvāpa.
2449: kalasikā (EI 33), same as kalasī or kalasa; probably the same as droṇa; cf. kalasikāvāpa.
2450: kalasikāvāpa (EI 33), a land measure; originally, a plot of land on which one kalasī measure of seed could be sown; cf. droṇavāpa.
2452: Kalavāḍa, Kalavāḍā, Kālavāḍa, Kālavāḍā (EI 24), same as Kālavāḻa, Kālavāḻā.
2453: Kālavāḻa, Kālavāḻā (EI 24), designation of uncertain meaning if it is not the same as Sanskrit Kalyapāla, a vintner.
2454: kāḻi-gaṇattār (SITI), Tamil; a committee for the temple of Kāḻi (Kālī).
2457: kaliṅga-vāriyam (SITI), Tamil; committee looking after the sluice; derived from kaliṅgu, ‘a sluice’.
2458: kāl-maṟuturu (CITD), Telugu; an unknown measure of land. Cf. maṟuturu, ghaḍa-maṟuturu, etc.
2459: kal-nāḍu (SITI), Tamil; a hero-stone; setting up of a hero-stone.
2460: kalpa (CII 1), same as saṃvarta-kalpa, the aeon of des-truction. (CII 3, etc.), name of a fabulous tree in Indra's paradise, supposed to grant all desires.
2461: kalpādi (EI 5; IA 18), name applied to certain tithis.
2462: Kalpāla (EI 30), also called Kalvapāla, Kalyapāla, Kalyā-pāla; a distiller of liquor.
2463: kālu (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; ‘one foot’; a unit of measure-ment.
2464: Kalvapāla (EI 30), same as Kalpāla, etc.; a vintner.
2465: Kalvapāla-vārika (IE 8-8), official designation indica-ting a spirit-distiller.
2466: kalyāṇa (CII 1), a good deed which is beneficial to the people; a ceremony to bring health and prosperity to a person (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 147); cf. maṅgala in the same senses. (EI 19), a festival (especially, marriage); cf. kalyāṇa-maṇdapa.
2468: kalyāṇa-dhana (HRS), tax levied for the expenses of festi-vals or for the performance of rites to avert evil. Cf. prathama-kalyāṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 147).
2469: kalyāṇaka (HA), a chief auspicious event in the life of a Tīrthaṅkara, there being five such events, viz. cyavana or des-cent from heaven, janma or birth, dīkṣā or initiation as monk, jñāna or attainment of kevala-jñāna, and mokṣa or nirvāṇa, i. e. death which means freedom from the last bondage in the life of a Jina. See kalyāṇikā.
2470: Kalyāṇasundara, Śiva represented as marrying Umā Haimavatī.
2472: kalyāṇikā (EI 8), a festival. (EI 11), certain auspicious days with the Jains. Cf. kalyāṇaka.
2473: Kalyapāla, Kalyāpāla (EI 30), same as Kalpāla, etc.; a vintner.
2474: Kalya-śreṣṭhin (IA 18), a dealer in liquors, Kalya being an abbreviation of Kalyapāla, or a word meaning ‘distillery’.
2477: kāma-koṣṭha, cf. kāma-kkoṭṭam (SITI), a shrine of the goddess Pārvatī as an adjunct of the Śiva temple in the same compound.
2478: kamala-pūjā (BL), probably, worship of a deity with lotuses or flowers of gold or silver.
2479: kāmali (EI 24), often written as kambalin, which means ‘a bull’; a levy probably on prize bullocks (cf. vara-balīvarda). Cf. yamali-kambali.
2480: kāmata (EI 21; CII 4), name of a tax.
2481: kām-āvacara (IA 10), Buddhist; belonging to the domain of sensual pleasure.
2482: kamba, kambha (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; name of a land measure; see kamma and stambha.
2484: kambalin (EI 24), ‘a bull’; a levy probably on prize bullocks (cf. vara-balīvarda); see kāmali and yamali-kambali.
2486: Kāmgār (BL), an official designation meaning a servant, a manager, a public officer; a person employed on public works. Cf. Wilson's Glossary.
2487: kamma (IE 8-6; EI 12, 19), Kannaḍa; same as stambha= skambha; a land measure equal to one-hundredth of a mattaru or nivartana.
2488: kammāḻar (SITI), Tamil; the five artisan classes; also called añju pañcālattār.
2489: kampala (ASLV), same as kampaṇa; name of an adminis-trative division.
2490: kampana, kampanā (IE 8-3), the army [in ancient Kashmir]; cf. Kampanapati, etc.
2491: kampaṇa (IE 8-4), a small territorial unit like a Parganā.
2492: Kampan-ādhipati (HD), commander-in-chief [in ancient Kashmir]; same as Kampanapati, etc. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 447; VII. 1362, 1366.
2493: Kampanapati (IE 8-3), same as Kampan-ādhipati, etc.; commander-in-chief [in ancient Kashmir].
2496: Kampan-odgrāhaka (HD), probably, collector of levies for the army. Cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 1430.
2497: Kaṃsakāra (EI 1, 19, 23), also called Kaṃsāra, Kāṃsāra; same as Kāṃsyakāra, ‘a brazier’.
2498: Kaṃsāra, Kāṃsāra (EI 23), same as Kāṃsyakāra. See Kāṃsāraka.
2499: Kāṃsāraka (BL), a worker in bell metal; a brazier. See Kaṃsāra, etc.
2500: Kāṃsyakāra (EI 19, 32), a worker in bell-metal; a brazier. See Kaṃsāra, etc.
2504: kanaka-haya (EI 24), same as hiraṇy-āśva; name of a mahādāna.
2506: Kanakasabhāpati (EI 3), ‘the god worshipped in the Kanakasabhā’, i. e. Naṭarāja Śiva in the Chidambaram temple.
2507: kanaka-tulāpuruṣa (EI 16; BL), name of a mahādāna.
2508: kaṇakka-kkāṇi (SITI), Tamil; cf. kaṇakka-ppeṟu; land set apart for the village accountant, Kaṇakka being the same as Sanskrit Gaṇaka.
2509: kaṇakka-ppeṟu (SITI), Tamil; cf. kaṇakka-kkāṇi; tax, payable in grains, for the maintenance of the village accountant.
2510: kāṇam (EI 21, 28; SII 3; SITI), Tamil; name of a coin; a gold coin; a weight; a share.
2514: kañcola (IA 15), same as kañcūla; a bodice or waistcoat.
2515: kañcūla, same as kañcola (IA 15), a bodice or waist-coat.
2516: kanda (CITI), name of a metre common in Telugu and Kannaḍa.
2518: kandala (LP), controversy; beating (from Sanskrit kand, to strike).
2519: Kāṇḍapati (IE 8-3); EI 31), an official designation of uncertain import; probably ‘the custodian of the arrows or the armoury’.
2521: kaṇḍāra, Prakrit; cf. utkṛ, ‘to engrave’. See kaṇḍāraṇa.
2522: kaṇḍāraṇa, Kannaḍa; carving or engraving; see Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 36.
2523: kāndiśīka (EI 13; LP), frightened; eager to flee.
2526: kānī (IE 8-6), Bengali; a land measure equal to one-sixteenth of a Doṇ; cf. kākinī.
2527: kāṇi (IE 8-6; EI 24, 28, 30; SII 3) Tamil; a land measure equal to one-eightieth of a veli. (SITI), Tamil; a weight.
2528: kānika (IE 8-5), Tamil; also spelt kānuka; same as kāṇika. (EI 33), also called kānikĕ or kānikĕ-kappa in Kannaḍa; tolls.
2529: kāṇika (IE 8-5), same as Kannaḍa kāṇika-kānĕ, kāṇikĕ-kappa or kappa-kānikĕ, ‘presents from an inferior to a superior’, etc.
2530: kānikĕ, kānikĕ-kappa (EI 33), Kannaḍa; same as kānika; tolls.
2531: kāṇikĕ, kāṇiki (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a land measure of 57000 square feet; sixty-fourth part [especially of any coin]; also (1/8) or (1/34) part; a visit; a present or gift. See kānuka.
2532: kaṇikkā (IE 8-8), same as Sanskrit kaṇikā, common seed.
2533: kaṇikkai (EI 17), kāṇikkai (EI 21; SITI), a voluntary offering; a present offered like nazarāna; presents or customary payments to the king and other high officials.
2534: Kaṇkāṇi (EI 25; SII 2), Tamil; overseer; cf. Māhe-śvara-Kaṇkāṇi.
2536: Kannaḍa, written in English as Kanarese; language and alphabet of the Kannaḍṙgas, i. e. the people of Karṇāta (Sans-krit form of Kannada).
2537: Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin (IE 8-3), ‘the Sandhivigrahin of the Kannaḍa (Karṇāṭa) country’; cf. Sandhivigrahin.
2539: kaṇṭaka, cf. catuṣ-kaṇṭaka-viśuddha (EI 23), same as catur-āghāṭa-viśuddha; probably, ‘the boundary demarcated by planting thorny shrubs’.
2540: kaṇṭaka-śodhanā (SITI), criminal justice; cf. the Madras Museum plates of Jaṭilavarman Parāntaka-pāṇḍya and the Arthaśāstra of Kauṭilya.
2541: kaṇṭhikā (EI 4, 25, 31; SII 1), a necklace; the emblem of heir-apparency.
2542: kaṇṭhikā-paṭṭa-bandha (IA 11), the ceremony of anointing the Yuvarāja with a necklace which was his sign.
2543: kānuka (CITD), Telugu; an offering or courtesy made in homage to a superior or a god. See kāṇikĕ, etc. (EI 33), same as kānika, tolls.
2544: kanyā-dāna (SII 1), giving a daughter in marriage. (EI 29; ASLV), a form of marriage in which bride-price was not demanded or paid; offering one's daughter in marriage without demanding bride-price.
2545: kanyā-dharma (EI 25), same as kanyā-dāna-dharma, the gift of a girl in marriage without demanding bride-price.
2546: kapahaḏī (Chamba), field meant for growing cotton only. Cf. kaphāḏī.
2549: kaparda (CII 4), also called kapardī, kapardaka, etc.; cowrie-shell used as coin.
2550: kapardaka (EI 1), a cowrie-shell used as coin.
2551: kapardaka-purāṇa (IE 8-8; EI 14, 21), ‘a purāṇa [of silver] counted in cowrie-shells’. Cf. paṇa-purāṇa.
2552: kapardaka-voḍi (EI 23), a cowrie-shell used as coin.
2553: kapardī, kapardikā (EI 9; CII 4), a cowrie-shell used as coin.
2556: Kapila-ṣaṣṭhī (EI 25), cf. Kapila-caṭṭi (EI 5), name of a tithi.
2557: kappa (EI 33), Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit śulka or kara. (SITI), Tamil-Telugu-Kannaḍa; periodical and custo-mary payments by persons engaged in some professions.
2558: kara (IE 8-5), explained by a commentator as ‘the dues (bhāga) to be realised by the king for the enjoyment of royal land by using it for cultivation and for grazing cattle’; tax in general. (IE 8-5) rent or tax to be paid in grains when mentioned side by side with hiraṇya. (HRS), tax in general, according to the lexicons; accord-ing to the Arthaśāstra, (1) periodical tax over and above the king's customary grain-share; (2) emergency tax levied upon the villagers over and above the normal grain-share; (3) tax upon merchants' profits. (EI 29; Chamba; CITD), a tax or impost; royal revenue; rent, dues; toll, tribute. (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’.
2560: kara-grāma (ASLV; SITI), a revenue-paying or ryotwari village.
2561: karaiyīdu (ASLV), system of periodical redistribution of lands.
2562: kāraka (IE 7-1-2), ‘six’. Cf. Prakrit Karavaka (EI 12), same as Prakrit Kārāpaka; superintendent of the construction of a building.
2563: karakaca (LP), ‘talk that may annoy the hearer’; cf. Gujarātī kackac.
2564: karākara-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of revenue.
2565: Karaṇa (EI 4), an accountant. (EI 28; HD), a clerk; a scribe. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 155. (EI 19), same as Marāṭhī Kulkarṇī. (SITI), a type of law-court lower in rank than an adhikaraṇa. (IE 8-1, 8-8; EI 28, 30), same as or a shortened form of adhikaraṇa; a court of law. (IE 8-3), an office or department. (CII 4), a committee. (LP), a department, according to the editors of the Lekhapaddhati, the thirtytwo karaṇas or departments being the following; śrī-karaṇa, vyaya-karaṇa, dharm-ādhikaraṇa, maṇḍapikā-karaṇa, velākula-karaṇa, jala-karaṇa, [sthala] patha-karaṇa, ghaṭi-kāgṛha-karaṇa, ṭaṅkaśālā-karaṇa, dravya-bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, aṃśuka-bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, vārigṛha-karaṇa, devaveśma-karaṇa, gaṇikā-karaṇa, karaṇa, hastiśālā-karaṇa, aśvaśālā-karaṇa, kalabhaśālā-karaṇa, śreṇi-karaṇa, vyāpāra-karaṇa, tantra-karaṇa, koṣṭhāgāra-karaṇa, upakrama-karaṇa, karākara-karaṇa, sthāna-karaṇa, deva-karaṇa, sandhi [vigraha]-karaṇa, mahākṣapāla-karaṇa, mahārasa-karaṇa, jayanaśālā-karaṇa., sattrāgāra-karaṇa, antaḥpura-[karaṇa] and koṣṭhikā-[karaṇa]. (CII 3, 4), a document. Cf. Karaṇam (SII 1; SITI), Tamil; also spelt Karṇam; a document; an accountant, also called Kaṇakkaṉ or Karaṇikka. (IA 17), name of the half of a tithi.
2566: kāraṇa, cf. ahaṃ kāraṇaṃ karomi (LP), ‘I shall prove’.
2567: karaṇa-daṇḍa (SITI), fine imposed by the karaṇa (court).
2569: karaṇa-karman (EI 30), the profession of the scribe.
2570: Karaṇa-kāyastha (EI 7; HD; BL), official designation of a scribe; a writer of legal documents. Cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 133. (IE 8-3), mentioned as a Pātra.
2573: Kāraṇavan (SITI), Tamil; an accountant; also called Kāraṇika and Karaṇattār.
2574: Karaṇika (CII 4; BL), official designation of a scribe; the writer of legal documents; explained by some as ‘an officer in charge of a State department or office’ (HD); but really, a scribe. Cf. karaṇika-ṭhakkura (i. e. a Karaṇika who enjoyed the dignity of a Ṭhakkura) in Ep. Ind., Vol. XX, p. 44; Vol. VIII, p. 158; and Karaṇika-Brāhmaṇa (i. e. a Karaṇika who belonged to the Brāhmaṇa community) in Bhandarkar's List, No. 350. See Mahākaraṇika. (EI 6; ASLV), same as Korṇam or Senabova; a village accountant. Cf. Vāśal-karaṇikam (SITI), same as Vāśal-kaṇakkam (°gaṇaka).
2576: Karaṇikka-joḍi (SII 2; SITI), the quit-rent of the Karaṇam or Karṇam.
2578: Karaṇin (HD), same as Karaṇika. Cf. karaṇi-parikara (Harṣacarita, VII, para. 2).
2579: karaṅka (EI 30), a cup made of coconut shell, used in measuring liquids; a karaṅka measure; also the same as tāmbūla-karaṅka (the king's betel-box). Cf. Karaṅkika.
2580: Karaṅkika (EI 13), officer in charge of the karaṅka (i. e. tāmbūla-karaṅka or the king's betel-box).
2581: Kārāpaka (EI 19; IA 19), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit Kāraka; an agent.
2582: kara-śāsana (EI 29, 33), charter recording a grant of land for which the donee had to pay rent; a grant for which revenue (either in full or at a concessional rate) was fixed; land granted in the said way.
2583: karaṭikā, cf. karaḍigai (SII 13), a musical instrument.
2585: Karika (Ep. Ind., Vol XIII, p. 119, text line 8), official designation; probably a mistake for Tarika.
2586: kariṇī-bhramaṇa (EI 24, 25), ‘taking the she-elephant around’; a ceremony in fixing the boundaries; cf. piḍi~śūl13ndu (SITI), walking around by a female elephant to mark the boundary of the gift land, etc.
2588: karīṣa (IA 9), name of a land measure.
2589: Kari-turaga-pattan-ākarasthāna-gokul-ādhikārin (EI 18, 24, 33), designation of an officer (or designations of several officers) in charge of elephants, horses, townships, mines and cowpens.
2590: Kari-turaga-paṭṭasāhaṇi (EI 5), military officer (or officers) in charge of the elephant force and cavalry. Sāhaṇi is the same as Sādhanika (q. v.).
2591: Kari-turag-oṣṭra-nau-sādhanika (EI 23), military officer (or officers) in charge of the elephant force, cavalry, navy and camel corps. See Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-bala-vyāpṛta, etc.
2592: Karivāhinīśa (EI 30), leader of the elephant force. Cf. Hasty-adhyakṣa, etc.
2593: Karivṛndanātha (EI 30), leader of the elephant corps. cf. Hasty-adhyakṣa, etc.
2594: kārkhānā (HA), office of the managing body of a Jain shrine or of a group of Jain shrines.
2596: karmānta (EI 13), cf. paśukul-āvadāra-karmānta-konakalika-gaṅgā-grāme. The reference seems to the karmānta, etc., at Gaṅgā-grāma. Cf. Karmāntika, Kārmāntika, etc. (EI 31), also called karmānta-sthalikā, a barn.
2597: karmāntaka (EI 15), cf. Khaliṣa-karmāntaka-prabhu-Bhaṭṭa-Jayasomasvāmin in the description of a donee Brāhmaṇa who was the master of a karmānta at Khaliṣa.
2598: Karmāntika (IA 14; LL), ‘the superintendent of a work’. Cf. Kārmāntika.
2599: Kārmāntika (HD), superintendent of the mines and state manufactories. See Arthaśāstra, I. 12 (mentioned among the 18 tīrthas); II. 12 (section called ākara-karmānta-pravartanam, ‘the working of mining operations and manufactories’). Cf. Karmāntika.
2601: Karma-saciva (IE 8-3; HD), an administrative officer; an executive minister; cf. Mati-saciva, a counsellor or minister. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 36.
2605: Karmin, cf. Tamil Kaṉmi (SITI), an official; ‘an officer’ as distinct from ‘a servant’.
2607: Karṇam, also spelt Karaṇam. See Karaṇa.
2608: Karṇaprāvṛta (SII 2), same as Karṇaprāvaraṇa, ‘a people whose ears are so large that they use them as a cloak’. Cf. Sircar, Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind., pp. 36, 67.
2611: karṇa-troṭana (IE 8-8), cutting off a bit from some-body's ears.
2612: karpaṭa, cf. karpaṭa-pade (LP), supposed to be something like nazarāna; literally, ‘[payment] on account of clothes’ (same as karpaṭa-bhāvena).
2613: karpaṭa-bhāva (LP), explained as Pāghḏī, i. e. a present, bribe or inām; but cf. also aśana-karpaṭā(ṭa)-bhāvena (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 50, text lines 16-17 and note 4).
2614: Kārpaṭika (BL), probably, a hermit or mendicant; cf. karpaṭi-vrata. (EI 11), explained as ‘a pilgrim’.
2615: karpaṭī(ṭi)-vrata (EI 31), observance of the life of a hermit.
2616: karpūra-mūlya, cf. kappūra-vilai (SITI), the sale-price paid for temple lands; the price paid for cultivation rights of temple lands and in commutation of the taxes thereon.
2617: karṣa (IE 8-8; CII 4), name of a weight equal to 80 ratis; same as tolā; sometimes regarded as 100 or 120 ratis in weight (JNSI, Vol. II, p. 3). (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 309), a measure of capacity for liquids. (CII 4), name of a coin; cf. kārṣāpaṇa.
2618: kārṣāpaṇa (IE 8-8; EI 29; CII 4), name of a gold, silver or copper coin one karṣa (80 ratis) in weight; name of a silver coin of 32 ratis, same as purāṇa or dharaṇa; name applied to the gold gaṇḍa-māḍa also called niṣka or gaṇḍa-niṣka (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 43). The weight of a copper or gold kārṣāpaṇa was 80 or 100 ratis (JNSI, Vol XV, p. 143); copper kārṣāpaṇa was also called paṇa. Cf. kāhāpaṇa (EI 8), Prakrit for Sanskrit kārṣāpaṇa; see kāhāṇa, kāhaṇa.
2620: kartavya (LP), derived from kṛt; ‘to be cut’.
2621: Kārtākṛtika (IE 8-3), probably, an officer who reported to the king about the progress of important undertakings; cf. kṛt-ākṛta-jño bhṛtyānām (Matsya Purāṇa, CCXV, 17). See Mahākārtākṛtika.
2622: Kartṛ (CII 3, etc.), the maker; a technical term for the composer of a record, as opposed to the person who reduced it to writing. Cf. Karttār (EI 33), Tamil; an officer.
2623: kārttika (CITD), crops reaped in the month of Kārttika.
2625: kārttik-odyāpana (IA 18), also called kārttik-odyāpana-parvan (BL), a festival in honour of Viṣṇu, connected with Kārttika su-di 11.
2626: kāru-deya, cf. sarva-parihāra-kāru-deya (EI 24); tax realised from the artisans; same as kāruka.
2627: Kāruka (LB), an artisan. The five classes of artisans may be the carpenter, the blacksmith, the potter, the barber and the washerman. (IE 8-5; EI 25, 32), tax on artisans and craftsmen; same as kāru-deya.
2628: kārukara (HRS), traced by some in the Prakrit passage sa-karukara in a Śātavāhana record and identified with udraṅga and uparikara; but may be Sanskrit kar-otkara, i. e. kara and utkara (probably the same as upakara or uparikara), or kāru-kara=kāru-deya (q. v.).
2630: kāru-śilpi-gaṇa, various types of artisans. Cf. Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 98.
2631: karvaṭaka (EI 13), a market town; cf. Sanskrit kharvaṭa.
2632: kārya, cf. Tamil kāriyavārāycci (EI 24), name of a tax. Cf. Vāśal-kāriyam (SITI), the officer in charge of the palace gate; also known as Vāśal-mudali or Vāśal-nirvāham.
2633: Kārya-cintaka (CII 4), a member of the executive commi-ttee of a corporation.
2635: Kārya-kartṛ (SITI), an agent; also called Kāriyattukku-kkaḍavar, a designation sometimes enjoyed by the Pradhāni or the provincial governor (ASLV).
2636: kārya-vārāycci (SITI), Tamil; also spelt ārāycci; cess paid for the superintendence of transactions.
2637: Kāsāra (EI 4), a brazier; same as Kāṃsyakāra.
2639: kāś-āya (SITI), same as kāśu-āyam; taxes and dues payable in coin; also called kāś-āya-vargam, kāśu-vargam and kāśu-kaḍamai. Cf. hiraṇy-āya, dhānya-varga.
2640: kāṣṭha, cf. a-tṛṇa-kāṣṭha-grahaṇa (IE 8-5), fuel or wood which the villagers were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers. See also devakuṭī-kāṣṭha.
2641: kāṣṭh-āgāra, cf. kaṭṭāgara (SII 3), a wooden house.
2643: kāṣṭha-yūti, cf. yūti; ‘a wood for preserving fuel’.
2644: kāśu (SII 1), Tamil; money; a coin; ‘a tax’; cf. kāśu-kaḍamai, tax payable in cash. (IE 8-8), name of a coin; sometimes called dīnāra (q. v.); cf. ūr-kāśu (EI 28), vīrapañcālaṅ-kāśu (SITI), sambiraṇippalaṅ-gāśu; also īl13a-kkāśu (EI 28), ‘the Ceylonese coin’; śol13iya-kkāśu (SITI), name of a copper coin believed to have been intro-duced by the Col13as; palaṅ-kāśu, nat-kāśa, nal-kāśu (SII 12); generally regarded as (1/100) of a paṇam; cf. triśūla-kāśu (SII 3). Cf. āśuva-kkāśu (SITI), or ājīvaka-kāśu, tax payable by the Ājīvakas. Cf. aḍimai-kkāśu (SITI), fees collected from the temple servants; also adi-kkāśu, tax collected from stall-keepers in the markets. Cf. uppu-kkāśu (SITI), salt-tax. Cf. vagainda-kāśu (SITI), tax payable in cash for marking details of land, etc.; fees for the division of land; also the fee for settlement of a dispute, etc. Cf. veli-kkāśu, veli-ppayaṟu (SITI), Tamil; tax payable in cash, the exact nature of which is not clear. Cf. veli-kkuḻ-ppaṇam. Cf. inavari-kkāśu (SITI), communal tax payable in coin; cf. jāti-siddh-āya of Telugu inscriptions. (SITI), Tamil; a measure of weight equal to (1/4) palam.
2645: kaṭaka (EI 8, 17), the camp or capital. (SITI), a fortified place; a cantonment; a military camp. Cf. kaṭakaṃ kartavyam (LP), ‘an army should be sent [against one]’.
2646: Kaṭak-ādhirāja (EI 4), same as Kaṭakarāja, etc.; a military officer in charge of the royal camp.
2649: Kaṭakarāja (EI 9; HD), officer in charge of the royal camp; same as Kaṭakādhīśa, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 309, note 1.
2650: Kaṭaka-vārika (EI 30), probably, officials serving under the superintendent of the royal camp (Kaṭakarāja, etc.).
2651: Kaṭakeśa (EI 29; HD), superintendent of the royal camp; same as Kaṭakarāja, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 185.
2652: ka-ṭa-pa-y-ādi (IE 7-1-3; EI 33; IA 19, 24), a system of recording numbers.
2653: kaṭhāri (ASLV), same as Sanskrit kartarī, a sword.
2655: kathita, drawn up or dictated (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 179). Cf. cintita, ‘composed’ (ibid., Vol. XXXV, p. 58).
2657: kaṭṭaṇa (SITI), periodical presents made to superiors by their subordinates.
2659: Kaṭuka (EI 13; HD), an official designation of uncertain import; cf. Mahākaṭuka. See Ep. Ind., Vol XIII, p. 117.
2660: kaṭumukha (EI 5), name given to a musical instrument.
2661: kauberacchanda (CII 3), a particular kind of pearl-necklace.
2664: Kaupitka (EI 1, 23), official designation of uncertain import; probably, a collector of tolls.
2665: kā-usaggiyā (HA), Sanskrit kāyotsargikā; the image of a Tīrthaṅkara standing in the kāy-otsarga posture. See kā-ussagga.
2666: kā-ussagga (HA), Sanskrit kāy-otsarga (q. v.); a posture of meditation in which one stands erect with arms hanging and the soles of the feet kept four inches apart.
2667: kauṣṭheyaka (HRS), occurring in the Arthaśāstra and understood by some in the sense of earnings from the king's store-houses.
2668: kaustubha (CII 3, etc.), a jewel worn on the breast of Viṣṇu.
2669: Kauṭumbika, cf. Prakrit Koṭubika (EI 24), a householder.
2670: kavaca (SITI), same as Tamil tiru-kkōl13gai, the metallic cover exactly fitting the image of a deity; same as kholī, kholikā.
2671: kavale, also called kavaleḍu, kavaligĕ (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a pack of written leaves; palm leaves prepared for writing accounts.
2672: kaveluka, kāveluka (LP), tile; cf. kivelu, Marāṭhī kaul, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 144-45.
2673: Kavirāja (IA 26), title; sometimes found also among the Musalmans.
2675: Kāyastha (EI 24; ASLV; HD), a clerk; explained by some as ‘a registrar’ (EI 31); a scribe or writer in the king's revenue department according to some. See Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 322; Viṣṇu Dharma Sūtra, VII. 3; etc. Cf. Aśvaghāsa-kāyastha and Grāma-kāyastha (Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 175; IHQ, Vol. IX, p. 12). See also Hist. Dharm., Vol. II, pp. 75-77. For derivation, cf. Bhār. Vid., Vol. X, pp. 280 ff.
2677: kāy-otsarga (EI 3), a kind of obeisance. Cf. Prākrit kā-ussagga (HA), a posture of meditation in which one stands erect with arms hanging and the soles of feet kept four inches apart. Cf. kāusaggiyā.
2678: kedāra (EI 28), a corn-field. (EI 32), low land. Cf. bhū-kedāra (EI 19); a land measure; cf. the land measure called keyār in the Sylhet region of East Pakistan.
2679: kedārikā (IA 15), a small field; cf. kedāra.
2680: kelā (IE 8-8; EI 30), meaning uncertain; probably, a doll or toy.
2682: kendra (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’. (CII 3), anomaly of the moon, taken to be her distance from apogee, from which point it is always reckoned by Hindu astronomers; the annual variation in the moon's kendra is 3 signs 2 degrees and 6.2 minutes, or 7 tithis 9 ghaṭīs and 42 palas. See also nīcocca-māsa, tithi-kendra, tithi-madhyama-kendra and tithi-spaṣṭa-kendra.
2684: kevala-jñāna (HA), Jain; omniscience; a technical term for the highest knowledge; the Jain doctrine of unity (IA 18).
2688: Khaḍgagrāha (IE 8-3; EI 30), probably the same as Khāḍgika; swordsman; sometimes distinguished from Khaṇḍapāla.
2689: Khaḍgagrāhi-mahāpātra (EI 28, 31), official designation in which Khaḍgagrāhin seems to indicate an officer in charge of swordsmen (as opposed to the clubmen); see Mahāpātra.
2690: Khaḍga-grāhin (EI 28), same as the Khaṇḍāita (originally, swordsmen of the kings of Orissa); cf. Khaḍgagrāha.
2691: Khaḍga-rakṣa (EI 30), same as Khaḍga-grāha; used in place of Aṅgarakṣa and Khaṇḍarakṣa of some records (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVII, p. 11, text line 14); probably, the king's bodyguards.
2692: Khāḍgika (IE 8-3), ‘swordsman’; probably ‘a palace-guard’; mentioned separately from Khaṇḍarakṣa which is also spelt Khaḍgarakṣa.
2697: Khādyaṭapākika (IE 8-3), probably a mistake for Khādyakūṭa-pākika (cf. anna-kūṭa, ‘a heap of food’); same as Mahānas-ādhyakṣa; called Sandhivigrahika, Kumārāmātya, Mahā-daṇḍanāyaka, etc., additionally. See Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ, Mahānas-ādhyakṣa, Sūpakārapati, Mahānasika.
2698: khājaṇ (IE 8-8), Marāṭhī, etc.; see khajjana, etc.
2699: khajjana, khajjaṇa, khajjāna, khajjaṇaka (IE 8-8; EI 33), same as Marāṭhī and Koṅkaṇī khājaṇ; an area near the sea shore, on which a thin layer of sand accumulates after the ebbtide coming through inlets; a rice field created out of such an area near a hillock by erecting embankments on the three other sides; a field created by reclaiming a river bed; cultivable land created from the bed of a river which carries the flood-water from the sea; a salty marsh or meadow; a rice field created near the bed of a nullah on the sea shore by putting embankments. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, pp. 53-54. It is sometimes called pukkoli-khajjana, pukkoli probably meaning a similar kind of land.
2701: khala-bhikṣā (EI 3, 25; HRS), a levy; cess payable at the threshing floor; portion of crop over and above the usual grainshare, collected from grains heaped upon the threshing floor.
2702: khalaka (IA 18), a threshing floor [probably situated near a well]; cf. khala. Cf. khalak-ānte (LP), ‘at the end of the threshing season’.
2703: khalakīya (LP), tax payable at or for using the threshing floor; cf. khala-bhikṣā.
2705: khalla (IE 8-5), same as Oḏiyā khāl; low land; cf. sa-khall-onnata (EI 12), ‘with low land and high land’. (IE 8-8), a hide. (EI 30), leather vessel for carrying wine.
2707: khaṃ, abbreviation of khaṇḍa, ‘a piece’ (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 204).
2708: khampaṇa (EI 23), a territorial division; same as kampaṇa.
2709: khampaṇaka (IE 8-4), a small territorial unit; same as khampaṇa or kampaṇa.
2710: khānaka (EI 15), same as khātaka in the sense of khanana.
2711: khaṇda (IE 8-4; EI 23), a territorial division; the sub-division of a deśa. (IE 7-1-2), ‘nine’. Cf. nava-khaṇḍa (IE 8-4), ‘having nine divisions’; an epithet of Bhārata or Bhārata-varṣa. (EI 30), a habitation. (EI 3, 24), also called khaṇḍi; a land measure. See khaṇḍaka. Cf. Tamil kaṇḍam (SITI), a portion of the mukha-maṇḍapa of a temple.
2713: Khaṇḍāit (IE 8-3), a community in Orissa; probably the swordsmen maintained by kings as opposed to their Pāiks or clubmen; cf. Khaṇḍarakṣa and Khaṇḍapāla.
2714: khaṇḍaka (SITI), cf. Tamil kaṇḍakam, a land measure. See khaṇḍa.
2716: khaṇḍala (IE 8-4; EI 12, 18), a territorial unit; a district or its subdivision.
2717: khaṇḍala, khaṇḍalaka, same as khaṇḍa; cf. kṣetra-khaṇḍala or °khaṇḍalaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135, text time 22; p. 139, text line 22).
2718: Khaṇḍapāla (IE 8-3; EI 28), official designation; same as Khaṇḍapati or Khaṇḍarakṣa (q. v.). See Khaṇḍavāla.
2719: khaṇḍapāla, also called khaṇḍapālīya (IE 8-3; EI 24, 28), tax for the maintenance of swordsmen; tax for the main-tenance of the Khaṇḍapāla or Khaṇḍapālas.
2720: Khaṇḍapati (EI 12, 28), official designation; same as Khaṇḍapāla.
2721: Khaṇḍarakṣa (IE 8-3; HD), sometimes spelt as Khaḍga-rakṣa, ‘swordsman’; probably the king's bodyguard; mentioned separately from Khāḍgika; cf. Khaṇḍapāla; also Khaṇḍāit; some-times regarded as the same as Khaṇḍapāla meaning the ruler of a small territorial unit. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321. Cf. Khaḍgarakṣa (Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., pp. 127-28).
2722: khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-jīrṇ-oddhāra (EI 23), also called khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-navakarman, khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-prakaraṇa; repairs.
2723: Khaṇḍavāla (EI 7; HD), modification of Khaṇḍapāla. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91; JBORS, Vol. V, p. 588.
2724: khaṇḍi (EI 3), also called khaṇḍa, a land measure. Cf. khaṇḍī spelt in English as candy.
2725: khaṇḍī (CII 4), a measure of capacity; cf. khaṇdīkā. See candy. (IA 15), a land-measure.
2726: khaṇḍika, khaṇdikā (EI 22; CII 4; IA 20), measure of capacity; same as khaṇḍī or candy; often regarded as equal to between 800 and 1000 seers. See puṭṭi. Cf. Ṛgveda-khaṇḍikā, a school for teaching the Ṛgveda (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 37 and notes).
2727: khaṇḍuga (IE 8-6; EI 4; CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a weight of 192,000 tolās for silk, sugar, drugs and cotton; a land measure; a land measure of 64,000 square yards of dry and 10,000 square yards of wet land [in Mysore]; a dry measure of 409,6000 or 134,400 or 128,000 tolās in different places. Cf. khaṇḍuka.
2728: khaṇḍuka (IE 8-6), a measure of capacity; cf. khaṇḍukavāpa.
2729: khaṇḍukavāpa (IE 8-6), an area of land requiring one khaṇḍuka measure of seed grains for sowing.
2730: khanika, cf. Prakrit khaniya (EI 20), a pillar. Cf. khāṇu.
2732: khāri (EI 17), a land measure; cf. khārī, khārīvāpa.
2733: khārī (IE 8-6; CII 4), a measure of capacity equal to sixteen droṇas. (IE 8-6), shortened form of khārīvāpa or khārikāvāpa.
2734: khārikā (IE 8-6), shortened form of khārikāvāpa or khārī-vāpa; also same as khārī.
2736: khārīvāpa (IE 8-6), an area of land requiring a khārī measure of seed grains for sowing; a land measure equal to sixteen droṇavāpas or two kulyavāpas.
2737: Kharoṣṭhī, an early Indian alphabet which was an Indian modification of the Aramaic alphabet; called Kharoṣṭrī by some.
2738: kharvaḍa (EI 5), Sanskrit kharvaṭa; a market town.
2739: kharvaṭa (ASLV), an administrative unit. See also kharvaḍa.
2740: khaścā (LP), also spelt ṣaścā; teasing; cf. khāṃc-khuṃc in Gujarātī. See khaśrā.
2741: khaśrā (EI 1), loss or injury. Cf. khaścā.
2743: khātaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 253, text line 33, note 4), probably, a canal; same as Bengali khāt.
2744: Khatiba, same as Arabic Khatīb, preacher (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 145).
2745: khāṭikā (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 253); the mouth of a river; same as Bengali khāḏī.
2746: khattaka (EI 8), Kannaḍa; a pedestal or seat. (EI 11; HA), a niche; a term found in Jain inscriptions in the said sense.
2747: khaṭvā, cf. a-kūra-chullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa (IE 8-5); a cot which the villagers were obliged to provide for a touring officer of the king.
2748: khaṭvāṅga (EI 5; SII 2), a club with a skull fixed at the top; a Śaiva emblem.
2752: khila (EI 15; Chamba), uncultivated land; fallow land; cf. sa-khila-nāla (IE 8-5).
2754: Khoja (EI 6), a merchant. Cf. Khwāja, the Muslim title of distinction.
2755: Khola (IE 8-3); HD), an official designation of uncertain meaning (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, pp. 250, 253); probably a kind of messenger. Utpala on the Bṛhatsaṃhitā, 85. 34, explains Dūta as Gamāgamika while some Pāla inscriptions place Khola between the two; probably the same as Preṣaṇika or Dūta-preṣaṇika, a dispatcher of messengers.
2756: Kholī, kholikā, same as kavaca (q. v.).
2757: khoṭa (HRS), what is payable to the king in the shape of hiraṇya, etc., and of compulsory labour and the provision of food for the Cāṭas and Bhaṭas, according to the Abhidhāna-rājendra, s. v. parihāra. See khoṭa-bhaṅga, ukkoṭa-bhaṅga.
2758: khoṭa-bhaṅga (HRS), applies to a person residing for one, two or three years, or as long as the king's favour extends, without contributing the hiraṇya, etc., and without providing food for the Gāṭas and Bhaṭas, according to the Abhidhānarā-jendra, s. v. parihāra; also called ukkoṭa-bhaṅga, akṣoṭa-bhaṅga.
2760: Khshathrapāvan (IE 8-2, 8-3), Old Persian; ‘a provincial governor.’ See Kṣatrapa.
2761: Khshāyathiya Khshāyathiyānām (IE 8-2), Old Persian; ‘king of kings’; same as Modern Persian Shāhān Shāh. See Basilĕos Basilĕon, Ṣāhānuṣāhi.
2762: Khshāyathiya vazrka (IE 8-2), Old Persian; ‘the great king’; royal title. It was translated by the Indo-Greek kings in Greek and Prakrit in the legend of their coins and was the original of the Indian royal title Mahārāja. See Basilĕos Mĕgalŏu.
2765: kīla-mudrā, letter written on wedge-shaped wooden tablets (Select Inscriptions, pp. 236-37).
2766: kiṃ-chandaḥ (CII 1), cf. kiṃ-chandaḥ svit rājā asmāsu, ‘of what attitude is the king towards ourselves?’
2767: kiṇva-kreṇi (EI 15), mistake for kliṇva-kreṇi meaning such articles as sugar, liquor, etc.
2768: kīrtana (EI 24, 28, 33; SII 1; CII 4), same as kīrti; a temple or any other thing that renders famous the name of the person responsible for it; often interpreted as ‘a building or temple’; but really, ‘any fame-producing work’; ‘a monu-ment of fame’; a pious work like a temple. See kīrtanā.
2769: kīrtanā (EI 33), same as kīrtana and kīrti; cf. kīrtita.
2770: kīrti (EI 20, 24; CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the thing that speaks of or glorifies one’; used in the special meaning of ‘any work which renders the constructor of it famous’; a merit-orious work; a pious deed; same as kīrtana, kīrtanā; often inter-preted as ‘a building or temple’; but actually, ‘any fame-producing work’. See kīrti-sthāna. (CII 1), fame of a dead person; cf. yaśo vā kīrtir = vā. See yaśas.
2772: kīrti-stambha, cf. mahāmeru-śrī-kīrtistambha (BL); ‘the pillar of fame’.
2773: kīrti-sthāna (EI 1), same as kīrti or kīrtana; a temple or some such object calculated to render famous the name of the person responsible for it.
2776: Kiśoravadavā-go-mahiṣy-adhikṛta (IE 8-3; EI 17, 23), cf. Go-mahiṣy-aj-ādhyakṣa, Kiśoravaḍavā-go-mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādhyakṣa, etc.
2778: kiṭikā (EI 14), Sanskritised form of kiḍi or kiḍā, ‘a matting screen’.
2779: kivelu (LP), ‘tile’; cf. Marāṭhī kaul. See kaveluka.
2780: kliṇva, cf. a-lavaṇa-kliṇva-khātaka (IE 8-5); probably, such things as sugar and liquor; same as kliṇva-kreṇi; cf. also a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha (IE 8-5), etc.
2781: kliṇva-kreṇi, cf. a-lavaṇa-kliṇva-kreṇi-khanaka (IE 8-5); same as kliṇva meaning articles like sugar, liquor, etc.
2782: kḷpta (CII 3, 4; HRS), cf. sa-kḷpt-opakḷpta (IE 8-5); pro-bably, the tax on permanent tenants or the fixed revenue; fixed tax which is one of the seven sources of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra; cf. upakḷpta, kḷpta-kara, udraṅga, kḷpta-śluka, etc.
2783: kḷpta-kara (IE 8-5), fixed tax; same as kḷpta-śulka; cf. sa-kḷpt-opakḷpta.
2784: kḷpta-śulka (IE 8-5), fixed duty; same as kḷpta, kḷpta-kara; cf. sa-kḷpt-opakḷpta.
2785: koḍe (CITD), Telugu; an unknown measure of capacity. Cf. Kannaḍa koda-visa, an allowance of a visa of grain, etc., for every bullock-load that comes into a town, paid to a person employed to check the demands of the toll-collector.
2788: kohlī (Chamba), wet land, irrigable land; same as āli; opposed to otaḍa.
2789: kol (IE 8-6), Tamil; a measuring rod; cf. śrīpāda-kkol, ‘rod measured according to the length of the king's foot’; māliga-kkol, ‘the measuring rod of the palace’; etc. (EI 25), a land measure.
2792: koḻaga (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; measure of capacity equal to 4 baḻas; a dry measure of 768 or 384 or 72 tolas in different places.
2793: kola-bhaṇḍālu, also called kolla-baṇḍi (CITD), Telugu; a bullock-cart load. Cf. busi-baṇḍi or busi-bhaṇḍālu.
2794: Kolika (IE 8-8; EI 30), same as Sanskrit Kaulika, a weaver.
2795: kolika-nikāya (CII 4), a guild of the Kaulikas or weavers.
2798: Komaṭi (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a Vaiśya shop-keeper; a member of the mercantile caste.
2800: koñjalla, cf. a-kara-viṣṭi-koñjalla (IE 8-5); a fiscal term of doubtful import.
2801: koraṭa (CII 3), a fiscal term of uncertain import.
2802: koṣa, treasure, see Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 15-16.
2803: Koś-ādhipa (EI 32, 33), a treasurer; same as Koś-ādhyakṣa.
2806: koṣavāha (EI 14), name of a land measure; as much land as can be irrigated by one koṣa or leather bucket.
2808: koṣṭh-āgāra (HRS), the royal granary. (EI 29), cf. Tamil koṭṭagāram, koṭṭāram (EI 22; SITI), treasury or store-house. Cf. Tamil koṭṭagāram, etc. (SII 2), stables.
2809: koṣṭhāgāra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP), department of the collection of the king's share of grains.
2810: Koṣṭhāgārin, officer in charge of the treasury or store-house; cf. Mahākoṣṭhāgārin.
2811: koṣṭhaka (BL; LP), a granary or store-house.
2812: Koṣṭha-karaṇa (EI 29), a treasury accountant; also the revenue department (cf. koṣṭha-vyāpāra).
2814: koṣṭhī, cf. Prakrit koḍhi (LL), a hall.
2817: koṭa (LP), also called koṭaḍī; ‘wall of the compound’.
2818: Koṭ-ādhikaraṇika (BL), officer in charge of or related to the government of a koṭa or koṭṭa (fort).
2819: koṭaḍi, kotaḍī; cf. koṭaḍi-sahita (LP), ‘together with walls of the compound’.
2820: koṭaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 313), ‘a district’; same as koṭṭaka; cf. koṭṭa-viṣaya.
2822: koṭha-vyāpāra (EI 28), same as koṣṭha-vyāpāra; the revenue department.
2824: koṭikā, a load [of cloth] (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309). (EI 14), a measure.
2825: koṭṭa (EI 24), a fort. See koṭṭai and koṭṭam of the South Indian inscriptions.
2828: koṭṭam (IE 8-4; EI 27), Tamil; a district; a district within a maṇḍala or province. (ASLV), a division of the rājya; sometimes subdivided into nāḍus.
2829: Koṭṭa-nigraha (EI 8; IA 30; BL), commander of a fort; same as Koṭṭapāla. Cf. Koṭṭanigrahin.
2830: Koṭṭanigrahin (IA 30), probably, the commander of a fort; same as Koṭṭanigraha.
2831: Koṭṭapāla (IE 8-3; EI 12, 18, 25, 30; BL), officer in charge of a fort; governor of a fort. Cf. the Bhagalpur plate of Nārāyaṇapāla (Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306); sometimes spelt Koṭapāla (cf. the Nalanda plate of Devapāla in Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321). Same as Koṭṭapati. (EI 25), the city prefect; same as Kotwāl.
2833: koṭṭa-viṣaya (IE 8-4; CII 1), a viṣaya or district around a fortress; a district with its headquarters in a fort. See koṭaka.
2834: Kotwāl (IE 8-2, 8-3), same as Talāra or the prefect of the city police; the chief police officer of a city or town.
2835: kovai (SITI), Tamil; name of a gold coin.
2836: kovera (IE 8-5), cf. karaṇe koveram; probably, some levy at the court of law.
2839: Kramāditya (IE 8-2), see āditya. The word krama here seems to mean vikrama.
2840: Kramaka (EI 5), also called Kramavid, Kramayuta; epithet of Brāhmaṇas. Cf. Krama-vitta.
2841: Kramavid (EI 5), epithet of Brāhmanas; same as Kramaka, Kramayuta. Cf. Krama-vitta.
2842: Krama-vitta (SITTI), a Brāhmaṇa well-versed in the method of reciting the Vedas according to the krama order. Cf. Kramaka, etc.
2843: Kramayuta (EI 5), epithet of Brāhmaṇas; same as Kramaka, Kramavid. Cf. Krama-vitta.
2844: kraya-cīrikā (EI 26), a deed of purchase or sale-deed.
2847: kṛś-ānna, ‘minor food’; cf. kṛśānna-mūlya which is the money to meet expenses of light food (Select Inscriptions, p. 159). See mukh-āhāra.
2851: krośa (CII 1), a distance of about two miles and a quarter.
2854: kṛṣṇala (IA 26), same as rati or guñjā. One kṛṣṇala is regarded by the Kṛtyakalpataru (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K. V. Ranga-swami Aiyangar, p. 125) as equal to three guñjās or raktikās apparently through confusion.
2855: kṛṣṇarāja-rūpaka (EI 30), name of a silver coin issues by the Kalacuri king Kṛṣṇarāja.
2856: kṛta (EI 12, 14, 23; BL; CII 3), literally ‘accomplished’. i. e. ‘completed’; used in earlier records in connection with the era later associated with Vikramāditya. Often spelt krita, possibly standing for krīta meaning ‘purschased’, which was a name sometimes applied to certain foreign rulers of North-Western Bhāratavarṣa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 152). (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’. (CII 1), ‘arranged for’, ‘made arrangements for’. (EI 23), fruit, booty, reward. (Sel. Ins., p. 202), ‘engraved’. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 41, verse 13), written, drafted or composed.
2858: kṛta-prānta, cf. sa-kṛta-prānta (IE 8-5), Prakrit sa-kuta-ppanta; probably, demarcated boundaries.
2859: kṛti (IE 7-1-2), ‘twenty’; cf. kṛtin, ‘twentytwo’. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 98), a composition or performance.
2861: kṛt-opasanna (EI 30), an expression of doubtful import; epithet of a house.
2863: krūra-dṛś (EI 12), designation of Mars and Saturn.
2867: kṣata (EI 23), engraved; cf. utkīrṇa, udghāṭita, etc. Cf. Prakrit chata (EI 7), ‘written’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 202).
2868: Kṣatrapa (IE 8-2, 8-3; ML; HD), feudatory title of foreign origin; Old Persian Khshathrapāvan, ‘a provincial governor’; a Satrap. See CII, Vol. II, pp. xxxiv, 23, 28; Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 166. See Mahākṣatrapa.
2869: Kṣattṛ (HD), a chamberlain. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 111. According to Manu (X. 16) and Yājñavalkya (I. 94), the offspring of a Kṣatriya woman from a Śūdra male was called Kṣattṛ. This apparently refers to a tribe or community.
2871: Kṣemarāja (LL), title of a pious king.
2872: kṣetra (EI 24), a department or committee. (SII 1), a sacred place. Cf. Varāha-kṣetra.
2874: Kṣetrapa (IE 8-3; HD), same as Kṣetrapāla; superintendent of the king's Khās Mahāl. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306.
2875: Kṣetrapāla (IE 8-3; EI 17; HD), same as Kṣetrapa. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321.
2877: kṣīra, cf. a-puṣpa-kṣīra-grahaṇīya (IE 8-5); milk which the villagers (probably, the milkmen) were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions and to the touring officials.
2879: kṣiti-dāna (EI 23), same as bhūmi-dāna; name of a gift.
2881: kṣobha, cf. a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha (IE 8-5; EI 1); obligation or trouble.
2883: kṣudra, cf. Prakrit cūla=culla ‘small’; prefixed to the names of persons, localities, etc., in order to distinguish them from others; e. g., Kṣudra-Mūla, Mahā-Mūla; Kṣudra-Dharmagiri, Mahā-Dharmagiri.
2884: Kṣudraka (CII 1), a person of a low position; a poor man. (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 44), same as tolaka or draṃkṣaṇa; also spelt kṣudrama.
2885: kṣudrama, see kṣudraka; same as tolaka.
2887: kṣūṇa (EI 3), fault or defect. Cf. kṣūṇāni (LP), probably, ‘expenses’; kṣūṇ-ādika, ‘ex-penses, etc.’ Cf. mānak-aikaṃ yāvat kṣūṇaṃ na hi (LP), ‘it matters not if there is a loss of one maund only’, i. e. such a case should not be considered a loss.
2888: ku (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’. (CITD), a contraction of Telugu kuṇṭalu or kuccelu, a certain measure of land.
2890: kucaṭa (LP), disturbance of the peace of mind; cf. Guja-rātī kacvāṭ.
2892: kula (LL), Jain; a particular section of the Jains. Cf. udhaḏīyā-jhumpaḏīya-kula (LP), ‘farmers on whom revenue is fixed in a lump sum and who live in huts’. Cf. kulam (EI 25), a land measure; equal to 2 halas.
2893: kūla (SITI), tax on grains and pulses; cf. Tamil kiru-kūlam. Cf. Tamil kūlam (SII 1), a market.
2895: Kulacārika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 119, text line 8), wrong reading of Kulavārika=Kulavāra (q. v.).
2896: Kulakaraṇi (EI 15; SII 11-1), a hereditary clerk or officer; a clerk; cf. the modern family name Kulkarṇī. The word occurs in the Sūdi inscription of Śaka 981 (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 91).
2898: Kula-kuṭumbika (LP), farmers who are permanently settled.
2900: Kulapati (EI 9), probably, the head of a school or institution.
2901: Kulaputra (EI 22; CII 8), literally, ‘high-born’; epithet of a nobleman. See Kulaputraka. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 156); explained as ‘the chief architect’.
2907: kuli (IE 8-6; EI 28), Tamil; a small land measure equal to (1/240) of a pāḍagam.
2909: Kulika (EI 15, 35), ‘the head of a guild’; but cf. Prathama-kulika, ‘the foremost among the Kulikas’, who was the member of a board of administration like the Pañcāyat Board. Some inscriptions of the Gupta age mention a board of administration consisting of the Nagara-śreṣṭhin Sārthavāha, Prathama-Kulika and Prathama-Kāyastha (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 130), where Kulika seems to mean ‘an artisan’. Kulika is also mentioned as a people probably meaning mercenary soldiers of the Kullu valley (ibid., Vol. XVII, p. 321); cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., pp. 126-27. (HD), an officer in charge of ten villages who was granted a kula of land for his salary (Manu, VII. 119, and Kullūka thereon); also ‘an arbitrator as a tribunal’ (IHQ, Vol. XIX, p. 14).
2910: kullaka, cf. udak-āsīhāra-kullaka; probably, a kind of channel.
2911: kulya (IE 8-6), a measure of capacity equal to 8 droṇas. (IE 8-6; EI 29), a land measure; shortened form of kulyavāpa.
2912: kulyavāpa (IE 8-6; EI 28), ‘an area of land requiring one kulya measure of seed grains to be sown’; a land measure which was not the same in different ages and localities.
2914: Kumāra (IE 8-2; EI 28, 30; BL; HD), designation of a prince or the king's heir-apparent; usually a prince younger than the Yuvarāja (heir-apparent). See CII, Vol. I, pp. 93, 97; Vol. II, pp. 40, 48. Cf. Devī-kumāra (IA 18; CII 1).
2916: Kumāra-Divāna (BL), possibly, a Divāna or minister enjoying the status of a Kumāra or a Kumāra who was the Divāna. Cf. Kumār-āmātya, Kumāra-mahāpātra.
2917: kumāra-gadiāṇaka (CII 4), taken to be the name of a coin by some scholars; but probably, a tax. Same as kumāra-gadyāṇa.
2918: kumāra-gadyāṇa (IE 8-5; EI 4; HRS), probably, a tax of one gadyāṇa (i. e. the coin of that name) payable on the occasion of a prince's birth. See kumāra-gadiāṇaka, komarina-gadyāṇa, etc. Cf. Tamil kumara-kaccāṇam (EI 21), supposed to be a tax payable in coin for the maintenance of the temple of Kumāra or Subrahmaṇya (SITI). But kumāra-gadyāṇa is found in the records of the Gāhaḍavālas of Vārāṇasī, in whose dominions the god in question was not as popular as in the South.
2919: Kumāra-guru (BL), probably, the royal preceptor enjoying the status of a Kumāra.
2921: Kumāra-mahāpātra (EI 8-3; EI 28), a Mahāpātra enjoying the status of a Kumāra or a Kumāra who was the Mahāpātra; cf. Kumār-āmātya.
2922: Kumār-āmātya (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), probably ‘an Amātya enjoying the status of a Kumāra’. Cf. Tamil piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam (SITI), ‘the status of a Piḻḻai (prince)’, an officers’ cadre mainly composed of the junior members of the royal family. See Proc. 6th AIOC, pp. 211 ff.; Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 123. (IE 8-3), in one case, a Kumār-āmātya was at first a Mantrin, but later became a Mahābalādhikṛta; in another case, a Kumārāmātya was also a Mantrin. Cf. Kumāra-mahāpātra, etc. Cf. Kumāra-varga=piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam (SITI), literally, ‘the status of the Piḻḻai or prince’; supposed to be an officers’ cadre composed mainly of the junior members of the royal family. (IE 8-3), also called Khādya(kū*)ṭapākika, Sāndhivigrahika, Mahādaṇdanāyaka, etc., additionally.
2924: Kumārapādīya-āmātya (BL), an Amātya serving a Kumāra or enjoying the status of a Kumāra. Cf. Kumār-āmātya.
2926: Kumāra-varga (SITI), subordinate chieftains who consi-dered themselves as sons of the king or members of the royal family.
2927: kumāra-vṛtti, cf. Tamil piḻḻai-vari (SITI), tax for the upkeep of the order of Piḻḻais or Kumāras (princes). Kumāra-vṛtti occurs in the inscriptions of the Western Cālukyas of Kalyāṇa.
2928: kumārī-sāhasa (IE 8-5; EI 3, 25; CII 4), ‘offence against an unmarried girl’; fine for abducting an unmarried girl; same as kumārīsāhasa-doṣa.
2929: humārīsāhasa-doṣa (EI 32), fine for abducting an unmarried girl.
2930: kumbha (EI 5), the pinnacle of a temple; same as kalaśa. See also kumbhaka.
2931: kumb-ābhiṣeka (SII 3), same as Tamil tiru-kkalaśa-muḍittal (SITI), the consecration ceremony of a temple.
2932: kumbhaka (LL), the base of a pillar.
2935: kāṇam (EI 16), name of a gold coin.
2936: kuñci (IE 8-6), a measure of capacity usually regarded as equal to eight handfuls.
2941: kuṅkuma-vastra (ASLV), ‘saffron-coloured cloth’; some-times the privilege to wear it was granted to particular persons.
2942: kunnu (Chamba), also called kunu; a land measure.
2944: kuṇṭa (EI 21), a land measure; cf. guṇṭha.
2946: kunu (Chamba), also called kunnu; a land measure.
2947: kūpa (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 46, note 8), an ordinary well; cf. vāpī which is a well with a flight of stairs.
2948: Kūpadarśaka (EI 24), a water-diviner; an inspector of wells.
2949: kupya-gṛha (HRS), a store-house for forest produce as indicated by the Arthaśāstra.
2950: kūra, cf. a-kūra-chullaka-vināśi-khaṭvā-vāsa (IE 8-5); ex-plained as ‘boiled rice’; but probably ‘unboiled rice’. The villagers were obliged to supply it to the touring officers of the king. See vodā, siddh-ānna.
2952: kūrma (EI 14), see madhya-kūrma, ‘a plot of land elevated in the middle.’
2953: kuṟṟam (IE 8-4), Tamil; a district or its subdivision; sometimes the same as nāḍu, but sometimes only the part of a nāḍu.
2954: kuruvinda, cf. kuṟuvindam (SII 2), an inferior ruby.
2955: kuśa, cf. kuśa-kkāṇam (SITI), Tamil, tax on the potters.
2956: kuśala (IA 17), used in the sense of puṇya, religious merit; cf. kuśala-mūla.
2957: kuśala-mūla (CII 2-1; ML), ‘the root of merit’; used to indicate ‘a pious deed’.
2958: Kuśalin (CII 3; SII 3; IA 9), ‘being in good health’, used in the preamble of charters to indicate the genuineness and validity of the grant made by the donors when they were in a healthy state of body and mind; epithet of a donor of copper-plate grants to indicate that the charters were issued when the donor was not subject to any disease like madness.
2961: Kūṭaka (EI 5), probably, headman of the cultivators; same as Grāmakūṭaka. (IE 8-5; EI 4, 26), tax for the maintenance of the Kūṭaka; see pravaṇikara-kūṭaka-prabhṛti-samast-ādāya (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 101). (CII 4), a measure of capacity. (EI 2), a load or measure of salt.
2962: Kūṭakolasa (IE 8-3; EI 29), known from the Bhauma-Kara records of Orissa; official designation of uncertain import; cf. Kūṭa or Kūṭaka.
2964: kūṭa-śāsana (EI 7; IA 30; BL), a forged charter.
2965: Kūṭāyukta (EI 22), official designation; probably Kūṭa (Kūṭaka) and Āyukta.
2966: kuṭī (IE 8-8), a factory; cf. nīla-kuṭī. (LL), a Buddhist temple; an abbreviation of gandhakuṭī.
2971: kuṭumba-vṛtti, cf. Kannaḍa kuttumbitti (EI 18), gift of land for the maintenance of the donee's family.
2972: kuṭumba-yātrā (EI 12; BL), name of a religious ceremony; a procession of the royal family to the temple of the family deity on the occasion of the king's coronation or a marriage in the palace.
2973: Kuṭumbin (EI 12, 17, 23; SII 1), a cultivator; an agri-culturist householder; a householder or ryot.
2974: kuṭumbinī (EI 19; CII 2-1; ML), originally, ‘the wife of a householder’; later, ‘wife’ in general (cf. Sel. Ins., p. 164).
2975: kuttumbitti, Kannaḍa; cf. grant of certain towns and kuttum-bittis as aṅuga-jīvita or fief (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, pp. 81-83); mentioned along with bhatta-grāma (Sanskrit bhakta-grāma), ‘provision village’ (ibid., Vol. XVIII, p. 193); pro-bably, Sanskrit kuṭumba-vṛtti, grant made for the maintenance of the donee's family.
2976: Kuvara (BL), regional modification of Kumāra. Cf. Kuṃvar (Kuñar), Kunwar, etc.
2979: lābhārikā, lābhālikā (Chamba), Sanskritised form of the land measure called lāhaḍī.
2980: lag, cf. lagitvā (EI 9), ‘commencing from, beginning with’.
2982: lagaḍā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309), a load; a bar of metal.
2985: laggāvayitvā (IE 8-5), ‘having planted’; cf. Bengali lāgāiyā. See JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 202.
2987: lagna (IA 17; SII 1), an astronomical term; the rising of a sign of the zodiac or its passing the meridian. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XVIII, pp. 16 ff.
2989: lāhaḍi, lāhaḍī (Chamba), a land measure. See lābhā-rikā, lābhālikā.
2991: lakaṭā (IE 8-8), meaning uncertain. Cf. ārdraka-lakaṭā, probably, dried ginger stick or undried fire-wood.
2994: lakṣaṇa (IA 18), the sexual parts; the male organ; cf. nirlakṣitavya, to be castrated. (CII 1), branding. (SII 3; SITI), a document or deed; an inscription.
2995: Lakṣaṇ-ādhyakṣa (HRS), according to the Arthaśāstra, the superintendent of the mint, or royal dues received by the superintendent of the mint.
2996: Lākula, also called Lākuleśvara (EI 15), a Śaiva sect follow-ing Lakulīśa.
2997: Lakuleśvar-āgama (CITD), a form of Śaivism associated with Lakulīśa.
2998: Lāḻa-khaṇḍeya-kāṟar-adhiṣṭhāyaka (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa-Sans-krit; ‘superintendent of the revenue from Lāṭa’.
3000: lāñchana (EI 28), an emblem. Cf. cihna. (EI 9), the [royal] emblem; cf. Tamil lāñjanai-ppeṟu, lāñjinai-ppeṟu, ilāñjai-ppeṟu (SITI), the royal seal. (CII 3, etc.), a crest as distinguished from dhvaja or a banner. Cf. cihna. (HA), the distinguishing mark or symbol of a Jina image, which helps one to identify the different Jinas.
3002: lāṅgaḍi (LP), a cart or carriage; cf. uchālaka-bhṛta-lāṅgaḍi, ‘a cartful of household furniture’.
3003: Laṅka (EI 19), a carpenter; cf. Leṅka, Leṅkā, Buḏhāleṅkā.
3004: lapita (CII 1), used in the sense of ukta.
3005: la-saṃ (IA 18), abbreviation of lakṣmaṇasena-saṃvatsara, ‘the era of Lakṣmaṇasena’.
3006: laṣṭi (CII 4), same as Sanskrit yaṣṭi; a memorial pillar.
3007: Lattalūrapura-parameśvara (IE 8-2), a typical title of the Rāṣṭrakūṭas claiming the city of Lattalūra to have been their original home. Similar titles are quite common in the early medieval records especially of the Kannaḍa-speaking area.
3008: lauki°, laukika° (IA 18), abbreviation of laukika-gaṇanayā. Laukika-saṃvatsara is a year of the Laukika era.
3009: lavalikā (LP), loquacity; cf. Gujarātī lavlav or lavāro.
3010: lavaṇa, cf. a-lavaṇa-khātaka (IE 8-5); salt [the produc-tion of which was the monopoly of the king or landlord]. (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’; also ‘cutting [of plants]’.
3011: lavaṇ-ākara (EI 24, EI 30), a salt pit or mine.
3012: layana (LL, EI 22), Prakrit leṇa; an excavated cave; a cave; the residence of monks.
3013: lekha (LP), official letter; cf. likhita, a private letter.
3015: Lekhahāra, Lekhahāraka (EI 21; HD), the carrier of letters (see Rājataraṅgiṇī, VI. 319).
3016: Lekhaka (CII 3, etc.), a writer; a technical term for one who wrote a record [on copper plates, stone slabs, etc., in order to facilitate its correct engraving by an artisan], as opposed to the composer of the document (see also likhita). (IE 8-3; EI 28, 30; LL; HD), a writer, scribe or clerk (see Bomb. Gaz., Vol. XVI, pp. 582 and 605; Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 26-28; Śukranītisāra, II. 120). (LP), a record or document; mistake for lekhana.
3017: Lekhan-ādhyakṣa (CII 3), the superintendent of the writing of documents.
3018: Lekhayitṛ (EI 12), one who is responsible for getting a grant recorded; mentioned together with Śāsayitṛ; cf. Ājñapti.
3019: Lekhita, Lekhitṛ (EI 24), same as Lekhaka; a writer.
3020: Leṇka (EI 3; SII 11-1), Leṅkā (EI 28), a servant; a Śūdra servant; a writer, according to some.
3021: Lepyakāra, model-maker (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, No. 1, p. 13).
3022: likhita (CII 3, 4, etc.), ‘written’; a technical term indi-cating the manual drafting or writing of a record, as opposed to the composition and engraving of it; see also lekhaka. (LP), a private letter; cf. lekha, an official letter.
3023: liṅga (BL; SII 1; CII 3, etc.), same as śiva-liṅga; the phallic emblem of Śiva; the emblem connected with the worship of Śiva; generally named after the founder with the suffix īśvara.
3024: liṅgoraṇa (IA 11), conjecturally translated as ‘the festival of rams [to be sacrificed] to the liṅgas’.
3026: Lipikara (IE 8-3; EI 3; HD), a scribe or writer. See CII, Vol. I, p. 176; Pāṇini, III. 2. 21.
3027: Lipikṛt-kula (EI 33), the community of scribes; the Kāyastha community.
3030: loha, cf. so-loha-lavaṇ-ākara (IE 8-5), ‘together with mines of metals and salt pits [the right of which normally belonged to the king]’.
3031: Loha-carma-kāra (EI 24), workers in metal and leather.
3032: lohaḍiyā, name of a coin equal to 20 pāvīsās and 100 cowrie-shells; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 238.
3033: Lohāra (EI 4; BL), modification of Lohakāra; a black-smith.
3037: lohitaka, weight equal to 3 māṣas (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 46).
3038: loka (IE 7-1-2), ‘fourteen’; sometimes also ‘three’; rarely used to indicate ‘seven’.
3039: Lokapāla (CII 3, etc.), a guardian of one of the quarters of the world, originally conceived as four in number and later as eight. (EI 15), cf. the king called ‘the fifth Lokapāla’, the four Lokapālas (guardians of the four quarters) being originally Yama of the south, Varuṇa of the west, Kubera of the north and Vāsava of the east. In the same sense, the king was also called madhyama-loka-pāla, though madhyama-loka may also mean ‘the earth’ standing midway between the heavens and the netherworld. See Suc. Sāt., pp. 196, 202; Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 93. Cf. Pañcama-lokapāla.
3040: Ma (IE 8-1), abbreviation of Maṅgala-vāra, Tuesday. (PJS), abbreviation of Mahattama, Mantrin, Mahetā (meaning ‘a clerk’ or ‘a teacher’ in Gujarātī), etc. (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions).
3041: mā (IE 8-6; SII 12; SITI), Tamil; a land measure equal to one-twentieth of a veli; also the name of a weight.
3042: māḍa (IE 8-8; EI 7), Telugu; same as Oḏiyā māḏha or māḏhā and Tamil māḍai; a coin of gold or silver; 40 ratis in weight; cf. biruda-māḍa, malla-māḍa, mallanandi-māḍa, surabhi-māḍa, gaṇḍa-māḍa, kulottuṅga-māḍa (EI 29), gandhavāraṇamāḍa (or gandhahasti-māḍa), cāmara-māḍa, uttama-gaṇḍamāḍa, padmanidhi-malla-māḍa, rājarāja-māḍa, rājendracol13a-māḍa, etc. The gaṇḍa-māḍa is sometimes called kārṣāpaṇa, niṣka and gaṇḍaniṣka and is also characterised in a few cases with the epithet ‘small’. See māḍai, māḍha. Note names like kulottuṅga-māḍa, a coin issued by the Col13a king Kulottuṅga. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 43. (CITD), Telugu; half a pagoda; half of a dīnār or the tenth of a paṇa (cf. badi-māḍuvulu); half or 50 per cent of revenue, etc.; a weight of gold; money in general. Four māḍas are equal to one carṣam (karṣa?). (IE 8-5), probably, payment of 50 per cent; see māḍalu.
3043: māḍa-baḍi-pātuka (CITD), Telugu; an unknown coin with a fraction of the value of a māḍa. Baḍi means ‘petty’ and pātika ‘a quarter’.
3044: Madahastipādarakṣā-pālaka (IA 30), explained as ‘the captain of the guards of elephants’.
3045: māḍai (IE 8-8; EI 7), Tamil; same as māḍha, māḍhā and māḍa; cf. rājarājaṉ-māḍai, madhurāntakaṉ-māḍai, bhujabala-māḍai (EI 7), etc.; often a gold coin (SII 12). Tamil māḍai is the same as māṣā derived from Sanskrit māṣaka. (SITI), name of a gold coin; a half pagoda; cf. nellūr-māḍai (SITI), a coin current in olden days and issued from Nellore; also known as nellūr-ppudu-māḍai; also cf. gaṇḍagopālaṉ-māḍai.
3046: māḍalu (IE 8-5; EI 33), same as māḍa, a levy; probably, ‘payment of 50 per cent’; cf. Kannaḍa pannasa or pannāsa.
3049: māḍāsyāta (CII 3), usually taken to be a word of uncertain import, but may really be the name of a locality.
3051: māḍha, māḍhā (IE 8-8; EI 28, 29, 30, 33), Oḏiyā; a silver coin; also a gold coin; 40 ratis in weight; same as māḍa or māḍai.
3054: madhya-kūrma (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV p. 98), probably, a plot of land elevated in the middle.
3055: madhyama (CII 1), a class between the upper and the lower.
3056: Madhyamalokapāla, epithet of kings; cf. Lokapāla.
3057: madhyastha (EI 8, 25; SII 2; ASLV; SITI), a neutral person, generally the village headman; a mediator or arbitrator; secretary of the village assembly (SII 13).
3060: Maga (EI 9; BL), the same as Śākadvīpīya; a community of Brāhmaṇas; name of the members of the Persian priestly community (Magi) settled in India and absorbed in the Brāh-maṇa class.
3063: Mahā (PJS), abbreviation of Mahājana (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions). Cf. Mahā-Mūla (i. e. the elder Mūla) distinguished from Kṣudra-Mūla (i. e. the younger Mūla); also Mahā-Dharmagiri and Kṣudra-Dharmagiri, etc.
3064: Mahābalādhikaraṇika (IE 8-3), superintendent of the office of the Mahābalādhikṛta.
3065: Mahābalādhikṛta (HD), ‘the great commander’; desig-nation of a military officer who was, in one case, originally a Mantrin (IE 8-3); see Balādhikṛta and Mahābalādhyakṣa.
3066: Mahābalādhyakṣa (CII 3), military title. See Balādhyakṣa and Mahābalādhikṛta.
3067: Mahābalakoṣṭhika (IE 8-3), treasurer of the military department. Cf. raṇabhāṇḍāgār-ādhikaraṇa (Raychaudhuri, PHAI, 1950, p. 563).
3069: Mahābhāṇḍāgārika (IE 8-2; HD) treasurer; one of the designations often included in the pañca-mahāśabda as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 39; Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 142. Cf. Bhāṇḍāgārika. (CII 4), explained as ‘the Chancellor of the Exchequer’.
3070: Mahābhāṇḍāgārin (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa Hiriyabhaṇḍāgārin; some-times also called Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, etc., additionally.
3071: Mahābhārata-vṛtti (SITI), land endowed to persons for expounding the Mahābhārata.
3072: Mahābhogapati (EI 26), official designation; probably, the superintendent of rent-free holdings; cf. Mahābhogika, Bhogapati.
3073: Mahābhogika (EI 26; HD), a big Jāgīrdār; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 9; also cf. Bhogika and Mahābhogapati.
3074: Mahābhoja (IE 8-2; EI 7, 22, 28; LL), a big Jāgīrdār; title of a feudatory ruler; see Bhojaka.
3078: mahābhūtaka (EI 14), name of a mahādāna; same as mahābhūtaghaṭa-dāna.
3079: mahācaturdaśī-parvan (EI 9), 14th tithi of the bright half of a month.
3081: mahādāha (SITI), name of a hell which one is supposed to pass through after death on the way to the other world.
3082: mahādāna (EI 7, 16; CII 4); a great gift, 16 of which are enumerated in the Purāṇas (see Hist. Dharm., Vol. II, pp. 869-70; Suc. Sāt. L. Dec., pp. 50f.).
3083: Mahādān-ākṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta (EI 31), officer in charge of the accounts section of the gift department.
3084: Mahādānapati (EI 23; ML; HD), ‘the great gift-lord’, designation of one who gives a gift. Cf. CII, Vol. II, Pt. i., p. 28. Cf. Dānapati (EI 28), dedicator of an image of a god on the fulfilment of a desire.
3085: Mahādānapatnī (EI 20), feminine form of Mahādānapati; a female bestower of gifts.
3086: Mahādaṇḍanāyaka (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL.; HD); commander of forces; also called Khādya(kū*) ṭapākika, Sān-dhivigrahika, Kumārāmātya, etc., additionally; one of the desig-nations sometimes included in the pañca-mahāśabda; cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I (Ep. Ind., Vol. XX, p. 7; Ind. Ant., Vol. IV, p. 105). The five mahāśabdas applied to Dhruva-sena are Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra, Mahā-kārtākṛtika and Mahārāja. See Daṇḍanāyaka, Sarvadaṇḍa-nāyaka, Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka, Daṇḍapati.
3087: Mahādānika (CII 4), head of the department of charity; officer in charge of donations; sometimes explained as ‘the officer superintending the performance of the mahādāna ceremonies’ (HD). See Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91. Cf. Dharmādhyakṣa.
3088: Mahādauḥsādhasādhanika (HD), cf. Dauḥsādhasādhanika. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321.
3090: Mahādevī (IE 8-2; EI 7; CII 3, 4; HD), a queen; often wrongly taken as the first wife of a king or his chief queen (SITI); a title of the wives originally of paramount sovereigns and later also of feudatory rulers; cf. Devī, Agra-mahādevī, Mahāmahādevī.
3091: Mahādharmādhikaraṇika (CII 4), explained as the chief justice (HD), Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309. See Dharmādhikara-ṇika and Mahādharmādhyakṣa, head of the department of religious; affairs.
3092: Mahādharm-ādhyakṣa (IE 8-3; EI 12, 21, 26, 33; HD), explained as ‘the chief judge’; but really ‘officer in charge of charities, etc.’; cf. Dharmādhyakṣa and Mahādharmādhikaraṇika.
3093: Mahādhirāja (IE 8-2; EI 12), royal title; cf. Adhirāja; also cf. Dharmamahādhirāja (EI 12). (CII 3), a feudatory title.
3094: Mahādhyakṣa (EI 12; CII 4), ‘the chief superintendent’; cf. Adhyakṣa.
3096: mahā-doṣa, cf. mahādoṣa-vivarjita (EI 23) as an epithet of the gift village; probably, fines for great crimes.
3097: mahā-dvādaśaka (IE 8-4), ‘the great twelve’; suffixed to the name of a district probably consisting of twelve Parganās or sub-districts.
3098: mahā-dvādaśī (EI 9; IA 26), also called pāpanāśinī; name of a tithi; eight kinds of the twelfth tithi.
3099: Mahādvār-ādhipati (BL), possibly the same as ‘the lord (i. e. the guard) of the Dvāra (a pass)’ of the Rājataraṅgiṇī; mentioned along with the Mahāsainyapati and Mahāpratihāra.
3100: Mahāgajapati (EI 30), ‘the great lord of elephants’; cf. Gajapati, etc.
3101: Mahāgaṇastha (IE 8-3; EI 26; HD), probably, the chairman of a guild or superintendent of guilds; cf. Gaṇastha and Gaṇattār. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 160.
3102: mahā-gandhakūṭī (LL), a Buddhist temple; cf. gandhakuṭī and kūṭī.
3103: Mahāgovallabha (EI 24), the superintendent of cattle; see Govallabha.
3105: mahāgrāma (IE 8-4), a small territorial unit; a group of villages; cf. grām-āhāra.
3106: Mahāgrāmika (IE 8-3), ruler of a mahāgrāma (subdivision of a district or a group of villages).
3107: Mahājana (SITI; ASLV), Brāhmaṇa residents of the entire village; all the members of the village assembly; general body of the sabhā or village assembly. (IE 8-3), a member of village council. (EI 8), a merchant. (LP), generally, the merchants, magnates, grandees.
3109: mahājaya, mahājayā (EI 7; IA 26), name of a tithi; same as su-di 7.
3110: mahākaraṇa, cf. sa-mañca-mahākaraṇa (IE 8-5), an expression of doubtful import; probably, ‘official records’.
3111: Mahākaraṇādhyakṣa (IE 8-3), head of the department of records.
3112: Mahākaraṇika (CII 4; HD), the chief secretary; the chief scribe. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309. Cf. Karaṇika.
3114: Mahākārtākṛtika (IE 8-2; EI 29, 30; CII 3; HD), official designation of uncertain import; probably, a reporter who informed the king about the progress of big undertakings; some-times explained as ‘the royal agent or judge’; one of the desig-nations sometimes included in the pañca-mahāśabda; cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306. See Kārtākṛtika.
3115: Mahākārttikī (EI 11; CII 4), full-moon day of the month of Kārttika.
3116: Mahākaṭuka (IE 8-3), official designation of uncertain import.
3118: Mahākavicakravartin (EI 30; BL), title of a poet.
3119: Mahākhaḍgadhara (EI 30), official designation. See Khaḍgadhara, Khaḍgagrāha, etc.
3120: Mahākhalarakṣaka (LP), superintendent of the king's threshing floors.
3123: Mahākoṭṭapāla (CII 4), chief guardian of a fort or the forts; cf. Koṭṭapāla.
3125: mahākṣa-ni (IE 8-1), abbreviation of mahākṣapaṭalika-nirīkṣita, ‘examined by the Mahākṣapaṭalika’; ni may not be an abbreviation of nibaddha (registered) in this case since mahākṣa-ni is often used along with several other expressions of the kind. See ni.
3126: mahākṣapāla-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the depository of legal documents’.
3127: Mahākṣapaṭal-ādhikaraṇ-ādhikṛta (BL) superintendent of the office of the akṣapaṭala or mahākṣpaṭala department; some-times regarded as the same as Mahākṣpaṭalika (HD). Cf. Mahākṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta, etc.
3128: Mahākṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta (BL), same as Mahākṣapaṭalādhi-karaṇ-ādhikṛta or Mahākṣapaṭalādhyakṣa; also called Mahā-kṣapāla (cf. karaṇa).
3130: Mahākṣapaṭalika (IE 8-3; CII 3; EI 30; BL; HD), record-keeper and accountant; same as Mahākṣapaṭal-ādhyakṣa; see Akṣapaṭalika, sometimes explained as ‘the chief keeper of records’ (CII 4), Cf. CII, Vol. III, p. 120. (IE 8-3), mentioned as a Pātra.
3132: Mahākṣatrapa (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 16, 27; CII 4; BL; ML; HD), the great Satrap or provincial governor; feudatory title of foreign origin; originally, title of a provincial governor; later the Śakas of Western India continued to use it even when they were practically independent. Cf. CII, Vol. II, p. 48. See Kṣatrapa.
3134: Mahākumāra (CII 4), title of a prince or the crown-prince. (IE 8-2; EI 28; BL), title of certain rulers; title of some semi-independent Paramāra rulers.
3135: Mahākumārāmātya (EI 29; CII 3; HD), see Kumārāmātya. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321.
3136: mahālayā (EI33), name of a tithi; pūrṇimānta Āśvina-badi 15.
3138: Mahallaka (IE 8-5; EI 25), probably, a member of the Pañcāyat; explained as ‘city elders’; cf. yat … nagara-mahallakā vicārya vadante, etc. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 20); also called Mahallāka, Mahallika. (CII 4), same as Mahattara. (EI 2; CII 1), an old man. In Oḏiyā, it means a guard of the royal harem. (CII 1), big, vast. (EI 23), a landlord.
3139: Mahaṃ (BL), abbreviation of Mahattama. (LP), abbreviation of Mahantaka.
3140: Maha, Mahaṃ (IA 18), abbreviations of Mahattara or Mahattama.
3141: Mahāmahādevī (BL), designation of a queen or the chief queen; cf. Mahādevī.
3142: Mahāmahantaka (EI 7; CII 4; HD), same as Mahā-mahattaka. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91.
3143: Mahāmahattaka (EI 25, 33; CII 4; HD; BL), head of a group of villages or of the village council; chief among the village headmen; same as Mahāmahattara, Mahāmahattama. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 362. See Mahattaka.
3145: Mahāmahattara (IE 8-3; EI 26, 29; BL), mentioned along with the Mahattara; probably, the chairman of the council of Mahattaras; same as Mahāmahattaka, Mahāmahattama; see Mahattara.
3146: mahāmahāvāruṇī (EI 4), name of a tithi; same as vāruṇī and mahā-vāruṇī; amānta Caitra-badi 13 with Śatabhiṣā-nakṣatra.
3147: Mahāmahiṣī (IE 8-2), cf. Piriya-arasi (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa; title of a chief queen; see Mahiṣī.
3148: Mahāmahopādhyāya, title of certain scholars like Jīvadeva of Orissa.
3149: mahamai (EI 17), Tamil magamai; name of a tax.
3152: Mahāmaṇḍal-ācārya (EI 26), title of a Buddhist teacher.
3154: Mahāmaṇḍala-nātha (HD), same as Mahāmaṇḍleśvara. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 227.
3155: Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 4; HD; BL; SITI; CITD), according to the lexicons, a sovereign ruler who is the lord of 40 yojanas of land and a lakh of villages; but, in inscriptions, generally, the governor of a district or pro-vince; title of a feudatory ruler or governor (see Bomb. Gaz., Vol. XXI, p. 354); see Maṇḍaleśvara essentially meaning ‘the ruler of a maṇḍala or district’; also called Mahāmaṇḍalika, etc., cf. Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati. The status of a Mahāmaṇdal-eśvara seems to have been superior to that of a Maṇḍaleśvara, while Mahāmaṇḍaleśvarādhipati apparently enjoyed a still higher rank.
3156: Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati (IE 8-2; EI 23), title of a feudatory higher in rank than a Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara (cf. Mahā-sāmantādhipati); a feudatory who had some subordinate chiefs under him; cf. Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara, Maṇḍaleśvara.
3158: Mahāmaṇḍalīka (HD), same as Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. IX, p. 35. See Mahāmaṇḍalika, Mahāmaṇḍale-śvar-ādhipati, Māṇḍalika etc.
3159: mahāmaṇḍapa (SITI), a large pillared hall next to the ardha-maṇḍapa in a temple; also called mukha-maṇḍapa.
3160: Mahāmantrin (EI 12, 30; CII 4; IA 19; BL; HD), ‘the chief minister or counsellor’. See Mantrin. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309.
3161: Mahāmanuṣya (IE 8-3), probably, a landlord; mentioned in the list of a king's subordinates. cf. Mahājana.
3162: Mahāmātra (IE 8-3), cf. Prakrit Mahāmāta (EI 3); a high executive officer employed in various capacities; cf. Nagara-vyavahārika-mahāmātra, Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra, Dharma-mahāmātra, etc.; adopted in Greek as Mamātrai. See CII, Vol. I, p. 92, etc.; Arthaśāstra, I. 12, V. 1; etc.; Kāmasūtra, V. 5. 17. 33 and 35. The word Mahāmātra in Manu, IX. 259, is explained by Medhātithi as ‘the Mantrin, Purohita and others’ and by Kullūka as meaning ‘the professional tamers of elephants’. (SITI) explained as ‘a senior minister.’ See Mātra in a similar sense. Cf. Antaḥpura-mahāmātra in the Masulipatnam plates of Amma II (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 276). (EI 28; CII 4), ‘an elephant-driver’.
3164: Mahāmātra-nagaravyavahārika (CII 1), an executive officer who is the judge or administrator of a city.
3165: mahāmātṛkā, ‘mother's mother’; used side by side with āryikā, ‘father's mother’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 225).
3166: Mahāmātya (IE 8-3; EI 25; CII 4; BL), the chief minister or executive officer; the prime minister or a viceroy (HD); see Amātya; sometimes also called a Mahāpradhāna additionally. Cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 122; Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 242.
3167: Mahāmātya-vara (EI 30), chief minister; cf. Amātya and Mahāmātya.
3168: mahāmeru-śrī-kīrtistambha (BL), name of Mahārāṇā Kumbhā's tower at Chitor.
3169: Mahāmudr-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; EI 12, 14, 15; HD), the keeper of the royal seal; officer in charge of the royal seal; cf. Mahāmudr-āmātya. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 9.
3170: Mahāmudr-āmātya (IA 11), same as Mahāmudr-ādhikṛta; cf. Mudr-ādhikārin, etc.
3172: Mahāna (Chamba), a writer; possibly from Sanskrit Mahantaka.
3173: Mahānāḍ-prabhu (ASLV), the Paṭṭanasvāmin (q. v.) of the rural areas.
3174: mahā-nāḍu (SITI), general assembly of the mercantile community of a district.
3175: mahā-nagara (SITI), merchants' guild of a city; cf. nagara.
3176: mahaṇaloka, possibly the same as Sanskrit mahalloka= mahājana (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 143).
3177: Mahānas-ādhyakṣa (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ (EI 5); superintendent of the royal kitchen; sometimes also called Mahāsāmantādhipati, Mahāpradhāna, Accupannāyadadhiṣṭhā-yaka, etc., additionally; cf. Mahānasika, Sūpakārapati, Khādya-(kū*) ṭapākika, etc.
3178: Mahānasika, ‘the kitchen-officer’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 156); cf. Mahanas-ādhyakaṣa.
3179: mahānavamī-amāvāsyā (EI 5; IA 18), Kannaḍa name for the new-moon of Bhādrapada; new-moon preceding the mahānavamī.
3180: Mahānāvika (EI 27), the captain of a ship.
3181: Mahānāyaka (EI 4; BL), official designation probably indicating a class of feudatories; a subordinate title.
3182: mahā-ni (IE 8-1), abbreviation of some such expression as Mahāsāndhivigrahika-nirīkṣita, ‘approved by the Mahāsāndhivi-grahika’. See ni.
3183: mahā-niyoga (SITI), king's order; royal command; an officer bearing the same.
3184: Mahant (EI 4), variant spelling of Mahanta; the same as Mahantaka.
3185: Mahanta (EI 8; BL), head of a monastery; title of a pontiff. (ML), Prakrit form of Sanskrit mahat; ‘the great’; a title.
3186: Mahantaka (LP), an accountant; a clerk. It is a term of respect among the Baniyās of Gujarat.
3187: Mahāpādamūlika (IE 8-3), the king's chief personal attendant.
3188: Mahāpalupati (Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 22), same as Mahā-pīlupati.
3189: mahāpaṇa, cf. māppaṇam (SITI), name of a coin.
3190: Mahāpañcakulika (CII 4; HD), ‘head of the department of Pañcāyats’ or ‘the chairman of a Pāñcāyat board’; see pañca-kula. Cf. JBORS, Vol. V, p. 588.
3191: Mahāpāndhākulika (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 87), a mistake for or wrong reading of Mahāpāñcakulika.
3193: Mahāpaṇḍita (EI 9; BL), title of a learned man, generally a learned Brāhmaṇa.
3194: Mahāparamaviśvāsin (IE 8-3; EI 5), probably, a private secretary or privy councillor; same as Rahasyādhikṛta, etc.; sometimes called Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, etc., additionally. See Paramaviśvāsin, Vaiśvāsika, etc.
3195: mahāparinirvāṇa (CII 4), the passing away of the Buddha.
3197: mahāpārṣika (EI 32), used in the sense of ‘a member of the mahāparṣad’.
3199: Mahāpātra (IE 8-3; EI 19, 30), a minister; a minister higher in rank than the Pātra; cf. Pātra and Ekapātra.
3200: Mahāpasāyita (IE 8-3; EI 5, 27), probably from Sanskrit Prasādita, ‘favoured’, meaning a Jāgīrdār of a particular type; sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Antaḥpuravĕrgaḍĕ, Daṇḍa-nāyaka, Sarvādhikārin, Mahāsāmanta, Senādibāhatta raniyogādhiṣṭhā-yaka, etc., additionally; cf. Pasāita, Pasāyita.
