3202: Mahāpīlupati (IE 8-3; EI 28), ‘the great superintendent of elephants’; chief of the elephant corps; the master of ele-phants; sometimes also called Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Pañcā-dhikaraṇ-oparika, Mahāpratīhāra, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika, etc., additionally. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 298. The word pīlu is the same as Perso-Arabic fīl. See Mahāpalupati and Pīlupati.
3203: Mahāprabhu (EI 21, 32), sometimes used in respect of subordinate rulers; (HD), a governor; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 335. (SITI) ‘the great banker’; the senior merchant; the title by which the leader of the nānādeśi merchant community was designated. (IA 30), a village official; see Prabhu. (EI 19), explained as ‘the high sheriff’.
3204: Mahāpracaṇḍa (EI 12), either a separate official desig-nation or an epithet prefixed to the designation Nāyaka or Daṇḍanāyaka.
3205: Mahāpracaṇḍa-daṇḍanāyaka (EI 20), official designation; cf. Mahāpracaṇḍa and Daṇḍanāyaka.
3207: Mahāpradhāna (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 4; BL; HD), ‘the great minister’; ‘the chief minister or administrator’; sometimes also called Mahāsāmant-ādhipati, Antaḥpura-vĕrgaḍĕ (°ādhyakṣa), Mahāpasāyita, Senāpati, Hĕri (Mahā) sandhivigrahika, Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ, Kaḍitavĕrgaḍĕ, Senādhipati, Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa, Hĕri-Lāḻa-Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin, Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ, Accupanāyadadhiṣṭhāyaka, Sarvādhikārin, Hĕri (Mahā) bhāṇḍāgārin, Bāhattaraniyogādhipati, Paṭṭasāhaṇ-ādhiṣṭhāyaka, Senāpati, Daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsāmanta, Senādibhāhattaraniyog-ādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāmātya, Paramaviśvāsin, Mahāparamaviśvāsin, etc., additionally. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 28. (SITI), senior councillor of the king, usually a military officer; same as Mahāpradhāni. See Pradhāna.
3208: Mahāpradhāna-nāyaka (IA 12), regarded as a single official designation; but probably Mahāpradhāna and Nāyaka.
3209: Mahāpradhāni (CITD; ASLV), often, the chief minister or administrator; same as Mahāradhāna; a high executive officer.
3210: Mahāpramātāra (BL; MD), same as Mahāpramātṛ, Mahā-pramātra or Mahāpramattavāra. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 280.
3211: Mahāpramātṛ (CII 4), explained as ‘the chief surveyor’; same as Mahāpramātāra, etc.
3212: Mahāpramātra (EI 12), same as Mahāpramātṛ, Mahā-pramātāra, etc.
3213: Mahāpramattavāra (HD), probably, the same as Mahā-pramātāra, etc.; explained wrongly as ‘the chief of the elephant corps’ (CII 4); cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 141.
3215: Mahāpratihāra, Mahāpratīhāra (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3; BL), head of the door-keepers of the palace or the king's chamber, or of the capital; city; sometimes explained as ‘the chief usher’ (CII 4). See Pratihāra. (HD), the superior officer above all door-keepers, the great chamberlain. See Kādambarī, para. 97; Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 142; Ep. Ind., Vol. X, p. 75; etc. (IE 8-2), one of the designations often included in the pañca-mahāśabda, as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. (IE 8-3), sometimes also called Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpīlupati, Pañcakaraṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika, etc., additionally.
3216: mahāpratihāra-pīḍā (EI 12), occurs in the Rājataraṅgiṇī; explained as ‘the office of the high chamberlain’.
3219: Mahāpurohita-ṭhakkura (IE 8-3), ‘the head of the chief priests’; mentioned as a Pātra along with Mahāpurohita, Dharmādhikaraṇika, Daivāgārika, Śaṅkhadhārin, Paṇḍita, Upā-dhyāya, Daivajña, Mahārthaśāsanika, etc.
3220: Mahāpuruṣa (BL), same as the god Viṣṇu. (EI 7), official designation; probably, the same as Mahā-manuṣya.
3221: Mahara (EI 1), probably a mistake for Mahattara, ‘a village-headman’ or ‘a member of the village Pañcāyat’.
3222: Mahārāja (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), royal title first assumed by the foreign rulers of India and later adopted by indigenous rulers; originally, an imperial title; later (when the emperors assumed more dignified titles), a title of feudatories and smaller rulers; cf. Greek Basileos Megalou and Old Persian Kshāyathiya vazrka. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 211. (IE 8-2), one of the designations sometimes included in the pañca-mahāśabda; cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I. (IE 8-3), sometimes also called Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra, Mahāpīlupati, Pañcādhikaraṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika, etc., additionally. (IE 8-2), often used in the South even when Mahārājā-dhirāja became the popular imperial title in the North. (ASLV), designation of a priest of the members of the Vallabhācārya sect. Cf. Mahanta-mahārāja, title of pontiffs.
3223: Mahārāja-bappa-svāmin (IE 8-2), designation by which the father and predecessor of a ruling king is sometimes referred to.
3225: Mahārājādhirāja (IE 8-2; EI 3; CII 3, 4), one of the technical titles of paramount sovereignty closely connected with Paramabhaṭṭāraka and Parameśvara; later sometimes also assumed by subordinate rulers.
3226: Mahārājādhirāja-parameśvarī (IE 8-2), title of certain ruling queens of Orissa.
3227: Mahārājādhirāja-pati (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 242), title.
3228: Mahārājakula (IE 4; BL), official designation of a feuda-tory; same as Mahārāval of the Rajasthan region; cf. Rājakula.
3230: Mahārāja-mātā (IE 8-2), epithet of the mother of a king.
3233: Mahārāja-pitāmahī (IE 8-2), epithet of the grandmother of a king.
3234: Mahārāja-prayojana (SITI), probably, fees collected for the performance of police duties; same as Tamil araśu-ppeṟu (SITI).
3235: Mahārājaputra (EI 26; CII 4; HD), ‘son of the Mahārāja’; designation of a prince. See Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309.
3236: Mahārājā-sāheb (BL), the same as Mahārāja with the Arabic honorific expression sāhib suffixed to it.
3238: Mahārājñī (IE 8-2; EI 4, 21; CII 4; BL; HD), designation of queens; see Rājñī. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91.
3239: mahārājya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 313), ‘a province’; cf. rājya.
3240: Mahārāṇā (EI 21, 24; BL), derived from Mahārāṇaka; feudatory title; later, also a royal title. See Rāṇā and Rāṇaka.
3241: Mahārāṇaka (EI 27; CII 4; BL; HD), title of feudatory rulers; see Rāṇaka. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XVII, p. 214.
3242: mahārasa-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the liquor department.
3243: Mahārāṣṭrin (IE 8-3; LL), Prakrit Mahāraṭhi; ‘ruler of a rāṣṭra (a district or subdivision or a group of villages)’; see Rāṣṭrin.
3244: Mahārāṣṭriṇī (LL), cf. Prakrit Mahāraṭhiṇī (EI 7), wife of a Mahārāṣṭrin.
3245: Mahāratha (EI 7), explained as ‘a race’ (EI 17); official designation; cf. Mahārathin.
3246: Mahārathin (IE 8-3; EI 7), wrong Sanskritization of Prakrit Mahāraṭhi (sometimes read as Mahārathi) which really stands for Mahārāṣṭrin.
3247: Mahārāula (EI 24; BL), same as Mahārāvala; derived from Mahārājakula; designation of a feudatory; title of nobility.
3248: Mahārāuta (BL), designation of a feudatory; from Sans-krit Mahārājaputra. See Rāuta, Rāvata.
3249: Mahārāva (BL), designation of a feudatory; from Sanskrit Mahārāja,
3250: Mahārāval, Mahārāvala (BL), same as Mahārāula; desig-nation of a fendatory; from Sanskrit Mahārājakula.
3252: Maharī, Mahārī, Māhārī (EI 33), same as Mehari, a dancing girl or Devadāsī.
3253: Mahāruṇḍā, a name of the Mother-goddess (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 36).
3254: Mahārtha-mahāmahattaka (CII 4), official designation; see Mahāmahattaka, Mahārtha may also be a separate official designation or an abbreviation of Mahārthaśāsanika (q. v.).
3255: Mahārthaśāsanika (EI 8-3; EI 7), probably, an officer in charge of gifts; sometimes mentioned as a Pātra. Cf. Mahā-rtha-mahāmahattaka.
3256: mah-āryaka (EI 8), probably, the great-grandfather; tentatively explained as ‘mother's grandfather’ (Select Inscrip-tions, p. 202).
3257: mahā-śabda (IE 8-2), cf. aśeṣa-mahāśabda (EI 22), same as pañca-mahāśabda (q. v.). Cf. paṭaha-ḍhakkā-mahāśabda (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVI, p. 325).
3258: mahā-sabhā (SII 1; ASLV; SITI), ‘the great assembly’; meeting of the general body of the sabhā; meeting of the Mahā-janas in session; body of the Mahājanas.
3259: mahāsādhanabhāga (IE 12; IA 14; HD), occurring in the Rājataraṅgīṇī; explained as ‘the office of the chief executive minister’; but cf. Mahāsādhanika; one of the five offices insti-tuted by Lalitāditya of Kashmir (Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 142-43).
3260: Mahāsādhanika (IE 8-2, 8-3; CII 4; BL; HD), official designation indicating a commander of forces; the chief mili-tary officer; one of the designations often included in the pañca-mahāśabda as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. See Sādhanika derived from sādhana or army. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91. (IE 8-3), sometimes mentioned as a Pātra.
3261: Mahāsāhanī (BL), cf. Masāhaṇī (EI 5), a military officer; the same as Sanskrit Mahāsādhanika.
3263: Mahāsainyapati (EI 29; HL), commander of forces; cf. Sainyapati and Mahāsenāpati.
3264: mahāśāit (EI 5), a kind of rice or paddy.
3265: mahāsāṃ-karaṇa-ni (IE 8-1), abbreviation of mahāsāndhi-vigrahika-karaṇa-nirīkṣita, ‘examined by the clerk of the Mahāsāndhivigrahika’. Karaṇa here may also be an abbreviation of Adhikaraṇa or office.
3266: Mahāsāmanta (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL), ‘the great chieftain’; title of a feudatory of a higher rank than the Sāmanta; sometimes called Mahārāja, Mahāpratīhāra, Pañca-karaṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika, Senādibāhattara-niyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, Mahāpasāyita, Daṇḍanāyaka, etc., additionally. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 217; Vol. IX, p. 107. (SITI), a vassal chief, sometimes holding the position of a minister or governor. (IE 8-2), one of the designations sometimes included in the pañca-mahāśabda; cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I. (IE 8-3), sometimes a feudatory of a lower grade than Rājan and Rājanaka.
3267: Mahāsāmantādhipati (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 29, 30; CII 4; BL; HD), a feudatory title; cf. Sāmantādhipati (EI 16); title of feudatories who had some subordinate chiefs under them; title of a feudatory of a higher rank than the Mahāsāmanta; cf. Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara, Samasta-mahāsāmant-ādhipati; sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Bhānasavĕrgaḍĕ, Accupannāyadadhiṣṭhā-yaka, etc., additionally. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 259. See Mahāsāmanta, Mahāmaṇḍaleśvarādhipati, etc.
3268: Mahāsāmantarāja (EI 33), feudatory title; cf. Mahāsāmant-ādhipati. It may also indicate one enjoying the titles Mahā-sāmanta and Rājan.
3269: mahāsā-ni (IE 8-1), abbreviation of mahāsāndhivigrahikaṇirī-kṣita, ‘examined by the Mahāsāndhivigrahika’. See ni, mahākṣa-ni.
3270: mahāsandhivigrah-ādhikaraṇa (EI 12; CII 4), the office or department of the Mahāsandhivigrahika; the department of peace and war.
3271: Mahāsandhivigrah-ādhikaraṇa-ādhikṛta (BL), superintendent of the office of war and peace or foreign affairs. See Sandhi-vigrah-ādhikaraṇ-ādhikṛta.
3272: Mahāsandhivigrah-ādhikṛta (CII 4; HD), same as Mahā-sāndhivigrahika; minister of peace and war. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 80; Harṣacarita, Parab's ed., p. 194.
3273: Mahāsandhivigrah-ādhipati (EI 21; CII 4), same as Mahā-sāndhivigrahika; cf. Sandhivigrah-ādhipati, etc.
3274: Mahāsandhivigrah-ākṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta (EI 31), officer in charge of the accounts section of the foreign affairs department; same as Mahāsandhivigrah-ākṣapaṭal-ādhipati.
3275: Mahāsāndhivigrah-ākṣapaṭal-ādhipati (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 274), same as Mahāsandhivigrah-akṣapaṭal-ādhikṛta.
3276: Mahāsandhivigrahika (BL; HD), same as Mahāsāndhivigra-hika; designation of the minister for war and peace or of foreign affairs. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309. See Sandhivigrahika, etc.
3277: Mahāsāndhivigrahika (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), same as Mahāsandhivigrahika; minister for peace and war or of foreign affairs; a civil or military title; one of the designa-tions often included in the pañca-mahāśabda as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. See Sāndhivigrahika. (IE 8-3), cf. Gauḍa-mahāsāndhivigrahika, etc.
3278: Mahāsandhivigrahin (BL), designation of the minister for war and peace or of foreign affairs. See Sandhivigrahin, Mahā-sāndhivigrahika, etc. (IE 8-3), sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ, Senādhipati, Kaḍita-vĕrgaḍĕ, etc., additionally.
3280: Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka (CII 3), the commander-in-chief. See Sarvadaṇḍnāyaka and Daṇḍanāyaka.
3281: Mahāsarvādhikṛta (EI 12, 28), the chief minister or adminis-trator. Cf. Sarvādhikṛta and Sarvādhikārin.
3282: mahā-satī (EI 31), spelt mā-sati in Tamil, etc.; a lady who has committeed satī; cf. satī. Cf. mā-sati-kal, a stone raised in memory of a satī (Journ. Mad. Univ., Vol. XXXII, p. 136).
3283: Mahāsattrapati (EI 13), superintendent of the sattras (houses for free distribution of food).
3284: Mahāsenādhipati (EI 19), commander of forces. Cf. Mahāsenāpati, Senādhipati, Samastasenādhipati, etc.
3285: Mahāsenānī, commander of forces (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 156).
3286: Mahāsenāpati (EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), ‘the great commander of armies’. See Senāpati, Mahāsenādhipati. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 94.
3287: Mahāsenāpatnī (IE 8-2; EI 20; LL), wife of a Mahāsenā-pati.
3288: Mahāśiraḥ-Pradhāni (ASLV), a high officer who had a seat in the Imperial Council of the Vijayanagara kings.
3290: Mahāśreṣṭhin (EI 7; CII 4; HD), ‘the great banker’; the chief banker; see Śreṣṭhin. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 91.
3291: mahāsthāna (EI 7), a holy place. (EI 24), a great temple.
3292: Mahāsthavira (LL), Buddhist; cf. Sthavira, an Elder.
3294: Mahāśvapati (BL), designation of the leader of horsemen. See Aśvapati.
3295: Mahāśvasādhanika (EI 12; HD), commander of a cavalry force. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 309. (CII 4), the great equerry.
3296: mahāśvaśālā (EI 12; HD), explained as ‘the office of the chief master of the horses’; one of the five high offices instituted by Lalitādiya of Kashmir (Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 142).
3297: Mahāśvaśāl-ādhikṛta (IE 8-2), superintendent of the stables; one of the designations often included in the pañca-mahāśabda (cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 142).
3298: Mahatā (EI 32), the same as Mahattaka, Mahattara or Mahattama. Cf. Mahato.
3299: Mahātalavara (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 25; HD), explained by some authorities as a subordinate ruler and by others as the police magistrate of a city or the prefect of the city police. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XX, pp. 6, 16. See Talavara, Talāra, etc.
3300: Mahātalavarī (IE 8-2; EI 20, 25), wife of a Mahātalavara.
3301: mahātantra (SITI; ASLV), often mentioned in South Indian records in the sense of ‘the army’; the army council; the great assembly of the army.
3302: Mahātantrādhikṛta (IE 8-3), explained by some authori-ties as ‘an officer in charge of judicial and charitable affairs’; but the word tantra also means ‘administration’ or ‘the army’; probably ‘the chief administrator’. The designation may have also indicated different functions in different localities and ages. See Tantrapāla, Tantrapati and Mahātantrādhyakṣa.
3303: Mahātantrādhyakṣa (EI 28), official designation; same as Mahātantrādhikṛta.
3304: Mahāṭhakkura (IE32; IA17), a title indicating office or rank.
3305: Mahātīrtha (BL), epithet of a holy place or shrine. Cf. tīrtha.
3307: Mahātman (CII 1), a person of high rank; a rich man; explained in some cases as ‘a magistrate’ (cf. Select Inscriptions, p. 248, note 6).
3308: māhātmya (IA 30), a culogistic work on deities or holy places, rivers, etc.; cf. sthala-purāṇa.
3309: Mahato (EI 8-3), same as Mahattaka, Mahattara or Maha-ttama. Cf. Mahatā; also Mahto in Wilson's Glossary.
3310: mahātoraṇa (SITI), a variety of temple lamps; pro-bably the same as makaratoraṇa.
3311: Mahattaka (EI 8; BL; HD), probably, a village head-man or a member of the Pañcāyat board; same as Mahattara. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 30 (Mahāmahattaka).
3312: Mahattama (IE 8-3; EI 29; CII 4; BL; HD), probably the village headman or a member of the Pañcāyat board; cf. Mahattara. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 306; Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 266 (Mahattara and Mahattama occur one after another, Mahattama being senior or superior to Mahattara); Rājataraṅgiṇī, VII. 438. (EI 26), same as Gujarātī Mahetā or Mehtā.
3313: Mahattara (IE 8-3; EI 23, 29, 30; CII 4; BL; HD), literally, ‘an elder [of a town or village]’; according to Stein (Rājataraṅgiṇī, VII. 659); a chamberlain, a village headman or head of a family or community and a member of the village council; cf. Hindī Mahato; Gujaratī Mahetā. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, p. 114 (rāṣṭra-grāma-mahattara); Daśakumāracarita, III, p. 77 (janapada-mahattara). Cf. mahattar-ādy-aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa (EI 31), ‘office of the administrative board of the aṣṭakula headed by the Mahattara’; see Mahattara and aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa. (IE 3-3), official guide. (Beal, Life of Hiuen Tsiang, p. 190).
3314: Mahattaraka (EI 23; LL), explained as ‘a chamberlain’; same as Mahattara.
3315: mahātrāṇa (IE 8-5), Bengali; a rent-free holding in the possession of non-Brahmanical communities, e. g. the Vaiṣṇavas).
3316: Mahāvaḍḍavyavahārin (EI 13; SII 11-2), see Vaḍḍavya-vahārin and Mahāvaṇḍavyavahārin; Sanskrit Mahāvṛddhavyavahārin.
3317: Mahāvalākoṣṭhika (IE 8-3), probably a mistake for Mahā-balakoṣṭhika (q. v.).
3318: Mahāvaṇḍavyavahārin (EI 19; SITI), the great banker or chief merchant; head of a mercantile guild; same as Mahāvaḍḍavyavahārin.
3319: mahāvāruṇī (EI 4), name of a tithi. See mahāmahāvāruṇī.
3321: Mahāvihāra-svāmin (EI 8; CII 3; BL), designation of the builder of a Buddhist monastery and his heirs who were res-ponsible for its maintenance; the builder or owner of a big monastery; cf. Vihāra-svāmin.
3322: mahāvihār-āyatana (EI 22), a monastic establishment. Cf. āyatana.
3323: Mahāvinayadhara (LL), Buddhist; cf. Vinayadhara, ‘one who has committed the Vinaya texts to memory’.
3324: Mahāvaratin (EI 27; SITI), name of a Śaiva sect; followers of the said sect of Śaivism; an ascetic of the Kālāmukha sect.
3325: mahā-vyavasthā (SITI), probably, the regulations framed by the mahā-sabhā.
3326: Mahāvyūhapati (EI 19, 28, 30; HD), the chief master of battle arrays. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 40.
3328: Mahāyuvarāja (EI 32), title of a crown prince; see Yuva-rāja and Yuvamahārāja.
3330: Maheśvara (SITI), Māheśvara, followers of the Śaiva reli-gion; a congregation of Śaiva devotees having a voice in the management of the affairs of a Śiva temple. (ASLV), trustee of a Śaiva temple. (IE 8-2), ‘devotee of Maheśvara (Śiva),’ epithet of a Kuṣāṇa king.
3332: Maheśvara-putra (EI 33), sometimes used as an epithet of one devoted to the god Śiva.
3335: Mahimada (EI 32), Indianised form of the Muhammadan name Muḥammad or Mahmūd.
3336: Mahīmaṇḍaleśvara (BL), rare modification of the feuda-tory title Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara.
3337: mahiṣa-kara, cf. Tamil erumai-ppon (SITI), tax on buffa-loes.
3338: Mahiṣī, cf. Agaramahiṣī Agramahāmahiṣī, Mahāmahiṣī, etc.
3339: Mahodaya (IA 18), used in the sense of Svāmin or possessor.
3342: Māhut (CII 4), derived from Mahāmātra, an elephant-driver.
3343: mahya (EI 28), same as namasya. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, pp. 77 ff.
3345: Maithilī, language and alphabet of Mithilā or the Tirhut region of North Bihar.
3346: maithuna (SITI), wife's brother; elder sister's husband.
3347: maitrī (CII 4), benevolence; one of the bhāvanās.
3348: makara-saṅkramaṇa (SITI), entrance of the sun into Cap-ricorn; commencement of the Tamil month Tai; same as Makara-saṅkrānti.
3350: makara-toraṇa (EI 29), one of the royal insignia. (EI 3; SII 1, 3), an ornamental arch; an arch in the shape of a makara (crocodile); gateway with figures of crocodiles. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol XXXV p. 107.
3351: makarikā (CITD), figures of crocodiles drawn in gold dust on the cheeks and breasts of women; same as makarikā-patra. (EI 14), cf. mukuṭa-makarikā-marakata.
3353: makuti (CII 4), an edict addressed to the Śūdras. Cf. Mākutika, official designation.
3355: Maladhāri (BL), epithet of a Jain religious teacher.
3357: malamārgaṇa (LL), cf. Gujarātī maḻavero; a tax to be utilised when the whole village wants to honour a particular man.
3358: Mālava-gaṇ-āmnāta, Mālava-gaṇa-sthiti, Mālava-pūrvā (EI 23), expressions used in early records in connection with the Vikrama-saṃvat.
3359: Mālavī, dialect of Hindī prevalent in Mālava (Malwa).
3361: malaya (IA 14), derived from Dravidian malai, ‘a hill’.
3362: Malayāḻam, name of a language and alphabet.
3363: Maleya-sāhaṇi (Naik's List, No. 264); mentioned along-with Peyiya-sāhaṇi; official designation. See Sāhaṇi.
3364: Mālima, same as Arabic Mualim, ‘an instructor’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
3367: malla-kara (HRS), found in Nepal inscriptions; tax levied as tribute to the Mallas or for defence against their attack. Cf. turuṣka-daṇḍa, etc. It may also be a professional tax on wrestlers.
3368: mallaka-vundhaka, cf. talabhedyā-ghāṇaka-mallaka-vundhaka (IA 18); probably, a professional tax on wrestlers.
3369: Malik, Malika (EI 4; BL), Muslim title of nobility; same as Arabic Malik; also spelt in Indian languages as Mallika.
3371: Mamátrai (IE 8-3), Greek modification of Mahāmātra; explained as ‘commanders or rulers among Indians’.
3374: man, cf. mānayitvā (LP) ‘having accepted’; cf. Gujarātī mānine.
3375: māna (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; (1/16)th part of the measure called tūmu; that which can hold rice of the weight of 4 ṭaṅkalamulu (varying in different localities); a particular measure or weight often regarded as half of a seru; a measur-ing rod. (EI 16), also called mānaka; name of a measure; a liquid measure (SII 11-1).
3376: māna, māṇa (IE 8-6; EI 30, 31), used in medieval Orissan records in the sense of a land measure; a land measure regarded as equal to an English acre in Orissa.
3379: mānaka (EI 14, 16), name of a measure; also called māna.
3380: māna-pautava (EI 30), probably, a store-house where grains were measured and stored. Cf. mānya (aḻḻāya-mānya). (IE 8-8), scales and measures.
3381: māna-stambha (EI 5, 8), a pillar; an elegant tall pillar with a small pinnacled maṇṭapa at the top erected in front of Jain temples.
3382: manavarti, manavartika (EI 32), grant for maintenance; also spelt as manovarti, manuvṛtti, etc., probably derived from Sanskrit mānya-vṛtti.
3383: Mānavya (EI 16), name of a gotra that was claimed by royal families which had originally no real Brāhmanical gotra.
3384: mañca, cf. sa-mañca-mahākaraṇa (IE 8-5); probably, elevated platforms for official use.
3385: maṇḍa, weight equal to 5 māṣas (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 46); cf. māḍa.
3386: maṇḍaī (EI 23), derived from maṇḍapikā; same as maṇḍī, ‘market’.
3388: maṇḍala (IE 8-4; EI 29, 30; CII 4), an administrative unit; a district or province. (SITI), a province consisting of several koṭṭams or valanāḍus. (IE 8-4), sometimes mentioned as bigger than a viṣaya and sometimes smaller than it; sometimes a viṣaya was included in a maṇḍala, but sometimes a maṇḍala was included in a viṣaya; some-times maṇḍala and viṣaya are identical; sometimes a maṇḍala was smaller than the vīthī or subdivision. (IE 8-4; SII 3; ASLV), sometimes used in a wider sense to indicate a country. Cf. Kona-maṇḍala (EI 22), also called an avani-maṇḍala or deśa. Here maṇḍala means a kingdom or territory. (ASLV), an assembled body. Cf. mātṛ-maṇḍala.
3389: Maṇḍal-ācārya (EI 33, IA 14), same as Paṭṭ-ācārya; desig-nation of a high priest. (BL), epithet of a [Jain] religious teacher.
3390: Maṇḍal-ādhipati (EI 25), the ruler of a maṇḍala; cf. Maṇḍaleśvara Maṇḍalapati.
3392: maṇḍala-karaṇa (LP), department dealing with the ad-ministration of districts.
3394: maṇḍala-mudanmai (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; leadership or governorship of a province, its governor or chief being known as Maṇḍala-mudaliyār.
3395: Maṇḍalapati (IE 8-3; EI 26, 33), ruler or officer-in-charge of a maṇḍala; the governor of a district or a feudatory ruler (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 78, text line 9); same as Maṇḍaleśa.
3396: Maṇḍaleśa (BL; HD), ‘lord of a maṇḍala’; a provincial governor; same as Maṇḍaleśvara. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, VI. 73; VII. 996; VIII. 1228, 1814, 2029.
3397: Maṇḍaleśvara (IE 8-2; BL; HD), title of a feudatory or governor lower in rank than a Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara; same as Maṇ-ḍaleśa. Cf. Bomb. Gaz., Vol. XXI, p. 354. Cf. Mahāmaṇḍa-leśvara, ‘governor of the provinces’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 110).
3398: Maṇḍalika (EI 26), ruler of a maṇḍala or district; same as Māṇḍalika.
3399: Māṇḍalika (IE 8-2; BL; CII 4), ruler of a maṇḍala or district; title of a feudatory chief; cf. Maṇḍalika, Maṇḍalīka.
3400: Maṇḍalīka (IE 8-2; SII 1; SITI; BL), feudatory title; ruler of a maṇḍala; same as Maṇḍalika and Māṇḍalika, also called Maṇḍaleśvara.
3401: maṇḍapa (IE 8-3), customs house; Marāṭhī māṇḍavī, from Sanskrit maṇḍapikā; explained by some as ‘a market place’ (Hindī maṇḍī); but Hindī maṇḍī seems to be derived from the same word because the toll-stations were often situated in market-places. (BL), name of a structure in front of a temple. (LL), a porch or hall. (CII 4), the hall in a temple. (CII 4), a temple. (EI 31), a temple or public building. Cf. vaiccamudu-maṇḍapa (SITI), kitchen; same as maḍaip-paḻḻi. Cf. vakkāṇikku-maṇḍapa (SITI), hall where disputations in the śāstras are held. Cf. śanivāra-maṇḍapa.
3402: maṇḍapikā (EI 1, 3, 33), customs house; same as śulka-maṇḍapikā (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 339 and note 31). See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 238-39. (EI 3; CII 4); market; a market pavilion. (CII 4), a small temple.
3403: Māṇḍapika (IE 8-2), cf. Prakrit Maṃḍavika (EI I), officer in charge of a maṇḍapikā or customs house; a collector of tolls.
3404: maṇḍapik-ādāya (EI 23), explained as ‘the market tax’; customs duties.
3405: maṇḍapikā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP), the customs depart ment.
3407: Māṇḍavī (LP), one who gets the market-tax; same as Māṇḍapika. (LP), a tax levied on articles that are to be sold in a market-place. (IE 8-3), Marāṭhī; same as maṇḍapikā, ‘customs house’.
3408: maṇḍavo (EI 22), market place; regarded as the same as maṇḍapikā.
3409: Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3; EI 16; SII 11-2), Kannaḍa; superintendent or steward of the royal household (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 77); sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Hĕri-sandhivigrahin, Antaḥpurādhyakṣa, Hĕri-Lāḻa-Kannaḍa-sandhivi-grahin, etc., additionally.
3410: Maneyasamastasainyādhipati (IE 8-3), leader of all the troops in the royal household. Cf. Samastasenādhipati, etc.
3411: maṅgala (CII 1), a ceremony for one's good or for averting evil; cf. kalyāṇa. (SITI), a Brāhmaṇa village; shortened form of caturvedi-maṅgala. (ASLV), a small administrative unit. (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’.
3412: maṅgala-kalasa (CII 4), an auspicious vase. Cf. nidrā-kalasa.
3414: māṅgalikya (LP), some present (made in lieu of the benefit one is going to get).
3415: māṅgalīyaka (LP), probably, a tax collected on the occa-sion of auspicious events in the royal family, such as the birth of a son to the king.
3416: māṅgalya (SITI), Tamil maṅgiliyam; the ornament called tāli worn round the neck as the marriage badge by a married woman with her husband living.
3417: maṅgaṇi, maṅgaṇī, maṅaṇī (Chamba), a tax in kind.
3419: māni (LP), a measure of capacity equal to about 6 maunds. (SII 11-1), Kannaḍa; also spelt Māṇi; a bachelor; Brahmacārin.
3420: māṇi (EI 14; Chamba), name of a measure.
3421: maṇi-bhaṇḍalu (CITD), Sanskrit-Telugu; probably, from Sanskrit maṇi-bhāṇḍa or the receptacle of jewels.
3423: māṇika (CITD), Telugu; a measure; (1/4) of a kuñcamu and (1/15) of a tūmu.
3425: māṇikya-bhāṇḍāra, cf. maṇikka-paṇḍāram-kāppār (SITI), ‘keeper of the treasury [of precious stones] in the temple or palace.’
3428: mañjāḍi (IE 8-8; EI 21, 33; SII 2, 12; SITI), Tamil; name of a weight for measuring gold and silver; about 2 or 3 ratīs or 4 or 5 grains; a weight equal to two kuṉṟi-maṇi used in weighing gold; (1/10) of a kal13añju and (1/100) of a śatamāna (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 141).
3431: Manneya (CITD), Telugu; same as Sanskrit Mānya; a respectable man; a chieftain; a commander; a chief. Cf. Mannīḍu, Manniya. (SII 11-1), ruler of a group of villages; cf. manneya-svāmya, tenure held by a Manneya.
3434: manohārī (LP), cf. nija-manohāryā, ‘at one's own will’.
3436: manovarti (EI 32), same as manavarti or manuvṛtti in the sense of namasya-vṛtti or mānya; probably derived from Sanskrit mānya-vṛtti.
3439: Mantrapāla (EI 22), official designation; probably, a private secretary or privy councillor.
3440: Mantrapuṣpa (IA 12), designation of a priest who repeats the mantra when the chief priest asks forgiveness at the conclusion of each pūjā at the Rāmeśvaram temple.
3441: mantra-śakti (CII 4), the power of good counsel.
3442: mantra-snāna (EI 4), repetition of prayers used at ablution without the actual bath.
3443: Mantrin (EI 12, 25; CII 4; BL; HD), a minister or coun-cillor; a counsellor; an executive officer. See Arthaśāstra, I. 80; Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 312; Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305. (IE 8-3), explained as vyavahāra-draṣṭṛ. Cf. Mahāmantrin. (IE 8-3), in one case, the Mantrin later became a Mahā-balādhikṛta; in another case, also a Kumārāmātya.
3444: mantri-pariṣad (CII 4; ASLV), the council of ministers; same as pariṣad.
3447: manuṣya-yajña (CII 4), reception of guests; one of the five mahāyajñas.
3448: manuvṛtti (EI 32), a grant made for the maintenance of the donee; same as manavarti, etc.; probably derived from Sanskrit mānya-vṛtti.
3449: manvādi (IA 18), name applied to certain tithis.
3450: mānya (IE 8-5; EI 20, 23; ASLV), a rent-free holding, tax-free land; same as sarva-mānya; cf. mānya-sthiti, manuvṛtti, etc. Cf. sthāna-mānya (CITD), an honour or glebe-land granted by the ruler on quit-rent or on various favourable tenures. (EI 13), land either liable to a trifling quit-rent or alto-gether exempt from tax. Cf. aḻḻāya-mānyam (SITI), right to receive a handful of grain or the prescribed quantity of an article brought for sale in the market as charges for measuring; cf. māna-pautava. Cf. guḍḍe-mānya (IA 19), a particular kind of rent-free holding.
3451: mānya-kaṇikĕ (EI 25), a small amount of tax levied from land declared rent-free. Cf. nikara, tṛṇodaka, etc.
3452: mānyaka-paṭṭa, a rent-free village (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71).
3454: manyavāntara-rāṣṭra (SII 1), same as nāḍu or district.
3456: māppaṇam (SITI), Tamil; same as Sanskrit mahā-paṇa; name of a coin.
3459: maramakkatayam (EI 9), system of inheritance prevalent in the Malayāḻam-speaking area, according to which property is owned by females and passes from female to female.
3460: Marāṭhī, language and people of Maharashtra.
3462: Mārga (IE 8-1), abbreviation of Mārgaśīrṣa, Mārgaśira, etc.
3463: mārg-ādāya (EI 23; SITI), same as vartma-daṇḍa; levy for passage of articles of merchandise through the gift village by the village road; tolls; tolls on the articles on transit. See mārgaka.
3464: mārgaka (EI 26), name of a levy; same as mārg-ādāya.
3466: mārgaṇaka (EI 3; IA 18; CII 4; HRS), known from re-cords like those of the Caulukyas; a levy; a kind of cess or tax; explained as ‘benevolences of a general character, as distin-guished from the special types called prasthaka and skandhaka’. See mārgaṇika.
3469: Mārgapāla (HD), same as Mārgapati, etc. See Nārada quoted in the Mitākṣarā on Yājñavalkyasmṛti, II. 71. Cf. Dikpāla.
3470: Mārgapati (BL; HE), explained as ‘the guardian of the frontiers or passes’ (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XX, pp. 37, 41); probably, a collector of customs duties on the roads. See mārg-ādāya, etc.
3472: marīchi, a theoretical unit of measurement (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
3476: maṟuturu (IE 8-6; CITD); also called maṟutu, mattaru, etc.; Telugu; Kannaḍa mattar or mattaru; a certain land measure of uncertain area generally used as an equivalent of nivartana, different kinds being mentioned as kāl-maṟuturu, ghaḍa-maṟuturu, kommu-maṟutu, etc.
3477: Marvāḏī, spelt Marwari in English; name of the Rājasthānī dialect prevalent in Marwar.
3478: maryādā (SITI), Tamil mariyādi; customary dues; manners; ways; extent; limit; also spelt in Tamil as marjādi, mariśādi, maruśādi, etc.
3479: Maryādā-dhurya (BL), explained as ‘the Warden of Marches.’
3480: maryādā-parihāra (EI 22), customary exemptions of taxes. See parihāra.
3482: māṣa (EI 21, 25, 30, 33; CII 4), according to the Kṛtya-kalpataru (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, p. 125), a gold coin as opposed to silver māṣaka; name of a weight; name of a coin; 5 ratis in weight; sometimes regarded as 10 ratis in weight and as equal to (1/4) of a śāna. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 41. It was sometimes regarded as (1/20) of a paṇa of 100 ratis (ibid., Vol. XV, p. 143). Cf. māṣaka, ādya-māṣa.
3483: māṣaka (IE 8-8), name of a coin; cf. māṣa and dināri-māṣaka; mentioned as a silver coin (K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, Kṛtyakalpataru, Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, p. 125).
3484: māsārdha (IE 7-1-2), used to indicate ‘six’; cf. māsa, ‘twelve’; also pakṣa, ‘two’.
3485: Māśu (Chamba), one enjoying land, who does not pay rent or tax but renders service; e. g., a carpenter, etc.
3487: mata, cf. guru-mata (CII 1), ‘a matter considered to be serious’. (LP), a signature; cf. the use of the word with the signature as in mataṃ mama amukasya found copied in many copper-plate grants.
3489: mātā-pitṛ-pād-ānudhyāta (IE 8-2), ‘meditating on or favoured by the feet of one's parents’; epithet of rulers; cf. mātā-pitṛ-pād-ānudhyāna-rata.
3490: Mātaraḥ (CII 3), the Divine Mothers, sometimes indicat-ed as seven in number; cf. Mātṛ and Mātṛ-gaṇa.
3491: maṭha (EI 17, 19, 23, 31, 32; CII 3, 4; SII 1; BL; ASLV; CITD), a school or religious college; a temple; a monastery; hermitage or convent; a monastery which was a religious and educational institution. See maṭhikā. In Telugu records, it also means ‘a bullock cart’ and ‘a cart load’ (cf. Kannaḍa maṭṭī, ‘a load’). (SITI), place where pilgrims and religious mendicants (tapasvins) are fed.
3492: Maṭhādhipati (EI 25), same as Jīyar and Mudaliyār; cf. Maṭhapati.
3493: Maṭhapati (EI 33), superintendent of a monastery; the chief priest of a temple.
3494: māṭhāpatya (SITI), the office or position of a Maṭhapati; management of the affairs of a maṭha or temple.
3496: maṭhikā (EI 31), a hut, cottage or cell. (EI 26, 32), a shrine or temple; cf. maṭha.
3497: Matisaciva (IE 8-3; HD), counsellor or minister; cf. Karma-saciva, administrative officer. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 44.
3498: Mātṛ (EI 9), the Divine Mothers, often described as seven in number; cf. mātṛ-maṇḍala, various forms of the Mother-goddess installed around a Śiva temple.
3499: Mātra, designation of a class of officers; cf. Mahāmātra in a similar sense. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 117 (mentioned along with Mūlaprakṛti; cf. Prakṛti).
3500: Mātṛ-gaṇa (IA 7), the Divine Mothers, often described as seven in number. Cf. mātṛ-maṇḍala.
3501: matsy-ākara, cf. sa-matsy-ākara (IE 8-5), ‘together with the sources of fish’, the fishing right belonging to the king or land-lord; cf. jala-kara.
3502: mātsya-nyāya (EI 4), ‘the law of the fish’; anarchy.
3503: matta (LP), a signature; corrupt form of mata, ‘approved’, written along with the signature as in mataṃ mama amukasya. See mata.
3504: mattal (EI 16; IA 11), land measure; same as mattar.
3505: mattar (EI 16, 20), Kannaḍa; land measure; same as maṟuturu or nivartana; cf. gaṇṭi-mattar (IA 9).
3506: mattaru (IE 8-6; CITD), same as mattar or nivartana.
3507: maṭṭa-skandha (LP), a layer of mud; cf. maṭṭa-skandha-rahita (LP), free from the layers of mud.
3509: maṭṭu (CITD), Telugu; an unknown measure of land.
3511: maulika (IE 8-5; EI 32), a tax; the principal or main tax or the perquisites of hereditary officers.
3512: mavāḍa (CII 4), name of a tax; cf. māvaḍai.
3513: māvaḍai (EI 17), name of a tax. cf. mavāḍa.
3514: mayūra (CII 1), a peacock; a bird in general.
3515: mayūṭa (HRS), probably, the contributions of fruits, fire-wood, etc., paid by villagers.
3517: meḍhi (LP), a barn-yard, a threshing floor.
3518: meḍhi-hāraka (LP), a special tax on the threshing-floor.
3519: medhya, cf. a-paśu-medhya (IE 8-5), ‘free from the obligation of supplying animals for sacrifices’.
3520: meḍi (EI 9), also called meli, a kidnapper of victims for sacrifices.
3527: Mel-śānti (SITI), Tamil-Sanskrit; chief priest in a temple.
3528: melviṭṭiya-vaḍḍāravuḻa (IE 8-5), Kannaḍa; name of a tax; see vaḍḍāravuḻa.
3530: Meridarkha (IE 8-3; ML), an official designation of foreign origin; same as Greek Meridarkhes, ‘a district officer’.
3532: meru (SII 3), name of a gift. (EI 2; CII 4), a kind of temple.
3533: meṣa-saṅkrānti (CII 3, etc.), the entrance of the sun into the sign Aries, regarded as the starting point of the Śaka year; see also abdapa.
3534: meya (IE 8-5; EI 31; HRS), the share of grains to be paid to the king or landlord; revenue from agricultural land paid in kind; same as bhāga. Cf. tulya-meya, tax on commodities brought to market for sale.
3536: majigiti (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 242), also spelt mijigiti; Indianised form of Arabic masjid, a mosque.
3537: mijigiti (A. R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 12); see majigiti.
3538: milivalita, same as Sanskrit sammilita, ‘taken collectively’ (JAS, Latters, Vol. XX, p. 204).
3539: miśra (IA 18), an honorific title; cf. Mahāmiśrapaṇdita.
3541: miti (IA 20), cf. Saṃvat 1384 miti Bhādra-vadi 3 Guru-dine; probably a corruption of Sanskrit mita, ‘counted’, ‘calculated’.
3542: Mleccha (EI 22), name applied to the Muhammadans and other foreigners; cf. Mleccheśvara (EI 32).
3544: modala-vāḍa (IE 8-4), Kannaḍa; the chief village in a Pargana consisting of a number of villages, i. e. headquarters; sometimes called rājadhānī.
3545: modati, cf. svarge modati bhūmidaḥ; parasmaipada in place of the expected ātmanepada.
3546: Modina, same as Arabic Muazzin, ‘a public crier to prayers’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
3547: Mohinī (IA 19), female devils who possess men.
3548: mokīraka (LP), a den in a mountain forest; Gujarātī bhokaruṃ.
3549: mṛḍa, also called pṛḍa or pruḍa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 40); unit of metal weight like the mañjāḍi.
3550: mṛga (CII 1), a deer; an animal in general.
3552: mṛtyuka-vṛtti (BL; HRS), land granted by the king as military pension to the heir of a person killed in a battle against the king's enemies; compensatory grant made in favour of the heir of a person who died fighting on behalf of his master. See rakta-mānya, etc. Cf. vīra-śeṣā.
3553: mūḍā (LP), same as mūḍaka or mūṭaka; a measure of capacity equal to a hundred maunds or to 24 maunds in the Surat District.
3554: mūḍaka (LP), same as mūṭaka or mūḍā.
3555: Mudal, cf. Evi-mudal (EI 25), an official designation.
3557: mudala (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 18), used in some Orissan inscriptions in the sense of a royal order [regarding the grant of land or its execution]. Cf. ibid., Vol. XXVIII, p. 305.
3558: Mudali, Mudaliyār (SII 12; SITI), Tamil; a chief. (EI 25), same as Maṭhādhipati.
3560: muditā (CII 4), cheerfulness; one of the Buddhist bhāvanās.
3561: mudrā (CII 4), the position of fingers in worship. (LP), the government seal.
3562: mūrdh-ādhikāra, cf. Tamil mūtt-ādikāram (SITI), supreme authority.
3563: Mudrādhikārin (EI 30), officer in charge of the royal seal; also called Mudr-ādhyakṣa, etc. Mudrādhikāri-saciva, may be Mudrādhikārin and Saciva.
3565: Mudr-ādhyakṣa, same as Mudr-ādhikārin, etc.; cf. Rājamudrā-dhikārin. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 96.
3566: Mudrāhasta (EI 33), official designation; same as Oḍiyā Mudiratha, designation of a class of servants in the temple of Jagannātha at Purī.
3567: mudr-āpavāra (IE 8-8; EI 30), the crime of using coun-terfeit coins or the misuse of official seals.
3568: mudrā-śaṅkha, cf. Tamil muttirai-ccaṅgu (SITI), a variety of conch-shell; conch-shell marked with a seal.
3569: mudr-āvatāra, cf. Tamil muttir-āvatāram (SITI), an ear-ornament.
3570: mudrā-vyāpāra (IE 8-2); 8-3; BL), ‘the affairs associated with the royal seal’; often used in connection with the function of the viceroy described as conducting the said business; cf. samasta-mudrā-vyāpārān paripanthayati, śrī-śrīkaraṇ-ādi-samasta-mu-drāvyāpārān paripanthyati. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 154. See also vyāpāra.
3571: Muduḍa (EI 27), same as Mutuḍa; probably, a village headman.
3572: muha-patti (HA), a piece of cloth held in front of the mouth by Jain monks and nuns, while they are talking, in order to avoid small living beings being destroyed by breath.
3573: muhūrta (CII 3; IA 17), the thirtieth part of a mean day and night; equal to fortyeight minutes.
3574: mukha (EI 22; LL), the face, the gate; a door. Cf. dāna-mukha (ML), the principal gift. (EI 16), used at the end of compounds in the sense of mukhya; ‘head’ ‘heading’ or ‘sum’. Cf. pañca-mukha-nagara. Cf. muha-patti.
3575: mukha-kaṭṭaṇa (SITI), porch; also called darśana-kāṇikkai; front side of a building (SII 12).
3576: mukha-maṇḍapa, Tamil muga-maṇḍaka (SITI), the front hall in a temple; cf. mahāmaṇḍapa.
3578: muktā (BL), epithet of a grant; a grant; possibly Arabic mukhta.
3579: mukti-bhūmi (EI 27, 30), a holy place where salvation is attainable on death.
3580: mukh-āhāra, ‘principal food or meals’; same as mukhy-āhāra. See Sel. Ins., p. 162, text line 5.
3581: Mukhya (EI 32), city elder; member of the city council. Cf. Hindī Mukhiyā, a village elder. (CII 1), chief officer. (EI 16), see mukha meaning ‘head’, ‘heading’ or ‘sum’. mukhy-āhāra, cf. mukh-āhāra.
3583: mūla (SITI), original; a document regarding a title to the property or right. (HRS), investment of capital which is one of the seven sources of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 26. (Sel. Ins., p. 163), seedling. Cf. sa-mūla (EI 13), a tree.
3584: Mūla-bhṛtya (SITI), the chief servant; also called Caṇḍe-śvara who was the chief servant of Śiva.
3585: mūla-gabhāro (HA), Jain; same as garbha-gṛha; the sanctum where the Mūla-nāyaka is installed.
3587: Mūla-nāyaka (BL), epithet of a Jain Tīrthaṅkara; Mahāvīra called ‘the Mūla-nāyaka of the Saṇḍeraka-gaccha’. (HA), the main deity in the sanctum of a shrine or in a devakulikā; also the central Jina in a sculpture representing a group of Jinas.
3588: mūla-pariṣad, cf. Tamil mūla-pariṣai (SITI), chief assembly [of a Śiva temple]; variously written in Tamil as mūla-paraḍai, mūla-paruḍai, mūla-pariḍai, mūla-paruṣai, etc.
3589: Mūlaprakṛti (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’. (EI 18), probably ‘the prominent subjects’ or ‘landlords’ or the six important officers styled Prakṛti (q.v.).
3590: Mūlaratnabhaṇḍarattār (SII 2), Sanskrit Mūlaratnabhāṇ-ḍārastha; treasures of the chief jewels.
3591: Mūla-saṅgha (EI 16, 25), name of a Jain sect.
3592: mūla-sthāna, cf. Tamil mūla-ttānam (SII 3; SITI; CITD), a place; the origin, base or foundation; the supreme spirit; the central shrine in a temple (SII 13); the place where the main image stands. (EI 18), an important seat of monks.
3593: mūla-vīsa (EI 6; ASLV), cf. Telugu-Kannaḍa vīsa, (1/16) of a haṇa (paṇa); name of a tax or levy.
3594: Mūliā (EI 31), Oḏiyā; a day-labourer; from Sanskrit Mūlika, possibly an abbreviation of Pādamūlika.
3595: Mūḻuḍa (LL), same as Mutuḍa or Muduḍa; probably, a village headman. Cf. Śīrṣaka.
3596: mūlya (CII 3), an endowment; equivalent to akṣaya-nīvī, a perpetual endowment. (HRS), proceeds of sale of metal-ware manufactured in the government workshops, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
3597: Mummuḍi, cf. Mummuḍi-col13a, ‘three times a Coḻa king’; cf. Nūrmaḍi and Immaḍi.
3599: mumoda (EI 13), parasmaipada form instead of the expected ātmanepada.
3600: Mū°-nā° (PJS), contraction of Mūla-nāyaka, ‘the principal deity in a Jain temple’; often found in medieval Jain inscrip-tions.
3601: muṇḍamola (IE 8-5), cf. khaṇḍapāla-muṇḍamola (EI 24); name of a tax.
3603: muni (SII 1; IA 30; LL), a Jain monk. (IE 7-1-2), ‘seven’.
3604: murā (EI 33), a measure of capacity; cf. muraka.
3606: mūrti (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’; rarely used to indicate ‘eight’; but cf. rūpa used in the sense of ‘one’.
3607: Muruṇḍa (EI 14, 19), Śaka title of a chief; a title or tribal name; supposed to be derived from a Scythian word meaning ‘a king’.
3608: Mūsara-vāru (CITD), Telugu; probably, goldsmiths or manufacturers of metallic objects.
3609: muṣṭi (IE 8-6), a handful. Cf. eka-muṣṭyā (LP), ‘at the same time’.
3610: muṭaka, mūṭaka (IE 8-5; EI 25), a measure or head-load; cf. caṇā-satka-mūṭaka, ‘one mūṭaka of peas’ (LP). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 303, text line 50; cf. moṭ (a load) in Hindī and other dialects.
3611: mūṭaka (LP), same as mūḍā, a measure of capacity equal to a hundred or twentyfour maunds; a bullock's load (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309; cf. Marāṭhī mūṭh, ‘a bullock's pack-saddle’).
3612: mu-ṭī, abbreviation of an expression probably meaning ‘a mound covered with jungle’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 56).
3613: mutirigai (IE 8-6), Tamil; a small land measure equal to (1/320) of a veli.
3614: mutkalanīya (LP), ‘may be sent’; cf. Gujarātī mokalavuṃ.
3616: Mutuḍa (EI 27), also spelt as Muduḍa, Muḻuḍa; probably, the headman of a village.
3620: nāḍ (ASLV), same as nāḍu; a district; the assembly of a district; the professional association and guild of a district.
3621: naḍa (IE 8-6), same as nala, a measuring rod.
3622: Nāḍa-gauḍa, same as Nāḍu-gauḍa, Nār-gāvuṇḍa, etc.
3623: nāḍaka, same as nāḍuka (IE 8-4); same as nāḍ, nāḍu.
3624: Nāḍa-senabova (ASLV), officer in charge of the accounts of a nāḍu or district.
3627: nadīpāla (HRS), fixed tax on villages situated upon the banks of rivers and lakes as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
3629: nāḍīyaka (LP), same as aṇāḍīyaka; a place where the carts stand to dispose of goods.
3630: nāḍu (IE 8-4; SII 1; SITI), a country; a territorial divi-sion; a district or a subdivision; the local assembly to govern the civic affairs of the division called nāḍu. (EI 31), a chamber.
3631: Nāḍu-gauda (ASLV), the head of an organisation relating to a district.
3635: nāgadala (BL), meaning uncertain; cf. ‘a race subsisting on nāgadala’.
3636: nāg-āmāvāsyā, cf. nāgara-amāvāsyā (EI 5), name of a tithi.
3637: Nagakāra (BL), wrong reading for Taṭṭhakāra, ‘a brazier’.
3638: nagara (IE 8-4), city; palace; cf. navara. (EI 21; SITI), a commercial guild; guild of merchants; a mercantile town; often spelt in Kannaḍa inscriptions as nakara or nakhara; cf. pañca-nagara. (CITD), in Telugu inscriptions, a territorial assembly like the sabhā and ūr; the merchant community in general or the organization of the merchant community of a town. In some places, the nagara and ūr carried on their functions side by side. The word is sometimes used to indicate occupational groups like śāleyanagarattom. Cf. K. A. Nilakanta Sastri, The Col13as, Vol. II, 1st ed., p. 294. (EI 4), same as Kaliṅga-nagara. Cf. śrī-Nagara-bhukti= Pāṭaliputra-bhukti (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 311). (IA 17), represented in Prakrit by nera further corrupted to ner or nar. See nagarī.
3639: Nagar-ādhikṛta (HD), the city prefect. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, IV. 81; VI. 70; VIII. 3334.
3641: Nāgaraka (HD), same as Nāgarika; chief officer of the city; the city prefect of police. See Arthaśāstra, II. 36; Kāma-sūtra, V. 5. 9 (the commentator explaining Nāgaraka as Daṇḍa-pāśika). Cf. Talavara.
3644: nagara-parivāra (ASLV), an organisation relating to a town.
3645: Nagarapati (EI 12, 32; HD), the city prefect; ruler of a city. See Ind. Ant., Vol. IV, p. 35.
3646: Nagara-rakṣaka (IE 8-2), same as Talāra, Nagararakṣin, Nāgarika, etc.
3647: Nagara-rakṣin, same as Nagara-rakṣaka, etc; prefect of the city police (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, pp. 156-57).
3648: Nagara-śreṣṭhin (IE 8-3; EI 15, 21; BL; HD), according to some, the city banker or guild president of the town; but actually, the chairman of a board of administration like the Pañcāyat; same as the Nagarseṭh who was the chairman of the board called Cauthiyā in late medieval Rajasthan. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 115; Proc. IHC, Ahmadabad, 1954, pp. 52 ff. See Pura-śreṣṭhin, Pura-pradhāna, Śeṭṭi, etc.
3650: Nagarattār (EI 30), Sanskrit Nagarastha; leading men of the city. (ASLV; SITI), members of a guild of a town; members of a mercantile guild.
3651: Nagara-vyavahārika (IE 8-3; CII 1; HD), Prakrit Nagala-viyohālaka; judicial officer of a city; superintendent of the judicial affairs of a city; the city magistrate; also styled a Mahā-mātra. See Paura-vyavahārika (Arthaśāstra, I. 12).
3652: nagarī (IA 17), represented in Prakrit by nerī; further corrupted into nar. See nagara.
3653: Nāgarika (HD), chief of the police. See Vikramorvaśīya, V (after verse 4); Daśakumāracarita, II, pp. 58-59. The Vaijayantī explains the word as Kārāpati, the superintendent of jails. (ASLV), the chief bailiff or prefect at Vijayanagara. See also Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 95-96. Cf. Nagara-rakṣin, etc.
3654: Nagar-seṭh (IE 8-3), Sanskrit Nagara-śreṣṭhin (q.v.); desig-nation of the chairman of an administrative board called Cauthiyā in Western India. See Śeṭṭi.
3656: naharaṇa, a thief's weapon to dig a hole in the walls (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, No. 1, p. 13).
3658: Naigama, cf. Negama (EI 24; LL), the inhabitant of a nigama (township); a merchant. See Nigama-putra.
3659: naijāyamāna (LP), from nija; ‘when they are going to get themselves separated’.
3660: Naimittika (EI 19, 26; HD), a soothsayer or astrologer. See Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305.
3663: Naiyāmika, Naiyamika (EI 24), also called Naiyāvika; a law officer or judge.
3664: Naiyogika (IE 8-3; EI 12, 24), cf. Niyogika (EI 8), ‘an officer’; officer-in-charge of an administrative unit; same as Niyogin.
3666: nakara, Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit nagara (q. v.); also spelt nakhara.
3668: nakhara, Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit nagara (q. v.); also spelt nakara.
3669: Nākhudā Arabic; captain or commander of a ship (Ep. Ind. Vol. XXXIV, p. 143).
3671: nala (IE 8-6), measuring rod; same as daṇḍa; sometimes regarded as 12 cubits, 22 cubits, 56 cubits, etc., in length; cf. Samataṭīya-nala, ‘the rod as used in the Samataṭa country’; Vṛṣabhaśaṅkara-nala, ‘the rod introduced by king Vṛṣabha-śaṅkara’, ‘the rod of the village of Pattiyamattavura’, etc. See kol, kolu, ghaḻe, etc. (IE 8-6), cf. aṣṭaka-navaka-nala, ṣaṭka-nala, etc., the first probably referring to the custom of measuring the length and breadth of a plot of land by rods of different length. (EI 28), used in some Orissan inscriptions in the sense of measurement of the area [of the gift land] (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 20). (EI 21), a measure.
3673: nāla, cf. sa-khila-nāla (IE 8-5; EI 14); cultivated land; same as nāla-bhūmi.
3675: nāḻi, nāl13i (EI 9, 28), a grain measure; same as nālikā.
3676: nālikā (IE 8-6), same as Pali nālī or nāḻi; regarded as the same as prastha, i. e. one-sixteenth of a droṇa.
3677: nālikāvāpa (IE 8-6; EI 31), a land measure; an area of land requiring one nālikā measure of seed grains for sowing.
3678: nalu, nāluka (EI 7; CII 4), a measure of land; same as nalva; 400 (or 100 or 120) square cubits.
3679: nāma-gṛha, cf. nāmghar (IA 25), Assamese; a place of worship of the Vaiṣṇavas, where plays, etc., are performed.
3680: namaka (IA 18), name applied to the first section of the Rudrajapa.
3682: nāma-liṅga (EI 15), a deity bearing the name of a person.
3683: namas (CII 3), ‘reverence’; an invocation, generally con-nected with the names of gods, at the commencement of ins-criptions.
3684: namasya (IE 8-5; EI 5, 13, 28), same as mānya, sarva-na-masya, namasya-vṛtti, etc.; a rent-free tenure.
3685: namasya-vṛtti (IE 8-5; EI 32), same as sarva-namasya, etc.; a tax-free holding.
3686: nāṇā (EI 30), name of a coin; same as nāṇaka.
3687: nānādeśi (EI 31; SITI; ASLV), guild of merchants coming from outside.
3688: nāṇai (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 197, text line 18), same as Sanskrit nāṇaka; ‘a coin.’
3690: naṅga (IE 8-5; EI 25), cf. naṅge gṛhītasya yac=c=āṣṭau ṣoḍaśa vā nagara-mahallakā vicārya vadante tad=eva pranāṇam; a word of uncertain meaning; but a fine is prescribed for a merchant's son described as naṅge gṛhīta.
3691: Nāṇī (CII 4), an engraver; probably a corruption of Vijñānin.
3693: nandā-dīpa, also called nandā-dīvigĕ (CITD); used in Telugu and Kannaḍa inscriptions in the sense of a lamp that is always kept burning before a deity in a temple; same as akhaṇḍa-dīpa.
3694: nandavana, nandāvana, cf. tiru-nandavanam, etc. (SII 1); a sacred flower-garden.
3695: nandā-viḻakku (SII 1, 2), also spelt as nondā°, nundā°; a perpetual lamp; same as nandā-dīpa, akhaṇḍa-dīpa.
3701: Narādhipati (IA 15), royal title; same as Narapati.
3702: Narapati (IE 8-2; EI 12, 19; HD; SITI), ‘lord of men’, ‘leader of the infantry’; title borne by the Col13a monarchs; Vijayanagara rulers, etc., in view of the large infantry they possessed; cf. the titles Aśvapati and Gajapati, and also Aśvapati-gajapati-narapati-rāja-tray-ādhipati which was the title of some kings. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 7; JBORS, Vol. V, p. 588.
3703: Narasvāmin, probably ‘a Jāgīrdār’; cf. °grāme mahattama-narasvāminaḥ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 51).
3704: Nār-gāvuṇḍa (EI 23, 27), village headman; also called Nāḍa-gauḍa; cf. Nār-gāvuṇḍa-svāmya-bhūta, ‘being in the posse-ssion of the Nār-gāvuṇḍas’.
3705: nārikela, cf. sa-guvāka-nārikela (EI 8-5); coconut palms [which the ordinary tenants had no right to enjoy].
3709: naṣṭabharaṭa (HRS), name of a levy; same as naṣṭibharaṭa; (see Ep. Ind., Vol. III, note 4); may be ‘compensation for losses’.
3710: naṣṭa-rājya (IA 22), former rule of a dead king. Cf. also vinaṣṭa-rājya.
3711: naṣṭibharaṭa (HRS), same as naṣṭabharaṭa; name of a levy (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 264, note 4).
3712: Naṭa (EI 31), a dancer; sometimes mentioned in the list of officials probably indicating ‘the chief dancer’.
3714: Nātha (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 313), same as Nāyaka.
3715: Naṭṭakāra (BL), mistake for Taṭṭhakāra, a brazier.
3716: Nāṭṭavar (ASLV), Tamil; members of an organisation relating to a nāḍu or district.
3718: Naubala-hasty-aśva-go-mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādi-vyāpṛta (IE 8-3; EI 12), an officer in charge of the royal navy and cattle; looks like a combination of Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-naubala-vyāpṛtaka and Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-go-mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādi-vyāpṛtaka.
3719: naudaṇḍa, same as naupatha (IHQ, Vol. XXIII, pp. 255-56).
3720: naukā-bandha (EI 32), a levy from the boatmen at landing places.
3721: Nauk-ādhyakṣa (IE 8-3), officer in charge of the navy.
3722: naukā-bhāṭaka (EI 14), charges for hiring a boat.
3723: nau-krama (EI 19), a bridge of boats or a ferry station.
3724: Nauvāha (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 244), a ship-owner, mari-ner or captain.
3725: Nauvāṭaka (EI 24), a naval officer. Cf. Ardha-nauvāṭaka. (EI 15), probably, a wall (so to say) made of a large number of boats.
3726: Nauvittaka, leader or owner of ships (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
3728: nava-cokī (HA), Sanskrit nava-catuṣkikā; a hall (open on three sides) adjacent to and in front of the gūḍha-maṇḍapa, so called because it is divided into nine sections by means of the pillars supporting its ceiling.
3729: nāvaḥ (HRS), charges for hiring royal boats; same as nau-bhāṭaka.
3730: navakāra (HA), Sanskrit namaskāra; the chief Jain formula for worship or an obeissance to the arhats, siddhas, ācāryas, upā-dhyāyas and sādhus.
3731: nava-karman, cf. Tamil nava-karumam (SITI); renovation; repairs. Cf. Prakrit nava-kama (EI 20), foundation, extension or repairs to buildings.
3732: Navakarmapati (EI 22), an architect or the supervisor of building operations; same as Navakarmika and Navakarmin.
3733: Navakarmika (EI 16, 23; LL), superintendent of a work (possibly of repairs); cf. Navakamika (EI 4, 20), an overseer of work (building or repairing operations); superintendent of building operations. Cf. Navakarmapati.
3734: Navakarmin (ML), same as Navakarmika, the superinten-dent of a work. Cf. Navakarmapati.
3735: nava-khaṇḍa (IE 8-4), epithet of Bhārata or Bhāratavarṣa; see khaṇḍa.
3737: navāṅga, cf. Pali navaṃga (EI 33); cf. navāṅga-Śāstṛ-śāsana.
3738: nava-nidhāna, cf. nava-nidhāna-sahita (IA 11), epithet of gift land; see Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, pp. 180 ff. (Inscriptions Nos. 4-11); explained as ‘new taxes imposed for the first time’; probably ‘a fresh assessment of tax’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 143).
3739: navara, Oḏiyā; same as Sanskrit nagara; capital city, palace.
3740: nava-ratna (BL), the nine gems at Vikramāditya's court.
3741: navarātra, navarātri (EI 11, 25; CII 4), the festival of Durgā; Āśvina-sudi 1 to 9.
3742: navarātri-amāvāsyā (EI 5), new-moon preceding the nava-rātri; also called mahālayā.
3744: navīna-pañjikā-karaṇa (LP), probably, ‘to have new fences’, i. e. ‘to have additional land in one's possession.’
3745: naya (EI 3), argumentation. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, pp. 318 ff, text lines 26-27), a territorial division like a Pargana.
3746: Nāyaka (EI 33; CII 4), a royal officer or ruling chief. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVII, p. 142, text line 35. (HD), explained as ‘the head of ten villages.’ See Artha-śāstra, I. 12; Śukra, I. 192. (EI 32; BL), title of a subordinate ruler. (ASLV), one who held lands from the Vijayanagara kings on the condition of offering military service (cf. Amara-nāyaka). (EI 7), a general. (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 313), head of a nāḍu or district. (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’.
3748: Nāyakavāḍi (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; watchmen stationed by the State or landlord to keep watch over the crops before or during harvest time; the inām granted to such persons was known as kākku-nāyaka-viḻāgam.
3750: nāyaṅkara, nāyaṅkāra (EI 16; ASLV), the feudal system prevalent in the Vijayanagara kingdom, in which the Nāyakas enjoyed royal land on condition of offering military service; see Nāyaka, Amara-nāyaka.
3755: netra (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; in some areas of Eastern India, it was used in the sense of Hara-netra, ‘three’. The word dṛk seems to bear the sense of three in the Pamulavaka plates of Eastern Cālukya Vijayāditya VII (JAHRS, Vol. II, p. 287, text line 67).
3757: ni (IE 8-1; EI 33), abbreviation of nibaddha or nirīkṣita, i. e. registered or approved. (Select Inscriptions, pp. 238-39, 247-48), explained as an abbreviation of nija and as a sort of genitive suffix often with a word indicating relationship understood.
3758: nī (LP), used for the verb ānī. (LP), to make.
3759: nibaddha (IE 8-1; EI 29), explained as ‘registered’. (IA 13), used in respect of a copper-plate grant and trans-lated as ‘prepared’. (IA 15), interpreted as ‘assigned’.
3761: nibandha (EI 7), an endowment. (Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 49), a register. (SII 2), also spelt nivanda or nimanda in Tamil; the fixed requirements of a temple; cf. Nivandakkārar, temple servants who attend to the nibandha. (SII 3; SITI), expenses or arrangements; arrangement for the conduct of affairs in a temple.
3762: nibarava (CITD), Telugu; an unknown weight used in the case of salt and paddy (unhusked rice).
3764: nīcocca-māsa (CII 3), the anomalistic month, the period in which the moon comes from perigee or apogee to the same point again; its duration is 27 days, 33 ghaṭīs and 16. 65 palas, or 27 tithis 59 ghaṭīs and 33. 36 palas; see also kendra.
3765: nidāna (CITD), Telugu; same as Sanskrit nidhāna; a treasure; a hoard or fund; store, wealth or property.
3766: nidhāna (HRS), explained as ‘cess imposed upon agricultural land’; but ‘freshly assessed tax’; cf. nava-nidhāna. cf. sa-nidhi-nidhāna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 139, text line 20), in which it is the same as nikṣepa; also sa-vana-śvabhra-nidhāna; probably, a mine.
3767: nidhān-ālipaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 274, text line 61), probably the same as nidhi-nikṣepa or nidhy-upanidhi. But ālipaka, also read as āliyaka and often spelt as ālīpaka, may refer to the right on beehives and honey (see alīpaka).
3768: nidhi (IE 7-1-2), ‘nine’. Cf. nidhi-nikṣepa (IE 8-5; HRS; SITI); treasure trove; a treasure-hoard; hidden treasure under the ground; one of the eight kinds of enjoyments allowed to the donees of rent-free land. Cf. nidhāna. (CITD), a treasure; a repository; store; a place where anything is placed. Cf. nidhi-nikṣepa-jala-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣ-prakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 247; text lines 101-02), privilege mentioned along with aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmya-daṇdaśulka-yukta.
3769: nidhyāpti, cf. Prakrit nijhati (EI 2; CII 1), explanation, ex-hortation or argumentation; to cause understanding; cf. anu-nidhyāpti.
3770: nidhyāyana, cf. nijhati (CII 1); the act of explaining; argu-mentation [in favour of a particular view]; consolation. See nidhyāpti.
3771: nidrā-kalasa, a pūrṇa-ghaṭa kept near the head of the bed (Matsya Purāṇa, 265. 14; Harṣacarita, IV).
3772: Nigama-putra (LL), inhabitant of a nigama (township); a merchant; cf. Naigama.
3773: nigama-sabhā (EI 7, 8), a public hall or the assembly of the town Pañcāyat; the city council.
3775: Nihelapati (IE 8-3; HD), official designation of uncertain import; probably, the governor of a territorial unit; also spelt Nihilapati. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 124; CII, Vol. III, p. 289.
3776: Nihilapati (IE 8-3; CII 3; HD), an official title of uncertain import. See Nihelapati. Cf. CII, Vol. III, p. 289.
3777: niḥsāra, cf. nissāreṇa (LP), ‘in an excellent manner.’
3778: nikara (EI 12, 33), cf. yathādīyamāna-bhoga-bhāga-kara-nikara-ādikam; a small tax or cess; small amount of rent fixed for a gift land; practically the same as kara or tax (IHQ, Vol. XXXIV, p. 279). Cf. upakara, tṛṇodaka, mānya-kaṇikĕ, etc.
3779: nikāya (EI 7), a religious corporation. (EI 18; LL), a Buddhist school or community; a frater-nity of Buddhist monks. Cf. Kaulika-nikāya (LL), a guild of the Kaulikas or weavers. (CII 1), a class or group.
3780: Nikephoros (IE 8-2), Greek; royal title; ‘victorious’; trans-lated into Prakrit-Sanskrit as Jayadhara.
3781: nikṣepa, cf. nidhi-nikṣepa (IE 8-5; HRS), deposits and finds on the soil (probably including beehives, cf. alīpaka, nidhāna); deposits; same as upanidhi; one of the eight kinds of enjoyment of the property allowed to the donees of rent-free land; sometimes wrongly explained as a treasure-trove (SITI). See nidhi.
3782: nīla-ḍumphaka (IE 8-8), probably, one whose profession was to press indigo plants for getting blue dye; ḍumphaka may be Sanskrit dṛmphaka.
3783: nīla-kūṭī (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, an indigo manufactory.
3784: nilaya (EI 9), cf. grāma-nilaya-nāḍa-sarva-bādhā-parihāreṇa; probably a territorial unit like a Parganā; the inhabited area of a district.
3785: nimantraṇa (IA 20), explained as ‘an invitation which admits of no refusal’.
3787: nimn-onnata (IA 16), explained as ‘what is above and below’; but really, ‘low and high lands’; cf. khalla-unnata.
3788: nindana (LP), weeding out grass growing along with the crops; cf. Gujarātī nindavuṃ.
3790: nipāna, same as pāna, cf. grāma-nipāna-kūpaka (EI 4); ‘the drinking well of a village’; may also be the same as āpāna.
3791: nipratiṣṭhāpita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 248), same as pratiṣṭhāpita; established, installed.
3792: nīra-gṛha (EI 31), ‘a water-house’; same as Persian abdār-khāna.
3793: nīrājana (SII 1), the waving of a lamp before an idol; same as ārātrika.
3794: nirasta, nirasti, cf. sarvajāta-bhoga-nirastyā (IE 8-5), ‘with all kinds of the [king's] rights renunciated’.
3795: niravakara (EI 31), used in some Orissan inscriptions in the sense of ‘the nett total after deductions’.
3796: nirayaṇa (CII 3), destitute of precession of the equinoxes.
3797: Nirgrantha (CII 1), a follower of the Jain religion.
3798: Nirgranthanātha (BL), epithet of a Jain poet of the Digam-bara sect.
3799: nirīkṣita (IE 8-1), same as ḍṛṣṭa, ‘examined [and approv-ed]’. See ni.
3801: nīroga, the science of medicine (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 146).
3803: nīru-nela, nīr-nela (CITD), Telugu; low lying land irri-gated by water from a tank, canal, well, etc.; usually called ‘wet land’ and considered the most valuable. Cf. veli-volamu or veli-cenu, i. e. land on a comparatively higher level, which depends solely on rain and is called ‘dry land’.
3804: nirūpa (SITI), written order; communication from the king or other superiors.
3805: Nirūpa (ASLV), the carrier of a royal order.
3806: nirūpaṇa (LP), order for transfer of service; appointment.
3808: nirūpita-daṇḍa (IA 18), wrongly regarded as a doubtful technical expression; actually, ‘appointed as Daṇḍa (i.e. Daṇda-nāyaka)’. Cf. niyukta-Daṇda.
3809: nirvacanīya, cf. bhoga-sambandha-nirvacanīya (EI 12), ‘the relations [of the gift land] with the district [to which it belong-ed] should not be reckoned’.
3811: nirvāha, cf. vāśal-nirvāham (SITI), same as vāśal-kāriyam (kārya).
3813: nirvāha-sabhā (SITI), a managing or executive committee.
3814: nirvāṇa (CII 3), annihilation of human passion; a stage in the Buddhist practices, anterior to parinirvāṇa or complete annihilation of personal existence by absorption into the all-pervading spirit. (HA), same as mokṣa; liberation from all bondage includ-ing that of this earthly body; the death of the Jinas or monks who have obtained kevala-jñāna.
3815: nirvāṇa-caitya (BL), name of the Buddhist memorial built at Kasia (ancient Kuśīnagara) in the Deoria District, where the Buddha obtained mahāparinirvāṇa (death).
3817: nirvṛtti (ASLV), same as viṣaya or koṭṭam; an administrative division.
3818: Niryāmaka (LP), probably, an officer who allowed licensed articles to pass.
3821: niśadam, also called niśadi (SII 1), supposed to be the same as nityam.
3822: niśadhi (EI 28), also spelt nisidhi, niṣidhi, niṣedhikā, etc.; the tomb of Jain monks. Cf. niśīdikā, etc. (Sanskrit niṣadyā).
3824: niṣadyā, cf. Prakrit nisidiyā (LL), a dwelling. Cf. niśliṣṭaka.
3826: niṣedhikā (BL), memorial on the burial ground of Jain religious teachers; cf. nisidhi, etc.; also niśīdikā.
3827: niṣidhi, niśidhi, niśīdhi (IA 12), Jain; the tomb of Jain monks.
3828: niṣīdī (EI 20), a Jain tomb; cf. niṣīdhi, etc.
3829: niśīdikā, also spelt niśīdigai (SITI), the death of a Jain by fasting; the memorial set up for such a person.
3830: nisima (ML), Prakrit; supposed to be the same as stūpa; cf. nissīma.
3831: niṣka (IE 8-8; EI 15, 27, 30), name of a gold coin; name sometimes applied to śatamāna, śāna, ṭaṅka, gaṇḍa-māḍa, etc.; cf. gaṇḍa-niṣka, also called gaṇḍa-māḍa. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 41 ff. (IE 8-8), a gold coin equal to sixteen silver drammas. (EI 5), a coin equal to a half-pagoda. (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 139), a silver coin equal to one śata-māna.
3832: niṣkāvala (LP), a thing on which no one has any right; cf. Sanskrit kavala.
3833: niśliṣṭaka, Prakrit nisiḍhayā (CII 1), explained as ‘a rest-house’. But the correct reading is nisidiyā = Sanskrit niṣadyā (q. v.). See Nach. Akad. Wissen. Goetting., 1959, No. 4, pp. 47ff.
3834: niśrā-nikṣepa-haṭṭa (EI 11), probably, a place in the market for storing goods to be exported.
3835: nissīma (CII 2-1), explained as ‘a piece of land outside a monastery’. See nisima.
3836: niṣṭhāpita, ‘caused to be completed’ (Sel. Ins., p. 224). Cf. nipratiṣthāpita, niṣṭhita. (LP), finished.
3837: niṣṭhita (Select Inscriptions, p. 203), completed. Cf. anuṣ-ṭhita, niṣṭhāpita.
3839: nivanda (SITI), allocated duties of servants in temples; temple expenses; same as Sanskrit nibandha.
3840: nīva-pāta (LP), the falling of rain-water from the eaves; cf. Gujarātī nev or nevāṃ.
3841: nivartana (IE 8-6; EI 21, 26, 28; CII 4), an area of land, which was not the same in different ages and localities. See Ind. Ep., pp. 409-10; also Matsya Purāṇa, 283. 14-15, represent-ing a gocarman as (2/3) of a nivartana (210×210 sq. cubits). (CITD), same as maṟuturu, the identification of the two being established by bilingual Sanskrit-Telugu inscriptions.
3842: nivartanin (CII 4), name of a land measure, same as nivartana.
3843: nivedanaka (EI 13), cf. Vāmanasvāmi-pādānāṃ nivedanaka-nimittam, ‘in order to be presented at the feet of Vāmana-svāmin.’
3844: nivedya (EI 15), same as naivedya; the food offering to a god.
3847: niveśita (CII 1), written [on stone]. Cf. prāsādo = yaṃ niveśitaḥ (Select Inscriptions, p. 295, text line 19); erected.
3848: nīvī (EI 17), a permanent endowment; same as akṣaya-nīvī.
3849: nīvī-dharma (EI 15, 17; HRS), the custom regarding per-manent endowments; the condition that the donee should not destroy the principal but should only enjoy the income arising from it.
3853: niyat-āniyata (IE 8-5), regular and fixed taxes and those which were occasional.
3854: Niyāyattār (ASLV), Tamil; Sanskrit Nyāyastha; a judge. Cf. Nyāyattār.
3855: niyoga (EI 24; SITI), an appointment; authority; the officer bearing the same. Cf. Niyogin, etc.
3857: Niyogastha (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVII, p. 11, text line 13), ‘an officer’; same as Niyog-niyukta, etc.
3858: Niyogi (ASLV), a class of Brāhmaṇas in the Telugu-speaking land.
3859: Niyogika (IE 8-3; EI 8, 25, 32), same as Niyogin or Naiyogika, ‘an officer’.
3860: Niyogin (EI 5, 24, 30), same as Niyogika; ‘one having a niyoga’. Cf. Parameśvara-niyogin.
3861: Niyukta (IE 8-3; EI 12, 21, 24), official designation; same as Niyuktaka, Tanniyukta, etc.
3862: niyukta-daṇḍa (IA 18), wrongly regarded as a doubtful technical expression; actually, ‘appointed as Daṇḍa (i. e. Daṇḍa-nāyaka’). Cf. nirūpita-daṇḍa.
3863: Niyuktaka (HD), probably, a subordinate officer under the Āyuktaka; same as Niyukta. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 84.
3867: Nūrmaḍi (IE 8-2; SII 3), Kannaḍa, ‘hundred times’; word prefixed to the names of certain kings in order to distinguish them from their predecessors bearing the same name; e. g. Nūrmaḍi Taila, ‘one who is a hundredfold Taila’; cf. Savāi Jayasiṃha, ‘one and one-fourth of Jayasiṃha’. See Immaḍi and Mummuḍi.
3868: nyāya, cf. niyāyam (SII 2), an appointment or pledge. (SITI), body or association of persons having the same duties or interests. Cf. gardabha-cāṇḍāla-nyāyena (LP), ‘like a donkey or a Caṇḍāla’. Cf. khaṇḍa-badarīphala-nyāyena (LP), ‘like sugar and the badarī fruit’. Cf. śāka-phalaka-nyāyena (LP), ‘like vegetables and fruits’. Cf. vṛddhi-phala-bhoga-nyāya (LP), principle of enjoying the interest of a deposit; also cf. gṛhasya bhāḍakaṃ na hi; drammāṇāṃ vyājaṃ na hi; eṣa vṛddhi-phala-bhoga-nyāyaḥ.
3869: Nyāya-karaṇika (EI 12), one responsible for settling disputes regarding the gift land. (BL), official designation of the writer of complaints or the scribe of the law-court.
3870: Nyāyattār (SII 12; SITI), Sanskrit Nyāyastha; judges; members of the court of justice; a committee of judges. Cf. Niyāyattār.
3872: Oḍaya (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a king, ruler, master or leader.
3873: Odayantrika (CII 4), correctly Audayantrika; a manufacturer of hydraulic machines or, more probably, a person in charge of such a machine.
3874: Oḏiyā, spelt as Oriya in English; people, language and alphabet of Orissa.
3875: ogho (HA), same as rajo-haraṇa; usually made of twisted woollen threads tied to a wooden handle, used by Jain monks and nuns, for removing dust particles and insects and for protecting the latter.
3876: ohoru (IE 8-5), Oḏiyā; cf. daṇḍoāsi-ohoru, ‘tax for the maintenance of watchmen’.
3877: Oja (SII 11-1), same as Ojhā; designation derived from Sanskrit Upādhyāya; cf. Bengali Ojhā, Maithilī Jhā.
3878: okapiṇḍa (IA 18; CII 1), explained as ‘a fox’; probably, ‘household vermin’.
3880: om, the praṇava sometimes found at the commencement of inscriptions; often represented by a sign which should not be con-fused with the symbol standing for the auspicious word siddham.
3885: otaḏa, otaḏā, otaḏī (Chamba), dry land, unirrigable land; opposed to kohlī or āli.
3886: Pa (CITD), abbreviation of the Telugu name of a certain measure of grain.
3887: Pā (EI 32), contraction of the surname Pāṭhin.
3889: pabāsaṇa (HA), the seat (āsana) on which the figure of a Jina is placed.
3891: pada (EI 33), share; quarter of the standard land measure. (EI 4, 9; IA 17), a share. (EI 21), a land-measure; cf. paḍa (paṭa) in Sel. Ins. p. 408. Cf. sv-āṅgabhoga-pada (LP), ‘under the head of personal expenditure’. (LL; ML), foot-print.
3892: pāda (IE 8-6), same as Kannaḍa hāda; ‘one-fourth’; a measure equal to one-fourth of the standard land measure. Cf. poā (EI 19), literally, ‘one-fourth’; name of a land measure. Cf. sa-pādika (LP), ‘with one-fourth in addition’. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 248), foot-print, foot-mark.
3893: paḍā, pāḍā (IE 8-4), corrupt forms of pāṭaka, ‘part of a village’; often suffixed to the names of localities.
3894: Pāda-bhakta (IE 8-2), ‘devoted to the feet of’; cf. Pād-ānu-dhyāta and Pād-ānudhyāna-rata.
3896: paḍaga (SITI), Tamil; name of a measure of land; cf. pāḍaga.
3897: pāḍaga (IE 8-6), Tamil; same as Sanskrit pāṭaka; a land measure which was equal to 240 kul13is, and 6(1/4) of which made one veli.
3900: paḍaipaṟṟu (ASLV), a military station or cantonment.
3902: padakāra (IE 8-8), probably, a shoe-maker or a hawker (Hindī pāukār).
3904: pāda-kula (EI 12; IA 15), probably, ‘a tribe of attendants’, Pāda being the same as Pāḍamūla or Pādamūlika, ‘an attendant’.
3905: pada-lekhyaka (LP), the ledger in which items of income are written.
3906: paḍalikai (SITI), Sanskrit paṭalikā; name of a measure of quantity.
3907: Pādamūla (EI 12), an attendant. (EI 25), foot-prints. (EI 21), a sanctuary (p. 156; Sel. Ins., 2nd ed., p. 512). (SII 13), cf. pādamūlattār, temple servants.
3908: Pādamūlika (EI 4; LL), a servant. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 156), a temple attendant.
3909: Pād-ānudhyāna-rata (IE 8-2), ‘engaged in meditating on the feet of … ’; cf. Pād-ānudhyāta.
3910: Pād-ānudhyāta (IE 8-2; EI 2; CII 3), ‘meditating on the feet or favoured by the feet of … ’, a technical expression for the relations of a feudatory to his paramount sovereign, of a subordinate to a chief, of a successor to his predecessor, of a son to his parents, of a nephew to his uncle, of a grandson to his grandfather, and of a younger to his elder brother; used also in respect of gods. In rare cases, the word pāda is omitted. Cf Pāda-bhakta and Pād-ānudhyāna-rata.
3911: Pāda-padm-opajīvin (CII 3; IA 18), ‘subsisting [like a bee] on the lotuses that are the feet of … ’; a technical expression (often occurring in medieval South Indian inscriptions) for the relations of a feudatory or officer to his master; cf. Pāda-piṇḍ-opajīvin, Pād-opajīvin.
3913: Pāda-piṇḍ-opajīvin (CII 3, etc.), ‘subsisting on the food supplied by the feet of … ’; a technical expression to denote the relationship of officials or subordinates to their master; same as Pād-opajīvin and Pāda-padm-opajīvin.
3916: pāda-rakṣā, cf. Tamil pāda-raṭcai (SITI), shoes; sandals.
3917: Pādaśaiva (IA 12), designation of a conch-blower at the Rāmeśvaram temple.
3918: pāda-saṅghāṭa, a pair of feet (i. e. foot-prints). Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 248.
3919: padāti-jīvya (IE 8-5; EI 12, 29), also spelt padāti-jīva; tax for the maintenance of Pāiks; same as Oḏiyā pāikāli; cf. khaṇḍa-pāla or khaṇḍapālīya.
3921: pādava-kkāṇi (SITI), Tamil; land given as wage for temple service.
3922: padavāra (SITI), also called paduvāra; fee payable for exchanging landed property; transfer fee.
3923: pādāvarta (IE 8-6; EI 4, 21, 24; CII 3), a land measure, an area of 100 pādāvartas being 100 feet each way, i. e. 10,000 square feet; also spelt padāvarta.
3928: pādika, cf. Telugu-Kannaḍa pātika (CITD); one-fourth of anything; (1/64)th part of the coin termed pagoda (q.v.).
3929: pāḍikāval (ASLV), the right of policing, which was some-times leased to people.
3930: Paḏirā, cf. Oḏiyā Sāmanta-paḏirā (EI 32); Sanskrit Prati-rāja; title of a fendatory or governor; cf. Pratirājya = Pratirāja.
3931: Pādiśāh (IA 20), Persian; spelt Pādisāha, Pātisāha, etc., in Indian records; a [Muhammadan] emperor.
3933: padma-bandha (CITD), a kind of artificial composition of verses, in which the syllables are arranged in the form of a lotus. Cf. padma-vṛtta.
3934: padma-nidhi (IE 8-8), a sacred deposit made in the temple treasury. Cf. the coin called padmanidhi-malla-māḍa which was probably issued by the temples.
3936: padm-āsana (IA 18), used to indicate ‘the sun’; cf. padma-sadman.
3937: padma-sadman (IA 18), used to indicate ‘the sun’; cf. padm-āsana.
3938: padma-vṛtta (CITD), probably, the same as padma-bandha.
3939: Pādonalakṣa (IE 8-4), name of a territory with reference to the number of villages in it; cf. Sapādalakṣa, Caurāśī.
3940: Pād-opajīvin (IA 18), same as Pāda-padm-opajīvin and Pāda-piṇḍ-opajīvin.
3941: padra (IE 8-4; EI 24; CII 4), ‘a village’; often suffixed to the names of villages; see padraka. Cf. pādrīyaka (LP), those living in the confines of a village. (IE 8-5), probably, ‘inhabited area’; may also be ‘com-mon land’ (cf. padraka); cf. sa-padr-āraṇyaka as an epithet of a gift village.
3942: padraka (IE 8-4; CII 3; etc.); ‘a village’; generally used as the termination of the name of a village; interpreted as ‘com-mon-land’ in expressions like Bhumbhusa-padraka and Śivaka-padraka. Wilson's Glossary explains pādar (i. e. padra) as ‘common-land, land adjacent to a village left uncultivated’.
3943: paduka (Chamba, etc.), sacred foot-prints; from Sanskrit pādukā.
3944: pāduka (EI 22; LL; HA), foot-prints. See pādukā, etc.
3946: pāduka-paṭṭa, pādukā-paṭṭa (LL), cf. Prakrit paduka-paṭa (EI 20), a foot-print slab.
3947: pādukā-paṭṭī, cf. Prakrit pājugā-paṭī (EI 24), a slab with foot-marks.
3949: pāga (bhāga ?), cf. Kannaḍa hāga (EI 9), name of a coin. (IA 11), same as Kannaḍa hāga; one-fourth [of the revenue collected]; may be Sanskrit bhāga.
3951: pagod, pagoda (EI 8-8), also called ‘star pagoda’; English name of the gold coin called hūn (hon) or varāha; probably so called because the coins often bore the representation of a temple called pagod or pagoda by the early European travellers. The word seems to have been derived from Sanskrit bhagavat or bhagavatī meaning the deities worshipped in the temples and also often figuring on the coins. Cf. ‘ṭaṅkakas stamped with the figure of the Bhagavat’ (Bhandarkar's List, No. 2033). Cf. Cīna-pagoda (SII 12), ‘the Chinese temple’; name of a Buddhist shrine at Nāgapaṭṭanam.
3952: pāhuḍa, Sanskrit prābhṛta; cf. pāhuḍa-pramāṇena (LP), ‘in proportion to the gift given by him’.
3953: Pāik (IE 7-3; EI 33), Sanskrit Padātika; same as Bhaṭa or Bhaṭa-manuṣya; a footman; cf. Piāda.
3954: pāikā (IE 8-5; EI 29), Oḏiyā; also called pāikāli; same as padāti-jīvya.
3956: paikamu (EI 6), Telugu; name of a coin.
3957: pāilā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 42), a measure of capacity.
3958: Paiṇḍapātika (LL), a Buddhist mendicant; cf. piṇḍapāta.
3959: paisā, used in Hindi, Bengali, etc., for pāvīsā or pāda-viṃśaka-(vimśopaka); ‘a copper coin’; ‘money’; also a land measure.
3960: Paiṭakin (LL), Buddhist; a teacher of the piṭakas.
3962: pākhī (IE 8-6), Bengali; a land measure in parts of Bengal, which is smaller than the bīghā.
3963: pakhila (IA 17), apparently a mistake for upakhila (q. v.); cf. sa-khilaṃ pakhilam wrongly read or written for sa-khil-opakhilam; semi-waste land.
3965: pakṣa-pāta, ‘one who works on behalf of someone else’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 250).
3966: pakva, cf. pakva-pura, ‘a brick-built house’, same as Bengali pākā-bāḏi. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 184.
3967: pala (EI 9, 21, 30; CII 3), name of a weight. (IA 26), a weight equal to 320 ratīs; sometimes spelt phala in Pāli. (CITD), in Telugu-Kannaḍa records, a weight equal to that of 10 pagodas; four karṣas or (1/100) of a tula; the 8th part of a ser, or 3 tolas or rupees; 4 tolas or 320 guñjās. (CII 3), the sixtieth division of a ghaṭī; equal to twenty-four English seconds.
3968: pālā (LP), sheds. (LP), a foot-soldier; cf. Gujarātī pāḻo.
3969: pālaka (EI 3), cf. grāmasya pālakaḥ, ‘the headman of a village’. (Select Inscriptions, p. 236), escort.
3970: pala-kāya (SITI), sundry spices as pepper, etc., used in preparing curry.
3971: paḻampuḻḻi-māḍai (SITI), Tamil; name of an ancient coin; see māḍai.
3973: pālāpana (LP), cf. Gujarātī paḻāvavuṃ, ‘to compel to obey’.
3974: palārdha, weight equal to half of a pala (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
3977: pāli-dhvaja (EI 30, 32; CII 4), name of the banner of cer-tain kings or dynasties, which was their royal insignia; same as pāli-ketana; sometimes explained as ‘flags in rows’ (SII 1).
3978: palikā, pālikā (EI 1, 11), same as pālī; a measure of capa-city; measure of capacity for liquids (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 309).
3979: pāli-ketana (EI 29; IA 7), name of the banner of certain kings or dynasties, which was their royal insignia; also called pāli-dhvaja, explained as ‘flags in rows’ (SII 1).
3981: pallaḍikā (IA 11, 18), cf. gṛhāṇāṃ pallaḍikā-sametā, an epithet of the gift land; probably, a cluster; sometimes referred to as property belonging to a deity (Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, pp. 180 ff., Inscriptions Nos. 5-11). Cf. ‘the entire pallaḍikā belonging to the god Vakuleśvaradeva and consisting of houses facing different directions’ and ‘another [pallaḍikā] which lay close to a two-storied temple’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 144-45).
3983: pallī (IE 8-4; EI 23), ‘a hamlet’; ‘a village or its part’; often suffixed to the names of localities.
