3984: paḻḻi (SII 1, 2; SITI), Tamil; often, a Jain temple; the shrine of non-Hindu communities like the Jains, Buddhists, Christians, Muhammadans, etc.; cf. paḻḻi-ccandam, temple land; paḻḻi-grāma, a village belonging to a temple.
3985: pallī-cchanda, cf. paḻḻi-ccanda (EI 23, 24), ‘temple land’; ‘land granted to a Jain or Buddhist temple’; mentioned along with devadāna and brahmadeya; see paḻḻi.
3989: Paṃ (IE 8-1; PJS), abbreviation of Paṇḍita. (PJS), abbreviation of Paṃnyāsa.
3990: paṇa (IE 8-8; EI 23, 24, 30; SII 11-1), same as Tamil paṇam, spelt in English as fanam; cf. Yādavarāyan-paṇam (SITI), name of a coin issued by the Yādavarāyas; name of a coin 80 ratis in weight; same as the copper kārsāpaṇa; equal to 80 cowrie-shells according to the Līlāvatī; copper coin (1/16) of a silver kārṣāpaṇa according to the Kṛtyakalpataru (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K.V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, p. 125), and (1/48) of a suvarṇa (JNSI, Vol. II, p. 7); also used to indicate ‘money’. In Tamil, paṇam means a particular coin (usually, a small gold coin), or money in general, or taxes; cf. paṇa-vargam (SITI), a class of taxes payable in cash, same as kāśāya-vargam; also paṇa-vāśi, ‘discount payable for the exchange of coins; amount pay-able to make up the wear in the coin’. Cf. vil-paṇam (SITI), sale-tax; also understood as a tax on bows or archery; vāśal-paṇam (SITI), door-tax or periodical payment due to the palace. (ASLV), a sect or caste, eighteen in number theoretically. (EI 19), a land measure.
3991: pāṇaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309), small quantity of a liquid; name of a measure.
3992: paṇa-purāṇa (IE 8-8), a purāṇa [of silver] counted in paṇas [of copper]. Cf. kapardaka-purāṇa.
3994: Pāṇavika, one who plays on the paṇava (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 241).
3995: pañca (EI 22, 23), abbreviation of pañcakula; same as Mahājana; a Pañcāyat Board.
3997: pañcadhāra (CITD), the five paces of a horse called dhorita, valgita, pluta, uttejita and utterita.
3998: Pañc-ādhikaraṇ-oparika (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 29; BL), official designation; cf. Pañca-karaṇ-oparika and Pañca-karaṇ-ādhikṛta; the head of five departments; sometimes also called Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra, Mahāpīlupati, Pāṭy-uparika and Purapāl-oparika, additionally. See Sapt-āmātya.
3999: pañca-dravya (SITI), five articles used in bathing an idol.
4000: pañca-gavya (SITI), same as Tamil ān-āñju; the five pro-ducts of the cow, viz., milk, butter, curds, urine and dung.
4002: pāñcaka (CII 3), a committee. See pañca-maṇḍalī and pañcakula.
4004: Pañcakalpin (EI 9), same as Pañcolī; title and family name.
4005: Pañcakaraṇ-ādhikṛta (EI 30), head of five departments; cf. Pañcakaraṇ-oparika, etc. See Saptā-mātya.
4006: Pañcakaraṇ-oparika (EI 29), same as Pañcādhikaraṇ-oparika, etc.; head of five departments. See Sapt-āmātya.
4007: pañca-karmāra, also called pañca-kammāḻar (SITI), the five castes of artisans, viz., goldsmith, blacksmith, brassmith, car-penter and stone-mason.
4009: pañcakula (IE 8-3; EI 5, 25; CII 4; LP; HRS), the Pañ-cāyat Board; an assembly of administrators and arbitrators, usually consisting of five members; a board of administration charged with control of the customs house, with the deposit of property of persons dying without heirs into the royal treasury, etc.; also called pañcapa (EI 4); members of such a board; ac-cording to some, an officer over a certain number of villages (HD). Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 242. Cf. Pañcavīra, Pāñca-kulika, añjaṣṭa-sabhā, etc.
4010: Pāñcakulika (CII 4), the head or a member of a pañcakula or Pañcāyat board; cf. Caturjātakīya.
4011: Pañcāla (EI 3; ASLV), an artisan; members of the artisan classes also called Pāñcāḻaṃvāru.
4012: Pañca-laguḍika (BL), title of a warrior who could pro-bably fight with five clubs at a time.
4014: Pañcāḻattār (ASLV), an organisation of the artisans.
4015: Pañcālī (IA 10), same as Pañcālikā; a Pañcāyat board or its members.
4017: Pañcālikā (IA 9), same as Pañcālī; a Pañcāyat board or its members.
4018: pañca-mahāpātaka (EI 26; CII 3; CITD), the five great sins or heinous crimes, viz., killing a Brāhmaṇa, drinking intoxi-cating liquors, stealing gold, committing adultery with the wife of a guru and associating with any one guilty of these crimes. Cf. daś-āparādha, pañc-ānantarya.
4019: pañca-mahāśabda (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; SITI; CITD; BL), refers to the privilege of enjoying the sounds of five musical instruments, or five titles beginning with mahat; five official designations or musical instruments mentioned in con-nection with feudatories; five official designations beginning with the word mahā in the North and five kinds of musical instruments in the South; in South India, it was the same as pañca-mahānināda, i. e. the sounds of the five great musical ins-truments called the pañca-mahāvādya enumerated by some as a horn, a tabor, a conch-shell, a kettle-drum and a gong; in some parts of North India, the expression indicated five official designations with the prefix mahā. (CII 3), sounds of five musical instruments, the use of which was allowed to persons of high rank and authority; usually a title of feudatories; cf. tat-pradatta-pañcamahāśabda (IE 8-2), used in respect of feudatory rulers who received the right of enjoying the pañca-mahāśabda from their overlords; rarely used in the South by independent monarchs. Cf. pañca-vādya (EI 4) and pañca-mahāvādya. See Samadhigata-pañcamahāśabda, etc. Cf. pañca-māśattam (SITI), the five musical instruments, to the use of which a nobleman was entitled; sometimes enu-merated as ceṇḍai, timilai, śegaṇḍi, cymbals and kāhaḻam or as tattaḻi, maddaḻi, karaḻikai, cymbals and kāhaḻam. (SII 11-1), cf. grant of 40 mattars of land to a piper for arranging to play the five musical instruments.
4020: pañca-mahāvādya (EI 12), enumerated as the horn, conch-shell, tambourine, trumpet and gong. See pañca-mahāśabda.
4021: pañca-mahāyajña (EI 29; CII 3, 4), ‘the five great sacri-fices’; the five daily duties of a Brāhmaṇa enumerated as bali, caru, vaiśvadeva, agnihotra and atithi.
4022: Pañcama-lokapāla (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 93), epithet of certain kings; cf. Lokapāla.
4023: pañca-maṇḍalī (CII 3, 4; HD), an assembly of five persons; equivalent to the modern Pañcāit, Pañcāyat or Pañc, i. e., a village jury. See pāñcaka.
4024: pañca-mātṛkā, cf. Prakrit paṃca-mātuka (EI 20), five princi-pal texts of the Buddhists, also called pañca-nikāya, viz., the Dīgha-nikāya, Majjhima-nikāya, Aṅguttara-nikāya, Khuddaka-nikāya and Saṃyutta-nikāya.
4025: pañca-mauṣṭika-loca (HA), plucking out five handfuls of hair by a would-be Jina at the time of dīkṣā.
4026: pañcamī-bali (EI 11), a particular tithi of the year.
4027: pañc-āmṛta (SITI), mixture of five objects for anointing idols, viz. banana, honey, sugar, ghee and grape.
4028: pañca-mukha-nagara (LP), explained as ‘a city in which there are five leading men’; cf. pañca-mukha-nagara-viditam (LP), ‘having informed the five leading men of the city’; explained as ‘the five-fold people of the town’ (Ind. Ant., Vol. XLI, p. 20); really ‘the citizens headed by the members of the Pañcāyat’.
4029: pañca-nagara, a mercantile guild (cf. nagara, also pañca); see A.R. Ep., 1956-57, No. B 190.
4030: Pañcanaikāyika (LL), Buddhist; a teacher of the five nikāyas (e. g. Dīgha-nikāya, Majjhima-nikāya, Khuddaka-nikāya, Saṃyutta-nikaya and Aṅguttara-nikāya).
4031: pañc-ānantarya (CII 3), the five sins that entail immediate retribution. See pañca-mahāpātaka, daś-āparādha, pañc-āparādha.
4032: pañcāṅga (CII 3), the Hindu almanac; in the Deccan and in some other parts, the pañcāṅgas are now prepared from the Grahalāghava and the Tithicintāmaṇi of Gaṇeśa-daivajña. The right of reading the pañcāṅga was sometimes granted by the rulers to individuals (ASLV).
4033: pañcāṅga-namaskāra (HA), bowing down in such a way that five limbs of the body (viz., two hands, two knees and the head) touch the ground. Cf. aṣṭ-āṅga-namaskāra.
4034: pañcāṅga-prasāda, cf. pañcāṅga-pasāya (Ind. Ant., Vol. IX, p. 95), translated as ‘five manners of gifts’; cf. pañcāṅga-pasāya chatra sukhāsana bbala gaddi aṅka-daṇḍa-khaṇḍane, translated as ‘gave [to that Māro-śĕṭṭi] five manners of gifts--an umbrella, a palanquin, an escort, a throne and with the faults, fines and divisions (really ‘with fines and the grain share’).’
4036: pañc-āparādha (HRS), known from the Gupta and other records; donee's privilege relating to the enjoyment of fines payable by persons committing five offences. Cf. daś-āparādha, pañc-ānantarya, pañca-mahāpātaka.
4037: pañcaparameṣṭhi-pada (EI 2), also called °paṭṭa; a slab for worship containing the oṅkāra.
4038: Pañcapāṭhin (EI 32), epithet or family name of Brāhmaṇas.
4039: pañca-pātra (SITI), literally, ‘a vessel made of five [metals]’; offerings of food made to a deity along with cooked rice; probably the same as pañca-bhakṣya.
4040: Pañcārtha (CII 4), the Pāśupata sect of the Śaivas.
4041: Pañcārthika, Pāñcārthika (CII 4; IA 18), same as Pañcārtha, the Pāśupata sect of the Śaivas; a follower of the Pāśupata sect.
4042: pañca-ratna (EI 19), a group of five stanzas.
4043: pañca-śabda (CII 4; BL), five [musical] sounds or five official designations [beginning with the word mahā]; same as pañca-mahāśabda (q. v.).
4046: Pañcastūpanikāyika (BL), epithet of a Jain religious teacher. See Pañcanaikāyika.
4048: pañca-vāra (EI 23), a tax; cf. pañcavāri, pañcupīli, etc.; also pañca-vāram (SITI), one-fifth of the produce due to the government as land-revenue. (SITI), five branches in the administration of big villages, each looked after by a committee called pañcavāra-vāriyam.
4050: pañca-vīra (EI 24), also called pañcavīra-goṣṭhī; an adminis-trative board of five members; cf. pañcakula. Also 5 deified heroes of the Vṛṣṇi clan.
4051: pañcāyat (EI 26), a board of administration usually con-sisting of five members; cf. pañcakula, pañcavīra, pañcāyati, etc.
4052: pañcāyati (IE 8-3), an administrative board consisting of five members; same as pañcāyat, pañcakula, etc.
4053: pañc-āyatana (EI 28; CII 4), a type of temple ‘consisting of five rooms’; a five-shrine temple.
4054: Pañcika (EI 1), a member of the pañcakula or Pañcāyat board.
4055: pañcīyaka-dramma (EI 1; CII 4), name of a coin. It is uncertain whether it was so called owing to its issue by some Pañcāyat board or because it was equal to five copper coins.
4056: pañcolī (HD), same as pañcakula. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 89.
4058: Pāṇḍā (EI 32), a temple superintendent; same as Vārika.
4061: Paṇḍita (HD), same as Dharmatattvavit according to Śukra, II. 85; head of the ecclesiastical department (Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 115). (CII 4), epithet of Brāhmaṇas. (IE 8-3), the court Pandit, mentioned as Pātra.
4064: paṅga, pāṅga (IE 8-5; EI 30, 33), Telugu-Kannaḍa; one-fourth of the produce sometimes collected from rent-free hold-ings in the possession of gods and Brāhmaṇas; a kind of tax; sometimes used to indicate ‘taxes in general’; cf. paṅga-śulka, paṅga-tappu, paṅga-tappu-śulka, paṅga-parihṛta, paṅga-parihṛta-parihāra, sarva-paṅga-parihṛta, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, pp. 54 ff.
4065: paṅga-tappu (IE 8-5), probably, interest or fine on arrears of paṅga.
4066: paṅg-otkoṭa (EI 33), see paṅga and utkoṭa, names of levies.
4069: Pāṇigrāhin (EI 26), Oḏiyā; Sanskrit Pānīya-grāhin, ‘one who receives water’; the principal donee who received the water on behalf of all the other donees of a gift village; stereotyped as a family name in Orissa.
4071: pānīya-chāyā-maṇḍapa (EI 28), probably, a shaded hall cooled by water.
4072: Pānīyāgārika (IE 8-3), superintendent of the water-chamber. See Pānīyagṛhika.
4073: Pānīya-grāhin (EI 31), ‘one who receives ceremonial water as the donee of a gift’; recipient of a grant. See Pāṇigrāhin.
4074: Pānīyagṛhika (LL), superintendent of a water-house. Cf. Pānīyāgārika.
4076: Pañjābī, name of the language of the Pañjāb.
4079: pannasa, also spelt pannāsa, pannāsu (IE 8-6; EI 5, 12; Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 336, note 3), Kannaḍa; probably derived from Sanskrit pañchāśat in the sense of a tenure in which the donee enjoyed fifty per cent of the revenue of the donated land. Cf. pannavīsa. (EI 20), explained as ‘a gift’.
4080: pannāsa (EI 30; IA 11), Kannaḍa; same as pannasa (q. v.).
4082: pannavīsa (A. R. Ep., 1958-59, No. B. 17), Kannaḍa; Sans-krit pañcaviṃśati; probably a tenure in which the donee enjoyed twentyfive per cent of the revenue of the donated land. Cf. pannāsa, etc.
4083: pannāya (IE 8-5; EI 27), Kannaḍa, name of a tax; cf. pannāsa.
4086: paṇya-saṃsthā (HRS), various dues collected for the king by the superintendent of the market and the superintendent of merchandise, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 76.
4088: Para, abbreviation of a modified form of Purohita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 143).
4090: pāra, cf. a-pār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra (IE 8-5); probably, [free] ferrying of rivers [by the royal officers], which the villagers were obliged to provide.
4092: paradatti (SII 2), Tamil; an assembly; cf. Tamil paraḍai= Sanskrit pariṣad.
4093: Para-deśin (SITI; CITD), an outsider; an emigrant; used along with Sva-deśin (i. e. native), while mentioning two classes of merchants or their respective guilds.
4094: paraganā (Chamba, etc.), parganā; a territorial division; subdivision of a district, same as pratijāgaraṇaka of the Paramāra charters.
4095: Parakesari-kāl (EI 30), Tamil; name of a land measure.
4096: Parakesari-kkal (EI 30), Tamil; name of a weight.
4097: Parakesari-nāḻi (EI 30), Tamil; name of a land measure.
4098: Parakesari-ul13akku (EI 30), Tamil; name of a land measure.
4099: parākhya (CII 3), a correction in time, to be applied to the mean tithi.
4100: parakoṇā (EI 31), probably, the same as parganā.
4103: Parama-bhāgavata (IE 8-2; EI 29, 30; CII 3), ‘highly de-voted to the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu)’, epithet of the followers of the Bhāgavata form of Vaiṣṇavism; cf. Paramavaiṣṇava (highly devoted to Viṣṇu), etc. See Atyanta-bhagavad-bhaktā.
4104: Parama-bhagavatī-bhakta (IE 8-2), ‘a devout worshipper of the goddess Bhagavatī (Śiva's consort)’.
4105: Paramabhaṭṭāraka (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4), one of the technical titles of paramount sovereignty, closely connected with Mahārājādhirāja and Parameśvara; sometimes applied to a priest (generally of the Śaiva order); cf. Paramabhaṭṭārak-ety-ādi-rājāvalī (IA 19); also Paramabhaṭṭārak-etyādi-rājāvalī-tray-opeta (IE 8-2), ‘endowed with the three royal titles beginning with Paramabhaṭṭāraka.’
4106: Paramabhaṭṭārikā (IE 8-2; EI 6, 7; CII 3), a title of the wives of paramount sovereigns and of ruling queens.
4107: Parama-brahmaṇya (IE 8-2; EI 29), probably not ‘highly devoted to the god Brahman’, but ‘highly devoted to the Brāh-maṇas’; epithet of certain Brāhmanical rulers. See Atibrahmaṇya.
4108: Parama-daivata (IE 8-2; EI 28, 30; BL), ‘highly devoted to the god (i. e. Viṣṇu)’; epithet of Vaiṣṇava rulers; epithet of a devotee of the Brahmanical gods. Cf. Parama-de(dai)vat-ādhidaivata, Parama-guru-de(dai)vat-ādhidaivata-viśeṣa (EI 28), epithets of pious rulers.
4109: Parama-daivat-ādhidaivata (EI 23), same as Parama-de(dai)-vatādhidaivata (q. v.); epithet of pious kings.
4110: Parama-de(dai)vat-ādhidaivata (IE 8-2; EI 23), ‘one who is a great devotee of the various gods and of the supreme god’; see Paramadaivata.
4111: Paramadevī (IE 8-2; CII 3), designation of the chief queen; cf. Devī, Mahādevī, etc.
4113: Param-āditya-bhakta (IE 8-2; CII 3), ‘a devout worshipper of the Sun-god’; cf. Parama-saura.
4114: Parama-guru (EI 31, 33), ‘the supreme teacher [of the subjects]’; royal title.
4115: Parama-guru-de(dai)vat-ādhidaivata-viśeṣa (IE 8-2), ‘one who is a great teacher to his subjects and is devoted to the various gods and of the supreme deity’; see Parama-daivata and Paramade(dai)vat-ādhidaivata.
4116: Paramahaṃsa (EI 5; BL), an ascetic; epithet of an ascetic. See Haṃsa.
4117: Parama-māheśvara (IE 8-2; EI 29, 30; CII 3, 4), a devout worshipper of Maheśvara (Śiva)’; epithet of Śaiva rulers; see Māheśvara.
4118: Parama-nārasiṃha (IE 8-2; EI 26), ‘highly devoted to the man-lion incarnation of Viṣṇu’; epithet of a devotee of the man-lion form of Viṣṇu.
4119: Parama-pāśupat-ācārya (BL), epithet of a Śaiva religious teacher.
4121: Paramarājādhirāja, royal title. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 219; cf. Paramarāja.
4122: Parama-saugata (IE 8-2; EI 29; CII 3; BL), ‘a devout worshipper of the Sugata (Buddha)’; cf. Parama-tāthāgata.
4123: Parama-saura (IE 8-2), ‘a devout worshipper of the Sun-god’; cf. Param-āditya-bhakta.
4124: Parama-svāmin (EI 28; SII 3), epithet of deities. (EI 3), title of an imperial ruler; an overlord.
4125: Parama-lāthāgata (IE 8-2; EI 29; BL), ‘a devout worshipper of the Tathāgata (Buddha)’; usually spelt Parama-tathāgata; cf. Parama-saugata.
4126: Parama-vaiṣṇava (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4), ‘highly devoted to Viṣṇu’; epithet of Vaiṣṇava rulers; cf. Parama-bhāgavata, etc.
4127: Parama-viśvāsin (IE 8-3), probably, a private secretary; same as Rahasy-ādhikṛta, etc.; sometimes called Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, etc., additionally. See Vaiśvāsika.
4128: parameṣṭhi-gadyāṇa (SII, Vol. IX, Part i, No. 68), cf. gadyāṇa.
4129: Parameśvara (IE 8-2; EI 29, 30; CII 3, 4), an imperial title; one of the technical titles of paramount sovereignty closely connected with Māhārājādhirāja and Paramabhaṭṭāraka.
4130: parameśvara-hasta (SII 2), the royal cubit; cubit measured according to the length of the king's forearm. Cf. śrīpāda-kol.
4131: Parameśvara-mahākoṣṭhakārin (EI 27), officer in charge of the royal treasury or store-house.
4132: Parameśvara-niyogin (A.R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 9), a special officer attached to the king. Cf. Niyogin.
4134: Parameśvarī (EI 6), title of a queen, especially a ruling queen.
4135: Param-opāsaka (BL; LL), epithet of a male member of the Buddhist laity; cf. upāsaka.
4136: Param-opāsikā (EI 22, 32; LL; BL), epithet of a female member of the Buddhist laity; cf. upāsikā.
4137: pārampara (EI 15), same as paramparā-balīvarda-grahaṇa; refers to the obligation of the villagers to supply bullocks in suc-cession for the cart of a royal agent on tour in their villages.
4138: paramparā, cf. a-paramparā-balīvarda (IE 8-5); ‘succession’; refers to the obligation of the villagers to supply bullocks for the cart of the touring officers visiting different villages in suc-cession.
4140: Pārasīka (EI 12), originally, a Persian; but used to indi-cate any foreigner; a Dutch in the present case.
4141: Pārasi, Pārasī, Pārasika (EI 5; SII 1), a Persian.
4142: Pāraśiva (SITI), probably Pāraśava; explained as ‘one who wields a weapon; a soldier’.
4144: parata (Chamba), return, exchange, substitute, compen-sation; derived from Sanskrit parivarta; same as badalā.
4145: pāratrika (CII 1), ‘benefit in the other world’; merit.
4146: para-samaya (EI 24), explained as a particular Jain doctrine; doctrines other than one's own.
4147: parganā (EI 9, 32), a group of villages; same as pratijā-garaṇaka (q. v.).
4148: Pāri (EI 31; LP; PJS), abbreviation of Gujarāti Pārikha, Pārekha (Sanskrit Pārīkṣaka), originally meaning ‘an examiner of coins’; a surname among the Baniās of Gujarat.
4150: paribodha (CII 1), obstacle, fetters; being in fetters.
4152: Paricāraka (EI 31), a servant; sometimes mentioned in the list of officials.
4153: paricchanda (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 16), a vessel.
4154: pariccheda (CII 3), a territorial term meaning a group of villages.
4155: Parichā (IE 8-3; EI 31), Oḏiyā; same as Sanskrit Parīkṣaka.
4156: paridarśanā (IE 8-5; EI 29), a supervision tax probably related to division of property; may also be the same as Persian nazrāna.
4157: parigha (HRS), ‘door-bolt’; one of the seven sources of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra.
4159: parigṛhīta (IE 8-2; EI 31), ‘accepted’, sometimes used in place of anudhyāta (‘meditating’ or ‘favoured’) in passages like tatpāda-parighṛhīta; cf. bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta, bhaṭṭāraka-Mahāsena-parigṛhīta, etc.; refers to selection or acceptance of a succession or appointment or receipt in one's favour. Cf. catuḥśāla-parigṛhītaṃ śaila-maṇḍapam and Samyaksam-buddhasya dhātu-parigṛhītasya (Select Inscriptions, p. 228).
4160: parihāra (IE 8-5; EI 6; SITI), same as maryādā-parihāra; exemptions from taxes and obligations granted to the donees of rent-free land; privileges of the donee of rent-free holdings; for many such privileges, see Appendix I. Cf. certain privileges in respect of a number of taxes and obligations enumerated in Tamil records as follows: vaṭṭi-nāḻi (payment of one nāḻi per vaṭṭi), pudā-nāḻi (or pidā°, cess on each door or tax for the main-tenance of sluices), maṇṟupādu (fine imposed by a court of law), ūrāṭci (tax for running the village administration), taragu (tax on brokers), kūlam (tax on grains), īl13am-puṭi (tax on toddy-drawers), nāḍu-kāval (tax for the policing of a district), ūḍupokku (meaning uncertain), uppu-kocceygai (tax for the manufacture of salt), nall-ā (tax for maintaining specimen cows), nallerudu (tax for maintaining specimen buffaloes), nerv-āypuvum (meaning un-certain) and others. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 124. (IA 17), a ring.
4161: pārihārika (HRS), land exempted from revenue, as sug-gested by the Arthaśāstra; privileges enjoyed by the donee of a rent-free holding. Cf. sarva-jāta-pārihārika; same as parihāra or the parihāras collectively. See Select Inscriptions, pp. 192, 194.
4162: pārihīnika (HRS), damage-fee which was a branch of accidental revenue, according to the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 28.
4163: parikara (IE 8-5; CII 4), same as uparikara, occasional or minor taxes; cf. sa-parikara (EI 23) which is the same as s-opari-kara. (SITI), requisites of a village. (HA), accessory decoration round the figure of a Jina, the motifs being taken from the Jain conception of the eight chief objects attendant upon a Jina (aṣṭa-mahāprātihāryāṇi, viz. the wheel of law, the caitya-tree, the lion-seat, the aureole behind the head, two attendant flywhisk-bearers, drum-beaters and pipe-players, and garland-bearers).
4165: Pārikh (EI 31), Gujaratī; Sanskrit Pārīkṣa; an examiner of coins; a family name amongst the Baniās. See Rūpa-darśaka.
4166: pārikh-āya (IA 19), a levy; cf. Pārikh, pārīkṣika.
4169: Parīkṣā (IE 8-3; EI 28, 31), same as Sanskrit Parīkṣaka; Sans-kritised from Oḏiyā Parichā; superintendent of a department or a governor; cf. Dvāra-parīkṣā.
4170: parīkṣā (IA 10), same as divya, an ordeal. (CII 1), self-examination.
4172: pārīkṣika (HRS), testing-charge for private minting of coins, according to the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 43. Cf. pārikhāya.
4175: parinirvāṇa (EI 8), the death of the Buddha.
4176: paripanth, cf. paripanthayati (IE 8-2), same as vyavaharati; cf. samasta-mudrā-vyāpārān paripanthayati.
4177: paripanthanā, ‘creation of obstacles’; same as vidhāraṇā (EI). See vādhā or bādhā.
4182: pariṣad (LL), four classes of the Buddhist order. (EI 32), used in the sense of pāriṣada, ‘a councillor’. Cf. Tamil paraḍai, etc. (SII 3), an assembly. (CII 1), cf. Prakrit parisā (EI 8), a council; the council [of ministers]; cf. mantri-pariṣad, ‘council of ministers.’
4184: pariṣadā (HD), same as sabhā; an assembly or audience.
4187: parisūtra (Hyderabad Archaeological Series, No. 18, p. 34), explained as ‘an establishment.’
4188: parityāga (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 10, text line 2), do-nation; cf. deyadharma-parityāga.
4189: Parivāra (SII 3), a servant. Cf. horaka-parivāra (ML), explained as ‘the following of horakas.’
4190: parivār-ālaya (SII 3), surrounding verandah of a temple.
4191: parivastra, cf. Tamil parivaṭṭam, pariśaṭṭam, pariyaṭṭam (SITI), literally, garment; honour done to a nobleman in a temple by tying a piece of cloth (generally, silk cloth) round his head.
4193: parṇ-ākara, cf. sa-parṇ-ākara (IE 8-5), ‘together with the fields producing leaves (i. e. betel-leaves).’
4194: parṇa-śaśan (CII 1), an animal; probably, a rabbit living on leaves.
4195: parokṣam (IA 18), ‘in the absence of’; ‘behind the back of’.
4196: paṟṟu (IE 8-4), Tamil; a small territorial unit.
4198: pārṣada, cf. Prakrit pāṣaṃḍa (CII 1), a religious community; one belonging to a parṣad or religious group.
4199: pārśva (HRS), extra charge upon land over and above the king's grain-share, which was a branch of ‘accidental re-venue’ according to the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 28, 38. (IE 8-4), explained by some as a small territorial unit; but may be ‘side’; cf. prāveśya.
4200: Pārśvika (EI 9; CII 4), an aide-de-camp; also used to in-dicate a neighbour or one having land in the neighbourhood of the gift land (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 197, text line 13).
4201: partāb (SII 1), Sanskrit pratāpa; a half pagoda.
4203: pāruttha, a silver coin equal to 8 drammas of copper or billon (JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 196).
4204: parvan (IA 18), used in relation to eclipses. Cf. Koṅkaṇa-vijaya-parvan (EI 33), festival celebrating the conquest of the Koṅkaṇ; an anniversary of the said conquest. (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’.
4206: paryāya (IA 18), used in relation to an allotment. (CII 1), cf. dharma-paryāya, ‘exposition of the doctrine’; a religious text. Cf. Pallānakāra (EI 23), Sanskrit Paryāyakāra, a saddler, a saddle-maker.
4207: paryuṣita (HRS), ‘outstanding revenue’ which was one of the three kinds of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra.
4208: pāśa (CII 4), fetters of worldly existence. (IA 18), a land measure. (EI 26), a girdle.
4209: Pasāita (EI 29, 33), also spelt Pasāyita; official designation; probably Sanskrit Prasādita in the sense of ‘a fief-holder’.
4210: pāṣāṇa (IE 8-5; SITI), one of the eight kinds of enjoyment of landed property; rocky soil and its products; mineral pro-ducts; probably, stony and hilly land referring to the right of quarrying, etc.
4212: Pasāpālaka (EI 33), official designation; cf. Pasāyita, etc.
4213: Pasāyati (EI 33), same as Pasāyita (q. v.), etc.
4214: Pasāyita (IE 8-3; EI 33), probably Sanskrit Prasādita used to indicate a Jāgīrdār. See Pasāita pañcāṅga-prasāda.
4215: pāścātya-likhita (LP), written on the back of the bond.
4216: paśu (EI 8), animal sacrifice. Cf. a-paśu-medhya (IE 8-5), ‘free from the obligation of supplying animals for sacrifices.’ (CII 4), the individual soul.
4217: Paśupāla (IA 22), nomads. (EI 1), also called Paśupālaka; a person in charge of cattle.
4218: pāśupata (SII 2), same as pāśupat-āstra; name of a weapon.
4219: Pāśupata (EI 32), name of a Śaiva sect.
4220: Pāśupat-ācārya (BL), epithet of a Śaiva religion teachers.
4221: Pāśupata-rājñī (BL), epithet of a Śaiva queen.
4222: paṭa, paṭā, pāṭa (EI 28; Chamba), charter, deed; same as Sanskrit paṭṭa or paṭṭaka.
4225: pāṭaka (IE 8-4; EI 4, 24; IA 18), ‘part of a village’, a quarter; the outlying part of a village; a hamlet; often prefixed to the name of localities; often modified to vāṭaka. (EI 15, 17, 28), a land measure. (IE 8-6), a land measure equal to forty droṇavāpas or to five kulyavāpas; part of a village. (EI 23, 24), a territorial division. (SITI), portion of a field. (SITI), anklet worn by women. (LP), same as Gujarātī pāḍo, a street or the division of a town.
4226: Paṭakāra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 186), a weaver.
4228: Paṭakīla (EI 23), village headman; same as Paṭṭakila, modern Paṭel or Pāṭīl; cf. Veṭakila.
4233: pātanīya (LP), ‘should be left aside’, i. e. ‘should not be taken into account’. (LP), to be kept uncultivated; see kheḍanīya.
4234: Pātasāha (EI 11, 30; BL), Muslim imperial title; same as Persian Pādshāh. Cf. Pātasāhi, Pātisāha, Pātusāha.
4235: Pātasāhi (BI), Indian modification of an imperial title of the Muhammadans; same as Persian Pādshāh; cf. Pātasāha, Pātisāhi, etc.
4236: pātayiṣyāmi (LP), ‘I shall deduct and thus take less.’
4237: Paṭel, Pāṭel (IE 8-3; EI 7), also called Pāṭīl; village headman; a member of the administrative board called Cauthiyā in Western India; cf. Paṭṭakila, Paṭakīla, Veṭakila.
4238: pātha (IE 8-6; IA 11), a land measure regarded as equal to 240 square feet.
4239: pathaka (IE 8-4; EI 4, 23, 27; CII 3, 4; LP), a group of villages; a territorial division like a Parganā of later days.
4240: Pathakīyaka (LP), explained as one who collects the road-tax [for the maintenance of the road] or the transit tax. But cf. pathaka also.
4241: pāthi (IA 15), a territorial unit; same as pathaka.
4242: Pāṭhin (EI3 1), epithet or family name of Brāhmaṇas.
4244: pati (LL), a king; cf. adhipati. (EI 18), same as Kuḍipati = Sanskrit Grāmapati. Cf. grāma-patyā (probably the same as grāma-jana-patitvāt) and nānā-patyā (probably nānā-grāma-jana-patitvāt). See JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, pp. 203-04.
4245: paṭi (IA 18), same as Sanskrit prati, but sometimes substi-tuted for Sanskrit pari in Prakrit; cf. paṭibhoga, ‘consumption [of food].’
4246: pati-bhāga (CII 4), a share of the produce payable to the landlord.
4251: Pātisāha, also spelt Pādisāha (EI 30; BL); same as Persian Pādshāh; ‘Muslim imperial ruler’. See Pādishāh.
4252: Pātisāhi (BL), Indian modification of an imperial title of the Muslim rulers; same as Persian Pādshāh. See Pātisāha, etc.
4254: pātita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 14), ‘killed in a battle’.
4255: patra (CITD), a letter or document; a note; a written paper or deed. (LP), a bond. Cf. tāmra-patra.
4256: Pātra (IE 8-3; EI 28, 29; BL), a minister; cf. Mahāpuro-hita-ṭhakkura, Paṇḍita, Upādhyāya, Karaṇa-kāyastha, etc., men-tioned as Pātra probably meaning ‘a courtier.’ See Ekapātra and Mahāpātra.
4257: pātra, probably, a document (patra). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169. (EI 9), a donee. Cf. Pātrapati.
4258: Pātrapati, probably, the driver or owner of a horse-cart (ṭaṅgā). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 145.
4259: patra-samaya (LP), the conditions laid down in a bond.
4260: Paṭṭa, abbreviation of Paṭṭakila (A.R. Ep., 1958-59, No. B 296).
4261: paṭṭa (IE 8-4; CII 3, 4), a territorial term meaning a group of villages; cf. apara-paṭṭa (EI 22) ‘the western district’. (EI 7, 9, 11; SII 1; BL), a school or spiritual line; a pontificate; a pontifical seat; the dignity of the head of a Jain school; cf. reference to a Jain religious teacher as belonging to the paṭṭa of another teacher and the santāna of a third teacher; cf., e. g., ‘in the paṭṭa of Dharma-sūri’; also cf. ‘paṭṭ-āvalī of the Kharatara gaccha’. Cf. rāja-paṭṭa, paṭṭa-bandha, paṭṭ-ābhiṣeka, etc. (EI 18), a piece of land. (LL), a slab; cf. Prakrit paṭa (EI 20), a stone slab. Cf. yoni-paṭṭa; Gaurī-paṭṭa. (Chamba), also called paṭha; a grain measure, derived from Sanskrit prastha.
4262: Same as paṭṭaka (q.v.); cf. Paṭṭa-lekhin, etc. (ASLV), an account book. (LP), abbreviation of Paṭṭadhara; probably one who has the charter for collecting government revenues; cf. Paṭṭakila. Cf. Paṭṭarājñī, Paṭṭanāyaka, etc.
4263: pāṭṭa, same as or a mistake for paṭṭa, a district. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 235.
4265: Paṭṭ-ācārya (IA 14), a religious title; same as Maṇḍal-ācārya.
4266: paṭṭaka (EI 30; IA 17), a passport; a charter; a copper-plate grant. Cf. paṭṭak-ārtha-samasta-karaṇāya (LP), ‘for fulfill-ing all the conditions in the charter’; also Tamil paṭṭayam (SITI), grant inscribed on copper-plates.
4267: paṭṭaka-dhārmika (IEZ 8-8; EI 30); probably, an authorised cess to be collected for performing a religious function; cf. dhārmika.
4268: Paṭṭak-āpacārika (IE 8-3; EI 31), officer in charge of deal-ing with paṭṭak-āpacāra (crime relating to the misuse or fraud concerning grants).
4269: Paṭṭakāra (EI 24), also called Paṭṭalekhin; writer of docu-ments.
4270: Paṭṭakila (EI 25; CII 4; HD), village headman; same as modern Paṭel, Pāṭel or Pāṭīl. See Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, pp. 51, 53. Cf. Veṭakila.
4271: paṭṭakil-ādāya (EI 21; CII 4), tax for the maintenance of the Paṭṭakila or village headman.
4273: paṭṭa-kūla (LP), silk cloth; cf. pāṭoluṃ in Gujarātī.
4274: pattalā (EI 8-3; EI 19, 24; 26; CII 4), a territorial divi-sion; a district. (IA 18; LP), same as paṭṭa, a royal charter; cf. prasāda-pattalā (LP), a deed recording the grant of rent-free land; (IA 18), cf. prabhoḥ prasād-āvāpta-pattalayā, explained as ‘[area enjoyed] under a patent obtained through the favour of the lord’.
4275: Pattalaka (IE 8-3; EI 3, 9, 23), official designation; pro-bably, not an officer in charge of a territorial unit called pattalā.
4277: Pattalikā (EI 9), official designation; feminine form of Pattalaka.
4279: Paṭṭamahādevī (IE 8-2; EI 4, 20, 22; BL), designation of the chief queen; cf. Mahādevī.
4280: Paṭṭamahiṣī (EI 28), a crowned queen; chief queen.
4281: paṭṭana (HRS), duties levied upon merchants at the ports, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. (EI 19), same as pattana, a township.
4282: pattana (IE 8-4; IP), a township; suffixed to the names of cities like Aṇahillapura-pattana (modern Pāṭan in the Kadi Dis-trict of the former Baroda State).
4284: Paṭṭana-svāmin (ASLV), head of an organisation or a guild in a city; sometimes regarded as the same as Mahānāḍ-prabhu. See Seṭṭi-Paṭṭanasvāmi. (SITI), chief or leader of the mercantile community of a town.
4285: Paṭṭanāyaka (IE 8-3; EI 29), the chief officer or a ruling chief; same as Puronāyaka (cf. Tamil Poṟṟu). It is a family name in Orissa.
4286: Paṭṭarājñī (IE 8-2; EI 23, 30; BL), designation of the chief queen; cf. Rājñī.
4287: Paṭṭarāṇī (BL), title of a chief queen; cf. Rāṇī. Same as Paṭṭarājñī.
4288: Paṭṭasāhanādhipati (IE 8-3; EI 15), same as Mahāsādha-nika, etc.; see Paṭṭasāhaṇi.
4289: Paṭṭasāhaṇi (EI 15), same as Paṭṭasāhanādhipati; see Sāhaṇi = Sanskrit Sādhanika; cf. Kari-turaga-paṭṭasāhaṇi (EI 5).
4290: paṭṭa-śāla (CITD), Sanskrit °śālā; a reading hall; probably, ‘the main hall’; in Kannaḍa, ‘a silk-shop’. (EI 3), name applied to the abode of certain Brāhmaṇas. (LP), cf. Gujaratī Paḍaśāla; the first room in a house.
4291: paṭṭ-āvalī (IA 19; SITI; BL), a list of Jain pontiffs; suc-cession list of spiritual heads among the Jains; cf. ‘paṭṭ-āvalī of the Bṛihat-Kharatara gaccha [of the Jains].’
4292: Paṭṭavārika, same as modern Paṭvāri; cf. Vārika.
4293: Paṭṭela (EI 7), same as Paṭṭakila, Paṭel or Pāṭīl.
4294: paṭṭi (IE 8-6; EI 8), a measure of land; same as nivart-tana.
4297: patti (SII 2), same as nivartana. (SII 1), a sheep-fold; a square measure. (CII 4), share of the produce. (IE 8-3), the smallest division of the army.
4299: patti-bhāga (CII 4), same as pati-bhāga, a share of produce payable to the landlord.
4300: Pattika (IE 8-3), leader of the patti, the smallest division of the army.
4301: pattikā (CII 4), a share; same as patti.
4302: paṭṭikā (EI 8, 17), same as tāmra-paṭṭa or tāmra-paṭṭikā; a copper plate or copper-plate grant. (EI 3), a document.
4303: Paṭṭikā-pālaka, same as Pustapāla (Select Inscriptions, p. 202).
4305: Pattiyāṇaka (IA 132), official designation of doubtful im-port; probably, an administrator or document-writer.
4307: paṭṭolai (SII 1), Tamil = Sanskrit paṭṭolā; a document.
4308: Pāṭṭolai (EI 21, 22), Tamil; official designation; cf. paṭ-ṭolai, ‘a document’.
4309: paṭṭolī, ‘a deed of purchase’ also ‘land purchased by means of a paṭṭolī’ (Jour. As. Soc., Letters, Vol. XX, p. 205). See Tamil paṭṭolai = paṭṭolā, ‘a document’.
4310: Paṭṭ-opādhyāya (HD), a writer or keeper of official docu-ments. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 397.
4311: Pātusāha (BL), Indian modification of a Muslim imperial title; same as Persian Pādshāh.
4312: Paṭvāri (IE 8-3), probably Sanskrit Paṭṭavārika; the accountant-clerk; a member of the administrative board called Cauthiyā in Western India.
4313: Pāṭy-uparika (IE 8-2; 8-3; BL), official designation of uncertain implication; possibly indicating ‘the head of the de-partment of accounts’; sometimes also called Mahārāja, Mahā-sāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra, Mahāpīlupati, Pañc-ādhikaraṇ-oparika and Purapāl-oparika, additionally.
4314: pāukā (IE 8-5; EI 29), same as Oḏiyā pāuseri; tax on the money realised by creditors from debtors.
4315: paūka (EI 31), misprint for Pāli pattha = Sanskrit prastha; a land measure.
4316: pauṇḍarīka (EI 4; IA 19), name of a sacrifice.
4317: Paurāṇika (EI 30; BL), a reciter of the Purāṇas; also pro-bably, an astrologer. Cf. Vyāsa.
4319: Paura-vīthillaka, probably officers in charge of a city and a subdivision; cf. Paura-vi(vī)thillaka-grāmakūṭa-niyuktāniyukta-pradhān-āpradhāna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 169, where the reading is given as visvillaka).
4320: Paura-vyavahārika, cf. Nagara-vyavahārika. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, pp. 112, 147.
4321: pauṣadha (HA), Sanskrit uposatha; living like a Jain monk for 12 or 24 hours; the observance of fast on the eighth and fourteenth of the fortnight, the full-moon day and the day before the new moon and abstention from wicked acts, chastity, abandonment of bathing, etc., i. e. living temporarily like a monk. See poṣadha.
4323: pautava (HRS), various dues collected by the superinten-dent of weights and measures, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. (EI 30), measurement.
4324: pauṭi (EI 29, 32), same as Sanskrit pravarti; a measure of capacity.
4325: pāvāḍai (SITI), Tamil; cloth spread on the ground for persons of distinction to walk on; also food-offering on a large scale spread over a cloth in front of the deity.
4326: pāvai (IE 8-5), same as darśana or nazrāna.
4329: pāvīsā (EI 33), probably, Sanskrit pāda-viṃśaka (viṃśopaka); name of a coin; regarded as equal to five cowrie-shells; same as modern paisā. See lohaḍiyā and dramma.
4330: pavitra (EI 9), the argha vessel. (Ind. Ant., Vol. IX, p. 187), thread, 360 of which are tied round the neck of the image of Kṛṣṇa on Śrāvaṇa su-di 12. Cf. Caitra-pavitra.
4332: pāyalā (EI 11), also called pāyalī; name of a measure.
4333: peḍā (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt piṭha, piḍā, pyoḍā.
4334: Peḍārpāta (BL), mistake for Peḍāpāla, ‘keeper of the record-boxes’. See Peṭapāla.
4335: pĕdda-gaḍyamu (CITD), Telugu; an unknown unit of measurement.
4336: pĕjjuṅka (IE 8-5), Kannaḍa; name of a tax; same as pĕrjuṅka.
4337: Pĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3; EI 4), Kannaḍa; a chamberlain; a superintendent or director (Sanskrit Adhyakṣa); see Vĕrgaḍĕ, Hĕggaḍĕ, etc.
4338: Pĕrggāvuṇḍa (EI 26), Kannaḍa, official designation. Cf. Gāvuṇḍa.
4339: pĕrjuṅka (IE 8-5), Kannaḍa; same as pĕjjuṅka; name of a tax or toll.
4342: Perumān-aḍigaḻ (SITI), Tamil; a term of reverence used to indicate a god or a king. Cf. personal names like Pramāḍi.
4344: Peṭakapāla (EI 28, 29), keeper of the boxes containing records; record-keeper; same as Peṭāpāla, etc.
4345: Peṭapāla (EI 30; BL), keeper of boxes containing official records; the record-keeper.
4346: Peṭāpāla (EI 29), also called Peṭakapāla; record-keeper; same as Peṭapāla.
4347: Peṭavika (EI 30), a class of officials; Peṭavika-vārika (IE 8-8).
4348: peṭha (IE 8-4; CII 3), a small territorial unit; a group of villages.
4349: Peṭṭapāla (EI 15, 28), keeper of the record-boxes; same as Peṭāpāla, Peṭakapāla, Peḍāpāla, etc.
4350: Peyiya-sāhaṇi (Naik's List, No. 264), mentioned along with Maleya-sāhaṇi; official designation. Cf. Sāhaṇi.
4353: phadyaka (EI 23), same as phadiyā; name of a coin; (1/20) of a rupee and equal to 5 dukrās and 2 dukānīs (JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 295).
4355: phaiṇḍivāya-maṟuturu (CITD), Telugu; a maṟuturu measure of land which brought an income in coin and not kind; in Telugu, paiḍi means gold and āyam income.
4356: phala (IA 27), a Pāli form of Sanskrit pala.
4357: phāla-divya (IA 17), the ordeal of taking a heated plough-share in hand.
4358: phalahika, cf. sa-phalahikaṃ (LP), with an open space round about the house; same as Gujarātī phaliyuṃ.
4359: phalaka (IE 3-5), a wooden slab used as a slate.
4361: phalita, cf. phalita-pade (LP), also Gujarātī huṃḍī pāke tyāre, ‘when the bill of exchange becomes due’.
4362: phika (LP), a bull which is not castrated.
4363: phuramāṇa (EI 2), Persian farmān; a royal order or grant.
4364: phuṭṭa (CII 3), a Prakrit word meaning a break or damage in a construction, sometimes Sanskritised as sphuṭita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 144, note 3).
4365: Piāda (IE 8-3), same as Bhaṭa or Bhaṭa-manuṣya; cf. Pāik.
4367: picula, weight equal to 6 māṣas (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 46).
4368: piḍā (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt piṭha, peḍā, pyoḍā.
4371: piḍha (LL), probably, a chair; cf. Sanskrit pīṭha.
4372: piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam (SITI), Tamil; status of the prince, sup-posed to be an officers' cadre composed of the junior members of the royal family. Cf. Kumār-āmātya.
4373: pīlu (IE 8-3), Indian form of Arabic-Persian fīl, an ele-phant.
4374: Pīlupati (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 13, 28; CII 4), leader of the elephant force or keeper of the elephants; cf. Mahāpīlupati, pīlu.
4375: piñcha (IA 18), bunch of feathers carried by a Jain ascetic.
4376: piṇḍ-ādāna (EI 12), quit rent. Cf. also piṇḍa-kara.
4377: piṇḍaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 254, text line 55), same as piṇḍ-ādāna or bhāga-bhoga; cf. samucita-kara-piṇḍak-ādi-samasta-pratyāya; taxes assessed in a lump; cf. piṇda-kara. (IA 2), same as grāsā; probably, a part of the produce of the fields for the maintenance of certain persons. (HRS), known from Pāla records; same as hiraṇya, according to some. (LL), probably, a slab.
4378: piṇḍa-kara (HRS), lump assessment upon villages, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. Cf. also piṇḍ-ādāna.
4381: Piṣāraḍi (IA 24), Malayāḻam; the manager of a temple.
4382: Piśunavetrika (EI 33; HD), probably, an officer who drives away undesirable persons with a cane; or, one engaged in a court for caning culprits. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 94. See Vetrika, Yāṣṭika, Veṭakila.
4383: piṭaka (CII 4), a measure of capacity. Cf. Traipiṭaka.
4385: Pitāmaha (EI 24, 33), epithet of the Buddha. (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’; but cf. Brahman used to indicate ‘nine’.
4386: piṭha (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt piḍā, peḍā, pyoḍā.
4387: pīṭha (CII 4; IA 12), receptacle of a Śiva-liṅga; the ablution trough of a Śiva-liṅga; also called Yoni-paṭṭa. (SITI), pedestal for the image of a deity.
4388: pīṭhī (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 16), a pedestal or seat; same as pīṭha and pīṭhikā.
4389: pīṭhika (ASLV), Sanskrit pīṭhikā; a throne; same as rājya.
4391: Pīṭhikāvitta (IE 8-3; EI 12; HD), probably, ‘those who have acquired [special] seats’; same as Utthitāsanika. The word occurs in such records as the Belava plate of Bhojavarma-deva (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 40). Cf. Velāvitta. Pīṭhikāvitta is sometimes explained as the collector of state dues from pil-grims or religious institutions (Sen, Hist. Asp. Ins. Beng., p. 552).
4392: Pīṭhīpati (BL), explained as ‘the lord of Magadha’ in the commentary of Sandhyākaranandin's Rāmacarita; title of the head of the Buddhist religious institution at Bodhgayā, who was the precursor of the later Mahant Mahārājas of Bodhgayā. The word pīṭhī in this title is the same as pīṭha or pīṭhikā meaning the vajrāsana at Bodhgayā.
4393: pitṛ-parvan (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 37), probably, śrāddha or dāna on each amāvāsyā day.
4394: pitṛ-yajña (CII 4), offerings to the manes; one of the pañca-mahāyajña.
4395: pla (IE 8-1), contraction of pala; often found in the re-cords of the Orissa region.
4397: poḍhī (LL), a cistern; cf. Sanskrit prahi.
4398: Poduvāl13 (EI 18), Tamil-Malayalam; an officer super-vising charitable endowments.
4399: polācya, cf. sa-khila-polācya (IE 8-5); cultivated land; same as nāla; Hindī polach, ‘land constantly under cultivation.’
4401: poṃdī (Chamba), bottom; foot of a hill.
4402: pon (SITI), also spelt poṉ; name of a gold coin also called māḍai. Cf. pon-bhaṇḍāram, ‘gold-treasury’; pon-paṇḍāra-vāśal, ‘the gate of the gold-treasury; royal gold-treasury’; pon-vargam (SITI), ‘a class of taxes payable in gold or coin; ponvari, ‘tax payable in gold (cash)’; also ‘the fee for minting gold into coins’; probably, the same as ponvari-māḍai. Cf. turai-miṉṉaṟ-pon (SITI), name of a coin. (IE 8-8; EI 16), name of a coin; same as gadyāṇa, hūn or varāha.
4405: Pora-Pāñjidhara-parīkṣā (EI 28), chief astrologer; cf. puro prefixed to certain official designations in Orissa. See Paṭṭanāyaka, etc.
4406: Pora-Śrīkaraṇa (EI 28), chief secretary; cf. puro prefixed to certain official designations in Orissa. See Poṟṟu.
4407: Poṟ-Bhaṇḍāri (EI 25), Tamil; temple officer mentioned along with Śāsana-bhaṇḍāri (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 132); cf. pora prefixed to Oḏiyā official designations like Pora-Śrīkaraṇa; also Tamil Poṟṟu.
4409: poṣadha, derived from Sanskrit uposatha; also called poṣa-dha-vrata; cf. pauṣadha.
4411: potaka (LP), the government's money-bag. (LP), cf. Gujarātī poluṃ; the amount of revenue of a village sent to the Government treasury. Cf. pottaka.
4412: potra (EI 26), name of a tax. Cf. potta.
4413: potta, cf. milita-potta-drammā (LP), collected government money. Cf. potra.
4414: pottaka (LP), same as Gujarātī potuṃ; the amount of the revenue of a village sent to the government treasury. Cf. potaka.
4416: pra (PJS), abbreviation of pratimā (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions). (IE 8-1), abbreviation of prathama.
4417: prabandha, name of hymnal compositions in Tamil by ancient Vaiṣṇava devotees. The contributions of hymns and prayers by the twelve āl13vārs in praise of Viṣṇu make up the Nālāyiradivyaprabandham. Nālāyira (four thousand) indicates the rough total number of items and prabandham is regarded as mean-ing a compilation. The first thousand is known as Tirumol13i and comprises hymns of Periyāl13vār, Āṇḍāl, Kulaśekhara, etc.; the second thousand contains the hymns of Tirumaṅgai; the third comprises the compositions of the first three āl13vārs called Iyaṟpā, viz. Tirumal13iśai, Nammāl13var and Tirumaṅgai, and the fourth called Tiruvāymol13i is entirely the work of Nammāl13vār. Nāthamunigal13 is stated to be the compiler of this anthology. See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, Tamil Literature, pp. 181 ff.
4420: prabhā (SII 2), an aureole or nimbus. Cf. prabhā-valaya.
4422: prabhā-valaya (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 16), aureole or nimbus.
4424: Prabhu (IA 30; BL), a village official; cf. Mahāprabhu.
4426: prabhu-śakti (CII 4), power derived from the royal position.
4427: prabhu-svāmya (SII 11. 1), a tenure held by a Prabhu (q. v.).
4429: pradakṣiṇa (CITD), circumambulation from left to right; paying homage to a temple, etc., by solemnly walking round it with the right hand towards it, so that the right side is always turned towards the person or object circumambulated; a rever-ential salutation made by walking in this manner.
4431: Prādeśika (IE 8-3; HD), cf. Prakrit Pādesika (EI 3), pro-vincial governor; governor of a pradeśa or province. Cf. CII, Vol. I, pp. 4-5.
4432: Pradeṣṭṛ (HD), a class of magistrates; the police magis-trate. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 147; Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 156; Arthaśāstra, I. 12; IV. 1 and 10 (last verse).
4434: Pradhāna (SII 1; HD; BL), an official designation some-times indicating the chief minister or administrator also called Pradhāna-saciva (EI 23); cf. pañca-Pradhānāḥ (EI 5) ‘the five ministers’. See Ind. Ant., Vol. IX, p. 35 where Mantrin, Amātya and Pradhāna are separately mentioned.
4435: pradhāna-maṇḍapa (LL), Buddhist; the hall for practising religious exercises.
4436: Pradhānin (CITD), according to lexicons, a governor, minister or president; noble or courtier; etc. (EI 31; ASLV), a high executive officer; same as Pradhāna. (EI 30), a village headman. Cf. Mahāpradhāni.
4437: pradhāni-joḍi (SII 2; SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; an inām held on a fixed quit-rent by a minister; the chief minister's quit-rent.
4439: pradvāra (IA 7), a place in front of the gate; explained as ‘a suburb’ (EI 21); same as Gujarātī parā. Cf. Valabhī-prad-vāra-Homba-vāsakāt (IA 9).
4440: Prāḍvivāka (HD), the chief justice; a judge. See Manusmṛti, IX. 234.
4443: pragrāhya (EI 12), cf. a-kiñcit-pragrāhya; same as grāhya.
4444: prahaṇīka (LL), a class of Buddhist monks.
4446: prāharikya (LP), cf. Gujarātī pahero; a guard or custo-dian.
4447: prahitaka (IA 6), doubtfully explained as ‘a messenger’ or ‘a committee man.’
4449: prakāla (Select Inscriptions, p. 305, text line 15); an era; cf. Gupta-prakāle gaṇanāṃ vidhāya. See kāla in kāl-ānuvartta-māna-saṃvatsare (ibid., p. 270, text lines 3-4), etc.
4452: prakrama (CII 1), an effort; zealous activity; same as parākrama.
4454: prakraya (HRS), income from mines and salt-works, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
4456: Prakrit, Anglicised spelling of Prākṛta, the name of a language.
4458: prakṛti (HD); cf. Mahābhārata, II. v. 23, speaking of the seven prakṛtis which Nīlakaṇṭha explains as referring to Durg-ādhyakṣa (commandant of the citadel), Bal-ādhyakṣa (con-troller general of the army), Dharma-ādhyakṣa (chief of the departments of charity and justice), Camūpati (commander of the army in the field), chaplain, physician and astrologer. The Milindapañha (IV. i. 36) mentions six officers, e.g., the com-mander-in-chief, prime minister, chief judge, chief treasurer, bearer of the sun-shade and bearer of the sword of state (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 77, note 6). Cf. Mātra. (EI 16), a temple official. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twentyone.’ (EI 9), the Kṣatriya community. Cf. sa-tantuvāya-gokuṭa-śauṇḍik-ādi-prakṛtika (IE 8-5); subjects of a king. (CII 1), usage.
4460: prakṣepa (EI 13), cf. amīṣāṃ prakṣepa-pratiṣedhau na karaṇ-īyau, ‘they should not be ousted [from the possession] or hindered [from their enjoyment of the gift land].’
4462: pramāṇa (EI 6; SII 1; SITI), a document; a title deed. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 109), authority; witness. (SII 12), cf. mūla-pramāṇa, original order.
4464: Pramātāra (HD), an officer concerned with the administra-tion of justice, according to some (Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., pp. 122-23). See Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 211. Cf. Pramātṛ, Pramattavāra.
4465: Pramattavāra (EI 21), official designation; same as Pramātṛ or Pramātāra (q. v.); the commander of the elephant corps according to some (CII 4).
4466: Pramātṛ (BL), same as Pramātāra, Pramattavāra (q. v.); a civil judge, according to some (HD); cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321; literally, ‘measurer [of the king's grain share]’.
4467: Pramukha (CII 4), a member of the executive committee of a corporation. (EI 28), probably the same as Pradhānin.
4468: prāṇa (CII 1), living being; same as prāṇin. (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’.
4469: Prāṇ-ācārya (EI 8), title of a physician; explained as the medical adviser of the king (HD). Cf. Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 33-34 (for his qualifications).
4471: praṇālī (CII 3), a conduit, a channel, an irrigation canal.
4472: prāṇāntika (SITI), ‘till the close of one's life’.
4473: pranaptrika (CII 1), cf. panatika (EI 22), the great-grandson; but cf. naptṛ.
4474: prāṇa-sameta, cf. Prakrit praṇa-sameda (EI 24), ‘endowed with life’.
4475: praṇaśya (LP), ‘going out of sight’; cf. Gujarātī nāśīne.
4476: praṇaya (IE 8-5; HRS), known from the Arthaśāstra, the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman, etc.; emergency tax or benevolence; also called praṇaya-kriyā (IE 8-5); cf. a-hiraṇya-dhānya-praṇaya-pradeya, an epithet of rent-free land.
4477: praṇaya-kriyā (EI 8), benevolence or emergency impost; same as praṇaya.
4478: Prāntapāla (IE 8-3; EI 18, 29, 31), warden of the marches; also explained as the governor of a province or guardian of the frontiers (HD). Cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 124.
4479: prapā (EI 3; IA 18; LL), watering trough; a cistern or reservoir. (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 46, note 8), a place of distributing water gratis to travellers; a cistern.
4480: prāpa (EI 17), ‘sub-division of a district’; but see prāpīya, prāveśya.
4481: Prapā-pūraka (IE 8-8; EI 30), a person responsible for filling the cisterns with water in a place for watering cattle or supplying water to travellers.
4482: praparṇaka, royal order; same as Persian parwāna (Select Inscriptions, p. 248).
4484: prāpīya (EI 17), same as prāveśya; cf. Akṣasaraka-prāveśya and Akṣasaraka-prāpīya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 109); cf. prāpa.
4485: Prāpta-pañcamahāśabda (IE 8-2), same as Samadhigata-pañcamahāśabda; subordinate title or epithet; sometimes applied to a crown prince. See pañca-mahāśabda.
4486: prāpti (SII 2), benefit. (EI 7), revenue. (SITI), enjoyment; what is obtained from someone.
4488: prārya (EI 15), father's father or father-in-law's father. Cf. āryaka.
4489: prasāda (EI 3), gift (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 162, note 2).
4490: prāsāda (CII 4; LL), a palace or temple.
4491: prasādaka, cf. Pali and Prakrit pasādaka (EI 20), one who converts some one to the Buddhist faith.
4492: prasāda-mukta (LP), cf. Gujarātī prasād choḍvā khāt, ‘for allowing this favour’.
4494: praśasti (EI 15, 23, 24; CII 3, 4), a culogy; a culogistic inscription generally on stone; a copper-plate charter (with reference to the introductory section of medieval charters); rarely praśastā (Ep. Ind., Vol. 36, p. 52), śubhā (Vol. 35, p. 59).
4496: Praśāstṛ (EI 31), probably, a judge; the chief magistrate, according to some (HD); cf. Arthaśāstra, I. 12.
4498: prasṛmara (EI 13), explained as ‘spreading out in some corner’.
4500: prastha (IE 8-6; CII 4; Chamba), a measure of capacity, often regarded as one-sixteenth of a droṇa; cf. Pāli pattha, a land measure.
4502: prasthaka (HRS), known from the Gurjara-Pratihāra re-cords; cess at the rate of a prastha of grain over and above the usual grain-share. Cf. akṣapatala-prastha, pratihāra-prastha, etc.
4505: Prathama (EI 21), prefixed to Kāyastha and Kulika to indi-cate representatives of certain classes as members of an adminis-trative board of the Pañcāyat type.
4507: Prathama-kāyastha (IE 8-3; EI 27; BL), representative of the scribal class on the local council of administrators; the clerk-member of the Pañcāyat board (see Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 130); the chief scribe, according to some (HD).
4508: Prathama-kulika (IE 8-3; BL), literally, ‘the chief artisan’; designation of a member of the artisan class represented on an administrative board like the Pañcāyat (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 130).
4509: Prathama-pustapāla (EI 15), wrongly regarded as occurr-ing in some epigraphs; see Pustapāla.
4510: prathama-skandha (LP), the first instalment. See skandha, skandhaka.
4515: pratibaddha (IA 15), generally used in the sense of ‘attached to’ or ‘belonging to’ in respect of a village pertaining to a terri-torial unit; sometimes used in the sense of ‘hailing from’ or ‘one whose family hails from’ (cf. vinirgata generally used in the same sense).
4516: pratibhāga (HRS), offerings of fruits, firewood, roots and the like payable by villagers to the king as indicated in the Manusmṛti. Cf. pati-bhāga. (CII 1), one's lot.
4517: prātibhedikā (IE 8-5; EI 9, 12), an obligation or impost of uncertain meaning; may be the same as prātivedhanika. (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 298, text line 20), explained by some as ‘a special right’ (CII 4); but cf. viṣṭi-prātibhedikā (EI 14); supposed to be related to umbara-bheda (q. v.) and meaning a special levy on defaulters in the payment of taxes.
4519: pratibodha (HA), teaching in the Jain doctrine; conversion to the Jain faith.
4520: pratibodhita (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVI, p. 132, note 3), same as vijñāpita.
4522: praticchanda, a model for artists (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, No. 1, p. 12). See lepyakāra.
4523: pratidiś, cf. bhuñjato bhojayatah kṛṣataḥ karṣayataḥ pratidiśato vā na ken = āpi paripanthanā kāryā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 280, text lines 65-66); probably, ‘to dispose of’.
4524: pratiḍhakkā (EI 4, 29), a kind of drum; one of the royal insignia of certain kings of South India.
4525: pratigaṇaka (EI 26), subdivision of a district; same as pratijāgaraṇaka.
4527: Pratihāra, Pratīhāra (EI 23; BL), also called Pratihārin (EI 3, 23), ‘a door-keeper’; but cf. Mahāpratihāra who was a high officer; officer in charge of the defence of the royal palace or bed-chamber or the head of the guards of the city gate; a chamberlain or inditer of grants, according to some (HD); personal attendant of a king, according to others (CII; 4). See Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 73; Vol. IX, p. 192; Bṛhaspati quoted by Viśvarūpa on the Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 307 (for his qualifications); Mahābhārata, Ādiparvan, 85. 28-29; Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 12; Śukra, I. 121. Cf. Antaḥ-pratīhāra (IE 8-3), Rajju-pratihāra.
4528: pratihāra (IE 8-5), levy for the maintenance of the door-keepers of the city gates; cf. pratihāra-prastha.
4529: pratihāra-prastha (HRS), tax paid by the villagers at the rate of one prastha of grain for payment to the Pratihāra; see pratihāra.
4530: Pratihāra-rakṣī (IE 8-3; LL), ‘a female door-keeper’; a female officer in charge of the gates of the royal harem or the personal attendant of a queen.
4531: Pratihārin (EI 23, 30), official designation; same as Prati-hāra.
4532: Pratihasta, cf. Oḏiyā Paḍihasta (EI 28), a representative.
4533: pratijāgaraṇaka (IE 8-4; EI 9, 32; CII 4), a territorial unit often found in Paramāra inscriptions; same as parganā.
4534: pratika, cf. Prakrit paḍika (EI 8), see pratikaṃ śatam, ‘one coin per cent’.
4535: pratikara, cf. kara; also a-kiñchit-pratikara (EI 23), ‘land without any yield of revenue’. (HRS), compensatory allowance paid by the government to dispossessed owners of rent-fee land, as indicated by the Rāja-taraṅgiṇī.
4536: pratikaraṇa, repairs; cf. khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-pratikaraṇa, same as khaṇḍa-sphuṭita-jīrṇoddhāra (q.v.). (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 114, note 2), meeting the expenses.
4538: pratimā, cf. pratimam (SII 2), image of a human being; usually, the image of a deity.
4539: Pratinartaka (CII 3; BL; HD), an official title; perhaps meaning ‘a herald’; cf. CII, Vol. III, p. 190 (a person described as tanniyukta-pratinartaka-kulaputr-āmātya).
4540: Pratinidhi, a representative (Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 150).
4541: Pratinivāsin (EI 20), same as Nivāsin, a resident.
4542: pratipad (CII 1), ‘to follow’; same as anuvṛt, anupratipad. (Select Inscriptions, p. 281, text line 10); cf. pratipādya, ‘having decided’.
4543: pratipadā (EI 24), a slab with foot-prints. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 247.
4546: pratipatti, cf. pratipattau (LP), explained as ‘convincing’; but actually ‘during the administration of … ’.
4547: Prātirājya (EI 3, 6), same as Pratirāja, ‘a hostile king.’
4548: Prātirājyika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIX, p. 71), probably, an envoy at the court of a hostile king; but cf. Paḍirā.
4550: pratisāṃvatsarika-śrāddha (CII 4), the annual śrāddha cere-mony; same as sāṃvatsarika-śrāddha.
4551: Pratisaraka (IA 7), cf. Vartmapāla-Pratisaraka-Rājasthānīya; official designation; same as Pratisāraka.
4552: Pratisāraka (EI31; HD), explained as an officer who collects tax and allows carts to go out of the nālī or a strip of low ground (LP); see Pratisārin; same as Pratīsāraka.
4553: Pratīsāraka (LP), explained as ‘a gate-keeper’. See Prati-sāraka, Pratisārin.
4554: Prātisāraka (HD), same as Pratisāraka. See Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 187.
4555: Pratisārin (LP) explained as ‘one who allows the merchants to go through strips of low ground’. See Pratisāraka.
4560: pratiśraya (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 46, note 8), a shelter-house for travellers. See ucchraya.
4561: pratiṣṭhā (EI 11; SII 1; BL; HA), installation, consecra-tion; ceremony of installation or consecration (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 20).
4562: pratiṣṭhāna, cf. yaṣṭi-pratiṣṭhāna (CII 2-1), used in the sense of pratiṣṭhāpana.
4564: Pratiśūraka (EI 31), probably, the superintendent of wrestling; cf. Pratiśūrika.
4565: Pratiśūrika (IE 8-3), probably, the superintendent of gladiatorial combats; cf. Pratiśūraka.
4567: Prati-vāsudeva (HA), an enemy of Vāsudeva in Jain my-thology.
4568: Prativedaka (IE 8-3; CII 1), a reporter or spy.
4570: prātivedhanika (HRS), punching-fee collected from mer-chants at the time of the inspection of weights and measures, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra.
4573: prativyañjana, Tamil paḍi-viñjanam (SITI), articles other than rice for the preparation of food-offerings in a temple, etc.
4574: pratolī (EI 9; CII 3; BL), a gate-way; a gate-way with a flight of steps; a gate-way strongly built and considerably high. (EI 31), probably, a street.
4577: pratyādāya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 21; Vol. XIV, p. 196; Vol. XXXV, p. 127), income or tax; cf. pratyāya in the same sense.
4579: pratyandhāruvā (IE 8-5; EI 12, 33), Oḏiyā; probably pratyarthāruvā (Sanskrit pratyartha-rūpyaka), name of a tax or levy of uncertain import; probably, a levy on the money rea-lised by money-lenders from debtors. See arthāruvā, pāukā.
4580: pratyanta (IE 8-4; CII 1), a state beyond the borders of one's territories; a land outside one's dominions; also its people; cf. anta.
4581: Pratyanta-nṛpati (EI 15), ruler of a bordering state.
4582: pratyarthāruvā (IE8-5), a tax of uncertain import; pro-bably Sanskrit pratyartha-rūpyaka in the sense of a levy on amounts realised by the money lenders from debtors; also read as pratyandhāruvā; see arthāruvā and pāukā.
4583: Pratyaya, probably, a lessee (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 143-44).
4584: pratyaya (EI 11, 15), a holding; sometimes also written as pratyāya (cf. CII, Vol. III, p. 170, note 5). Cf. Prakrit avija-pracaga saṃkara (CII 2-1) = Sanskrit avidyā-pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ, ‘in inter-connection with delusion are the saṃkāras’, i. e. the saṃkāras spring from avidyā. Cf. etat-pratyaye, in this matter (Select Inscriptions, p. 237).
4585: pratyāya (IE 8-5; EI 29; HRS), revenue; income or tax; dues payable to the king including bhāga-bhoga-kara and hiraṇya; cf. bhūla-vāta-pratyāya (EI 10). See pratyaya.
4586: pratyaya, pratyāya (CII 3), primarily ‘income’ and secon-darily ‘a holding, the income of which is enjoyed.’ Cf. amuka-pratyaya-amuka.
4587: Pratyeka-Buddha, cf. Prakrit Pracega-Budha (CII 2-1), Buddhist; name of certain Buddhas.
4591: pravacana, exposition of texts (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 150).
4592: pravahaṇa (LP), same as vāhana; a boat.
4596: pravaṇikara (EI 18, 24, 26; HRS), cf. yathādīyamāna-bhāga-bhoga-kara-pravaṇikara-kūṭaka-prabhṛti-samast-ādaya (IE 8-5), known from the Gāhaḍavāla records; a minor tax other than what was bhāga-bhoga-kara, according to some; explained by some as a tax levied from a class of merchants. See pravaṇivāda. (IA 15), explained as hiraṇya or tax in cash.
4597: pravaṇivāda (EI 21), name of a tax; cf. pravaṇikara.
4598: pravara (IA 19), an invocation of ancestors at the perfor-mance of certain rites. (CII 4), a member of the executive committee of a corpo-ration.
4599: Prāvārañcara (EI 24), supposed to be ‘a licensed spy’.
4601: pravartavāpa (EI 32), also called pravarta; a land measure; cf. pravarti and pravartikā.
4602: pravartamāna (IA 18, 19), current [year]; cf. atīta or expired.
4604: pravarti, pravartikā (EI 32), a measure of capacity; cf. pauṭi, pravarta and pravartavāpa.
4605: praveśa, prāveśa (EI 17), explained as ‘a small territorial unit’; but probably refers to the assessment of the rent of a loca-lity along with another; cf. Siviḍi-praveśa-Kandalivāḍa-grāma inter-preted as ‘Kandalivāḍa-grāma having its rent assessed along with Siviḍi’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 59, note 1). See prāveśya, prāpīya.
4606: Praveśa-bhāgika (HD), a subordinate officer of the treasury who received cash payments, according to Stein (Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII, 278).
4608: prāveśya (EI 31), also spelt praveśya; explained by some as a small territorial unit; sometimes translated as ‘situated in’ (CII 4); but may refer to the revenue assessment of a village along with another; cf. Ardhaṭi-prāveśya-Lavaṅgasikāyām (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 143); same as praveśa. Cf. Hastiśīrṣa-prāveśya-Tāpasapottake with Siviḍi-praveśa-Kandalivāḍa-grāma interpreted as ‘Kandalivāḍa-grāma having its rent assessed along with Siviḍi.’ Same as prāpīya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 109); cf. Akṣa-saraka-prāveśya used in the sense as Akṣasaraka-prāpīya. Cf. praveśa, prāveśa, prāpīya (LP), also patra-pṛṣṭhato praveśyo dātavyaḥ, ‘should get [the sum] entered at the back of the docu-ment’ (dātavya from dā ‘to cut’). Cf. a-prāveśya, etc. (IE 8-5); entrance. (IE 8-8; EI 30), an entry tax or levies relating to the entry of royal agents.
4609: pravrajita (CII 1; LL), a Buddhist monk; an ascetic.
4611: prayāṇa-daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 25, 26), cf. rājasevakānāṃ vasati-daṇḍa-prayāṇa-daṇḍau na staḥ; refers to the obligation of the villagers to provide free conveyance and carriage of loads, etc., when royal officers passed through their village. Prayāṇa thus seems to mean ‘passage, transit’, and daṇḍa ‘levy’; cf. rūḍhabhāroḍi.
4612: prayojana (LP), need; cf. drammaiḥ hasta-prāptaiḥ prayojanaṃ jāyate (LP), ‘when there is a necessity of having the money back [before the stated time].’
4613: Prāyopaveś-ādhikṛta (HD), officer who watched those that had resolved to fast unto death at the palace gate. See Rājata-raṅgiṇī, VI. 14.
4615: Pregaḍā (EI 9), Kannaḍa; a minister. Cf. Pĕrgaḍĕ, etc.
4616: preṣaṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 9, text lines 13-14), service.
4618: Preṣaṇika (IE 8-3), officer in charge of the despatch of messengers; the dispatcher of messengers; cf. Praiṣaṇika, Vaik-ṣepika.
4620: preta-dakṣiṇā, cf. peta-dakkhinā (EI 24), a gift to one's dead ancestors.
4621: Priyadarśin (CII 1), cf. Priyadasi (EI 5), secondary name of the Maurya king Aśoka.
4622: Pro, abbreviation of Prohita = Sanskrit Purohita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 192).
4623: Prohata, Prohita (Chamba, etc.) a priest; from Sanskrit Purohita. Cf. Para.
4625: pṛṣṭha, cf. pṛṣṭhe hastaḥ (LP), ‘hand on someone's back’; a sign of warning.
4626: pṛthivī, cf. Prakrit sava-puṭhaviyaṃ (CII, Vol. I, p. 87, text line 7); used to indicate the dominions of the Maurya emperor Aśoka, versions other than Dhauli (Rock Edict V) having sarvatra vijite (i. e. ‘everywhere within the dominions’) in its place. Cf. Jambudvīpa.
4628: pṛthvī-liṅga (SII 2), a Śivaliṅga made of earth.
4630: pu (PJS), abbreviation of putra, ‘a son’ (especially in medieval Jain inscriptions).
4631: pūjā (CII 1; ML), an honour; the act of honouring.
4632: Pūjāhāri (EI 33), same as Pūjāri (Sanskrit pūjādhārin); priest.
4633: Pūjaka (SITI), one who performs worship; a temple priest.
4634: Pūj-āmātya (IA 11), official designation; cf. ‘the Pūj-āmātya of the province of Timbāṇaka’.
4635: Pujāri (EI 5, 15), a priest; a temple priest; called Pūjārī or Pūjāhārī (Sanskrit Pūjādhārin) in the early medieval records of Orissa.
4636: pūjā-śilā (EI 16, 22), same as śālagrāma-śilā (the stone emblem of Viṣṇu).
4637: pūjā-vṛtti (SITI), tax-free land endowed to a temple for conducting worship. Cf. tala-vṛtti, etc.
4638: pukkoli, pukkolli, pukkūli (IE 8-8), cf. pukkoli-kṣetra, explain-ed as ‘an arecanut palm plantation’. An inscription of Kadamba Mṛgeśvarman seems to suggest that it really means ‘land in-undated by floods’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 152). See khajjana.
4639: pukkoli-khajjana (EI 33), a type of land; see khajjana and pukkoli.
4640: pukkoli-kṣetra (EI 33), a type of land like khajjana; see pukkoli or pukkoli-khajjana.
4641: pūlaka (CII 4), a small bundle (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 309).
4642: Punarjanman (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 290, text line 3), used in the sense of Dvijanman (i. e. a Brāhmaṇa).
4643: puṇḍarīka (CII 3; BL), name of a sacrifice.
4644: puṇyāha-vācaka (EI 11), a priest who officiates in a cere-mony and proclaims by means of mantras a happy day to the ceremony and its performer.
4646: puṇya-vācana (IA 21), a purificatory rite [in Madras]; cf. puṇyāha-vācana.
4647: pura, a temple (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 184). See bhavana.
4648: pūraka (CII 3; etc.), used as a termination of the names of villages.
4649: purāṇa (IE 8-8; EI 12, 21, 29), name of a coin; a silver coin also called dharaṇa and kārṣāpaṇa (32 or 24 ratis); cf. kapar-daka-purāṇa (EI 26), meaning purāṇa calculated in cowrie-shells; also paṇa-purāṇa (i. e. purāṇa counted in copper paṇas). (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 246), the Purāṇa texts, e. g. the Āditya Purāṇa.
4651: Purapāl-oparika (IE 8-2, 8-3; BL), official designation pro-bably indicating the governor of a city or chief amongst the governors of cities; called Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāprati-hāra, Mahāpīlupati, Pañcakaraṇoparika and Pāṭyuparika addition-ally (IE 8-3). The expression may also mean two different designations, viz. Purapāla and Uparika. With Purapāla, cf. Pura-pati, etc.
4652: Purapati (EI 25), mayor of a town; cf. Pura-pradhāna, Puraśreṭhin, Nagara-śreṣṭhin, Purillaka, etc.
4653: Pura-pradhāna (CII 4), mayor of a city; cf. Purapati, Puraśreṣṭhin, Nagara-śreṣṭhin, Purillaka, etc.
4654: Pura-śreṣṭhin (EI 25), official designation; same as Nagara-śreṣṭhin, Pura-pradhāna, Purapati, etc.
4655: puratobhadra (EI 9), probably, a building with only one gate in the front side.
4656: Purillaka (EI 29; CII 4), explained as ‘the mayor of a town.’ Cf. rāja-sāmanta-viṣayapati-grāmabhogika-purillaka-cāṭa-bhaṭa-sevak-ādin (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIX, pp. 114-15); also Deśillaka and Pura-pati, Pura-pradhāna, Pura-śreṣṭhin, Vīthillaka, etc.
4658: pūrṇaghaṭaka-paṭṭa (LL), slab bearing the representa-tion of a flower-vase.
4659: pūrṇimānta (CII 3, etc.), the technical name for the scheme of the lunar months in Northern India, according to which the months end with the full-moon day, and the dark fortnights precede the bright; Fleet states that in astronomical works, it is always the amānta arrangement that is actually taken for calculations though, even in Southern India, the pūrṇimānta arrangement was used with the Śaka years, for the civil reckoning, up to between 804 and 866 A. D.; on the other hand, according to him, even in Northern India, it was not used with the Newar era in Nepal, though it was adopted there when the Newar era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern variety.
4660: Puroga (EI 23), prominent among a particular class of people; sometimes wrongly taken to be the same as Purohita.
4661: Purohita (CII 4; SII 1; BL; ASLV; HD), a priest; a family priest; the royal priest; occurs in the list of functionaries in records like those of the Gāhaḍavālas (Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305) and Senas (ibid., Vol. XII, p. 9). See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, pp. 111-12, 117.
4662: Puro-nāyaka (IE 8-3; EI 28), the chief Nāyaka; probably the same as Paṭṭa-nāyaka or Puro-Parīkṣaka; cf. Nāyaka. Puro may really be the modification of a Dravidian word (cf. Tamil Poṟṟu).
4663: Puro-parīkṣa (EI 28, 31), probably, the same as Paṭṭa-parīkṣaka, ‘the chief superintendent’; the chief superintendent of a department. Puro may really be the modification of a Dravidian word (cf. Tamil Poṟṟu).
4664: Puro-pratihasta (EI 31), probably, ‘the chief representa-tive’. Puro may really be the modification of a Dravidian word (cf. Tamil Poṟṟu).
4665: Puro-śrīkaraṇa (EI 31), probably, ‘the chief secretary’. Puro may really be the modification of a Dravidian word (cf. Tamil Poṟṟu).
4666: Puruṣa (IE 8-3), same as Rāja-puruṣa, ‘royal officer or agent.’ (HD) an inferior servant (Arthaśāstra, II. 5) or a bailiff attached to a court of justice (as in Bṛhaspati). See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 278.
4671: Puruṣottama-putra (EI 33), epithet of one devoted to the god Puruṣottama-Jagannātha of Purī. See Rudra-putra, Durgā putra.
4672: puruṣa-yuga, cf. Prakrit purisa-yuga (EI 20); a generation.
4675: pūrvā (IE 8-8; CII 4; ML), ‘the above’; ‘the aforesaid (tithi or praśasti)’; used with reference to a tithi and a praśasti; sometimes wrongly used as a synonym of a tithi or praśasti. Cf. anupūrvī used with reference to a tithi.
4676: pūrv-ācāra (SII 3; SITI), an old usage or ancient custom. Cf. pūrva-rīti.
4677: Pūrv-āgrahārika (EI 23), the former holder of an agrahāra.
4679: pūrva-rāja (EI 17), a king of eastern countries or of early times.
4681: pūrva-siddh-āyatana (EI 33), epithet of a Buddhist temple; see siddh-āyatana.
4682: puṣkala (IE 8-6), a measure of capacity usually regarded as equal to sixtyfour handfuls.
4684: puṣpa (IE 8-8), a coin having the shape or sign of flower. Cf. a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa (IE 8-5), flowers which the villagers (probably, the florists) were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officials.
4687: pustaka, cf. Tamil pottagam (SITI); register, as of land and revenue.
4689: Pustakapāla (IE 8-3; EI 6, 29), record-keeper; same as Pustapāla; cf. Peṭapāla, etc.
4690: Pustapāla (IE 8-3; EI 28; CII 4; HD), record-keeper; occurs in epigraphs like the Damodarpur plates of the Gupta age (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 13; cf. Vol. XX, p. 61).
4691: puṣya-rāga (SITI), same as puṣpa-rāga; a kind of gem.
4692: puṣya-ratha (EI 3), a car. Cf. puṣpa-ratha or puṣpaka-ratha, the celestial car.
4693: puṭi (EI 33), same as puṭṭi or puṭṭidosillu.
4694: pūti (EI 12, 14), also read as yūti; cf. tṛṇa-pūti (or yūti)-go-cara-paryanta, epithet of a gift village. The expression tṛṇa-pūti or tṛṇa-yūti may mean ‘grass-land’. The word is some-times written as yutī and yuthī also.
4695: putra, cf. Nigama-putra (LL), ‘the inhabitant of a nigama (township).’ Cf. Durgā-putra, Puruṣottama-putra, etc. (IE 7-1-2), probably confused with pāṇḍu-putra and used to indicate ‘five’.
4696: putra-sūnu (SII 2), used in the sense of pautra, ‘son's son’.
4697: puṭṭi (CITD), Telugu; a measure equal to twenty tūmus; also called khaṇḍi (spelt candy in English and found as khaṇḍikā in Sanskrit inscriptions) and regarded as equal to between 800 and 1000 seers. Khaṇḍi at Masulipatam has 3 weights, viz. 488 pounds for tobacco, 500 pounds for metals, hardware, etc., and 560 pounds for sugar, dates and other soft articles. The puṭṭi and its fractions also denote the area of the land that is supposed by some to produce the particular quantities of grain. According to some, it is a land measure equal to 8 acres being presumably the area which can be sown with a puṭṭi of grain. There were different kinds of puṭṭis, e. g. gāl-puṭṭi. Cf. also pelle-puṭṭi regarded as equal to 80 kuñcas and Malaca-puṭṭi or Malacca ton as equal to 300 to 240 kuñcas. (EI 4, 27), a land and grain measure. (IE 8-5), same as Telugu puṭṭi-dosillu, ‘a fee of two hand-fuls from each puṭṭi of grain paid to the village-servants’.
4699: pyoḍā (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt piṭha, piḍā, peḍā.
4700: Rā (LP), abbreviation of Rājaputra, Rāuta, etc.
4703: racita (CII 3; etc.), composed; a technical term used in connection with the composition of a record, as opposed to the writing on the plate or slab for facilitating the work of engrav-ing and also to engraving. Cf. cintita in Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 59.
4705: rādhā (EI 8), a posture of standing with the feet a span apart.
4709: Rāhasika (IE 8-3; EI 27, 30), same as Rahasy-ādhikṛta, etc.; a privy councillor; a private secretary or adviser.
4710: Rahasi-niyukta (IE 8-3), a private secretary; same as Rahasy-ādhikṛta, etc.
4711: Rahasya (IE 8-3; EI 3-6, 23, 27, 30), a private secre-tary; same as Rāhasika, Rahasy-ādhikṛta, etc.
4712: Rahasy-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; EI 6, 27, 30; SITI; HD), a privy councillor or private secretary; same as Rahasya, Rāhasika, Rahasi-niyuka, etc.; cf. also Vaiśvāsika, Paramaviśvāsin Mahāpara-maviśvāsin, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 7; Vol. VI, p. 13; Vol. XXII, p. 298.
4713: Rāhuta, Rāhutta (IE 8-2), same as Rāvata = Sanskrit Rāja-putra; a title of nobility. (IA 20), also called Rāuta; explained as ‘a horseman.’
4714: Rāhutta-rāyan (SITI), Sanskrit Rājaputra-rājan; title of nobility; explained as ‘a cavalry officer’.
4716: Rāja (LP), abbreviation of Rājaputra (Rājpūt); explained as a cavalry-soldier or a Rājpūt. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 143-44, where it is probably an abbreviation of Rājakula (Rāval).
4718: rāja-bhaṇḍāra (SITI, ASLV), Sanskrit rāja-bhāṇḍāra; royal treasury or store-house.
4719: rāja-bhoga (EI 12), also rāja-sambhoga; dues enjoyed by the king or land belonging to the king's Khās Mahāls.
4720: rāja-daṇḍa (SII 1), punishment imposed by the king.
4722: Rāja-dauvārika (EI 2; BL), door-keeper of the royal palace (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 115). See Dauvārika.
4723: rājadhānī (EI 23), the capital; sometimes used to indicate the headquarters of a chief or governor.
4724: Rājādhirāja (IE 8-2; EI 21, 22, 30; CII 3, 4), title of paramount sovereignty; an imperial title meaning ‘the king of kings’; used in the Gupta period in some metrical passages, both alone and along with Rājarājādhirāja. Cf. Adhirājarāja (EI 9).
4725: Rājādhyakṣa (IA 12; SII 11-2), official designation; probably the same as Rājasthānīya, literally, ‘an officer acting for the king.’
4728: rāja-graha (IE 8-8); apprehension or recruitment in the king's name.
4729: rāja-gṛha, cf. Tamil rāja-karam (SITI); palace (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 107) or government; officers or autho-rities; also the taxes due to the same. Cf. rājakaraṅ-kāṇikkai, ‘customary presents to be made to the palace’; rājakara-upādi, ‘tax payable to the palace or to the government officers’.
4730: Rājaguru (EI 21, 27, 30; CII 4; BL; ASLV; HD), king's preceptor. Cf. Bomb. Gaz., Vol. XXI, p. 354; Ind. Ant., Vol. XII, p. 120.
4731: rāja-huṇḍikā (LP), the royal bill of exchange.
4732: Rājājñāprada (EI 27), probably, the same as Ājñapti, etc.
4733: rājaka-daivaka (LP), calamities owing to the king or the gods; cf. rājaka-daivaka-vaśāt (LP).
4734: rāja-kara, cf. rāja-garam (ASLV), taxes in general.
4735: rāja-kārya (SITI), duties of the state; official work.
4736: rājakārya-bhāṇḍāra (SITI; ASLV), a treasury related to state business; an official committee of management.
4737: rājakīya (LP), government tax. Cf. samasta-rājakīyānām = apraveśya (IE 8-5); same as Rāja-puruṣa or Rāja-sevaka; also Rāja-satka; an officer of the king.
4739: Rājakula (IE 8-5; CII 3; IA 20; BL; HD), royal house-hold; the king, royal officers and members of the royal family. Originally, ‘the royal family’; then ‘a member of the royal family’; and then ‘a royal officer’; later, a title of nobility, same as modern Rāval or Rāul. See Bhandarkar's List, No. 324. Cf. rājakulaṅ-kāṇi-ppaṟṟu (SITI), ‘land or village in the enjoyment of the members of the royal family’. The expres-sion occurs along with devadāna, brahmadeya, paḻḻiccandam, etc.
4740: Rājakumāra (IE 8-3; LL; HD), same as Rājaputra; desig-nation of a prince. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 5.
4742: rāja-māna (IE 8-6; EI 12, 23, 28; SII 11-1), royal measure; the standard measure fixed or accepted by the king or government; same as rājakīya-māna.
4743: rāja-māṅgalīyaka (LP), auspicious occasions for the royal family.
4744: Rāj-āmātya (EI 26; CII 3; HD), Prakrit Rāy-āmaca; the king's minister. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 91; CII, Vol. III, pp. 213, 216. (IE 8-3), sometimes used to indicate the ministers of the feudatory rulers; see Amātya.
4745: Rājamudr-ādhikārin (BL), official designation indicating the keeper of the royal seal or a governor. Cf. Mudr-ādhikārin, etc.
4746: Rājan (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), royal title; originally used by imperial rulers; later, when emperors assumed more dignified titles, a title of feudatories and smaller rulers. Cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 121; Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 297.
4747: Rājanaka (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 23, 29), same as Rājānaka, Rājanyaka, Rājānika; a feudatory; in some cases, smaller than the feudatory called Rājan.
4748: Rājānaka (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; BL; HD), same as Rājanaka, Rājanyaka, Rājānika or Rāṇaka; title of feudatory rulers or of the nobility; often a feudatory smaller than a Rājan. Cf. Rāja-taraṅgiṇī, VI. 117, 261 (title given for services to the king and surviving in the form Rāzdān as a family name of Kashmir Brāh-maṇas); Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, pp. 394, 306.
4749: Rājānika (EI 1), same as Rājanaka, Rājānaka, etc.
4751: Rājanya (ASLV; SITI), officers of the king. (IA 22), same as Kṣatriya.
4752: Rājanyaka (IE 8-2; EI 15, 23, 29; HD), same as Rājanaka, Rājānaka, Rājānika or Rāṇaka, title of subordinate rulers. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 9.
4754: Rāja-paṇḍita (EI 32), a court Pandit; a scholar patronised by the king.
4758: rāja-paṭṭī (EI 4; BL), royal fillet or tiara; status of a ruler or a feudatory indicated by turban. Same as rāja-paṭṭa.
4759: Rājapuruṣa (IE 8-5), a royal agent or officer; same as Rāja-sevaka or Rājakīya; cf. also Rāja-satka.
4760: Rāja-putra (EI 30; CII 3; 4; HD), originally ‘a prince’; title of princes and subordinate rulers; but later a title of nobi-lity especially in the modified forms Rāvata, Rāuta, etc.; some-times also used in the sense of ‘a Rājpūt’ often explained as ‘a horse-man’. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321. See Rāja-putraka.
4761: Rāja-putraka (EI 17), same as Rāja-putra; mentioned in the list of subordinates and officials addressed by the king in respect of a grant.
4763: rājaprāsāda-caityaka (LL), a small caitya in the royal palace.
