4764: Rājarāja (IE 8-2; LL), imperial title; cf. Greek Basileos Besileon.
4766: rāj-ārghikā (IE 8-8; EI 30), name of a levy; probably, periodical offerings to the king or the king's share of articles sold in the markets.
4768: Rājasāmanta (EI 25), a Rājan and a Sāmanta, or one feuda-tory enjoying both the designations.
4769: rāja-sambhoga (EI 12), same as rāja-bhoga (q. v.); land belonging to the king's Khās Mahāls (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 46). Cf. ratnatraya-sambhoga.
4770: Rāja-satka (IE 8-3; EI 29), literally, ‘one belonging to the king’, i. e. ‘a servant of the king’; same as Rāja-puruṣa or Rāja-sevaka.
4771: Rāja-sevaka (IE 8-5), same as Rāja-puruṣa, Rājakīya or Rāja-satka.
4772: rāja-siddhānta (EI 24), science of polity; same as rājanīti.
4773: rāja-śrāvita (EI 6; IA 19), a royal decree or proclamation.
4774: rāj-āśraya (IA 8), the capital; same as rājadhānī.
4775: Rāja-śreṣṭhin (HD), king's banker or the chief of the bankers. See Commentary on the Yaśastilaka, I, p. 91.
4776: Rājasthāna, same as Rājasthānīya and Rājasthān-ādhikāra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 292).
4777: Rājasthān-ādhikāra (IE 8-3), probably, the chief justice; cf. Rājasthānīya (a viceroy), etc.
4778: Rājasthānī, dialect of Hindī prevalent in Rajasthan.
4779: Rājasthānīya (IE 8-3; EI 24, 26, 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), ‘an officer acting for the king’; generally a viceroy; probably also a subordinate ruler; but cf. Rājasthān-ādhikāra who was also a judge; an official title indicating a viceroy in some areas and a judge in others; an officer who carried out the object of protecting subjects, according to some (Ind. Ant., Vol. V, p. 207). Cf. CII, Vol. III, p. 157; Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 112; Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 176 (probably, a chief justice), explained wrongly as ‘an officer connected with other kings, i. e. a foreign secretary’ (Ind. Ant., Vol. XII, p. 122, note 76).
4780: Rājasthān-oparika (EI 29), probably a viceroy; cf. Rājas-thānīya and Uparika. See Rājasthān-ādhikāra and Rājas-thānīya.
4782: rājasva (SITI), property belonging to the king or state [by confiscation, etc.].
4783: Rājātirāja (IE 8-2; EI 21, 26, 30; ML), imperial title of certain foreign rulers; cf. Basileos Basileon Megalou.
4784: Rāja-vaidya (IE 8-3; LL), physician to the king; the royal physician.
4785: rāj-āvalī (EI 9; IA 30), genealogy of rulers; a list of lineal succession of kings. (EI 10), royal titles; cf. rājāvalī pūrvavat (IE 8-2), ‘the royal titles as above’, often used when a repetition of the string of royal titles was avoided. Cf. Paramabhaṭṭārak-ety-ādi-rāj-āvalī-tray-opeta referring to the imperial titles Paramabhaṭṭāraka, Mahārājādhirāja and Parameśvara.
4786: Rāja-vallabha (EI 6, 9, 24; CII 4), explained as ‘a court-favourite’; a courtier.
4787: rājāvarta (SII 2; SITI), a kind of gem; lapis lazuli; same as vaiḍūrya.
4789: Rāja-veśyā-bhujaṅga (SITI), ‘the lover of the courtesans of the [enemy] kings’; a title assumed by some kings after cap-turing the enemies’ countries, probably describing rājya-śrī as a prostitute.
4790: rāja-vilāsinī, king's courtesan (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 107).
4791: rāja-viṣaya (CII 1), a king's dominions. Cf. Rājaviṣayādhyakṣa.
4792: Rājaviṣay-ādhyakṣa, explained as ‘the royal superintendent of a district’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 234); but rāja-viṣaya in this case may be the king's Khās Mahāls so that the designa-tion means ‘the superintendent of the king's Khās Mahāls.’
4794: rajjū (HRS), used in the Arthaśāstra probably in the sense of the cost realised by the government in connection with the expenses of land-measurement or survey.
4796: Rajjuka (IE 8-3; HD), Prakrit Rajuka or Lajūka (EI 2); an officer of the land survey and revenue department, accord-ing to some; but seems to be the governor of a district, one of whose functions was probably the survey of land with a measur-ing rope for the fixation of the amount of the king's share of the produce; probably the same as Greek Agronomoi mentioned by Megasthenes.
4797: Rajju-pratihāra (EI 24), ‘rope-jugglers or dancers’; cf. rajju-pratihār-āpaṇa, ‘booths of rope-jugglers and dancers’; but rajju-pratihār-āpaṇājīvika may be a tax for maintaining surveyors and gate-keepers (toll-collectors) and from shop-keepers.
4798: Rājñī (IE 8-2; EI 26; CII 3; HD), a queen; a title of the wives of paramount sovereigns and subordinate rulers; cf. Mahā-rājñī, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 305.
4800: rājya (IE 8-4; EI 19), district or province of a kingdom; (SITI; ASLV), the biggest administrative unit of the Vijaya-nagara empire; same as pīṭhika; also means ‘sovereignty’.
4802: Rājya-cintaka (EI 11; BL), a minister or the chief admi-nistrator; same as Rājyacintākārin.
4803: Rājyacintākārin (EI 1), a minister or the chief adminis-trator; same as Rājya-cintaka.
4804: Rājy-ādhikṛta (EI 22, 23), chief minister; cf. Rājyādhikārin; also cf. rājya.
4805: rākā-śaśāṅka (SII 1), same as rākā-viṭa; the full-moon.
4806: rakata-paṭā (JBORS, Vol. XVIII, pp. 219-20), Oḏiyā; Sanskrit rakta-paṭṭaka, same as rakta-mānya; also called sira-kaṭā tambā-paṭā in Oḏiyā.
4807: rākā-viṭa (SII 1), same as rākā-śaśāṅka; the full moon.
4808: rakṣā (EI 17), confirmation of a former grant.
4809: rakṣā-bhoga (EI 9), same as rāja-bhoga, the king's share. (SITI), a fee or a share in the produce given to the village watchman.
4811: rakṣaṇa, cf. doṣa-vināś-āvaṣṭabdhi-rakṣaṇāya (LP), ‘for keeping it safe from the three faults, viz. doṣa, vināśa and avaṣṭabdhi’.
4814: rakta-mānya, cf. Tamil iratta-mānya, iratta-kkāṇikkai (SITI); ‘blood-present’; endowment of rent-free land for the support of the descendants of warriors killed in battle; same as mṛtyuka-vṛtti. See rudhira, rakatapaṭā, vīra-śeṣā, etc. See Ind. Arch. Rev., 1960-61, Section III, No. 42.
4816: raktikā (IA 27), same as ratī or guñjā (q. v.); a unit of measurment; about 1-825 grains or 119 grammes in weight.
4819: rāmānuja-kūṭa (SITI), a rest house for Vaiṣṇava tra-vellers.
4821: Rāṇa (EI 16, 23), same as Rāṇaka; see Rāṇa-putra, rāṇa-kula.
4822: Rāṇā (IE 8-2; EI 23, 30), derived from Rāṇaka; title of ruling chiefs; same as Rāṇa, Rāṇaka. Cf. Rannā.
4823: Rāṇaka (IE 8-2; EI 23, 30; CII 4; BL; HD), derived from Rājanaka, Rājānaka or Rājanyaka; a feudatory title; title of feudatory rulers and, later, of the nobility. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321. (EI 9), explained as ‘the chief counsellor’. (EI 1), title of the great artist Śūlapāṇi described as Vārendraka-śilpi-goṣṭhī-cūḍāmaṇi.
4827: raṇa-stambha (CII 3, 4), a victory-pillar; a column in memory of the victory in a battle; same as jaya-stambha. (BL), a memorial pillar raised for a person who died fighting for his master on the battle-field; same as vīra-kkal (q. v.).
4828: Rāṇa-putra (BL), also called Rāṇa-utra; literally, ‘the son of a subordinate king’; a title of nobility. See Rāja-putra.
4830: randhra (IE 7-1-2; EI 25), ‘nine’; used in the sense of ‘cypher’ in a few late works.
4831: Randhrapūraka (CITD), probably, a musician who played on some kind of wind instrument.
4833: raṅga-bhoga (EI 17), amusement to be arranged for a deity and land granted for it; also called śṛṅgāra-bhoga (EI 5). (CITD), enjoyment of splendour other than aṅga-bhoga or personal decoration; gift land received for raṅga-bhoga. See aṅga-bhoga.
4834: raṅga-lekha (LP), ‘coloured letter’; probably refers to the custom of sprinkling saffron water on the letters addressed to a king.
4835: raṅga-maṇḍapa (SITI), inner hall of a temple; same as Tamil tiruv-araṅgu. (HA), same as sabhā-maṇḍapa; main hall in a shrine. (EI 9), hall in front of a shrine.
4836: raṅg-āṅga-bhoga (EI 3), same as aṅga-raṅga-bhoga (i. e. raṅga-bhoga and aṅga-bhoga), etc.
4838: Rāṇī (EI 23, 33), feminine from of Rāṇa or Rāṇā (i. e. Rāṇaka); designation of a queen.
4839: Rannā, name of the Sun-god's wife in West Indian my-thology; probably a modification of Rājñī. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 343. The name is also spelt Raṇṇā or Rāṇā.
4840: Ranneśa, a name of the Sun-god; cf. Rannā. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 343. The name of the Sun-god worshipped at Thanwala near Pushkar was Rannāditya (also spelt Raṇṇāditya and Rāṇāditya).
4841: rāśi (IA 17), a sign of the zodiac. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twelve’. Cf. rāśi-ppon (SITI), also called rāśi-paṇam; explained as ‘pure gold’; probably, ‘current good coin.’
4842: Rāśi-mitra (EI 32), a friend of one, because of the birth of both under the same rāśi.
4843: rāśi-paṇa, also called rāśi-ppon (SITI); probably ‘current good coins’.
4844: raśmi (IE 7-1-2), probably confused with śīta-raśmi and used to indicate ‘one’.
4845: rāṣṭra (IE 8-3, 8-4; EI 9, 23; CII 4; LL), a district or its subdivision; often the subdivision of a district; cf. Śātavāha-nīya-rāṣṭra; also Kona-rāṣṭra (EI 32), variously called deśa, maṇḍala, sīma, sthala, etc.
4846: Rāṣṭra-grāma-kūṭa (EI 28), i. e. Rāṣṭrakūḷa and Grāmakūṭa; cf. Rāṣṭra-grāma-mahattara.
4847: Rāṣṭra-grāma-mahattara (IE 8-3; EI 6, 28), i. e. Rāṣṭra-mahattara and Grāma-mahattara; cf. Rāṣṭra-grāma-kūṭa.
4848: Rāṣṭrakūṭa (EI 8-3), same as Rāṣṭra-mahattara; either the officer in charge of a territorial unit called rāṣṭra or, more pro-bably, a member of the administrative council of a rāṣṭra; cf. Grāma-kūṭa; also Deśakūṭa (IA 7). (EI 9), interpreted as ‘the headman of a village’. (EI 24), according to some, a land-holder. (CII 4; HD), interpreted as ‘the head of a district or sub-division’; cf. JBBRAS, Vol. XVI, p. 117.
4849: Rāṣṭra-mahattara (IE 8-3), same as Rāṣṭrakūṭa; either the head of a territorial unit called rāṣṭra or, more probably, a member of the administrative council of a rāṣṭra.
4850: Rāṣṭramahattar-ādhikārin (EI 25), official designation; probably, Rāṣṭramahattara and Adhikārin.
4851: Rāṣṭrapāla (HD), head of a district, province or subdivi-sion; same as Rāṣṭrapati. See Arthaśāstra, V. 1.
4852: Rāṣṭrapālaka (EI 28), ruler of an administrative unit called rāṣṭra; same as Rāṣṭrapati.
4853: Rāṣṭrapati (EI 12, 25; HD), ruler of a province, district or subdivision called rāṣṭra; same as Rāṣṭrapāla. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, pp. 278, 285; Vol. VII, p. 39.
4854: rāṣṭra-viṣaya (IE 8-4), originally, a rāṣṭra, but later a viṣaya; cf. Karma-rāṣṭra-viṣaya.
4855: Rāṣṭrika (IE 8-3; CII 1; HD; LL), Prakrit Raṭhika (EI 2), Raṭṭhika (EI 7); same as Rāṣṭrin; ruler of a rāṣṭra, i. e. a district or its subdivision; also the name of a people called ‘hereditary Rāṣṭrikas’. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 5; Bhandarkar, Aśoka, p. 30. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 78), mentioned in the list of officials addressed by the king in respect of a grant.
4856: Rāṣṭrin (EI 7), ruler of a rāṣṭra; same as Rāṣṭrika. Cf. Rāṣṭrapati, Mahārāṣṭrin, etc.
4857: Rāṣṭriya (IE 8-3; LL; HD), same as Rāṣṭrika, ruler of a district or province; a provincial governor. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 43; Pāṇini, IV. 2. 93; Mahābhārata, Śānti-parvan, 85. 12.
4858: Rāṣṭrīya (IE 8-3), same as Rāṣṭriya; a provincial governor.
4859: Rāta (BL), modification of or mistake for Rāvata or Rāuta.
4860: ratha, rock-cut temples at Mahābalipuram (Journ. Mad. Univ., Vol. XXXII, p. 140).
4862: Rathakāra (SITI), artisan classes; also their association.
4863: ratha-saptamī (EI 22; CII 4; IA 17), an auspicious tithi; same as Māgha śu-di 7.
4864: rath-āṣṭamī EI 29; CII 4; IA 17), same as Māgha śu-di 8.
4866: Rathika, superintendent of chariots (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 156).
4869: rati, ratī (IE 8-8; IA 19), also spelt rattī; a small weight; see Sanskrit raktikā.
4871: ratna (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’; sometimes also used to indicate ‘nine’, and rarely even ‘fourteen’. (EI 22; CII 4), same as the Buddhist tri-ratna, i. e. the Buddha, Dharma and Saṅgha. (ML), a relic [of the Buddha].
4873: ratna-gṛha (CII 3), ‘the jewel-house’; the house enshrining the three ratṅas, regarded by some as denoting a great Buddhist stūpa. (EI 19; LL), Buddhist; a sanctuary; the sanctuary of a Buddha image.
4875: ratna-traya (EI 8), Jain; samyag-darśana, samyag-jñāna and samyak-cāritra. (EI 27, 30, 31), Buddhist; the tri-ratna or trinity; a Buddhist religious establishment enshrining the three ratnas; rent-free land in its possession (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 46). Cf. ratnatraya-sambhoga.
4876: ratnatraya-sambhoga (HRS), traced in Bengal records; rent-free holding in the possession of Buddhist religious establishments where the Buddha, Dharma and Saṅgha were worshipped; same as ratna-traya. Cf. rāja-sambhoga.
4877: Raṭṭaguḍi (EI 30), same as Raṭṭoḍī; official designation; probably the same as Rāṣṭrakūṭa.
4878: Raṭṭaguḻḻu (EI 27), probably, the same as Rāṣṭrakūṭa.
4880: Raṭṭoḍi (EI 30), official designation; same as Raṭṭaguḍi.
4881: Rāu (IA 18), same as Rāva (Sanskrit Rājan) or abbrevia-tion of Rāuta (q. v.).
4882: raukya-dra (LP), abbreviation of raukya-dramma; ‘drammas in cash’; cf. raukya with Gujarātī rokaḏā.
4883: Rāula (EI 24, 28), derived from Sanskrit Rājakula; title of nobility; same as Rāvata, etc.
4884: raupya-ṭaṅka, ‘silver ṭaṅka (q.v.)’. See JNSI, Vol. XXII, p. 197. According to Nārada, a silver kārṣāpaṇa was called raupya in South India.
4885: Rāuta (IE 8-2; EI 4, 28, 30, 31; CII 4; BL), same as Rāvata = Sanskrit Rājaputra; a title of feudatory rulers and noblemen. (IA 20), also called Rāhutta; explained as ‘a horseman’.
4886: Rāutta (IE 8-2; EI 5, 30, 32), same as Rāuta or Rāvata = Sanskrit Rājaputra; a title of feudatories and noblemen. See Rāuta.
4887: Rāva (IE 8-2; BL), spelt in English as Rao; title of subor-dinate rulers and noblemen; derived from Sanskrit Rājan; cf. Rāya.
4889: Rāval (BL), title of subordinate rulers and noblemen; derived from Sanskrit Rājakula.
4890: Rāvala (EI 24; BL), same as Rāval; derived from Sanskrit Rājakula; title of subordinate rulers and noblemen.
4892: rāvaṇa-hasta (ASLV), a musical instrument; may also indi-cate ‘twenty’ (cf. rāvaṇa-bhuja).
4894: Rāvat (EI 32), a title of subordinate rulers and noblemen; same as Rājaputra, Rāuta, etc. See Rāvata.
4895: Rāvata (IE 8-2; BL), same as Rāvat; derived from Sanskrit Rājaputra; a title of feudatories and noblemen.
4899: Rāvutu (EI 21), same as Rāuta, Rāvata, etc.; derived from Sanskrit Rājaputra; a title of feudatories and noblemen.
4900: Rāwa (EI 30), variant spelling of Rāva; derived from Sanskrit Rājan; title of nobility.
4901: Rāya (IE 8-2; BL), title of nobility; derived from Sans-krit Rājan; cf. Rāva.
4902: Rāya-rāuta (EI 31), title of nobility; derived from Sanskrit Rāja-rājaputra.
4903: Rāyarāya (EI 21), title of nobility; derived from Sanskrit Rājarāja.
4904: rāya-rekha (IA 15), a system of land measurement.
4905: Rāyasa (EI 3, 17; ASLV), Kannaḍa; a secretary; an officer in the Vijayanagara administration.
4906: rāyasa (ASLV), royal order. (SITI), office of a writer; clerkship; order of the king; written orders. Cf. Rāyasa-svāmin, head of the rāyasa.
4907: Rāyasa-svāmin (ASLV), ‘the head of the rāyasa’ (SITI); the chief secretary.
4909: ṛddhi-pāda, cf. iddhi-pāda (EI 5), Buddhist; four in number.
4911: rekhā (EI 19), a land measure. Cf. rekai, rekai-ppon (SITI), irekai; regarded as the name of a gold coin (probably bearing signs in straight lines); used in Vijayanagara inscriptions; probably, revenue income in cash.
4912: rekhā-daṇḍa (EI 14), name of a linear measure.
4914: rintakāvaḍḍi (EI 33), name of a levy; cf. antarābaḍḍi or āturā-baḍḍi.
4919: rocīka (IE 8-5), a tax or obligation of uncertain import.
4920: rohaṇa (SITI), function performed at the commence-ment of a festival.
4922: roka (Chamba), cash. See rūka under rū.
4925: rū (IE 8-1), abbreviation of rūpaka or rūpyaka. (CITD), abbreviation of Telugu rūka meaning ‘cash’ and probably derived from Sanskrit rūpaka.
4926: rūḍhabhāroḍi (HRS), system of forced carriage of loads as indicated by the Rājataraṅgiṇī. Cf. prayāṇa-daṇḍa.
4927: rudhira, cf. Tamil udira-paṭṭi (SITI), literally, ‘blood-land;’ land given to the descendants of a person who fell fighting on the king's behalf; see also rakta-mānya, mṛtyuka-vṛtti, rakta-paṭṭaka and vīra-śeṣā.
4930: rudradāmaka, ‘silver coin (kārṣāpaṇa) issued by Rudra-dāman’; name of the silver coins issued by the Śaka rulers of Western India (JNSI, Vol. XIII, pp. 1 7 ff.).
4931: Rudra-gaṇa (SITI), devotees of Śiva, their managing com-mittee looking after the affairs of a Śiva temple and being known as Rudragaṇa-pperumakkaḻ.
4932: Rudra-gaṇikā (SITI), a dancing woman attached to a Śiva temple; a devadāsī serving in a Śiva temple.
4933: Rudra-māheśvara (SITI; ASLV), the two classes of Śaiva devotees, known as the Rudras and Māheśvaras; designation of the authorities of a Śaiva temple.
4934: Rudra-putra (EI 33), epithet of one devoted to the god Śiva. See Durgā-putra, Puruṣottama-putra.
4937: rundra (IA 6, 10), cf. guṇa-rundra, an epithet of Jinendra; also cf. Himavad-girīndra-rundra-śikhara.
4938: rūpa (HRS), according to the Arthaśāstra, (1) a subsidiary charge in excess of the prescribed fines; (2) a charge upon mines and upon imported salt. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 94, 106. (IE 8-8; EI 20, 21), currency or coins; name of a silver coin; same as rūpya or rūpaka. (EI 1), an animal. (CII 1), a representation.
4939: Rūpa-dakṣa, cf. Prakrit lupa-dakha (EI 22), a painter or sculptor. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 30. (LL), explained by some as ‘a copyist’.
4940: Rūpa-darśaka (EI 20, 21; HD), an examiner of coins. See Arthaśāstra, II. 5. Cf. Pārikh.
4941: rūpaka (IE 8-8; EI 30; CII 4), name of a coin of silver; cf. kṛṣṇarāja-rūpaka (EI 25; CII 4), a silver coin issued by the Kalacuri king Kṛṣṇarāja; silver coin (1/16) of the value of a gold dīnāra in the Gupta age (JNSI, Vol. II, p. 5); same as dramma.
4942: Rūpakāra (EI 8; BL), a sculptor; epithet of a sculptor. See Rūpakāraka, Rūpakārin.
4943: Rūpakāraka (LL), a sculptor; same as Rūpakāra, Rūpakārin.
4944: Rūpakārin (EI 5), a sculptor; same as Rūpakāra, Rūpakāraka.
4946: rupee, Anglicised form of rūpīa (q. v.); derived from Sans-krit rūpyaka. See JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 142.
4947: rūpīa (IE 8-8), same as rūpya or rūpyaka.
4948: rūpika (HRS), tax on the sale of salt; one of the sources of revenue specified in the Arthaśāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 25, 92, 106.
4949: rūpyaka (IE 8-8), same as rūpaka, rūpīa, rupee.
4950: sa (IE 8-1), also written as saṃ; abbreviation of saṃvatsara.
4951: Sā (EI 32), abbreviation of Sādhanika (q. v.). (PJS), abbreviation of Sāhu or Sādhu, designation of a member of the mercantile community often used in medieval inscriptions.
4952: śabda, same as mahā-śabda; cf. pañca-śabda (BL).
4954: sabhā (SII 2; SITI; ASLV), same as mahāsabhā; the body of the Mahājanas; the assembly of a Brāhmaṇa village of the Tamil-speaking area, such an assembly of a non-Brāhmaṇa village being called ūr; local assembly of a Brāhmaṇa village; same as Tamil kuṟi. (EI 22), the Buddhist saṅgha.
4955: sabhā-madhyama (SITI), the village common or waste land in the village belonging to the sabhā; also called sabhai-ppodu, ūr-ppodu, ūr-mañjikkam, sabhā-mañjikkam, etc., in Tamil.
4957: sabhā-viniyoga (SITI), individual share payable to make up the expenses of the sabhā.
4958: Sabrahmacārin (CII 3), a religious student of a group that follows the same śākhā.
4959: sācitta (LP), probably, ‘land attached to government ser-vants as long as they serve’.
4960: Saciva (EI 33; BL; HD), minister or counsellor. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 105, note 150.
4962: sadaka, cf. upari-sadaka, explained as ‘the upper region’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI. p. 234).
4963: sadā-sevā, cf. Tamil sadā-servai, sadā-sevai (SII 1; SITI); constant service; permanent service.
4965: ṣaḍ-āyatana, cf. Prakrit ṣaḍ-ayadana (CII 2-1), the six organs.
4966: ṣaḍ-bhāga, cf. dharma-ṣaḍ-bhāga (Sel. Ins., p. 348, text line 16), one-sixth of the merit for a pious work done by the subjects, which goes to the king. See ibid., p. 344, text line 3.
4967: Sādhācārya (IA 12), assistant to the officiating priest at the Rāmeśvaram temple; also called Adhyayana-bhaṭṭa.
4968: sādhana (IE 8-3; EI 24; LP), an army, cf. sādhana-sahasra-aikam, an army consisting of one thousand men. (EI 15), an army, or money. (SII 12), cf. mūla-sādhana, the original deed; also called mūla-olai in Tamil.
4969: Sādhanika (CII 4), a general; same as Sāhaṇi, etc.
4970: Sādhanin (EI 23), explained as a ‘a councillor’; but really, the same as Sādhanika (q. v.).
4971: sādhāra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 177), either a mistake for sādhāraṇa, ‘common’, or means ‘together with the adjacent grounds’.
4972: sādhāraṇa (IA 20), used in the sense of laukika.
4973: sadharmi-vātsalya (HA), attachment to or service of the followers of one's own faith.
4974: sadhryagvihārin (LL), doubtful Sanskritisation of Pāli saddhi-vihārin (Sanskrit sārdhaṃvihārin under the influence of sādhya), companion of a Buddhist monk. Cf. Jain Sārdhaṃcara, Sārdhaṃcarī (LL).
4975: Sādhu (EI 9), a priest. (HA), a Jain monk. (LP; HA), same as Sāhu, a merchant. (CII 1), an adjective meaning ‘good’.
4977: sādhya (IE 8-5; EI 15; SITI), a type of income; income from land that may be brought under cultivation in future; one of the eight kinds of enjoyment of property. See aṣṭa-bhoga, siddha.
4978: Sādhyapāla (HD), a bailiff who summoned parties and witnesses. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 278.
4979: sādyaskra (EI 22; CII 3; etc.), name of a sacrifice.
4980: sagara (IE 7-1-2), confused with sāgara and rarely used to indicate ‘seven’.
4981: sāgara (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’; used in the sense of ‘seven’ by some late writers (IA 19).
4982: Sagotra (CII 3, etc.), belonging to the lineage of the person from whom the gotra name is derived.
4983: Sahadeśa (IA 17), also called Sahadeśin, ‘belonging to the same country’.
4984: sahagamana (ASLV), self-immolation of a widow on the funeral pyre of her husband; same as satī.
4985: Sahaja-kavi (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 231, note 1), epithet of a poet.
4986: Sāhaṇi (IE 8-3), also called Sāhiṇi, etc.; derived from Sanskrit Sādhanika; cf. Gaja-sāhiṇi, etc. (EI 15), see Paṭṭa-sāhaṇi, Peyiya-sāhaṇi, Maleya-sāhaṇi.
4987: Sāhānī (EI 33), same as Sādhanika, Sāhaṇi, etc.
4988: Sāhaṇia (IE 8-3), Prakrit form of Sādhanika from sādhana or army; cf. the modern family name Sāhnī. Same as Sāhaṇiya, etc.
4989: sāhaṇikāṭi (SII 11-1), supposed to be the name of a coin.
4990: Sāhaṇiya (EI 11), Prakrit form of Sādhanika; same as Sāhaṇia, etc.
4991: Sāhānuṣāhi (IE 8-2; EI 19, 22, 30), title of the Kuṣāṇa kings, derived from Old Persian Kshāyathiyānām Kshāyathiya; same as modern Persian Shāhān Shāh.
4992: śahar, Persian shahr, a town (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 145-46).
4994: Sāhasādhipati (HD), a judicial or police officer. See Śukra, I. 120.
4995: sāhasamallāṅka (BL), epithet of a year of the Kalacuri era probably through confusion, as normally the expression would mean the Vikrama era.
4997: sahasr-āyatana (EI 29), epithet of a temple; literally, ‘having one thousand rooms or shrines’.
4998: Sāhi, Śāhī (IE 8-2; EI 30; LL), same as Persian Shāh, Old Persian Kshāyathiya; royal title used by some Indian rulers of foreign origin.
4999: Sāhijādā (BL), title of a prince; same as Persian Shāhzādah. See Sāhiyādā.
5000: sahī-karī (Chamba), ‘having approved; having got ap-proved; having put the signature on’.
5002: Sāhiṇi (IE 8-3; EI 32), same as Sanskrit Sādhanika (q. v.), interpreted as ‘the master of the royal stables’ (BL).
5005: Sāhiyādā (BL), title of a prince; same as Persian Shāhzādah. See Sāhijādā.
5006: Sāhnī (IE 8-3), modern family name derived from Sans-krit Sādhanika = Prakrit Sāhaṇia, Sāhaṇi.
5007: sahodara (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’ possibly referring to Kuntī's sons.
5008: Sāhu (LP), same as Sanskrit Sādhu; a merchant.
5009: śaibara, cf. sa-śaibaram (EI 17); a levy in kind according to some; but see saivara.
5010: saïkā (EI 28), Sanskrit śatikā; a levy per one hundred articles; one payable in a hundred articles.
5015: Śailālaka (EI 1; LL), same as Śilālin, an actor.
5017: Śaila-vardhakin (LL), cf. Prakrit Sela-vaḍhākī (EI 20); a stone mason.
5018: Sainika-saṅgha-mukhya (EI 22), official designation; pro-bably, a general.
5019: sainya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 71), probably, an adminis-trative unit.
5022: Śaiv-ācārya (CII 4), an ascetic of the Śaiva sect.
5023: śaivācārya-kṣetra (SITI), tax-free land endowed to a Śaiv-ācārya.
5024: śaiva-dīkṣā (EI 32), initiation into the Śaiva faith.
5025: śaivara, a revenue term; cf. śaibara; a levy in kind accord-ing to Ghoshal (H. Rev. Syst., p. 220); but probably the same as Marāṭhī śerī, ‘arable land originally excluded from the village assessment’ (Wilson's Glossary); may also be a tax on farm-houses (cf. śibara).
5026: Śaka (EI 24), originally, the Seythians; later any foreigners including Muhammadans; used to indicate the Musalmans (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 44; Bhandatkar's List, No. 926).
5027: śaka, śāka (IA 9, 19), used in the sense of ‘a year’ or ‘an era’; cf. Vikrama-śaka (IA 18).
5028: śāka, cf. a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa (EI 8-5); vegetables which the villagers were obliged to supply to the king or land-lord on occasions or to the touring officers. Cf. śāka-śaka.
5029: sākā (IA 29), Rājasthānī; same as jauhar or javhar.
5030: śākambharī-vidyā (EI 29; CII 4), name of a science, the nature of which is uncertain.
5031: Śakānikā (CII 4), a Śaka woman. Cf. anikā.
5032: śāka-paṇikā, cf. śāka-paṇikā-nyāyena (LP), ‘like vegetables in a market’.
5033: sakarukara, occurs in a Śātavāhana inscription probably for Sanskrit sa-kar-otkara meaning the same thing as s-odraṅga-s-oparikara, ‘with the udraṅga (kara) and uparikara (utkara) taxes’; may also be sa-kārukara. See kāru-kara.
5034: śākhā (CII 3, 4; IA 18, 19), literally, ‘a branch’; a Vedic school following any particular recension of the Vedas. (LL), a section of the Jain community.
5038: śakr-otthāna (EI 32), a festival, same as śakradhvaj-otthāna. Cf. śakra-dhvaja, indra-daṇḍa.
5039: Sākṣin (EI 3, 23; SITI), a witness; an eye-witness.
5042: Śakti (EI 17), name of the wife of Kāmadeva.
5044: śakti-mukha, (SITI), cf. śatti-mugam; king's order; probably the same as śrīmukha.
5047: Śākya-bhikṣu (BL; LL), epithet of a Buddhist monk; same as Śākya.
5048: Śāky-opāsikā (LL), a female member of the Buddhist laity.
5049: śālā (EI 4; SII 1), a hall. (EI 4; SITI), a school; same as pāṭha-śālā. (SII 3), cf. śālai (EI 7; SITI), an alms-house; a feeding house; cf. śālā-bhoga. Cf. śālai (EI 24), a hospital; cf. ārogya-śālā, ātura-śālā.
5050: śālā-bhoga (SII 2; SII), same as Tamil arac-cālā-bhogam; land granted in favour of a feeding house (sattra-śālā). (EI 23), mentioned along with devadāna and brahmadeya; a rent-free hold-ing in the possession of a śālā meaning an almshouse or a school.
5051: śalākā, cf. śalāgai (SITI), name of a coin also called palañ-śalāgai (accu) and śrīyakki-palañśalāgai.
5052: Śālāsthāna-mukhya (EI 32), probably, officer in charge of the stables.
5053: Salāṭa (PJS), Gujarātī; also called Salāvaṭa; a stone-cutter or mason.
5054: Sālavī (LP), Gujarātī; a weaver. (PJS), Gujarātī; a carpenter.
5057: sallekhanā (EI 3, 6; SITI), Jain; a religious practice of the Jains; starving oneself to death; starving oneself to death in fulfilment of a vow; same as samādhi.
5058: Sa-lohita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 295), ‘one having the same blood’; a relation.
5060: saṃ (IE 8-1), abbreviation of saṃbaddha, ‘attached to’, ‘belonging to,’ etc.; possibly also saṃsakta, ‘relating to’ (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 204). (CII 3, 4), abbreviation of the word saṃvatsara, a year, or of its declensional cases that can be used in expressing a date.
5061: Saṃ (PJS), also written Saṃgha; contraction of Saṃghavī or Saṃghapati in medieval Jain inscriptions; same as the modern Jain family name Siṅghī.
5062: sāṃ (IE 8-1; LP), abbreviation of sāṃvatsarika, annual. See sāṃ-hi.
5064: sama, cf. sam-ālindakam (LP), ‘with a terrace in front of the door.’
5066: samādhi (CII 4), poetic quality of a composition. (EI 33), explained as a ‘granary’; probably ‘an agreement’. Cf. sallekhanā.
5067: Samadhigata-pañca-mahāśabda (IE 8-2; CII 3), a customary epithet of feudatory rulers, indicating that they were entitled to the privilege of the pañca-mahāśabda (five kinds of musical instruments), or of using five official titles beginning with the word mahā. There are a few instances in which the epithet is applied to paramount sovereigns in South India. The title is sometimes stated to have been conferred on a feudatory by his overlord. See mahāśabda, etc.
5068: Samāhartṛ (EI 27; HD; HRS), official designation; ex-plained as ‘the collector-general’; officer in charge of the collec-tion of various branches of revenue; compared by Ghoshal with the Qānungo of Mughal times (H. Rev. Syst., p. 52). See Artha-śāstra, I. 12; II. 6; Śabara on Jaimini, XII. 1. 28; Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 141; Vol. XI, p. 94.
5069: samāja (EI 20; CII 1), a fair; a festival; a festive gather-ing on a particular occasion or for the celebration of an event.
5072: samakara-grāma (LP), a village for which a permanent revenue is fixed at a particular rate, not to be increased in future.
5073: samakara-kula (LP), family on which rent is fixed once for all; farmers that have to pay revenue at a particular rate.
5074: samākrānta (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 20), used in some Orissan records probably in the sense of ‘endowed with boun-daries’.
5077: Samañjita (SITI), accountant of a village or a village assembly.
5079: Sāmanta (IE 8-2; 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), title of feudatory rulers; a feudatory smaller than the Rājan; a sub-ordinate chief; also explained as ‘a minister’ (SITI). See Bomb. Gaz., Vol. XXI, p. 354; Ep. Ind., Vol. IX, p. 297. Cf. Mahāsāmanta.
5080: Sāmanta (CII 1), a neighbour; ‘one who is in possession of a piece of land in the neighbourhood of the gift land’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 220).
5081: samantabhadra (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 199), prosperous on all sides.
5084: Sāmanta-paḍirā (EI 32), Oḏiyā; Sanskrit Sāmanta-pratirāja; title of a feudatory or nobleman.
5085: sāmantika, derived from Sāmanta; chiefship (A.R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 12).
5087: sāmānya, cf. traividya-sāmānya (EI 23), cāturvedya-sāmānya; ‘belonging to’; Valabhī-cāturvidya-sāmānya, ‘one of the Catur-vedins of Valabhī’; used also in the sense of vāstavya, ‘resident of … ’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, pp. 172, 176).
5088: samāracana, repairs (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
5089: samāraṇa Prakrit used in Sanskrit for samāracaṇa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 59).
5090: samarāpaṇīya (LP), to be got repaired; cf. Gujarātī samrā-vavuṃ; see samarcāpanīya, samāracana.
5091: samarāpya (LP), ‘should be repaired’; cf. Gujarātī samrā-vatruṃ; also samāracana.
5092: samarcāpana (LP), repairing; cf. samarcāpanīya (LP), ‘to be got repaired’; cf. samarāpaṇīya; also samāracana.
5093: samasta (IE 8-1), corrupt form of saṃvat especially in medieval Orissan records.
5094: Samasta-mahāsāmant-ādhipati (BL), title of a feudatory ruler of the highest rank. See Mahāsāmant-ādhipati.
5095: Samasta-sen-ādhipati (EI 29, 30), ‘leader of all the forces’; commander-in-chief. See Sen-ādhipati, Senāpati, Manĕya-samasta-sainy-ādhipati, etc.
5103: sāma-vāda, cf. Prakrit sama-vāyo (CII 1), found in a rock edict of Aśoka; ‘restrained speech’; same as saṃyama (i.e. vāk-saṃyama) found in one version; generally sama-vāyo is taken as samavāya or concord.
5104: Sāmavājika (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 135, note 6), probably, an officer; cf. Sāmavāyika, Sāmavājin, Sāṃmavājin.
5105: Sāmavājīn (EI 6), probably, an officer; cf. Sāṃmavājin, Sāmavājika.
5106: samavasaraṇa (HA), congregation-hall believed to be built by celestials when a Tīrthaṅkara delivered his sermon.
5107: Sāmavāyika (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 135, note 6), probably, an officer; cf. Sāmavājika.
5108: samaveta (IE 8-3), ‘associated’; generally explained as ‘assembled’; but see samupāgata, upeta, upayāta, etc.
5109: samaya (EI 10), a religious system. (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a sect; an assemblage, a company or congregation; established moral or ceremonial custom; cf. samaiyam (EI 24), a creed. Cf. samaye (EI 19), used instead of varṣe in the dates after saṃvat. (SITI), a religious mendicant; cf. Samay-mudali, religious head.
5110: samay-ācāra (SITI), religious usage; established custom; super-vision of the religious and social life of the people; censoring of public morals; also a class of officials called Samayācārya or Dāsari.
5111: Samayācārya (ASLV), also called Samayācāra; same as Dāśari; a censor of morals; a class of officials.
5112: samaya-dharma (SITI), law of the samaya or agreement. The expression is generally used in relation to the organisation of merchants and agriculturists known respectively as Nānādeśīn and Citramel13i.
5113: samaya-patra (SII 1; SITI; LP), an agreement; a docu-ment containing an agreement; a deed of agreement.
5114: sāmāyika (HA), remaining steadfast in worship or medi-tation (at least for 48 minutes), with the mind drawn away from attachments or ill will and abstaining from committ-ing sins, which is the daily duty of a Jain.
5115: sambaddha (IA 15), ‘belonging to’ or ‘connected with’. Cf. Devadroṇī-sambaddha (IE 8-3), probably, superin-tendent of a temple property.
5118: saṃbhāla (LP), care, protection; cf. Gujarātī saṃbal.
5120: sambhoga, cf. rāja-sambhoga, ratnatraya-sambhoga; same as bhoga.
5121: Sambhoga (LL), a section of the Jain community.
5123: sambuddha (LP), one who is no longer a minor.
5124: saṃgrahaṇa, adultery (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 237).
5125: samhalātamaka, cf. samhalātamaka-samanvita (EI 9), mean-ing uncertain; may be a name.
5126: sāṃ-hi, abbreviation of sāṃvatsarika-hiranya, ‘annual re-venue income in cash’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 55).
5129: saṃkācitaka (EI 30), cf. poṭṭalikā-saṃkācitak-ādāna, ‘tax on bundles suspended from loops at both ends of a pole’.
5131: sammat (ASLV), same as samuta; an administrative unit.
5133: sammukha-vāra, probably, Sunday (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 115).
5135: samprāpti, cf. sampirātti (SITI) ‘that which has been ob-tained’; ‘an acquisition’.
5136: Samprati (SITI), senior accountant; the manager of a temple.
5138: Samrāṭ (EI 19, 22; CII 3, 4), imperial title; a paramount sovereign.
5143: saṃsthā (HRS), king's dues derived from the market-place, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
5144: saṃstuta (CII 1), cf. mitra-saṃstuta-jñāti, ‘friends, acquin-tances and relatives’.
5145: samta (IE 8-1), corrupt form of saṃvat. Mta = mat.
5147: samudāya (ASLV), same as gaṇa-bhoga; a tenure in which land is enjoyed by a group of people. (SITI), a village under the gaṇa-bhoga tenure. (SITI), village common; managing committee of a temple.
5148: samudaya-bāhya (HRS), occurs in the Damodarpur ins-criptions; ‘revenue-free’ or ‘yielding no income’.
5149: samudāya-prāpti, cf. samudāya-ppirātti (SITI), any acquisi-tion from the village to be enjoyed in common by the villagers.
5151: samudra (EI 16), same as sapt-āmbhodhi; name of a mahā-dāna; also means 4 (rarely 7).
5152: samudra-ghoṣa (EI 5), name given to a musical instrument.
5153: samūha (EI 28; CII 4), an assembly; the assembly of a corporation.
5154: samupagata (EI 12), explained as ‘assembled at’; really, ‘having connection with’, ‘associated with’; cf. samupagama, ‘contact’; also samaveta, upeta, upayāta, etc.
5155: samupāgata (IE 8-3), ‘associated’; often explained as ‘assembled’; but cf. samaveta, samupagata, upayāta, upeta, etc.
5156: samuta (ASLV), same as sammat; an administrative unit.
5157: samutkrīḍā (EI 15), same as krīḍā or sport.
5158: samva (IE 8-1), mistake for saṃva which is an abbreviation of saṃvatsara.
5159: saṃva (IE 8-1) same as saṃvat; contraction of saṃvatsara.
5162: saṃvāsa, cf. a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭvā-saṃvāsa (IE 8-5); same as āvāsa; shelter or accommodation [which the villagers were obliged to supply to the touring officers of the king].
5163: saṃvat (IE 8-1), originally an abbreviation of saṃvatsara (a year) or any of its declensional cases that can be used in ex-pressing a date; later stereotyped in the sense of ‘a year’ or ‘an era’. It was generally regarded as indeclinable; but we have some cases of the use of forms with case-endings, e. g., saṃvataḥ, saṃvatā, saṃvati and saṃvatām. See also saṃvate (IE 8-1), the seventh case-ending of saṃvata, a corrupt form of saṃvat. Since the late medieval age, the word specially indi-cates the Vikrama era, although originally it was used with the name of any reckoning in quoting the dates of records, especially the regnal reckoning. The word is used in inscriptions in a large number of corrupt forms, e. g., samvata, samvatta, samata, samanta, samatta, saṃmat, samasta, smat, samvatu, samvatū, etc., etc.
5164: samvat (IE 8-1), mistake for saṃvat, originally an abbre-viation of saṃvatsara.
5165: saṃvatsara (CII 3; 4; IA 17), ‘a year’; ‘an cra’, the earlier years of the Indian eras being quoted by this term (or by its abbreviations saṃ, saṃvat, etc.), without any dynastic or other appellation just as in the case of the year of a regnal reckoning.
5166: Sāṃvatsara (HD), an astrologer. See Viṣṇu Dh. S., III. 75; Bṛhatasaṃhitā, 2. 9; cf. Sāṃvatsarika (EI 5).
5168: saṃvatsara-śrāddha (CII 4), śrāddha performed on the first anniversary of a person's death.
5169: saṃvatsara-vāriya (SITI), annual committee appointed by the sabhā; annual committee for supervising the management of village affairs; also called āṭṭi-vāriyam (SITI) in Tamil.
5170: saṃvatsara-vimokṣa-śrāddha (CII 4), same as saṃvatsara-śrāddha performed on the first anniversary of a person's death.
5171: Sāṃvatsarika (HD), an astrologer. See Paiṭhīnasi quoted in Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 193.
5172: sāṃvatsarika-hiraṇya (IE 8-1), annual revenue in cash; often abbreviated as sāṃ-hi.
5174: samvatu, samvatū (IE 8-1), corrupt forms of saṃvat.
5176: saṃvibhāga (CII 1), separation of one thing from another.
5178: sāṃvinayika, cf. a-raṭṭha-sāṃvinayika (EI 1), a-rāṣṭra-sāṃ-vinayika (IE 8-5); administration or control, i. e. administrative control.
5179: Saṃvyavahārin (EI 23), an administrator; same as Vyava-hārin; cf. Saṃvyavahāry-ādi-kuṭumbinaḥ (EI 24), the agricul-turist householders led by the village-headman or the collector of royal dues.
5180: sāmya (EI 23), often written for svāmya; cf. leja-sāmya standing for tejaḥ-svāmya.
5181: samyak-pradhāna, cf. sammappadhāna (EI 5), Buddhist; four in number.
5182: san (IA 18), Arabic; a year; an era; sometimes used in Sanskrit records; in some cases, corrupted to sna.
5184: śāṇa, name of a weight or coin; a silver coin which was (1/8) of a śatamāna in weight and value; generally regarded as 40 ratis in weight, but sometimes also as 32 or 24 or 20 ratis; also called niṣka, ṭaṅka or dharaṇa or śānaka. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 42, 44-45. See śāna-pāda.
5185: Śānabhoga (IE 8-3), village-accountant; same as Senabova, etc.
5187: śāna-pāda, same as māṣa (JNSI, Vol. p. 47).
5188: Sanātha (IA 7), wrongly supposed to mean ‘one whose father is alive’ or ‘a worthy’; actually, a personal name.
5189: sañcakāra (IA 19), same as satyakāra; an agreement.
5190: Sañcarantaka (HD), Prakrit; ‘a spy’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. I, p. 5. Kauṭilya (Arthaśāstra, I. 12) speaks of Sañcāra (wander-ing spies like Tīkṣṇa, Rasada, etc.). Cf. Sañcārin.
5194: ṣaṇḍa (IA 18), a bull living or wandering at liberty.
5195: ṣaṇḍa-gula (LP), same as Gujarātī khāṃḍ-gol, i. e. sugar and molasses.
5196: sandhi (EI 4; SITI), literally, ‘twilight’; but actually, ‘service in the temple in the morning and evening’; daily wor-ship in temples; special worship offered in the names of persons who arrange for it by creating endowments, etc.
5197: sandhi-pāta, emergency (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 213).
5198: Sandhivigrah-ādhikaraṇa (CII 4), department of peace and war.
5199: Sandhivigrah-ādhikaraṇ-ādhikṛta (EI 30; BL), official desig-nation indicating a person in charge of the office of war and peace (i. e. foreign affairs); an officer of the ministry or the minister of foreign affairs.
5200: Sandhivigrah-ādhikaraṇa-kāyastha, official designation of a scribe of the office of war and peace (i. e. foreign affairs).
5201: Sandhivigrah-ādhikṛta (CII 4; BL), an officer in charge of the department or the minister of war and peace; same as Sandhivigrahin.
5202: sandhi-[vigraha]-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); department of foreign affairs.
5203: Sandhivigrahakārin (EI 21), same as Sandhivigrahika. See Mitākṣarā on Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 320.
5204: sandhivigraha-ppeṟu (EI 24; SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; a fee payable to the village Madhyastha; also a fee payable to document-writers; cf. sandhivigrahi-paṇṇu.
5205: Sandhivigrahika (HD), minister for peace and war. See Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 17; Mahābhārata, Śānti-parvan, 85. 30. See Sāndhivigrahika.
5206: Sāndhivigrahika (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD; LP), minister for peace and war, i. e. of foreign affairs; sometimes also called Khādya[kū]ṭapākika, Kumārāmātya, Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, etc., additionally; same as Sandhivigrahika, etc. See Viṣṇudhar-mottara, II. 24. 17; Mitākṣarā on Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 320; CII, Vol. III, p. 15.
5207: Sandhivigrahin (IE 8-3, SITI), minister in charge of peace and war; officer in charge of the foreign relations department, who was often the writer of important documents; same as Sandhivigrahika, etc. Cf. Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin (EI 16), Hĕri-Lāḻa-sandhivigrahin (EI 12), Hĕri-sandhivigrahin (EI 12), Lāḻa-sandhivigrahin (EI 12), Hĕri-Lāṭa-Karṇāta-sandhivigrahin, Hĕri-Lāṭa-sandhivigrahin, etc.
5208: Sandhivigrahi-paṇṇu (EI 30), name of a levy; same as sandhivigraha-ppeṟu.
5209: sandhi-viḻakku (SII 1), a sacred lamp; cf. nandā-viḻakku, sandhi-dīpa.
5210: sandhyā (CITD), the morning, noon and evening prayers of a Brāhmaṇa. (CII 3; IA 17), a period at the commencement of each of the four Hindu ages; the sandhyā of the Kali-yuga lasts for 36,000 years of men, and is still running; cf. sandhyāṃśa.
5211: sandhi-dīpa, cf. sandi-viḻakku (SITI), a twilight lamp; generally lighted in the temples in the evening, but sometimes in the morning; same as sandhyā-dīpa.
5212: sandhy-āṃśa (AI 17), a period at the end of each of the four yugas, the sandhy-āṃśa of the Kali-yuga to last for 36,000 human years.
5213: sandoha, cf. a-puṣpa-kṣīra-sandoha (IE 8-5), realisation or levy (cf. a-puṣpa-kṣīra-grahaṇīya).
5214: Saṅgaḍi-rakṣā-pālaka (EI 6), an officer; the meaning of saṅgaḍi is uncertain.
5215: saṅgam, Tamil; same as Sanskrit saṅgha; an assembly of ancient Tamil poets; the name given to an assembly of poets reported in tradition to have functioned in three different pe-riods. The poets are believed to have been both literary critics and composers. Literary compositions of the age were later collected and compiled into anthologies known as Eṭṭuttokai, Pattuppāṭṭu and Padineṇkīḻkaṇakku according to their contents and size. The saṅgam is stated to have flourished at Kūḍal (also called Madurai in later literature) in the first and last period and at Kavāṭapuram in the middle period. The latest limit for the first two anthologies may be placed round about 700 A.D. See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, Tamil Literature, pp. 14-18; S. Vaiyapuri Pillai, History of Tamil Language and Literature, p. 38.
5216: saṅgha (ASLV), a social organisation. (BL), a community of Buddhist monks; the Buddhist Church. (HA), a Jain congregation; the Jain Church (made up of four constituents, viz. sādhu, sādhvī, śrāvaka and śrāvikā) also called Jaina-saṅgha; a group of pilgrims going together on pilgrimage under the leadership of a Saṅghapati (q. v.). (EI 22), a tribe. Cf. Tamil saṅgam (q. v.).
5217: Saṅgha-pati (EI 8; BL), title of the leader of a group of Jain pilgrims to a holy place, who bears all the expenses of the whole group; same as Saṅghaprabhu, Saṅghavī, etc. Cf. the modern Jain family name Siṅghī.
5218: Saṅgha-prabhu (EI 8), Jain; same as Saṅghapati, etc.
5219: Saṅgha-prakṛta (LL), Buddhist; probably, a supporter of the saṅgha; translated as ‘commissioners of the community’ (Lüders, Mathurā Inscriptions., pp. 84 ff.).
5220: Saṅgharāja (EI 8), Buddhist; title of the principal ec-clesiastical functionary in Burma.
5221: saṅghārāma (EI 4; ML; LL), a Buddhist monastery.
5222: Saṅgha-sthavira (LL), an Elder of the Buddhist congrega-tion. Cf. Sthavira.
5223: saṅghāṭa, saṅghāṭā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 248), cf. pāda-saṅghāṭa or pāda-saṅghāṭā, ‘a pair of feet (i. e. foot-marks)’.
5224: saṅghāṭī (EI 25), robe of a Buddhist monk.
5225: Saṅghavī (BL; HA; PJS), derived from Sanskrit Saṅgha-pati (q. v.); designation of the leader of a saṅgha or group of Jains; the leader of a group of Jain pilgrims, who bears expenses of all the pilgrims going with him (cf. the Jain family name Siṅghī).
5227: Saṅgrahītṛ (HD), explained by some as ‘a treasurer or charioteer’ (Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 111); probably, col-lector of the king's grain share. Cf. Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 9.
5228: śāni (SITI), Dravidian; wife; a term by which a Brāhmaṇa woman was referred to.
5229: śanivāra-maṇḍapa (A.R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 13), name of a build-ing attached to a temple apparently meant for some function held there on Saturdays; cf. vaikkāṇikku-maṇḍapa under maṇḍapa.
5230: sañjāti (LP), cf. rāja-sañjātyāṃ kartavyaḥ, ‘may be made a government property.’
5231: Sañjīva-rāja, cf. Sañjīvarāyar (SITI), name of Hanumān.
5232: saṅkācitaka (IE 8-8), a loop; same as Sanskrit kāca.
5233: saṅkalpa (Chamba), also called saṅkalpa-hast-odaka; liba-tion of water; donation.
5234: saṅkara (EI 9), also called saṅkuru; a double sack.
5236: saṅketa, cf. sva-saṅketa (LP), ‘one's own special arrange-ment’.
5237: śaṅkha (CII 3, etc.), conch-shell as an emblem on seals; cf. śaṅghu (ASLV), the use of which was sometimes granted by kings to their favourites as a privilege.
5238: śaṅkhadhārā, cf. śaṃkudhāra (CITD); Telugu; continuous blowing of the conch-shell. See Śaṅkhadhārin.
5239: Śaṅkhadhārin (IE 8-3), blower of the conch-shell; sometimes mentioned as a Pātra.
5240: Śaṅkhakāra (EI 28), also called Śāṅkhika (q. v.); maker of conch-shell bangles.
5241: Śaṅkhika, Śāṅkhika (EI 24, 28), same as Śaṅkhakāra (q. v.), worker on conch-shells.
5242: saṅkramaṇa (CII 3; IA 17), also called saṅkrānti; the entrance of the sun into a sign of the zodiac; regarded as an auspicious time for performing religious duties.
5243: saṅkrānti (CII 3; IA 17), same as saṅkramaṇa (q. v.). (IE 7-1-2), ‘twelve’.
5246: Sannidhātṛ (EI 27), official in charge of the receipt of various articles into the king's treasury, according to some (HRS); superintendent of the construction of the royal treasury, store houses, etc., according to others. See Artha-śāstra, II. 5; cf. I. 10 and 12; Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, pp. 138, 141; Vol. XI, pp. 93-94.
5247: sannidhi, cf. sannadi (SII 1), presence of a deity; the front of a temple.
5248: Sanniyuktaka (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVII, p. 11, text line 14), same as Tanniyuktaka or a mistake for it.
5249: Sanskrit, Anglicised form of Saṃskṛta, the name of the sacred language of the Indians.
5250: santa (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a fair or market day. (EI 14), name of a measure or a coin; probably, a small coin (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 309).
5252: santaka (EI 27; CII 3), Prakrit; ‘belonging to’; some-times Sanskritised as satka. Sometimes santaka (also santika apparently used in the same sense) has been regarded as meaning ‘a territorial unit’; supposed similarly to mean ‘a ser-vant’ (EI 23) or ‘an officer’ (EI 24).
5253: Sāntakika (IE 8-3), official designation of uncertain import.
5254: santāna (SITI), lineage. (BL), cf. a Jain religious teacher described as belonging to the paṭṭa of another teacher and the santāna of a third teacher. (IA 20), used in the sense of āmnāya or kula-krama. (EI 6), same as santānaka, santati; seven in number.
5256: Santānika-śaiva (SITI), Śaivas who belong to the line of ācāryas of the santāna-kuravar.
5257: santati (SITI), lineage. Cf. also sapta-santati (EI 14) and santānaka (under santāna).
5259: Śānti, a priest in a temple; cf. Tamil-Sanskrit Mel-śānti; also cf. Śāntikāra, of which Śānti seems to be an abbreviation.
5260: śānti (EI 33), a propitiatory rite; cf. śānty-āgāra.
5262: Śāntikāra (SITI), a temple priest; also known as Śāntiy-aḍigal and Śānti-śeyyān.
5263: santīraṇā, cf. artha-santīraṇā (CII 1), despatch of business.
5264: Śānti-vārika (EI 12, 30, 33), priest in charge of the performance of propitiatory rites or the priest who provides for śānti-vāri, ‘propitiatory water’.
5265: śānty-āgāra (EI 12, 30), room wherein a bath is taken with the propitiatory water after a sacrifice; the room for performing propitiatory rites. See Śāntyāgārika, Śāntyāgār-ādhikṛta.
5266: Śāntyāgār-ādhikṛta (EI 30), priest in charge of the room for the performance of propitiatory rites. Cf. śānty-āgāra, Śānty-āgārika.
5268: Shaonano Shao (EI 30), known from the legend of Kuṣāṇa coins; same as Sāhānuṣāhī (q. v.), Persian Shāhān Shāh.
5269: Sapādalakṣa (IE 8-4), name of two territories so called with reference to the theoretical number of villages in each of them. Cf. Pādonalakṣa.
5271: sapta-kṣetra (IA 19), Jain; seven spheres of action.
5272: Saptama-cakravartin (LP), ‘the seventh emperor’, i. e. the ruling monarch; according to the Abhidhānacintāmaṇi, the six older Cakravartins are: Māndhātā Dhundhumāraś = ca Hariścan-draḥ Purūravāḥ | Bharataḥ Kārtavīryaś = ca ṣaḍ = ete cakravartinaḥ ||
5274: Sapt-āmātya (EI 27), an officer in charge of seven depart-ments. Cf. Pañca-karaṇ-ādhikṛta, etc.
5275: sapt-āmbhodhi (EI 16), name of a mahādāna; same as sapta-sāgara.
5276: sapt-āṅga (CII CITD), the seven constituent parts of a kingdom, viz., king, ministers, allies, treasury, territory, forts and forces.
5277: sapta-sāgara (EI 24), name of a mahādāna; same as sapt-āmbhodhi.
5278: sapta-santāna (SITI), also called sapta-santati; merit equal to that obtainable through progeny from their performance of seven kinds of great deeds, viz. digging of tanks, hoarding of treasure, founding of agrahāras, erection of temples, creation of flower gardens, getting literary works written by poets, and the establishment of Choultries. An inscription (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, pp. 88 ff.) mentions the following seven meritorious acts a man ought to perform during his lifetime; viz. procrea-tion of sons, accumulation of wealth, planting of groves, help-ing people (Brāhmaṇas) to marry, getting poems composed, erection of temples and excavation of tanks.
5280: sapta-vidhi (LP), probably, seven kinds of defects.
5282: sārā (EI 9; LP), care; cf. etair = aṣṭabhir = goṣṭhikaiḥ … sārā karaṇīyā, ‘[this place of worship] has to be taken care of by the following eight trustees’. Cf. also Gujarātī sāravār. (EI 8, 11), supervision.
5283: Śarabhaṅga (IE 8-3; 8-8; EI 23), a leader of forces; an officer of the military department; possibly, a military governor; same as Persian Sarhang and Hindī Serāṅg; also spelt Sarabhaṅga and Sarobhaṅga; Wilson's Glossary explains Sarhang as ‘a com-mander’ and says, “but [it is] generally applied in India to the headman of a native crew, whether on board a ship or a boat; also to the headman of a gang of natives attached to artill-ery, dragging guns, or to the army in general, as tent-pitchers, and the like, or to the head of gangs of a superior order of labour-ers employed in public or private works, in docks, buildings, etc.’ Cf. Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., pp. 123, 166 (spelt Sarobhaṅga), Ind. Cult., Vol. VII, p. 309. Kane (Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 1005) is certainly wrong when he thinks that it may be con-nected with śarayantra and Śarayantrin (a title bestowed in Mithilā upon a very learned man who faced the ordeal of answering satisfactorily all questions on any śāstra put to him by learned Ācāryas and also the questions put by common people). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, pp. 95. ff. See Sarāṅgha, Sarāhang, etc.
5284: Sāradā, name of the alphabet which developed out of late Brāhmī and was prevalent in the Kashmir region.
5285: Sarāhang (IA 20), also called Sarang, Sarhang, etc. See Sarāṅgha, Śarabhaṅga.
5286: Śaraṇāgata-vajrapañjara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 317), ‘the impregnable shelter for one who seeks for it’; a subordinate title of the Kannaḍa-speaking area; used by the Sena kings of Bengal because they hailed from the same region.
5287: Sarang (IA 20), also called Sarhang, Sarāhang, etc.; see Sarāṅgha, Śarabhaṅga, etc.
5288: Sarāṅgha (IE 8-3), Persian Sarhang and Indian Śarabhaṅga, Serāṅg, etc. cf. Giligittā-sarāṅgha, ‘the chief of the army at Gilgit’, in the Hatun inscription of Paṭoladeva (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 228).
5289: Sarasvatī-bhāṇḍāra (EI 25; SITI), a library. Cf. Saras-vatī-bhāṇḍārika.
5291: śarayantra, Maithilī; test [prevalent in Mithilā] of the scholarship of one who is prepared to answer any question on any śāstra put to him by any other scholar or by the common people. See Proc. AIOC, Benares, 1943; Kane, Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 1005.
5292: śarayantraka (IE 3-1), same as sūtra; the string passing through the hole in the leaves of manuscripts for holding them together (Vāsavadatta, Hall's ed., p. 250).
5293: Śarayantrin (EI 35), one who has been successful in the śarayantra test of Mithilā. See śarayantra.
5294: sārayitvā (LP), ‘having finished’; cf. Gujarātī sārvuṃ, ‘to accomplish’.
5295: Sārdhañcara, Sārdhañcarī (LL), companion of a Jain monk.
5296: Sārdhaṃvihārin, cf. Sādhyavihāri (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 10), Pāli saddhivihāri; one's fellow-priest living at the same monastery; a fellow-student. Cf. F. Edgerton, Bud. Hyb. Sans. Gram. Dict., Vol. II, p. 593. See Sadhryagvihārin.
5297: Sarhang (IE 8-3; IA 20), Persian; see Śarabhaṅga, etc.
5298: śarīra (SITI), person; individual. (EI 24; ML), corporeal relies of the Buddha.
5299: Sarobhaṅga (IE 8-3), same as Śarabhaṅga or Sarabhaṅga (q. v.).
5302: sarṣapa, a small unit of measurement; sometimes specified as ‘red’ (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
5303: Sārthavāha (IE 8-3; EI 24, 31; BL; LL), a trader, a mer-chant; designation of a member of the mercantile community represented on an administrative board like the Pañcāyat.
5304: Sārthavāhinī (EI 1, 24), wife of a merchant (Sārthavāha) or a female merchant.
5305: sārtha-vahitra (IE 8-3), probably, a cart-load of articles for sale.
5306: sārūpya (CITD), assimilation in the deity, one of the four states of mukti.
5308: sarv-ābhyantara-siddhi (IA 19; SII 11-1), a fiscal term denot-ing full and complete right of enjoyment of agricultural income or internal revenue or taxes to be paid to the village authorities; cf. sarv-ābhyantara-siddhyā (IA 18), also abhyantara-siddhi.
5309: Sarva-daṇḍa-nāyaka (CII 3; IA 9; IA BL), official desig-nation; ‘lord of all the forces’; cf. Samasta-sainy-ādhipati. See Daṇḍa-nāyaka, Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Sarva-mahā-daṇḍanāyaka. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. VIII, p. 19; Vol. IX, p. 167.
5310: Sarva-deś-ādhikārin (AI 7), chief minister; see Deśādhikṛta, Sarv-ādhikārin, etc.
5311: Sarv-ādhikār-ādhikṛta (EI 31), chief minister or adminis-trator; same as Sarv-ādhikārin, Sarv-ādhyakṣa, etc.
5312: Sarv-ādhikāra-karaṇa (EI 30), probably, the office of the chief secretary, administrator or minister.
5313: Sarv-ādhikāra-niyukta (EI 32), official designation; same as Sarv-ādhikārin, Sarv-ādhyakṣa, etc.
5314: Sarv-ādhikārin (IE 8-3; EI 19; CII 4; HD), prime minister (cf. Rājataraṅgiṇī, VII. 568); minister plenipoten-tiary or viceroy; sometimes also called Senāpati, Mahāpradhāna, Hiriya-bhaṇḍāgārin, Mahāsāmanta, Sen-ādi-bāhattara-niyog-ādhipati, Daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāpasāyita, Amātya, Paramaviśvāsin or Mahāpramaviśvāsin, etc., additionally. (IE 8-3), a governor or chief administrator (cf. ‘the Sarv-ādhikārin of Hagaraṭage-300’).
5315: Sarv-ādhyakṣa (EI 24, 27; CII 3), literally, a general superin-tendent; probably, the chief minister or administrator; same as Sarv-ādhikārin.
5316: Sarv-ādhikṛta (HD), same as Sarv-ādhikārin, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, pp. 360, 362. See Mahāsarvādhikṛta.
5318: sarva-jāta, cf. sarva-jātaa-bhoga-nirastyā (EI 8-5), ‘with all kinds of the [king’s] rights renounced’.
5319: sarva-mānya (IE 8-5, SITI; CITD), a free tenure; a rent-free holding; land exempted from taxes; lands and villages fully exempt from all taxes. This corresponds to the iṟaiyili class of land mentioned in the Col13a inscriptions. Often this is associated with aṣṭa-bhoga, i. e. the eight forms of enjoy-ing the land. For a discussion of this form of land tenure, see JAHRS, Vol. X, pp. 123-32. It is noteworthy that even the so-called tax-free (iṟaiyili) lands paid to the king certain dues of the nature of taxes. See K. A. Nilakanta Sastri, The Col13as, 2nd ed., pp. 534-35. See sarva-namasya, etc.
5322: sarva-namasya (IE 8-5; EI 23; CITD), a rent-free holding; same as sarva-mānya, sarva-namaskṛta, namasya-vṛtti.
5324: Sarva-sainy-ādhikārin (IE 8-3), commander-in-chief; cf. Maneya-samasta-sainy-ādhipati, commander of all the soldiers in the royal household; also cf. Sarva-daṇḍa-nāyaka.
5325: sarvasva-haraṇa (SITI), forfeiture of one's entire property.
5326: Sarva-tantr-ādhikṛta (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV pp. 144-45), a superintendent of all departments; but tantra is used in South Indian records in the sense of ‘the army’. See tantra, Tantr-ādhikārin, etc.
5327: sarvatobhadra (EI 9), a building having doors on all the four sides.
5328: sarvatobhadrikā (LL; HA), quadruple image showing a Jina (or several Jinas) on each of the four faces; same as caumukha.
5329: Sarvavādināyaka (EI 10), explained as ‘superintendent of the intelligence department’; probably, ‘the chief court Pandit.’
5332: śāsana (EI 19; IA 20), order, a royal edict; any royal record (cf. vijaya-śāsana). (IE 8-4; EI 13, 23; CII 3; BL), a charter; land or village granted by a charter; rent-free land or village; some-times suffixed to the names of localities which were once rent-free holdings. See also tāmra-śāsana, a technical term for a deed of conveyance on copper-plates. (EI 9, 10), a doctrine; religion or religious faith.
5333: Śāsana-baddha (SITI), people bound by a royal charter; original grantees of a charter.
5334: Śāsana-bhāṇḍārin (EI 25), official designation; cf. Śāsan-ādhikārin, etc.
5335: Śāsanadevī (IA 18), divine female messenger of a Jain Arhat; same as Śāsana-sundarī.
5336: Śāsan-ādhikārika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 155, text line 85), same as Śāsan-ādhikārin, etc.; officer in charge of grants (or their writing or issue), mentioned along with Dān-ādhikārin, ‘officer in charge of gifts’.
5337: Śāsan-ādhikārin (EI 28, 31), officer in charge of royal grants or their issue, who was often the writer of documents; same as Śāsan-ādhikārika, etc.
5338: śāsana-paṭā (Chamba, etc.), charter; same as Sanskrit śāsana-paṭṭaka.
5339: śāsana-maryādā (EI 15), specification of privileges by a charter.
5340: śāsan-ārdhika (IE 8-5; 12, 28), name of a levy; probably, the half of the cultivator's share of the produce of the land in the gift village.
5341: Śāsayitṛ (EI 12; BL), one who is responsible for getting a royal grant executed; cf. Dūtaka, Lekhayitṛ, Ājñāpti.
5342: Śāsana-sañcārin (EI 8, 24), same as Ājñā-sañcārin; an official messenger.
5346: Şaṣghānī, coins issued by the Tughlaq Sulṯtāns, 4 jitals in weight (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 44); same as chagānī, equal to (3/4) of a ṭaṅka (ibid., Vol. XXII, p. 198). See śāśukāni.
5348: Ṣaṣṭh-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; HD), a collector of the king's grain share which was originally one-sixth of the produce according to many authorities; cf. Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇika. See Gho-shal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 246.
5349: ṣaṣṭhatapa (IA 19), Jain; a kind of penance.
5350: ṣaṣṭhī-amāvāsyā, cf. caṭṭī-amavāse (EI 5), new-moon follow-ing the campā-ṣaṣṭhī.
5353: śāśukāni, Indianised form of Şaṣghānī; also called śāśukāni-ṭaṅka. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, ‘The Śāṇa’, p. 5.
5355: śata, cf. ekādaśa-śata (ML), ‘one hundred and eleven’.
5356: Sāta (EI 32), abbreviation of the name Śātavāhana or Śātakarṇi.
5357: śataghnī (IA 7, 12), a gun or canon according to late works; a mechanical weapon placed at the gate of forts according to the Vasudevahiṇḍī (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, No. 1, p. 15). Seekālacakra.
5358: śatamāna, name of a coin; a silver coin weighing 320 ratis (rarely also 160 ratis); also called pala, niṣka, śukti, aṣṭamikā and nalā; wrongly regarded as 100 ratis in weight. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 41, 46-47. For śatamāna as a gold coin, see ibid., Vol. XV, p. 140.
5361: satera, sateraka, same as Greek stater; regarded as equal to two dīnāras (JNSI, Vol. XV, p. 153).
5362: satī (EI 6, 30; CII 3, 4; BL; CITD), literally, ‘a chaste woman’; really ‘a woman burning herself with her husband’. (EI 6, 30), self-immolation of a widow usually on the funeral pyre of her husband; usually spelt suttee in English.
5364: sa-til-odaka (IA 19), cf. sa-til-odakena vidhinā; same as udaka-pūrvam, etc.
5365: satka (EI, 1, 13; IA 17), Sanskritised from Prakrit santaka; ‘the holding of … ’, ‘belonging to … ’.
5366: ṣaṭ-karman (SII 1), the six duties of a Brāhmaṇa.
5367: ṣaṭpañcāśat, ‘all’; cf. ṣaṭpañcāśad-deśa = chappanna-deśa (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 217, note 7), literally, ‘fiftysix countries’; but really, ‘all the world’.
5371: sattra (SII 1; CII 3, 4), ‘a charitable feeding house’; an alms-house; sometimes used to indicate one of the five mahā-yajñas, usually called atithi. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 46, note 8. (EI 10, 19, 23), also spelt satra; hospitality to guests; one of the five mahāyajñas. (IA 15), a hall for the charitable distribution of food, etc. Cf. satra-śālā (SII 11-1), etc.
5372: satr-āgāra (LP), a house where alms are distributed. Cf. satra-śālā.
5373: satr-āgāra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); department of Dharmaśālās.
5374: Satrap (IA 20), Greek; same as Khshathrapāvan, Kṣatrapa, Sertīp.
5375: Sattrapati (BL), priest in charge of a sacrificial session.
5376: ṣaṭtriṃśat, literally, ‘thirtysix’, but actually ‘all’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 115). See aṣṭādaśa, ṣaṭapañcāśat, etc.
5377: ṣaṭtriṃśad-daṇḍ-āyudha (LP), thirtysix (really, all), kinds of weapons; sometimes enumerated as: Cakra pāsa mogaru gadā ghana tomara tīraha | sakati sūla trisūla vajra kātara karaḍaṃḍha || Paṭukaṭārī kaṃta sarasī ghaḍu avājī | kaṇīu churī khaḍga nāli golā nārājī || ṣaṃḍuṃ ṣapnu muṃsala hala sīṃgani pharasī gupati gaṇi | niṣaṃga śāṃgi aṃkuśa guruja kuhaka bāṇa batrīsa bhaṇi || Cf. Prācīnagurjarakāvyasaṃgraha, G.O.S., pp. 106-07.
5378: śāttvika-dāna (SITI), gift without the pouring of water and therefore not expecting any merit in return for the donation.
5379: Satyadharma-sthita (IE 8-2), ‘adherent of the true religion’; same as Dharma-sthita; epithet of a Kuṣāṇa king probably point-ing to his Buddhist faith.
5380: Satya-jñāna-dariśanigaḻ (SITI), followers of a sect of Śaivism; evidently those belonging to the lineage of Mĕykaṇḍār.
5381: Śau, abbreviation of Śaulkika or Śauṇḍika (A. R. Ep., 1953-54, No. B 117).
5382: saudha (IA 15), used in the sense of brahmapurī, ‘a Brāhmaṇa settlement’.
5383: Saugandhika, cf. Prakrit Sagandhaka (EI 18); a dealer in scents or superintendent of the perfumery.
5385: Śaulkika (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HD), toll-collector or customs officer; officer in charge of collecting customs duties; superintendent of tolls or customs duties. See Yājñavalkyasmṛti, II. 173; CII, Vol. III, pp. 50, 52; Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 246.
5387: Śaunika (IE 8-3), superintendent of slaughter-houses and the sale of meat.
5390: sauvarṇa (EI 19), name of a coin; cf. suvarṇa.
5391: Sauvarṇika (HD), cf. Prakrit Sovaṇika (EI 10), a gold-smith; the State goldsmith. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, pp. 144-45. See Hairaṇyika, etc.
5392: sauvarṇika (HRS), profits of the royal monopoly of manu-facture of gold and silver articles, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra.
5393: sava (IE 8-1), contraction of Prakrit savachara = Sanskrit saṃvatsara.
5394: śāvaḍi (IE 8-4), a subdivision; same as uśāvaḍi or cāvaḍi.
5396: Sāvu (EI 9; CII 4), a title; same as Sāhu (Sanskrit Sādhu).
5397: śaya (IE 3-4), derived from a Chinese word; paper.
5399: sāyana (CII 3), ‘inclusive of precession of the equinoxes’.
5401: śayanīya, a cot; cf. śayanīy-āsana-siddānnaṃ na dāpayet (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 171).
5402: sāyara (PJS), Arabic shāher; a tax on palm-tree juice.
5403: Śayyāgrāhaka (HD), explained as ‘the guardian of the bed-chamber.’ See A. S. Gadre, Imp. Ins. Bar. St., p. 72. Cf. Śayyāpāla, Vāsāgārika, Vitān-ādhipa.
5404: Śayyāpāla (EI 25; HD), officer in charge of the king's bed (i. e. bed-chamber); guardian of the bed-chamber. See Śayyāgrāhaka, Vāsāgārika, Vitān-ādhipa.
5405: seiā (IE 8-8), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit selikā (q. v.); cf. seigā.
5406: seigā (IE 8-8), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit setikā (q. v.); cf. seiā.
5407: Segāṇa (BL), official designation of uncertain import, found in the Chamba inscriptions.
5408: śeka (EI 11), same as Sanskrit śikya, a loop or swing made of rope and suspended from the ends of a pole placed on one's shoulder for carrying loads, or the load itself. Cf. saṃkācitaka.
5409: Sekyakāra (EI 12; BL), a brazier; secondarily, an engraver; cf. Bengali seṅkrā, a goldsmith.
5410: Selahasta (EI 11), probably, the collector of the king's grain share.
5411: senā-bhakta (HRS), contribution of oil, rice, etc., which the villagers had to pay to the royal army on march, as suggest-ed by the Arthaśāstra.
5412: Sena-bhoga, cf. Śeṇai-bhogam (SITI), an accountant. See Śāṇa-bhoga, Senabova.
5413: Senabhogika (EI 18; HD), same as Senabova, etc.; a clerk or an accountant-clerk. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 285.
5414: Senabova (EI 5, 10; IA 18; SII 11-1), a clerk; an account-ant; a village accountant; modern Śānabhoga or Kuḻkarṇī.
5415: Sen-ādhikārika (EI 23), same as Senāpati, Sen-ādhipati, etc.; a general.
5416: Sen-ādhipa (BL), ‘leader of forces’. See Senāpati, etc.
5417: Sen-ādhipati (IE 8-3; EI 23; SII 11-1), same as Sen-ādhikārika, etc.; sometimes also called Mahāpradhāna, Hĕri-sandhivigrahin, Kaḍita-vĕrgaḍĕ, etc., additionally. Cf. Mahā-senādhipati, Senāpati, etc.
5418: Sen-ādi-bāhattara-niyog-ādhiṣṭhāyaka (IE 8-2; EI 5), sup-perintendent of all appointments including those in the army.
5419: Sena-gaṇa (SITI), a division of the Jain community; also known as Sen-ānvaya.
5420: Senāgopa (LL), a general; same as Senāpati, etc.
5422: Senai-mudaliyār (SITI), Tamil; same as Sanskrit-Tamil Senāpatiy-āl13vār; name of the god Viṣvaksenai.
5423: Senaiy-al13ṅgāḍika (SITI), a class of merchants who follow the army with their merchandise; a class of cloth merchants.
5425: Senāpati (IE 8-3), leader of forces; mentioned separately along with Bal-ādhyakṣa; probably, a subordinate of the latter; the military governor of a district, according to some (HD); commander-in-chief (ASLV), also called Sarva-sainy-ādhikārin and Dalavāya, i. e. the chief officer in charge of the military department. See Bṛhaspati quoted by Viśvarūpa on Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 307; Ind. Ant., Vol. XV, p. 187. Puṣya-mitra, the founder of the Śuṅga dynasty, was called Senāpati even after his accession to the Maurya throne. See Sen-ādhipa, etc.; cf. also Anusenāpati (EI 18). (IE 8-3), sometimes called Mahāpradhāna, Bāhattara-niyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Paṭṭa-sāhan-ādhipati, etc., additionally.
5426: senāpati-pperuvilai (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; the sale of lands of a Viṣṇu temple executed in the name of Senai-mudaliyār, i. e. the god Viṣvaksenai.
5427: Senāpatiy-āl13vār (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; same as Senai-mudaliyār, i. e. the god Viṣvaksenai.
5428: ser (Chamba), also called seri; crown land; state demesne. (Chamba, etc.), a weight equal to 80 tolās.
5431: Sertīp (IA 20), Persian; same as Old Persian Khshthrapā-van and Indian Kṣatrapa.
5432: śervai (ASLV), Tamil; derived from Sanskrit sevā (q. v.); a service inām.
5434: sesi-biyyamu (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; sesi means the remains of flowers, raw rice and other offerings made to an idol or used in a śubha-kārya and afterwards distributed among the worshippers and attendants. The expression probably means raw rice over which incantations have been pronounced and which is thrown on the heads of the bride and bridegroom dur-ing the marriage ceremony and in connection with similar other rites.
5435: setikā (IE 8-5; EI 25), Prakrit seiā, seigā; a measure of weight equal to two handfuls.
5436: Śeṭṭi (ASLV), Sanskrit Śreṣṭhin; the leading member of a guild. Cf. Nagar-seṭh, Nagara-śreṣṭhin.
5437: Śeṭṭi-Pattaṇasvāmin (ASLV), designation of the president of a merchants' guild. Cf. Nagar-seṭh, Nagara-śreṣṭhin.
5438: setu, embankment; income or taxes resulting from it (Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 108-09).
5439: sevā, cf. Tamil sevai, śervai (SITI); service; inām for services; tax-free land given to servants for enjoyment in lieu of salary.
5440: Sevaka (SITI), a soldier; cf. sevaka-ttevai (SITI), expenses in connection with the supply and maintenance of retainers of chiefs and officers during their visit to a place.
5441: śeviḍu (SITI), Tamil; a small grain measure; (1/5) of an āl13ākku.
5442: Śāh (IE 8-2; EI 30), Persian; royal title; same as Old Persian Khshāyathiya. See Sāhī.
5443: śibara, sibara (CII 4), a farm-house. But cf. śaibara, śaivara.
5444: Siddha (CII 4), a person possessing miraculous powers; an emancipated person. (CII 3), ‘a perfect one’; the epithet of a class of Jain saints who are invoked in the plural. (LL), a Jain saint. (CII 4), cf. siddham (q. v.), used at the beginning of ins-criptions to ensure the success of the undertaking and meaning siddhir = astu, ‘let there be success’. Cf. siddhi. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twenty-four’.
5445: siddha, (IE 8-5), income from land under cultivation. See siddh-āya, etc. (SITI), also called siddhi; the right of cultivating land; one of the eight kinds of enjoying landed property; may be the same as abbyantara-siddhi. See siddha, siddh-āya, ūrdhv-ādhaḥ-siddhi.
5447: siddham (EI30; CII 3), literally, ‘success has been attained’; an invocation found in early inscriptions at the commencement of the text; used in the sense of siddhir = astu, ‘let there be success’; sometimes confused with the praṇava; generally indicated in later records by a symbol having several varieties; sometimes indicated by the letter cha. Cf. siddhi
5448: Siddhamātṛkā, name of the Indian alphabet which is deri-ved from Late Brāhmī and from which are derived North Indian alphabets like Nāgarī; wrongly called Kuṭila, etc.
5449: siddh-ānna (IE 8-8), cooked rice or uncooked food (cf. Hindī sīdhā).
5450: siddhānta (CII 4), ‘an established doctrine’; sometimes used to indicate the Śaiva doctrine or religion (SITI). Cf. Lākula-siddhānta (EI 32), doctrine of the Śaiva teacher Lakula (Lakulīśa).
5453: siddha-sādhya (EI 13), present income and the income that may accrue in future.
5454: siddha-sthāna (EI 22), the place sanctified by a holy man.
5455: siddh-āya (EI 23; SII 11-2; ASLV), fixed income; regular income; same as Tamil sidd-āyam, sometimes explained as ‘a tax’ (EI 27); probably, agricultural income. (SITI), a fixed assessment; minor taxes; minor taxes payable in cash in the days of the Vijayanagara kings; also written in Tamil as sidd-āyam, sitt-āyam. See pratiṣiddh-āya.
5456: siddh-āyatana (EI 33), cf. pūrva-siddh-āyatana (Buddhist); temple associated with a Siddha.
5457: siddhi (CII 4), emancipation; sometimes used at the beginning of documents to ensure the success of the undertaking, as siddham in early inscriptions, and meaning siddhir = astu. (SITI), same as siddham, the right of cultivating land. Cf. ūrdhv-ādhaḥ-siddhi-yutā (IA 18), together with income from horticulture and agriculture; cf. sa-bāhy-ābhyantara-siddhi, siddhi meaning ‘income’. (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’.
5458: śīghra-likhita, a document written in a quick hand or cursive characters (SII, Vol. XI, Part i, p. 29, No. 42).
5459: siglos (IE 8-8), name of the old silver coin of the Persians (86. 45 grains or 5.6 grammes).
5461: śikhara (SITI; CITD), top portion of the turret built over the main shrine and the gateway of a temple; the top of the gopura or vimāna of a temple.
5465: śilā-guṇṭha (EI 12), Sanskrit-Telugu; a pond with a demarcation stone.
5469: śilā-laṣṭi (CII 4), Sanskrit śilā-yaṣṭi; memorial pillar of stone.
5470: śilā-lekha (IA 30; SITI), writing on a stone; an ins-cription on stone.
5473: śilā-prāveśa (IA 9), laying the corner-stone of a building.
5474: śilā-śāsana (IA 30), a stone-charter; a document engraved on stone.
5475: Śilpin (EI 4, 8; BL), epithet of an artist or artisan; generally, applied to engravers of inscriptions.
5477: śilotara (EI 32), also called śilotarī, śilotra, śilotrī, śilot-tara; name of a tax or income; cf. śrotaka.
5482: śilvari (EI 23), Tamil; name of a tax.
5483: sīma (IA 18), used for ‘country’ in the areas on the banks of the Kṛṣṇā and the Godāvarī. Cf. Kona-sīma (EI 32), also called a deśa, maṇḍala, sthala, etc.
5484: sīmā (EI 11), five types enumerated by Nārada: Dhvajinī matsyinī c = aiva naidhānī bhaya-varjitā | rājaśāsana-nītā ca sīmā pañca-vidhā smṛtā (i. e. big trees or hills, rivers or tanks, under-ground signs and artificial marks made by men and by the king's order). Cf. Tamil śīrmai, śīmai (SITI), a territorial division; also called sīman.
5485: Sīmakarmakara (HD), officer in charge of boundaries or of boundary disputes. See CII, Vol. III, pp. 213, 216.
5486: sīman (IE 8-4; ASLV), Kannaḍa sīmĕ; a small terri-torial unit like a Parganā; the sub-division of a district; some-times used to indicate ‘a province’.
5487: sīmā-vivāda, cf. Tamil śīmai-vivādam (SITI), a boundary dispute.
5488: Śīmĕhabbaruva (ASLV), an officer associated with the ad-ministrative unit called sīmai.
5489: siṃhanikā, service rendered in lieu of taxes (Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 28).
5490: siṃha-pāda, cf. Tamil śiṅga-pādam (SITI), legs of a vessel or vessel-stand in the shape of lion's feet.
5491: siṃh-āsana (EI 29), literally, ‘the lion-seat’; the throne which was one of the royal insignia. Cf. siṃha-sthāna.
5492: Siṃhāsan-ādhipati (EI 25), officer in charge of the king's throne.
5494: siṃha-sthāna (LL), a lion-seat; same as siṃh-āsana.
5496: sindūra (IA 19), corruption of sindhura, an elephant.
5497: sīrā (IA 18), a land measure equal to four halas. See hala.
5498: Śiraḥ-pradhānin (ASLV), cf. Tamil Śirappradāni (SITI), a senior minister; cf. Pradhāni, Mahāpradhāni, etc.
5499: śiraḥ-sthāyin (IA 17), used in the description of a trial by ordeal with reference to the bearing of some sacred symbol or image on the head of the accused while undergoing it.
5500: sira-kaṭā, cf. sira-kaṭā tambā-paṭā (JBORS, Vol. XVIII, pp. 219-20), Oḏiyā; same as rakata-paṭā, Sanskrit rakta-paṭṭaka. See also rakta-mānya.
5501: siriḍika, siriḍikā (EI 32), name of a tax.
5503: śiro-varttanā (SII 2), top part of a Śiva-liṅga.
5504: Śīrṣaka (EI 28), village headman; same as Mutuḍa or Muḻuḍa of South Indian inscriptions.
5508: sītā (EI 31), cultivated land. Cf. hala. (HRS), produce of the royal farms, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
5509: sita-cāmara (EI 29), ‘white chowrie’; one of the royal insignia.
5510: Sīt-ādhayakṣa (CII 4), officer in charge of the king's Khās Mahāl.
5516: Śithil-ācārya (IA 19), Jain; an Ācārya permitting laxity of observances.
5518: śiva (IE 7-1-2), ‘eleven’. (SITI), title applied to a Śaiva devotee; often śiva, śambhu etc., are used as the ending of the names of Śaiva ascetics.
5519: śiva, cf. śrīvijaya-śiva-Mṛgeśavarman; used as an honorific. Cf. śrī, vijaya, vijayaśiva.
5520: Śiva-bhāṇḍārin (SITI), treasury officer of a Śiva temple.
5521: Śiva-Brāhmaṇa (EI 25; SITI), a Śaiva Brāhmaṇa; the priest of a Śiva temple; also called Ādi-śaiva.
5523: Śiva-drohin (ASLV), a sinner against the god Śiva.
5524: śiva-māna (EI 33), a measure approved by a Śiva temple.
5526: Śiva-pañcāyatana (EI 27), a Śiva temple consisting of five shrines.
5527: śiva-sthala (CII 2-1), probably, the same as dharma-sthāna, or a Śiva shrine.
5528: Śiva-tithi (EI 5), same as Śiva-rātri or Śiva-caturdaśī.
5530: skambha (LL), a post or pillar; cf. dīpa-skambha (LL), a lamp post. Same as Kannaḍa kamba, kamma. Cf. stambha.
5531: Skandaka (HD), a petty officer; probably the head of the village administration. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 175.
5532: skandaka (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIII, p. 69), an instalment; cf. skandha.
5534: skandhaka (EI 3; HRS), known from Gujara-Pratīhāra records; name of a tax; probably, a cess at a certain rate per shoulder-load.
5535: skandhāvāra (EI 29; CII 3; BL), camp; usually called jaya-skandhāvāra (i. e. the victorious camp) which indicates the capital of a king in some cases. Cf. Kannaḍa neleviḍu = Sans-krit sthira-śibira.
5537: ślotra (EI 32), same as śilotara, etc.; cf. śrotaka.
5539: smṛty-upasthāna, cf. satipaṭṭhāna (EI 5), Buddhist; four in number.
5540: snāna-yātrā (IA 9), festival of bathing the image of Kṛṣṇa on Jyaiṣṭha su-di 15.
5541: snāna-mahotsava (HA), bathing ceremony (i. e. birth-bath) of a Jina performed by Indra and other gods.
5543: śoḍaśī, śoḍaśikā (SII 4), name of a coin which may have been (1/16) of the standard coin in weight or value; cf. paṇa.
5544: ṣoḍaśin (EI4, 22; CII 3), name of a sacrifice.
5545: sodraṅgīkṛtya (IE 8-3), same as udraṅgīkṛitya; used in res-pect of a gift land.
5546: śoḻaga (IE 8-6), Kannaḍa; name of a land measure.
5548: soma-grahaṇa (SII 1), lunar eclipse; same as soma-parvan.
5549: soma-parvan (LP), lunar eclipse; same as soma-grahaṇa.
5550: Somaskanda, South Indian representation of Śiva along with Umā and Skanda.
5551: somavatī (IA 26), same as ba-di 15 falling on a Monday.
5552: soma-yāga (CII 4), name of a Vedic sacrifice.
5553: Somayājin (SITI), one who has performed the soma-yāga.
5554: sopāna (SITI), steps; stairs; a sloping roof; the base of the garbha-gṛha of a temple.
5555: Soter (IE 8-2), Greek; ‘saviour’; royal title; translated into Prakrit as Tratara = Trātara (Sanskrit Trātṛ).
5556: śoṭī (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, pot for measuring liquids like wine; a ladleful; name of a measure.
5558: spaṣṭa (CII 3), an astronomical term meaning ‘apparent’; cf. spaṣṭa-tithi, ‘an apparent tithi’, from which the mean tithi has to be determined.
5564: śrāddh-āṅga (EI 28), gift for the merit of a deceased person.
5565: śrāddha-kara, tax for performing śrāddha at Gayā (Rājatar., VI. 254; VII. 1008).
5566: śrāddha-tithi (CII 4), date on which the śrāddha is to be performed.
5567: śrāhe, also spelt śrāhi, srāhi, śrāhī, srāhī, ‘the year’ (pro-bably derived from Prakrit sarahi, Sanskrit śaradi, ‘in the year’); the period of 12 months. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 80, note 2; Vol. XXIX, p. 106; Vol. XXX, p. 161, note 12; XXXII, p. 233 and note 8.
5568: śrāhi, śrāhī (IE 8-1; EI 6, 23), probably, derived from Sanskrit śaradi = Prakrit sarahi; ‘in the year’; ‘the year’; used sometimes in place of saṃvat, but sometimes side by side with it. See srāhe, etc.
5569: srāhi, srāhī, same as srāhe, etc.
5570: Śramaṇa (EI 8; CII 3; LL; BL), a Buddhist or Jain monk; an ascetic.
5571: Śramaṇa-śrāvikā (LL), female disciple of Jain ascetics. Cf. Śramaṇ-opāsaka.
5572: Śrāmaṇera (EI 25), cf. Sāmanera (EI 2); Buddhist; a novice monk; cf. the feminine form Śrāmaṇerī.
5573: Śramaṇikā (LL), cf. Samaṇikā (EI 25), a Buddhist nun.
5575: Śramaṇ-opāsaka (LL), lay follower of Buddhist Śramaṇas. Cf. Śramaṇa-śrāvikā.
5576: Śrāvaka (EI 7, 8, 24; ML; LL; HA), a lay follower of Jainism or Buddhism; cf. the feminine form Śrāvikā, sometimes called Śrāvikā bhaginī in Jain records.
5577: śrāvaka (CII 1), ‘a matter relating to a declaration’.
5578: śrāvaṇa (SITI), also called śrāvaṇa-patra (q. v.), sale deed; a document; cf. śālāvaṇam (SITI), a sale deed (āvaṇa-śālāvaṇam).
5579: śrāvaṇa-patra (EI 30), a deed of declaration; a sale-deed. Cf. śrāvaṇa.
5580: Śrāvikā (HA), cf. Sāvikā (EI 7), Jain; a female lay wor-shipper.
5581: śrāvita, cf. rāja-śrāvita (EI 6; IA 19), decree; a procla-mation. (EI 28), religious instruction.
5582: śre (PJS; LP), contraction of Śreṣṭhin, ‘a banker’ or śreyase, ‘for the merit of … ’ (especially in medieval Jain ins-criptions).
5583: śreṇi, śreṇī (CII 3, 4; LL), Prakrit seni (EI 25); a cor-poration or guild; cf. śreṇī-bala, the army maintained by a guild.
5584: śreṇi-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of guilds.
5585: śreṣṭhi-jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya, wrongly read as śreṣṭha (LP), probably a mistake for jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-viśvamalla-priya; name of a coin struck by Śreṣṭhin Viśvamalla. See jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-viśvamalla (or śrīmalla) -priya.
5586: Śreṣṭhin (IE 8-3; CII 4; LL), a banker or merchant or the foreman of a guild; sometimes mentioned in the list of the king's officials and subordinates addressed by him while making a grant (Ep.
