Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 276). (BL), representative of the banker class in the council of the local administrators of a town. Cf. Śeṭṭi, Nagara-śreṣṭhin.
5587: śrī (CII 3, etc.), honorific prefix to names often rendered variously in English; e. g., in the case of paramount sovereigns and their wives by ‘glorious’; of feudatories and other ordinary persons by ‘illustrious’; of priests, teachers, etc., by ‘saintly’; of gods by ‘holy’; sometimes śrī is used before consonants and śrīmat before vowels. The honorific śrī is sometimes used in South Indian records along with the words vijaya or vijaya-śiva (q. v.). Cf. śrī-ni, Śrīcaraṇa, etc. (IA 17), cf. śrī-pūrva used for śrī-yuta; śrī is sometimes repeated for emphasis, e. g., ‘śrī 108’ is written to indicate the repetition of the word for 108 times.
5588: śrī-bali (SITI), daily offering of the bali service in temples; also havir-bali. Cf. Tamil śrī-bali-koṭṭuvār, a musical troupe playing on the instruments at the time of the śrī-bali in temples. (SITI), image of the deity taken round the temple when the bali is offered; the procession circumambulating the temple at the time of the bali service.
5589: śrī-bali-bhoga (SITI), land set apart to meet the expenses of the śrī-bali service in a temple; also called śrī-bali-ppaṭṭi.
5590: śrī-bhāṇḍāra (EI 33; SITI), the treasury of a temple. (ASLV), collective name for the trustees of a temple; same as śrībhaṇḍāra-vāriyam.
5591: śrībhaṇḍāra-vāriyam (EI 33), executive body in charge of the administration of a temple. Cf. śrī-bhāṇdāra.
5592: Śrīcandana, a title of nobility in medieval Orissa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVIII, p. 310, text lines 8-9). Cf. Haricandana.
5593: Śrī-caraṇa (IE 8-1, 8-8; EI 28), literally, ‘the honourable feet [of the king]’; the king; cf. Śrī-hasta, Śrī-pāda, śrī-ni.
5594: śrī-dvāra (EI 6), a special type of gateway like the makara-toraṇa.
5596: śrī-gośālā, cf. Tamil tiru-kkośālai (SITI), cow-stall of a temple.
5597: Śrī-hasta (IE 8-1, 8-8; EI 28), literally, ‘the honourable hands [of the king]’; the king; see Śrī-caraṇa, Śrī-pāda, śrī-ni.
5598: śrī-jñāna, cf. Tamil tiru-ñānam (SITI), sacred hymns sung to the deity in a temple during worship.
5599: śrī-kaṇṭhamaṇi, cf. tiru-kkaṇṭamaṇi (SITI), a kind of necklace.
5601: śrīkaraṇa (IE 8-3; EI 11, 21, 31; HD), the drafting of docu-ments; a scribe or scribe-accountant or secretary; the minister Hemādri was styled Sarva-śrīkaraṇa-prabhu (Hist. Dharm., Vol. I, p. 356, note 849). Cf. Karaṇa, Śrī-karaṇ-ādhipa, śrīsrīkaraṇa. (EI 23, 29, 30), record office; the record department; the department responsible for drawing up documents. (EI 30; CII 4), record officer; the officer in charge of drawing documents. Cf. Puravuvari-śrīkaraṇa-nāyaka (EI 21), official designation. Cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the income department.’
5602: Śrīkaraṇ-ādhipa (IE 8-3; HD), superintendent of the department of records; head of all the scribes or of all the depart-ments. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 17. Hemādri was styled Samasta-karaṇ-ādhīśvara or Samasta-karaṇ-ādhipati (Hist. Dharm., Vol. I, pp. 356-57, notes 850-51). See śrīkaraṇa.
5604: śrīkāra-mudr-āṅkita (LP), sealed with the syllable śrī.
5606: śrīkaraṇa-viditam (LP), ‘having informed the records office or officer’.
5610: śrīkhaṇḍa (LP), also spelt śrīṣaṇḍa; sandal wood.
5613: śrīmad-ādivarāha-dramma (EI 1), name of a coin, issued by king Ādivarāha (Bhoja I Pratīhāra, c. 835-85 A.D.).
5614: Śrī-māheśvara (ASLV), a Śaiva ascetic who is one among the authorities of a Śiva temple.
5615: śrī-malaya, cf. Tamil tiru-malai (SITI), literally, ‘the sacred hill;’ but really, the central shrine, generally of a Śiva temple.
5616: śrī-mālikā, cf. Tamil tiru-māḻigai-ppatti (SITI), small shrines or niches in the prākāra of a temple on the inner side of the com-pound wall. Cf. tiru-māḻigai-ppiḻḷai, the temple executive.
5617: śrī-mandira, cf. Tamil tiru-mandiram (SITI), a temple; also tiru-mandira-kkoḍi, cloth threaded round the flag-staff of a temple during festivals. See also Tiru-mandirav-olai, a secre-tary of the government; an officer entrusted with the duty of communicating the decisions of the king in writing; also Tiru-mandirav-olai-nāyakam, the chief secretary to the government; chief of the tiru-mandirav-olai department.
5618: śrīmal (CII 3; IA 13), prefixed, like śrī, to names of per-sons and also of places; often used before names beginning with a vowel.
5619: śrī-mukha (SII 12; SITI), royal order or charter; a letter from the king or a chief. Cf. Tamil tiru-muga-kkāṇam, expenses as wages, etc., paid to the person who brings the tiru-mugam (royal order) to the village.
5620: śrī-nakṣatra, cf. Tamil tiru-nakṣatra (SITI), natal star; annual birthday; a year.
5621: śrī-nāman, cf. Tamil tiru-nāma-kkāṇi, tiru-nāmattu-kkāṇi (SITI), literally, ‘the hereditary right of enjoyment in the sacred name’; actually, land or village, generally tax-free, endowed to a Śiva temple.
5622: śrī-nayana, cf. Tamil tiru-nayanam (SITI), an ornament made of gold or silver resembling the eye and put on the eyes of the idol; same as Tamil kaṇ-malar.
5623: śrī-ni (IE 8-1), abbreviation of Śrīhasta-nirīkṣita, ‘examined by the king’. See ni and Śrī-hasta, etc.
5624: Śrīpāda (IE 8-8), used to indicate ‘the king’; cf. Śrī-caraṇa, etc.; also Tamil Śrīpādaṅgal (SITI), an exalted personage; used as an expression of respect. Cf. Tamil śrīpadatāṅgikaḻ (SITI), vehicle-bearers attached to a temple, as supporting the feet of the god.
5625: śrī-paścima-mandira, cf. Tamil tiru-meṟ-koyil (SITI), sacred temple in the west; a Viṣṇu temple which is situated to the west of a village.
5626: śrī-paṭṭa (EI 15), royal charter or seal. (EI 2), diadem bestowed [upon a favourite] by the king. (Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 344), same as rāja-paṭṭa or paṭṭī (EI 4).
5627: śrī-paṭṭikā, cf. Tamil tiru-ppaṭṭigai (SITI), girdle worn by the image of a deity.
5629: Śrī-pṛthivī-vallabha (IE 8-2), literally, ‘the husband of [the goddesses] Śrī and Pṛthivī (i. e. the god Viṣṇu)’; title assumed by some kings of the Deccan probably claiming to be incarnations of the god Viṣṇu; often abbreviated as Śrīvallabha or Vallabha.
5630: Śrī-Rāma (ASLV), sign manual of some kings of Vijaya-nagara who often wrote Śrī-Virūpākṣa for the purpose.
5631: śrī-raṅga, cf. Tamil tiru-araṅgu (SITI), same as raṅga-maṇḍapa.
5632: Śrī-rudra (SITI; ASLV), also called Śrī-rudra-māheśvara; a Śaiva devotee; same as Śrī-māheśvara.
5633: Śrīsāmanta (EI 21, 26), sometimes a personal name (e. g. Sandhivigrahin Śrīsāmanta who was the writer of a royal charter) and sometimes a designation (as in Kaṃsāra-kulapu-traka-śreṣṭhin Śrīsāmanta-Svayambhū who was the engraver of the same charter). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 240.
5636: śrīvatsa (SII 2), mole on Viṣṇu's chest; sometimes represented in the shape of a crown as found in the Hathingumpha inscription of Khāravela.
5637: śrī-vijaya, cf. śrī-vijaya-Nandivarman, śrī-vijaya-Veṅgīpura, etc. See The Successors of the Sātavāhanas, p. 63. Cf. śrī.
5638: śrī-vijaya-śiva, honorific prefixed to the names of a few South Indian kings; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 152, text line 4; The Successors of the Sālavāhanas, p. 63. Cf. śrī, vijaya-śiva, śiva.
5639: śrī-vimāna (SII 2, 13), same as vimāna; central shrine in the temple.
5640: Śrī-Vīrūpākṣa (ASLV), sign manual of the Vijayanagara kings, Virūpākṣa being their tutelary deity. Cf. Śrī-Rāma.
5641: Śrī-vīthi-nāyaka, cf. Tamil Tiru-vidi-nāyakar (SITI), a metal-lic image of the deity for being taken in procession along the streets round the temple.
5642: śṛṅga (EI 14), mentioned in relation to a tank.
5644: śrotaka (IE 8-5; EI 32), a kind of rent; cf. śrotra, etc.
5645: śrotra (IE 8-5; EI 32), probably, a tax in kind collected from farmers by a lessee of State lands; same as Marāṭhī śilotara, śilotarī or śilotrī; cf. śrotaka.
5646: śrotriya (SITI), land or a village granted to a Śrotriya or Brāhmaṇa learned in the Vedas.
5649: Śrutimān (SITI), elders of a community looking after its affairs; perhaps adapted from Tamil Keḻvi.
5650: śry-ājñā, cf. Tamil śrīy-ājñai (SITI), royal order.
5651: śry-amṛta, cf. Tamil tiruv-amudu (SITI), food offering (mainly, rice) to a deity in a temple.
5652: stambha (BL), a tower. (LL), a pillar. Cf. skambha. (IE 8-6; EI 3), same as Kannaḍa kamma, kamba, kambha; a land measure equal to one-hundredth of a mattaru or nivartana. (SITI), lamp-stand or lamp-post.
5653: sthā, cf. paratra sthāpayitvā (LP), ‘by laying it out at in-terest’; yaṣṭi-pratiṣṭhāpanaṃ sthāpayitvā, ‘besides raising the pillar’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 136). See sthāpayitvā.
5654: sthaḻ (IA 15), a standard for measuring gardens.
5655: sthala (IE 8-4), shortened form of deva-sthala; sometimes suffixed to names of localities; also the subdivision of a district. (IE 8-4; EI 12, 18, 24; ASLV), a small territorial unit like a Parganā; a district or its subdivision. Cf. Kona-sthala (EI 32), also called a deśa, maṇḍala, rāṣṭra, sīma, etc. (CITD), a place, habitation; a holy place; a district. Cf. sa-jala-sthala (IE 8-5); the land [of a village]. Cf. Tamil sthala-kkāval (SITI), village watch.
5656: sthala-durga (ASLV), fort built on the plains.
5657: Sthala-gauḍa (ASLV), officer associated with the admi-nistration of the unit called sthala; cf. Sthala-karṇam, Gauḍa.
5659: Sthala-karaṇa, cf. Sthala-karṇam (q. v.)., a village official (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVI, p. 261).
5660: Sthala-karṇam (ASLV), an accountant-clerk associated with the administration of the unit called sthala. Cf. Sthala-karaṇa.
5661: [sthala]-patha-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of roadways.
5662: sthala-purāṇa (IA 30), a eulogistic work on a holy place, river, etc. Cf. māhātmya.
5663: sthala-vṛtti (EI 13), explained as ‘a tenure in which pay-ment of tax was made in kind from the produce’; cf. tala-vṛtti (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 273).
5664: sthalī (IE 8-4), shortened form of deva-sthalī; sometimes suffixed to names of localities; also the subdivision of a district (EI 11).
5665: Sthāmya (EI 24), wrong reading of Sthāyin (q. v.).
5666: sthāna (EI 8), residence. (IE 8-4; SITI), literally, ‘a place’; abbreviation of deva-sthāna or a temple; sometimes suffixed to names of localities. Cf. bhagavato … sthāne (Lüders, Mathurā Ins., p. 62, text lines 2-3). (LL), also sthānaka, a temple; cf. Sthānika, Sthānattār. (SII 1), a shrine; cf. mahāsthāna, a great temple. (IA 3), a Bhūta temple. Cf. tāna-mānam (SITI), dignity or honour attached to a status or office. Cf. siṃha-sthāna (LL), same as siṃh-āsana. (SII 11-1), cf. Kannaḍa thāna; name of a geographical unit.
5667: Sthāna (CII 4), a superintendent cf. Sthānapāla, etc. (EI 9), cf. ‘officer in charge of the sthānas.’
5668: sthāna-bhūmi (EI 24), land belonging to a temple.
5669: Sthān-ācārya (EI 5, 6, 16, 28), priest of a temple; the chief priest.
5670: sthāna-dāna (LP), allowing one to stand somewhere, i. e. allotting some land to one.
5671: sthān-ādhikāra (IA 18), office of the superintendent of a shrine.
5672: Sthān-ādhikaraṇika (EI 3, 6, 24), officer in the administra-tion of an outpost; see Sthān-ādhikṛta.
5673: Sthān-ādhikṛta (IE 8-3; EI 24), modern Thānādār; officer in charge of a police or military outpost; cf. Gaulmika. See Sthān-ādhipati, Sthānapāla, etc.
5674: SThān-ādhipati (CITD), same as Sthān-ādhyakṣa, Sthānapati, etc.; a local governor; superintendent of a place; a watch-man; a police officer; often also called Sthānika-dharma-kartṛ. (EI 24), officer in charge of an outpost.
5675: sthānaka (LL), same as sthāna, a temple.
5676: sthāna-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the public works department’.
5678: Sthāna-mahājana (EI 31), same as Tamil Sthānattār (Sanskrit Sthānastha).
5679: sthāna-mānya (CITD), probably, land granted by the ruler to his officers for their maintenance in lieu of salary.
5680: Sthānāntarika (IE 8-3; EI 23, 28, 29), probably, superin-tendent of encampment or transfer of the king's residence from one camp to another.
5681: Sthānapāla (EI 15; HD), officer in charge of a police out-post. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 149.
5682: Sthānapati (IE 18), a civil agent kept by the Nāyakas at the imperial court at Vijayanagara. (EI 18, 28), officer in charge of an outpost. (IA 18), designation associated with a religious office; cf. Sthān-ācārya.
5683: Sthānattār (SITI; ASLV), Sanskrit Sthānastha; managers of a temple; the temple executive.
5684: Sthānika (IA 12; ASLV), superintendent or manager of a temple; cf. Tamil Tānigar (SITI), temple executive; also Tānika-rāyar, director of the temple ceremonies. (EI 8), title of priests in Jain temples. (EI 28), an officer belonging to an outpost probably serving under the Sthānapati, or the same as the Sthānapati. (HD), an officer in charge of a ward of a city or a district. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, pp. 143 and 149. (HRS), according to the Arthaśāstra, (1) officer in charge of one-fourth of the kingdom; (2) officer in charge of one-fourth of a city.
5685: Sthāpan-ācārya (HA), same as Thavaṇī (q. v.). Cf. Sthān-ācārya.
5686: Sthapati (EI 4; BL; HD), a mason or architect. See Viṣṇudharmottara, II. 24. 39.
5687: Sthapati-samrāj (CII 3; HD), ‘the chief of architects’; the chief architect. See CH, Vol. III, p. 119.
5688: sthāpayitvā, cf. Prakrit ṭhapaīchaṃ (CII 2-1), literally, ‘having kept’; relly, ‘besides’, ‘in addition to … ’; cf. yaṣṭi-pratiṭhanaṃ ṭhapaīchaṃ (Sanskrit yaṣṭi-pratiṣṭhāpanaṃ sthāpayit-vā), ‘in addition to the erection of the memorial pillar’.
5689: sthāvara, cf. sa-sthāvara-jaṅgama (IE 8-5); the immovable belongings of a village.
5690: Sthavira (CII 3, etc.), a Buddhist priestly title; same as Pāli Thera; an Elder in the community of Buddhist monks; a senior monk. Cf. Thaira (EI 3), an Elder among Buddhist monks; also Saṅgha-sthavira (Lüders, Mathurā Ins., p. 190), ‘the senior of the order’.
5691: Sthavira-kalpin (HA), a Jain Sādhu whose practices are not so rigorous as that of a Jina-kalpin and are easier to practise.
5692: Sthavirī (LL), Buddhist; a senior nun; Pāli Therī.
5693: Sthavirīya, cf. Prakrit Therīya (EI 33), community of the Buddhist monks called Sthaviravādin.
5694: Sthāyin (wrongly read as Sthāmin in Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 145, text line 2), possibly, the permanent tenants of a village. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 234. Cf. Āsthāyika-puruṣa.
5695: sthirā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 181), a permanent endowment.
5696: sthira-śibira (IA 12), same as Kannaḍa nele-vīḍu; ‘a stand-ing camp’; capital; cf. jaya-skandhāvāra of the Pāla inscriptions.
5697: sthita (CII 1), same as upasthita, present. (BEFEO, Vol. XLIII, p. 6, text lien 15), same as pratiṣṭhita, installed.
5699: sthiti (EI 32), decree. (IE 8-5), regulation; see ācāra-sthiti. (EI 12), usage; practice [in respect of calculation of dates]; Mālava-gaṇa-sthiti-vāśāt=kāla-jñānāya likhiteṣu, ‘[in the years … ] written for the knowledge of time (i. e. the date of some event) according to the practice [of calculation] of the Mālava republic’; Mālavānāṃ gaṇa-sthityā yāte śata-catuṣ-ṭaye, ‘four hundred years … having elapsed according to the practice [of calculation] of the Mālavas.”
5700: sthiti-pātra (IE 8-5), same as ācāra-sthiti-pātra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169); a document containing regulations; see sthiti-vyavasthā, etc. Pātra seems to be used for patra.
5702: sthitipātra-vyavasthā (IE 8-5), same as sthiti-pātra or ācāra-sthithi-pātra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169).
5703: sthiti-vyavasthā (IE 8-5), same as sthiti-pātra or ācāra-sthiti-pātra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 169).
5705: Stratega (IE 8-2, 8-3), Greek Strategos (q. v.), com-mander of forces.
5706: Strategos (IE 8-2, 8-3), Greek; commander of forces, transliterated as Stratega (q. v.) in Indian records; a feudatory or gubernatorial title.
5708: Stry-adhyakṣa (IE 8-3; CII 1), superintendent of matters concerning the ladies of the royal household; cf. Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa, Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra, etc.
5709: Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra (HD), Prakrit Ithijhakha-mahā-māta, etc.; superintendent of the harem. See CII, Vol. I, p. 20. Cf. Antaḥpura-mahāmātra in the Masulipatam plates of Amma II (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXIV, p. 276).
5710: stūpa (CII 3; BL; LL), technical name of a type of Buddhist monument; a Buddhist structure enshrining relics. Sometimes the term ratna-gṛha (i. e. the house enshrining the three ratnas or the best amongst the three) seems to be used to denote a stūpa. (EI 2), a Jain religious establishment. (SITI), pinnacle of a temple.
5711: stupī, same as vimāna (IA 9), q. v.
5712: śu (IE 8-1; CII 3; LP), abbreviation of śukla-pakṣa or śuddha-pakṣa or the bright fortnight; a day of the bright half of the month; used in connection with di (e. g. śu-di), but some-times by itself; often written as su. Cf. ba-di.
5714: subhāṣita (CII 4), a pithy saying in a stanza.
5715: śubhra (IA 17), used to indicate the bright fortnight.
5717: śu-di (IE 8-1), abbreviation of śukla (or śuddha) -pakṣa-dina (or divasa), often written as su-di. See śu-ti.
5719: śuddh-āvāsa (IA 10), Buddhist; ‘pure abode’ being five in number.
5723: śuka-nāsa, cf. śukanāsi (Arch. Rev., 1960-61, Section III) literally, ‘a parrot's nose’ explained as ‘a gargoyle or the water spout in a building’ (Acharya, Ind. Arch., p. 169) and ‘a vestibule’ (R. Narasiṃhachar, The Keśava Temple of Somanāthapur, p. 3); but also as ‘the projection of the main body of the śikhara of a temple originally at the front-side’ (Kramrisch, Hindu Temple, p. 241); also called śuk-āṅghri. The Dīpārṇava (ed. Prabhāśaṅkar O. Sompurā, p. 116) has the following stanzas on the subject: agre kolī kapolas = tu śuka-nāsas = tu nāsikā | sāndhāre stambha-rekhā ca kartavyā madhya-koṣṭhake || prāsādasya puro-bhāge nirvāṇa-mūla-śṛṅgakam | tad-agre śuka-nāśaṃ ca ek-ādi saptam = udgamam || tasy = opari siṃhaḥ sthāpyo maṇḍapa-kalaśa-samaḥ | dvi-stambhaḥ śuka-nās-āgre vijñeyaḥ pāda-maṇḍapaḥ ||
5724: Sukara-kavi (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 231, note 1), epithet of a poet; cf. Āśu-kavi.
5726: sukhaḍi, sukhaḍī (LP), Gujarātī; also spelt suṣaḍī; a kind of sweetmeat; a reward.
5728: sukh-āsana (Ind. Ant., Vol. IX, p. 95), translated as ‘a palanquin’; enumerated as one of the five prasādas granted by a king to a subordinate. Cf. pañcāṅga-prasāda.
5729: sukha-saṅkathā-vinoda (IA 8), ‘the delight of pleasing conversation’; cf. ‘while he was ruling, with the delight of pleasing conversation, at the capital of Kalyāṇa’.
5734: Śulapāla (EI 11), probably, an associate of the courtesans.
5735: Sulatāna (BL), Indian modification of a title of the Muhammadan kings; same as Arabic Sulṯān. Cf. Sulitāna, etc.
5736: śūlavari (EI 25), Tamil; name of a tax.
5738: Sulitāna (BL), Indian modification of a title of the Muhammadan kings; same as Arabic Sulṯān. Cf. Sulatāna, etc.
5739: śulka (IE 8-5; EI 12, 23, 25, 30; CII 4; CITD), tolls; customs duties; octroi duties; taxes particularly levied at ferries and passes and on roads, etc.; cf. krīḍara-śulka (EI 5), name of a tax; also śuṅgam, śuṅkam (SITI), customs, tolls. (HRS), tax, probably identical with bali according to early authorities; ferry dues, tolls and transit duties according to the Smṛtis and lexicons; according to the Arthaśāstra, (1) duties levied upon articles imported into a city, (2) port-dues, (3) duty upon the sale of liquors, (4) customs collected by the ferrymen and boundary-officers, (5) duty upon mining products, (6) duty upon imported salt, and (7) duty upon animals intended for slaughter; according to Śukra, tolls and duties upon building-sites, etc. The Amarakoṣa explains śulka as ghaṭṭ-ādi-deya and Kṣīrasvāmin enumerates the dues as ferry duties, tolls paid at military stations or police outposts and transit duties paid by merchants.
5740: śulk-ādhikāra, cf. suṅk-ādhikāra (EI 5), ‘office for the collec-tion of tolls [of the Banavāsi District]’. Same as Śulk-ā-dhyakṣa.
5741: Śulkagrāha (HD), an official who collected tolls or cus-toms duties. See Śukra, II. 128.
5742: śulka-maṇḍapikā (EI 3, 9), customs house. See śulka-śālā. (CII 4), explained by some as ‘a market-pavilion’. (Ind. Ant., Vol. XI, p. 329 and note 31), translated as ‘the rent office’.
5743: śulka-śālā, cf. śuṅga-śālai (SITI), place where tolls are collected; a customs house. See śulka-maṇḍapikā.
5744: śulk-ātiyātrika (IE 8-8; EI 30), boundary-crossing fee; exit tax; cf. atiyātrika.
5745: Sumantra (HD), king's counsellor on matters relating to income and expenditure. See Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 114, note 150.
5746: sūnā (HRS), royal dues collected by the superintendent of the slaughter-house, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
5747: suṇḍaka (IA 19), meaning doubtful; probably, a bundle.
5748: suṅka (EI 12), a corrupt form of śulka often found in South Indian inscriptions.
5749: Suṅkapannāyadadhiṣṭhāyaka (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa-Sanskrit; superintendent of the income from tolls. See Suṅka-vĕrgaḍĕ.
5750: Suṅka-vĕrgaḍĕ (EI 19), Kannaḍa; official designation; Sanskrit Śulk-ādhyakṣa. See Suṅkapannāyadadhiṣṭhāyaka.
5752: śūnya-grāma, cf. ‘she made a further grant of five śūnya-grāmas’ (Arch. Rev.,) 1960-61, Section III, No. 44).
5753: Suṇyārā, Sunyārā (Chamba), a goldsmith; from Sanskrit Suvarṇakāra.
5754: Sūpakārapati (EI 13; HD), the chief cook. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, pp. 109, 115. Cf. Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ, Mahānas-ādhyakṣa, Ma(Mā)hānasika, Khādya(kū*)ḷapākika.
5756: suprabhāta (IA 12), name of the morning worship at the Rāmeśvara temple.
5760: surahī (HA), Sanskrit surabhi; inscribed stone with the representation of a cow with her calf and the sun and the moon in the upper part, the inscriptions usually recording gifts or donations or exemptions from obligations or taxes declared by kings. This indicated permanence and inviolability.
5762: Suratāṇa (IE 8-2; EI 12), same as Arabic Sulṯān; see Suratrāṇa, Sulatāna, etc.
5763: Suratrāṇa (IE 8-2; EI 4, 1, 13, 32; BL), variously spelt as Suritrāṇa, Suratāṇa, etc.; Hindu adaptation of the Muslim royal title Sulṯān; often adopted as a personal name. Cf. Hammīra. See Sulatāna, etc.
5764: Suravāla (EI 33), one who sets songs or musical instru-ments to tune.
5765: Sūri (EI 9), title of Jain religious teachers; often used as their name-ending.
5768: sūrya-bha (JAHRS, Vol. II, p. 287, text line 64), literally, ‘the sun's asterism’, the Hastā-nakṣatra.
5771: śuśrūṣā (CII 1), obedience; cf. dharma-śuśrūṣāṃ śuśrūṣatu, ‘one should practise obedience to morality.’
5772: suta (IE 7-1-2), confused with Pāṇḍu-suta and used to indicate ‘five’.
5773: Sūta, one of the king's high functionaries (ratna or ratnin); cf. Hist. Dharm., Vol. III, p. 111.
5776: sūtra (IA 20), a manual of religious rituals, etc. (HRS), royal receipts collected by the superintendent of weaving, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. (IE 3-1), same as śarayantraka; the string holding the leaves of a manuscript together (Vāsavadatta, Hall's ed., p. 250).
5777: Sūtra (PJS), abbreviation of Sūtradhāra, a mason.
5779: Sūtradhāra (EI 24; CII 4; BL), a mason; an artisan; an epithet generally applied to the engravers of stone inscriptions of the medieval period. See Sūtrabhṛt, Sūtradhṛt, Sūtradhārin.
5780: Sūtradhāra-pitāmaha, cf. pitāmaha (IA 19); ‘the very Brahman among the masons’; title of a mason.
5783: Sūtrāntika (LL), a Buddhist monk versed in the sūtra works. See Sūtrāntikinī.
5784: Sūtrāntikinī (LL), a Buddhist nun versed in the sūtra works. See Sūtrāntika.
5786: suvarṇa (IE 8-8; EI 28; CII 3), name of a gold coin and also of a weight of gold; equal to 16 māṣas or 80 ratis; also called akṣa, picu, pāṇi, kroḍa, binduka, viḍālapadaka, haṃsapada, grāsagraha and tola. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 46. (SII 13), same as Tamil kaḻañju.
5787: suvarṇa-daṇḍa (IE 8-5; EI 12, 28), tax on goldsmiths; same as Tamil taṭṭar pāṭṭam, etc., noticed in Appendix II.
5788: suvarṇ-ādāya (CITD), same as suvarṇ-āya. Cf. hiraṇya, etc.
5789: Suvarṇ-ādhyakṣa (EI 24), official designation; probably the same as Suvarṇavthy-adhikṛta (q. v.).
5790: Suvarṇakāra (EI 24, BL), a goldsmith; often the epithet of the engravers of copper-plate grants.
5791: Suvarṇavīthy-adhikta (EI 18), superintendent of the gold-smith's business. Suvaṇa-vīthī literally means ‘the quarters of the goldsmiths’.
5792: suvarṇ-āya (also called suvarṇ-ādāya); land revenue paid in cash. Cf. hiraṇya, etc.
5793: śuvāstiyam (SITI), Tamil; right of hereditary enjoyment.
5795: Svadeśin (CITD), often used with the word Para-deśin or Nānādeśin with reference to the two main communities of traders and merchants.
5796: sva-hasta (EI 23; CII 3; IA 8), signature or sign-manual. Cf. sva-hast-ākṣarāṇi (LP), a receipt. (Ind. Ep., p. 187, verse 77), used to indicate a grant of land because the donor's signature was required to be put on a deed of grant.
5798: svalpa (EI 24), small; sometimes prefixed to the name of a locality (e. g. Svalpa-Vallūra), etc., to distinguish it from others of the same name but styled ‘big’ or ‘medium’. Cf. Kṣudra-Dharmagiri and Mahā-Dharmagiri; Vaḍa-Hosa and Maṃjhi-Hosa (EI 35).
5799: Svāmin (IE 8-3; EI 24; CII 3; LL), royal title probably of foreign origin, assumed by the kings of Śaka-Kuṣāṇa ex-traction; adopted by indigenous rulers like the Śātavāhanas. Cf. Śāmi (SITI), the king. Cf. Vihāra-svāmin (founder or master of a monastery), etc. (EI 7), same as Svāmi-Mahāsena, i. e. Kārttikeya. (EI 23), designation of the member of a guild. (EI 5), cf. ‘the 500 Svāmins of Aiholĕ’; probably meaning the Māheśvaras. Cf. svāmi-vāram (SITI), land-lord's share; same as Tamil mel-vāram.
5800: svāmi-bhoga (EI 8; SII 3), ‘the master's share’; the land-lord's share.
5801: Svāminī (CII 3), a noble lady or mistress. Cf. also Vihāra-svāminī.
5802: sva-mukh-ājñā (CII 3), ‘the order or command from one's own mouth’; used with reference to the king's verbal order for the preparation and issue of charters.
5803: svāmya (SITI), ownership; right to property; cf. ubhaya-svāmya (EI 5), tejaḥ-svāmya; also mameya-svāmya (SII 11-1), tenure held by a Manneya.
5807: svarṇa, cf. śoṇa-vari (SITI), svarṇa-vari, explained as ‘tax payable in gold'; same as Tamil pŏn-vari; but cf. also suvarṇa-daṇḍa, profession-tax payable by the goldsmiths.
5808: Svarṇa-bhāṇḍārin, cf. Poṉ-paṇḍārigal (EI 33), members of the administrative council of a temple.
5809: svarṇ-ādāya (SII 1; SITI), ‘revenue in gold’; taxes pay-able in coin. Cf. hiraṇya, suvarṇ-ādāya, etc.
5814: svarūpa (SITI), an estate of the Nambūdris, royal per-sonages, etc., of Malai-nāḍu.
5815: sva-samaya (EI 24), explained as a Jain doctrine; the doc-trines of one's own religion.
5816: svasti (CII 3, 4), welfare; auspicious word used at the beginning of some inscriptions to ensure success of the under-taking; an exclamation used at the commencement of inscrip-tions. Sometimes used as a neuter noun, with astu in the maṅgala at the end of documents.
5817: svastika-paṭṭa (LL), slab with the representation of a svastika symbol.
5819: sva-tala (EI 11), surface of the ground [of the gift land].
5820: svatantra (SITI), a share; a customary fee; emoluments.
5821: svayaṃvara (EI 8), the bride's selection of her husband.
5822: śveta-cchatra (EI 29), ‘the white umbrella’; one of the royal insignia; same as śvet-ātapatra.
5824: śvetāmbara (IA 7), a Jain sect; same as Śvetapaṭa.
5826: śvet-ātapatra (EI 29), ‘the white umbrella’, one of the royal insignia; same as śveta-cchatra.
5827: svolikā-pāta, svolī-pāta (EI 1), meaning doubtful. Svo = kho?
5828: syādvāda (EI 3; SII 1), Jain; also called syādvāda-mata, syādvāda-vidyā; scepticism.
5829: Syāramallika (EI 33), probably Persian Sair Malik (i. e. Malik-us-Sai), collector or taxes, Sair meaning ‘tax’.
5831: Tad-āniyuktaka (IE 8-3; EI 23), official designation; same as Tad-āyuktaka.
5832: tadātva (CII 1), the present time; the time being.
5833: Tad-āyuktaka (IE 8-3; EI 6, 23), an officer who was a subordinate to the Āyuktaka; mentioned along with Viniyuktaka; cf. Tad-āniyuktaka, Tan-niyuktaka, Tad-viniyuktaka, etc.
5835: tad-bhava (IA 7), a word in Prakrit or the regional languages, which is modified from a Sanskrit word.
5836: Tad-viniyuktaka (IE 8-3), same as Tad-āyuktaka or Tan-niyuktaka.
5838: taila, oils; a branch of revenue according to the Artha-śāstra. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 90.
5842: Tailika-rāja (EI 23), ‘chief of a guild of oilmen’; desig-nation of the chairman of the oilmen's guild.
5843: Tairthika (EI 32), same as Tīrthika, a priest [of the non-Buddhists]. (IE 8-3), cf. Tūthika (EI 1; LL), ferry-officer or officer in charge of the places of pilgrimage.
5844: Tājika Tajjika (EI 23, 32), Tājiya, Tāyika; an Arab.
5845: ṭākā, Bengali form of ṭaṅka, meaning a silver coin (rupee) and also money.
5847: takṣ-ācārya, cf. Tamil tacc-ācāriyam (SITI), the status of the master carpenter; chief of the carpenters. Cf. tacc-ācāriya-kkāṇi, the right of officiating as the chief carpenter, as also the stone-mason of a temple; the land set apart for the enjoyment of the holder of that office.
5849: tala, cf. sa-tala (IE 8-5); surface of the ground.
5850: tāla (IE 8-5), a palmyra palm; cf. sa-tālaka as an epithet of a gift village referring to the right of enjoying the trees by privileged tenants in some areas.
5851: tāla (SII 2), Tamil; a dish. (EI 21; SITI), Tamil; the treasury
5852: tala-bhedyā (IA 18), word of uncertain implication; men-tioned with ghāṇaka, mallaka, vundhaka etc. (IA 18); cf. talabhedyā-ghāṇaka-mallaka-vundhaka-daṇḍadoṣa-prāpt-ādāya (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVIII, p. 83, text lines 19-20), epithet of gift village. See tala-bhoga.
5853: tala-bhoga (IA 7; SII 11-1), explained as ‘the enjoyment of sites of land’; really, ‘land granted for the maintenance of a temple at the time of its consecration’; same as tala-vāṭaka, tala-vṛtti, and probably also tala-bhedyā.
5854: Tāladhvaja (BL), official designation of the governor of a territory; same as Gujarātī Tāḻājā.
5856: Talaiyāri (SII 1), Tamil; same as Kannaḍa Talāri; a watchman. See Talavara.
5857: talaka (LP), ‘on the spot’. (EI 23), a territorial division.
5858: taḻāka (EI 14), same as taṭāka, taḍāga; a tank.
5859: tala-pada (HRS), known from Caulukya records; lands fully assessed for revenue, as distinguished from estates which were held on condition of service or for a reduced lump assess-ment; explained as Gujarātī talpat, ‘land paying rent to the government’ (IA 11).
5861: tāla-patra, Tamil olai (SITI); literally, ‘palmyra-leaf’; an order from the king or a person in authority. Cf. olai-ccāda-nam, ‘a document written on palm-leaf’; olai-ccampaḍam, ‘wages paid to the messenger who brings the olai to meet his expenses on the way’; also written as olai-ccambaḻam, olai-ccammāḍam, etc.; same as nirūpa-ccambaḍam; cf. olai-nāyaka, ‘the chief secretary or the senior officer looking after correspondence.’
5862: tāla-paṭṭa (IA 15), probably the same as tāla-patra, mean-ing ‘an ear-ornament’.
5863: Talaprahārin (EI 6), official designation; probably the same as Talārī or Kotwāl.
5864: Talāra (IE 8-2; EI 22; LP; BL; HD), administrator of a city or prefect of the city police; same as Talavara, Talārī or Kotwāl. Talavara of early South Indian inscriptions means a Rājasthānīya (a Duke or a viceroy) according to some commentators and the Kotwāl or a city magistrate according to others. A subdivision of high class Khatris of the Punjab is called Tālwār. Cf. Tala-rakṣa or Tal-ārakṣa; also called Ārakṣika and Daṇḍapāśika. See Bhandarkar's List, No. 579; IHQ, 1960, p. 266.
5865: talār-ābhāvya (EI 11), tax for payment to the Talāra; ac-cording to some, Talāra is the Kotwāl and bhāvya or ābhāvya is what is called saṃbhāvanā, i. e. pāghḍī, and talār-ābhāvya is the pāghḍī money given to the Kotwāl (LP).
5866: Talārī (IE 8-2), Telugu-Kannaḍa; ‘a village watchman’; same as Talāra.
5867: talārika (ASLV), the office of the Talāra.
5869: Talāṭī (Ind. Ant., Vol. XII, p. 165, noted 38), a stipendiary (i. e. not hereditary) village accountant in the Kannaḍa-and Marāṭhī-speaking areas.
5870: Talavara (IE 8-2; EI 20, 28), a title of the nobility or of subordinate rulers in some cases (a Rājasthānīya according to Vinayavijaya's Subodhikā commentary on the Jain Kalpa-sūtra); but the designation of the administrator of a city or of the police officer in charge of a city, according to some sour-ces (Hemacandra explaining Talāra as Nagara-rakṣaka); cf. Talāra, Talārī, etc.; also Mahātalavara. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 78), cf. Talavara mentioned in the list of royal officials.
5872: talavārikā, cf. Kannaḍa taḻavārikā (EI 1), the village-watchman's quit-rent; cf. Taḻavāra or Talāri (Tamil Talaiyāri), ‘a village-watchman’.
5873: Tālāvārika (IA 12), official designation; same as either Talārī or Talāṭī (a stipendiary village-accountant in the Marāṭhī-and Kannaḍa-speaking areas).
5874: tala-vāṭaka (EI 31), same as tala-pāṭaka or tala-vṛtti. But cf. tala-vāṭaka in tala-vāṭaka-vāstunā saha kṣetram, ‘a piece of land together with suburbs, gardens and homestead land’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 349, text line 18). The meaning here may also be ‘adjoining land’ which was probably the original implication of the expression.
5875: Talāvāṭaka (CII, Vol. III, p. 216; also p. 217 and note), possibly the superintendent of temple property (cf. tala-vāṭaka); same as Gujarātī Talāṭī (a petty revenue officer), accord-ing to some (HD).
5876: tala-vṛtti (EI 13, 15, 21, 33; IA 7; SII 11-1; SITI), ‘endowment of the adjoining land’; land granted for the main-tenance of a temple or deity at the time of its consecration; same as tala-bhoga, tala-vāṭaka, tala-pāṭaka.
5877: tāli, tālī (EI 1), a measure of liquor. (SII 3), the marriage badge; cf. māṅgalya.
5880: Tāmbūladān-ādhikṛta (EI 19), officer supplying betel bīḍās to the king. Cf. Vārgulika, etc.
5881: Tāmbūlaka-vāhaka (EI 28), bearer of the king's betel-box; same as Oḏiyā Vāguli. See Tāmbūladān-ādhikṛta, etc.
5882: Tāmbulika (EI 28), producer and seller of betel leaves.
5884: Tamil, name of an alphabet and language.
5885: Tammaḍi (CITD), Telugu; also called Tammaḻa, Tāṃbaḻi, Taṃbala-vāḍu and Taṃbiga; a Śaiva priest.
5886: tāmra (IE; EI 8, 23), same as tāmra-śāsana; a copper-plate grant; also land granted by means of such charters.
5888: tāmraka (IE; EI 1, 4), same as tāmra-paṭṭa; a copper-plate grant; also gift land.
5889: tāmra-patra (EI 23), also called tāmra-paṭṭa, tāmra-paṭṭaka; same as tāmra-śāsana.
5890: tāmra-paṭṭa (EI 19, 23, 24; CII 4; Chamba), a copper-plate charter; gift land. Cf. tāmra-patra, tāmra-paṭṭaka.
5892: tāmra-phalī (EI 22), a copper plate. Cf. triphalī-tāmra-śāsana.
5893: tāmra-praśasti (CII 4), culogy written on copper plates; a copper-plate charter.
5894: tāmra-śāsana (IE; EI 23; CII 3), a copper-charter; a techni-cal term for a deed of conveyance written on copper plates; also gift land. See śāsana.
5895: tāna (IE 7-1-2), ‘fortynine’; but sometimes used to indicate ‘thirtyfour’.
5897: tāṇḍava (CII 4), name of the dance of Śiva.
5898: taṇḍula, unit of measurement; half of a dhānya-māṣa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 48).
5900: ṭāṅk (IA 26), also called tāṅkī, etc.; same as ṭaṅka.
5901: ṭaṅka (EI 9, 20; CII 4; ML), name of a coin; cf. Vijayarāja-ṭaṅka, ṭaṅka issued by Vijayarāja; spelt often as ṭaṅkā and in old Bengali as taṅkā; same as śāna also called dharaṇa; a coin in general; regarded as equal to 4 silver fanams; name applied to both gold and silver issues 80 ratis in weight (JNSI, Vol. XXII, pp. 197-98); silver coins of the Delhi Sulṯāns--96 or 100 ratis in weight. See JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 42-49. Cf. śāśukāni-ṭaṅka, hema-ṭaṅka, raupya-ṭṅka; also ṭaṅka (LP), a copper coin equal to half of a pice. (Chamba), a copper coin equal to (1/20) of a Rupee.
5902: ṭaṅkaka (EI 19; CII 4; BL), name of a coin; a silver coin. Cf. ‘ṭaṅkakas stamped with the figure of the Bhagavat’ (Bhandarkar's List, No. 2033).
5903: ṭaṅka-śālā, cf. Tamil iṭaṅka-śālai (SITI), a mint.
5904: ṭaṅka-śālā-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of minting coins.
5906: Tan-niyuktaka (IE 8-3); an officer probably under the Āyukta; same as Tad-āyuktaka or Tad-viniyuktaka.
5907: tantali (IE 8-5), a tamarind tree; cf. sa-tantalika, epithet of a gift village referring to the right to enjoy such trees by privileged tenants in some areas.
5908: tantra (ASLV), army, government; cf. Tantrin in South Indian inscriptions. (SITI), army, mainly the infantry; cf. Tantrin in South Indian inscriptions. (CII 4), explained as ‘Home Affairs’. (LP), cf. tantre nirūpita, ‘officially sent’. (HIQ, Vol. XXXIV, p. 277), cf. Tantr-ādhikārin, ‘officer in charge of administration’, in the Bhāturiyā inscription of Rājyapāla. In this case, a person was at first a Mantrin, then a Saciva and finally a Tantr-ādhikārin. Cf. Sarva-tantr-ādhikṛta (EI 24), superintendent of all departments.
5909: Tantr-ādhikārin (EI 33), also called Tantr-ādhyakṣa, Tan-trapāla, etc.; probably, officer in charge of administration. See Sarvatantr-ādhikṛta.
5910: Tantr-ādhipa (EI 25, 29; CII 4), same as Tantr-ādhikārin, etc.; minister for home affairs, according to some. See Sarvatantr-ādhikṛta.
5911: Tantr-ādhyakṣa (EI 33), same as Tantr-ādhikārin, etc. See Sarvatantr-ādhikṛta, Tantrapati, etc.
5912: tantra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the political department’.
5913: Tantra-nāyaka (ASLV), official designation associated with tantra meaning the army or government. See Tantr-ādhi-kārin, etc.
5914: Tantrapāla (SITI), chief of the army. (IE 8-3; EI 33), probably, officer in charge of adminis-tration; cf. Mahātantr-ādhyakṣa, Sarva-tantr-ādhikṛta, Tantra-pati and Mahātantr-ādhikṛta, etc. (HD), an officer like the Chargé-d' Affaires, according to some; cf. Tantrapāla-Mahāsāmanta-Mahādaṇḍanāyaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 185; cf. Vol. V, p. 77). (Hyderabad Archaeological Series, No. 18, p. 34), explained as ‘an officer of the king's bodyguard or royal retinue.’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 77), explained as ‘a councillor.’ (SII 11-2), cf. Tantrapālaradhiṣṭhāyaka; also Tantra-pāladadhiṣṭhāyaka (A. R. Ep., 1958-59, p. 12).
5915: Tantrapati (IE 8-3); HD), occurs in the Rājataraṅgiṇī, VIII. 2322; explained as Dharm-ādhikārin, ‘officer in charge of the department of justice and charity’; see Bṛhattantrapati. Cf. the Muslim official designations Sadrus-Sudūr, etc., explained as ‘the chief judge and officer in charge of the king's charities’ (Journ. As. Soc. Pak., Vol. IV, pp. 53-54).
5916: Tantravāya (EI 24), a weaver. Cf. lunnavāya = a tailor.
5917: Tantrin (SITI; ASLV), a soldier; a trooper; a leader of the army; a temple priest; a weaver. It has been sup-posed that the Tamil words Kaikkoḻar and Aṭavi came to signify both a soldier and a weaver on the analogy of the word Tantrin used in both the senses. Cf. Tantrimār, members of the army corps; a class of persons who perform worship in temples; a priest.
5918: tanu (IE 7-1-2), ‘one’; rarely used to indicate ‘eight’. (Select Inscriptions, pp. 241, 245); one's own; see tanuvaka.
5919: tanuvaka (CII 2-1), Prakrit; used in the sense of svakiya; see tanu.
5920: tapana (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’ with reference to Agni; but ‘twelve’ with reference to ‘the sun’.
5921: tapasvin (SITI), an ascetic; a recluse; a religious mendicant.
5922: tāpa-traya (SII 1), the three kinds of pain.
5923: tāpita (EI 23, 24), ‘heated’ [for affixing the seal to a cop-per-plate grant].
5924: Tapodhana (CITD), in Telugu-Kannaḍa records, often used to indicate Jain monks; in Orissan records, a Śaiva ascetic.
5925: tār (SII 1), name of a silver coin, equal to (1/6) of a gold fanam.
5926: tara (EI 9), same as nilaya; the family aggregate of dwel-lings with some of them meant for servants and artisans; also a street or a hamlet. (HRS), same as tara-deya, ferry dues, as indicated by the Arthaśāstra. See tārya. Cf. taram (EI 7), revenue.
5927: tara-deya, ferry dues. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 78, 227.
5928: tarapaṇī (HA), a wooden water-vessel used by Jain monks.
5929: Tarapati (IE 8-3; CII 4; HD), officer in charge of the ferries; superintendent of the ferries; cf. Tarika and Tairthika; but see Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321, where Tarika and Tara-patika are separately mentioned, and Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, p. 306, text line 35 where Tarapati is likewise mentioned sepa-rately from Tarika.
5930: Taravara (EI 20, 25), same as Talavara (q. v.); official designation.
5931: Taravu-śāttu (SITI), an officer of the Col13a kings, possibly associated with taravu.
5932: Tarika (IE 8-3; HD), a ferry officer or one in charge of a ferry service. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVII, p. 321.
5933: tarika (HRS), same as tara; ferry dues.
5935: Tarkuka (Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 34, note 7), a supplicant; a beggar.
5936: tārya (HRS), same as tara; ferry dues.
5937: tata (IE 7-1-2), probably confused with tattva and used to indicate ‘five’.
5939: tāt-āmbā (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 261), the mother, step-mother or aunt of one's father.
5941: tathā-jñātīya (EI 8), used for taj-jñātīya (taj-jātīya; cf. jñātīya).
5943: tatsama (IA 7), a Sanskrit word used in the regional languages without change or with slight change.
5945: Taṭṭhakāra (EI 15, 28; BL), a brazier, cf. Ṭhaṭhara, Ṭhaṭherā.
5946: tattva (IE 7-1-2; EI 8), ‘twentyfive’; rarely also used to indicate ‘five.’
5947: tauṇḍika (IE 8-8), ‘biting of crops with the mouth’; cf. gavāṃ tauṇḍike.
5949: tejaḥ-svāmya (IE 8-5; EI 16), cf. aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya; tejaḥsvāmya is tejo-yukta-svāmya, ‘ownership endowed with full authority’, which resulted from the eight (i. e. all or various) kinds of enjoyment. See tejo-mānya.
5953: tejo-mānya, cf. teja-mānyam (SITI), the ownership of landed property with the aṣṭa-bhoga or eight (various or all) kinds of enjoyment; also called tejaḥ-svāmyam.
5954: Tĕlugu, also spelt Tĕnugu, name of a language and al-phabet.
5955: Tĕlugu-Kannaḍa, also called Kannaḍa-Tĕlugu; name of the medieval alphabet prevalent in the Telugu-and Kannaḍa-speaking areas.
5956: Ṭha (IE 8-1; LP; PJS), abbreviation of Ṭhakkura.
5957: Ṭhā (PJS), contraction of Ṭhākura, a modification of Ṭhakkura.
5958: thaḍa (LP), stem or trunk of a tree; a tree.
5959: ṭhaka, cf. ṭhakka (IA 6); ṭhaka-purisa is explained as ‘a trader’, and associated with ṭhag, ‘a cheat’.
5960: thākamāna (LP), remainder; what remains to be paid up; cf. thakalelī bākī in Marāṭhī. See also apūryamāṇa-thākamāna-drammāḥ, i. e. drammas (coins) which are not completely paid off and are still to be paid.
5961: Ṭhakkura (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 4; HD), supposed to be a title derived from a Turkish word (Tegin); occurs as a title in the Rājataraṅgiṇī, VII. 290, 706, 738; probably, a fief-holder; sometimes mentioned in the list of subordinates; generally used as a title of particular persons indicating their rank or office. The significance of the word possibly varied in different localities and ages. Its foreign origin is sup-ported by its unpopularity in the South. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 297; Vol. XIX, p. 243. (IE 8-3), probably a fief-holder; mentioned as Pātra. (EI 9), explained as ‘the lord-in-waiting’.
5962: Ṭhakkurājñī (EI 8; CII 4; IA 16), title of the wife of a Ṭhakkura; same as Ṭhākurāṇī in some dialects.
5964: Ṭhakura, Ṭhākura (EI 23, 33; CII 4), same as Ṭhakkura.
5965: Ṭhākura (LP), Gujarātī; often a member of the Koli caste of Gujarat, who generally tries to detect thieves, etc. (LP), Gujarātī Ṭhākor, the chief among certain tribes of Rajputs; a small chieftain.
5966: ṭhāmi (LP), a kind of earthern pot.
5967: Thānāpati (EI 30), same as Sthānapati; officer in charge of an outpost.
5968: Thaṭhara, Thaṭhāra (Chamba), a brazier or copper-smith; same as Taṭṭhakāra.
5969: thavaṇī (HA), a wooden stand used as a symbol for the teacher or the Tīrthaṅkara, a religious text or certain pres-cribed small objects being placed on it and worshipped by Jain monks; same as sthāpan-ācārya.
5972: ṭi (IE 8-1), abbreviation of ṭikar or ṭikkara, ‘a mound’.
5973: tiguḻa-daṇḍa (IE 8-5), name of a tax; see turuṣka-daṇḍa and āndhra-daṇḍa. Tiguḻa is the same as Tamil13. Tiguḻa-daṇḍa may also be ‘the Tamilian measuring rod’.
5974: ṭīkara (IE 8-1), same as ṭikkara; a mound.
5976: ṭikkara (EI 28), same as ṭīkara; a mound.
5977: tilamaka (CII 3; IA 9), a water-course; probably, a channel leading the waters from the hillside over the terraced fields.
5979: tīmmira (EI 11), a land measure; cf. timpira, etc.
5980: timpīra (IE 8-6; EI 23, 24, 29), also spelt timpira, ṭim-pira, etc.; a land measure mentioned in Orissan records.
5984: tīrtha (IE 8-3, 8-4; EI 3; SII 1; CII 4; LL), a place of pilgrimage; a holy place or holy waters; a bathing place; a flight of steps for descent into a river; a ferry; sometimes suffixed to the names of localities.
5985: Tīrthakara (BL), epithet of the Jinas; same as Tīrthaṅ-kara (q. v.).
5986: Tīrthaṅkara (CII 3; EI 9); epithet of the 24 great leaders of the Jain faith; propagator of the Jain faith or tīrtha; creator of the four sections, viz. monk, nun, layman and laywoman (sādhu, sādhvī, śrāvaka and śrāvikā); same as Jina; sometimes spelt Tīrthakara; also called Ādikartṛ.
5987: Tīrthika (EI 9), Buddhist; teacher of a religion other than one's own; a non-Buddhist (especially, Śaiva) teacher. (EI 32), same as Tairthika, ‘a priest’.
5988: Tīrth-opādhyāya (BL), title of a family priest at Jagan-nātha-kṣetra (Purī).
5991: tithi (CII 3; IA 17), a lunar day; one mean tithi is equal to 0.9843529572 of a mean solar day and night; the mean tithis in a solar year are 371, and 3 ghaṭīs and 53.4 palas; gener-ally the term tithi means the end of a tithi, not its beginning or duration, and the week-day of a tithi is the week-day on which that tithi ends; the tithis given in the Pañcāṅga are apparent, not mean, and they are intended to be given from apparent sunrise. Cf. Tamil tiyadi, tedi (SITI), a date. (IE 7-1-2), ‘fifteen’. (EI 16), same as mahā-tithi, an auspicious tithi; cf. saptamī called the tithi of the sun-god and aṣṭamī that of the god Śiva (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 168, note 4).
5992: tithi-bhoga (CII 3; IA 16), duration of a tithi.
5993: tithi-dhruva (CII 3; IA 16), constant of a tithi; a term denoting the number of complete tithis that elapse from the commencement of Caitra upto the tithi during which the Meṣa-saṃkrānti occurs. See tithi-śudhi.
5994: tithi-kendra (CII 3), anomaly of a tithi, expressed in tithis; an annual variation in the tithi-kendra is 7 tithis, 9 ghaṭīs and 42 palas. See kendra.
5995: tithi-spaṣṭa-kendra (IA 16), the apparent anomaly of a tithi.
5996: tithi-śuddhi (CII 3), the subtraction of tithis; a term de-noting the number of tithis that elapse from the commence-ment of Caitra up to the time of the Meṣa-saṃkrānti. See tithi-dhruva.
5997: tola, tolā, cf. Telugu-Kannaḍa tulā (CITD), weight of a rupee, taken as the unit of the system of weights; fixed at 180 grains troy by the British; also called suvarṇa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 46).
5998: tolaka, same as tola; equal to 2 śānas or 80 ratis; also called kola, draṅkṣaṇa, badara, kṣudraka, vaṭaka, etc. (JNSI, Vol. XVI, pp. 41, 44).
5999: torai (SITI), Tamil; a standard linear measure of four fingers' breadth.
6000: toraṇa (CII 4; LL; CITD), an arch; a gateway; an arched doorway; a portal; a temporary ornamental arch; also a garland in Telugu-Kannaḍa. Cf. toraṇa-kkāṇikkai (SITI), tax on gates or presents for decorating the village with arches.
6001: Traipiṭaka, cf. Trepiṭaka (EI 9), one versed in the three piṭakas, i. e. the three classes of Buddhist religious literature.
6002: Traipiṭak-opādhyāya (LL), Buddhist; teacher of the three piṭakas.
6003: Traipuruṣa (Hyderabad Archaeological Series, No. 18, pp. 34-35), same as the composite god Tripuruṣa.
6004: trairājya (EI 19), a group of three realms.
6005: trairājya-sthiti (EI 27), cf. trairājya-sthitim = ātmasāt = kṛtavataḥ, ‘of one who has obtained steadiness in the three realms.’
6006: Traividya (LL), Buddhist; teacher of the three piṭakas. (EI 16), cf. Trivedin.
6007: Traividya-sāmānya (EIZ23), same as Trivedin; cf. Cāturvidya-sāmānya = Caturvedin.
6009: Trātṛ (IE 8-2; LL), same as Prakrit Trātara, ‘the savi-our’; royal title of foreign origin; Greek Soter.
6014: tribhāg-ābhyantara-siddhi (IE 8-5), generally spelt tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi; the right to enjoy one-third of the revenue, the other two parts going in equal shares to gods and Brāh-maṇas. Cf. abhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-ābhyantara-siddhi, tribhoga.
6015: tri-bhaṅga (EI 17), pose in standing images with bends in three limbs, viz. the neck, the wrists and the knees.
6016: tri-bhaṅgi, cf. tri-bhaṅga; see Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 65.
6017: tri-bhoga (EI 16; IA 19), a joint tenure enjoyed by a private person, a god (or gods) and the Brāhmaṇas (cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 271). See tribhāg-ābhyantara-siddhi, etc.
6018: tribhog-ābhyantara (EI 15), same as tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi, tribhāg-ābhyantara-siddhi, tribhoga.
6019: tribhogya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 313), cf. gaṇa-bhogya.
6020: tribhuvana-vijaya-stambha (SII 1), a pillar commemo-rating the conquest of ‘the three worlds’, the conventional claim of a hero.
6021: tri-cīvara (EI 25), complete robe of a Buddhist monk.
6022: tri-daṇḍa, cf. Tridaṇḍin (IA 10); tree staves tied to-gether as borne by Brāhmaṇa mendicants.
6024: tridīnārikya (EI 15), same as traidīnārikya, ‘priced at three dīnāras.’
6027: tri-jagat (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’; but jagat sometimes also means ‘fourteen’.
6028: trika (HA), a group of three figures of the Tīrthaṅkaras.
6029: tri-kāla (SII 1; SITI), the three parts of the day, viz. morning, noon and evening [when worship is offered in temples]. (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’.
6030: trikūṭa (EI 3), a junction of three villages (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 34, note 3); same as trikuṭa or trikuṭṭa. Cf. tri-sandhi; also Telugu muggaḍa, ‘a junction of three or more villages’.
6032: tṛṇa, cf. a-tṛṇa-kāṣṭha-grahaṇa (IE 8-5); grass which the villagers were obliged to supply to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers.
6035: tṛṇ-odaka (IE 8-5; EI 12, 28), name of a tax or cess; the grazing tax.
6037: tripada (LP), the three chief account books, viz. rojmol, khātā-vahī and pāvtī-vahī.
6038: tripada-lekhyaka (LP), accounts book and receipt book.
6039: Tripāṭhin (EI 4, 31), same as Trivedin; epithet or family-name of Brāhmaṇas.
6040: triphalī-tāmraśāsana (EI 3), a grant engraved on three copper plates.
6041: tri-pīḍi-dāna (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 271), a grant to be enjoyed by three generations.
6042: Tripuruṣa (EI 33), a composite deity (tri-mūrti); a com-bined image of Brahman, Viṣṇu (represented as Sūryanārāyaṇa in Gujarat) and Śiva.
6043: trisahasra (EI 31), also called trisahasra-vidyā; certain sciences.
6044: tri-sandhi (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 34, note 3), a junction of three villages; cf. trikūṭa or trikuṭṭa; also Telugu muggaḍa, ‘the junction of three or more villages’.
6047: tri-sthalī (EI 21), the three holy places, viz. Gayā, Pra-yāga and Kāśī.
6049: triśūla, cf. tiriśūlam (SITI), trident; same as śūla.
6050: tri-tīrthī (HA), an image showing figures of three Jinas, usually one Jina standing or sitting in the centre as the main deity of the group and two others sitting or standing on the two sides.
6051: tri-varga (SII 1), the three objects of human life.
6052: Trivedin (EI 4), same as Tripāṭhin; epithet of Brāhmaṇas later stereotyped as family name.
6053: Trividha-kṣitīśa-cūḍāmaṇi (IE 8-2), epithet of a king pro-bably referring to the Aśvapati, Gajapati and Narapati types of rulers, i. e. those who were strong in elephants, cavalry and infantry respectively.
6054: troḍanikā (IE 8-5), same as troṭana; cf. karṇa-troḍanikā, ‘cutting somebody's ears.’
6055: troṭana (IE 8-5), cf. karṇa-troṭana, same as karṇa-troḍanikā.
6058: tukkhāra (CII 4), a Tokharian horse; cf. Tuḥkhāra people of the Purāṇas.
6059: tulā (IA 26), a weight [of silver]. (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; same as Sanskrit tola or tolaka; the weight of one rupee or 30 canteroy fanams; (1/3) of a navaṭāku; a measure or weight of gold and silver, being 100 palas or about 145 ounces troy. The tulā varied a great deal according to the age and locality.
6060: tulā-bhāra (EI 4, 17, 26; SITI), name of a mahādāna; same as tulāpuruṣa; weighing a king or an exalted personage against gold or other precious metals and stones and distributing the same to temples, etc.
6062: tulā-puruṣa (EI 29; CII 4), name of a mahādāna; same as tulā-bhāra.
6064: Tulu, name of a language which is written in Malayāḻam characters.
6066: tulya-meya (EI 7, 10; HRS), ‘what is to be weighed and measured’; same as meya in deya-meya; known from records like those of Harṣavardhana, in which it may be epithet of bhāga-bhoga or a separate item (Ind. Ep., p. 394).
6067: tūmbu (SITI), Tamil, a measure of capacity; cf. tūmu.
6068: tūmu (EI 27), a grain measure; cf. tūmbu.
6069: tūnk (HA), Jain; top of a mountain or hill on which there is a shrine or several shrines.
6071: Turaga-sādhanika (EI 25), the leader of cavalry. Cf. Sādhanika, etc.
6072: Turaka (EI 32), same as Turuka and Turuṣka; a Turk or Turkish Muhammadan; a Muhammadan.
6076: Turuṣka (EI 5, 17, 32), originally, a Turk or a Turkish Muhammadan; later, Muhammadans in general.
6077: turuṣka-daṇḍa (HRS; Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 196, Vol. XI, p. 21), name of a tax collected by the Gāhaḍavāla kings from their Muhammadan subjects or for defending their king-dom from Muhammadan attacks; cf. the danegeld in early English history. See andhra-daṇḍa, tiguḻa-daṇḍa, bhoṭṭa-viṣṭi.
6079: Tyāgī-ācārya (IA 19), Jain; an Ācārya who does not permit laxity of observances.
6080: u (IE 8-1), abbreviation of the land measure called udāna (q. v.).
6081: ubhaya, cf. ubhaiyam (SII 1), an offering. Cf. ubhaya-paliśai (SITI), interest in two ways, i. e. in money and in kind. (SITI), a tax payable in gold; probably the same as ubhaya-mārga or the tolls collected on the highways in both the directions, i. e. inward and outward. (SII, Vol. III, p. 209), a gift to a temple or monastery in Tamil records.
6082: ubhaya-mukhī (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 15, note 4), a cow in the act of giving birth to a calf; sometimes explained as ‘a pregnant cow’ (EI 6).
6083: ubhayamukhī-dakṣiṇā (CITD), some special kind of re-ligious present or fee; the gift of a cow at the point of giving birth to a calf (cf. ubhayamukhī).
6084: Ubhaya-nānā-deśi (SITI), the two divisions of the Nānā-deśi organisation, e. g., the Nānādeśi and the Citramel13i. (CITD), explained as the entire merchant commu-nity, i. e. including both the Sva-deśi and Para-deśi.
6085: ubhaya-svāmya, cf. ubhaya-sāmya (EI 5), probably, two kinds of ownership.
6086: ucaṭa (LP), impatience, anxiety; cf. Gujarātī uchāṭ.
6088: ucchanna (CII 3), corruption of utsanna; found in Sanskrit inscriptions. See JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, 1954, p. 204.
6090: ucchraya (Ep. Ind., Vol. VIII, p. 46, note 3), a shelter; same as pratiśraya.
6092: uchālaka-bhṛta (LP), loaded with uchālaka (Gujarātī ucāḻo), i. e. household furniture that can be easily moved about.
6094: udag-ayana (EI2 3), the winter solstice; same as uttarāyaṇa.
6096: Uḍaiyār (SITI), Tamil; literally, a possessor; a king or lord; the chief deity of a temple. Cf. uḍaiyār-śālai, the feeding house attached to a temple.
6098: udaka-dhārā, cf. udaka-dārai (SITI), [a gift given] with the libation of water; also referred to in Tamil as udakañśeydu and udakaṃ paṇṇi. See udaka-pūrvam, etc.
6099: udaka-pūrvam (IA 7), also expressed as udak-ātisargeṇa, ‘with libations of water’; refers to the custom of pouring water in the hand of the donee while making the ceremonial gift of an object which cannot be placed in the latter's hands. Cf. Dra-vyasya nāma gṛhnīyād=dadān=īti tathā vadet | toyaṃ dadyāt=tato haste dāne vidhir=ayaṃ smṛtaḥ || (Agni Purāṇa, Ch. 209, verses 49-50).
6101: udak-āsīhāra-kullaka, cf. sa-vanaspaty-udak-āsīhāra-kullaka-pānīya-sametā (IE 8-5), translated as ‘together with the fruit-trees and with the water-courses and channels’ (with the omission of the doubtful words).
6102: udamāna (IE 8-6; EI 29), a small land measure; pro-bably the same as unmāna and udāna.
6104: udapāna (CII 1; LL), a well or reservoir.
6105: udāra (CII 1), a person of high rank; a rich man.
6106: udara-bandhana (SII) 2), a waist-band; name of an or-nament.
6107: udaram-bharīṇa (IA 17), same as udaram-bharin, ‘filling the belly.’
6109: udāsīna, cf. udāsina-vāriyam (SITI), a committee which is neutral to both the parties; same as madhyastha or the arbi-tration committee.
6112: udbali, cf. umbaḻi (EI 13), umbaḻam, umbaḻikkai, umbaḻika (SITI), rent-free gift of land; land granted rent-free for the performance of service; same as mānya. See udbalika.
6113: udbalika (IE 8-5; CII 1), free from taxes; free from the obligation of paying bali probably meaning land tax payable in addition to the king's share of grains.
6115: uddātavya, ‘to be repaid’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 239); ‘to be handed over’ (ibid., p. 246).
6116: uddeśa (CII 4), a territorial division. (EI 14), cf. s-oddeśa (IE 8-5); space above the ground; same as ūrdhva.
6118: uddha-grāma (LP), the village of which the revenue is fixed in a lump sum.
6119: uddha-khila-bhūmi (LP), table land which is uncultivated (khila). But cf. uddha-grāma.
6120: uddhāra (LP), borrowed on trust or credit; cf. udhār. (IE 8-5), same as udraṅga; cf. Tamil uttāra.
6121: uddhāra-proddhāra (LP), taking on credit; cf. Marāṭhī udhār-pādhār.
6122: uddhārya (LP), ‘may be debited’; cf. Gujarātī udhāra-vuṃ.
6123: uddhārya-vyavahāra (LP), the business of lending money.
6124: uddyotita (EI 13), literally, ‘caused to shine’; actually ‘with repairs effected.’
6126: udgaṇanīya (LP), cf. Gujarātī gaṇī āpavuṃ, ‘the charge should be handed over.’
6127: udghāṭita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 20), same as utkīrṇa.
6128: udgrāh, cf. udgrāhayiṣyāmi (LP), ‘I shall get the revenue collected [from the country in this way]’; also udgrāhita (LP), ‘taxed’; udgrāhyamāṇa (LP), cf. Gujarātī ughrāvayuṃ.
6131: Udīcīpati (BL), literally, ‘the ruler of the north (i. e. the northern province of an empire)’; title of a viceroy.
6132: udraṅga (IE 8-3; 8-5; EI 22; CII 3, 4; HRS), explained as ‘the fixed tax’, ‘the land tax’, ‘the principal tax’ or ‘the tax on the permanent tenants’; generally mentioned along with uparikara, i. e. minor taxes or the tax on temporary tenants; same as kḻpta. Udraṅga may have been paid in grains at least in soem regions since the Audraṅgika (collector of ud-raṅga) is sometimes separately mentioned together with the Hiraṇyasāmudāyika (collector of revenue in cash). In one case, the land is said to have been granted after making it udraṅga, i. e. s-odraṅga. See s-odraṅga (IA 10), draṅga, uttāra. Cf. mah-odraṅga in pravartita-mahodraṅg-ādi-dāna-vyasan-ānupajāta-santoṣa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 118, text line 40).
6133: udraṅgīkṛtya (IE 8-3), same as s-odraṅgīkṛtya; used in respect of a gift land. Cf. udraṅga.
6135: udumbara (LP), ‘threshold’; cf. gṛh-odumbara-madhye, ‘into the house’; cf. umbara-bheda.
6136: udvasa, cf. udvasa-kuṭumbika (LP), cultivators who have come from outside and settled.
6138: udyāma (CII 1), used in the sense of udyama or exertion.
6140: ukka, ukkā (Chamba), the total sum; a lump sum.
6141: ukkoḍa, a kind of levy; probably, periodical presents; same as utkoṭa. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 56.
6142: ukkoṭa-bhaṅga, same as khoṭa-bhaṅga (q. v.) according to the Abhidhānarājendra, s. v. parihāra; cf. utkoṭa and ukkoḍa, periodi-cal presents (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 56).
6144: ukta-niyoga (EI 33), doubtful expression probably indi-cating an official designation. Cf. uttara-niyoga.
6145: ukthya, (EI 22; CII 3), name of a sacrifice.
6146: ullanbana (IE 8-8), a crime, the real nature of which is uncertain.
6148: Ullekhaka, engraver (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 203 and note 11). See Vilekhaka.
6150: Umarāva (EI 26; BL), title of a feudatory ruler; same as the Muhammadan title Umrah.
6151: umbaḻi (ASLV), Tamil; same as Sanskrit udbali (q. v.).
6152: umbara (IE 8-8), same as Prakrit ummara; threshold or door; cf. umbara-bheda, also udumbara and unmara.
6153: umbara-bheda (IE 8-5; EI 25), ‘violation of the closed door’; the right of royal officers to enter into a house with doors closed for realising taxes. This probably related to the houses of merchants who were away from their home-towns in the course of their business; cf. unmara or umbara; also prātibhedikā.
6154: umura-bheda (CII 4), mistake for umbara-bheda (q. v.); forcible entry into a house. Cf. unmara.
6156: uñcha, cf. uñcha-kara-bhar-ādi-vivarjita; tolls (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 89); may be collection of small quantities of crops (cf. prastha).
6158: uñchamanna (EI 26), used along with maṟumanna; a privi-lege of the donee of rent-free land; see uñcha.
6160: unmāna (IE 8-6; EI 15, 21, 29), name of a small land measure; same as udāna or udamāna (q. v.).
6161: unmara (EI 30), Sanskritised form of Prakrit ummara (cf. umbara); threshold. Merchants, who were often absent from home for a long time, were sometimes made free from unmara-bheda (entry into their house) by royal officers probably be-cause they paid their dues on their return from business tours. Cf. prātibhedikā.
6164: upa-dhā (CII 1), cf. hīta-sukham=upadadhyuḥ; to bring [welfare and happiness to the people].
6165: upādhi (SII 1), probably, a condition. Cf. opādi (SII 2), dues.
6166: Upādhyāya (CII 4), a teacher; epithet of Brāhmaṇas. (IA 19), Jain; an Ācārya who has the right of reading the sacred text, but not of explaining it. (IE 8-3; EI 7), epithet of teachers; mentioned as a Pātra. (CII 3), a sub-teacher who is the instructor in only a part of the Veda, or in grammar and the other Vedāṅgas.
6167: Upādhyāyinī (LL), a female teacher; the wife of an Upādhyāya.
6168: upaga (CII 1), suitable; cf. manuṣy-opaga, ‘beneficial to men’.
6169: upagata (CII 1), same as saṅgata, intimately associated; see upeta, etc. See Ind. Ep., pp. 161 ff.
6171: upa-han (CII 1), to harm; cf. upaghāta, injury.
6172: upakara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 106, note 5), cf. nikara and upaskara.
6173: upakārikā, probably, a territorial unit around the headquarters of an administrative unit (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 286).
6174: upakhila, cf. sa-khil-opakhila (Chamba), ‘together with fallow (khila) and partially fallow (upakhila) land’. See pakhila.
6175: upakḷpta (EI 15; CII 3, 4), a levy; probably, the tax on temporary tenants or the unfixed taxes or minor in-come; cf. sa-kḷpt-opakḷpta (IE 8-5), also kḷpta, kḷpta-kara, udraṅga and uparikara.
6176: upakrama-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the department of new undertakings.
6177: upakṣaya (LP), expense; ‘other expenses’; cf. s-opak-ṣaya, sañjāt-opakṣaya, ‘expenses incurred’.
6178: upakṣiti (IE 8-5; EI 33), probably, tax on inferior land; may also be the same as upakṣaya.
6180: upāna (SITI), the first moulding above the plinth, in the construction of temples.
6181: upanidhi (IE 8-5; EI 12), same as nikṣepa; cf. nidhi.
6183: upapātaka (CII 3), sins of the second degree.
6184: upapīṭha (SII 2), a lower pedestal; cf. pīṭha; also upa-pīṭhattukaṇḍappaḍai, the lower tier of the basement of a temple.
6185: Upapradhānin (ASLV), an executive officer lower in rank than the Pradhānīn.
6188: Uparika (IE 8-3; CII 3; BL; HD), a viceroy; the governor of a province. An Uparika was appointed by the emperor and he himself appointed the governor of the district (cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 130). He is sometimes styled Mahārāja and Rājaputra. Viśvarūpa on the Yājñavalkyasmṛti, I. 307, quotes a prose passage from Bṛhaspati where the re-quisite qualities of an Uparika are set out. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 123. The word literally means ‘one placed at the top’. (IE 8-3), cf. Auparika, a viceroy. Cf. Bṛhad-uparika (IE 8-3).
6189: Uparika-mahārāja (IE 8-3), an Uparika enjoying the title Mahārāja.
6190: uparikara (IE 8-5; CII 3, 4; HRS), explained as ‘ad-ditional taxes’, ‘unfixed taxes’, ‘minor taxes’, or ‘tax paid by the temporary tenants’; cf. s-oparikara (IA 10), sometimes called parikara (cf. sa-parikara in place of s-opakriara). See upri.
6192: Upāsaka (EI 3, 8, 27; CII 3), a Buddhist lay worshipper; a lay follower of the Buddha; cf. Upāsikā. (SII 13), a temple servant.
6193: upasampadā (EI 9; IA 22), the initiation of a Buddhist monk.
6194: upasandhi (SITI), intermediary service of worship in a temple, between the morning and the midday service.
6195: Upāsanin (EI 32), title or family name of Brāhmaṇas.
6196: upasanna, cf. kṛt-opasannā (EI 30); word of doubtful import.
6197: Upāsikā (CII 3, 4), feminine form of Upāsaka (q. v.); a female lay-follower of the Buddha.
6198: upaskara (HRS), known from the Kamauli plate of Vaidyadeva; probably meaning upakara (q. v.) or the appur-tenance to a tax (kara). Cf. nikara.
6200: upasthāna (LL), reception room. (HRS), a group of royal receipts arising from underhand methods of collection of the contributions in kind, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
6202: upatalpa (EI 8), the upper story [of a house].
6203: upāti (SITI), Tamil; also spelt opādi; Sanskrit upādhi; literally, obstruction; dues; anything payable as a debt or obligation.
6204: upātta, cf. sa-bhūt-opātta-pratyāya (EI 23), ‘together with the income derived on account of changes in the natural phenomena.’
6205: upāya (EI 6, 25), four in number; ‘four’. Cf. catur-upāya (SII 1). (SITI), probably, minor taxes.
6206: upayāta (EI 33), same as opeta, upagata, ‘closely asso-ciated’. See samupagata, samaveta, etc.
6207: Upayukta (HD), same as Upayuktaka, ‘a subordinate officer’. See Arthaśāstra, II. 5; Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 285.
6208: Upayuktaka (IE 8-3; HD), probably the same as Niyuk-taka, Viniyuktaka, Tad-viniyuktaka, etc. See Upayukta; cf. Yuktak-Opayukta (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 40).
6209: Upayuktika (EI 23), official designation; probably the same as Upayuktaka.
6210: upekṣā (CII 4), Buddhist; indifference; one of the bhā-vanās.
6211: upeta (CII 1), same as saṅgata; ‘intimately associated’; cf. upagata, upayāta, samupagata, samaveta, etc.
6213: uposath-āgāra (EI 23), ‘the uposatha hall’. See poṣadha, pauṣadha
6214: upri (IE 8-5), Marāṭhī; same as uparikara (q. v.), tax on temporary tenants, according to some.
6215: ūr (ASLV), the assembly of a non-Brāhmaṇa village, that of a Brāhmaṇa village being called sabhā or mahāsabhā.
6217: ūrdhva, cf. s-ādha-ūrdhva (IE 8-5), ‘[what is] above the surface of the ground’; same as uddeśa. Cf. ūrdhva-dina-pāṭikāyām (LP), ‘for the series of days afterwards.’
6218: ūrdhv-ādhaḥ (IA 16), explained as ‘what is above and below [in the gift land]’; cf. ūrdhv-ādhaḥ-siddhi-yutā (IA 18), ‘with income from the produce above and below the surface of the ground’; same as s-ādha-ūrdhva, epithet of the gift land.
6220: ūrdhvayita, cf. Prakrit ubhayita (EI 20), raised. See ūrdhvita.
6221: ūrdhvita, Prakrit ubhayita (Sel. Ins., p. 222), raised, contributed. See ūrdhvayita.
6222: Ur-gāmuṇḍa (IA 12), Kannaḍa; official designation; cf. Gāmuṇḍa.
6223: ūrṇa (EI 8), a mark between the brows of the Buddha.
6224: ūrṇa-sthāna (IE 8-3), a wool factory. Cf. Aurṇasthānika, officer in charge of the ūrṇā-sthānas (Select Inscriptions, p. 360, text line 4).
6225: Uroḍĕ (IA 8), Kannaḍa; the village headman; cf. Uroḍĕya.
6226: Uroḍĕya (IA 12), Kannaḍa; official designation; cf. Uroḍĕ.
6227: ūr-paddinkāḍi (EI 28), name of a rural tax.
6229: uṣara, cf. sa-gartt-oṣara (IE 8-5); a saline spot or barren land.
6230: uśāvaḍi (IE 8-4; SITI), a subdivision of the district; same as śāvaḍi or cāvaḍi.
6232: uṣṇiṣa, cf. Prakrit uṃnisa (EI 20; LL), a coping stone. (EI 8), protuberance of the Buddha's skull.
6233: utkalita, cf. kaṭakam=utkalitam (IA 14, 30), ‘the camp was pitched’.
6234: utkara (IE 8-5), probably, minor taxes; but see kāru-kara. Cf. upakara, nikara, etc. But see also Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 47.
6236: utkarṣa (CII 1), used in the sense of utkṛṣṭa.
6238: utkheṭana (EI 32; HRS), known from certain records from Assam; explained as an impost levied upon the villagers on specified occasions; probably, the trouble of free labour. Cf. Utkheṭayitā, Autkheṭika.
6239: Utkheṭayitā (EI 12; BL; HRS), known from certain Assam records; explained as a tax-collector; officer in charge of utkheṭana (q. v.); same as Autkheṭika.
6240: utkīrṇa (CII 3), ‘engraved’; a technical expression for the actual engraving of an inscription on copper or stone; some-times indicated by the word udghāṭita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 20) and ghaṭita (Ind. Ant., Vol. XII, p. 121). See Ullekhaka, likhita.
6241: utkoṭa (IE 8-5, 8-8; EI 33), Prakrit ukkoḍa; a levy; cus-tomary presents to be made on occasions to the king or land-lord and others. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 56.
6242: ut-kṝ, ‘to engrave’; cf. Prakrit kaṇḍāra, used in some Kannaḍa inscriptions (Bul. Dec. Col. Res. Inst., Vol. XI, 1950, pp. 170-71). Cf. utkīrṇa, udghāṭita, Ullekhaka, Vilekhaka.
6243: utkṛṣṭi (IE 8-8; EI 30), same as Prakrit ukkuṭṭhī (q. v.), Sanskrit utkrośa; wailing.
6246: utpadyamāna-viṣṭika (CII 4), ‘with the right to unpaid labour as occasion may arise’; a privilege attached to gift lands.
6247: utpanna, decided or ascertained (Select Inscriptions, pp. 284, 286); same as pratipanna; cf. pratipad.
6248: ut-pāṭ (LP), Gujarātī upāḍavuṃ; cf. Vaidyanātha-patram= utpāṭayati, ‘takes a bilva-patra of the god Vaidyanātha (Śiva)’, i. e. swears.
6250: utpaṭṭa, cf. upaṭṭa (EI 13), abundance; exuberance or overflowing [especially of rich dishes at a feast].
6251: utpatti (EI 12), cf. samast-otpatti-sahita, ‘together with all the produce (or income)’.
6252: utsāha (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 189), generous gift, bounty.
6254: utsaṅga (HRS), extra cess levied upon villagers and citizens on occasions of festival events, such as the birth of a prince, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
6255: utsarpaṇa, cf. pañca-mahāyajña-kriy-otsarpaṇ-ārtham (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 279, text lines 64-65).
6257: utsṛta (CII 1) = ucchrita, man of a high position; a rich man.
6259: uttama-dāni (SITI), a gift made without expecting any merit for the same; a superior kind of gift.
6262: uttāna-dvādaśi (SITI), twelfth day of the bright fortnight in the month of Kārttigai when the god Viṣṇu is believed to wake up from his sleep; see utthāna-dvādaśī.
6263: uttara, cf. uttarāṇi (LP), same as uttar-ākṣarāṇi. See akṣara.
6264: uttāra (SITI), a regular fixed payment; same as uddhāra.
6266: Uttarakulika-vārika (IE 8-8), an official designation of uncertain import. See Vārika.
6271: uttar-āyaṇa (IA 17; SII 1), the winter solstice; the period during which the sun gradually moves from south to north; cf. dakṣiṇ-āyana.
6273: utthāna-dvādaśī (Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, pp. 163, 167, 169), name of a tithi (EI 9); twelfth day of the bright fort-night in the month of Kārttigai when the god Viṣṇu is believ-ed to wake up from his sleep (SITI).
6274: utthāya, ‘of one's own accord’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 248).
6276: uttiram (SII 2), the projecting part of a wall.
6277: uvaṭaka (EI 1), probably, a verandah, porch or vesti-bule; cf. Marāṭhī oṭī.
6278: va (IE 8-1), abbreviation of vaḍḍavāra (Saturday or Thursday).
6279: va (CII 3; IA 8-1), an abbreviation of vadya or ‘the dark fortnight’ or else a substitute for ba (abbreviation of bahula) used in connection with di; see ba-di, va-di.
6280: va, vā (IE 8-1), abbreviation of Prakrit vassa or vāsa-Sanskrit varṣā, the rainy season.
6281: vā (IE 8-1), abbreviation of vāra. Cf. vā-bhū, vā-ṭī. (LP), abbreviation of Vāṇija, a merchant.
6285: Vacanakāra (EI 23), an author of vacanas or sayings; cf. subhāṣita.
6286: vācanika, cf. rāja-vāchanika (CII 1), a royal order.
6287: vaco-gupti (CII 1), restraint in the matter of speech.
6288: vāḍa (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a street, a range of houses. (EI 11), a ward. (IA 7), also vāḍi; often suffixed to geographical names. (CII 4), name of a tax.
6289: vāḍa, vāḍā (IE 8-4), corrupt forms of pāṭaka, ‘part of a village’; in soem dialects, also ‘a village’; often suffixed to the names of localities.
6290: Vaḍaharaka (EI 11), same as Marvāḏī (Marwari) Baḍero; an old man.
6291: Vaḍḍ-ācārya (SII 11-1), Sanskrit Vṛddh-ācārya or Bṛhad-ācārya; designation of a Jain teacher.
6292: vaḍḍa-vāra (EI 13; CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa;' Satur-day or Thursday (A. Venkatasubbiah, Some Śaka Dates in Inscriptions, pp. 57. ff.); same as bṛha-vāra. The word in the Telugu part of an inscription is explained as śanaiścara-vāra in the Sanskrit portion of the said record; sometimes wrongly supposed to stand for some other day, e. g. Friday (IA 23) or Sunday (Venkatasubbiah, op. cit., p. 58). Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 147; XIII, p. 16; Vol. XXXI, p. 100, note 1; Vol. XXXIII, p. 1, note 2; Ind. Ant., Vol. XXII, pp. 111, 251-52; XXIII, p. 168. Vaḍḍa=vṛddha or bṛhat.
6293: Vaḍḍa-vyavahāri (SITI; ASLV), the leader of a merchant guild; a banker; the principal money-changer; chief of the Nānādeśi (non-local) merchants. Cf. Mahāvaḍḍavyavahāri.
6297: vāḍhaḍhā (IA 15), a doubtful word probably meaning ‘a drum’.
6298: vadhri-kukkuṭa (IA 18, CII 1), Prakrit vadhi-kukuṭa; a capon; also Sanskritised as vṛddhi-kukkuṭa.
6299: vadhū, one's own wife; one's son's wife. (putra-vadhū)
6300: va-di (IE 8-1), abbreviation of vadya-pakṣa-dina or a mistake for ba-di (q. v.).
6301: vāḍi (IA 7), same as vāḍa; often suffixed to geographical names.
6303: Vādya-mahārāja, cf. Tamil Vācciya-mārāyaṉ (SITI), the head musician or the chief Meḻakāraṉ of a temple or palace; title conferred by the king on an expert in instrumental music.
6305: Vāgulī (EI 28), Oḏiyā; also written Bāgulī; the king's betel-bearer; same as Vārgulika, etc.
6306: Vāgulika, Vāgūlika (CII 4; BL), explained by some as ‘a seller of betel-leaves’; the bearer of the betel-box of an Orissan ruler; same as Vārgulika, etc.
6308: vaha, cf. a-vaha (IE 8-5); [free] carrying of loads [which the villagers had to provide for the touring officers of the king or land-lord]; may also be a horse for the use of the officers. (EI 31; IA 18; CII 4), a streamlet; a water-channel. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 177), a common highway.
6310: Vāhaka (EI 3), probably, a driver or attendant of cattle.
6312: Vāhali (BL), official designation explained as ‘the lord of horses’.
6313: vahamāna (LP), cf. vahamāna-hala-balīvarda, ‘bullocks used in ploughing land’; vahamāna-samakara-bhūmi in which vahamāna means ‘[the land that is] being ploughed’. (LP), travelling.
6314: vāhana (LP), a load-carrier; a cart, ship, etc. See vahitra.
6315: Vāha-nāyaka (EI 23), official designation; probably, ‘the officer in charge of the king's Khās Mahāls’ (from vāha, a plough); may also be the superintendent of transport. See vāhoṭaka.
6317: Vāhinīpati (EI 28; IA 10), leader of forces; a general; cf. Senāpati, etc.
6319: vahitra (IE 8-5, 8-8; EI 30), boat or any large carrier like a cart; see vāhana. Cf. sārtha-vahitreṣu praveśe nirgame ca pratyekaṃ rūpakaḥ devasya yātr-otsave dātavyaḥ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 232). (IE 8-8), cf. bhāṇḍa-bhṛta-vahitra, ‘a wagon full of pots or jars’.
6321: vāhoṭaka (LP), either Gujarātī vighoṭi, an assessment of land collected per vighā (bīghā), or the plough tax (i. e. land tax) from vāha, a plough.
6322: vāhyāli (BL), explained as ‘stables’; cf. bāhy-āli. (EI 6), explained as ‘a camp’.
6324: vaibhoga, cf. aṅga-raṅga-vaibhoga (EI 3; SII 1; SITI); same as bhoga.
6325: vaidarveyaka, cf. vedaveyaka (IA 18; CII 1), an eel.
6326: vaidharaṇa (HRS), a compensation fee levied upon the sale of liquors, royal merchandise, mining products and imported salt, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
6327: vaidila (CII 3), a word of uncertain import.
6328: Vaidya (EI 9, 30; BL), a physician; member of the physician community.
6330: vaidya-bhoga (SITI), also called vaidya-bhāga, vaidya-vṛtti; land set apart for the maintenance of the physician.
6331: Vaidya-paricāraka, cf. Tamil Vaijya-paricārakar (EI 24), medical attendants.
6332: vaidya-vṛtti (SII 1), land enjoyed by the Vaidyas for their maintenance; cf. vaidya-bhāga, vaidya-bhoga.
6334: vaijayika, carrying victory; cf. Ep. Ind., XXXII, p. 88. See vijaya-vaijayika.
6336: Vaikṣepika (EI 8-3; EI 26), probably, the dispatcher of messengers; same as Preṣaṇika. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVI, p. 206. See also vikṣepa.
6337: Vailabdhika (EI 8-3; EI 30), officer in charge of vilabdhi (q. v.); probably, the custodian of recovered stolen property.
6338: Vaidāntika (BL), an exponent of the Vedānta.
6340: Vairāgi (SITI), an ascetic serving in a temple.
6341: vaiśāradya cf. vesārajja (EI 5), Buddhist; four in number.
6342: Vaiṣayika (EI 7), probably, the ruler of a viṣaya or district.
6343: vaiśvadeva (EI 10, 14, 23; CII 3, 4), offerings to gods; one of the five mahāyajñas; sometimes called vaiśvānara.
6345: Vaiśvāsika (IE 8-3; EI 9, 28, 29), probably the same as Rahasyādhikṛta, etc.; cf. Paramaviśvāsin, Viśvāsa, Viśvāsika; the privy councillor or private secretary. (EI 3), mentioned along with Antaraṅga.
6346: vaiśy-āgrahāra (IE 8-5; EI 30, 33), a privileged holding created in favour of members of the mercantile community; see agrahāra.
6347: vaiśya-vāṇiya-nagarattār (SITI), ASLV), Sanskrit vaiśya-vāṇija-nagarastha; a corporation of the merchants; the guild of a class of merchants.
6348: vājapeya (EI 22; CII 4; BL), name of a Vedic sacrifice.
6350: Vāji-vaidya (BL), explained as ‘a veterinary physician’; literally, ‘a physician for horses’.
6351: vajra (HA), thunderbolt. Cf. vaccira-ppaḍai (SITI), the lower or foundation tier of the wall of a temple.
6352: vajrāsana (LL), name of the seat on which the Buddha sat for meditation for the attainment of supreme knowledge (bodhi).
6354: vākṣa (Chamba), tax in cash; same as bācha.
6355: valadī (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVIII, p. 17, text line 21), correctly baladī derived from balīvarda; same as vara-balīvarda, etc.
6356: vāḻa-giri (SITI), abbreviation of the name of the mythical mountain called cakravāla-giri.
6357: vaḻanāḍu (IE 8-4; EI 25), Tamil; a province; a district consisting of sub-divisions called kuṟṟam or nāḍu.
6358: valakṣa (IA 17), used to indicate the bright fortnight.
6360: Valatkauṣan (CII 3), official designation of uncertain import; probably, a mistake for Bala-kauṣṭhika, officer-in-charge of the treasury of the military department. Cf. Mahavalākoṣṭhika.
6361: Valākoṣṭhika, probably, a mistake for Balakoṣṭhika; cf. Valat-kauṣan, Mahāvalākoṣṭhika.
6362: valaya (CITD), a ring; a bracelet; in Telugu-Kannaḍa, also an enclosure, a boundary.
6363: vala-yaṣṭi (CII 4), mistake for bala-yaṣṭi, memorial pillar.
6364: valaya-yaṣṭi (EI 33; CII 3), wrong emendation of bala-yaṣṭi and supposed to mean ‘a boundary-pillar’. See bala-yaṣṭi.
6368: valisyati (LP), cf. Gujarātī vāḷi levāmāṃ āvaśe; see vālanīya.
6369: valita, vaḻita (E 12; SITI), same as vaṇita; a small terri-torial unit; a district or its subdivision.
6371: valīvarda, variant spelling of balīvarda (q. v.); cf. a-param-parā-valivarda, etc. (IE 8-5); a pair of bullocks [which the villagers were obliged to provide for the cart of the royal officers when they were camping or touring in the village].
6372: valla (IE 8-8), name of a weight equal to 3 ratis; see dvi-vallakya.
6373: Vallabha (IE 8-3; EI 12, 26), the king's favourite or a courtier; same as Rājavallabha. (IE 8-2), same as Vallabharāja; a shortened form of the title Śrī-pṛthivī-vallabha assumed by certain imperial rulers of the Kannaḍa-speaking area.
6375: Vallava (IE 8-3; 27; LL), official designation; officer in charge of the king's cattle; same as Sanskrit Vallabha, a herdsman.
6376: vāmana-mudrā (SITI), figures of śaṅkha and cakra marked on the boundary stones set up to demarcate the lands of a Viṣṇu temple. Cf. Vāmana-kkal, boundary stone of land granted for religious purposes.
6377: vāṃphaya, cf. niddhi-vāṃphaya-sahita (EI 12), wrong reading of nidhi-nikṣepa-sahita.
6380: Vaṃś-āvalī (IA 30), a genealogical list; called kula-pañjī or kula-pañjikā in Bengal.
6383: vana, a source of income. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 109-10. Cf. nāga-vana (IE 8-4), an elephant-forest.
6385: vanadhi (IE 7-1-2), used in the sense of vāridhi to indicate ‘four.’
6386: vana-durga (ASLV), fort built in the midst of forests.
6387: Vaṇajāraka, also spelt Vaṇijāraka (EI 11), same as the Vanjārī of Rājasthān, whose hereditary calling is to carry grains on pack-bullocks; cf. Vaṇijjāraka.
6388: vandāpanā (IE 8-5; EI 12, 33), Oḏiyā; presents to be made on meeting the king or landlord; same as Persian nazrāna; cf. vijaya-vandāpanā.
6389: Vaṅgālī, see Bengali which is its Anglicised spelling.
