6391: Vaṇijjāraka (BL), probably, merchants or traders of cara-vans; cf. Vaṇajāraka.
6392: Vaṇik (IE 8-3; BL), merchant or a member of the merchantile community.
6393: vaṇik-patha, ‘trade-route’; a revenue term. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 79-80.
6395: Vaṇik-suvarṇakāra (BL), probably, ‘one who is a banker and a goldsmith’; cf. the Suvarṇa-vaṇik community of Bengal.
6398: vaṇita (IE 8-4; SITI), Kannaḍa; same as vaḻita; a small territorial unit like a Parganā.
6400: vanniā (IE 8-8), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit varṇikā (q. v.).
6402: vaṇṭya (EI 12), a district; cf. vĕṇṭhĕ, vĕṇṭhĕya.
6403: vāpa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 310, note 4), explained as a handcast or handful; but really, the same as vapa, sowing [seed grains appa ently by handcast]. (EI 15), cf. kulyavāpa (area requiring one kulya measure of seeds to be sown by handcast); see vāpa-gatyā, etc. (EI 3), a land measure.
6404: vāpa-gatyā, cf. vauge (EI 10), grain sown broadcast.
6405: vāpī (EI 13), step-well; an irrigation well; same as vāpikā. (Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, p. 46, note 8), a well with a flight of stairs; cf. kūpa which is an ordinary well. (EI 22), a reservoir of water.
6406: vāpikā (CCI 3), a step-well, an irrigation well; same as vāpī.
6407: vappaka (EI 23), a land measure. Same as vapyaka, vāpa.
6408: vapyaka (EI 3), a land measure; same as vappaka, vāpa.
6409: vāra (BL), a board of administrators [formed by the śreṣṭhins, sārthavāhas and others]. (IA 16), the solar day. (SITI), method of reciting the Vedas. (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 17, note 1), probably, a week. (EI 30; SITI), a share of the produce. (EI 24), a multitude. Cf. also vāra-Nāka-Lokta-Gāñīk-ādīnāṃ, ‘belonging to Nāka, Lokta and Gāñīka collectively’ (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, pp. 202, 204). (CII 1) cf. vārataḥ, ‘in consequence of an occasion.’ (EI 23), same as vāra-goṣṭhī; a committee; cf. vāra-pra-mukha. Vāra is the same as Tamil vāriyam. (IE 7-1-2), ‘seven’. Cf. bāre (Chamba), ‘during or in the time of’.
6410: vara-balīvarda (EI 12, 33), tax on choice bullocks for bull-fights; cf. valadī, yamalikambali, etc.
6411: varada-mudrā (HA), the gift-bestowing attitude of the right hand with palm outwards and fingers pointing downwards.
6413: vara-grāma (SITI), village given as a gift to a temple or maṭha or a Brāhmaṇa.
6414: vāra-gṛha (EI 19), outside houses; cf. Sanskrit bahir-gṛha.
6415: varāha (IE 8-8; EI 25; SITI; SII 1), also called hūn or hon; name of a gold coin called pagoda or ‘star pagoda’ in English; Cf. doḍḍa-varāha (EI 20), varāha-paṇam (SITI), varāhanpuḻḻi-kuḻigai (SITI), parumuḻai-varāhan (SITI); etc.
6416: varāha-gadyāṇa (EI 8, 27), same as varāha or gadyāṇa; i. e. a pagoda.
6417: varāhakīya-viṃśopaka (EI 1), name of a coin which was one-twentieth of a varāha in value.
6418: varāha-mudrā, cf. varāha-muddirai (SITI), the seal or emblem bearing the figure of a boar, being the crest of certain kings like those of Vijayanagara.
6421: varaṇa (SITI), the selection or election of a person to a committee.
6423: Vāra-pramukha (EI 5), the head of a committee.
6424: vāra-siddhi, cf. a-vāra-siddhika (EI 8-5); probably refers to the supply of unpaid labour by the villagers in turn.
6425: varaṭakā (EI 1), ‘cowrie-shell used as a coin’; same as varāṭikā.
6426: varāṭikā, ‘a cowrie-shell used as a coin’; money. See Gaurī-varāṭikā, varaṭakā, barāḍ.
6427: varavajhe (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIV, p. 103, text line 12), doubtful name of a tax; same as vara-balīvarda, baladī, etc.
6428: vara-yātrā (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, the procession of a bride-groom to the bride's place for marriage.
6429: Vardhaki (LL), a carpenter; cf. Śaila-vardhaki, a mason or sculptor.
6432: varga (CII 1), a group or cadre of officers.
6433: Vārgulika (IE 8-3; EI 28; BL), same as Oḏiyā Bāguli, Vāguli; the bearer of the king's betel-box. Cf. Veṭakila.
6434: vari (SITI), Tamil; tax; revenue register; order of the king and his officers fixing the revenue. Cf. vari-ppotta-gam, tax register; an officer maintaining the same; also Vari-ppottaga-nāyakam, the head office of the revenue accounts; the chief officer of the same office.
6437: vāri-gṛha-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); explained as ‘the department of water works’.
6438: Vārika (IE 8-8; EI 30, 32), a class of officials; the priest or superintendent of a temple like a Pāṇḍā of modern times; cf. Deva-vārika (EI 27), superintendent of a temple; also cf. Tamil Vāriyan (SITI), a supervisor. Cf. Mahāgandhakuṭī-vārika (LL), ‘superintendent of the great gandhakūṭī (q. v.).’ The official designation Pāṭvāri seems to be derived from Paṭṭavārika. Cf. Tamil vāriyaṃ (SITI), an executive committee; appointment as a member of that body; an office of supervision; cf. śrībhaṇḍāra-vāriyam (EI 33). See SII, Vol. III, p. 151, note. Cf. bārika (EI 5, 19), a village official; one entrusted with putting an official seal or stamp to a document; cf. bārika-jana-hasta.
6440: varkara (IA 19), a goat; cf. botkaṭa, etc.
6441: varṇa (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’. (Select Inscriptions, p. 187, text line 6), same as varṇanā, a description or list.
6442: varṇana (Select Inscriptions, p. 202), a written order.
6443: varṇikā (IE 8-8; EI 30), same a Prakrit vanniā, a sample; sometimes, a small measure of capacity (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 302, verse 69).
6444: varṣa (CII 3, 4; IA 17), a year; used for saṃvatsara or its abbreviations. (EI 23), the rainy season. Cf. varṣe (IA 19), used in the dates after the quotation of saṃvat; sometimes abbreviated to va. Cf. samaye used in the same sense. Cf. Tamil varuṣa-kāṇikkai (SITI), annual presents. (IE 7-1-2), ‘nine’; cf. the nine divisions of Jambu-dvīpa.
6446: varṣa-paryuṣita (IE 8-8; EI 30), probably, ‘camping for the rainy season only’; used in connection with merchants.
6447: varṣa-vartamānī, the annual Durbar (Journ. Or. Inst., Vol. X, p. 15).
6448: varṣa-vṛddhi, probably ‘birthday anniversary’ (JAS, Letters, Vol. XX, p. 206).
6449: Vārta, Vartta (CII 4; IA 14), same as Vṛtti-bhuj, ‘one who enjoys a grant or the share of a grant’; a person in possession of a vṛtti.
6450: vartamāna (HRS), ‘running revenue’, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
6451: vartamāna-bhaviṣyat (IE 8-3), ‘of the present and future’; used with reference to the officers associated with a gift land.
6452: vartanā (SITI), perquisites due to an office; periodical presents to be offered to an officer of rank by his subordinates and the people. Cf. vartanī.
6453: vartanī (HRS), transit duties collected by the ferrymen, the superintendent of tolls and the boundary officer, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra. Cf. vartanā. (IA 18), a district; often found suffixed to the names of districts in the Kaliṅga region. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 174), a road.
6454: Vārt-ānukarṣaka (IA 6), official designation of doubtful meaning; probably, a spy; mentioned in the Mahābhārata.
6455: vartma-daṇḍa (IE 8-5), tolls collected on the roads for the passage of articles of merchandise through a village. Cf. Tamil vaḻiy-āyam (SITI), ‘tolls on the roadway’.
6456: Vartmapāla (IE 8-3), superintendent of roads or the collector of the vartma-daṇḍa.
6457: vāru-ghoṭaka (LP), a riding horse; cf. Marāṭhī vāru.
6458: vāruṇī, cf. mahāmahāvāruṇī, mahāvāruṇī (EI 25); name of a tithi.
6459: Va-sā (PJS), probably, an abbreviation of Vaṇik-sādhu, ‘a merchant’.
6460: vasad-bhoga-maryādā (IA 5), explained as ‘the condition that the gift villages should be enjoyed only by those residing therein’; the custom relating to the enjoyment of the gift land by the donee by residing therein; but see vasad-bhogya-maryādā.
6461: vasad-bhogya-maryādā (EI 24), interpreted as ‘with the tenants’ occupancy rights assured’; same as vasad-bhoga-maryādā.
6462: vasadi (EI 10), Sanskrit vasati; a Jain temple; cf. vasahī.
6463: Vāsāgārika (IE 8-3; EI 30), officer in charge of the king's bed-chamber. See Vitān-ādhipa, Śayyāpāla, Śayyāgrāhaka.
6464: vasahī (HA), Sanskrit vasati; a Jain temple; cf. vasadi.
6465: vāsaka (EI 3, 14, 23, 30; IA 13), royal residence whence the copper-plate grants were often issued; the camp or capital of a king.
6466: vāsa-kṣepa (HA), scattering of powder; also the powder itself.
6467: Vāśal (ASLV), same as Vāśal-kāriyam; chief guard of the palace.
6468: Vāśal-kāriyam (ASLV), also called Vāśal; chief guard of the palace.
6472: vasanta-maṇḍapa (SITI), maṇḍapa in the midst of a plea-sure garden where the spring-festival of a deity is celebrated.
6474: Vāsāpaka (EI 6, 12; CII 4; IA 12, 13), explained as ‘officials whose duty was to assign places of residence to strang-ers’; also spelt Vāsāvaka; cf. also the tax called vāsāvakī (EI 33). Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. XIII, p. 69, note 11.
6476: vasāvakī (EI 33), name of a tax; cf. the official designation Vāsāpaka or Vāsāvaka.
6477: vasati, modified to basadi (EI 10), basahi (HA), pasti, basti (SITI), etc.; a Jain temple.
6478: vasati-daṇḍa (EI 25), obligation of the villagers to supply food to the royal officers camping in their village; explained by some as ‘the tax for the lodging of touring royal officers’ (CII 4); but probably refers to an obligation and not a tax.
6479: Vāsela-kuṭuṃbika (LP), resident farmers; cf. Gujarātī Vasṇārā-kaṇbī.
6480: Vāstavya (EI 16), a community of the Kāyasthas. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 172, note 3), rarely also called sāmānya; ‘resident’.
6483: vāstuka, a building site. See Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., pp. 97-98.
6485: vāstu-parivāra (SITI), vacant site attached to a house.
6486: vastu-prābhṛtaka, cf. vastu-prābhṛtakena (LP), ‘in exchange for a present’.
6492: vāla (IE 8-5; EI 15; CII 3), cf. sa-bhūta-vāta-pratyāya, etc.; probably, storms (cf. udvāta; also called āvāta.)
6493: vāt-ādeya (EI 32), ‘income resulting from storms’; same as vāta-pratyāya.
6494: vāṭaka (LL), a garden. (IE 8-4; EI 15; IA 7), corrupt form of pāṭaka; ‘part of a village’; often suffixed to names of localities. Cf. the second component in Talla-vāṭaka, meaning modern vāḍa, spelt in English as wara.
6496: vāta-pratyāya (EI 32; CII 4), explained by some as ‘octroi duty’, but actually, ‘income resulting from storms’; same as vāt-ādeya. See bhūta-vāta-pratyāya, etc.
6497: va-ti (IE 8-1), contraction of vadya-pakṣa-tithi, though va may be a mistake for ba (bahula).
6498: vāṭi, vāṭī (IE 8-6; EI 28, 30), also called vāṭikā (q. v.); land measure equal to twenty māṇas in Orissa.
6499: vā-ṭī, abbreviation of vāstu-ṭīkara, ‘a mound containing land suitable for building houses.’ See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 56.
6500: vāṭikā (EI 15; SITI), same as nilam or veḻi, defined in the Mayamata as 5120 square daṇḍas, the length of the daṇḍa being 4 cubits; 4. 48 acres. (EI 30), a land measure equal to twenty māṇas in Orissa; same as vāṭi, vāṭī; equal to 20 acres. (EI 27), a hamlet.
6501: vāt-ottara (IE 8-5), ‘resulting from storms’; cf. vāt-ādeya, etc.
6504: Vaṭṭel13uttu, name of a alphabet prevalent in medieval times in the southern part of the Tamil-speaking area and the land to its west.
6505: vāva (IE 8-2), one's uncle or a relation of one's father's generation; cf. vāva-pād-ānudhyāta, ‘meditating on (or, favoured by) the feet of the uncle (or a relation of one's father's generation).’
6506: Vāy-kkeḻvi, Vāy-kkeḻviyār (SITI), an officer who received the king's oral orders; an officer in attendance on the king, acting as the intermediary between the king and his subjects; the king's order. Cf. Ājñapti.
6508: veda (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’ (the four Vedas being Ṛk, Yajus, Sāman and Atharvan); rarely used to indicate ‘three’ (cf. trayī) in late records (IE 7-1-2; IA 9).
6509: veda-maṭha (ASLV), school for teaching the Vedas. There was such a school at Kāñcīpuram. Cf. śālā, khaṇḍikā, Ṛgveda-khaṇḍikā.
6510: Veda-pārāyaṇa (IA 12), priest who repeats the Veda at the Rāmeśvaram temple.
6512: veda-vṛtti (SITI), tax-free land set apart for meeting the expenses of reciting, the Vedas.
6513: vedi (EI 32), a seat; also a raised platform (cf. vedikā). See JBRS, Vol. XXXIX, Parts 1-2, pp. 43-44, 47; Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 192.
6514: vedikā (LL), a rail; also, a raised platform (cf. vedi). See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 192.
6515: Vĕggaḍĕ (IE 8-3), same as Vĕrgaḍĕ, Pĕggaḍĕ, Pĕrgaḍĕ, Hĕggaḍĕ, etc. (q. v.).
6517: Veḻai-kkārar (SITI), Tamil; trusted warriors even pre-pared to lay down their lives in the service of their master.
6518: velākula, velākūla (IE 8-4; EI 31; LP), a harbour.
6519: velākula-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP); the harbour department.
6520: velāpura, cf. velāura (IA 10, 14), a harbour; same as velākūla.
6521: Velāvitta (HD), meaning uncertain. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, V. 226; VI. 73, 106, 126. Cf. Pīṭhikāvitta.
6522: veḻi (IE 8-6; EI 25), Tamil; a big land measure. See vāṭikā.
6523: veli-cenu (CITD), Telugu; usually, a field on a high level depending on rain water.
6525: veli-volamu (CITD), Telugu; also called veli-polamu; similar to veli-cenu.
6529: veṅkaṭa-vilāsa-maṇṭapa (ASLV), hall in which the royal council met at Vijayanagara.
6530: vĕṇṭhĕ (EI 16; ASLV), same as viṣaya, nirvṛtti, koṭṭam, etc.; an administrative division; also called vĕṇṭhĕya, vaṇtya, vĕṭha, vĕṭa.
6531: vĕṇṭhĕya (EI 16), a sub-division or district; same as vĕṇṭhĕ.
6532: Vĕrgaḍĕ (IE 8-3), Kannaḍa; same as Vĕggaḍĕ, Pĕrgaḍĕ, Hĕggaḍĕ, etc.; also Sanskrit Adhyakṣa, Adhikārin (a superin-tendent or governor).
6533: veśya (CII 4), explained as ‘situated in … ’ Cf. prāveśya.
6535: Veṭakila (IE 8-3); HD), probably ‘the bearer of vīṭikā (betel bīḏā)’. See Vogel. Ant. Ch. St., p. 128. Cf. Vārgulika; also Paṭṭakila.
6536: vetana, vetanā (SITI), wages (used along with veṭṭi, i. e. Sanskrit viṣṭi or unpaid labour); probably wages for the labourers in the public works of the village.
6537: vĕṭha (IE 8-4), Kannaḍa; same as vĕṇṭhĕ, vĕṭa, etc.; a small territorial unit.
6538: Vetrika (EI 9; CII 4), explained by some as ‘the chamber-lain’; cf. Yāṣṭika, Piśuna-vetrika.
6539: vi (CITD), abbreviation of Telugu vinnapamulu, represen-tation or saying. It may stand for visālu (visā or vīsa) also.
6540: vibhāga (HRS), king's share of the output of mines; as suggested by the Arthaśāstra, rent from mines and from the private manufacturers of salt.
6541: vibhava (IA 14), used in the sense of nirvāṇa (q. v.).
6542: vibheda (IE 8-4), subdivision of a khaṇḍa of Bhārata or Bhārata-varsa.
6543: vibhoga (EI 16), holy ashes; same as vibhūti (q. v.).
6544: vibhūti (IA 12), holy ashes; same as vibhoga. (SITI), also called vibhūti-kāṇikkai in Tamil inscriptions; originally, voluntary contribution to a temple by the devotees while receiving the sacred ashes; later, it was collected as a tax.
6546: vicitra-kavitva (CITD), probably, a class of poetry like citra-kavitva, abounding in all kinds of highly artificial verses displaying the pedantry and verbal jugglery of the composer.
6553: vidvaj-jana (SITI), a body of learned men.
6555: vidyā-bhoga (EI 18), same as vidy-ānubhoga and vidyā-dhana.
6557: vidyā-dhana (HRS), explained as land assigned as a re-ward for learning; same as vidyā-bhoga and vidy-ānubhoga.
6558: vidyādhara-toraṇa (SII 2), an ornamental arch probably depicting Vidyādharas; cf. makara-toraṇa.
6559: Vidy-ādhikārin (EI 11, 25; HD), officer in charge of a school or of schools; the director of education. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 314.
6560: vidy-ānubhoga (SITI), an endowment of land to a school for the encouragement of learning.
6562: vidyā-sthāna (EI 2; SII 2; SITI), an educational insti-tution for higher studies; a college.
6563: vigrahadramma-visovaka (EI 1), name of a coin; the latter part of the name (i. e. visovaka = viṃśopaka) suggests that it was one-twentieth of the vigraha-dramma in value.
6564: vigrahapāla-dramma (EI 1), name of a coin; same as vigrahapāla-satka-dramma, vigrahapālīya-dramma.
6566: vigrahapālīya-dramma (EI 1; CII 4), name of a coin apparently so called after a king named Vigrahapāla.
6567: vigrahatuṅgīya-dramma (EI 1; CII 4), name of a coin apparently so called after a king named Vigrahatuṅga.
6568: vihāra (EI 22, 25; CII 3, 4; BL), a Buddhist or Jain monastery or temple or convent (EI 35). (HA), wandering of a Jain monk; also a Jain temple.
6569: Vihārakāraka, cf. Prakrit Viharakarahvaa (CII 2-1), ‘one who builds a monastery’; same as Vihārasvāmin; explained by some as ‘the superintendent of monastery’ (ML).
6570: Viharamāṇa-Jina (HA), a Jina at present living in other kṣetras.
6571: Vihārapāla, ‘the manager of a monastery’ (Select Inscrip-tions, p. 345).
6572: Vihārasvāmin (EI 8, 33; CII 3; BL; LL), ‘the master of a monastery’; the builder or owner of a monastery. Cf. Vihāra-kāraka.
6573: Vihārasvāminī (CII 3; IA 11), the feminine form of Vihārasvāmin; wife of a Vihārasvāmin or the female owner of a vihāra.
6575: vihārikā (EI 23, 27), derived from vihāra, vihāraka; a small vihāra or monastery.
6579: vijālayitavya, to be untied (Select Inscriptions, p. 238).
6580: Vijāṭin (IA 11), cf. Vijāṭi-vidyādhara, ‘a Vidyādhara unwind-ing his head-dress’.
6581: vijaya, used in Kannaḍa inscriptions in the sense of ‘going in state, going in a triumpal procession, making a state procession, making a state progress through one's dominions’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 223, note 6; Vol. VI, p. 51, note 5). (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 18), Oḏiyā, etc.; used in Oḏiyā inscriptions in the sense of ‘stay’. (IA 7), cf. vijaya-rājya-saṃvalsara, vijaya-saṃvatsara, vijaya-kaṭaka, vijaya-skandhāvāra, etc. Cf. śrī-vijaya and śrī-vijaya-śiva.
6582: vijayā (IA 26), same as su-di 11 or the eleventh tithi.
6583: vijay-ābhiṣeka (SITI), being crowned as a victor; same as vīr-ābhiṣeka.
6587: vijaya-kaṭaka (EI 2; LP), ‘the victorious camp’; the royal camp or capital.
6589: vijayarāja-ṭaṅka (CII 4), name of a coin apparently so called after a ruler named Vijayarāja who was its issuer.
6591: vijaya-śāsana (EI 33), any royal record (cf. śāsana); sometimes the same as dharma-vijaya-śāsana (q. v.).
6592: vijaya-śiva, cf. śrī-vijaya-śiva-Mṛgeśavarman, etc. (The Successors of the Sātavāhanas, pp. 261 ff.); an honorific prefixed to royal names. See śrī, vijaya, śiva.
6594: vijaya-vaijayika, victory; sometimes used as an adjective qualifying the regnal date (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 152, text line 5; cf. ibid., Vol. XXXII, p. 88).
6595: vijaya-vandāpanā (IE 8-5; EI 12), Oḏiyā; a levy; pre-sents to be offered to the king or landlord on the occasion of his victorious return from a campaign or for the preparation of a campaign; cf. vandāpanā.
6596: vijaya-vikṣepa (IA 13), epithet of a place where a king was staying. See vikṣepa.
6598: Vijñānin (EI 20, 32), an artisan; same as Śilpin; epithet of an artisan who is usually the engraver of an inscription.
6599: vijñāpanā (IA 10), also called vijñapti; an application; a request; cf. Kannaḍa binna-vattaḷĕ = Sanskrit vijñāpana-patra (SII 11-1).
6600: Vijñapti (EI 29), official designation. Cf. Ājñapti, etc.
6601: vijñapti (SITI), sometimes also spelt vijñāpti; peti-tioning to the king (cf. vijñāpanā); an officer who brings the petition of the subjects to the king's notice. (EI 23; SII 2), also called vijñāpya, an application or petition.
6602: vi-jñāpi (CII 3, etc.), verb used in connection with the making of a grant by the king at the request, or on the advice, of someone who was the real donor.
6603: vijñāpya (EI 23), cf. Tamil viṇṇappam (SII 1), a peti-tion; also called vijñapti.
6604: vikara, cf. vikara-padāni (LP), a small present, a bonus; cf. Gujarātī pān-sopārī. (LP), cf. vikara-pada explained as ‘miscellancous expenses’.
6608: vikṣepa (IA 7, 13), cf. vijaya-vikṣepa used as an epithet of the place whence a royal charter was issued; cf. vijaya-vikṣepāt Bha-rukaccha-vāsakāt; wrongly interpreted as ‘a camp or cantonment’ (IA 17). See also Vaikṣepika.
6609: vilabdhi (IE 8-3; EI 30), used in the Rājataraṅgiṇī, probably in the sense of presents offered to the king or the stolen property recovered; explained as ‘an assignment’. See Vailabdhika.
6611: Vilāsinī (EI 33), same as Devadāsī; also called Gaṇikā, etc.
6612: Vilekhaka (EI 22), an engraver. Cf. Ullekhaka, utkṛ.
6613: vi-lok, cf. vilokyante (LP), ‘are being searched for’, used in respect of one who is in search of money in times of difficulty.
6614: vimāna (SITI), the pinnacle or upper structure over the sanctum of a temple; the central shrine of a temple (SII 3); also called śrī-vimāna (SII 13); same as garbha-gṛha. (EI 3, 23), a shrine. (IA 9), the steeple tower over a shrine; also called stupī.
6615: viṃśatika, regarded as equal to 20 māṣas (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 52); cf. viṃśopaka.
6617: viṃsopaka (EI 1), corrupt form of viṃśopaka, a copper coin which was (1/20) of the standard silver coin in value.
6618: viṃśopaka (IE 8-6, 8-8; EI 29, 30; CII 4), a copper coin which was one-twentieth of the standard silver coin in value; cf. Viśālapriya-viṃśopaka (IE 8-8); Varāhakīya-viṃśopaka (EI 1); Vṛṣa-viṃśopaka (q. v.); a land measure equal to one twentieth of the standard land measure. See vīsa, viṃsopaka, vīsovā, visovaka. Cf. viśopaka (LP), supposed to be the same as vighā, a measure of land equal to 20 vasas [in Gujarat].
6619: vīṇā (ASLV), a musical instrument. Cf. vīṇai-kkāṇi (SITI), right of playing on the vīṇā before the god in a temple during worship.
6620: vinamu (CITD), Telugu; an unknown weight greater than a cinna or cinnamu, otherwise called sinna.
6622: vināśin, cf. a-kūra-chullaka-vināśi-khaṭvā-vāsa (IE 8-5), an attendant, or fuel. The villagers were obliged to supply it to the touring officers of the king.
6623: vinaṣṭa-rājya (IE), same as gata-rājya or atīta-rājya, someone's sovereignty that was a thing of the past.
6624: vinaya (IE 8-8; EI 30), fines. (EI 13), same as indriya-jaya.
6625: Vinayadhara (LL), Buddhist; one who has learnt the Vinaya texts by heart.
6626: Vināyaka (LL), a teacher of the vinaya texts; a name of the god Gaṇeśa.
6627: Vināyaka-homa (EI 26), a rite; same as Gaṇeśa-homa.
6628: vindu (EI 7-1-2), also spelt bindu; ‘cypher’. (SII 2), a flaw in diamonds.
6630: Vinibandhakāra (EI 8), same as Vinibaddhakāra; explained as ‘one who registers [a document]’; really, ‘one who cancels the registration [of a document]’ (Select Inscriptions, p. 202).
6631: vinirgata (EI 7), cf. Pāṭaliputra-bhaṭṭāgrahāra-vinirgata (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 122, text line 16); ‘hailing from’, or more suitably ‘one whose family hails from’. When a locality called Aṭṭamūla is described as vinirgata from Bṛhad-dhaṭṭa, it seems to mean that the former was originally a part of the latter (ibid., Vol. XXXIII, p. 151).
6632: viniyoga (SITI), an employment; use; expenditure. (EI 24), a tax; cf. Tamil vāśal-viniyogam (SITI), same as vāśal-paṇam; also sabhā-viniyoga (SII 13).
6633: Viniyukta (HD), an officer probably under the Āyuktaka; same as Viniyuktaka (q. v.), etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 256.
6634: Viniyuktaka (CII 3, 4), an official title meaning a smaller administrative officer serving under a higher officer; an official probably under the Āyuktaka; same as Viniyukta. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, pp. 80, 83. (IE 8-3), mentioned along with Tadāyuktaka. Cf. Tad-viniyuktaka.
6635: Vipra-vinodin (SITI), a class of Brāhmaṇas who were adepts in jugglery and magical practices.
6636: vīra (IE 8-2), sometimes prefixed to the names of kings and even treated as almost an integral part of the name; cf. pratāpa, vīra-pratāpa, etc. (EI 3), Jain; same as Mahāvīra. Cf. vīra-kaḻ (SITI), also written vīra-kkaḻ, vīra-gaḻ; a hero-stone; an inscribed or uninscribed stone pillar raised in honour of a person who died in fighting for a good cause.
6637: Vīrabhadra (SITI), also called Vīramuṣṭi; member of a militant class of temple servants who diligently protected the properties and rights of the temples. Cf. Vīrakośa.
6639: vīra-bhoga (SITI), land assigned for the maintenance of a warrior.
6640: vīra-gaḻ (CII 4), also written vīra-kkaḻ. See vīra.
6641: vīra-kkaḻ (CII 4), also written vīra-gaḻ, a stone pillar raised in memory of heroes. See vīra.
6642: Vīrakośa, official designation (The Successor of the Sāta-vāhanas, p. 110, note 2); mentioned along with Hastikośa as an officer related to a district; probably, an officer in charge of the local soldiers or infantry men. Cf. Vīrabhadra, etc.
6643: Virakta (SITI), an ascetic; a man free from worldly attachment; a recluse of the Śaiva order.
6644: viral-ariśi (ASLV), rice provided for goldsmiths for am-putating the last two fingers of the wives of farmers.
6645: vīra-mālā, cf. vīra-mālai (SITI), a poem in praise of a warrior.
6647: vīra-paṭṭa (SII 2; SITI), an ornament; a front plate, pro-bably a plate worn on the forehead by distinguished warriors.
6648: vīra-paṭṭaṇa (SITI), also called eṟi-vīra-paṭṭaṇam; a mer-cantile town inhabited by the eṟi-vīrar.
6650: vīra-śāsana (SITI), CITD) explained by some as the same as vīrakaḻ, ‘a hero stone’, established for commemorating the death of soldiers on the battle-field; a grant made by the king in recognition of the heroic activity of a person; a charter recording the grant of land or other property to a warrior.
6651: vīra-śeṣa, cf. vīra-śeṣai (SITI); probably, the provision made for the descendants of dead warriors; sometimes explained as a tax (EI 22). Cf. mṛtyuka-vṛtti, rakta-mānya, etc.
6653: Vīra-yātrika (IA 17; HD), an official designation; probably, the leader of an expedition; a person taking part in a military expedition. See Vogel, Ant. Ch. St., p. 129.
6654: Virūpākṣa-pati, cf. Prakrit Virūpakha-pati (EI 20), epithet of the god Mahāsena or Kārttikeya, Virūpākṣa probably being the name of a host of which the god was conceived as the leader.
6655: vīsa (IE 8-8; EI 5), name of a coin (JNSI, Vol. XXVI, pp. 127ff.); cf. lokkiya-vīsa, probably meaning ‘a vīsa minted at Lokkiguṇḍi’; Sanskrit viṃśa, viṃśaka, viṃśatika, or viṃśopaka. (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 232, note 6), Telugu-Kannaḍa; (1/16) of a haṇa (paṇa); but (1/20) of the standard coin in value essentially. (CITD), also called visā, visya, visāmu; Telugu-Kannaḍa; the fraction (1/10); gold equal in weight to one grain of rice; (1/256) of a Hun or Pagoda; 40 palas; a measure of land equal nearly to 2 acres.
6656: visā, also spelt visāmu (CITD), see vīsa.
6657: viṣahara-bhoga (SITI), also called viṣa-vṛtti; land set apart for the support of a poison-doctor.
6658: vīsala-priya-dramma, also called vīsala-prī-dramma; cf. jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya, etc. (A. R. Ep., 1957-58, Nos. B 490-92).
6660: visatiaṭhū-prastha (IA 18), a levy; probably viṃśatisatka-prastha, ‘one out of 20 prasthas.’
6662: viṣaya (EI 8-4), a district; often a kingdom or terri-tory; sometimes a viṣaya was included in a maṇḍala; but, in some cases, a maṇḍala was included in a viṣaya; at times maṇḍala and viṣaya were synonymous. (IE 8-5; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL; SITI), a district; cf. viṣaya-suṅka (EI 24), the tax of a district; Viṣaya-vyavahārin, officer in the service of a district. (ASLV), same as nirvṛtti or koṭṭam; an administrative division. (IE 8-4; CII 4), sometimes used in a wider sense to indi-cate ‘a country’. (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’.
6663: visaya (CITD), same as Telugu visā, visāmu.
6664: Viṣaya-bhogika (EI 28), probably, the ināmdār or ināmdārs of a district.
6665: Viṣaya-bhūbhuj (IA 15), explained as ‘a native ruler’ as opposed to a ‘foreign conqueror.’
6666: viṣaya-dāna (HRS), name of a tax (Ep. Ind., Vol. XI, p. 21; Vol. XIV, p. 196), probably, a regional tax or taxes realisable from a particular district; known from Gāha-ḍavāla records; cf. viṣayālī.
6667: Viṣaya-dānika (EI 7; CII 4), collector of the levy called viṣaya-dāna; or a district officer in charge of gifts or an officer in charge of gift lands in a district; or the collector of the revenue of a district.
6668: Viṣay-ādhikaraṇa (EI 23, 31), administrative officer of a district; the district administrator's office.
6669: Viṣay-ādhipati, same as Viṣayapati (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 219).
6670: Viṣaya-karaṇa (EI 32), probably, the chief scribe at the office of the administrators of a district.
6671: viṣayālī (EI 33), name of a tax; probably the same as viṣaya-dāna.
6672: Viṣay-āmātya (EI 27, 30), governor of a district; an Amātya in charge of a viṣaya or an Amātya under the Viṣayapati. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 64.
6675: Viṣayapati (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), governor of a district called viṣaya; distinguished from Viṣaya-vyāpṛtaka; same as Viṣay-ādhipati. Cf. Ind. Ant., Vol. V, p. 114. See Viṣa-yeśa, Viṣayeśvara, etc.
6676: Viṣaya-vyāpṛtaka (IE 8-3), sometimes distinguished from the Viṣayapati; an officer associated with the administration of a district (cf. Viṣaya-vyavahārin).
6677: Viṣaya-vyavahārin (IE 8-3), an administrative officer in a district or a member of the district council. Cf. Viṣaya-vya-vahārin, Viṣayika, Viṣayin.
6680: Viṣayika (EI 24), same as Viṣaya-vyavahārin; cf. Viṣayin.
6681: Viṣayik-ādhikārika (EI 32), taken to be a single official designation; probably Viṣayika and Ādhikārika.
6682: Viṣayin (EI 24, 32), possibly, the same as Viṣaya-vyava-hārin; cf. Viṣayika.
6683: viseṇima, viseṇimā (CII 4), a tax, also called viseṇim-ādāya (EI 21).
6684: viśeṣ-ādāya (SITI), also called viśeṣ-āya; a special group of taxes.
6686: viśikha (BL), name of a kind of building.
6687: viśīrṇa, wearing out, worn out part of a building; cf. bhagna-viśīrṇa-samāracana (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 144).
6688: Viśiṣa (IE 8-3; EI 1, 30), probably, the governor or commander of a fort; a word of uncertain derivation.
6693: viṣṇu-śrādha (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 37), an expres-sion of doubtful meaning.
6694: vīsovā (CII 4), name of a coin; a land measure; same as viṃśopaka.
6695: visovaka (EI 1), corrupt form of viṃśopaka (q. v.).
6698: viṣṭi (IE 8-5; CII 4; HRS), labour which the villa-gers were obliged to provide to the king or landlord on occa-sions; unpaid labour; forced labour. Cf. veṭṭi (SITI), unpaid labour for public works in the vil-lage without time or other limits; usually mentioned along with vetana as veṭṭi-vetanai. Cf. veṭṭi-ccoṟu, the obligation of feed-ing veṭṭi labourers free of cost; also cf. Tamil veṭṭi-pāṭṭam (EI 24), explained as ‘a kind of tax’; tax in lieu of viṣṭi.
6699: viśuddhi, cf. viśuddhiṃ yāvat (LP), ‘till the account is clear’.
6700: viṣuva (CII 4; SII 1), the autumnal or vernal equinox; also called viṣuvat (q. v.).
6708: Viśvāsa (EI 24), official designation; same as Vaiśvāsika; cf. the titles Viśvāsa-Khāna, Viśvāsa-rāya, etc., conferred by the Muslim rulers especially in the Bengal region.
6710: viśva-sattā (IA 14), wrong Sanskritisation of Prakrit vasa-sata (Sanskrit varṣa-śata); translated as ‘universal rule’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 241, note 1.
6711: Viśvāsika (EI 24), same as Vaiśvāsika (q. v.), etc.
6712: Viśvaviśvopaka (IA 19), Jain; explained as ‘one whose body and soul exhibit marks of an ācārya’.
6714: Vitān-ādhipa (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIII, p. 325, note 3), supposed to be ‘an officer in charge of the king's bed-chamber’. Cf. Vāsāgārika, Śayyāpāla, etc.
6715: viṭapa (IE 8-5), a bush; used in sa-jhāṭa-viṭapa; a branch. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. V, p. 183.
6716: viṭha-vigāra (Chamba), unpaid labour; from Sanskrit viṣṭi and Persian begār.
6717: vīthi, vīthī (SII 1), a street. (EI 24, 30; CII 4), a shop; a stall or shop in a market. (EI 21, 23, 29, 30), a territorial unit; the subdivision of a district. (IE 8-4), sometimes a subdivision forming part of a maṇḍala, but sometimes a district forming part of a bhukti or province.
6718: Vīthī-mahattara (HD), headman of the territorial unit called vīthī. Cf. IHQ, Vol. XIX, pp. 16, 21.
6719: vīthy-adhikaraṇa (EI 31), administrative office of a sub-division called vīthī.
6721: viṭṭolla-kara (HRS), known from Maitraka records; ex-plained as the contribution in forced labour.
6722: Vivāha (EI 12), ‘one whose vehicle is the bird’; i. e. Viṣṇu.
6723: vivāha (CII 1), marriage of a daughter; cf. āvāha which means the marriage of a son.
6724: vivāha-kara, cf. Tamil kaṇṇāla-kkāṇan (EI 28), the marriage fee; cf. vivāha-ppaṇam.
6725: vivāha-paṇa, cf. vivāha-ppaṇam (SITI), same as kaṇṇāla-kkāṇam; a tax on marriage.
6726: vivīta (HRS), royal dues collected by the superintendent of pastures, as suggested by the Arthaśāstra.
6727: Vivīt-ādhyakṣa (EI 28), known from the Arthaśāstra; officer in charge of the pasture land. Cf. Vrajabhūmika.
6729: vodā (IE 8-5; EI 29), a kind of levy in Oḏiyā records; same as Oḏiyā vadāi, ‘the obligation of offering uncooked food.’
6730: voḍī, voḍrī (EI 23), (1/4) paṇa; 20 cowrie-shells; cf. kapardaka-voḍī, ‘voḍī counted in cowrie-shells’.
6732: Volāpika (LP), an officer in charge of collecting the tax called volāpana or vulāvī. It is supposed that a Volāpaka or the men under him accompanied the merchants in their journey for the safety of their goods and the volāpana tax was collected from the merchants for safeguarding their goods.
6734: vraja, see Vraja-bhūmika. Cf. Ghoshal, H. Rev. Syst., p. 110.
6736: Vrajabhūmika (CII 1; EI 2; HD), Prakrit Vacabhūmika; superintendent of cowpens; officer in charge of the royal cattle and pasture lands. Cf. Vivīt-ādhyakṣa.
6737: vrata (CITD), religious vow; a self-imposed task; a religious act of devotion or austerity; vowed observance; a vow in general. There are many vratas mentioned in the different Purāṇas. But new vratas crop up in different parts of the country. (EI 4), five in number.
6738: vrīhi-kara, cf. Tamil arisi-kkāṇam (SITI), a levy for husking paddy into rice.
6739: vṛddha (LP), participle of vṛdh, ‘to cut’. Cf. Vṛddha-Gaṇeśa (IA 19), ‘the senior Gaṇeśa’.
6740: Vṛddha-dhānuṣka (IE 8-3), senior archer; the chief archer.
6741: Vṛddharāja (EI 3; LL), ‘prosperous king’; title of a pious king.
6742: vṛddhi (EI 28), a super tax or the interest on arrears of taxes; also interest.
6743: vṛddhi-kukkuṭa (CII 1), Prakrit vadhi-kukuṭa; a cock that has been caponed; also Sanskritised as vadhri-kukkuṭa.
6745: vṛṣa-viṃśopaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 39), name of a coin (probably bearing the figure of a bull); cf. viṃśopaka.
6746: vṛtti (SITI), means; livelihood, occupation; grant of land for one's livelihood. (SII 3), land granted for service. (EI 17, 31; CITD), share; share in a village granted to a Brāhmaṇa as a free gift.
6747: Vuḏhā-leṅkā (EI 28), Oḏiyā; official designation; cf. Leṅkā.
6748: vulāpikā (LP), tax for the maintenance of the camp-followers; cf. Gujarātī vaḻāmaṇ vulāyiyā; also volāpika, vulā-viyā (q. v.).
6749: vulāvī (LP), same as volāpana; a tax.
6750: Vulāviyā (LP), a camp-follower; cf. Gujarātī Vuḻāviyā. See vulāpikā and Volāpika.
6751: vuṃvaka (EI 14), name of a measure. Cf. ‘rūpakas to be levied on each vuṃvaka of the distillers’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XIV, p. 309).
6752: Vya (PJS), abbreviation of Vyavahārin, especially in medieval Jain inscriptions.
6753: Vyā (PJS), abbreviation of Vyāpārin (merchant) or Vyāsa (exponent or reciter of epic and Puranic texts) especially in medieval Jain inscriptions. Cf. vyā-bhū.
6754: vyā-bhū (IE 8-1), abbreviation of vyāmiśra-bhūmi; ‘mixed land’; land containing different categories such as cultivable, fallow, homestead, etc.
6756: vyāghra-carman (IE 8-5; EI 12, 28), tiger's skin [which was the king's monopoly]; tax probably payable by hunters in tiger's skin; refers to the right to keep tiger's skins without surrendering them to the king.
6757: vyāja, vyājaka (LP), interest; cf. dvika-śata-vyājena, ‘at 2 per cent interest’. See vyājī.
6758: vyājī (HRS), as suggested by the Arthaśāstra, (1) com-pensation fee levied upon the sale of liquors, royal merchan-dise, mining products, salt and sugar; (2) charge paid for minting coins; (3) subsidiary charge over and above the regular fines. See vyāja.
6759: vyākaraṇa-dāna-maṇḍapa (SITI), hall in the Śiva temple at Tiruvoṟṟiyūr, where Sanskrit grammar is taught with the belief that the Māheśvara-sūtras, on which Sanskrit grammar is founded, were composed by the god Śiva.
6760: vyākhyā-vṛtti (SITI), land set apart to meet the expenses of expounding the Purāṇas and other śāstras.
6762: vyāmiśra-bhūmi (IE 8-1), an area consisting of different kinds of land such as cultivated land, homestead land, fallow land, etc. See vyā-bhū.
6763: vyañjana, cf. vĕñjanam, viñjanam (SITI), condiment; vegetable relish; condiments and curry in food offerings; cf. vĕñjana-bhaṇḍāram. (CII 1), a letter or an implication.
6765: vyāpāra (SII 1), a trade. (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXVI, p. 20), administration. Cf. mudrā-vyāpāra.
6766: vyāpāra-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP), the department of com-merce.
6768: Vyāpṛta (IE 8-3; EI 6), cf. Vāpata (EI 9), a governor; a superintendent; cf. also official designations like Hasty-aśva-naubala-vyāpṛta or °vyāpṛtaka, etc.
6769: Vyāsa (EI 11; PJS), a reciter or exponent; a Brāhmaṇa who recites or expounds the epics and Purāṇas in public. Cf. Paurāṇika.
6771: vyāṣedha (LP), vyāṣedhaḥ kāritaḥ or niṣedhaḥ kāritaḥ, ‘prov-ed the contrary [in the court that it was his own land and not ḍohalikā land’]; vahamāna-bhūmi-vyāṣedha, ‘no one should stop him when he is ploughing his own piece of land’. (LP), seizure; confiscation as government property.
6773: vyatīpāta (IA 19), used in relation to eclipses.
6774: Vyava (LP), abbreviation of Vyavahārika in the sense of a dealer, a money-lender, a merchant.
6776: vyavahāra, cf. vyavahāra-pade (LP), ‘as a tax from mer-chants’.
6777: Vyavahār-ābhilekhitaka (EI 30), the clerk who writes down the statements of cases in a court of law.
6780: vyavahāra-patra (LP), a deed relating to a loan or debt.
6782: Vyavahārika (EI 7, 32), an administrator; same as Vyava-hārin (q. v.) or Vyavahartṛ; see also Vyava.
6783: Vyavahārin (EI 19, 24, 28, 29; BL; LL; HD), an ad-ministrator; sometimes explained as ‘a controlling officer’; same as Vyavahārika. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XVIII, pp. 60, 63. (LL), a merchant. See also Vyava.
6784: vyavasthā, cf. vyavasthai (EI 24; SITI), regulations; rules of proper conduct; a settlement or arrangement; a deed of agreement. (EI 22; SII 2), a resolution; a declaration. (EI 32), an agreement. (SII 3), conditions.
6785: vyaya (HRS), government expenditure; cf. Tamil viyā-yam (SITI), expenditure, as opposed to āyam or income. (IE 7-1-2), ‘twelve’.
6786: vyaya-karaṇa, cf. karaṇa (LP), the department of expen-diture.
6789: Vyuṣita (Prakrit Vivutha), sometimes taken to be Vyuṣṭa (CII 1); ‘one who is away from his residence’. See IHQ, 1962, pp. 222 ff.
6791: Yakṣa (CII 4; HA), a semi-divine being; a demi-god belonging to the class of vyantara-devatās according to Jain mythology.
6792: yajña-vidyā (EI 8), knowledge regarding the perfor-mance of sacrifice.
6794: Yādava-cakravartin (IE 8-2), title assumed by kings of the Yādava dynasty; see Cakravartin.
6795: yāga-maṇḍapa (SITI), sacrificial hall in a temple; same as yāga-śālā.
6797: yakṣa-dvāra, gateway adorned with Yakṣa figures (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 107).
6802: yamalikāmali (EI 24), a tax probably on a pair of prize bullocks (yamala-kambalin; cf. varabalīvarda); also spelt yamalikambali, yamalikāmbali. See valadī.
6803: yamalikambali (IE 8-5), name of a tax; also spelt yama-likāmbali, yamalikāmali (q. v.).
6804: yamalikāmbali (HRS), a tax known from the Gāhaḍavāla records; also spelt yamalikamabali, yamalikāmali (q. v.).
6805: yānaka (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV, p. 253, note 4), probably a cart-road.
6806: yānikā, same as yānaka, probably, a cart road (Ep. Ind., Vol. IV. p. 253, note 4).
6807: yantra (SITI), a mechanical contrivance, as for diverting water. (HA), a mystic diagram.
6808: yantra-kuṭī (IE 8-8; EI 30), an oil mill or manufactory.
6809: yaśas (CII 1), glory in this life; cf. yaśo vā kīrtir = vā. See kīrti.
6810: yaṣṭi (EI 33; CII 4; ML), a memorial pillar; a relic pillar raised in memory of the dead. Cf. jaṣṭi (EI 19), a land measure. Cf. laṣṭi (EI 16), a memorial pillar. Cf. śilā-yaṣṭi (LL), a stone pillar.
6811: Yāṣṭika (HD), staff bearer; an attendant on the king. See Rājataraṅgiṇī, VI 203; Pāṇini, IV. 4. 59. See Vetrika, Piśuna-vetrika.
6812: Yaṣṭi-prātiṣṭhānaka (ML), the erection of a pillar; same as Sanskrit yaṣṭi-pratiṣṭhāpana.
6813: yathākāla-bhāvin (IE 8-3), same as vartamāna-bhaviṣyat, yathāsambadhyamānaka; also written as yathā-kāl-ādhyāsin (q. v.).
6814: yathākāl-ādhyāsin (EI 4, 23), ‘one who may be employed [in the area including the gift land] from time to time’; one who may be associated with the area about the gift land in differ-ent periods of time; same as yathākāla-bhāvin, vartamāna-bhaviṣyat, yathā-sambadhyamānaka.
6815: yathā-sambadhyamānaka (IA 9), same as yathākāla-bhāvin, vartamāna-bhaviṣyat, yathākāl-ādhyāsin.
6816: yaṭhi (CII 4), Prakrit; same as Sanskrit yaṣṭi (q. v.); a memorial pillar.
6818: yātrā (EI 11; CII 4), festival; the festival of a deity; same as yātr-otsava.
6819: yātrā-dāna (EI 27), gift or levy for running a festival. (SITI), propitiatory gift made before starting on an expedition of conquest by the king.
6820: yātr-otsava (IE 8-5; EI 3, 9), same as yātrā (q. v.); the festival of a deity; festival in honour of a deity.
6822: yava, one-fifteenth of a māṣa (JNSI, Vol. XVI, p. 45); equal to 2 dhānyamāṣas (ibid., p. 48); (1/3) of a rati.
6823: Yāvadeka-pātra (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXVII, p. 122, text lines 4-5), official designation. See Pātra.
6824: Yavana (EI 26; CII 1), originally, an Ionian Greek; then, people of Greek nationality; ultimately, any foreigner.
6825: Yavuga (EI 14), royal title of foreign origin.
6826: yoga (CII 4), meditation; a philosophical system. (EI 18), a council or corporation. (CII 3; IA 17), addition of the longitudes of the sun and moon; an astrological element. Cf. yogaṃ yuñjantām, ‘let them obtain the association [of the gods]’. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 208. Cf. yuj.
6827: yoga-kṣema (IA 7; LP), death; cf. jāta-yoga-kṣema, dead.
6828: yoga-paṭṭa (EI 14), band used by the ascetics to keep their limbs in a position of rigidity.
6829: yoga-paṭṭaka, cf. joga-vaṭṭigĕ (IA 14), explained as ‘a garment worn during contemplation’; same as yoga-paṭṭa (q. v.).
6830: yoga-pīṭha (IA 10), a holy place where an ascetic obtained perfection (siddhi) by his austerities; also called siddha-pīṭha.
6832: yojana (CII 1, 4), name of a measure of distance; a dis-tance of about nine miles.
6833: yoni-paṭṭa, same as gaurī-paṭṭa; see pīṭha.
6834: yuddhita, ‘onewho died fighting’ (Ep. Ind., XXXI, p. 324).
6837: yuga, yugā (EI 1), meaning doubtful; cf. yugā in the sense of ‘a voucher’.
6839: yug-ādi (CII 4; IA 18), name applied to certain tithis; day of the commencement of a yuga; e. g. Vaiśākha-sudi 3, regarded as the commencement of the Kṛta-yuga.
6841: Yugādi-parvan (EI 14), name of an auspicious time; same as yugādi-tithi.
6846: yuj (CII 1), cf. vṛddhir=yujyatām, ‘should devote them-selves for an increase’; śāśvataṃ samayam=[etad]=yuñjyuḥ, ‘they may strive for this at all times’. Cf. yoga.
6847: Yukta (EI 8-3; HD), an officer in general; also an offi-cial designation (CII, Vol. 1, p. 4); the word used in Rock Edict III of Aśoka is explained by some scholars as the designa-tion of a class of officers, although there also the word may be understood in the sense of ‘an officer’; but it is an official desig-nation in passages like yukta-niyukta-vāsāvak-ādhikārika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXI, p. 144) where it may be the same as Āyuktaka. Cf. Yuktaka, Āyukta, etc.
6848: Yuktaka (IE 8-3; HD), same as Yukta, Āyukta or Āyuktaka. See Ep. Ind., Vol. VII, pp. 26, 39-40.
6849: yūpa (EI 2, 24, 33), sacrificial pillar; it was sometimes made of stone and inscribed.
6850: yūthī, also spelt yūtī (IA 17), generally written as yūti or pūti; cf. tṛṇa-yūti (or pūti) -gocara-paryanta, ‘as far as grass land and pasture land’.
6851: yūti, cf. sva-sīmā-tṛṇa-yūti-gocara-paryanta (IE 8-5); also written as pūti; a word of uncertain import; probably, ‘[land] reserved [for growing grass, etc.]’ Cf. go-yūti, tṛṇa-yūti, kāṣṭha -yūti.
6852: Yuvamahārāja (IE 8-2; EI 3, 20, 24), modification of Yuvarāja; designation of the heir-apparent or crown-prince; same as Mahāyuvarāja.
6853: Yuvarāja (IE 8-2, CII 3, 4; HD; ASLV), designation of the heir-apparent or crown-prince. See Arthaśāstra, I. 12 (men-tioned among the 18 tīrthas); cf. CII, Vol. II, Part i, p. 40. Cf. Tamil Tuvarāśaṉ (EI 4), also Duvarāja. Cf. Mahāyuvarāja (EI 32), same as Yuvamahārāja (q. v.).
6854: a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya (EI 26, 27; CII 3), same as a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-prāveśya, Chātra (literally, ‘the umbrella-bearer’) being used for Cāṭa probably meaning ‘the leader of a group of Bhaṭas (i. e. Pāiks or Piādas)’; same as a-prāveśya, etc.
6855: a-bhaṭa-prāveśya, same as a-prāveśya, etc. Cf. Prakrit a-bhaḍa-papesa (Select Inscriptions, p. 435).
6856: a-bhṛta-praveśya (EI 24), same as a-bhaṭa-prāveśya; cf. a-prāveśya, etc.
6857: abhyantara-siddhi (EI 22), same as abhyantara-siddhyā, abhyan-tara-siddhika; refers to internal revenue income or taxes to be paid to local authorities; cf. sa-bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya.
6860: abhyantara-siddhyā, ‘together with the internal income or taxes to be paid to the local authorities’; cf. abhyantara-siddhika and sa-bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 398.
6861: ā-candr-āditya-kālīya (IE), ‘to be enjoyed as long as the moon and sun endure’ (i. e. permanently); epithet of the gift land.
6862: ā-candr-ārka-kṣiti-sama-kālam, ‘as long as the moon, the sun and the earth exist’ (i. e. permanently).
6864: ā-candr-ārk-ārṇava-kṣiti-sthiti-sama-kālīna (EI), ‘to last as long as the moon, the sun, the seas and the earth endure’ (i. e. permanently); cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 134.
6865: ā-candr-ārk-ārṇava-kṣiti-sarit-parvata-sama-kālīna, ‘to be en-joyed as long as the moon, the sun, the seas, the earth, the rivers and hills exist (i. e. permanently)’; cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIII, p. 134.
6866: ā-candra-tārakam, ‘as long as the moon and stars endure’ (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 149, text line 12), i. e. permanently.
6867: a-cār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra (IE; EI 27), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation to supply conveyance, accom-modation, hide (i. e. hide-seats) and charcoal free of charges to the touring officers on their visit. The word cāra meaning ‘passage or conveyance’ is sometimes substituted by pāra meaning ‘ferrying’.
6868: a-cāra-siddhika (EI 26), explained by some as ‘without grazing right for the royal cattle’. Cf. a-vāra-siddhika.
6869: a-carm-āṅgāraka, refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation to supply hide-seats and charcoal to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring royal officers on their visit. Cf. Prakrit a-camm-aṅgālaka (Select Inscriptions, p. 409).
6871: a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa (EI 27, 29; CII 3), refers to the free-dom of the gift village from the entry of the Cāṭas (leaders of groups of Pāiks and Piādas) and the Bhaṭas (Pāiks and Piādas); cf. a-bhaṭa-praveśa, a-bhaṭa-chātra-prāveśya, a-bhṛta-praveśa, etc.
6872: a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-prāveśya (CII 3, 4), same as a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-pra-veśa; refers to the freedom of the gift land from being entered by the Bhaṭas (the king's Pāiks and Piādas) and the Cāḷa (the leader of a group of Pāiks and Piādas); cf. Chātra in place of Cāṭa in a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya; also Bhṛta for Bhaṭa in a-bhṛta-praveśya.
6874: a-cullaka-kūra-khaṭvā-grahaṇa, similar to a-kūra-chullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 5.
6875: a-dugdha-dadhi-grahaṇa, refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation of supplying milk and curs to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officials on their visit. Cf. Prakrit a-dudha-dadhi-gahaṇa (Select Inscriptions, p. 439).
6876: a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa, refers to the freedom of the gift land from the supply of myrobalan, vegetables and flowers to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers on their visit. Cf. Prakrit a-haritaka-sāka-pupha-gahaṇa (Select Inscriptions, p. 439).
6877: a-harīta-parṇa-śāka-puṣpa-phala-dugdha-dadhi-ghṛta-takra-grahaṇa, similar to a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa and a-dugdha-dadhi-grahaṇa, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXI, p. 5.
6878: a-hasta-prakṣepaṇīya (EI 11, 23), same as a a-bhaṭa-praveśa, etc. Cf. samasta-rājakīyānām=a-hasta-prakṣepaṇīya.
6879: a-hiraṇya-dhānya-praṇaya-pradeya (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the gift land from the payment of revenue in cash, the king's grain share and the benevolence or emergency imposts. Cf. Prakrit a-hiraṇṇa-dhaṇṇa-ppaṇaya-ppadeya (Select-Inscriptions, pp. 408-09).
6880: a-karada (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the donee of the gift land from paying taxes in general.
6882: a-kara-vāt-ottara (IE; EI 32), sometimes with āvāta, vāt-ādeya, bhūt-opātta-pratyāya, etc., in place of vāt-ottara; cf. sa-bhūta-vāta-(or pāta) -pratyāya, etc; ‘free from the collections resulting from storms (e. g. uprooted trees, fruits, etc.).’
6883: a-kara-viṣṭi-koñjalla (IE), refers to the freedom of the donee of the gift land from the payment of taxes and the obligation to supply free labour and koñjalla (kāñji) to the king's labourers. Cf. Select Inscriptions, p. 439.
6884: a-khaṭvā-cullaka-vaināśika, cf. Prakrit a-khaṭṭa-collaka-veṇe-sika (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation to supply cots, food and attendant or fuel to the touring royal officers on their visit or to the king or landlord on occasions. Cf. a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa, etc.
6885: a-kiñcit-kara, ‘not to pay even a small amount as rent or tax’; epithet of gift land; same as a-kiñcit-pragrāhya. It has to be noted that sometimes a small amount of tax was fixed for the gift lands. Cf. kara-śāsana.
6887: a-kiñcit-pragrāhya (EI 29), refers to the freedom of the gift land from the payment of taxes and the obligation of supplying articles to the king or landlord on occasions and to the touring officers on their visit; same as a-kiñcit-kara, etc.
6888: a-kiñcit-pratikara (EI 23), ‘[land] free from any yield of revenue’; cf. utpratikara. But pratikara also means ‘compensation’.
6889: a-kūra-cullaka-vaināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa (or °saṃvāsa), cf. a-kūra-yollaka-venesi-khaṭṭ-āvāsa (EI 26); refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation of supplying boiled or unboiled rice, pots or fire-places for cooking, attendant or fuel, cot and shelter to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers on their visit; same as a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭvā-saṃvāsa, etc. See sāmant-āmātya-dūtānām=anyeṣām c=ābhyupāgame śayanīy-āsana-siddh-ānnaṃ na dāpayet (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 171).
6890: a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha (EI 26), same as a-lavaṇa-khātaka, guḍa or sugar being added to lavaṇa or salt; cf. a-lavaṇa-klinna-khātaka.
6891: a-lavaṇa-khātaka, cf. Prakrit a-loṇa-khādaka (EI 7), refers to the freedom of the gift land from being dug out or its trees being pierced for salt.
6893: a-lavaṇa-klinna-khātaka, same as a-lavaṇa-khātaka, klinna, sometimes wrongly spelt kliṇva, probably, ‘toddy, sugar, etc.’ being added to lavaṇa or salt. Cf. a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha, a-lavaṇa-klinna-kreṇi-khanaka, etc. Cf. Select Inscriptions, p. 408.
6896: a-lekhanī-praveśatayā (EI 29), probably refers to the absence of the right to re-grant the gift land to any other party on the part of the king and to alienate the gift land on the part of the donee; lekhanī-praveśa may mean that the gift land should not be made the subject of another document.
6897: anācchedya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 267, note), ‘unresum-able’; but since anāhāra, ‘unresumable’, is sometimes used in the same context, probably, ‘uncurtailable’; epithet of gift land.
6900: anaṅguli-prakṣepaṇīya (EI 23), also called anaṅguli-prekṣaṇīya same as a-bhaṭa-praveśa, etc.
6901: anaṅguli-prekṣaṇīya (EI 23), same as anaṅguli-prakṣepaṇīya, a-bhaṭa-praveśa, etc.
6902: anāsedhya (Ep. Ind., Vol. II, p. 267, note 4), refers to the freedom of the people associated with the gift land from legal restraints.
6903: anavamarśya, refers to the freedom of the gift land from troubles associated with the visit of royal agents. Cf. Prakrit anomasa (Select Inscriptions, pp. 192, 194).
6904: a-pārampara, same as a-paramparā-balīvarda or a-paraṃ-parā-balīvarda-grahaṇa, a privilege of the donee of rent-free land (Ep. Ind., Vol. XV, p. 42).
6905: a-paramparā-balīvarda (SITI), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the supply of bullocks primarily for the con-veyance of royal officers on tour.
6907: a-paramparā-go-balīvarda (EI 22, 26, 27), same as a-pāram-para, etc., in which go (cow) has been added to balīvarda (bullock).
6908: a-paripanthya, ‘without opposition’; cf. Ind. Ep., p. 394.
6909: a-paśu-medhya (Select Inscriptions, p. 414), refers to the freedom from the supply of animals for sacrifice.
6910: a-prāveśya, refers to the freedom of the gift land from the entry of royal agents; same as a-bhaṭa-praveśa, etc. Cf. Prakrit a-pāvesa (Select Inscriptions, pp. 192, 194).
6912: a-puṣpa-kṣīra-grahaṇīya, refers to the freedom of the gift land from the supply, of flowers and milk to the king or land-lord on occasions or to the touring officers on their visit; same as a-puṣpa-kṣīra-sandoha, etc. Cf. Prakrit a-puppha-kkhīra-gahaṇi (Select Inscriptions, p. 409).
6914: aputra-dhanaṃ nāsti, ‘there is no confiscation, by the king, of the property of persons dying without a son’; cf. aputrā-sahita, etc. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 237.
6915: aputrā-sahita (IE), ‘together with the right to confiscate the property of persons dying without leaving any son’; epithet of gift village. Cf. aputra-dhanaṃ nāsti.
6916: a-rāṣṭra-sāṃvinayika (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the gift land from the administrative control to which the district in which it was situated was subject. Cf. Prakrit a-raṭha-saṃ-vinayika (Select Inscriptions, pp. 92, 94). See bhoga-sambandha-nirvacanīya, grāma-nilaya-nāḍa-sarva-bādhā-parithāreṇa, etc.
6917: asan-nara-pravṛtti-vinivṛtt-ācāra (Ind., Ant., Vol. XI p. 113, text lines 36-37), translated as ‘the established customs [of the gift land] are withheld from [injury by] the enterprise of wicked men.’
6918: aṣṭa-bhāgika, ‘paying one-eighth of the produce [in place of the usual one-sixth]’. Cf. Prakrit aṭha-bhāgiya (Select Ins-criptions, p. 70).
6919: aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya-daṇḍaśulka-yukta (Ind. Ant., Vol XIX, p. 247, text line 102), mentioned along with nidhi-nikṣepa pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣprakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita. See aṣṭa-bhoga, tejaḥ-svāmya, etc.
6920: aṣṭādaśa-jāti-parihāra, the eighteen (i. e. all or various) kinds of exemptions [usually enjoyed by rent-free holdings]. Cf. Prakrit aṭṭhārasa-jāti-parihāra (Select Inscriptions., pp. 439-40).
6921: a-tṛṇa-kāṣṭha-grahaṇa (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the donee of the gift village from the supply of grass and fuel to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers on their visit.
6922: a-vaha (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation of carrying loads of the touring officers, etc., or of supplying a horse to them free of charges.
6923: a-vāra-siddhika (IE), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation to supply unpaid labour in turn. Cf. a-cāra-siddhika.
6924: bhāga-bhoga-paśu-hiraṇya-kara-śulka (EI 20), ‘together with [the right to] the share of the produce, periodical offerings, cattle or animals [for sacrificial purposes], tax in cash, tax in kind and tolls’.
6925: bhāviṣyat-kara-rahita (EI 24), ‘without all the taxes to be levied in future.’
6926: bhogasambandha-nirvacanīya (EI 12), ‘the relations [of the gift land] with the administrative unit (i. e. bhoga, to which it belonged) should not be reckoned [since the land is granted after separating it from the district] (bhogād=uddhṛtya)’. Cf. a-rāṣṭra-sāṃvinayika, grāma-nilaya-nā ḍa-sarva-bādhā-parihāreṇa.
6927: bhūmi-cchidra-nāyena or °cchidra-pidhāna-vyāyena, ‘in accor-dance with the principle of cultivating the land for the first time and enjoying it free of taxes as a result’. The word chidra in the first means ‘cultivation’ and chidra-pidhāna in the second ‘reclamation of uncultivable land for the first time.’ Some-times vidhāna is wrongly used for pidhāna. See Ind. Ep., pp. 397-98.
6928: bhūta-bhaviṣyad-vartamāna-niḥśeṣ-ādātya-sahita, ‘together with the arrears of taxes and with the present and future taxes in their entirety’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
6929: candr-ārka-kālikaṃ śulkam=ādeyaṃ samasta-rājye n=āsti, ‘there is no collection of tolls in the whole kingdom as long as the moon and the sun exist’. Cf. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXV, p. 237.
6930: candr-ārka-sthiti-kālaṃ yāvat, ‘as long as the moon and sun endure (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135, text lines 21-22); some-times candr-ārka-ksiti°, candr-ārk-ārṇāva-kṣīti-sarit-parvata°, etc.
6931: caluḥ-sīm-āvacchinna, same as sva-sīm-āvachinna, catur-aghāṭa-viśuddha, etc. Cf. Majumdar, Ins. Beng., Vol. III, p. 125.
6932: catuḥ-sīmā yāvat, same as catuḥ-sīmā-paryanta, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6933: catur-āghāṭa-viśuddha, ‘with the boundaries well demarca-ted’; same as catuḥ-sīm-āvacchina, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 396.
6934: catur-āghāṭ-āntarvarti-jala-pāṣāṇa-nidhi-nikṣepa-śulk-ādi-sarva-tejaḥsvāmya-sahita  (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXIV, p. 40, text lines 37-38). See tejaḥ-svāmya, etc.
6935: catuṣ-kaṇṭaka-viśuddha (EI 23), cf. catur-āghāṭa-viśuddha; probably refers to the custom of demarcating a plot of land by planting thorny shrubs on the borders.
6936: caura-varjam, also quoted as cora-varjam, cora-daṇḍa-varjam, cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam, etc.; according to some ‘with immu-nity from the police tax’, while others take it to be related to a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa and think that the policemen were prohi-bited from entering a gift village except in connection with the apprehension of criminals; may also mean ‘without any right to inflict punishment of thieves, etc., or to levy fines from thieves, etc.’ See CII, Vol. III, p. 109.
6938: cora-varja (IE), ‘without the right to punish the thieves and to realise stolen articles’; cf. sa-caur-oddharaṇa. But see also cauravarjam.
6939: deśa-maryād-āruvaṇ-ānvila (Ind. Ant. Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 103), refers to the right to levy the tax called āruvaṇa (Sanskrit ṣaṭ-paṇa) according to the local custom.
6940: deva-Brāhmaṇa-bhukti-varja (EI 23, 30), ‘excluding the property of the gods (i. e. temples) and Brāhmaṇas’.
6941: devakula-puṣkariṇy-ādhikaṃ kārayitvā, refers to the right of the donee to build temples and excavate tanks in the gift land without the permission of the king or landlord as was necessary in the case of ordinary tenants. Cf. Majumdar, Ins. Beng., Vol. III, p. 125.
6942: go-gauḍa-sameta, ‘together with the cattle and herdsmen [of state farms] or with the grazing tax’; epithet of gift village. Go-gauḍa may be the same as go-kara. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6943: grāma-nilaya-nāḍa-sarva-bādhā-parihāreṇa (EI 9), ‘with the exemption of all troubles connected with [the administration of] the village, subdivision (literally, habitation) and district [in which the gift land is situated]’. Cf. a-rāṣṭra-sāṃvinayika, etc.
6944: gṛh-āvataraṇa-harita-pakva-sasy-ekṣu-cāraṇa-lavan-opamardana-rocikā-ciṭolā-grahaṇa-pīṭhaka-pīṭhikā-khaṭv-āpaharaṇa-kāṣṭh-endhana-ghāsa-bus-ādikaṃ na kenacit = [kartavyaṃ] pragrāhyaṃ [ca], ‘no one should enter into the donce's house, should graze one's cattle on the green crops in his fields, should harvest the ripe crops in his fields, should crush his sugar-cane, should accept rocikā and ciṭolā from him, should take stools, seats and cots from him and should take wood, fuel, grass, chaff, etc., from him’. For gṛh-āvataraṇa, see umbara-bheda. Words like rocikā, ciṭolā, etc., are not intelligible, although they certainly refer to certain obligations or levies. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 394.
6945: guvāka-nārikel-ādikaṃ laggāvayitvā, refers to the right of planting arecanut and coconut palms in the gift land without the permission of the king or landlord as was necessary in the case of ordinary tenants; cf. sa-guvāka-nārikela. Cf. Majum-dar, Ins. Beng., Vol. III, p. 125.
6946: hastidaṇḍa-varabalīvarda-coṭāla-andhā(rthā?)ruvā-pratyandhā-(rthā?)ruvā-adattā-padātijīva-ahidaṇḍa-ānta(tu?)rāvaḍḍi-bandha-daṇḍa-vijayavandāpanā-mārgaṇika-prabhṛti-bhaviṣyat-kara-sahita, refers to the donee's right to enjoy various taxes the nature of some of which is doubtful. These include the tax for keeping elephants and prize bullocks, tax for the maintenance of the king's Padātis (footmen or Pāiks), tax on the professional snake-charmers, ransom in lieu of imprisonment, presents to be made to the king on his return from a victorious campaign and tax to be paid for using the road in the gift village for the transit of articles of merchandise. See the expressions separately as noticed above. See also suvarṇa-daṇḍa-ahidaṇḍa … below. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 401.
6947: jana-dhana-sahita (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135), ‘to-gether with the tenants and revenue income [of the village]’; some as sa-jana-dhana.
6948: kuśa-latā-pūta-hast-odakena, cf. udaka-pūrvam, etc. See Ind. Ep., p. 395
6949: mahādoṣa-vivarjita (EI 23), ‘excluding fines for great crimes’; cf. doṣa and daṇḍa-doṣa (fines) noticed above.
6950: mukt-oparikara (EI 29), free from minor taxes or without freedom from them. Cf. s-oparikara.
6951: nānā-vṛkṣa-sameta, ‘together with the various trees’; epithet of gift village. Some of the trees not to be enjoyed by unpri-vileged tenants were mango, madhūka, jack, coconut, arecanut, palmyra palm, sīsu, tamarind tree, etc. But the group was different in different parts of the country. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6952: nava-nidhāna-sahita (IA 11), probably, ‘with the taxes fixed afresh’, though nidhāna is often the same as nikṣepa (q. v.).
6953: nidhi-nikṣepa-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣprakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita  (Ind. Int., Vol. XIX, p. 247), mentioned along with aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmy-daṇḍaśulka-yukta. See the expressions as sepa-rately noticed above.
6954: nidhi-nikṣep-āputrakadhana-daṇḍ-opajātaka-sahita, ‘together with the right to enjoy treasure-trove and the occasional finds and accumulations on the land and to confiscate the property of persons dying without leaving any son, and to enjoy the right to appropriate the income derived from fines’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., 406.
6956: nidhy-upanidhi-hastidanta-vyāghracarma-nānāvanacara-sameta, refers to the right of the donee to treasure-troves, occasional finds or accumulations on the ground, elephants’ tusks, tiger's skin and certain prized animals without surrendering them to the king as ordinary tenants had to do; epithet of the gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6958: parihṛta-paṅg-otkoṭa (EI 33), ‘exempted from the levies called paṅga and utkoṭa’. See the words as separately noticed.
6959: parihṛta-sarva-pīḍa (EI 27, 29), ‘free from all troubles’; same as sarva-pīḍā-varjita, sarva-bādhā-vivarjita, etc.
6960: phalaratika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135), refers pro-bably to the right to enjoy all kinds of fruits in the gift land with-out special permission that was necessary for ordinary tenants.
6961: prasiddha-catuḥ-sīm-āvacchinna, ‘demarcated by the well-known boundaries on all the sides’; epithet of the gift land. Cf. catur-āghāṭa-viśuddha, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6963: pratiṣiddha-cāṭ-ādi-praveśa (I. E., p. 395), same as a-praveśa, etc.
6964: pūrva-bhujyamāna-deva-brāhmaṇa-kṣetra-khaṇḍalakaṃ varjayitvā (or vihāya), see Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135; same as deva-brāhmaṇa-bhukti-varja, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 398.
6966: pūrva-pratta-deva-brahma-deya-rahita, sometimes with dāya in place of deya; refers to the absence of the donee's right to have any control over that land in the gift village which was already a rent-free holding in the possession of gods or Brāhmaṇas; same as deva-brahmaṇa-bhukti-varja, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 398.
6967: putra-pautrādi-santati-krameṇa, same as putra-pautr-ānvaya-kram-opabhogya, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 399.
6968: putra-pautr-ādy-anvay-opabhogā, °ānugaminī, etc.; same as putra-pautr-ānugamaka. Cf. Ind. Ep., pp. 394-95.
6969: putra-pautr-ānugamaka, ‘the donce's right of enjoying the gift land should pass on to his sons and grandsons’; epithet of gift land; same as putra-pautr-ānvaya-kram-opabhogya, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 392.
6970: putra-pautr-ānvaya-kram-opabhogya, refers to the permanent nature of a gift of land to be enjoyed by the donee as well as his descendants; same as putra-putr-ānugamaka (I.E., p. 398).
6971: rāja-bhāvya-sarva-pratyāya-sameta (EI 23), bhāvya being often changed to ābhāvya; same as a-kiñcit-pragrāhya, etc.
6973: rāja-rājapuruṣair=apy=anaṅguli-nirdeśyam, same as srava-rāja-kīyānām=a-hasta-prakṣepaṇīyaḥ, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 400.
6974: rājasevakānāṃ vasatidaṇḍa-prayāṇadaṇḍau na staḥ, refers to the freedom of the gift village from the obligation to provide accommodation and conveyance, etc., to the royal officers on tour; cf. a-kūra-chullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa, a-paraṃparā-balīvarda, etc. See CII, Vol. III, p. 98, note 2.
6975: rājñā rājapuruṣair=apy=anaṅguli-prakṣepaṇīya (Ind., Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 247, text lines 103-04), same as sarva-rājakīyānām= a-hasta-prakṣepaṇīyaḥ, etc.
6976: ramya (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135), refers to the fact that the gift land had nothing unpleasant about it.
6977: ṛṇ-ādāy-ādi-sambandha-varjita (EI 23), refers to the free-dom of the gift land from confiscation for the realisation of debts incurred by the donee.
6978: sa-bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya, ‘together with the external and internal income or taxes to be paid to the state and to the village authorities’; epithet of the gift village; cf. abhyantara-siddhyā, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
6980: sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya (CII 3), refers to the income from the gift land as a result of some action of nature's agencies. Sometimes vāta and āvāta are found for pāta probably in the sense of ‘a storm’ (cf. udvāta) and also upātta, ‘realised’.
6981: sa-bhūta-vāta-pratyāya (EI 23), with pāta sometimes in place of vāta; ‘together with the income arising out of a change of the natural phenomena (such as due to earthquakes, storms, etc.)’; epithet of gift land.
6982: sa-bhūt-opātta-pratyāya (EI 23), same as sa-bhūta-vāta-pra-tyāya, etc. The word upātta means ‘realised’.
6983: sa-caur-oddharaṇa (EI 12, 23, 29), ‘together with the right to punish thieves and recover stolen property or fines’; epithet of gift villages. Cf. caura-varja, etc.
6984: sa-daṇḍa-doṣa (EI 23), ‘together with [the right to] levy fines for crimes’; the meaning of doṣa is really doubtful in the context.
6985: sa-daṇḍa-nigraha (EI 24), refers to the king's power to punish [culprits] by fines or corporal punishment.
6986: sa-daś-āpacāra, same as sa-daś-āparādha; cf. Ind. Ep., p. 397.
6987: sa-daś-āparādha (EI 27), also quoted as sa-daś-āpacāra; ‘together with the right to punish and realise fines for the ten offences (murder, theft, etc.)’; epithet of gift village; cf. sahya-daś-āparādha probably meaning that the crimes committed in the gift village should not be punished by the king.
6989: sa-dhānya-hiraṇy-ādeya (EI 11, 12, 23; IA 9), ‘together with the king's grain share and taxes in cash’.
6990: s-ādha-ūrdhva, ‘together with what is [produced or found] below and above the ground’; epithet of gift land. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
6991: s-āgama-nirama-praveśa, ‘together with approaches, ingress and egress’; epithet of gift land. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 394.
6992: sa-gart-āvaskara (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135), mentioned along with s-oṣara. The word avaskara (also avakara) probably means ‘a mound’.
6993: sa-gart-oṣara (EI 27, 29), ‘together with pits and saline spots or barren lands’; epithet of gift village.
6994: sa-giri-gahana-nidhāna (EI 24), ‘together with hills, forests and deposits’. See also nidhāna noticed above.
6995: sa-gokula, ‘together with the cowpens’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
6998: sa-gulma-latāka, ‘together with shrubs and creepers’; epithet of the gift land. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
6999: sa-guvāka-nārikera (EI 12), sometimes with nālikela in place of nārikera; ‘together with the arecanut and coconut palms’; epithet of gift land; see guvāka-nārikel-ādikaṃ laggāvayitvā.
7000: sa-haṭṭa-ghaṭṭa-sa-tara (EI 22), ‘together with market-places and ferries (or passes) and with ferry-dues’.
7001: sa-hiraṇya-bhāga-bhoga (EI 23), same as sa-deya-meya, etc. See the words as separately noticed.
7002: sa-hiraṇya-bhāga-bhog-oparikara-sarv-ādāya-sameta (EI 23), ‘together with all levies such as hiraṇya, bhāga, bhoga and upa-rikara’. See the various words as noticed separately.
7003: sa-hiraṇy-ādāna (EI 26), ‘together with levies in cash’; privilege of the donee of rent-free and.
7005: sa-jala-sthala (EI 12, 27, 29), ‘together with land and waters [of the gift village]’.
7006: sa-jala-sthal-āraṇya (EI 23), ‘together with the land, waters and jungles [of the gift village]’.
7008: sa-jana-dhana (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 139), same as jana-dhana-sahita. Cf. sa-jana (ibid., Vol. V, p. 185).
7009: sa-jāṅgal-ānūpa (EI 12), ‘together with arid and marshy lands’.
7010: sa-jhāṭa-viṭapa, ‘together with bushes and shrubs (or branches)’.
7011: sa-kar-otkara = Prakrit sa-kar-ukara (EI 7); refers to a piece of land granted with the donee's right to enjoy major and minor taxes; cf. s-odraṅga-s-oparikara and sa-kḷpt-opakḷpta, etc. See kar-otkara as noticed separately above; also cf. kāru-kara.
7012: sa-khalla-unnata=sa-khall-onnata (EI 12), ‘together with low and high lands’; epithet of gift land. Khalla is Oḏiyā khāl ‘low land’. Cf. sa-nimn-onnata.
7013: sa-khaṇḍapālīya, ‘together with the tax for the maintenance of the swordsmen’; epithet of gift village; cf. padāti-jivya, tax for the maintenance of Pāiks or footmen. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
7014: sa-khaṭa-viṭapa (EI 12), mistake for sa-jhāṭa-vitapa or sa-kheṭa-viṭapa.
7015: sa-kheṭa-ghaṭṭa-nadītara-sthān-ādi-gulmaka (EI 29), ‘to-gether with the military, police or customs outposts in the ham-lets, landing places on the banks of rivers (or passes in the hilly tracts) and ferrying stations’; epithet of gift village.
7016: sa-kheṭa-viṭapa, ‘together with outposts and bushes’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 402.
7017: sa-khila-nāla, ‘together with the fallow and cultivated lands’; epithet of gift village; same as sa-khila-polācya. See Majumdar, Ins. Beng., Vol. III, p. 125.
7018: sa-khila-polācya, ‘together with fallow and cultivated land’; same as sa-khila-nāla. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 394.
7019: sa-khil-opakhila, ‘together with land which is fallow and partially fallow’. Pakhila in the same context is a mistake for upakhila.
7020: sa-kḷpta (EI 24), ‘together with the tax on permanent tenants or the fixed revenue’; same as s-odraṅga.
7021: sa-kḷpt-opakḷptaka (EI 24, 27), refers to the freedom of the gift land from the payment of fixed taxes on permanent tenants as well as occasional taxes or taxes on temporary tenants; same as s-odraṅga-s-oparikara.
7022: sa-kṛta-prānta, cf. Prakrit sa-kutu-ppanta (EI 26), ‘together with the demarcated boundaries’; epithet of the gift land.
7023: sa-lavaṇa (EI 12), ‘together with salt (i. e. the right to enjoy salt produced in the land). Cf. a-lavaṇa-khātaka, etc.
7024: sa-lavaṇ-ākara (EI 12), ‘together with the salt pits’. Cf. a-lavaṇa-khātaka, etc.
7025: sa-loh-ādy-ākara, together with the mines of metals, etc.’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
7026: sa-loha-lavaṇ-ākara (EI 23, 26), ‘together with the mines and salt-pits’, epithet of gift land. Cf. sa-loh-ādy-ākara, a-lavaṇa-khātaka, etc.
7027: sa-madhūka-cūta-vana-vāṭikā-viṭapa-tṛna-yūti-gocara-paryanta, ‘together with the madhūka and mango trees, forests, gardens, bushes (or, branches), grass yūti (grass land) and including the pasture land’; cf. Ind. Ep., p. 396. It is better to take sa-madhūka-cūṭa-vana-vāṭikā-viṭapa and tṛnayūti-gocara-paryanta separately.
7028: sa-madhūk-āmra-vana-vāṭikā-viṭapa-tṛṇa-yūti-gocara-paryanta (EI 24), ‘together with the madhuka and mango trees, forests, gardens, shrubs and as far as and the grass yuli (grass land) and pasture lands’. See sa-madhūka-cūta … , above.
7029: sa-mandira-prākāra, ‘together with temples and walls’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395. trees and areas covered by jungles (or areas covered with mango and madhūka plantations)’; see Ind. Ep., p. 402.
7030: sa-mañca-mahākaraṇa (EI 26), ‘together with mañca (pro-bably, platforms for the collection of tolls) and mahākaraṇa (official documents)’; epithet of the gift land.
7031: sāmant-āmātya-dūtānām = anyeṣām = c = ābhyupāgame śayanīy-āsana-siddhānnaṃ na dāpayet, refers to the obligation of the people to supply beds, seats and boiled or unboiled rice to feudatory rulers, ministers, messengers and others encamped in a village; see a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa, etc. See Ep. Ind., Vol. XXX, p. 171.
7032: samasta-bhāga-bhoga-kara-hiraṇy-ādi-pratyāya-sameta, ‘together with all incomes including the king's grain share, the periodical offerings to be made to the king or landlord and to the touring officers, taxes in grains, taxes in cash, etc.’; epithet of gift land; same as sa-hiraṇya-bhāga-bhoga, etc. See Ind. Ep., p. 397.
7034: samasta-rājakīyānām = apraveśya, same as a-bhaṭa-praveśa, a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśya, a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya, etc. (Ind. Ep., p. 398).
7035: samasta-rājakīyānam = ahasta-prakṣepaṇīya (CII 3), same as ā-bhaṭa-praveśa, etc.
7036: samasta-rājapratyādāya-sameta (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 129), same as sa-hiraṇya-bhāga-bhoga, etc.
7037: samast-otpatti-sahita (EI 12), ‘together with all the pro-duce or income’.
7038: samast-otpatti-śulk-otpatti-sahita (EI 23), ‘together with all the produce of the land and the income arising from tolls’.
7039: sa-matsya-kacchapa (EI 12), ‘together with the right to catch fish and tortoises’; epithet of gift village.
7040: sa-matsy-ākara (EI 24), 26), ‘together with the sources of fish (e. g., rivers, tanks, etc)’; epithet of gift village.
7041: samhalālamaka-samanvita (EI 9), the reading is apparently wrong; meaning uncertain.
7042: sa-mīna-toya (EI 24), ‘together with fish and the waters’ or ‘together with the waters containing fish.’
7043: s-āmra-madhūka (IE; EI 12, 27, 29), ‘together with the mango and madhūka trees’.
7046: s-āmra-panasa (EI 12), ‘together with mango and jack trees’.
7048: samudayabāhy-ādyastamba (EI 23), ‘[land] covered with original shrubs (i.e. never cultivated) and not yielding any revenue [to the State].’
7050: nidhān-ālīpaka-kumārīsāhas-āputrādhana-pradhān-āpradhāna-doṣa-samanvita (Ep. Ind., Vol. III, p. 274), see the words as noticed separately above. The word doṣa here means ‘fines’.
7051: sa-nidhi (EI 27), refers to the freedom of the donee of the gift land from the obligation of surrendering to the king under-ground treasures in the land on their discovery.
7052: sa-nidhi-nidhāna (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 139), same as sa-nidhi-nikṣepa, etc.
7053: sa-nidhi-nikṣepa, see nidhi, nikṣepa, nidhāna, ālipaka, etc., as noticed separately. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 396.
7057: s-ānūpa-jāṅgala (Ind. Ant., Vol. XVIII, p. 34, text line 5), same as sa-jāṅgal-ānūpa.
7059: sa-padr-āraṇyaka (EI 12), ‘together with habitations and jungles’; epithet of gift land.
7060: sa-pallika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 135), ‘together with its hamlets’.
7061: sa-parikara (EI 23), same as or a mistake for s-oparikara.
7062: sa-parṇ-ākara (EI 26), ‘together with the fields growing betel leaves’; epithet of gift village.
7063: sa-pratīhāra, ‘together with the tax for the maintenance of the watchmen of the city gates’; cf. Ind. Ep., p. 401.
7066: sarv-ābhyantara-siddhi (EI 20; IA 19), ‘together with the entire internal revenue income or all the taxes to be paid to local authorities’.
7068: sarv-ādāna-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna (CII 4), ‘free from all levies, ditya, forced labour and prātibhedikā’. See ditya and prātibhedikā as noticed above.
7069: sarv-ādāna-saṅgrāhya (6II 4), ‘with the right to levy all the dues’; same as sarv-ādāya-sameta.
7070: sarv-ādāna-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna (CII 4), ‘free from the payment of all imposts and the obligation regarding unpaid labour and prātibhedikā’; epithet of gift village. See prāti-bhedikā as noticed above.
7072: sarv-ādeya-viśuddha (CII 4), ‘with all kinds of taxes fixed’; same as sarv-ādāya-sameta (cf. sarv-āya-viśuddha).
7073: sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-jemaka-kara-bhara-parihīna (CII 4), ‘free from the burden of all the ditya, forced labour, jemaka and taxes’. See ditya and jemaka as noticed above.
7074: sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna (EI 9; CII 4), ‘free from all kinds of ditya, forced labour and prātibhedikā’. See the words as noticed separately.
7075: sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihṛta (Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 298, text lines 201-21), same as sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna. See the words as noticed above.
7076: sarva-jāta-bhoga-nirasta, refers to a grant of land with all kinds of royal rights abrogated. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 390.
7077: sarva-jāta-bhoga (EI 24), ‘together with all kinds of privileges to be enjoyed’.
7078: sarva-jāta-pārihārika, cf. Prakrit sava-jāta-pārihārika (Select Inscriptions, pp. 92, 94), ‘endowed with all kinds of exemptions.’
7081: sarva-paṅga-parihṛta (EI 33), ‘free from all levies falling in the category of paṅga’. See paṅga noticed above.
7082: sarva-parihāra-kārudeya (EI 24), refers to all kinds of exemptions including the dues from artisans.
7083: sarva-piḍā-parihṛta (EI 23), same as sarva-pīḍā-varjita, sarva-pīḍā-vivarjita, etc.
7084: sarva-pīḍā-varjita (EI 23), same as parihṛta-sarva-pīḍa, sarva-bādhā-vivarjita, etc.
7086: sarva-rājakīyānām = a-hasta-prakṣepaṇīyaḥ (CII 3), same as a-bhaṭa-praveśa, a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-prāveśya, a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya, etc.
7087: sarva-vādhā-vivarjita, with vādhā in the place of bādhā; same as parihṛta-sarva-pīḍa, sarva-pīḍā-varjita, etc. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 401.
7088: sarva-viṣṭi-parihāra-parihṛta (EI 23, 24, 26), ‘endowed with the exemptions from all kinds of unpaid labour’; epithet of the gift village.
7089: sarv-āya-sahita (Ind. Ant., Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 203), ‘together with the entire income.’
7092: sarv-oparikar-ādāna-sahita, ‘together with the right to levy all minor taxes or taxes on temporary tenants’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 401.
7093: sarv-oparikara-kar-ādāna-sameta (EI 23), ‘together with all the levies falling in the categories of uparikara and kara’. See kara and uparikara as noticed above.
7094: sarv-otpatti-sahita (EI 23), ‘together with whatever is produced (i. e. crops or income).’
7095: sarv-eṣṭi-parihāra-parihṛta (EI 27), sarv-eṣṭi may be a mistake for sarva-viṣṭi.
7096: sa-saibara (EI 17), also written sa-śaivara; ‘together with unassessed arable lands or the tax on farm-houses’; cf. śaivara and saibara noticed above.
7097: sa-sarva-pallika (Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXV, p. 129), ‘together with all the hamlets’.
7098: sa-sarv-āśan-ekṣu-karpāsa-śaṇ-āmra-madhūk-ādi-bhūruha, ‘to-gether with aśana (pītaśāla), sugarcane, cotton-plants, hemp-plants, mango, madhūka and other trees’; epithet of gift land. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
7099: sa-sāṭa-viṭapa (EI 12), mistake or wrong reading of sa-jhāṭa-viṭapa (q. v.).
7100: s-āṣṭādaśa-prakṛty = opeta (EI 2), ‘together with the eighteen (i. e. all) kinds of tenants (i. e. tenants belonging to all the communities)’.
7101: sa-sthāvara-jaṅgama, ‘together with the immovable and movable belongings [of the gift village]’. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
7102: sa-tala (EI 12, 29), ‘together with the surface of the ground’.
7103: sa-tālaka (EI 12), ‘together with palmyra palms’; epi-thet of gift village.
7105: sa-tantuvāya-gokuṭa-śauṇḍik-ādi-prakṛtika, ‘together with such tenants as the weavers, cowherds or milkmen and vintners’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 393.
7108: sa-tṛṇa-kāṣṭh-odak-opeta (EI 24), ‘together with the grass, fuel and waters [of the gift village]’.
7109: sa-vanaspaty-udak-āsīhāra-kullaka-pānīya-sameta ‘together with the fruit-trees and various kinds of water courses’; epithet of gift land. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 394.
7110: sa-vana-śvabhra-nidhāna, ‘together with forests, pits and mines’; epithet of gift village. Cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
7111: sa-vāta-bhūta-pratyāya (EI 11; IA 9), same as sa-bhūta-vāta-pratyāya, etc.
7113: sa-viṭap-āraṇya, ‘together with bushes and jungles’; epithet of gift village.
7114: sa-vṛkṣamālā-kula (EI 23; IA 11), ‘together with vari-ous gardens or plantations’. See nānā-vṛkṣa-sameta.
7116: sīm-āntargata-vastu-sahita, ‘together with [all] things with-in the boundaries’; cf. Ind. Ep., p. 395.
